HEADLINE: Searching for Incentives To Entice Polluters

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
As Congress last week discussed the renewal of the Clean Air Act, it wrestled with expanded use of an unusual concept in pollution control: letting industries buy and sell the right to emit pollutants, with companies deciding among themselves how to share the work that the Government wants done. Under President Bush's proposal, this flexibility would extend to automobiles. The law would specify the number of ''alternative fuel'' cars but would not say what fuel or precisely which companies would make them or the fuels.
Industry generally favors these trading programs, saying they lead to greater economic efficiency. But environmentalists warn of pitfalls that will make the cleanup program less effective.
Last week Charles J. DiBona, the president of the American Petroleum Institute and an economist, and David G. Hawkins, senior attorney at the Natural Resources Defense Council, who was the Environmental Protection Agency's Assistant Administrator for Air, Noise and Radiation from 1977 to 1981, met to debate the merits of pollution trading. Matthew L. Wald of The New York Times moderated. 
 
 
Mr. DiBona: We now spend on the order of $100 million per year, or about 2 percent of G.N.P, on environmental controls. In the future the cost will undoubtedly rise, perhaps quickly. If the Europeans and Asians should utilize incentive approaches to protect their environments while we do not, our industries will be at a competitive disadvantage. While there is not much experience with incentive systems, they have in some cases provided substantial economies, and many academic studies show large potential economies.
Mr. Hawkins: In some circumstances the environmental community feels comfortable with incentive systems based on trading the right to pollute. An example is the President's proposal on the trading of sulfur dioxide emission allowances for acid rain control. A reduction somewhere in the market is fungible with a reduction elsewhere. It does not involve trading one individual's right to a clean environment against another's right to a clean environment. And the pollutants, particularly sulfur dioxide, can be accurately monitored.
But we are not as confident in the President's bill to allow market alternatives with respect to automotive air pollution, particularly ozone and smog. It violates fundamental principles of environmental protection.
 
Question: In what way?
Mr. Hawkins: The so-called alternate fuels proposal would obligate vehicle makers starting in 1995 to sell 500,000 vehicles a year, going up to 1 million, that can use alternate fuels like methanol. The proposal would allow auto makers to market cleaner vehicles in one metropolitan area and dirtier vehicles in another. It would permit fuel refiners to market cleaner fuels in one metropolitan area, dirtier fuels in another.
This approach is different from acid rain in that these reductions are not fungible. Why should New Yorkers be subjected to dirtier cars because auto makers found it convenient to sell cleaner cars in L.A.?
 
Mr. DiBona: There is a provision in the bill that permits fuel manufacturers and auto manufacturers to trade or share the responsibility of delivering these fixed numbers of autos or volumes of fuel, so I don't think that it runs into the problems you suggest. I agree that it would not make much sense to reduce the quality of air in Chicago to improve it in some other area. What we ought to insure is that the trades are commensurate.
Now, we can debate a trade between areas. You can imagine that part of a given region might meet the ambient air standard and part of it might not. A trade between these two areas that reduced costs, brought the area not in compliance into compliance, raised the level of pollutants in the other, but not enough to put it over the standard, in some instances would be a sensible step.
You'll get the most bang for your buck in environmental reduction if the next increment of pollution reduction comes from the emitter who can do it cheapest. And you will do that until his costs rise to the point where there's someone else who can now start doing it even more cheaply.
 
Q. Why is that better than just ordering pollution reductions?
Mr. DiBona: The problem of the command and control system, in which the government sets pollution levels and everyone must comply, is that you set a set standard for everybody. Some people are going to be able to do better, but they don't have to. In fact, they have every incentive not to let you know they can do it better.
Mr. Hawkins: The system often does lack the incentive to do better. However, our fix is different.
The fix that's typically proposed is that you start with a base line. The government, with all its inability to spot developing pollution control trends, determines the amount of opportunity for further progress. A trading system is set up where people who have successfully withheld from the government information showing that they can do better will be able to turn that into allowances to pollute more elsewhere.
 
Q. In other words, this is a system that rewards those who have hidden their capabilities thus far?
Mr. Hawkins: It certainly does. For example, in the Clean Air Act, there is a term - reasonably available control technology. A lot of proposals want to allow trading of pollution allowances if you do anything beyond what's reasonably available. Politically, how could you be opposed to giving credit for going beyond what's reasonable? Our remedy would be to impose a charge on emissions, to create an incentive for reductions.
On the other hand, if you introduce trading of allowances into a system that is in the process of defining regulatory requirements, you have introduced a new incentive. You introduce an incentive to define the pre-existing regulatory requirements as leniently as possible. Because the more lenient the base line, the more opportunity there is for trade.
 
Q. Are we arguing over what level should be reached, or how to reach it?
Mr. Hawkins: We are not arguing what levels should be reached. And, indeed, in Congress the petroleum industry is not arguing that the ambient air quality standard should be changed for smog. They are arguing about how many years these cities should be allowed to violate these health standards. It's not acceptable to have a 21-year period where these standards can be violated.
Mr. DiBona: We are not arguing about the standards. We have argued that we and the government should spend a little more time getting information about alternative fuels. Companies might implement it faster once they have that information. They do not have the information on methanol because there have not been enough tests.
The advantage of even using a lousy system of trading rights is that you don't have to set them for eternity. Then you watch how the system works. You'll get a lot of information on how to clean up that you would never get otherwise. And then you can re-set the system.
 
Q. We're still left with this issue of how to pick a starting point, of what is reasonably available control technology.
Mr. DiBona: Let's say you use the current system of standards for pollution levels. And it was very bad because some people had succeeded in duping the authorities, and therefore had lots of trading rights. You will quickly learn whether or not they have the capability of going further at low cost because someone else will buy their rights. And you will discover those are the guys who can do it better, and you will learn about the technology they are using.
Mr. Hawkins: If you try to change it at that point, as a regulator you will be accused of disrupting the market and eliminating the incentives.
Mr. DiBona: You have to leave it in place, but not indefinitely. You have to say, this is something we're going to let run for 5 years, or 10 years to foster innovations. Because now I've got something I can sell. Not only can I use it myself to reduce my costs, but I can provide it to others. And I think that there's some evidence that the current system doesn't provide much innovation.
Mr. Hawkins: We're in favor of innovation. But the air pollution control area demonstrates just as many examples of scams, if not more, than of innovation.
I'll give you an example I worked on personally. A steel company persuaded the state of Michigan that reasonable control for dust from its plant was to water the dirt road. That was the regulatory benchmark. Then the company went out and did something truly innovative - it paved the road. That's the innovation for which they claimed all sorts of credit so they could take off controls on a steel-making furnace.
Everything that Charlie says about innovation using the regulatory benchmark approach is far truer about the approach that I am advocating, charging a fee for being permitted to pollute. If we want to try an incentive system, let's use what our economic system is based on: dollars.
Mr. DiBona, couldn't your arguments be used to suggest a system where there was no benchmark, there was just a charge for pollution?
Mr. DiBona: We have been advocates of fees in some areas. But fees can generate an immense revenue and that raises questions about whether you want the revenue effects or you want to use something like a marketable permit instead. Most fees are probably highly regressive and would tend to increase consumer costs in a particular industry. To the extent that the industry is in international competition, fees raise the cost of your goods relative to foreign produced goods.
The marketable permit system permits you to specify the amount of reduction because you've just issued that many permits to emit pollutants. Then let people trade them.
Mr. Hawkins: There are hybrid systems being considered that would auction allowances. One of the issuesabout the marketable permits system - in fact it's being raised about the acid rain proposal now - is who receives these allowances, and whether there are barriers to entry created because the allowances are initially allocated free of cost to existing polluters.
Mr. DiBona: You can structure them so it's not a problem. Auctions are a way of establishing value. But they're a problem because they may generate very large revenues.

HEADLINE: Venture Capital Loses Its Vigor

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: MENLO PARK, Calif.

 BODY:
An air of serenity pervades 3000 Sand Hill Road, a campus-like cluster of office buildings that is the venture capital business's equivalent of Wall Street. More than 20 venture firms in plush offices here plot their next investments in Silicon Valley, a few miles to the south, hoping to pick the next Apple Computer or Genentech. At lunch, their partners congregate at the Sundeck, an airy restaurant in the center of the complex that serves ''venture burgers'' and puts pencils on the tables so customers can scribble the details of their deals on the placemats.
But looks can be deceiving. The venture capital business is anything but serene these days. Profits for venture capitalists have dropped sharply and a shakeout is now gathering momentum. And fundamental changes in the business raise questions about whether venture capital, the pilot light of America's high-technology world, can continue to ignite innovation.
Once a collegial business with a few dozen main firms, venture capital is now fiercely competitive. The high returns on venture capital early in the decade attracted a pile of capital and people to manage it. More than 650 firms now vie for a portion of a venture capital pool that has grown to $31 billion, up from only $3 billion a decade ago. Few venture capitalists today would dare discuss a deal at the Sundeck within earshot of their rivals. 
But with so much money to invest, the high profits of the past have become harder to achieve. ''The basic profitability of the venture business will, must, has declined,'' said William A. Sahlman, an associate professor at the Harvard Business School. ''For the first time in history, a large number of venture capitalists will lose money.''
Indeed, the most recent funds started by ''many big-name venture capital firms are under water,'' said Anthony Hoberman, senior vice president and head of venture capital investing at Alliance Capital Management in New York, which invests in venture funds and analyzes their returns for institutional investors.
A decline in returns, in fact, has caused the new money flowing into venture capital to drop significantly in 1988 the first time in several years, according to Venture Economics in Needham, Mass., which tracks industry trends. The downturn has continued in 1989.
Some companies like the General Electric Company and Paine Webber Inc. have sold off their venture units. Venture firms, especially young ones without much of a track record, are being turned away by institutional investors when they seek new funds. ''They said come back when you have something more tangible,'' said Tony Ellis of Pacific Venture Partners, a six-year-old firm here that has been unable to raise a second fund.
Of an estimated 140 venture firms trying to raise money ''80 will not be funded at all,'' predicted Harold Bigler Jr., chairman of Bigler/Crossroads in Farmington, Conn., which invests in venture firms on behalf of pension funds.
 
Short-sighted
 Some critics think venture capitalists already have too much money - one reason they argued against lowering the capital gains tax recently. Critics say the huge amount of money and pressure from institutional investors have made venture capitalists less venturesome and more short-term oriented, much like publicly traded companies that answer to Wall Street every quarter. Rather than invest small chunks of money to start companies, many put larger chunks in more mature companies, which are less risky and closer to going public, and in leveraged buyouts, which provide quicker, and often bigger, returns.
''It's getting more like the money management business,'' lamented Franklin (Pitch) Johnson Jr., a partner in the Asset Management Company of Palo Alto, Calif.
The danger, said his partner, John S. Shoch, is that ''if you have too much of a short-term focus, it will discourage you from doing important investments in companies with core technologies.''
Indeed, some leading high-technology venture capitalists like Brentwood Associates of Los Angeles and Adler & Company of New York now spend more time and money on leveraged buyouts. The venture unit of Continental Illinois recently decided to stop investing in new startups. And the recent leveraged buyout of Prime Computer was financed by J.H. Whitney, a venture firm.
The result, some say, is a paradox: Venture capitalists have more money than ever before but startups find it harder to find backing.
''The formula is dead and we don't know what's going to replace it yet,'' said Paul Saffo, a research fellow at the Institute for the Future, a consulting firm in Menlo Park.
This formula has been peculiarly an American phenomenon and dates back to just after World War II. In the late 50's, the American Research and Development Corporation in Boston plunked down about $60,000 to back a company being formed by a computer scientist from M.I.T. named Ken Olsen. About 12 years later, that investment in the Digital Equipment Corporation was worth more than $500 million.
Venture capitalists raise money for partnerships that generally last 10 years rom wealthy individuals and institutional investors like pension funds and insurance companies, who become limited partners of the fund.
The venture capitalists, who are the funds' general partners, invest the money, usually in return for a stake in small, privately held companies. A company usually requires several rounds of investment, and if it is succeeding, each round commands a higher price. Returns are realized when the company makes a public stock offering or is sold to a larger company. The general partners typically keep 20 percent of the gains and the limited partners get the rest.
Generally, one or two big winners that return 10 or 20 times the invested money compensate for the majority of the investments, which yield little or nothing. ''We're in the business of hitting home runs,'' said Andrew S. Rachleff, a partner at Merrill Pickard Anderson & Eyre in Palo Alto.
But the business has not always thrived. In the mid-1970's, venture capitalists found it difficult to raise money. In 1975, only $10 million in new money flowed into the field, according to Venture Economics.
Venture capital's boom years began in 1978, when the capital gains tax rate was reduced and rules that kept pension funds from investing in venture capital were relaxed. Money started flowing into venture capital in a big way. And with the personal computer industry just beginning and gene-splicing newly discovered, there were opportunities galore.
 
Frothy Returns
 Some would argue that the influx of capital enabled many companies to get financing they ill deserved. The funds financed more than 40 companies making disk drives and many look-alike personal computer companies. Although many ultimately crashed, but not before venture capitalists unloaded them at high multiples in the frothy initial public offering market of 1983. ''The stock market craziness of 1983 made a lot of venture capitalists look like geniuses,'' said Richard Shaffer, editor of the Technologic Computer Letter.
Returns may never be the same. Although funds started in the early 1980's have not completed their 10-year life, it is clear that returns of many will be 20 percent or less, compounded annually, and some will be negative. That compares with more than 30 percent for funds started in the late '70s. Many venture capitalists are ''sitting with a lot of puppies in their portfolios,'' said Jane Morris, vice president of Venture Economics. Puppies, she said, are emerging dogs.
Several factors have reduced returns. The market for initial public offerings cooled after 1983 and has been in the doldrums since the 1987 stock market crash, making it harder for venture capitalists to cash out.
New companies also take more capital. That is because industries have become more capital intensive and simply because money is available. Some computer startups have required tens of millions of dollars.
The higher the investment, the greater a success a company has to be to yield a return. And the greater the losses if it fails. Venture capitalists lost an estimated $500 million on failed mini-supercomputer makers.
But as returns have withered, so have venture capitalists' abilities to command big management fees of 2 to 2.5 percent of committed capital. That rate seemed reasonable when venture funds were $10 million, but many today are $100 million or more. Investors worry that venture funds will get rich on these fees and invest their money less carefully. ''One might question whether the motivation has swtiched from the venture capitalists making money from their participation in the profits to a fee-generation business,'' said Mr. Hoberman of Alliance.
 
Watchdogs
 Adding to the pressure on the venture capitalists is a new class of watchdog that has emerged to help pension funds and insurance companies place their venture capital. Almost half the new money flowing into venture funds now passes through about seven ''gatekeepers'' like Alliance and Bigler/Crossroads.
These advisers have already forced some venture firms to reduce their fees. And one gatekeeper, Brinson Partners, which until recently was a unit of the First Chicago Corporation, is leading an effort to impose standards for how venture firms should report interim results.
Gatekeepers also come under criticism for the commissions they earn and for drawing money into venture capital, adding to the excess. ''It's not clear what they contribute to the return on investment,'' said Donald T. Valentine, a general partner of Sequoia Capital in Menlo Park and an early backer of Apple Computer Inc.
 
Sticklers for Startups
 While some would-be entrepreneurs might be having trouble finding backers, money is still available for promising ideas, venture capitalists say. A core group of traditional funds, including Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers, Asset Management, the Mayfield Fund, Merrill Pickard and Sutter Hill Ventures, continues to finance young technology companies. Sequoia Capital reduced the size of its most recent fund to $60 million from $100 million in the previous fund to allow it to invest more carefully in startups, Mr. Valentine said. Bigger funds tend to invest in more mature companies that require larger amounts of capital to reduce the number of investments in their portfolio.
There are also alternatives to venture capital. Foreign companies, particularly Japanese, are investing in American startups at an increasing rate and are willing to pay what seems irrational amounts to American venture capitalists. Some of the most notable recent financings have come from Japanese companies, including Canon's $100 million investment in Steve Jobs's Next Inc. and Fujitsu's investment in Poqet Computer, which recently introduced a one-pound portable. C-Cube Microsystems, a new startup working on video circuits in Palo Alto, recently turned down venture capitalists for a better deal from Kubota, the Japanese tractor company.
Such seemingly cheap money come at a price. ''We're selling a lot of our technology,'' said Paul Wythes, a general partner at Sutter Hill.
The competition for technology, in fact, is one reason venture capitalists have sought new opportunities in areas like retailing and waste management, or certain geographic regions. ''The name of the game is to broaden the opportunity set,'' said Peter C. Wendell, general partner of Sierra Ventures in Menlo Park, which specializes in service businesses.
With funds in Taiwan and Singapore, Walden Capital in San Francisco is one of several that thinks opportunities are fresher abroad. Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe in New York distinguishes itself by buying established companies and merging them together to create larger, more efficient ones.
Instead of waiting for entrepreneurs to come to them, some venture capitalists are going to the entrepreneurs. When new high-temperature superconductivity was discovered a few years ago, Mr. Shoch of Asset Management convinced leading scientists in the field to serve on the advisory board of a new company, Conductus Inc. He later recruited a president.
Venture capitalists say that with proper focus, they will be able to mine opportunities and provide returns that, while perhaps not as astronomical as in the past, will still exceed those of stocks and bonds. They say enough money should pour into venture capital to keep the innovation machine in motion.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: WHEN TRAGEDY LANDS IN COURT;
Put Limits on Death Compensation

BYLINE: By RANDAL R. CRAFT JR.; Randal R. Craft Jr. is a senior partner in the law firm of Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens.

 BODY:
Much has been written recently about the adverse impact on American industry and society of skyrocketing verdicts (and settlements in fear of such verdicts) for personal injuries and deaths in tort cases.
One simple reform needs more consideration than it has received so far: In a lawsuit where compensatory damages for accidental death are being sought, monetary recovery should be given only for monetary injuries. In other words, monetary compensation should be awarded only for what can reasonably be compensated for by money. If anything more is to be awarded, it should be according to a schedule established legislatively. 
All too often, large jury verdicts include compensation for intangible non-economic injuries, like the decedent's pre-death fear or decedent's loss of enjoyment of life (hedonic damages) or for decedent's family's grief, anguish, mental distress, and loss of nurture, companionship and love. Without in any way questioning the significance of injuries, the fact is that money does not alleviate them.
If a defendant's negligence has caused an accidental death resulting in economic harm to plaintiffs in a case, then sufficient monetary compensation should be awarded to compensate for that harm. But the financial compensation for nonfinancial injuries should be eliminated or, at a minimum, strictly limited.
Some states, including New York, profess to follow this principle, but juries are frequently allowed to roam well beyond the constraints this principle should impose.
In death cases the application of this principle sometimes becomes confused by well-meaning observers who talk about ''the value of human life.'' Defendants cannot bring back the lost life or replace it, for human life is unique and its true value is not quantifiable. The real question in court is what is the proper amount of money to be awarded when a defendant's negligence causes an accidental death. This is not a question about the value of human life except in the sense that it is a question about the money value of life. In a case in which money is to be awarded to compensate for the loss of life, the law should require the jury to focus on how money can actually be used to compensate for that loss.
Obviously, neither a decedent nor the decedent's estate can use money to compensate for the decedent's pre-death pain and suffering or for the decedent's so-called loss of enjoyment of life. Money is also useless in making up for a decedent's family's genuine grief, loss of companionship, and so on.
Of course, confining monetary awards to just the amounts of monetary losses demonstrated by the plaintiffs can seem particularly harsh in a case involving the death of a child. Even here, however, the only thing that can be replaced is the financial loss that the child's family incurred as a result of the child's death. If there is no financial loss, then financial compensation is inappropriate.
My wife and I lost our first child, a newborn just a few days old. We will never get over it. We had some serious doubts about the medical care, but we did not pursue the matter because there was no point in it. Any money we could have obtained through a malpractice award might have improved our creature comforts, but it would not have compensated us for what we lost or for our grief. Court judgments and money awards are not the answer to everything.
Another reason why juries and judges should not be permitted to make financial awards for intangible non-economic losses is that the law does not and cannot give juries and judges any legal principles or other useful yardsticks to determine how to evaluate these losses. Faced with the necessity of making such evaluations, juries and even judges become unguided missiles. They operate with vague instructions, insufficient standards and no limitations. The closest thing to guidance that they have is the last verdict that they read about in the newspaper, not realizing that in that case the facts were completely different or that the court later set aside or reduced the verdict. In this connection, it should be pointed out that judicial review is hardly sufficient protection against excessive verdicts, for the judges themselves have little to guide them.
Accordingly, awards for intangible non-economic damages are particularly susceptible to a jury's natural and understandable sympathy for the decedent's family. The result can be extremely high verdicts - windfalls beyond any rational connection with compensation for the plaintiffs.
Society at large obviously bears the burden of such windfalls. Legislatures and judges alike should take steps to prevent these windfalls. In death cases, the law should allow juries to award money as compensation only for what can reasonably be compensated for by money.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL FINANCE;
A Helping Hand on Reverse Mortgages

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD; Carole Gould writes about personal finance topics from New York.

 BODY:
A pilot program run by the Federal Housing Administration that could spur the use of reverse mortgages is just now getting under way around the country.
Reverse mortgages are taken out mainly by older borrowers eager to tap the unused equity in their homes. These homeowners, who are cash-poor but house-rich with a small mortgage or none at all, put up their home as collateral, receiving regular payments from the lender for a fixed term or for the rest of their life. The loan is repaid, along with accrued interest, in a lump sum at the end of the fixed term or when the borrower moves, sells or dies. Reverse mortgages can be more attractive than traditional ones because eligibility is based on the amount of equity, rather than income. 
But thrticipating lenders, said Judith V. May, a policy analysis officer in Washington with the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the F.H.A.'s parent agency.
In late summer, final regulations were issued and applications are now being accepted. The F.H.A. is authorized to insure 2,500 mortgages, but legislation is before Congress to raise that number to 25,000. The bill is supported by Jack F. Kemp, the Housing Secretary, and action on the measure could come early next year.
The program would reduce or eliminate much of the risk to lenders and borrowers. Nonetheless, a reverse mortgage should not be the only solution considered by older homeowners in need of cash, Mr. Scholen cautioned. Check other sources of help for the elderly by contacting your local Social Security office and state Office for the Aging.
You should also consider other ways to use your house to raise money or to cut expenses. Carve out a rental apartment in your house - assuming local zoning laws permit that - or simply take in a roommate. You may also want to think about moving to a smaller, less expensive home, perhaps pocketing a handsome profit from the sale. (Generally, those 55 years of age and older can escape capital gains tax on the first $125,000 of profit from the sale of a primary residence.) In addition, look into property tax and loan deferral programs offered by city, county or state housing agencies. In 16 states, including Connecticut but not New York or New Jersey, the property taxes of older homeowners may be put off until the property is sold or the owner dies. Other local government agencies offer similar programs for loans they issue that are used to make home repairs. Interest on such loans, if any, is likely to be below market rates. If these other options still are not enough, consider the reverse mortgage. Because of hefty up-front fees, conventional reverse mortgages available privately and through the F.H.A. program - those that are not repaid until the borrower dies, moves or sells - are very costly in the short run and generally should not be used if the borrower anticipates moving within three or four years. A less costly alternative is a fixed-term reverse mortgage that is uninsured. (Even without insurance, the risks are not that large, some experts say. Steep penalties built into the private programs make it economically unlikely for lenders to default, and none have, the experts note.) Of course, the real cost of a conventional reverse mortgage goes down over time as the up-front expenses are amortized. In fact, if you remain in your home beyond your actuarial life expectancy, you can end up with a bargain, assuming your home's value appreciates only modestly.
That is because all of the mortgages currently available are non-recourse loans; that is, you cannot ultimately owe more than what your home is worth, regardless of how many payments you receive from the lender. The lender cannot seek repayment from your other assets or your heirs.
The loans differ in a variety of ways besides the cost in up-front fees, so potential borrowers should be prepared to do their homework. Interest rates vary, as do many other loan terms. Most, but not all, of the reverse mortgages written so far, for example, have a ''shared appreciation'' feature; this is optional for the Government-insured loans. The lender takes a stated percentage of any increase in the value of the property when the loan is due. The greater the percentage given to the lender, the higher your monthly payment can be. But that will leave you, or your heirs, with less when the loan is finally paid.
Another key factor to consider is the size of the monthly payment you want. In general, borrowers can receive higher monthly payments from private lenders than they would through the F.H.A. program. This reflects the more optimistic view that private lenders have of how much homes will appreciate. Moreover, the F.H.A.-insured loans are based on a maximum of $101,250 of equity even if the house is worth more, a cap that does not apply to other loans. The difference can be dramatic. A 75-year-old borrower with a $200,000 home, for example, would receive no more than about $360 per month from a Government-insured loan. But the same borrower could get about $1,000 a month from a private lender outside the program.
Government-insured loans have other advantages, however, including flexibility. Borrowers who have sufficient funds to cover living expenses, for example, may opt for a line of credit rather than monthly payments. In the private sector, lines of credit so far are available only in conjunction with monthly payment plans.
The payments received from a reverse mortgage are not taxable, because they are considered a loan. They will also not affect eligibility for Medicare or Social Security, but they may affect Supplemental Security Income or Medicaid payments, because those programs are based on need.
To qualify for the F.H.A. program, borrowers must be 62 years of age or older and meet with an F.H.A.-certified counselor to discuss the program as well as other financial options.
For the names of local lenders participating in the Government-insured program, call 800 245-2691. For a comprehensive list of public-sector and private lenders, send a self-addressed, stamped, business-size envelope to: The National Center for Home Equity Conversion, 348 West Main Street, Marshall, Minn. 56258.

HEADLINE: TV's Future

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the debate on ''Tomorrow's Television'' (Business Forum, Sept. 17), the suggestion by Michael Borrus and Jeffrey A. Hart that niche markets may be the smoother, more profitable path for HDTV will likely become clearer as we move farther along that road.
As we grapple with the conceptual basis of TV's future, we should anticipate drifting into a thriving, hybrid marriage of microcomputer functions with conventional TV uses (we can call it PCTV). In contrast, our push for a national policy to foster an HDTV broadcast standard is misguided. It would inevitably bring second-rate technology. But it is more than bad policy: it is fruitless. 
Contrary to conventional wisdom, HDTV cannot be economically launched via existing commercial broadcast in the United States for several reasons. There is no additional spectrum available to allocate for the 50 percent to 100 percent increase in band width necessary for HDTV as an augmented broadcast format. No legislative, regulatory or judicial relief is likely available for simulcasting on additional channels by current commercial broadcasters. And if it were, we would face the ''chicken and egg'' failure. Neither a consumer market to buy $50 billion worth of new TV sets nor a commercial market to finance $25 billion in transmission for broadcasting can exist without the other being developed first.
We should realize, as Mr. Borrus and Mr. Hart do, that aggregates of various unfettered markets can drive a pervasive new high-resolution technology by combining the following niches - direct-broadcast satellite and cable television; video disks and cassettes; a variety of CD video formats; microcomputers and videogames; fiber-optic phones, data networks and videotex.
All of these formats may ultimately be dependent upon cheap and powerful computer-driven TV's. That realization can shape a truly creative American resolution to the challenges of our rapidly changing media environment.
 
GLENN RALSTON
Indianapolis, Sept. 20

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN VENDING MACHINES;
Sustaining Sales by Improving Convenience

BYLINE: By JACK STEINBERG

 BODY:
Taken a good look at your favorite vending machine lately?
Chances are, it is a more sophisticated piece of equipment than its predecessor of even three years ago. Technological innovations have opened up tantalizing new opportunities for the nation's 8,000 or so vending operators, which contract with building owners to place and service machines on their property. 
Paper-money acceptors mounted on many machines have turned people without change into patrons. A new method of packaging food to increase its shelf life has opened up the range of possibilities for the machines. And more sophisticated refrigerated dispensing units are enabling operators to go beyond basic sandwiches to offer cold platters and other fresh entrees at ever higher prices.
The vending business, that symbol of America's perpetual quest for convenience, is on a roll. In 1988, Americans dropped $22.6 billion into the dispensers, double what they spent in 1978, according to Vending Times, a trade journal. ''It isn't a fad anymore,'' said Victor Lavay, its executive publisher. ''It's an integral part of the economy.''
Traditionally resistant to any sort of technological change, the mom-and-pop operators who dominate the business have not innovated entirely by choice. Vendors were forced to broaden their selections to include popular fruit juices and health snack bars and to find new ways to peddle food to offset declines in their core cigarette business. Concerns over lung cancer and legislative efforts to ban smoking in public places have caused machine sales of cigarettes to drop by half since the late 1970's, to $1.6 billion last year, according to Mark Dlugoss, editor of the American Automatic Merchandiser, a trade journal. The category now accounts for only 8 percent of industry sales, down from 27 percent in the late 1970's.
Food has more than compensated for the loss, but may not be able to sustain the current clip of sales growth for long. People simply don't carry enough change to pay the higher prices asked these days. And not all operators can afford to install dollar changers. To cope, the industry is putting its weight behind a proposal to mint a new dollar coin. Plastic charge cards may also have their place.

HEADLINE: The Hospital Workers Are The Envy of Labor Now

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
WITH a sophisticated strategy that even its opponents agree was carried out to near perfection, New York City's major health-care workers' union gained a victory last week that many experts say provides the nation's labor movement with a badly needed ray of hope.
The accomplishment, a contract that includes wage increases of about 21 percent over the next three years for about 50,000 members, re-establishes Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Workers in the front ranks of American labor. The union has long been known for its organizational ability and activism, but had recently seemed to be falling apart.
''All the groups that have gone out to organize in the service sector - the teamsters, the various government employee unions and others - have always seen 1199 as something of a pacesetter, even when they saw it as a rival,'' said David Montgomery, a professor of history specializing in labor studies at Yale University. 
While not a sign that the ''union movement has re-entered any period of great growth,'' Mr. Montgomery sai unions in the service sector, with ''an example of cohesivenss and lends a sense of direction.''
The workers covered by the accord include nurses aides, pharmacists, orderlies, and laboratory technicians, whose average annual salary is about $18,000.
Labor economists and historians say the hospital union's contract settlement, achieved just before dawn Wednesday after months of intense politicking and mostly fruitless negotiations with the city's private hospitals, was only the second settlement in recent years that labor can point to as an unabashed success.
''The only place a union has gotten a similar deal is the Harvard workers,'' said Richard B. Freeman, a professor of economics at Harvard University, referring to an agreement last June under which the university's clerical and technical workers received an average raise of 32 percent over three years. ''Things have been so bleak in the labor movement,'' he said, that union organizers ''must feel like a sports team that has really been taking a beating and has finally scored a run.''
Local 1199's contract was the product of a campaign of old-fashioned organizing and astute lobbying, begun last winter and sustained throughout the year.
A clear sign of the union's renewed vigor came last April when it brought more than 12,000 people to Albany to demonstrate, along with hospital management, against proposed state Medicaid cuts. In an even more impressive feat, a telegram with 200,000 signatures from workers, patients, doctors and others was delivered to the office of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. Albany quickly relented, eliminating many cutbacks.
Local 1199 then turned its attentions to New York City, where politicians during the recent primary election campaign seemed to fall over themselves to support a union that had shown it could do so much so quickly.
With memories of steep wage losses still fresh in the minds of workers who suffered through the union's ineffective 47-day strike in 1984, leaders of Local 1199 knew that threatening a strike this year carried as much risk for the union as it did for the hospitals.
''We went into those negotiations with a paper sword and just got cut up,'' said Moe Foner, a longtime force in the union, referring to 1984. ''We were determined to go into this year's talks showing a different face.''
 
Surprising Enthusiasm
To gauge the workers' fervor while turning up the heat on the hospitals, Dennis Rivera, the union's newly elected president, devised a plan of abbreviated job actions: three strikes of one, two and three days carried out over the summer. Enthusiasm among the workers surprised even the organizers and local politicians, including the Democratic mayoral candidate, David N. Dinkins, who strongly supported the union and has its active support in his campaign.
In July, John Cardinal O'Connor brokered a contract with the union calling for two annual wage increases of 8.5 percent at four hospitals of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York. The union used the Cardinal's generous terms against the other hospitals to great effect with a slogan: ''If the Catholics can pay it, why can't some of the world's greatest medical centers?''
Over the next two months, with the discreet assistance of state officials anxious to avoid the disruption of hospital care that any strike would bring, the union was able to chip away at the united front of the hospitals.
First, three financially troubled hospitals, which depend on special state assistance, signed separate contracts similar to the Catholic hospitals' agreement.
On the eve of last week's strike deadline, the financially weakest of the city's major teaching hospitals, Presbyterian Hospital, also settled separately. And as the threatened walkout approached, one hospital after another, sensing that industry negotiations were going nowhere, signaled their willingness to settle, too.
In addition to its clever tactics, labor experts say that Local 1199, like the Harvard workers' union, was helped immeasurably by the fact that its opponents were in a nonprofit, nonmanufacturing business.
These analysts caution that for all of the tonic effect on the labor movement of the settlement, similar victories will not automatically begin to proliferate.
''They were not bargaining against a Frank Lorenzo,'' said Mr. Freeman of Harvard, referring to the airline takeover specialist. ''In other industries the company can look you in the face and say, 'Fine, with wage demands like that we can make a lot more money in Korea or Mexico' - and they would not be bluffing.''

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
How New York City Is Trying to Keep Its Numbers High

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
FEARING the loss of millions of dollars and of incalculable political power as the result of another undercount in the Federal census, New York City officials have begun mapping the demographic terrain over which they will have to travel to insure that the most invisible and reluctant New Yorkers are enumerated next year.
Those most in need of the money and influence that can flow from a full census count are, in many cases, the very people who are least likely to be counted. They are people who are hard to track down or unwilling to cooperate with any government official for fear that information they provide will be used to punish them.
''How is it that we can instill in people a sense of trust in government?'' asked Diane Mulcahy Coffey, the city's census coordinator and chief of staff to Mayor Edward I. Koch. 
For New York City, the stakes are high. In 1980, city officials contend, the Census Bureau undercounted the city's population by about 6 percent, or some 450,000 people.
''We lost one member of Congress,'' Mr. Koch said. ''We lost about three Assembly members and one state senator from the City of New York.'' Moreover, he said, ''Most of the major formulas in Federal and state legislation relate to population. The last time we went through this, we estimated that as a result of the undercount, we're losing at the rate of $20 million a year.''
Now, the city is preparing an extensive public information campaign, which city officials say will be much larger than the limited one the city ran in 1980.
''This time, we will do everything possible to insure that the program is far reaching, hits as many people as possible - particularly those hard-to-count areas - and to insure that the data are confidential,'' Ms. Coffey said. ''We are targeting specific populations with messages. These include tenants who are doubled up illegally in public and private housing, persons who receive public assistance and fear a reduction in benefits if their census response is at odds with information they have previously provided to city or state agencies and undocumented immigrants who - as you can imagine - may strive to avoid any contact with the government, particularly the Census Bureau, for fear that they will be deported.''
 
Different Messages
The messages have not yet been devised, although the city plans to use newspapers, radio, television and other media to get them across. The director for the city's $1.5 million census project, Roberta Lentz, said, ''In some cases, it may be a subway campaign in Chinese or a community-based campaign in the schools.''
But first, of course, the people who need to be reached must be found.
The city is already at work on a ''site inventory'' for a special count of some of New York's homeless population that is to be made by the Census Bureau next March, just before April 1 when the census will be taken across the country. As described by Ms. Coffey, the inventory ''contains the addresses of every street and shelter location where the Census Bureau can expect to find homeless persons.'' The first part of the inventory will be sent to the bureau later this month.
Another piece of groundwork is a map prepared by the City Planning Department that shows, by community board district, the location of households characterized by factors that can lead to an undercount: ''social and economic distress,'' insufficient proficiency in English or comprehension of the census and frequent change of address.
Together with more detailed neighborhood findings, the map will help the city plan its public-relations effort, although the number of factors in an area does not necessarily indicate the severity of the problem. ''If an area has just one factor, and that happens to be English-language proficiency, that might be much more complex than an area with all three factors,'' Ms. Lentz said. ''That map is the basis of our planning. But it does not indicate a strategy right now.''
 
Measuring Households
''Distress'' was determined by a low percentage of men in the work force and a hiercentage of households on public assistance. English proficiency problems were indicated by a high percentage of foreign-born people who have recently arrived in the United States. And frequent address changes were indicated by a high percentage of nonfamily households headed by someone under the age of 65 and a high percentage of people who moved after 1975.
City planners relate these factors to instances of undercounting: census questionnaires that never reached given households, questionnaires that were not returned or questionnaires that were returned without an accounting of all the people in the household. To bring their findings up to date, planners also used recent data on immigration, on recipients of aid to dependent children, on births to foreign-born mothers and on births out of wedlock.
City officials were pleased last July when, on the verge of a trial in Federal court on a suit brought by New York City and other local governments and groups, the Census Bureau announced that it. Koch said, ''when they had the census, everybody had to go back to their hometown. You may read about it in the New Testament. I was thinking of issuing an order that everybody had to report to City Hall and that I would personally count them.''

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Time for Straight Talk

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
This is the time of year, the High Holy Days, when Jews are supposed to look into themselves, reflect on what has been and commit themselves to what should be. In 1989 it should be a time also for honest thinking about the future of Israel.
Prime Minister Shamir and his Likud colleagues have just said no to a gentle suggestion by President Mubarak of Egypt on how to get a peace process going. Their no told us as clearly as anything has where Israel is heading under its present leadership. Ten or twenty years from now, if it stays on that path, it will be this kind of country:
* It will be a Jewish state in which Arabs make up nearly half the population and will soon be more than half. Jews will maintain political control because Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza have no vote or other political rights. 
* It will be a garrison state. The only way to retain control over the occupied territories will be by increasing military force and increasing abandonment of the rule of civilized law.
* It will be a brutalized state. Imprisoning Palestinians by the thousands without trial, deporting them without evidence, shooting children -all this and more will have become part of normal life.
* It will be an isolated state. The one link to Israel's Arab neighbors, the treaty with Egypt, will have frayed or broken by then. And some of the isolation will be self-imposed: Israelis who even talk with Palestinian leaders will be imprisoned.
* It will be a dependent state. Dependence on United States aid for economic existence, which grew during the 1980's, will by now be overwhelming - if American taxpayers are still willing to bear the heavy burden.
That future is a necessary consequence of the choice that Prime Minister Shamir and his Government have made. They chose the status quo - indefinitely. Even though President Mubarak leaned way over backward to please Mr. Shamir, the idea that Israeli and Palestinian delegates meet in Cairo was rejected because it might conceivably lead to a change in the status quo. It might develop movement toward Palestinian rights.
The talks in Cairo would only have been to flesh out a proposal made by Mr. Shamir himself: for Palestinians in the occupied territories to elect representatives who would negotiate with Israel. Some doubted Mr. Shamir's sincerity when he came up with the idea on May 14. I did not, but I see no reason now to think he was serious.
After rejecting the Mubarak invitation, Mr. Shamir said there could still be other ideas to follow up. But such talk is a familiar tactic. It is designed to create an illusion of hope that covers the reality of Mr. Shamir's determination to do nothing.
Clarity is the one gain from the decision in Jerusalem. It is clear now where responsibility rests for the lack of progress toward peace in the Middle East. It rests on the Government of Israel.
Objectively, the prospects for peace have never been brighter. Palestinians have found a voice at last for negotiation and compromise. The P.L.O. has recognized Israel and, in the many months since that historic decision, refrained from terrorism. But the Government of Israel says no.
The clarity of the situation has con-sequences in the United States. It requires a response from American Jews and from the American Government.
The Jewish community in this country is concerned about where Israel is heading. Many American Jews, probably most, are opposed to the Shamir policy of holding on to the West Bank and Gaza forever by force, with all the self-brutalizing consequences.
But the voice of the community is muted. The major Jewish organizations do not speak out critically about the Shamir policy. They do not say what many believe: that the rejection of President Mubarak, the refusal to talk with Palestinians are steps that threaten the future of Israel.
The reluctance is understandable. The Jewish organizations have to work with the Israeli Government that is. Their constituents worry about anything that looks disloyal.
But when the life and character of Israel are at stake, those are not adequate excuses. Honesty is required.
President Bush and Secretary of State Baker have muted their voices, too. They worry about the short-term political risks of openly disagreeing with an Israeli Government. But in the longer term, they must know, Americans will become restless about supporting an Israel that rejects the chance of peace. It is in the true interest of Israel for the United States to speak out about the danger of an isolated, embattled future.

HEADLINE: Try Drug Legalization On Experimental Scale

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A. M. Rosenthal gave me pause with his column titled ''The Case for Slavery'' (Sept. 26). Despite the weighted analogy to slavery, Mr. Rosenthal makes some valid points regarding the dangers lurking in legalization of drugs. 
Nevertheless, in conversations I had with some reputable church leaders in Bolivia some months ago, I heard a clear call for legalization in this country as the only sure hope of mitigating the effects of drug cartels in that country.
One highly placed churchman insisted in the strongest terms that nothing short of legalization would undercut the enormous profits from the drug trade, which signify a parallel economy in Bolivia (as well as in Peru and Colombia). I was told that Bolivia's earnings from foreign trade amounted to $400 million, while the intake from drugs came to $700 million in the same year.
With President Bush and our drug czar, William J. Bennett, offering platitudes, money and failed policies as remedies for the crisis, would it not be instructive at least to try legalization. This might be done in one or two places by way of experiment to test the facile conclusions that one hears on both sides of this untried remedy.
 
(Rev.) JOSEPH NANGLE
 Silver Spring, Md., Sept. 27, 1989

HEADLINE: Economic Forces That Knock Down The Oldest Forests

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
ONE hundred years ago, John Muir, the pioneer naturalist, rhapsodized about the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest and warned that the carpet of greenery stretching from the Cascade Mountains to the Pacific Ocean might one day shrink to a few small patches.
Muir's cautionary words were being tested in the woods of Washington State this month while in the other Washington Congress grappled with a short-term settlement of the fight over logging in what remains of the nation's virgin forests.
A compromise was approved by Congress last week after a year of court fights and political squabbling and is expected to be signed by President Bush. It will impose a yearlong prohibition of lawsuits aimed at protecting the spotted owl, a bird whose existence is said to be threatened by heavy logging in the national forests. Such suits have held up most logging in important old-growth areas. In turn, the Forest Service has agreed to protect certain forests that had been scheduled for clear-cutting - essentially doing, for one year, what conservationists had been asking the courts to do. But both sides said the temporary settlement was no more than a Band-Aid. Representative Les AuCoin, Democrat of Oregon, said the contending parties have bought one year to come up with a permanent solution. 
For two decades, foresters have been warning logging companies that they cannot keep cutting old-growth timber at the present rate and expect to have any giant trees left early in the next century. What is needed, they say, is to switch from logging the irreplaceable evergreens to an industry based on second-growth trees, like those grown on the Weyerhaeuser Company's six million acres of tree farms.
But the logging industry, primarily in Oregon, the main timber-producing state, has been slow to change. Industry spokesmen say that if companies cannot cut the remaining big trees in public forests, 5,000 to 30,000 jobs will be lost. Economists say that the country's lumber needs can be met without harvesting the centuries-old Western red cedars and Douglas firs.
Last year, for example, a record one out of every four logs from the West Coast, including old-growth and tree-farmed logs, was exported. Weyerhaeuser, the world's largest timber company, temporarily shut down some logging operations this month because it has a surplus of wood stockpiled for export. Japan, the prime consumer of raw logs from the Pacific Northwest, is glutted with American timber.
Meanwhile, the owners of dozens of small sawmills in Washington and Oregon cannot afford available timber at current prices, and they are fighting environmentalists over the right to cut down large stands of old-growth trees. The last independent sawmill at Coos Bay, Ore., recently shut down because it could not pay the going price for the available logs, while the port was stuffed with timber for export from a nearby Weyerhaeuser tree farm.
 
Japan Pays Double
Prices have stayed high despite the glut in Japan, where buyers are paying up to $600 per thousand board feet, twice what American mill owners are accustomed to paying for raw logs. Even in a glut, forest owners can afford not to sell at lower prices but to wait for premium prices. The foreign buyers have nowhere else to go for prime Douglas fir logs. The United States and Chile are the only countries that export raw logs on a large scale. Canada permits log exports only when domestic mills have all they need.
Priced out of the state and private timber markets in their own region, owners of small mills in the Northwest have pressured the Forest Service to allow them to cut more trees from Federal land, from which raw-log exports are prohibited.
What is at issue in the old-growth debate, then, is a regional economy based on cutting the oldest and biggest trees on public land, the last 1 percent of America's original forest cover. Of the two million to three million acres of untouched old-growth trees left in the country - all in the Northwest - about 60,000 acres a year on Federal land are being cut to keep alive the region's small timber towns, which have had double-digit unemployment rates even during the best of times.
The fight over these forests has intensified as acreage shrinks. In 1938 loggers and the Forest Service objected when President Roosevelt established the Olympic National Park, an emerald sanctuary that has become one of the five most-visited national parks. ''If the exploiters are permitted to have their way with the Olympic Peninsula, all that will be left will be the outraged squeal of future generations over the loss of another national treasure,'' Harold Ickes, Roosevelt's Interior Secretary, said at the time.
Since then, all but 90,000 acres of the 600,000-acre Olympic National Forest have been cut. Most of the land has been replanted, but it will never resemble the forest that preceeded it. Now experts say that at the present rate of old-growth cutting throughout the Northwest, most of the remaining towering trees of original forest will be eliminated in a generation. Lou Gold, an Oregon environmentalist, calls the old-growth logging campaign ''the last great buffalo hunt.''

HEADLINE: The Tax Breaks America Couldn't Give Up

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE brief experiment in tax reform seems to be coming to an end. The three-year-old law, the dream of generations of academic experts, has fallen victim to political reality - a new President who wants to use the tax code to meet economic and social goals, powerful interests that lobby for favorable tax treatment and Americans' pervasive conviction that they are overtaxed.
The Senate last week put off voting on major tax proposals as well as other budget-related issues, like expanding Federal support for child care. But as Congress continued working toward an Oct. 16 budget deadline, the odds appeared strong, following a lopsided vote in the House last month and assiduous nose-counting in the Senate last week, that some form of cut in the capital gains tax would be approved before the year is out. That action would dismantle the delicate balance of the 1986 tax law. Along the way, other tax changes may be approved as well. 
Economists say that not enough data are available to tell whether the tax experiment succeeded in making the system fairer and more economically efficient. What is clear is that President Bush pulled the thread that could result in the unraveling of the fabric of the 1986 law, unless the mood in Congress changes unexpectedly.
Under the Tax Reform Act of 1986, tax rates were sharply reduced at all levels of income, and deductions and other breaks that had been written into the tax code one after another for years were eliminated or curtailed. The law was the product of dozens of carefully drawn political and economic bargains.
A central compromise was that in return for cutting the tax rate of the wealthiest Americans nearly in half, to 28 percent from 50 percent, capital gains would be taxed at the same higher level as other income. Capital gains are the profits from the sale of investments like stocks, bonds and real estate, and are realized mostly by the affluent. Ronald Reagan made enactment of the tax law the top domestic priority of his second term, and his personal influence outweighed the political forces working against it. Mr. Reagan maintained that market forces, not the tax code, should be the determining factor in how economic resources are allocated.
But George Bush was never enthusiastic about the measure. As Vice President, he pressed unsuccessfully to retain tax breaks for the oil and gas industry. And in his Presidential campaign last year, he advocated, among other tax breaks, a lower capital gains rate and deductions for child-care costs, college tuition and other expenses.
This year, the President has pushed Congress harder on this issue than on any other. With Senate leaders of both parties struggling for some kind of agreement that would let them pass the budget bill without becoming embroiled in an extended debate over capital gains, Mr. Bush went to the Capitol Friday and told the senators that reducing the capital gains tax was ''not an extraneous matter with me.''
Economists say that most people and businesses learned to accommodate themselves to the loss of tax breaks. A benefit of taxing capital gains at a lower rate than other income, proponents say, is that it increases investment in business start-ups. But in 1987, the first year the capital gains tax break was ended, more money was put in such investments than ever before. Individual retirement accounts, which were limited by the 1986 law, supposedly encouraged people to save. But the rate of personal saving, after declining in 1987, rose again in 1988 to where it was before the law was changed.
Nonetheless, the pressure to regain old tax breaks simmered quietly among corporations and industry associations. And President Bush's vigorous advocacy of reducing the capital gains tax had the effect of turning up the heat.
Democrats responded to the Bush plan with a proposal to restore tax-deductible I.R.A.'s to all working Americans, a measure which, like a capital gains cut, would largely benefit the affluent. Timber interests, which have strong influence in many Southern and Western states, also began pressing their case for tax advantages.
The Senate Finance Committee met until well past midnight Tuesday and approved tax breaks for producers of a grain-based gasoline additive, pineapple growers, millionaire grandparents, liquor stores, cattle raisers, investors in low-income housing, tuxedo rental companies and many others.
Many of those special provisions were adopted so one senator or another could please a particular constituent, and it was generally accepted that those would be stricken from the legislation before it became law. But some provisions were approved with serious intent and were considered likely to remain. Dozens of lobbyists who waited outside the Finance Committee room, the same ones who fought tooth and nail against the 1986 law, had looks of satisfaction when they finally went home at about 2 A.M. Wednesday morning.
Paradoxically, some of the lawmakers and political operatives who were most responsible for putting the tax compromises together three years ago are the ones now involved in tearing them apart. They include Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee; Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee; Richard G. Darman, Mr. Bush's budget director, who was Deputy Secretary of the Treasury in 1986, and Bill Diefenderfer, who was Senator Packwood's chief of staff then and is now Mr. Darman's deputy.
Politics, not tax policy, is central to the thinking of these men. And after the capital gains issue arose, pressure rose quickly for other changes. ''People who want a tax break will push it to the hilt,'' said David H. Brockway, former staff director of the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation. ''No one ever comes up and says, 'Raise my taxes.' ''
The House Speaker, Representative Thomas S. Foley, would like to leave the tax law untouched, but says he cannot win that fight, in part because the argument that mostly rich people would benefit from a particular tax break carries little weight nowadays.
''You don't hear the $8,000 restaurant worker say, 'I'm faxing my views up to you,' '' he said. Taxpayers do not care if Donald Trump gets a $25,000 tax cut, Mr. Foley said, as long as they get $10 in the bargain.

HEADLINE: The Panama Jinx;
What Should Washington Do About Noriega?

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AFTER Washington stops arguing about the extent to which President Bush fumbled last week's attempt by Panamanian troops to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Administration will have to think about where American policy goes from here.
The failed coup leaves the Administration with even more limited options in Panama than before, and not one is appealing.
The most obvious way for Mr. Bush to get rid of General Noriega quickly and dispel criticism that he missed an opportunity last week would be to order an old-fashioned military operation. Conservatives like Elliott Abrams criticize him for an unwillingness to topple General Noriega with force. But that would risk American casualties and hostages, a domestic political backlash, Latin American censure and perhaps failure. 
''Removing Noriega by force is a ridiculous idea,'' said Robert A. Pastor, a Carter Administration official who is an expert on the region. ''If we failed, we'd be humiliated, and if we succeeded, even our closest friends in Latin America would condemn us. We could be faced with a hostile new regime or find ourselves compelled to support a regime through military occupation.''
Mr. Bush could improve his management of crises and hope the Panamanian military organizes a new coup, one more to Washington's liking. But the combination of the American decision not to intervene and General Noriega's most recent repression make it questionable that the United States will be given another chance, at least any time soon.
Perhaps President Bush could take another tack altogether, distancing himself from the failed policy he inherited from the Reagan Administration. His predecessor turned to economic and diplomatic sanctions, assuming they would quickly force General Noriega from power. This did not work, and for a long time some analysts have recommended that Mr. Bush begin to regard General Noriega as someone the United States may have to live with.
But switching to such a policy would incense American conservatives and send a signal to Latin America that Mr. Bush has backed down on promises to do whatever is needed to fight the hemisphere's drug trade.
As part of a long-term approach, Mr. Bush could assert that any coup by Panama's military, which for decades has had a reputation for corruption and ruthlessness, would not necessarily usher in a democratic regime. After the coup last week, the Administration said that it hung back partly because the rebels were less interested in democracy and bringing General Noriega to justice than in grabbing power for themselves.
Some experts say Mr. Bush should recognize that what is at stake in Panama is not a strategic prize, but the image of the United States as a great power. While American conservatives point to the Panama Canal and American listening posts and military bases in Panama as evidence of its importance, some analysts like Mr. Pastor argue that these things have largely lost their strategic value, particularly in an era of waning East-West tensions. The Pentagon, anticipating the transfer of the canal from American to Panamanian control a decade from now, is planning to relocate its ground-command operations for Latin America from Panama to somewhere in the United States.
Mr. Bush could put more emphasis on multilateral diplomacy. Many Latin American and European countries have already recalled their ambassadors in protest against General Noriega's voiding of Panama's presidential election last May. But the United States failed last month in its efforts to get a tough resolution against General Noriega from the Organization of American States, illustrating just how difficult it is to use an instrument of diplomacy that successive American Administrations have ignored for more than a decade. The failure also showed how politically difficult it is for the O.A.S. to use muscle against one of its own.
Mr. Bush, in addition, has been accused of being unwilling to close a gap between his words and deeds. By announcing last spring that he would ''love'' to see the Panama Defense Forces oust General Noriega, he raised expectations that the United States favored quick military action and would support just such an effort as took place last week.
The words-deeds gap was noted by foreign policy experts last week and was illustrated by a Panamanian opposition leader who supports American policy, Guillermo Ford. Mr. Ford met briefly with Mr. Bush a day after the coup attempt. ''I looked Bush straight in the eye and he told me he'd do whatever it takes to get Noriega out, that nothing has been ruled out.'' Mr. Ford said. ''He said he would not allow a dictator like Noriega to make a fool of the United States and the rest of the world.'' But Mr. Bush offered no concrete strategy or new ideas to achieve that goal, Mr. Ford said.
 
Marching in Place
Indeed, the possibility remains that Mr. Bush will simply beat the Noriega drum loudly while marching in place. None of his top advisers seem to have a clear idea where to turn next. Despite reports of tension between John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, over flaws in the handling of last week's crisis, neither is advocating a shift in basic policy. And Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, who has still not focused much attention on various regional issues, including Panama, told Mr. Ford in a meeting last week that the United States intends to follow its current course.
Some Administration officials have tried to characterize the failed coup as a vindication of their policy. ''The pressures we've been bringing to bear on the Noriega regime are having a real effect,'' said Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. ''At the end of the day, Noriega is more isolated, more paranoid and less secure in his control than before.''
What makes any prediction difficult is that Panama's military leader was both weakened and strengthened last week. He was weakened because the rebellion reached deep into the ranks of the military, narrowing his circle of loyalists and exposing him as vulnerable. He was strengthened because his crackdown that followed is likely to discourage any new plot for some time.
Even a successful coup and the installation of the civilian opposition might not guarantee an end to General Noriega's influence. In his conversation with Mr. Bush last week, Mr. Ford said, he made it clear that the Panamanian opposition would never turn the General over to the United States to stand trial on drug-trafficking charges.
''I told Mr. Bush that we will fully comply with the Constitution of Panama,'' Mr. Ford said. ''If Noriega wants to stay as a decent human being in Panama, he can stay in Panama.''
