LENGTH: 4058 words

HEADLINE: OUR MOST NOTORIOUS SCULPTOR

BYLINE: By Deborah Solomon; Deborah Solomon, the author of ''Jackson Pollock: A Biography,'' is writing a book on Joseph Cornell for Farrar, Straus and Giroux.

 BODY:
Cape Breton, Nova Scotia, is a scenic place. Every summer, Canadian tourists descend by the thousands to camp along its beaches and hike its winding trails. There are souvenir shops everywhere, and the gifts they carry - tartan tams, bright plaid ties, bagpiper key chains -proudly advertise the island's Scottish ancestry. 
But the tourists seldom stop in Inverness, an old mining town on the western edge of the island. The coal mines began closing in the 1950's, and today Inverness is a desolate place plagued by unemployment and alcoholism. It's easy to buy a six-pack of beer here, but impossible to go to a library or see a movie. Richard Serra has come to Inverness for 20 years now, and he says it's the one place where he feels at home. He spends most of the year in Manhattan, but the city, to him, ''is just a trading post, a place to exchange services and commodities. This is where I really live.'' Serra, a stocky man of 49, dressed in a navy blue T-shirt and a pair of jeans, could easily pass for one of the island's fishermen. As we drive toward his home one evening - he lives three miles outside town -people strolling the dirt road recognize his blue Chevrolet truck and wave hello. Serra waves back. Here, on the island, he is liked. But, then again, here he has never attempted to create a sculpture for a public site. Serra is one of America's most esteemed artists. In the two decades since he first started assembling immense steel plates into ''site-specific'' sculptures - his best-known pieces are created for bustling urban plazas - he has risen from the ranks of the 1960's avant-garde into the annals of art history. A vocal leftist, he first made a name for himself with splashed-lead sculptures designed to challenge the tradition of the collectible art object and the patronage system by which art is bought and sold. Yet it would be hard to call Serra an enemy of the art establishment today. His paint-stick drawings and indoor sculptures are exhibited at fashionable Manhattan galleries like Leo Castelli and Pace (he has one-man shows at both this month). In 1986, a Serra was comissioned for the London Stock Exchange - at a price of $650,000, a record for the artist's work.
Yet, for all the respect he commands within the art world, Serra can safely be described as the most notorious sculptor in America. His work has been called ''garbage,'' ''hideous,'' ''dehumanized,'' ''an irritant,'' ''a calculated offense,'' ''scrap iron'' - to borrow the appraisals of irate office workers who in 1985 testified against a Serra sculpture that had been placed in their midst. The sculpture no longer exists. Last March, ''Tilted Arc'' - 120 feet of curved Cor-Ten steel - was removed from Federal Plaza in Manhattan after years of acrimonious wrangling between the artist and the Federal Government, which commissioned the work.
Opposition to other Serra sculptures appears to be mounting in the wake of the ''Tilted Arc'' controversy; the latest brouhaha is at Yale University, the artist's alma mater. In Europe, however, where Serra is at work on a dozen commissions from Oslo to Geneva to Grenoble, both the art and the artist are receiving far more gracious treatment. In 1985, as Americans were railing against ''Tilted Arc,'' a similar sculpture installed in the Square de Choisy in Paris prompted Francois Mitterrand to personally name Serra a Chevalier in l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. (''I was tickled,'' he says. ''I felt like Lancelot.'') How does one explain the cultural differences that lead one country to name an artist a knight and another to dismantle his best-known sculpture and haul it off like a broken-down truck to a motor-vehicle warehouse?
SERRA EXPLAINS IT IN TYPICALLY BLUNT TERMS: ''IN Europe you have a historical continuum of public sculpture that's gone on from Donatello to Rodin and continues today. In the United States, you have just the opposite; the Government has excluded the possibility of any public sculpture that does not reinforce the official ideology of the state.'' He is sitting in the kitchen of his home, an 18th-century white-shingle farmhouse perched on a hill above the Northumberland Strait. His wife, Clara Weyergraf, a patient, soft-spoken German emigre, sits beside him at the table. ''In the United States,'' he continues, ''any sculpture commissioned by the Government that isn't an expression of America's ideals is going to be suppressed or censored.''
Serra is not a man of moderate opinions. He speaks in fast, almost manic bursts, and with a sense of self-righteousness that makes it easy to picture him in his youth -a fiery member of S.D.S. with hair below his shoulders. The counterculture no longer exists, and Serra's hair is now short and gray. But, as much as ever, he's political, implacable and distrustful of authority. Sen. Howard M. (Continued on Page 74) Metzenbaum, a supporter of ''Tilted Arc,'' once advised the artist that people would take him more seriously if he weren't so shrill. That's true. But it's also somehow beside the point. Serra is fond of provocative gestures - but of course he has to be to create the art he does.
Serra came of age at a time when Minimalism was stripping the forms of art to the bone, and the basic traits of his work - simplified forms, super-large scale, industrial materials - derive directly from that movement. Yet while Minimalism began as a reaction against the emotional excesses of Abstract Expressionism, Serra doesn't try to purge emotion from his work. His hulking steel plates seem to suggest that explosive feelings are trapped within their impassive surfaces. He works with the modern material of steel, yet his sculptures possess a primitive rawness.
Serra's work might be described as he-man Minimalism - a combination of pared-down shapes and forceful maneuverings of space. Compared to more traditional sculptures, which are objects we can possess, a Serra sculpture possesses us. More often than not, it is taller than we are and seems designed to force us into an encounter. On first acquaintance, Serra's assemblages of steel plates can seem menacing. Yet if his sculptures slice the air around them like a knife, they also enclose us in safe, tranquil places, or curve around us with graceful solicitude. Virtually all of his sculptures play with our anxieties about inclusion and exclusion, and this is what gives his spare metal forms their unexpected emotional charge.
Serra would agree with none of this. While he readily concedes that he wants the viewer to interact with his sculptures, he can't understand any response other than a newfound appreciation of gravity and space. He tends to rely on the dry, precise language of engineering to describe his work - he can talk for hours about ''compression'' and ''point-load'' and ''the rotation of weight'' - and adamantly denies that his sculptures possess psychological content.
At the suggestion that his work might be ''deeply expressive,'' Serra breaks into stunned laughter. ''You mean I'm a closet expressionist?'' he teases. The laughter quickly subsides and his face resumes its usual tense expression. ''I don't set out to make objects of beauty or sensibility, and I don't set out to make objects for museums. Museums, to me, border on funeral parlors. I'm not saying you can't learn from museums. But my work, to be fulfilled, needs the interaction of people. What I'm trying to do is get sculpture off the pedestal and into the street.''
Does his work address traditional themes like nature and death and transcendence?
''That's a lot of literary claptrap!''
Does his sculpture come out of emotional necessity?
Serra thinks for a few seconds, then replies quietly. ''Out of anger. Anger at the United States Government.''
VIRTUALLY EVERY conversation with Serra starts and ends with ''Tilted Arc.'' He and his wife seem to share an all-consuming sorrow over the sculpture and its short, beleaguered life; they speak of it as if it were a child they lost (they in fact have no children). ''I'm still in mourning,'' Serra says. ''The destruction of my sculpture was like a death, and that's how I took it.''
Where does the story of ''Tilted Arc'' begin? Technically in 1979, when the General Services Administration awarded Serra a $175,000 contract to build a sculpture for the plaza of the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building, at Foley Square in lower Manhattan. But perhaps it begins in 1962, when the culture-conscious Kennedy Administration adopted a resolution requiring the Government to allocate a substantial amount of money - one-half of one percent of the cost of all new Federal buildings - for the purchase of public art. Or perhaps it begins in the 19th century, when equestrian statues and battle monuments proliferated in America, and the public came to believe that outdoor sculpture could somehow serve a civic purpose.
In July 1981, ''Tilted Arc'' -a curving, unadorned wall of steel, 12 feet high and nearly the length of a city block -was installed in Federal Plaza. Unlike the sculptures of the previous century, it didn't try to commemorate valiant deeds or represent grand moral sentiments. Rather it tried to shape the space of the plaza and draw passers-by into an experience whose meaning resided not in symbolic or metaphysical references but solely in the physical elements of which the work was composed.
''Tilted Arc'' looked different depending on one's vantage point. Viewed from above, it formed a graceful, sweeping curve, a Cor-Ten rainbow. Seen head-on, though, it stuck up from the plaza like a shark's dark fin, and its presence disturbed many of the office workers who passed it every day. It was quickly nicknamed ''The Berlin Wall of Foley Square.''
In March 1985, the outcry had reached such a pitch that the G.S.A. called a public hearing to discuss the work's suitability. By then ''Tilted Arc'' had become a cause celebre, and disgruntled workers attending the hearing found themselves pitted against more than 100 prominent citizens (including Joan Mondale, Bess Myerson and Joseph Papp) who testified on the artist's behalf.
Despite the show of support for Serra, the Government decided to move ''Tilted Arc'' to another site. Serra responded in December 1986 with a $30 million lawsuit, arguing that to move the sculpture would be to destroy it. Federal courts dismissed his complaint, as well as his subsequent appeal. Last March, in the middle of the night, construction crews arrived in Federal Plaza to dismantle the sculpture and transport it to a motor-vehicle compound in Brooklyn. (In its new home it takes up eight parking spaces.) ''Tilted Arc'' is gone, yet the issues it symbolized resound as loudly as ever: Is a good sculpture necessarily a good public sculpture? Who's to decide? Does a ''site-specific'' sculpture lose its meaning if it is moved to a new location? If so, how do we explain the enduring appeal of such formerly ''site-specific'' works as the Elgin marbles (which were created for the Parthenon but are now in the British Museum)? Once an artist sells his work, should he have any legal recourse if its owner wants to alter or destroy it? (He would under a legal concept known as le droit moral, or ''moral right,'' which has been accepted in 78 countries.) Or is a sculpture just a piece of property, like a car or a rug, that can be thrown away if its owner so decides?
Serra spent virtually all of his savings - about $200,000 -on his campaign to keep ''Tilted Arc'' standing. ''In this country,'' he says angrily, ''the right of property exceeds all other rights. Art is property, and if you sell your art, you've sold your free speech. We're not very far from seeing Reagan on a bronze horse in our Federal plazas.''
If Serra holds the Government responsible for the ''destruction'' of his sculpture, he is no less embittered toward the The New York Times, which he feels helped turn public opinion against him. (One of the artist's recent works, a drawing, is entitled ''The New York Times Manufactures Censorship.'') In 1985, the newspaper ran an editorial, ''Intrusive Arc,'' that called for the sculpture's removal. ''The Times supported the Government's position,'' Serra says. ''A private individual going up against the power of the Government, the power of the press and the power of dishonesty is in a totally helpless situation.''
He casts his visitor an accusing glance, then admonishes: ''I know I can't say that. I know that line will be axed from the story.''
BORN IN SAN FRAN-cisco in 1939, Serra grew up in a working-class household. His father, Tony, was a Spanish immigrant who earned his living as a foreman in a candy plant. His mother, Gladys, a Russian Jew, kept house and looked after her three sons. Richard, the middle boy, remembers himself as a sensitive youth who felt overshadowed by his athletic older sibling and wondered it he'd ever be known as anything other than ''Tony's little brother.'' But he did have his art. Night after night, Serra would sit at the kitchen table drawing pictures of planes, trains and other boyhood fascinations on large sheets of butcher's paper. It pleased his mother to think of him as an artist. An artist, she used to tell him, can bypass the class system and rise to the highest levels of society. If art held a certain romance for Serra, so did industry. At 18, after completing his freshman year at the University of California at Berkeley, he took a job with U.S. Steel to help pay for his education. ''I worked on a rivet gang,'' Serra recalls with undisguised pride. ''It was a great experience. I liked the scale of it all, the color of it all, the sound of it all.'' Outside the factory, he continued to draw. It didn't occur to him that the boundary separating the ideals of high art from the grit of the steel mills was one he might someday cross.
In 1959, Serra transferred to the University of California at Santa Barbara, where he majored in English literature. (''My mother was this voracious reader,'' he says by way of explanation.) His plan was to earn a master's degree, but a discerning professor - the literary scholar Hugh Kenner - intervened. ''Richard,'' Kenner asked him one day, ''do you really want to take German?'' Serra said no. Kenner suggested he send off his drawings to Yale University and apply for a scholarship to study art.
And so Serra went east. It was a time when Yale's art students were splashing out canvases that owed everything to Abstract Expressionism, and Serra was no exception; he describes his early work as ''a cross between Pollock and de Kooning.'' Yet already he was beginning to experiment with nontraditional art materials, and his irreverence sometimes got him into trouble. One day, in a design course taught by the painter Neil Welliver, students were asked to consider ''spot and dot'' problems. Serra tackled the assignment by running wet cement through a meat grinder. ''Welliver got completely annoyed with me,'' Serra recalls buoyantly, ''and told me he'd pass me on one condition - if I never came back to his class.''
At 25, Serra received his master of fine arts degree and headed off to Europe for an extended jaunt on a Yale Traveling Fellowship. He was accompanied by a fellow Yalie, the sculptor Nancy Graves, whom he married in Paris (''we were trying to appease our landlady,'' Serra says) and divorced a year later. It was during this period that Serra first became serious about sculpture. Afternoons, he often visited the Musee National d'Art Moderne, where he spent long hours admiring the Brancusis and sketching their smooth, simplified shapes. He liked the work of Giacometti, too, and sometimes after midnight would stop by the cafe La Coupole, where he would espy the artist himself, a thin, spindly figure, Serra recalls, ''with plaster stuck in his hair.''
In 1966, Serra finally settled in New York, moving into an old loft building in lower Manhattan. By now he had given up painting and was eager to turn to sculpture, but he wasn't sure exactly where to begin. Around him, everyone else seemed so focused. The Pop artists, with their pictures of soup cans and comic-book girls, had already won a wide public following. The Minimalists, with their steel cubes and flat copper squares, were challenging the hedonism of their Pop counterparts with a grim, reductivist esthetic. ''There was so much going on,'' Serra recalls, ''but I was on the outside. I knew I had to protect myself somehow, and I did it by isolating myself in my studio.'' To support himself, he bought a truck and started a company called Low-Rate Moving.
One of the more radical developments of the 60's avant-garde was a movement known as Process Art, and this was the backdrop against which Serra first established himself. His earliest sculptures were made from rubber scraps; they had a raw, unfinished look, and they didn't try to represent anything other than the ''process'' - or the manual procedures - that had brought them into being. From there he went on to challenge the status of art as a saleable commodity in a series of works that bordered on performance.
The stories by now are classics. He splashed molten lead against a wall in the Whitney Museum. He filled up the Pasadena Museum in California with redwood logs. His ''prop'' pieces - soft-lead plates that leaned precariously against one another, the floor or a wall - threatened imminent collapse. Serra's early work was conceived as a series of provocations, yet there's nothing the art establishment likes so much as a bold assault on its values. By 1969 the young rebel was regularly showing his works at the Leo Castelli Gallery and receiving a regular gallery stipend of $500 a month.
Around 1970, Serra shifted his activities out of doors and became a pioneer of site-specific sculpture. Commissions took him all over the world. There was ''Shift'' (1970-72), six walls of concrete that zigzag across a grassy hillside in King City, Ontario. There was ''Spin Out'' (1972-73), a trio of steel plates that face one another like wary strangers on the grounds of the Rijksmuseum Kroller-Muller in Otterloo, Holland. There was ''Terminal'' (1977), four 41-foot-tall trapezoids that form a kind of collapsing tower in the middle of a traffic circle in Bochum, West Germany. And, unforgettably, there was ''Clara-Clara'' (1983), a surprisingly anthropomorphic work composed of two curving walls set back-to-back, like reclining figures, outside the entrance to the Tuileries in Paris. Since the early 70's, Serra has completed about 60 commissions, most of them funded by European patrons.
Serra has created only seven sculptures for public sites in the United States; they've met with varying reactions. ''Carnegie'' (1984-85), a 39-foot-high vertical shaft outside the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh, has received high praise. Yet opposition to ''Twain'' (1982), eight steel plates that form a kind of triangular corral in downtown St. Louis, has been mounting in the wake of ''Tilted Arc''; city officials have censured the work as a waste of property and considered calling a referendum on whether to remove it. And, at Yale University, a group of art history professors distressed about a recently commissioned Serra sculpture (it would displace medieval and Renaissance statuary in the school's Sculpture Hall), drafted a letter to the director of the university gallery asking that the commission be rescinded.
''Because of 'Tilted Arc,' Serra says, ''my reputation in America has been seriously damaged. People come to my work with a built-in prejudice, with the idea that it's alright to censor or destroy it since that's what the U.S. Government did.'' Asked what projects he's working on now, Serra produces a sheet of paper with 14 cities listed - all but two (New Haven and Des Moines) are outside the United States. ''There's a higher respect for art in Europe,'' he says.''Unlike Americans, Europeans don't define culture in terms of the box office, in terms of what sells, what's popular.''
Serra's image as a creator of willfully menacing art has been further distorted by two tragic accidents. In November 1971, a laborer installing a Serra sculpture at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis was crushed to death when a two-ton steel plate toppled over on him. A subsequent lawsuit absolved the artist and museum of blame. Last October, a worker lost a leg while dismantling a 16-ton Serra sculpture at the Castelli Gallery. A lawsuit is pending.
''The first accident was devastating,'' Serra says. ''It shook me to the bone and made me question the whole activity of building. I couldn't work for a year. The second accident, I knew the person, a young man with two children . . . '' Serra is not the only sculptor in recent times whose work has been linked to fatal accidents (Alexander Calder and Beverly Pepper are two others), yet he is the only one to read about his misfortunes on the front page of newspaper tabloids. ''The accidents,'' he says dejectedly, ''have led people to read meanings into my work that simply aren't there.''
Serra usually begins a sculpture by making a small maquette (or model) from flat plates of steel. He then consults a structural engineer, who specifies how the piece should be made to retain its balance and stability. He purchases his materials from Lukens Steel Company, in Coatesville, Pa., and the sculpture is fabricated by a nearby shipbuilding company. When the works are finished, Serra pays a visit to the factory. (''I go to stand the sculptures up,'' he says.) His indoor sculptures are made from hot-rolled steel; his outdoor sculptures, from Cor-Ten steel, which has been the primary building material for turnpikes, bridges and industrial buildings since World War II.
Cor-Ten steel was designed to acquire a dark, even patina of rust over time, and this natural process endows Serra's sculptures with a handsome brown hue. The rust can function metaphorically, too, reminding the viewer of his own inevitable decay. When I share this idea with Serra, he is predictably displeased. ''I don't go into the studio to ruminate on death. I go into the studio to build.''
IT IS NOT UNUSUAL for American artists and writers to think of themselves as anti-intellectual. Jackson Pollock, for instance, dressed in old jeans and muddy boots and affirmed that American art must be unrefined. Jack Kerouac, too: he had an almost naive faith in the value of his own experience. Serra belongs to this romantic tradition. Nearly everything about him - from his battered blue truck to his bellicose manner to his fascination with steel - can be seen as a consciously cultivated roughness. Although deeply knowledgeable about European art, he is reluctant to acknowledge its influence on him. Asked about the artists who have shaped his work, Serra jumps up and fetches a book on the bridge-builder Robert Maillart: ''People like this are much more interesting to me than Picasso and Brancusi,'' he says.
For Serra, the American artist is a kind of primitive who comes out of nowhere and shocks the world with the rawness of his vision. This may be the reason that Europeans are in love with his work; they're in love with the image of America as a country of wild men. Serra's towering assemblies of steel confirm, for them, the essential qualities of the American character: bluntness, forcefulness and a lack of artifice.
In America, meanwhile, where the public wants its art to be optimistic and friendly, Serra's sculptures make people angry. This in itself is a kind of achievement. At a time when the art world is awash in money, it's nearly impossible for artists to challenge established tastes and values. Yet Serra's work does.
One night, as we're sitting at his kitchen table, I ask whether he sees himself as a provocateur. Serra looks startled by the question. He puts down his coffee and answers slowly, a bit painfully, ''I'm not looking for political arguments. I'm looking to do the best work I can.''
Yet, an hour later, when I get up to leave, he can't resist one final defiant gesture. He hands me a folded sheet of gray paper. When I return to my hotel, I open it up and see that he's scrawled a message in pencil: ''The only freedom an artist has is not to deal with the United States Government.''

PUB-DATE: October 8, 1989

HEADLINE: LECH'S AMERICAN ANGEL

BYLINE: By David Margolick; David Margolick is a New York Times reporter who covers legal affairs. This article is adapted from his book on the contest over the will of J. Seward Johnson Sr., the pharmaceutical heir, to be published next year by William Morrow & Co.

 BODY:
IT WAS A PERFECT PLACE FOR AN EPIPHANY. THE SCENE WAS near St. Brygida's Church in Gdansk, the spiritual home of Poland's Solidarity movement. The date was May 25, 1989, the occasion the annual Corpus Christi procession. Among those leading the 25,000 marchers were Lech Walesa and Barbara Piasecka Johnson, the Polish-born American woman who inherited much of the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune.
As is so often the case in Poland, religion and politics merged as the marchers made their way from the Marianska Basilica to the square outside St. Brygida's. Mr. Walesa began describing to Mrs. Johnson, who left her homeland in 1968, the precarious state of the Lenin Shipyard, where, nine years ago, Solidarity was born. In October 1988, the Communist authorities announced plans to shut down the unprofitable facility. The Government said its motives were strictly economic; Solidarity officials insisted they were political. But by now that almost didn't matter: unless someone came along to rescue it, and soon, Mr. Walesa said, 10,000 jobs and the very cradle of Solidarity would be lost. He placed the cost of such a rescue at somewhere between $70 million and $100 million. 
Those kinds of numbers did not faze the 52-year-old Mrs. Johnson. At roughly $300 million, her wealth is impressive enough in dollars; were it converted to zlotys - on the black market, the way everyone in Poland changes money, or even at the lower official rate - she would become a multi-trillionaire. ''I will help,'' she told Mr. Walesa without missing a beat. ''I'm taking it.''
At first, the Solidarity leader didn't think Mrs. Johnson could possibly be serious. But within hours, an exultant Mr. Walesa, along with shipyard officials and Mrs. Johnson, had signed an in-formal, handwritten letter of intent. ''He was so excited, he started to hug and kiss me,'' Mrs. Johnson recalled. ''He said: 'You've set an example for how to make Poland economically strong. I've met presidents, kings, queens, heads of state - the most important people in the world, but never someone as wonderful as you. From now on, when I see the world I want to have you always at my side.' He repeated and repeated and repeated that.''
Last June 1, on behalf of a new entity called the Barbara Piasecka Johnson-Gdansk Shipyard Company, Mrs. Johnson signed a three-page, typewritten document. In it, she declared her readiness to spend up to $100 million - though the actual cash outlay could be much lower - for a 55 percent interest in the yard, ''subject to the organization's books and cash flow being in shape,'' and with the Polish Government guaranteeing her investment in the event of nationalization or expropriation. In a country so desperate for hard currency that it still shakes down Western visitors for $15 a day, Mrs. Johnson was brandishing a fortune. Indeed, with the stroke of a pen, she had conceivably committed almost as much money to the beleaguered Polish economy as President Bush would in his initial proposal, a few weeks later, on behalf of the entire American Government.
Within days of the initial agreement, a swarm of consultants, lawyers and accountants, all on Johnson's payroll, descended on the sprawling yard. There, they worked through the summer and into the fall, attempting to nail down the privatization of the premises. The transaction is still not complete; under the terms of the letter of intent, the negotiators have until Dec. 31 to complete their discussions. But Mrs. Johnson says they are proceeding ''perfectly'' and she hopes to conclude the deal ahead of schedule.
By any standard, Polish hotels are to tourism what Polish suits are to fashion: threadbare, grim, utilitarian. Nonetheless, in the last few months, Mrs. Johnson has exchanged her usual haunts - the Ritz in Paris, the Connaught in London, Jasna Polana, her $30 million estate in Princeton, N.J. - for a spartan suite in Gdansk's Hotel Hevelius, a place more accustomed to serving West German tourists and East Bloc businessmen than American heiresses. Here she now spends much of her time, like some 19th-century New England textile magnate, overlooking her domain: the vast shipyard complex, dominated by mammoth, genuflecting cranes, framed by the steeples of German Danzig and the belching smokestacks of Stalin and Gomulka.
Twelve hours a day or more she devotes to the deal, much of it at the shipyard offices, questioning, listening, negotiating, inspecting, learning, translating. ''It isn't as if she's just plopping down a lot of money,'' said Mrs. Johnson's lawyer, James D. Whisenand of Miami. ''For a woman who doesn't have to do this, she's working very hard.''
THEY'VE BEEN BUILDING SHIPS IN GDANSK for over 400 years; it was in this Baltic port city that the Kaiser constructed his cruisers and Hitler built his U-Boats. But since 1970, when 28 workers were killed during food riots nearby, the Lenin shipyard - renamed for the Russian leader in 1968, according to Mr. Walesa, in an attempt by the Polish superintendent to endear himself to the Communist authorities - has also been something of a shrine, marked by the three towering steel crosses at its gates. ''No one ought to pass this with indifference,'' reads an inscription near the site of the massacre.
In 1980, when Mr. Walesa, then an electrician in the yard, jumped over its gates and began the strike that launched Solidarity, the shipyard became another, prouder symbol. And in the 1990's, if the virulently anti-Communist Mrs. Johnson has her way, it will symbolize something else again: the rejuvenation, through Western capital and know-how, of Poland's economy and work force, both sluggish and demoralized after four decades of Communism. As important as the privatization could be in its own right, it would occur against the backdrop of similar but more cataclysmic changes now under way in Poland.
Mrs. Johnson stresses that for her the deal constitutes investment rather than charity for Poles. ''I believe in these people,'' says Mrs. Johnson. ''For 50 years, they haven't had a chance to show how great they really are.'' Her message, she says, is also for Americans, who have forgotten what Poles did for Americans in the Revolutionary War and what America did to Poland at Yalta. The plan to privatize the shipyard, says Walesa, is at ''the heart of the Polish reform - a model for other industries.'' The name Piasecka Johnson, he suggests, says it all: a joint venture between Poles and Americans.
For a decade or more, European shipbuilding has been in the doldrums, the result of overcapacity and of Japanese and Korean competition. But suddenly, ships built back in the 1960's, particularly tankers, are wearing out, and with many yards in mothballs, there's a shortage of berths and skilled labor for building replacements. ''A year ago, no one would have given you two pence halfpenny for a shipyard,'' says Martin Stopford, senior shipping economist with the London branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''But now, there is a new wind blowing through the shipbuilding industry. As businesses go, Mrs. Johnson is probably buying into the bottom of a cycle.'' Indeed, other parties, including Germans and Norwegians, have expressed some interest in parts of the yard, and because the letter of intent is non-exclusive, Mrs. Johnson could theoretically be outbid.
The very notion of an American woman, with little experience in boats aside from her late husband's pleasure crafts, going behind the Iron Curtain to become a shipbuilding magnate reveals much of what Barbara Piasecka Johnson, who (Continued on Page 64) is called Basia, is: impulsive, emotional, dramatic, patriotic, restless, romantic, even messianic. Three years after she inherited her late husband's fortune, a fortune she secured only after a bitter court battle with her six stepchildren that cost her $20 million in legal fees, she is still a woman in search of a mission. Just as surely, she is someone who, highly sensitive about being perceived as a gold-digger, craves respect as an educated woman and art connoisseur - respect she feels she has never gotten in the United States.
At first blush, the Basia Johnson story is the American dream come true. A pretty, ambitious woman leaves Poland at the age of 31 with $200 and an art degree to her name, finds work as a maid in the home of one of the nation's most wealthy men - J. Seward Johnson Sr., son of the founder of Johnson & Johnson - and, within three years marries him, though he is 42 years her senior. They remain together for 12 years, until his death from cancer. His last will, read a few days after his funeral, leaves her virtually everything.
But Mrs. Johnson, a radiant blonde with a broad smile and buoyancy who looks and acts younger than her years, has never thought of herself as a Cinderella. She bristles at frequent press references to her as a ''former chambermaid'' and sees nothing charming or magical in her tale. To her, it was somehow all ordained. Moreover, as far as she is concerned, hers is a story without a happy ending - at least not yet. Her two decades in the United States have been turbulent, a time of constant projects, court battles and ever-changing interests, associates, employees, friends.
True, she emerged from Manhattan Surrogate's Court in June 1986 as one of the world's wealthiest women. True, too, her stepchildren, who charged that she had charmed, bamboozled and bullied their increasingly enfeebled father into disinheriting them, largely failed to prove their case, though they picked up $42 million for their trouble. Still, the highly publicized 17-week-long trial left Basia Johnson bruised and battered, tagged with an image of extravagance, eccentricity, ego and abusiveness. A host of disgruntled former employees rounded up by lawyers for the Johnson children told damaging tales about her: of her tirades, her lavish expenditures on art, furniture, or indulgences, such as an air-conditioned doghouse with a kitchenette and custom-made mattresses. Those Americans who recognize her name are likely to conjure images of her screaming at a maid, flashing a V-for-victory sign at 15 employees from her estate who disrupted the trial to demonstrate on her behalf (and at her behest, despite her protestations to the contrary), or spending $25,000 on two antique cushions.
''My American hell,'' as she sometimes calls the whole bloodying experience, has left Basia Johnson feeling embittered toward her adopted land and disinclined to launch any major charitable initiatives here. At times, she has talked of abandoning the United States altogether, presumably for some more sympathetic European locale. She has already gone into a kind of philanthropic exile, financing schools, hospitals and shelters throughout Poland. But, in scope, ambition or worldwide reaction, none of this compares to the shipyard project. If in America Mrs. Johnson will always be a maid, in Poland she has instantly become a queen. Priests pay her homage, high government and Solidarity officials kiss her hand, women bring her flowers, surround her limousine, clamor for her autograph, chanting ''Pani Johnson! Pani Johnson!'' - or Lady Johnson -whenever she passes. Last month, she met with Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the new Polish Prime Minister, who, she said, told her that all of Poland thanked her for saving the symbol of Solidarity.
Though most of the shipyard workers have never seen her - at the souvenir stand outside the gate, photographs of her (large and wallet-size) are still outsold by pictures of Mr. Walesa with President Bush and Margaret Thatcher - they, too, sing her praises. ''She will improve the organization and quality of work,'' said one. ''The technology we have right now is the hammer, the chisel, the torch,'' another commented. ''Pani Basia will make our work easier.'' ''She's very feminine and all the men like her,'' said Alojzy Szablewski, Solidarity's chairman in the yard. ''They would go to battle for her.''
Mrs. Johnson has certainly won the undying gratitude of Mr. Walesa. Judging from the good-natured, almost flirtatious banter between the two, they have become fast friends. ''What's a frail woman like you doing in a shipyard with cranes and rusting metal?'' Walesa asked Johnson recently, over the phone from his office. ''You belong in a garden of flowers or in a coffeeshop, with me.''
Not surprisingly, Mr. Walesa is besieged by the press these days, and is visibly bored by most of the questions he's asked. But when the subject turns to Barbara Johnson, he suddenly grows animated and voluble. ''I didn't think she'd be so first-rate, with such personal charm and courage,'' he says. ''I thought that with all her money, she would walk around on the street with a lot of cats and dogs and men carrying her bags after her. Instead, I found a simple, pretty girl - quiet, composed, unpretentious, and at the same time quite great. In brief: grand in her simplicity.''
''I like Pani Basia as a woman, not only for her money,'' he continues, almost impishly. ''I like to kiss her and I am quite happy that she still lets me. And I'm quite interested to see how long she lets me.'' The interpreter cautions Mr. Walesa, happily married and the father of eight, that his remarks may appear in print. ''That's all right,'' he replies. ''My wife doesn't speak English.''
Amid the general euphoria, there are some caveats about the proposed purchase. Some think the shipyard, beset by declining orders, increased competition, outdated equipment and deep-seated labor troubles is beyond salvation. One worker poses a question to a reporter, then answers it: ''You know what I really think about the shipyard? That this is one great, if you will excuse me, burdel'' - or whorehouse. Actually, to a visitor, another Polish word comes to mind: balagan, or mess. The Lenin complex resembles a huge and crumbling city, a rusty, dusty network of pipes and sheds, Victorian brick buildings and trolley tracks. One sees just about everything here but ships, save for a few scattered hulks.
So debris-strewn is the entire 340-acre compound that it is almost impossible to envision anything shiny ever emerging from it. In fact, production here has slipped from 27 ships in 1979 to only 14 scheduled for this year. In the last 15 years, the work force has dropped, through layoffs and attrition, from 16,500 to 10,200.
It was perhaps inevitable that Mrs. Johnson's initiative would be compared to placing Band-Aids on a hemorrhage. ''Maybe she wants to be in the Guinness book as the investor who's lost the most money,'' our Polish driver says grumpily. ''If she really wants to help, let her get into shoe or meat business.''
Other skeptics, noting the inherent conflict between labor and capital, predict that sooner or later the interests of Mrs. Johnson and Solidarity will collide. That tension was hinted at in a recent headline in Gazeta Wyborcza, the Solidarity daily newspaper: ''Pani Johnson Doesn't Like Strikes.''
Mrs. Johnson also has her skeptics in America. They note her mercurial nature, her penchant for adopting causes suddenly and fervently, only to abandon them just as quickly out of pique or lack of interest.
Still, this undertaking seems different. This time, she has brought in an entourage of experts - accountants from Arthur Andersen & Co., maritime consultants from London's A. & P. Appledore Ltd. This time, she has already displayed a proprietary attitude toward the place; in August, for instance, she asked five United States Senators visiting Gdansk whether they had seen ''her'' shipyard. She takes frequent walking tours around it, wearing a helmet emblazened with her name and Solidarity's distinctive logo, giving pep talks to workers.
This time, what was undertaken emotionally may even make sense economically, as a shrunken shipbuilding industry tries to meet growing worldwide demand for new vessels. Her advisers insist that the decrepitude of the yard has been exaggerated. ''It's not some rusted-out old hulk,'' said John Peach, Mrs. Johnson's aide. ''The slipways, the main cranes, are in good shape.''
Already, Mrs. Johnson's advisers say, they are receiving inquiries from customers. Perhaps most important, this time, an entire nation - her homeland - will be watching everything she does.
''She should be admired as a very brave woman who took a great burden on her shoulders,'' said the Rev. Henryk Jankowski, the pastor of St. Brygida's and the matchmaker who brought Mrs. Johnson and Mr. Walesa together. ''She did it above all for Poland, to help out the economic situation. Not everyone has the courage she has. God is helping her. Obviously, God wanted it this way.''
Mrs. Johnson does not quarrel with that. ''I'm fortunate to be in a position to do this,'' she says. ''Somebody had to be brave. I'm very grateful to God that He chose me to do these things.''
TECHNICALLY, THE principal issue in the will contest was J. Seward Johnson's mental competence on the day he signed his last will. The lawyers representing the Johnson children, from the New York firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, might very well have proved that Mr. Johnson was too ill on April 14, 1983, to realize what he was doing. But the Milbank lawyers faced additional hurdles: there were 12 years' worth of prior wills in which a far healthier Mr. Johnson had left as much to his wife as he could under the existing tax laws. The children's only real option was to make things so miserable for their stepmother that she would pay them to go away.
With the fortune their father had already bestowed upon them - trust funds collectively worth nearly $400 million - they pawed over her past. The investigation, conducted by Milbank operatives, came complete with private eyes - who traveled to Wroclaw, Warsaw, Cracow and Rome - code names, couriers and secret Swedish rendezvous.
Their efforts came to naught. They found none of the spurious degrees, former husbands or other assorted scandals they had hoped for. The rags-to-riches saga so intriguing to everyone but Basia Johnson herself remained largely intact.
Barbara Piasecka was born on Feb. 25, 1937, in Staniewicze, a village in what was then the northeastern portion of Poland. She was the fourth child and only daughter of a poor farming couple. (Mrs. Johnson, who once boasted of her common origins, has more recently come to speak of an aristocratic lineage.) Among her first sensations were fear and flight; she was 2 when the Germans and Russians marched into Poland and divvied it up. The Piaseckis fled west, toward Warsaw, where they spent the rest of the war. They then moved to Poznan, and when their farm there was confiscated by the Communists, moved on once more, to Wroclaw.
At Boleslaw Bierut University, in Wroclaw, Basia took courses in art history, studies she continued at the Jagiellonian University in Cracow, where she earned her master's degree. In 1968, she left Poland, first for Rome, then America. Friends arranged for her to be interviewed at the Oldwick, N.J., home of Mr. and Mrs. J. Seward Johnson Sr., where Edith, the cook, had just quit. Mr. Johnson, 73 at the time, was Johnson & Johnson's largest individual stockholder but held only a ceremonial post at the company; by all accounts he was far more interested in sailing, farming, oceanography and women than in sutures or suppositories. (His elder brother, Gen. Robert Wood Johnson, had controlled the company, and, in many ways, Seward as well. On his death in 1968 - shortly before Basia arrived from Poland - the elder Johnson left virtually all of his multimillion-dollar inheritance to a foundation bearing his name. The foundation has since become famous for its support of medical research, while Seward Johnson's principal legacy so far has been to enrich lawyers.) After a brief interview, the second Mrs. J. Seward Johnson hired the third. Miss Piasecka tried her hand in the kitchen, poring over recipe books in a language she could not yet understand. Several mishaps later, on the brink of dismissal, she was rescued by a kindly upstairs maid, who agreed to change jobs with her.
A young Basia once told her friends that when she returned to Poland, it would be in a Rolls-Royce. That proved prophetic. In the fall of 1969, shortly after she had left the Johnsons' employ to attend New York University, Mr. Johnson, whose 32-year marriage to Esther Underwood Johnson had long since soured, summoned her to his New Brunswick, N.J., office. As she later recalled, he told her how much he admired her industry, which reminded him of the American pioneers, and asked her to work for him, assembling the art collection he had always wanted and helping him conduct oceanographic research. She agreed. Soon the two were romantically involved, and in 1971 he divorced his wife to marry her. None of his children was invited to the wedding.
Over the next 12 years, the Johnsons traveled widely, built or bought homes in Italy, Poland and the Bahamas as well as in Princeton, and assembled a large collection of art and furniture, built around Basia Johnson's ephemeral tastes. At first, she favored more recent works, but over time the Van Goghs and Picassos, Monets and Modiglianis gave way to Renaissance and Baroque works by such painters as Caravaggio, Montagna and Raphael -this even though Mrs. Johnson has never been particularly religious. ''In the past half-century, many private collections of Old Masters have been dispersed, but very few have been assembled, and none has been so large and so wide-ranging as that of Mrs. Johnson,'' the art historian John Pope-Hennessy wrote in a catalogue for an exhibition of her collection, organized by her close friend, the film maker Franco Zefferelli, to open in Warsaw next spring.
As cosmopolitan as she became, Mrs. Johnson always retained her ties to Poland. Replicating original works in Warsaw, Cracow, Gdansk and Gniezno, Polish craftsmen fabricated and installed the cast-iron gates, grillwork and lanterns at Jasna Polana. (The name, which means bright meadow, or glade, in Polish, is the same as that of Tolstoy's Russian estate, Yasnaya Polyana, but Mrs. Johnson insists it is her creation.) Mr. Johnson purchased a Polish fishing trawler and had workmen in Szczecin convert it into a pleasure boat, and dubbed it Mazurka - an experience she points to as evidence of her shipbuilding expertise. The couple sponsored the 1975 Chopin Piano Competition in Warsaw and befriended the late Witold Malcuzynski, a prominent Polish emigre pianist. She supported the New York-based Nowy Dziennik, the daily newspaper of the Polish-American community, which may account for the scant space it devoted to her legal travails. She continues to award grants to young Polish artists, and has become a kind of Polish-American John Beresford Tipton, television's ''Millionaire,'' impulsively handing out large sums of money to various countrymen down on their luck. In American Polonia, she is the philanthropist of first, last and, often, only resort. ''Why don't you do what everyone else does and call Mrs. Johnson?'' an official of the Kosciuszko Foundation told one recent grant-seeker.
Even by Polish standards, Mrs. Johnson is fiercely anti-Communist, a woman who once condemned compatriots like Zbigniew Brzezinski and John Cardinal Krol of Philadelphia for shaking hands with Wojciech Jaruzelski. She is a dedicated supporter of Solidarity: a marble plaque inscribed with slogans from the movement is to be installed in the chapel now under construction at Jasna Polana, the one atop the bomb shelter equipped with periscopes. After martial law was declared in Poland in 1981, the Johnsons sent $1 million for humanitarian relief; recently, she pledged another $1 million, primarily to improve health and day-care services. There were other, more covert, contributions to Polish causes, like the $250,000 in cash she is said to have stuffed into a Louis Vuitton carrying case and smuggled into Europe and handed over to Ginetta Sagan, one of the founders of Amnesty International.
Still, Basia Johnson occupies an uncertain place in the Polish emigre community. Only once has she attended the annual Bal Polanaise, the premiere social event of New York's Polish elite. She was to have been the guest of honor at a similar event held two years ago by Nowy Dziennik, but failed to show up. Her attempt to buttress the troubled Biblioteka Polska in Paris, the venerable institute that Chopin and Mickiewicz once frequented, was rebuffed when library officials accused her of trying to take over the place. She also withdrew her support for the Institute for Polish-Jewish Studies, in Oxford, England - a group she helped start - when one of its top officials wrote an article on Polish anti-Semitism that she considered unduly harsh.
Mrs. Johnson also embraced the idea of an institute on Central and Eastern European studies, first proposed in 1985 by Czeslaw Milosz, the Polish-American poet, and spoke about it with several leading scholars, including Alexander Schenker of Yale and Wiktor Weintraub and Stanislaw Baranczak of Harvard. But the project, to which she had talked of donating as much as $100 million, was delayed by the will contest, then abandoned altogether. Since then, she has not endowed a proposed Barbara Johnson Chair in Polish history at Yale, nor did she help that school purchase and catalogue its archives of Mr. Milosz and Aleksander Wat, the late Polish-Jewish writer.
Over the years, Basia Johnson has picked or perpetuated countless fights with charities, contractors, employees and, especially, lawyers. During the will contest, for instance, she repeatedly feuded with Sullivan & Cromwell, the New York firm representing her, prompting one exasperated lawyer to quit the case. Afterward, she sued Shearman & Sterling, the Wall Street firm that did Mr. Johnson's estate work, for malpractice - the first such suit in Shearman's more than 100-year history. Among others, the suit named Nina S. Zagat, the Shearman lawyer who supervised Mr. Johnson's last will and who, for many years, was as close to a friend as anyone Basia Johnson had. The malpractice suit ultimately failed, but not before Mrs. Johnson dragged herself to the dreary Manhat-(Continued on Page 70) tan courtroom of Surrogate Marie M. Lambert for two more months - and paid millions more in legal fees for the privilege. What accounts for this contentiousness? Partly it's that Mrs. Johnson is a perfectionist, a quality she repeatedly demonstrated in her meticulous care for her dying husband. It is paranoia - the fear, common, perhaps, to those who win lotteries of any kind, that everyone is out to exploit her. It is her imperious nature, which demands subservience, even servility, from those who work for her. It is also justifiable anger over shoddy work, like the poor job Sullivan & Cromwell did defending her; given a case that was all but impossible to lose, the firm very nearly did.
For Basia Johnson, disputes often become matters of high principle, and consume an inordinate amount of her time, money and passion. Amid all her frustrations, she has periodically retreated to Jasna Polana, the estate she shares with her servants and her dogs. She has told friends that though her first marriage was for love, her next will be for money; whether or not that was said facetiously, no man ever seems to have replaced Seward Johnson in her affections. From time to time, she appears amidst the glitterati. ''The competing interest earlier in the day . . . had been 'What will Basia Johnson wear next?' '' Barbara Lazear Ascher wrote in European Travel & Life last year, in an article about a fund-raiser in Venice. ''It was hard to see, because the widow of John Seward Johnson traveled with an entourage consisting of her English decorator-cum-art adviser and a bevy of hungry young men snapping at her heels like Venetian puppies.''
But Basia Johnson seems to squirm in the bold face of the gossip columns. She thinks that world trivial, and herself, conversely, destined for far greater things.
FATHER JANKOWSKI OF ST. Brygida's knows many Americans - the gallery at the Gdansk rectory includes a photograph of the Kennedy brothers. But before coming to the United States last spring, he had never heard of Basia Johnson. Nor, surprisingly, had many other Poles; the state-controlled press had made little mention of her over the years, perhaps fearful of publicizing one of its wealthiest -and, therefore, most dangerous -critics. Another priest suggested that Father Jankowski visit Mrs. Johnson in Princeton, and it was during that visit that he invited her to Gdansk.
On a Sunday two days after the signing ceremony, as she sat next to Mr. Walesa at the front of St. Brygida's, Father Jankowski praised Mrs. Johnson from the pulpit. When he introduced her she came forward, to tumultuous applause, bowed her head slightly, and smiled, almost shyly. Fists shot into the air and several women began to cry. So did Mrs. Johnson.
Three months later, Mrs. Johnson's enthusiasm had not waned, as was apparent one afternoon as she and Mr. Walesa posed for photographs in front of the shipyard gates. Like some couple in a comic opera, they ran through a gamut of exaggerated gestures and emotions. Mr. Walesa cautioned those present not to eavesdrop on their banter, and she smiled broadly, like a woman who felt perfectly protected and content.
And perhaps she is. For whatever Basia Johnson ends up paying for her piece of the shipyard, she will presumably have plenty left over. She'll also, perhaps, have some of the things that have eluded her up to now: respect, peace, and maybe, even, some happiness.

LENGTH: 626 words

HEADLINE: Beauty;
UPS AND DOWNS

BYLINE: By Linda Wells

 BODY:
MISS AMERICA CONTESTANTS wear them with bathing suits. Playboy Playmates wear them with little else. The Rockettes kick up a storm in them. And Barbie's slender plastic feet are permanently poised to be slipped into them. They, of course, are high heels: instruments of torture, symbols of sexuality and fodder for fetishists.
Meanwhile, a number of American designers - Calvin Klein, Donna Karan and Isaac Mizrahi, for instance - paired flat shoes with skirts in their fall shows. ''With a really short skirt, a flat shoe, like a brogue, can look frumpy,'' says Mr. Mizrahi. ''But elf shoes or velvet slippers with the same color hose -I love that.'' A collective sigh was released by women who value comfort. Teetering around city streets and offices on sharp, stratospheric heels is a challenge for all but the most adroit. 
Podiatrists and orthopedists are probably cheering, too. In a national survey conducted by the Gallup Organization for the American Podiatric Medical Association, 37 percent of those polled said they walked around in high heels despite the discomfort. ''Wearing high heels will certainly aggravate back problems,'' says Dr. John F. Waller, chief of foot and ankle services at Mount Sinai Hospital, in New York. ''They put the foot and the body at a disadvantage.''
But high heels have their fans, among them the female population of Paris. Despite all the musings on the secrets of French style, it can be pinned on a predilection for precariously high heels. Manolo Blahnik, the shoe designer who has stores in London and New York, is vigorously promoting high heels. ''Elegant women prefer them,'' he says. ''In London, I've been selling more high heels than ever.''
Comfort aside, high heels are an alluring piece of fashion. They ''may well be the most potent aphrodisiac ever concocted,'' writes Dr. William A. Rossi in the Journal of the American Podiatry Association. ''When worn by women, the high heel sensuously alters the whole anatomy.'' The leggy Rockettes almost always dance in heels. ''They change a dancer's balance and help push her forward,'' says Bruce Michael, senior producer of the Rockettes. And beauty contestants seem to have them welded to their feet. ''The basic standard pump with a three-inch heel makes the leg look most attractive,'' says Rex M. Holt, the co-producer of the Miss Texas U.S.A. and Miss California U.S.A. pageants. But Mr. Holt abolished high heels from his pageant's swimsuit competition this year. ''Who wears high heels with a bathing suit?'' he asks. ''It was the phoniest part of the competition.''
Instead, the contestants go barefoot, padding down the runway on tiptoes to give their legs a long, tight look.
Those women who want to wear flat shoes and are not willing to mince around on their toes may turn to exercise. Stretching the calf muscles helps to elongate them. To strengthen the calf, balance the ball of one foot on the edge of a step.
Holding a weight in one hand, slowly lower and raise the heel.
''Everyone ignores calf exercises, but they can shape the muscle,'' says Toni McGinley, director of exercise testing at the Plus One Fitness Clinic in New York.
Board-flat shoes can be just as detrimental as high heels, because they put stress on the back of the legs, says Dr. Waller: ''All shoes, even men's shoes, should have some heel. One-and-a-half- to one-and-three-quarter-inch heels are best for most women. If you're going to wear high heels, it's a good idea to switch to low heels from time to time, to keep the muscles flexible.''
Clearly, high heels do more to flatter the legs than flats do, mostly because they make the legs look fit and shapely. Then again, ''if you have wonderful legs, the heels don't matter,'' says Mr. Blahnik.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 8, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 34, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 2942 words

HEADLINE: The Baby Bomb

BYLINE: By Carin Rubenstein; Carin Rubenstein is a freelance writer in North Tarrytown, N.Y.

 BODY:
SINCE HER DAUGHTER, CARMEN, was born, Jasmine Gazzarato of Royal Oak, Mich., says she has taken on three jobs. She works full time developing training programs for the Ford Motor Company and the United Automobile Workers, takes care of her daughter and caters to her husband, Melvin Winkler.
Although they had their baby relatively late in life - she is 38 and he is 39 - and had grown accustomed to sharing household chores equally, they slipped into what Ms. Gazzarato calls ''the old roles'' after becoming parents two years ago. ''Even if he is around,'' she says, ''the baby is my job.'' She also does ''pretty much everything around the house.'' As a result, she and her husband argue more often than they used to. They argue about what to do in their valuable free time, how much money they should be saving and even whether they should swear in front of the baby.
For his part, Mr. Winkler believes he does as much as he can, given that he puts in almost 60 hours a week in the art department at Oakland Community College in Auburn Hills, Mich. ''My time off is with the baby,'' he says. ''A lot of husbands are golfing, sailing or sitting around watching baseball.'' If his wife complains about how little he helps out, he says, ''I shrug it off.'' 
More people became parents for the first time in 1987, the last year for which figures are available, than in any other year in United States history, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. Like Ms. Gazzarato and Mr. Winkler, many first-time parents discover that the birth of a baby has the impact of a bomb, the first salvo in an ever-intensifying marital battle. Most new parents are prepared for some inconveniences - they expect their social lives to be restricted, for example, and to get less sleep. But many find that the difficulties they experience are much greater and more enduring than they had anticipated.
Two major research projects - one in California and the other in Pennsylvania - have documented in greater depth than ever before the astonishingly stressful social and emotional consequences of parenthood. The studies revealed that for about half of the couples who participated, marital satisfaction declined after the birth of a first child. The researchers also found that postponing parenthood makes no difference in the ease or difficulty of the transition and that after having a child, husband and wife tend to take on traditional gender-specific roles - even if both spouses work outside the home.
The new findings on parenthood are based on data from studies in which researchers recruited couples during pregnancy and studied them both before and after the birth of their first child. Previous studies on parenthood were conducted by a less reliable method that involved asking parents to recall any problems they had had after their first child was born, sometimes as long as 10 years earlier.
Philip A. Cowan, a professor of psychology, and Carolyn Pape Cowan, a research psychologist, both at the University of California at Berkeley, began their transition-to-parenthood study in 1979. They followed 96 couples in northern California, 72 of whom were expecting their first child, for six years. The Cowans became interested in the topic after they themselves experienced great distress upon becoming parents - as Carolyn Cowan puts it, she and her husband discovered ''how really thrown we were by what it had done to us as a couple.'' Jay Belsky, a professor of human development at Pennsylvania State University, followed 250 couples in rural Pennsylvania for three to five years, between 1981 and 1988. When recruited, all of the couples were expecting their first child.
Both projects have found that certain problems are common among couples whose marriage suffers after the birth of their first child. These couples argue more often and with greater intensity than before about such things as the division of labor at home, the time they spend alone, their in-laws and sex. Many husbands and wives express less affection for each other - they seldom kiss and hug or give each other compliments. Some couples become ambivalent about their marriage, doubting their feelings for each other and even questioning whether they should have married in the first place. Wives generally become dissatisfied with their marriage first, usually about six months after the baby's birth, but the husbands become equally unhappy after 18 months.
ALMOST TWO YEARS after the birth of her daughter, Ginni Morani, 30, of Columbia, Md., admits that she is still in shock. ''I thought everything would be right back to normal,'' she says. Mrs. Morani, a former assistant clinical director of a drug program, and her 30-year-old husband, Rick, a management consultant, hardly see each other during the week anymore. Because her husband works long hours, Mrs. Morani confesses that she sometimes feels like a single parent.
''We're definitely on different schedules as far as Monday through Friday goes,'' says Mr. Morani, who sees his daughter, Megan, for only a short time in the morning. At night, he adds, his wife seems ''much more tired than she used to be.''
''By the time I get into bed, sex is the last thing I think of,'' Mrs. Morani says. Although her husband seems sympathetic, she has noticed that ''while he's saying, 'It's O.K., it's O.K.,' he's biting his lip.'' Jasmine Gazzarato and Melvin Winkler have had similar problems. For a long time after their baby was born, Ms. Gazzarato says, ''there was no sexual interaction. Then it was few and far between.'' Even now, two years later, she says that sex is ''more of a strain'' and that some of the pleasure she and her husband shared in their lovemaking is gone.
Many women lose their desire for sex after having a baby. Experts disagree over whether the reason is hormonal or psychological. ''The sexual relationship doesn't feel as comfortable for a lot of couples even two years later,'' Carolyn Cowan says. ''Those who don't know that's the way it is get very frightened by it.''
A majority of new parents who took part in a survey conducted by Parenting magazine last year said that their sex life suffered after the birth of their first child. Almost all of them said that mothers pay more attention to their babies than to their husbands. In addition, half of the new fathers asserted that they received less love and affection from their wife for six months after the birth of their child. Three-quarters of them said that during that period they had sex far less often than before. Half of the couples said their sex life had not recovered one year later.
Of course, not all couples fight the postparenthood wars. About half of the parents in Jay Belsky's study said they were more satisfied with their marriage after having a child, or experienced few changes. His data also indicate that it may be possible to predict which couples are most likely to be vulnerable to the baby bomb. Those who view their marriage primarily in sexual or romantic terms, rather than as a partnership, tend to be less happy as parents. Couples who have an infant with ''irregular biological rhythms and routines'' - or, in blunter language, a cranky baby - are more apt to experience a decline in marital satisfaction than parents of a more easygoing infant. Finally, couples who are young and not well educated and who have not been married long are likely to have trouble with their relationship after the birth of a baby.
At first glance the evidence seems to suggest that there may be an advantage to having children later in life. ''Couples who postpone parenthood do seem buffered from marital deterioration,'' says Belsky. But he cautions that psychological maturity and the number of years a couple have been married are probably more important than age in determining the ability of a marriage to withstand the stress of parenthood.
Although there is no conclusive evidence on the effects of postponing parenthood, some research supports Belsky's view. The Cowans have found no difference in adjustment between younger and older parents. And in a one-year study of 64 couples, Mark W. Roosa, an associate professor of family resources and human development at Arizona State University in Tempe, reported that, on average, those who had their first child after age 28 were no happier with their marriage and felt no more in control of their lives than younger parents.
The first major study of the effects of postponing parenthood was completed in 1981 by Pamela Daniels, now a dean at Wellesley College, and Kathy Weingarten, a family therapist in the Boston area. They interviewed 36 couples who had started a family when they were in their late teens or early 20's, 36 who were in their late 20's or early 30's and 14 who were in their late 30's or early 40's. Daniels and Weingarten found some differences among the three groups. The mothers who were in their late teens and early 20's, for example, relied on their family for help, whereas the older mothers received more help from their husband. In addition, couples who postponed parenthood were more likely to regard their child as an intrusion. But almost all of the couples, regardless of age, found that they had to put their marriage on hold while they coped with a new baby. ''No one timing pattern has only advantages,'' Weingarten says.
REGARDLESS OF when a couple choose to have a first child, the mother usually ends up doing most of the parenting chores. When Robert Reed, 34, and his 29-year-old wife, Wendy, of Troy, N.Y., had a baby last year, Mrs. Reed quit her full-time job to stay at home. She spent so much more time with her son than she did with her husband that she came to think of herself as ''95 percent a mother and 5 percent a wife.'' Now, she says, ''it's a little easier, mostly because the baby is more independent.'' But she still does most of the work.
Mr. Reed, the head lacrosse coach at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, works near home, and occasionally stops in for lunch. But during the school year he spends only about an hour a day with his son, Travis. ''I never had any idea how much work it would be to take care of him,'' he says. ''My wife says I should do more. She's probably right. I'm not helping as much as I should.''
One reason why so many new parents assume gender-specific roles might be the different self-images that men and women develop after becoming parents. The Cowans and Jay Belsky have found that when a woman becomes a mother, her sense of herself as a wife and a worker tends to decrease. When a man becomes a father, however, he often still thinks of himself primarily as a worker and a husband. ''The role of parent remains primary for most mothers and secondary for most fathers,'' says Belsky.
Men whose wives work outside the home often spend more time caring for their children, but sometimes at the expense of their marriage. Ann C. Crouter and Susan M. McHale, associate professors of human development at Pennsylvania State University, compared 20 young, single-earner, blue-collar couples whose first child was 2 years old or younger with a similar group of 20 dual-earner, blue-collar couples. They reported that the fathers in the dual-earner families helped more with tasks such as feeding, changing diapers and putting the baby to bed. But the more chores they did, the more likely they were to be dissatisfied with their marriage and to say that their love for their wife had diminished. Compared with the husbands who were the sole breadwinners, these men were more likely to say that they quarreled with their wives frequently and that their wives yelled at and criticized them.
When men do spend a lot of time caring for their infants, they tend to do so only out of necessity. When his wife works the night shift, Paul Slivinski, 28, of Taunton, Mass., cares for their daughter, Jenna. Mr. Slivinski confesses that he never expected to spend so much time with the baby. In fact, he has had to cut back on his night-school classes and playing in his band. ''I've had to make a (Continued on Page 40) lot of sacrifices,'' he says, ''and I spread myself a little thin.''
Susan Slivinski, 31, would prefer not to have to rely on her husband's help. But because they need a second income, she often works five nights a week. ''Jenna doesn't see my face the last thing at night,'' she says, ''and I don't like that.''
Some women who stay at home full time admit that although they want their husband to be more involved with the baby, they have difficulty relinquishing control. Ginni Morani says that when her husband tries to help out, she has to force herself not to correct him. ''It's so hard not to,'' she says. ''I try to keep my mouth shut.''
''If I roll around with the baby on the floor,'' Mr. Morani says, ''my wife says, 'Don't do that, she just ate.' I think, 'Oh, so what.' '' When he is alone with the baby, Mr. Morani does what he thinks is best for her, although he acknowledges that ''it feels strange'' to make even a simple decision, such as what the baby should wear, because ''my wife usually does that.''
Women who have quit their job to stay home with their baby sometimes unwittingly sabotage their husband's efforts, Carolyn Cowan believes. Perhaps that is because these women view motherhood as their only remaining domain. ''Women want men to be involved, but they push them away when they try,'' Cowan says. ''And men want to be involved, but they don't like to be criticized, so they give up too easily.''
FOR MANY COUPLES, one of the most disappointing aspects of new parenthood is the gap between their egalitarian expectations for family life and reality. Many husbands and wives expect to share responsibility for breadwinning, and they do. But the related expectation on the part of many women - that their husbands will share household and parenting chores - is often unrealized. ''Many women believe that sex roles have changed a great deal more than they actually have,'' Jay Belsky says. ''Our ideology has outpaced our practice by leaps and bounds.''
Expectant parents rarely discuss their assumptions about the amount of work each will do, according to Diane N. Ruble, a professor of psychology at New York University. She has studied the effects of unrealistic assumptions about parenting by interviewing 670 women who were either pregnant or new mothers. Most of the pregnant women anticipated that they would be saddled with more child-related tasks than their husbands, but only 12 percent expected the difference to be significant. Almost half of the new mothers, however, said that they were actually doing much more of the work.
Ruble's research also indicates that women whose expectations are violated are more dissatisfied with their marriage than those whose ideas were more realistic. Women whose husbands were helpful during pregnancy may expect equality, she says. But after the baby is born, ''just when they need more assistance, their husbands think everything is back to normal.''
All this is not to say that new parents are powerless to avoid marital devastation. Most experts agree that both men and women stand a better chance of enjoying the rewards of parenthood if they prepare themselves. ''In childbirth classes, couples get ready for one day, then they spend the next 20 years on their own,'' says Philip Cowan, meaning that these classes don't address the stresses of raising a child.
The Cowans have developed a technique for preventing, or at least minimizing, early-parenthood problems. Small groups of couples meet with trained leaders before and after the birth of their babies to discuss five issues that the Cowans believe have a bearing on postpartum marital happiness: the degree of each spouse's sense of well-being; the quality of the relationship between husband and wife, as well as between the couple and their families; the intensity of each parent's bond to the child, and the amount of support the parents receive from family, friends and colleagues. These workshops have been beneficial. New parents who have participated report being more satisfied with their roles and duties at home than similar couples who did not attend such a group.
There may be no way to keep the baby bomb from hitting the household. But with advance warning and preparation, couples can learn how to build themselves a durable bunker.
 
Delayed Childbearing
THE STRESSES AND STRAINS OF HAVING A BABY are common even among the increasing numbers of people who are postponing parenthood until they have established their careers, eased into married life and become financially secure.
''The most important social change regarding parenthood is timing,'' says Arthur J. Norton, a demographer at the Census Bureau. ''People are bearing children later. The transition to parenthood is much more planned than ever before.''
At a time when many middle-class people have trouble affording a house, postponing parenthood is regarded as almost a necessity. ''The fertility pattern of women bearing children in the 1980's looks like the pattern of women bearing children during the Great Depression,'' says S. Philip Morgan, an associate professor of sociology at the University of Pennsylvania. Morgan, co-author of ''First Births in America,'' believes that ''delayed childbearing is a time-honored tradition in harsh economic situations.''
Among the roughly 1.6 million women who had a first child in 1987, about 16 percent were 30 years or older, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. This figure has tripled since 1975. - C.R.
