The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 8, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2, Page 22, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5067 words

HEADLINE: America Tackles The Pesticide Crisis

BYLINE: By Susan Gilbert; Susan Gilbert is a freelance writer and editor on The Good Health Magazine.

 BODY:
JIM KNUTZON IS SITTING IN THE restaurant of the Hilton Hotel in Pleas-anton, Calif., near Oakland, solemnly regarding the plate of swordfish smothered in sauteed vegetables just set before him. With his head bowed, he delivers what might be construed as a modern-day meditation. Knutzon, a former pesticide salesman who now advises farmers on pesticide alternatives, expresses the hope that people across America will soon be able to sit down to meals that are free of toxic pesticide residues. This said, he begins to eat.
Knutzon's wish is not unrealistic. There are powerful stirrings throughout the country, from the vast fruit and vegetable farms of California to the cornfields of Iowa to the apple orchards of New England, not to mention Capitol Hill, indicating that America is making substantial changes in the way it grows its food. Tens of thousands of farmers have scaled down their use of pesticides they relied on for decades -compounds that in many cases were not adequately tested for safety and are now known to be dangerous to human health. Major supermarket chains and food manufacturers are refusing to buy produce that contains even minute, legally permissible residues of certain pesticides. And Congress is considering a bill that would, in all likelihood, restrict the use of dozens of pesticides to such an extent that they would no longer be profitable to produce. 
In lessening the nation's dependence on agricultural chemicals, farmers, food manufacturers, supermarkets and legislators are all taking their cue from the top of the food chain: the American consumer. People are now well aware that good nutrition and all-around healthful behavior can work in tandem to help spare them from many of the illnesses that claimed their parents and grandparents. But the increasing evidence that pesticide residues in foods can cause cancer and other serious health problems has transformed the private matter of eating well into a political issue with a resounding message: Get hazardous pesticides out of the food supply and do it now.
AS JIM KNUTZON SEES IT, farmers have been twice victimized - first, by the Government and the chemical companies, which led them to believe that pesticides were safe. And, second, by the public, which now expects farmers to give up pesticides overnight. ''Still, more and more farmers are saying, 'If consumers are lit up about pesticides, I ought to be a thousand times more lit up,' '' he says.
Knutzon recently joined NutriClean, an Oakland, Calif., company whose goal is to get most pesticides off the farm and out of the American diet. Toward this end, the company serves as a consultant to both supermarkets and growers. Among the alternatives to pesticides that NutriClean recommends to farmers is the release of insects that are actually beneficial, because they prey on other insects before those bugs can prey on a crop. Ladybugs, for example, eat the eggs of most of the worms that eat lettuce and cabbage.
The trend away from agricultural chemicals is strongest in California, where about 53 percent of America's vegetables and 42 percent of its fruits and nuts are grown. In California the number of organic farms, which use no manmade pesticides or fertilizers, has doubled in the past year, to about 1,500. In addition, thousands of other California farms now use pesticides -a term that encompasses insecticides, herbicides and fungicides - only as a last resort. Together, these farms grow and ship to the rest of the country virtually every kind of fruit and vegetable that Americans eat regularly: lettuce, tomatoes, celery, carrots, broccoli, oranges, peaches, grapes.
Driving his white Mercedes on the dirt roads that surround his farm, Don Goldberg, a grape grower in Delano, Calif., in the San Joaquin Valley, proudly points out the differences between his field and that of his neighbor, the Dole Food Company. Goldberg, who is co-owner of the Skyline Ducor Ranch, has been able to reduce his pesticide use by 78 percent in the past three years, chiefly by releasing beneficial insects onto his 400 acres. Larvae of such insects as the green lacewing are literally sprayed onto the field either by a crop-duster or by a rig fitted on top of a tractor. These bugs devour mealybugs, thrips, worms, mites and other pests that can devastate a grape crop.
The soil between the rows of Dole's grapes is completely free of weeds, a sign that herbicides are routinely sprayed. By contrast, the soil between the rows of Goldberg's grapes is barely visible under a covering of tall grasses and flowers. Those plants provide three things: a breeding ground for beneficial insects; nitrogen for the soil, which in turn reduces the need for fertilizer, and a lure for harmful insects that would otherwise attack the grapes.
''This is a holistic system,'' says Goldberg, a trim, athletic-looking man with white hair and bronzed skin. His point is that no one technique can serve as a substitute for pesticides.
Even something as simple as redesigning his grape trellises has helped Goldberg reduce the amount of pesticides he must use. He has found that by making the trellises taller and wider, more air circulates between the vines, thereby significantly decreasing the risk of fungal infections.
The transition from chemical to nonchemical farming can be costly, often requiring an initial investment of many thousands of dollars. But, as Goldberg sees it, farmers don't have a choice: ''If the consumer wants a two-door car, don't try to give him a six-door car. I saw this trend coming, but it got very intense this year because of that Alar thing and that Meryl Streep.'' The public was galvanized into acting against pesticides by a shocking report last February from the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. The report concluded that children face a tremendous risk of getting cancer and other health problems, such as kidney damage and depressed immune function, from pesticide residues in fruits and vegetables. According to the council, the cancer threat to children is as much as 460 times greater than is considered acceptable under Federal law. The main reason children are so vulnerable is that they eat many times more fruit and fruit products than the average adult - on whom the Government bases its safety standards.
Among the N.R.D.C.'s findings: Between 5,500 and 6,200 of today's preschoolers may get cancer sometime in their life solely because of their exposure to eight pesticides in amounts typically found in fruits and vegetables - amounts that are well within Federal limits. In addition, at least three million of today's preschool-age (Continued on Page 000) children are being exposed to other pesticides in fruits and vegetables at levels - again, legal levels - that are potentially harmful to the brain and other parts of the central nervous system.
The chief villain in the N.R.D.C. report was Alar, a growth regulator that, as of last spring, was sprayed on about 15 percent of the nation's apple orchards to make the fruit ripen at the same time. A number of studies had found that when the treated apples were processed - to make apple juice, for instance - Alar broke down into a potent carcinogen called unsymmetrical dimethylhydrazine, or UDMH. There was evidence, too, that Alar itself was carcinogenic.
Alar quickly became a symbol, and the actress Meryl Streep spearheaded a crusade against it. In television and newspaper interviews she urged parents to buy organic produce. And in passionate testimony before the Senate, she suggested that the Government's failure to take Alar off the market amounted to little more than a laboratory experiment on the nation's children. The public responded with a vengeance. School cafeterias stopped buying apples. Supermarkets stopped doing business with Alar-using growers, and growers got stuck with warehouses full of suddenly unsalable fruit.
As a result, Uniroyal, the manufacturer of Alar, stopped selling it in the United States last June. (The company still sells it abroad.) But that was only one step toward safer food.
As an indication of the scope of the problem that remains, the National Academy of Sciences has listed more than a dozen foods in which pesticide residues present potentially significant risks. Tomatoes top the list. Next is beef, because the grains fed to cows contain pesticides that accumulate in the animals' tissue. The other foods cited by the academy are potatoes, oranges, lettuce, apples, peaches, pork, wheat, soybeans, all other beans, carrots, chicken, corn and grapes. The academy believes that these foods account for 95 percent of the health problems associated with pesticides.
One reason the academy considers pesticide residues so dangerous is that they can't all be washed off. Apples, tomatoes and cucumbers, for example, are typically coated with a fungicide mixed with wax to keep them looking fresh and prevent them from spoiling. The wax makes it impossible for the fungicide to be rinsed off. And, while peeling fruits and vegetables may get rid of pesticides on the skin, it doesn't remove those that are absorbed by the plants' leaves or taken up by the roots. These pesticides, known as systemics, become part of a plant's chemistry. Bananas, potatoes and melons are among the crops often grown with a systemic called aldicarb, which even in small amounts can cause temporary nervous disorders, stomach cramps and various other ailments in children.
THE ENVIRONMENTAL PRO-tection Agency does not dispute the scientific findings that legally permissible levels of pesticides can be dangerous. Indeed, the agency has estimated that pesticide residues cause 6,000 cases of cancer each year - many more than exposure to asbestos in homes and schools and as many as passive smoking. While that figure is less than 1 percent of the 900,000 cases diagnosed each year, health experts point out that cancers caused by pesticide residues are preventable. ''Among the easiest cancers to prevent are those with causes that can be regulated by the Government, like pesticide residues in foods,'' says Dr. Robert N. Hoover, an epidemiologist at the National Cancer Institute.
What many people find difficult to comprehend is why the Government permits harmful pesticides to stay on the market. The National Academy of Sciences says the Government actually understates the dangers of pesticide residues because it relies on outdated information. The E.P.A. estimates that Americans eat about one avocado, one artichoke, one nectarine, one wedge of melon, a quarter of an eggplant and a handful of mushrooms each year. But health-conscious individuals are likely to eat far greater amounts of these foods. Department of Agriculture statistics indicate that consumption of many fruits and vegetables has increased significantly in recent years, largely at the urging of nutritionists and health authorities such as the Surgeon General. It is ironic that, in striving to improve their health, people end up consuming more pesticides. This is not to say that people are wrong to change their diets. But the National Academy of Sciences points out that as consumption of fruits and vegetables rises, the need to restrict pesticide use becomes more crucial.
In the E.P.A.'s defense, Rick Tinsworth, an official in the agency's pesticide programs, says that in many cases delays in banning chemicals are caused by protracted court hear-(Continued on Page 52) ings. (The E.P.A. has banned only 26 pesticides since it was created in 1970, although it has said that about 70 now in use are carcinogenic in animals.) While admitting that ''some cancellations of pesticides take too long,'' Tinsworth explains that chemical companies routinely bring lawsuits against the Government for trying to ban their products, arguing that there is a lack of scientific data. He cites bureaucratic ''glitches'' and insufficient funds as other factors that slow down the process of banning pesticides. In 1988, the budget for reviewing the risks associated with pesticides was just under $14 million, an amount that Tinsworth maintains was inadequate to finish the task before ''well into the next century.''
Many agricultural and health experts believe that despite its financial constraints, the agency has been dragging its feet. ''E.P.A. has become averse to being sued and has only taken chemicals off the market that have been uncontested,'' says Charles M. Benbrook, executive director of the National Academy of Sciences' Board on Agriculture. The academy has recommended that the E.P.A. be required to accelerate its review of all 40,000 pesticide products that came on the market without proper testing. In part because of that recommendation, Congress last year passed an amendment to the pesticide law that orders the agency to complete its review by 1996 and doubles the budget for doing so. The academy has also urged Congress to simplify the law, stating, in effect, that it is so labyrinthine that even E.P.A. bureaucrats don't completely understand it.
A bill currently before Congress would both streamline the law and make all pesticides subject to more stringent health standards. For the first time, the effects of pesticide residues on infants, children, pregnant women and other vulnerable people would have to be taken into account. If a product has the potential to cause more than one case of cancer for every million people exposed to it, any of the following actions would occur: the product would be banned for use on particular crops; the number of times it could be applied to a crop would be reduced, or, if these restrictions were inadequate, the pesticide would be swiftly taken off the market - regardless of its benefits to agriculture. The bill, sponsored by Representative Henry A. Waxman and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, could result in the biggest change in American farming since the green revolution.
TOGETHER WITH THE IN-vention of mechanized farm equipment and the hybridization of vigorous crops, pesticides helped bring about a lifesaving explosion in food production. Chemical fertilizers and pesticides have been instrumental in enabling farmers to grow all the food the world needs; that hunger still exists is largely a distribution problem.
Most pesticides used today are man-made compounds. The first widely used synthetic pesticide, DDT, was sprayed by the United States Army during World War II to prevent the spread of malaria by killing mosquitoes. It was so effective that by the end of the war, American farmers had begun applying it to their crops to kill a wide range of other pests.
Contrary to popular belief, the health problems associated with pesticides did not begin with DDT. For centuries farmers relied on natural poisons such as arsenic, lead and copper, and according to historical accounts, fruits and vegetables would occasionally come to market dusted with these pesticides.
As far back as 100 years ago, journalists were writing that the residues might be dangerous. But their warnings were largely ignored by the public because there was no scientific proof. An article in The New York Times on Sept. 25, 1891, under the headline ''Poisoned Grapes on Sale,'' reported that the city's Health Department had ordered that all grapes covered with a greenish powder be removed from grocery store shelves after determining that the coating on some of the grapes was a potentially toxic concentration of copper sulfate. Other cities in the East then threatened to ban the sale of all grapes. (Continued on Page 54) Fearing for their livelihood, a number of Hudson Valley grape growers appealed to the United States Department of Agriculture for help. The U.S.D.A. insisted that the residue was safe and criticized the Health Department for overreacting. In the days that followed, the paper changed its tone, referring to the incident in one headline as ''That Silly Grape Raid.''
At about the same time that the Agriculture Department was proclaiming the safety of New York State grapes, Britain and France were passing laws restricting pesticide use. In 1892, an editorial in The British Medical Journal warned that apples and other produce imported from the United States might be poisonous, because they often arrived covered with arsenic powder. The response of American apple growers was to accuse the journal of attempting to hurt their sales.
Although the apple growers refused to abandon pesticides, many American farmers in the late 19th century still did not use them, either because they didn't think they needed them or because they feared being poisoned. The number of holdouts was significant enough to rattle the Agriculture Department, which went as far as to put pressure on farmers who didn't apply arsenic, lead or other poisons to their fields. At the department's urging, several states passed laws requiring that all farmers use insecticides, on the theory that the insects in unsprayed fields were bound to infest neighboring farms.
After the turn of the century, medical evidence mounted that pesticide residues on fruits and vegetables were poisoning and in some cases killing people. Emotional pleas for reducing pesticide use were made in books, magazines and newspapers. More than 50 years ago, a book titled ''40,000,000 Guinea Pig Children'' made an appeal strikingly similar to Meryl Streep's: the author warned that children were especially vulnerable to pesticide poisoning because they ate more fresh fruit than adults. As a result of such evidence, the Federal Government in 1947 passed the first law explicitly regulating the use of pesticides.
The law went into effect just as DDT was gaining in popularity. Once farmers had DDT, which worked faster and killed more insects than any chemical they'd ever used, they rapidly abandoned arsenic and other age-old pesticides. Confident that they had the ability to conquer their chief enemies, many farmers expanded their operations. Small farms with a patch of lettuce here and some tomatoes there turned into large farms with a thousand acres of nothing but lettuce. Farming became a factory-style business. And soon after DDT came on the market, other powerful pesticides emerged.
But now enter Rachel Carson. Her book ''Silent Spring,'' published in 1963, described as never before the threat of pesticides, conjuring up a ghostly American landscape: birds were absent, cows had stillborn calves and people lay dying of cancer, all because of pesticides in the air, water and food. Carson, a biologist, supported her case with scientific evidence that DDT and other pesticides persist in the environment for decades, entering the food chain and building up in the tissues of humans and other animals; she also pointed out that babies swallow pesticides with their mothers' milk.
After the publication of ''Silent Spring,'' a consensus grew among scientists and Government officials that pesticides as they were being used had the potential to harm human health. Federal regulations governing the testing and use of agricultural chemicals were strengthened, and in 1972, DDT was banned. (It is slow to break down, however, and is still one of the most commonly found residues in many foods grown in this country.) Despite the increasing awareness of the dangers of pesticides, the amount of chemicals deposited on American farms continued to grow.
The use of agricultural pesticides in the United States peaked in 1982, when 880 million pounds were sprayed, a tenfold increase in the nearly 40 years since synthetic pesticides were introduced. During the same period, farm productivity more than doubled. Clearly, large-scale commercial farming could not exist without any pesticides. But since 1982, their use has been declining, as more and more farmers have come to realize that many of the chemicals they once routinely applied to their fields are not really necessary.
THE DECLINE IN PESTICIDE use is welcome news to people concerned about their health, but many experts take the position that as long as most farmers ignore effective alternatives to insecticides, herbicides and fungicides, these chemicals are being overused. A report released last month by the National Academy of Sciences concludes that alternatives to pesticides not only work but are economically viable. The report indicates that the potential exists for an even greater transformation of American farming than the one now under way. ''You don't need any of the worst chemicals,'' says Charles Benbrook, whose staff helped put together the report. He says that even if a significant number of pesticides were suddenly taken off the market, ''there's no way that any major fruits and vegetables would become unavailable.''
The alternative farming methods cited by the academy include the widespread use of disease-resistant crop varieties, the introduction of beneficial insects and crop rotation - planting a crop in a different field each season to prevent insects, fungi and microbes from gaining a foothold in any one area. In places where these methods would not work for particular crops, the report recommends that they simply not be raised. ''Most fruits and vegetables probably would not be able to be grown in the Southeast, because in hot, humid climates, pests are too great a problem,'' says Benbrook. ''Even now, the cost of pesticides is killing farmers there.'' He believes that virtually all of the nation's fruits and vegetables - the crops that are most vulnerable to insects and diseases - should be grown in California and other hot, dry Southwestern states, where the alternatives to pesticides work best.
Jim Hightower, Texas Commissioner of Agriculture, who for a number of years has initiated programs in his state to encourage farmers to adopt non-chemical practices, attests to their success. ''What we've had here, and what we found elsewhere, is that farmers doing this kind of agriculture make money,'' he was quoted as saying a few weeks ago. ''They pay off their notes; they pay for tractors and they do it without crop subsidies. There is a conversion coming.'' A reduction in pesticide use sometimes means higher food prices. One need only walk the aisles of a health-food store to see that many organic fruits and vegetables are selling for double or more the price of conventionally grown produce. It's true that organic farming is labor-intensive, and labor is expensive. Still, many people are willing to pay more for what they believe to be healthier food.
But what many supermarket chains around the country, including some of the largest, have begun to prove is that people don't have to pay much, if anything, more for produce with little or no pesticide residues. Several of these supermarkets, among them Stop & Shop in the Northeast and Raley's in the Sacramento area, sell fruits and vegetables that have been certified by NutriClean as having no pesticide residues detected in laboratory tests. The produce comes from farms that are not necessarily organic but that keep pesticide use to the minimum.
''Only rich people can buy organic food,'' says Stanley Rhodes, the president of NutriClean. ''With our system, we can keep food at market prices and, most important for consumers, get pesticide residues out of the food.'' Rhodes is a former 60's rebel who now wears a suit and tie and sits in a large corner office overlooking the modern buildings of downtown Oakland, Calif. He is the son of a wine maker in the Napa Valley who refused to use grapes grown with pesticides, just like his father, his grandfather, his great-grandfather and his great-great grandfather - all wine makers in Germany.
Rhodes, who holds a Ph.D. in chemistry, is quick to point out that he is not antipesticide. Some pesticides help protect the public from natural substances that are harmful; aflatoxins, for example, chemicals produced by a fungus that grows on peanuts and corn, are much more potent carcinogens than any fungicide used to destroy them. And Rhodes says that some of the toxins that plants themselves produce to fight off insects may be just as dangerous to human health as pesticides. For these reasons, he eventually would like to test food, whether it is grown conventionally or organically, for the presence of all kinds of toxic substances. But for now, his focus is on pesticides.
In addition to certifying produce, each week NutriClean takes samples of all the fruits and vegetables delivered to the supermarkets that participate in its program and tests each one for the presence of up to 200 pesticides. If any are found, NutriClean immediately notifies the supermarkets; the stores can return shipments that contain food with residues in excess of legal limits. At the end of each week, NutriClean circulates a memorandum to the markets listing those farmers whose goods showed residues that week and those whose produce didn't. The philosophy is simple: Information is power. What this really amounts to, Rhodes says, is giving consumers more power over their own food system. NutriClean's success has prompted a few other companies to jump into the food-testing business.
THE FEAR OF BEING blackballed by supermarkets is but one of many factors that are causing farmers across the country to cut down on pesticides. In Iowa, for example, some 300 growers of soybeans, corn and other grains are trying alternatives to pesticides because the state government is encouraging them to do so. A law passed in 1987 caused a sharp rise in pesticide prices by increasing the fees that manufacturers must pay to register the chemicals and that retailers must pay to sell them. The fees help fund a research program that gives farmers information on alternative means of pest control .
Following their colleagues in California, New York and a number of other major agricultural states where organic farms have been certified under voluntary programs for several years, New Jersey's organic farmers recently set standards for certification. New Jersey ranks in the top 10 in the nation in the production of various fresh fruits and vegetables, including peaches, blueberries and tomatoes, and the certification program is giving many conventional farmers the incentive to try organic methods.
Frank J. Stiles, a second-generation New Jersey farmer, is cultivating about 90 of his 200 acres organically this year. His organic crops include tomatoes, bell peppers, broccoli, cauliflower, melons, blueberries, asparagus and apples. ''The more you read, the more you wonder whether you need it all,'' he says, referring to the pesticides he relied on. ''You worry about your safety and your workers' safety.''
Instead of using synthetic insecticides, Stiles uses a spray derived from a bacteria that kills worms without harming anything else. He eliminates other insects by releasing their natural predators, and controls weeds with thick layers of mulch and weeding machines. To fight crop diseases, Stiles uses copper and sulfur sprays - the same pesticides that were so controversial in the past - but he applies them in smaller amounts and well in advance of harvest time to help minimize residues. None of the pesticides he uses are systemics, so they can be washed off.
So far, Stiles's results have been mixed. ''The crops aren't as good as with chemical controls,'' says Helen Athowe, a horticulturist who man-ages the organic portion of the farm. ''We will probably have more crop losses.'' While Stiles's experience is fairly typical of farmers who try to switch to organic methods, Athowe is confident that the problems they've encountered are solvable. After a few years of organic farming, growers tend to learn which methods work best on which field, and their crops generally improve.
IN THE MAJOR APPLE-producing states of Washington, New York and Massachusetts, organic apple farming is extremely difficult. Apples have been grown for so long in these states that the insects and diseases that plague them are strongly established. But with the help of state and private programs aimed at reducing pesticide use, many growers have cut back on spraying without harming the quality or quantity of their fruit. In fact, in a five-year experiment begun in 1978 by Ronald J. Prokopy, an entomologist at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, 40 orchard owners were able to reduce their use of insecticides by 40 percent and bring down their costs without sacrificing yields or quality.
Alar was a crucial tool for many of these growers - those who raise McIntoshes, in particular - because it helped prevent the fruit from dropping prematurely and attracting insects that would then attack the trees. David G. Bishop, a McIntosh grower in Massachusetts and Vermont, says that without Alar he had to make one extra application of insecticides last summer. Even so, Bishop's overall pesticide use was less than it was seven years ago, when he stopped spraying all of his trees according to a fixed schedule and adopted a policy of applying pesticides only when and where they were needed.
Although consumer demand bears much of the responsibility for the recent decline in pesticide use, farmers point out that it was consumer demand that impelled them to use pesticides in the first place. Americans like uniformly red apples, unblemished tomatoes, peaches without bruises. But such cosmetic perfection can be achieved only with pesticides. It was Alar, for example, that made McIntoshes enticingly red; this year's crop is expected to be streaked with more green, although the change in color will not affect the taste.
A study by the California Public Interest Research Group concluded that 40 to 60 percent of the pesticide applications on tomatoes and 60 to 80 percent of those on oranges are made primarily for cosmetic purposes. But in another study by the group, two-thirds of the consumers surveyed said they would pass up a flawless orange in favor of one with scarred skin that was grown with half the amount of pesticides.
Consumers are beginning to realize that the best-looking produce is not necessarily the best for their health - and demanding what is. Now that farmers have strong economic incentives to stop using so many pesticides, Charles Benbrook predicts that what is now called alternative agriculture may, in a decade or so, be mainstream.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1149 words

HEADLINE: CRIME

BYLINE: By MARILYN STASIO

 BODY:
In their relentless quest for a decent apartment in Manhattan, New Yorkers sometimes resort to UNORTHODOX PRACTICES (Pocket Books, Paper, $3.50), an apt title for this hilarious first mystery by Marissa Piesman, co-author of ''The Yuppie Handbook'' and, more to the point, a practicing real estate attorney. Nina Fischman, the Legal Aid housing lawyer who makes her snooping debut here, suspects foul play when two elderly clients die unexpectedly, leaving vacant prime apartments with absolutely no trace of cockroaches. The sinister significance of this unheard-of situation is also not lost on Nina's mother, Ida, a shrewd Upper West Sider whose profound grasp of real estate issues should be an inspiration to us all.
Feisty Ida instigates whatever serious detective work needs doing in this snappy caper, freeing Nina for other important activities, such as shopping at Loehmann's. The Fischman women are delightfully brash - ''Try thinking of us as chroniclers of the human spirit,'' Nina suggests, ''instead of a bunch of yentas'' - and what they have to say about the agony and the ecstasy of living in New York City is funnier than the co-op ads in the Sunday real estate section. 
 
*
 There's nothing gentle about spring in southern Louisiana. It comes roaring into the Atchafalaya basin, James Lee Burke tells us in BLACK CHERRY BLUES (Little, Brown, $17.95), shaking life into the sluggish bayous and stirring the fishermen, roustabouts and rednecks to jump into their pickups and punch up some Waylon on the tape deck.
Like spring on Bayou Teche, Mr. Burke makes a lusty racket when he writes about the local life that courses through the cottonwoods and clatters down the highway. But although he gives his Cajun hero, Dave Robicheaux, the lyric voice to celebrate his bayou home, he denies him the peace to enjoy it. For reasons murkier than a river bottom, the former New Orleans policeman must flee to Montana to escape a psychopath.
The scenery in Montana is also nice, prompting more bursts of lyricism about trout fishing in Blackfoot River canyon and sudden rains over the Mission Mountains. Some vivid characters wander onto the scene, including Dave's old buddy Dixie Lee Pugh, a burned-out blues singer with a mouth still on fire. But the thin story that emerges between nature studies and character portraits deals implausibly with a Mafia takeover of Indian lands.
With so little real action to occupy him, the soulful hero falls into his old, self-indulgent habits of analyzing his dreams and examining his conscience for existential guilt. Even in Montana, the soliloquies of this bayou Hamlet get pretty soggy.
 
*
 Nice of Simon Brett to take pity on Charles Paris. In A SERIES OF MURDERS (Scribners, $16.95), the alcoholically inclined and perennially unemployed actor-sleuth of Mr. Brett's satirical theatrical mysteries has actually landed a j-o-b, on a new mystery series being filmed for British television. Too true, these period dramas are, to Charles's jaundiced eye, ''a bit arch and mimsy-pimsy,'' besides being ponderously written and pretentiously produced. But so long as the actor can count on gainful employment, he's not complaining - at least, not until he realizes that a fatal backstage accident was probably murder.
When the show leaves its cozy rehearsal quarters (at St. John Chrysostom Mission for Vagrants Lesser Hall) to go on location, and when another ''accident'' occurs, Charles steps up his rather desultory sleuthing and peers more closely for suspects among the benighted production company. Could the killer be the ''completely cardboard actor'' who stars as the hammy detective hero? Or the cynical screenwriter who declares, ''If I delivered 'Hamlet' to this lot, they'd come back to me with a great pile of notes''? Or perhaps the prurient stage manager, who suggests, ''Maybe we should play up the soft-porn element in this series''?
They're all guilty, of course; if not of literal murder, then surely of murderously funny backstabbing and lethal character assassination. Such lovely company for dear Charles.
 
 *
 Stephen Solomita, a former New York cabby, is barreling around the city in a new vehicle, FORCE OF NATURE (Putnam, $19.95), that's built hard and rides like a tank. So, better not expect any subtleties from this sequel to ''A Twist of the Knife,'' which returns the police detective Stanley Moodrow to his Lower East Side turf on a manhunt for a homicidal crack addict who is terrorizing the entire precinct by indiscriminately cutting down cops and drug dealers.
The ethics driving this procedural are simple enough. ''What you done, you gotta pay for,'' Moodrow tells the rogue cop who has been harboring the deranged killer in exchange for a piece of the drug sales. The veteran police officer and his rookie partner also encounter no moral ambiguity on the street, where they enlist the aid of dope dealers, prostitutes, gangster bikers and the local Mafia don, among other strikingly well-drawn denizens of the area. ''You kill him, man,'' one taxpayer counsels Moodrow. ''Shoot him like a dog in the street.''
Mr. Solomita gives his maverick cop an appealing philosophy - ''There's gotta be someone to speak up for the neighborhoods'' - and some unorthodox guidelines for separating the criminals from the solid citizenry. If the author has a blind spot about the middle class, he's loaded with compassion for the tattered humanity clinging to the lower rungs of society. His peeled-back views of crack houses, rotting tenements and shelters for the homeless certainly seem authentic; so do his feelings of sorrow and outrage.
 
*
 In his thoughtful new mystery, WORSE THAN DEATH (Holt, $17.95), Thomas Bunn examines the emotional complexities and the technical legalities of parenthood. Adoption is difficult in Michigan, and surrogate motherhood arrangements that involve money transactions are illegal. So the Lansing private investigator Jack Bodine risks his license just by taking on the case of a couple who paid $20,000 for a Vietnamese infant. But Bodine is moved by the adoptive mother's anguish when the baby girl is kidnapped and the baby broker demands an additional $10,000 for her return.
The author's unwavering focus on the substantive issues of parenthood keeps the story from turning into a conventional search-and-grab adventure. All the characters involved in this tricky case contribute to its complications by injecting their own strong, and often messy, feelings as biological, adoptive, foster or would-be parents. The detective himself is such a devoted dad he takes his 8-year-old son along on stakeouts. Although Mr. Bunn writes in a curious, deadpan style - everyone, including a family of Vietnamese, speaks in the same flat, precise idiom - he addresses serious questions about a painful subject, and doesn't presume to have the answers.

HEADLINE: About Cars;
BMW Cuts Back On Price of Luxury

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
Conventional wisdom has it that luxury cars are bulletproof.
The manufacturers like that word, bulletproof. It means that no matter what happens to the economy, them-what-has goes out and gets.
But . . . . they aren't. They may be going out, but they aren't buying. So BMW has made more equipment standard and cut its prices, chopping as much as $5,000 off the ticket for its fancy 735 sedans. 
The stickers of the mid-level 525 and 535 also have been reduced by $2,000, and that says a fair-to-middling amount about the state of today's luxury and near-luxury markets.
''I think sales are off because of things affecting the whole luxury-performance segment,'' Carl Flescher said Friday, a day after the West German company announced the rollbacks. Flescher, BMW's vice president for marketing, said competition was one of the keys.
''There just isn't room for everybody,'' he said.
Flescher's ''everybody'' points a finger at Nissan and Toyota, which have recently gone mountain climbing with their Lexis and Infiniti nameplates, following the lead of Honda, which has done nicely with its thirtymething Acura division.
''This market peaked at about 1.4 million units in 1986,'' Flescher said. ''What we have today is about 1.1 million, and every manufacturer has been affected.''
In the United States, BMW's sales for the first nine months of 1989 totalled 49,987, compared with 53,286 last year; the company is plainly hurting, as are its competitors.
Part of the problem, at least for the imports, has been the weakness of the dollar against other currencies, but that is changing.
''We went through a period of enormous challenge when the dollar was in free-fall,'' Flescher said. ''We had to manage that at the same time that we were introducing an array of new products, and that obliterated the price-value ratio of our cars. But the strengthening and stability of the dollar gave us a chance to take an action like this.''
What BMW is saying, Flescher said, is that the market has changed.
What he also said is that his company hurts less than the likes of Porsche, which has counted heavily on the American buyer and on a very sporty lineup.
For 1990, BMW will offer 13 models in a wide range of styles. BMW sells only 15 to 18 percent of its product here, relying more on its home market and its worldwide sales than on the U.S. Yuppie.
Germany is home to about 190,000 of BMW's sales every year, compared with 70,000 in the United States. Of the latter, more than half are the entry level 3-series models, although the biggest single seller is the 525i, whose price has been cut to $35,000 from $37,000.
In America, Flescher said, much of the young professional market was vulnerable to the market plunge of 1987.
''The area that was hit hardest was New York,'' he said. ''So many individuals who worked in the stock market lost work or lost money, and that slowed the sale of expensive cars.''
Along with the cuts, BMW announced that it would not use incentives to sell its cars, calling them a device that ''erodes value.''
But the announcement was accompanied by a mailing to recent buyers, who will receive a certificate to be applied to the purchase of a new BMW within the next three years.
A letter, designed to head off anguished cries from those who paid the old and higher prices, told the owners they were reaping both the benefits of the new policy and the lower prices of the future.
''What we want to do is to regain our position,'' Flescher said. ''We have introduced more new products than anybody else in the last three years, and we are going to continue with that. But we want our effort to be driven by sales, not by production.''
What is hoped for, he said, is a very clear notion about BMW's commitment to the American market, and ''a signal to a lot of consumers out there to come back and look at BMW, because the cars are more affordable than they think.''
Bayerische Moteren Werke decided to go after the market for expensive cars years ago, but it was only in recent times that the company really got serious about high-ticket items. And it put its technology where its advertising was with 1989's 750il, a sedan sporting a V12 engine.
The new 750 costs an uncut $70,000 and may be worth it. Yes, I said that, although neither my wife nor my bank wants to hear it.
The 750 is the best car I have ever driven, and I'd truly be lusting after it if BMW wasn't planning to introduce an even better sport-coupe version next June.
I hope it will be more affordable than I think.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL NOTEBOOK;
Players Cashing In Before Playoffs End

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Last winter, Scott Sanderson was convinced the Chicago Cubs were certain he would not make the team this year.
''I knew I'd be here at the end of the season,'' Sanderson said. ''But no one expected me to be on the team at the start of the season.''
Not only was Sanderson right, but the Cubs were wrong to the tune of an extra $300,000. That's how much the veteran pitcher earned in bonuses this year, and that's $100,000 more than his nonguaranteed salary. 
Sanderson is one of seven playoff pitchers who earned more than $100,000 in bonuses based on their pitching exploits. An eighth pitcher, Steve Bedrosian of San Francisco, picked up an additional $200,000, but that was because he was traded within a year after he signed his contract.
Besides the $300,000 Sanderson earned, Matt Young of Oakland got $250,000 more than his $75,000 salary, Jim Acker of Toronto made an extra $219,000, Rick Reuschel of San Francisco $187,500, Dave Stewart and Dennis Eckersley of Oakland $125,000 each and Atlee Hammaker of San Francisco $104,166.58.
Hammaker's windfall will actually be doubled because the amount he earned in bonuses this year will be added to his 1990 salary. Stewart's bonus income will also rise because he will receive $50,000, $75,000 or $100,000 depending on where he finishes in the Cy Young Award voting.
Nonpitchers have not fared as well with bonuses. Dave Parker and Tony Phillips of Oakland have earned the largest such payments among playoff hitters, receiving $75,000 each for number of plate appearances.
Sanderson had a contract heavily stacked with bonus provisions because he was coming back from a season that he spent primarily recuperating from back surgery.
''Our general feeling is we'd just as soon stay away from bonus situations for such things as games played and innings pitched,'' said Donald Grenesko, the Cubs' president. ''It can put the manager and the player in an uncomfortable position. The player can think that the manager is keeping him out purposely so he doesn't get his bonus.''
With Sanderson, however, the bonus arrangement was the right way to go, Grenesko explained.
''It made sense to have a small base and bonuses where he could make a substantial amount of money if he was healthy and pitched all season,'' the executive said.
Sanderson started 23 games and relieved in 14 others. Under the point system that is used in most such bonus provisions - 2 points for a start, 1 for a relief appearance - he accumulated 60 points. His bonuses were $60,000 for each of five point levels: 20, 30, 40, 50 and 60.
Thus, Sanderson's start last Sunday, in which he pitched two innings, was worth $60,000 to him because it gave him exactly 60 points.
''No matter what amount of money I make, in salary or incentives,'' Sanderson said, ''it doesn't enter my mind and I'd be surprised that it entered any pitcher's mind when he's out there pitching. We should all have a professional integrity about it.''
Grenesko said the Cubs did not give such bonus information to their manager.
''I don't know what Sanderson's perks are,'' said Don Zimmer, the Cubs' manager. ''I don't want to know. I got caught on that once.'' Zimmer recalled an incident from the 1976 season, in which he became manager of the Boston Red Sox. The team was out of the division race by the last month of the season, and Zimmer decided to take a look at some of the younger players, one of them at second base.
''Denny Doyle, who played a very big part in our going to the World Series the year before, came into my office one day,'' Zimmer related. ''He said I need so many games for so many dollars. I said: 'I wish you hadn't told me that. I want to see what this other guy can do.' He came in the next day and apologized and said, 'I never should have said anything; I put you in a tough spot.' I said, 'You did.' ''
 
Another Healthy Bonus
 Oakland's Young was another pitcher returning from an injury-wrecked season. He had a $75,000 salary, a payment of $100,000 if and when he returned to the active roster and a series of 11 $30,000 bonuses based on innings or games pitched. He appeared in 26 games, giving him 5 of the bonuses, or $150,000.
Acker relieved in 73 games for Atlanta and the Blue Jays. At $3,000 a relief appearance, he added $219,000 to his $250,000 salary.
Under Reuschel's bonus arrangement, he earned $12,500 for each of his last 15 starts, adding $187,500 to his $800,000 salary.
Hammaker, Reuschel's teammate, had a $775,000 salary and a bonus plan under which he received $50,000 for 16 points and $2,083.33 for each point from 17 through 64. Getting 2 points for a start, 1 1/2 points for relief appearances of 2 innings or longer and a point for a relief outing under 2 innings, he amassed 42 points and $104,166.58.
Stewart, who will probably finish second in the Cy Young voting and receive a $75,000 bonus, picked up $25,000 for being on the All-Star team and $100,000 for his 36 starts and 257Z innings pitched.
Eckersley earned an extra $25,000 for appearing in 51 games and $100,000 for the second successive season for his finish in the Rolaids relief standing. Last year he was first, this year second.
 
A's Are Richest
 Of the four playoff teams, counting post-season rosters only, Oakland has the largest payroll, slightly more than $17 million. Chicago has the smallest, $10.6 million. The average salaries compute to $711,188 for Oakland, $635,986 for Toronto, $592,340 for San Francisco and $441,854 for the Cubs.
Besides having the smallest payroll of the four teams, the Cubs join the Blue Jays in appearing to be in the best off-season negotiating position. The Cubs' three highest-paid players, Andre Dawson, Rick Sutcliffe and Ryne Sandberg, are already signed for 1990. The two unsigned players who figure to seek the biggest raises are Mitch Williams and Shawon Dunston.
The Blue Jays don't have to worry about George Bell, Tony Fernandez, Dave Stieb and Jimmy Key because they have contracts for next season. Fred McGriff will be their biggest economic problem.
The Giants have to sign Kevin Mitchell, Will Clark and Scott Garrelts. The Athletics have an expensive winter ahead because they have to deal with Rickey Henderson, Dave Parker and Storm Davis, who can be free agents, plus Jose Canseco and Mark McGwire.
 
A Rookie's Downfall
 With Ken Griffey Jr. running into injury and a falloff in performance, Tom Gordon, Kansas City's versatile pitcher, seemed to be headed for the American League rookie of the year award when he reached a 16-4 record (10-2 in relief, 6-2 as a starter). Gordon, in fact, gained his 16th victory three days before Bret Saberhagen recorded his en route to 23 victories and, most likely, the Cy Young Award.
In his next seven starts, though, the 21-year-old Gordon lost five times, won none, compiled an 8.13 earned run average, averaged only 4.5 innings per start and averaged 16.5 baserunners per 9 innings. He didn't win again until his last start of the season.
''In my view,'' said John Schuerholz, the Royals' general manager, ''what happened was he was exposed to the pressure of a pennant race and it took its toll in him. He tried to do more than he is capable of doing.''

HEADLINE: Panel Discussion;
Preservation And Growth

 BODY:
With the mayoral election, changes in the new York City charter and a wave of commercial development under way in Manhattan, many experts are questioning whether the city has struck a proper balance beetween economic development, construction and historic preservation. Do architects, builders and neighborhood advocates share a vision of the urban environment? Are they working together for the city's betterment? 
These questions and the relevance of the election, the charter and ocmmercial development will be explored in ''Toward a Civilized City: Architects, Developers and Preservationists,'' a panel discussion sponsored by the New York Landmarks Preservation Foundation and the American INstitute of Architects.
Panelists will be Deputy Mayor Robert Esnard; Sally Goodgold, chairwoman of the City Club of New York; Hugh Hardy, a partner in Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Architects, and Fred Rose, chairman of Rose Associated, developers. The panel will be moderated by Barbaralee Diamonstein-Speilvogel, chairwoman of the New York Landmarks Preservation Foundation.
The discussion is to start at 5:30 P.M. Tuesday at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, near 51st Street. Admission is $7 and seating will be on a first-come basis.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Prairie Growth;
In Sioux Falls, Commerce Blooms Like Wildflowers

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

DATELINE: SIOUX FALLS S.D.

 BODY:
AT first glance, the modern office buildings and an expanding mammoth retail center set amid grazing cattle and cornfields that edge this prairie city seem inappropriate investments for such a setting.
But they are far from speculative enterprises. Rather, they represent a response to the pressing business demands that, over the last five years, have changed the city's image, as the locals like to boast, from one of ''prime cuts to prime rates'' - an evolution from a meatpacking center as the home of John Morell & Company into a major Midwestern regional commercial center.
The activity is evident in the value of building permits for nonresidential construction for the first half of 1989 - $24.4 million, compared with $14.1 million in the first half of 1988, in itself a bumper period, according to Steve Metli, director of the city's Department of Planning and Building Services. 
An important trigger, local business leaders recall, was the 1981 arrival of the credit-card division of Citibank. Richard McCrossen, division executive for Citicorp's Distribution Services, said the division had fled New York to escape the strict limits on interest rates it could charge its customers.
South Dakota was one of the few states without such restrictions. And Sioux Falls, a metropolitan area with some 100,000 people in the southeast corner of the state, seemed the best choice, since it offers a relatively mild climate and one of the state's largest labor pools.
But even though interest-rate restrictions were later lifted in other states, it became apparent that Sioux Falls offered a lot more than a banking haven, said Mr. McCrossen. The area's appealing combination of low business and personal taxes, relatively low housing and commercial leasing costs, a low incidnece of crime and workers with ''a lot of old-fashioned pride in what they do,'' he said, became an unexpected enticement. So Citibank expanded from an original workforce of 50 people housed in 14,000 square feet of leased space to three custom-built buildings totaling 370,000 square feet at a total cost of $25 million that today accommodate 2,500 employees. Construction was completed in 1984.
Other credit-card operations are following. Sioux Falls now has Sears Payment Systems and the credit divisions of First City Bank of Texas as well as Norwest Financial Corporation of Des Moines. Together these companies are creating a credit-card and loan-servicing colossus that bills from here more than 15 million customers nationwide each month. This, in turn, has forced the local post office and the telephone companies to expand and modernize facilities in the city, generating yet further business appeal.
Thus, with businesses proliferating as fast and thick as the black-eyed Susans, tiger lilies and prairie roses in the nearby fields, Sioux Falls is becoming equally renowned as a major regional retail center, a rapidly growing medical center with treatment facilities not otherwise found outside major cities, and a transportation and wholesale distribution hub.
THIS has helped create a boom in commercial construction. Consider, for a moment, the expansion of the Empire Mall south of the city. Covering 93 acres, it is owned by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and managed by the General Growth Company of Des Moines.
It began as a relatively modest operation in 1975 serving the local population with 47 stores covering 599,000 square feet. It now offers four anchor stores - Dayton's, Sears, Younkers and J. C. Penney - and some 170 smaller stores in a total of 1.2 million square feet. General Growth puts the annual traffic at more than 10 million people, many of whom drive from 200 miles away.
This has led to a heavy demand for rooms in nearby hotels. The 105-room, four-story Encore, one of the city's more luxurious hotels barely 100 yards from the mall entrance, is now so regularly filled with overnight shoppers and business travelers that a major expansion is taking place. Designed as a round tower at one corner of the hotel, the addition, adding 58 rooms, is due for completion by next fall at an estimated cost of $3 million, said Peter Hegg, developer and general partner in the Encore.
In addition, the long-abandoned 90,000-square-foot square foot Shriver department store in the downtown area, dating from 1918, is undergoing a restoration that will create one of the city's first upscale period-style hotels at a cost of $4.8 million, according to Southeast Properties, the developers.
About two miles south of the mall, crews are at work on a 60,000-square-foot, two-story contemporary building costing $5.2 million that will house the credit-card operations for First City Bank of South Dakota. David Elgena, the bank's president, said the division had originally come to South Dakota from Texas in 1984 for reasons similar to Citibank's, leasing 45,000 square feet in two different locations on a trial basis.
A year ago a decision was made, he said, to purchase a nine-acre site for the new building with an option on another eight acres for possible expansion. Acquisition costs for the land were $1.50 per square foot with construction costs at $87 a square foot.
A major reason for the long-term commitment to Sioux Falls, said Mr. Elgena, was the quality of the workforce the operation could attract - including wives of farmers seeking to augment a dwindling farm income and graduates of the many small colleges here, where 38.9 percent of the population achieve some level of higher education.
Residents, Mr. Elgena added, have a strong work ethic. Local families are mostly of German, Dutch and Scandinavian descent. The explosion of jobs has even begun to attract young farm women who had been drifting to the major cities as nannies.
FURTHER, the modest cost of housing makes it easy, said Mr. Elgena, to draw executives from more costly parts of the nation. The average of cost of home in Sioux Falls is now $61,000 with taxes of $1,400 a year, according to local realtors. An ''executive-style'' home of 2,000 square feet with three bedrooms and two bathrooms costs about $120,000, according to Coldwell Banker, the national brokerage chain. Its recent nationwide survey of comparative housing costs shows Sioux Falls to be one of the nation's least expensive cities, with rents averaging $375 for a two-bedroom apartment. Further, relatively low incomes - on average no more than $20,000 for each working adult - plus an abundant supply of housing keeps home prices in check.
Don Dunham, president of the Sioux Falls office of Coldwell Banker, estimates that commercial leases are equally attractive. Class A space rents for about $12 a square foot, compared with $25 in Minneapolis and other major cities. And class B space goes for about $8 a square foot, compared with $18 elsewhere.
Local developers say these relatively depressed figures are the reason for so little speculative construction is taking place. ''We still cannot command the prices that make for a really good return,'' said Craig R. Lloyd, executive vice president of Lloyd LaCrow, a local construction company.
Tenants will not even accept an inflation adjustment on a commercial lease, he said.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
An Off-Key Tremor in Darien's Even Tenor

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE even tenor of life in Darien - a community known for its low profile, high incomes and relative freedom from commercial development - has been fractured for months by disputes over two pieces of property, one marked for low-income housing, the other a movie theater expansion, and by other indicators of change.
On May 26 the town bought for $2 million a 2.2-acre parcel from the Prindle and Hopkins families at Leroy Avenue and Squab Lane to build 30 units of public housing for town employees and the elderly.
United Artists, which owns the Darien Playhouse on the Post Road, wants to install four screens in the 1928 theater instead of one, without enlarging the building.
Objections to both projects have generated three suits and a referendum. 
The land purchase and its use were approved by the Representative Town Meeting and appropriate town boards last December. A referendum on Feb. 7 resulting from a petition drive by those hoping to kill the approvals produced a vote of 2,334 against and 1,508 for them, 262 votes short of the 25 percent of the 10,381 registered voters needed to void the town's action.
Fourteen citizens then sued in Federal Court, Bridgeport, challenging the validity of the 25 percent rule and seeking an injunction to prohibit the town from proceeding. The injunction was denied and decisions on the suit itself and in two additional suits, in State Superior Court in Stamford, are pending.
One Stamford proceeding, filed in February, charges illegal rezoning of the property from single-family residential to mixed use, allowing multifamily development through spot zoning, and violations of state fair-housing statutes prohibiting preferential treatment of specific groups as tenants.
The other Stamford suit, filed June 30 by nine residents against the town and United Artists, challenged a Zoning Board of Appeals decision permitting the theater - closed for three years - to operate with existing parking when its seating capacity is increased from 625 to 875, presumably creating heavy traffic in the area and burdening residential street parking.
''Anything less than a four-screen theater is not economically viable,'' said Wilder Gleason, the lawyer for United Artists. The project goes to the Planning and Zoning Commission Oct. 24.
The Playhouse and the Prindle-Hopkins property are contiguous. Behind them is Old Stone Road, which comes off Leroy Avenue and goes back to the town dump; north of the road are railroad tracks and south of it is commercial development and a condominium complex. Joellyn and Kevin Gray, who live on Old Stone Road, started the drive for a referendum and are plaintiffs in all three suits. ''Frank brought together a wide variety of economic groups concerned with losing the Darien we love,'' said Mrs. Gray, referring to Frank H. Wilcox, who won the Republican primary for First Selectman in September on a platform opposing public housing. ''I'm willing to do what people want,'' said Mr. Wilcox.
His Democratic opponent, Frederick Sammis, said that he would not approve multifamily housing ''if the need for affordable housing is not established.'' First Select woman Ann Mandel, a Democrat who advocated the housing, is not running again and did not respond to phone calls.
APART from these matters, the renovation of Goodwives Shopping Plaza, a drab, 30-year-old semicircle on Old Kings' Highway, has angered those who lost their shoe repairman, hairdresser, barber and other tenants who could not meet the rent increase.
''Some of those 30-year tenants were paying $6,000 a year,'' said Donald A. Direnzo, executive vice president at Cushman & Wakefield Realtors in Manhattan and one of the Goodwives Partners, a separate entity that bought the 100,000-square-foot shopping plaza in 1985. ''We hope to attract some major chains as tenants.'' He said rents will be around $25 a foot, slightly more than double what the tenants had been paying.
Two million dollars will be spent on new facades, windows, roofs, landscaping and building a clocktower. Grand Union, the plaza's supermarket, is investing an additional $4 million in its own renovation and expansion into 5,000 square feet of adjacent space.
Last July, the State Office of Policy and Management issued a report saying that while Connecticut is expecting a 12.6 percent increase in population by 2010, Darien will experience a 25.6 percent drop, from 20,336 in 1970 to 17,300 next year and 14,050 in 2010.
''High real estate costs play a part,'' said James Palma, planning analyst for the study. He also cited Darien's lack of facilities for the elderly and a general decline in the area as a result of corporate relocations and dissatisfaction with commuting.
Median prices for houses and condominiums in Darien have risen 2 percent this year, to $535,000 and $325,000, respectively, in spite of the soft market, according to Douglas D. Milne, president of Kelley-Milne Real Estate, a local firm.
''There is a need for affordable housing, but the minute the town acquires a piece of property the term affordable goes out the window,'' he said. ''Land should cost between 25 and 30 percent of a project. When it costs near $70,000 a unit, the final unit cost goes up to $220,000.''
Some residents fear being taxed for the projected overall cost of $5 million, including construction, if the town rejects state and Federal aid. ''People don't understand that there are a lot of longtime residents here like me who earn less than $35,000 a year,'' said Mr. Wilcox. ''This housing will require incomes of more than $40,000. It's ridiculous that we should be paying taxes for people who earn more than we do.''
Kevin Newman, a member of the town's Board of Finance, has worked out a series of rental plans indicating that household income eligibility would range from $24,000 to $37,000, depending on how much outside aid the town accepted.
''If the town were to do this it would be on the basis of getting some state and Federal aid, as we did for 53 units of moderate-income housing built in the 1950's and 30 units of low-income elderly housing completed in 1987,'' said Mr. Sammis.
Lewis A. Miller, a founder of Darien Community Homes, a nonprofit agency that promoted the existing low- and moderate-income projects, said, ''I hope Wilcox will be soundly defeated, but I doubt it. I'm discouraged at the moment.''

HEADLINE: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Make a Comeback

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
AFTER an erratic six-month decline that brought mortgage rates down more than a percentage point since last spring, much of the nation is experiencing a minirevival of demand for home loans, most of it in plain vanilla fixed-rate financing.
The lower rates, although not enough to offset the sluggishness of housing demand in some areas, particularly the Northeast, have come as good news to buyers and lenders alike. With fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages widely available at 10 percent or slightly higher, surveys indicate that summer sales of low and moderately priced homes were robust.
''The cumulative impact of declines in interest rates since March significantly helped to open the housing market to entry-level buyers,'' said the National Association of Realtors in a report in September. Overall home sales in August, down sharply from the previous year, nonetheless increased a brisk 3.3 percent over July, the trade group said. 
In perhaps the clearest change, borrowers beat a speedy retreat from adjustable-rate financing, which as recently as January accounted for 63 percent of new home loans across the nation, according to a survey by the Federal National Mortgage Association. By August, the group said, the share of adjustables had dropped to 15 percent, the lowest level in two and a half years.
The shift had been predicted by bankers and thrift industry analysts, who now say it resulted from factors beyond the decline in fixed mortgage rates, which always makes them more competitive with adjustable loans. Indeed, many had been warning for years that the low initial rates or ''teasers'' charged on many adjustables made bad business sense, providing an insufficient return to lenders and prompting some buyers to exceed their budgets on the basis of artificially low first-year payments.
Now, in a year when the deep financial woes of the savings-and-loan industry have come to light in a Congressional bailout in which the assets of many lenders will be seized - dozens will go out of business and the Federal regulations on others will be tightened - lenders are changing their ways.
To be sure, nobody has stopped trying to package and promote home loans. Many lenders this year began offering what they call ''graduated payment'' loans that feature low first-year payments on fixed-rate financing. But borrowers seeking adjustable-rate loans can no longer expect a bargain-basement price during the first year. ''The teaser is all but gone, and we knew it had to happen,'' said Marc Stone, regional vice president of Crossland Mortgage Corporation, a major lender in New York City and its suburbs.
Like most mortgage lenders in the Northeast and Middle West, Crossland has avoided the soured loans and defaults that have plagued thrift institutions elsewhere, particularly in Texas and elsewhere in the Southwest. But the changes at Crossland are typical of policies across the nation: Its initial rate on adjustable loans, as low as 6.25 percent and 3 points below its fixed-rate financing in 1987, has risen to 9 percent, only 1 percentage point below the 10 percent financing it offers on 30-year, fixed-rate loans.
SOME experts warn that more changes are in the offing, and unlikely to benefit borrowers, as lenders adapt to stiffer Federal regulations. One key change, already adopted by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, is a rule that requires lenders to have on hand capital, mainly in the form of deposits, that comes to at least 6 percent of their assets, mainly comprising loans outstanding. The old rule had required a capital-to-asset ratio of 3 percent.
Analysts say some thrifts may respond by becoming less aggressive in lending and by charging borrowers more. Closing costs, points and other charges could go up, income and down-payment requirements could become more stringent and many types of loans could simply disappear from the industry's menu of financing options, they say.
''The experience of the Southwest has got to affect all mortgage underwriting,'' said Dennis Jacobe, research director for the United States League of Savings Associations in Washington. ''It means lenders will be more conservative and the cost for consumers will go up.''
But for now, mortgage companies, thrifts and commercial banks continue to compete intensely to make mortgage loans. And even though traditional fixed-rate loans are in vogue, many lenders are promoting alternatives.
One option proliferating around the country is a loan with payment schedules that are fixed, but are graduated in a way that allows borrowers to pay far less in the first years. And many mortgage companies are promoting lending policies that require little or no income verification from borrowers.
''Lenders are competing as though they were in a gas war,'' said Edward Goldberg, executive vice president of the Midlantic Home Mortgage Corporation, a major mortgage lender in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. He added that some may have become too liberal in qualifying borrowers, particularly at a time when home values in the New York area and elsewhere in the Northeast are holding steady or declining.
But for now, because rates have fallen to a level that is drawing more buyers into the market, and with the resurgence of demand for the most conservative, time-tested form of home financing, lenders are under little pressure to change their approach.
''This is a period of laissez-faire bidding for mortgage loans,'' said Robert Heady, a thrift industry analyst in Florida.
And Thomas Cirillo, managing director of real estate and business banking for Citibank in New York City, said: ''It is probably fortuitous, but at the moment we are in a fixed-rate market, and that relieves pressure on the industry.''
INTEREST rates, although dropping throughout most of the year, have not done so in a straight line. An analysis by HSH Associates, a Butler, N.J., company that tracks mortgage lending across the country, found that the national average on 30-year, fixed-rate loans originated in the last week of September was 10.16 percent; the low for the year was 9.82 percent, in early August, and the high, 11.33 percent, in mid-March.
The first-year rate on one-year adjustable loans had also come down, HSH said, to a national average of 8.67 percent at the end of September from a high for the year of 9.44 percent in mid-April.
Average rates in the New York metropolitan area were slightly higher than the national average - 10.24 percent on a fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage originated in late September, and 8.75 percent on the first year of a one-year adjustable loan.
As always, those buying cooperative apartments in New York City and its suburbs paid an interest-rate premium over those buying houses or condominiums. HSH said the average rate on a fixed-rate co-op loan was 10.68 percent in late September, and on a one-year adjustable it started at 9.02 percent.
Lenders say they charge higher rates to cooperative buyers - who are technically buying shares in a corporation instead of title to their homes - because it is much more difficult to resell co-op loans than conventional home loans into the nation's secondary markets for mortgage financing.
FORECASTS of interest rates, never very reliable, offer little help now because economists differ widely. But whichever way rates move over the next six months, most agree that the change will be modest.
Mr. Heady, publisher of Bank Rate Monitor, has one of the most optimistic forecasts, saying he expects rates on fixed-rate, 30-year loans to drop by 0.75 by March. He said lenders would lower their rates to compete for business as loan demand goes through a normal downturn in the winter months.
If rates fall below 9.5 percent on fixed-rate mortgages, as Mr. Heady is predicting, lenders say they expect a surge of demand from people refinancing existing mortgages. Although such refinancing carries the price of points and other loan initiation fees, it becomes attractive to many people if they are paying off fixed rate loans with rates 2 percentage points or more higher than the current rate.
Refinancing at below 9.5 percent would also be attractive to homeowners with adjustable loans who simply want to lock in their payments at a relatively low, constant rate, experts said.
Although refinancing picked up modestly during the spring and summer - accounting for about 25 percent of the business - lenders said they did not expect a larger demand at the current interest-rate level.
Some economists are looking into a different crytal ball than Mr. Heady's and saying that recent indications that the economy is robust will prompt the Federal Reserve, which is worried about inflation, to tighten credit. That would mean higher rates on all types of loans, including mortgages.
David W. Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, said he expects rates on fixed-rate 30-year mortgages to move up by 0.5 to 0.75 percentage point over the next year.
''Most economists are expecting the economy to weaken and rates to trend downward, but that is not our view,'' he said, adding that higher rates would ''weaken demand for housing.'' Another result, experts said, would be renewed interest in adjustable-rate loans, which are still being offered with initial rates 1 percent to 1.5 percentage points below fixed-rate financing.
Between the two differing forecasts, most experts have accepted the view that, for now, interest rates will hover at about 10 percent or slightly higher on traditional fixed-rate loans and that these loans will be the most popular.
''Recent economic data may delay the downward trend in rates, but fortunately we don't see much in the way of further upward pressure either,'' said Gordon Shanks, president of the Home Mortgage Assistance Corporation, a mortgage lender in Manhattan.
Although demand for adjustable-rate financing has been sharply reduced, lenders across the nation are experimenting with loans that carry fixed rates and graduated payments. That means borrowers can pay below-market rates early in the term of the loans, and the payments will be increased in six- or 12-month intervals. But unlike adjustable-rate financing, where payments are pegged to the movement of other interest rates and are impossible to predict, graduated payments are established in advance for the entire term of the loan.
Borrowers usually pay a premium for the graduated-payment feature, either through higher loan intitiation fees or by paying a higher underlying fixed rate for the mortgage than for standard fixed-rate financing.
ONE example of the approach is at Citibank, which is marketing its graduated-payment mortgage as the ''Home Owner's Key.'' Borrowers pay a fixed underlying rate of 10.75 percent, slightly higher than is being charged on traditional, nongraduated fixed-rate loans by other lenders in the New York area.
But the advantage is that borrowers can pay an intitial rate during the first year of only 5.75 percent, far below the teaser rates - where they still exist - on adjustable-rate mortgages. To qualify, the borrow deposits money in what the bank calls a ''subsidy account,'' which is used to subsidize his payments, effectively prepaying a small part of the mortgage.
In the case of a borrower with a $100,000 mortgage, the bank said, a subsidy account deposit of $798 would be required and would be used up over the first two years of the loan. Beginning at 5.75 percent interest, the borrower's monthly payments would start at $895.83 and increase 7.5 percent a year, reaching a maximum monthly payment of $1,309 in the eighth year of the loan.
SOME lenders say the most dramatic change in their practices over the last year has not been in interest rates or payment schedules, but in their approach to qualifying borrowers. For many, particularly mortgage banking concerns, which do not take deposits and sell all their loans to a secondary market, the so-called ''nonverification'' loan has become standard business procedure.
''Many lenders have determined that if they are getting a down payment of 20 percent or more, it lessens the need to verify incomes or assets and it speeds the process up,'' said Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, which last month released a survey of 30 large mortgage banking concerns that found 51 percent of their loans were being approved with reduced documentation, or none at all.
Like graduated-payment loans, the nonverification financing normally comes at a price of increased loan initiation fees, higher interest rates, or both.
Although they are popular among borrowers who do not savor the time and aggravation it can take to provide tax records, formal statements from their employers and other documents normally required in mortgage lending, critics say lenders may be offering the nonverification loans too liberally.
Even though the loans require down payments of 20 percent or more, which should be an ample amount to cushion the lender against losses if the borrower defaults, some say the sluggishness in some housing markets could lead to trouble.
One area of concern is the New York metropolitan area, where experts say the prices on some properties have fallen in the weak market of the last 12 months. Indeed, in some cases where homeowners have been under pressure to sell, they have had to take prices 10 percent to 20 percent lower than they would have in the stronger market of early 1988. That kind of price movement can only be unsettling for lenders. At Crossland, Mr. Stone said loans were being extended to people without verification of their assets, but the policy of qualifying people without documentation of their incomes had been eliminated in recent months.
And at Midlantic, which continues to originate loans to some people with no verification of their incomes or assets, Mr. Goldberg said the policy is coming under intense internal scrutiny.
''That kind of loan assumes that real estate prices will appreciate or at least hold their own,'' he said. ''Time will tell whether we run into trouble.''
