HEADLINE: Trimming the Fat From School Costs

 BODY:
Right on, Mr. Gerber! (''Trim the Fat From High Cost of Education,'' Opinion, Sept. 24). I am a founder of the East Northport-Northport School Tax Watch and believe he hit the target. Our district still has 10 schools and half the students of a decade ago. We have one superintendent and three assistant supers. We have just given the teachers' union approximately an 8 percent increase for the next three years. The average salary is around $40,000 and it costs about $11,000 to educate each student.
Northport has lived high off the hog because of the Lilco plant, which pays around 40 percent of the school taxes. Yet, our taxpayers rose up last spring and defeated the budget by a 3-1 margin. People voted who confessed it was their first time or their first school vote in 10 years. They were angry and distressed. But only when they felt threatened, did they bother to participate in school affairs. 
This is a problem Mr. Gerber did not address. I served on the school board three years until I was defeated by a union-backed candidate. In that time, I repeatedly tried to reduce budget items: trips to New York City, jaunts to conferences, social programs not connected with education or the classroom teaching; with no success.
I failed because the Board of Education never heard from the taxpayer-owners of the schools protesting the cost of education. Only the young parents wanting more services - extra business, all-day kindergartens, more staffing - appeared, and always the same two or three warners about costs. When they stood up to speak, the board tuned out because we knew their song. The board is bombarded with student claques, organized by teachers, to ask for more - new classes, new sports, increases in funding.
How can board members, bombarded at each meeting with ''Gimmee! Gimmee!'', understand the anger of people who no longer have children in schools, who see taxes a threat to their home ownership and do not understand that state-mandated programs cause some of the cost increase?
It is hard to stare at 25 eager young faces, representatives of unions, and the administrative staff and say, ''No.'' You are elected because of union backing; you live in the community. You will be attacked as cruel to children, as destroyers of the family and betrayers of education.
Since you, the board member, never hear the other side, it is easy to go along with the ''Gimmees'' (an all-day kindergarten has validity), especially in a booming economy. Only this spring did the nay-sayers express their outrage and vote down the budget.
To break the cycle of rising costs, the so-called selfish senior must come out of their homes and take action. Groups like ours must reach out to all taxpayers and show that fiscal prudence does not mean the destruction of our schools. Older people must come to board meetings to express their opinions and to learn the difference between mandated and discretionary costs. The board must hear from more than three people. The seniors cannot leave their voice to the same three people. Secondly, seniors must be more willing to run for the thankless task of running a school district. Running a $65 million business is not for amateurs. School districts need members with financial experience on boards; members who can resist the ''Gimmee'' pressures of vocal minorities.
The boards desperately need the continued interest of all taxpayers in running a complicated but essential system. Our students are our future. However, school districts cannot bankrupt the present for the future.
 
ELEX INGERSOLL
 Northport
Send letters to The Editor, Long Island Weekly, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: FAIR LAWN JOURNAL;
For the Automobile's Sake, An 1855 House Faces Razing

BYLINE: By ALBERT J. PARISI

DATELINE: FAIR LAWN

 BODY:
ITS shutters hang at odd angles, and many of the windows are broken. A wraparound front porch, once the hallmark of Victorian splendor, is now weatherworn and buckled. But for James R. Croucher, 58 years old, the battered house brings back visions of a time when neighbors knew neighbors and farm life revolved around the rising and setting sun.
Pointing to the front of the house, he noted sadly that his grandmother's porch swing was only a memory now. ''Over there is where we all gathered after breakfast to get ready for work,'' said Mr. Croucher, a pharmacist and salesman for a national pharmaceutical company, ''and over there is where we gathered after dusk and talked until it was time for bed.''
In mid-October, the 17-room frame house, known historically as the Hopper House, will be razed to make way for a highway cloverleaf connecting Fair Lawn Avenue and Route 208 here. It is the house where Mr. Croucher grew up, but more importantly, he says, it epitomizes an era of New Jersey history when farming ruled the local economy and labor was not measured in a five-day work week but in crops picked and bushels filled. 
Over the last two years, Mr. Croucher and both the county and borough historical societies have joined in efforts to save the house. Letters to state officials were written and plans for a cloverleaf redesign were studied, but changes would have proved too costly to undertake, he and state transportation officials said.
''I understand the reason the house has to come down,'' said Mr. Croucher, accompanying a recent visitor to the 134-year-old farmhouse originally built by Henry Hopper, a former state legislator and county sheriff, ''but progress has a way of dealing a nasty blow to communities that forget their past.''
The new cloverleaf is essential, officials say. With increased traffic congestion on both the highway and Fair Lawn Avenue in recent years, automobile accidents have soared. Even though the house is a local landmark and a state-registered historial site, the designation offers no protection against its destruction under the circumstances.
''When we first learned of the state's plans, we thought that perhaps if we moved the house to a different location, it could have been saved,'' Mr. Croucher said. But it would cost nearly $120,000 to have the structure braced and lifted from its foundation. The cost would have been too expensive for the historical groups' limited budgets.
Several years ago, another historical site here, the Cadmus House, had been saved in such a fashion, at a cost of $60,000, but the structure was considerably smaller than the Hopper House, said Carl J. Koenig, president of the Fair Lawn Historical Sites Preservation Corporation.
''Such a move involves a major project,'' Mr. Koenig said, ''and if we were to take the Cadmus House as an example, that was only moved two blocks and the cost was very high.''
While officials stress the benefits of the cloverleaf, many longtime residents here say that the landmark house stands as a reminder of a bygone time when Bergen County, and indeed most of the state, flourished in a farming economy. In recent years, according to the State Department of Agriculture in Trenton, the number of active farms in New Jersey's 21 counties have drastically diminished.
Landowners have increasingly chosen to give up tending the soil for meager profits. Instead, the Department of Agriculture said, landowners have chosen to profit from lands that have turned many former farms into vast tracts of commercial and housing developments.
''Landmarks such as this should be preserved for our youth so that they can learn from it,'' Mr. Koenig said. ''Our life is so fast paced today, and children can't understand that a slow life on a farm could be rewarding.''
Built in 1855 as the main house of the 300-acre farm, the Hopper House was partly rebuilt in 1890 after a fire destroyed one wing and part of the roof. In 1919, the house and 55 acres were bought by Mr. Croucher's grandfather and were owned by the family until 1954.
The property was then sold to a local developer, who converted the house into real-estate offices. The house was sold to the state in 1988 and has remained vacant since. Many of its Victorian fixtures and artifacts have been stolen.
''Growing up in the house in the 1930's and 40's was a special time for me, not just because it was my childhood but because of the small community, we all knew one another and relied on each other's help,'' Mr. Croucher said. ''All that has changed today. People don't know one another.
''Since that time as a child, I've never heard the sound of wind blowing through the trees so distinctly, or the sound of horses being led to pasture or the quiet whispers of voices on the front porch after a hard day at work. Time stood still for adults and children alike, until we broke the silence with a game of kick the can.''
He recalled that from his bedroom window at night, he was able to see a nearby clock tower and that the clock face ''stood out in the distance like a big old moon that was full.''
While the house's fate has been decided, Mr. Croucher did convince the state to save a towering blue spruce that he and his brothers and sisters had planted as a sapling. The county plans to erect a plaque commemorating where the house stood.
Though a construction crew is awaiting word to demolish the house, state officials authorized an archeological dig on the site to study 19th-century life.
''We've come up with some interesting and unusual finds,'' said Dr. Rebecca Yamin, an archeologist with the Ebasco Environmental Corporation of Lynhurst, which supervised the dig. In addition to bits and pieces of pottery and glassware, team members were able to study an underground well system and the house's foundation.
David Zmoda, an archeologist who is the transportation agency's project site manager, said: ''It's a shame to see any old house like this go, but at least we're able to record a portion of the history here before it's lost forever.''
Lois Dekker, 38, of Fair Lawn, a great-great-granddaughter of Henry Hopper, came to the site recently with a family album filled with photographs and letters that she wished to share with the study team.
''If I had the money, I would have bought the house outright and tried to restore it,'' she said. ''There are many great memories here, and they are memories that we must pass down to all concerned.''
For Mr. Croucher and his brother Warren, there will be more than memories to cherish about the house.
''When we were kids sitting in the kitchen, I remember my grandfather giving us each a quarter and that was a lot of money back then,'' James R. Croucher said. ''We were fooling around and Warren, by accident, dropped his coin behind a section of paneling and he was heartbroken.''
After the house was sold for demolition, Mr. Croucher returned and decided to pry open the paneling with a penknife.
''Off it came, and there on the floor was 100 years' worth of plaster dust and no coin,'' he said. ''I brushed away some of the dust and there was the coin, untouched by another hand for decades. I'll have it framed, or encased or something, then give it back to Warren for his birthday.''

PUB-DATE: October 8, 1989

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 38, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1230 words

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Having No Sense of Direction Is Neither Here Nor There

BYLINE: By Phyllis Heller Wharton; Phyllis Heller Wharton lives in Armonk.

 BODY:
I HAVE a terrible sense of direction. Having lived in Westchester County now for nearly 13 years I go by rote to most of my accustomed destinations: the supermarkets, library, mall, even to New York City. I have, I suppose, more or less memorized my way to these places, but this accomplishment was slow and painstaking in coming.
Sometimes I wonder about people's sense of direction. I have a friend who moved here from Santa Monica not quite five years ago, but almost immediately she could find anything. Not just content to reach her destination (as I always am), she found shortcuts and alternative routes to everything.
I remember setting off with her for Westport, Conn. I don't think she had lived here more than a year at that point. We were on the Merritt Parkway, coasting along at the speed limit along with all the other cars on the road, when she said: ''I'm getting off this road. The traffic is unbearable!'' I looked at her and realized she wasn't kidding. 
I never take an alternative route; not unless a road is closed and there is no possible option. She pulled off at the next exit, unfolded an enormous map she stored in the glove compartment and in minutes we were threading our way through an unknown town onto a string of auxiliary highways, arriving at our destination not only in good time but rather scenically.
I envied her her skill - or is it nerve coupled with a dose of inventiveness? I panic at the very thought of getting lost. I suppose I offend my own feminist sensibilities when I admit this, but I can't help thinking that a good sense of direction is a predominantly male characteristic, much like baldness and deep voices. It's not that I haven't come upon the trait in women - I have - but it seems more common in men.
I mentioned this to a friend and she disagreed. Her theory is that men are too stubborn to admit they are lost. I pull over and talk with anyone I can find when I even suspect I'm lost. Men will go for miles without blinking, - certain that they will find their way ''any minute.''
Maybe men are less worried about the consequences of being lost. I worry about the dark or being lost in questionable neighborhoods. Then there is the matter of the car itself. I feel on friendly terms with my car until it does anything out of the ordinary. When one of the little windows lights up on my dashboard, I go into a panic. My deal with my car is that I'll take care of it if it will take care of me.
I have it serviced regularly. No, frankly, I adhere to the suggested schedule of check-ups much the way the folks at NASA must go about meeting deadlines. My goal in car maintenance is to always beat the car to the mechanic before it realizes it needs to get there.
Sometimes I think my feelings of vulnerability - about being lost, not knowing my way, and all too often (though I would rather not admit it) of striking off for a destination and becoming hopelessly confused - have to do with not learnng to drive until I was nearly 30.
I was a non-driver, a situation that happened not by choice but because of economic circumstances. My mother's car had grown old and was beyond repair. We could not afford to replace it. When I turned 16 years old and was eligible to take driver's education in high school, it seemed pointless to take the course along with my friends, knowing that I would have no opportunity to practice. I didn't sign up when the list came around, though I do remember feeling terribly cheated and even embarrassed about it.
Driving is a real rite of passage for a teen-ager. It was all anyone talked about for months. As my friends passed their tests one by one and got their senior licenses, learning to drive seemed further and further away from anything that would ever happen to me. Later on, in college, I didn't need a car; everyone walked the small rural campus. Still later, I lived in New York City, where driving, even then, was a nightmare and garaging a car prohibitively expensive.
It wasn't until I married and we decided to move 30 miles north of the city that it became obvious that my time had come. I had not told anyone, but in the intervening years, as my friends went from novice teen-agers to seasoned pro's, I grew more and more certain that I could not do it.
Driving seemed to represent an enormous responsibility to me. What if I'm driving and cause an accident? What if I'm driving and my passenger is hurt? What if I wreck the car? But even more than that, I worried because of my rotten sense of direction, which was largely related to day-dreaming, and how scattered my thoughts often tend to be.
I didn't realize that after a time, after the initial newness fades and the mechanics of driving kick in and take hold, most good drivers seem set on automatic pilot.
These days I often reach my destination barely having noticed the trip because I am so caught up in my own thoughts. At first I felt a deep sense of panic, wondering if I had missed stop signs or red lights along the way. I have never had a ticket (except for parking) and am not given to speeding, so I must be obeying the rules of the road, I reasoned.
Except for my inability to really understand east from west (I seem to have mastered north/south) and my hopeless inability to ''feel'' my way home after I have struggled to get where I'm going, I enjoy driving. I can go where I want with no better reason than that I want to go. I still get a real kick out of that even this many years later.
There is a heady freedom for me that I experience when I decide to go somewhere, reach for my car keys, go out to the car and start off. This is probably a delayed reaction, a thrill better understood and recognized in teen-agers. For the first few years, when I was in my early 30's, I would go off to the drugstore for a tube of toothpaste or a bottle of shampoo, not because I needed the item at that moment, but rather to experience the freedom of not needing a ride, asking a favor or fitting into someone else's schedule.
In the spring and summer I sometimes get into my car, push open the sunroof, pop a favorite tape into the cassette and go out for a spin. I have a few favorite destinations, too. If my son is along with me we are apt to stop at Ben & Jerry's, but if I'm alone and have the time, I sometimes drive to the beach in Connecticut. I long ago learned my way along the back roads, and though it is a circuitous route and time-consuming to avoid I-95, I enjoy the trip.
I know I never feel more independent, young and carefree than when the windows are open, my hair flying, sunglasses in place, singing along with Elton John as I make my way.
Car ads pulse with enthusiasm and sex appeal. ''The heartbeat of America'' one intones with a steady rhythmic beat and a rugged male voice. A car is the first thing most boys buy. My son, not yet 12, has for years talked about buying a car and about what kind it will be. He has more than a passing acquaintance with the kind and patient man who works at a small foreign car showroom nearby.
Maybe by the time he's grown and carrying his own drivers license in his wallet someone will have invented a map with an automatic compass to orient him.
I need one that lights up with a big red spot stating, ''You are now here.'' Until then, I know I can never think of moving. I have conquered the county. Detroit take notice!

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1795 words

HEADLINE: Into the Woods: Junk Cars and Old Stoves

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
A HIKER in the woods accustomed to rounding a corner and coming upon a deer or other wild animal is just as likely these days to confront a rusting Ford or a rotting La-Z-Boy. Across the state, many of the remaining unspoiled areas are fast becoming spoiled by the illegal dumping of automobiles, tire, furniture and major appliances.
State park officials and other custodians of public and private lands say the closing of many municipal dumps and the imposition of fees for such items as washing machines and refrigerators have brought an increase in the illegal dumpings.
''Durable goods - that's what they're called when they're made and that's what they are when they end up on our land,'' said Gerard E. Loiselle Jr., a spokesman for the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company, which owns 20,000 acres of largely undeveloped land throughout Fairfield County. ''We're seeing a dramatic increase in the amount of waste products being dumped on our land.'' 
Keith R. Cudworth, the superintendent of the White Memorial Foundation, the 4,000-acre wildlife sanctuary in Litchfield, said the problem becomes more obvious at this time of year. ''Once the leaves come off the trees, you'll notice a lot more - the miscellaneous trash bags, the major appliances,'' he said.
 
A Problem With Tires
''We've had refrigerators and stoves, a car one time, and our biggest problem has been tires.'' Mr. Cudworth said the dumping of tires increased after a nearby landfill stopped accepting them last year. He said someone once dumped 70 tires at one time.
Because of the illegal dumpings, White Memorial this year closed most of its roads and trails to motor vehicles.
''The state forests and state parks, in particular, have become an inviting place to dump off unwanted stuff,'' said John H. Spencer, the eastern district manager for the State Department of Environmental Protection. He said his crews have already hauled 65 cars out of the woods of eastern Connecticut this year, at a cost of about $200 each.
''Some of the things people do are just unbelievable,'' Mr. Spencer said. ''If somebody ever did the same thing to them, they'd be livid.''
''And I'm sure we're going to find a lot more in a few weeks,'' Mr. Spencer said. ''You don't see the extent of the problem until the leaves fall off.''
Jerry A. West, the operations manager of Sherwood Island State Park in Westport, said his crews had pulled cars, appliances, tires and other junk off the boat launches and flood control areas.
 
'A Real Problem'
''It's a real problem in places we don't patrol every day, where people can get in and out without being seen,'' Mr. West said. ''When they dump off trash, we go through it looking for a letter or something that has their name on it. If we find one, they get a littering citation through the mail.''
But in the more serious instances of illegal dumping, the haulers make sure all evidence of origin is removed, the land custodians said.
''And these problems are only going to increase,'' said John E. Hibbard, the executive director of the Connecticut Forest and Parks Association. He said he knew of a couple who recently paid $30 to dispose of two televisions.
''Unless something is done to lower the cost, some of that material is going to be discarded along the road,'' Mr. Hibbard said.
 
Outdoor Enthusiasts Suffer
For instance, many dumps now charge $1 or more to dispose of an old car tire. When dealers attempt to pass that charge onto customers, some of them take the tire away in their trunk and dump it in the first isolated spot they pass.
Mr. Hibbard, whose group maintains the 500-mile Blue Blaze trail system in Connecticut, said outdoor enthusiasts might suffer because of the illegal dumping.
''It goes beyond merely the degradation of the hiking experience,'' Mr. Hibbard said. ''People are sophisticated enough to realize that someone who abandoned an automobile was not up there hiking,'' Mr. Hibbard said. ''But you could predict landowners restricting public use of their property if the problem gets any worse.''
 
Dwindling Landfill Space
Most landowners blame the problem on dwindling landfill space.
''In our area, Redding is about the only town left with an active landfill,'' Mr. Loiselle said. ''And that's in the process of being phased out.''
Thomas H. Pregman, an environmental analyst for the solid-waste unit of the State Department of Environmental Protection, said part of the problem stemmed from the closing of a dozen bulky waste dumps for large items like tires and appliances over the last four years.
There are 35 bulky waste dumps in Connecticut, and some of the 21 mixed solid waste landfills that closed recently still accept limited amounts of bulky waste.
''But those are largely municipal operations and therefore handle only the waste generated in the town,'' Mr. Pregman said.
 
Stiff Fee Schedules
More towns have implemented stiff fee schedules for materials they will accept, Mr. Pregman added, and are turning away things like tree stumps that take up a lot of room.
''The majority of land clearing waste now goes off to who knows where,'' Mr. Pregman said. ''And even if the facilities are available, some haulers are still going to dump illegally if it's cheaper and they can get away with it. Right now, some of them have to haul it halfway across the state and pay $750 a load to dump it.''
Gian-Carl Casa, senior legislative associate for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, said that another problem was junk cars. Years ago, the scrap metal in cars made them worth a few dollars, he said. But because of the processing costs and the depressed prices paid for scrap, it now costs money to have them hauled away.
 
Market for Scrap Metal
''Some people have been able to get gypsy towers, who give you a better deal on hauling a car away, but what they do with it you never know,'' Mr. Casa said. ''It may turn up on a city street or in a smaller town, out in the forest.''
In the last year, the market for scrap has improved, which has helped the situation somewhat, Mr. Casa said. While municipalities paid $100 to dispose of an abandoned car a year ago, they now pay no more than about $50, he said.
''People are still abandoning cars at the same rate, but because metal prices have moved up municipalities are towing them off the streets a lot quicker,'' Mr. Casa said.
He said his organization estimated that 30,000 cars were abandoned last year, and that the number would not be much different this year.
 
Boulders and Logs
Mr. Cudworth said that in an effort to control the problem, White Memorial had blocked many of the 50 entrances to the preserve's 35 miles of private roads and trails with boulders and logs, to discourage traffic.
''As far as people walking, there's been no restriction on access,'' Mr. Cudworth said. ''And we have tried to keep our patrolling pretty intense.''
Mr. Loiselle said it was impossible to have intense patrolling on the 20,000 acres of watershed land that Bridgeport Hydraulic owns throughout Fairfield County, but the company recently added a second position to its inspection crew.
He said four areas were especially troublesome for the water company: land near Booth Hill Road and East Village Road in Shelton; Velvet Street, a dirt road in Monroe and Trumbull, and Valley Road, a dirt road in Redding.
 
Demolition Material Along Road
For instance, the company recently found demolition material including displays and shelves from a large retail establishment dumped along Valley Road.
But there are also problems in areas that are heavily traveled, Mr. Loiselle said. On Route 58 in Easton, the company recently found four truckloads of roofing shingles and other demolition materials, and on Route 25 it found an entire tractor-trailer load of old tires.
''When the economic incentive increases, people take bigger risks,'' Mr. Loiselle said. Mr. Spencer said his unit had hauled junk from many areas in northern and eastern Connecticut, especially along the abandoned railroad beds that have been converted to public hiking trails.
 
Old Rail Beds and Viaducts
''It's very easy to drive up an old rail bed and dump off a car or washing machine,'' Mr. Spencer said. If the junk is tossed from an old viaduct or bridge, it can remain hidden for a long time, he said.
But Mr. Spencer declined to identify specific sites where dumping has been a problem. ''I don't want to give anyone else any ideas,'' he said.
''The worst part of it is that we have to spend time we desperately need for other things,'' Mr. Spencer said. When an abandoned car is found, it can take a crew of two or three park employees several hours to wrestle it from undergrowth and move it to a road, where it can be hauled away a junkyard. Meanwhile, he said, park maintenance suffers.
 
Threat to Water Supply
Mr. Loiselle said his company recently sponsored the reprinting of a pamphlet on household hazardous waste, and a public television documentary, ''Town Dump Closed,'' to make people more aware that illegal dumpers could be ruining everyone's water supply.
''We're trying to make the public aware of the problem, to become our eyes and ears,'' Mr. Loiselle said.
Thomas C. Jackson, a spokesman for the Regional Water Authority, which owns 24,000 acres throughout the New Haven area, said a few years ago, the company became alarmed at the amount of garbage being dumped on its property, and began issuing permits to hikers, anglers and others for recreational uses of the land.
''If someone's dumping trash next to your favorite fishing hole, you tend to get angry, and report it,'' Mr. Jackson said. ''The program allows people to join us as stewards of the land.''
 
Stiffer Penalties
Mr. Jackson said the company also employed four guards who patrol the utility's holdings and arrest illegal dumpers, and several other groundskeepers who look for evidence of illegal dumping.
Mr. Pregman noted that penalties for illegal dumping are now stiffer and less complicated to enforce. The old fine was $10,000 a day, but it took weeks or months to obtain a final order to levy the fines.
A new law that took effect last Sunday imposes a fine of up to $25,000 a day and up to one year in jail for violations of the waste laws, and the penalty doubles on the second offense.
In addition, a new criminal statute allows fines up to $100,000 and two years in prison for someone whose illegal dumping results in death or injury, with the penalties rising to $250,000 and five years in prison for a second offense.
''Things are real tough with the landfill capacities that are out there,'' Mr. Pregman said. ''But perhaps these tougher laws will make a dent in what's going on.''

HEADLINE: JOBS BEING FILLED BY ILLEGAL ALIENS DESPITE SANCTIONS

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Despite the Government's effort to turn the workplace into the front line in the battle against illegal immigration, most illegal aliens are able to find jobs in the United States.
Immigration officials and other experts say most companies are trying to comply with the provisions of the 1986 immigration law that prohibit the hiring of illegal aliens.
But many illegal aliens continue to find jobs using fraudulent identity papers. Most of the rest are forced deeper into the underground economy, where few questions are asked, no records are kept and the potential for workers to be exploited is high.
''Like the undocumented workers already here who didn't qualify for amnesty, the new arrivals have not become unemployable in this country because of employer sanctions,'' said Wayne A. Cornelius, the director of the Center for United States-Mexican Studies at the University of California at San Diego. ''It's just that their range of job options may have been reduced somewhat.'' 
 
Fines or Jail for Employers
Congress imposed the sanctions in the hope that jobs would become impossible to obtain and therefore no longer would be a magnet for illegal immigration. Two years after the law began to take effect thousands of people continue to enter the country illegally every day.
The ease with which the law is being violated is raising increasing questions about whether migration from Mexico and other economically troubled nations can be deterred by the 1986 law, the Immigration Reform and Control Act. In addition to granting legal status to many illegal aliens, the law requires all employers to demand that new workers show proof of legal residency or other evidence of their right to work.
Employers who do not demand such documents or who are found to have knowingly hired an illegal alien are subject to fines of $100 to $10,000 for each violation. In the most severe cases, the law provides that employers may be jailed for up to six months, although no such sentences have been imposed. After a period of issuing warnings, the Immigration and Naturalization Service began fining employers in June 1988, and it is prosecuting them more aggressively.
Officials of the immigration service acknowledge that the law has not yet had its intended effect. But they say there are many promising signs, including a decrease in the number of aliens apprehended while crossing the nation's southern border and reports from illegal aliens themselves that good jobs are harder to obtain.
''People are still coming here and looking for jobs, and some are still finding jobs,'' said A. D. Moyer, Executive Associate Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization.''But it's not as easy as it used to be.''
 
Fraudulent Documents Abound
By all accounts, the law is being undermined primarily by the spread of fraudulent Social Security cards, ''green cards'' signifying alien residency status and other documents widely accepted by employers as proof of the right to work. Employers are not required to verify the authenticity of the documents, and critics of the law call this a gaping loophole.
''Compliance with the law has come to mean compliance with the paperwork requirements,'' said Kitty Calavita, a sociology professor at the University of California at Irvine who studies immigration. ''Because of the ready availability of fraudulent documents, employers can comply and still employ the same people they always have.''
The law's effect is most visible at places like the intersection of Pico Boulevard and La Brea Avenue in Los Angeles, where dozens of illegal aliens wait every morning for employers seeking day laborers for construction, gardening, painting and cleaning jobs that generally pay less than $5 an hour.
Standing on the corner one recent morning, Francisco Javier Saldivar, a 38-year-old Mexican, who came here illegally about two months ago, said the law is undoubtedly having an impact, but not enough to stop the flow of immigrants.
 
Work One Day but Not the Next
Mr. Saldivar, who also spent time in the United States last year and in 1980, said: ''It was much easier then. Now it's hard to find work. In 1980 I could make $500 in two weeks, and now I'm making $4.25 an hour. I make about $300 a month because I'll work one day but not the next.''
''It's less secure,'' Mr. Saldivar said. ''Still, lots of people keep coming because life is very tough in Mexico.''
Neither the immigration service nor other experts see evidence that the law is prompting more than a handful of illegal aliens to return to their native countries, where the few jobs available pay far less than those here.
Immigration officials acknowledge that their task in enforcing the law is daunting. In Los Angeles, for example, about 70 agents are assigned to monitor roughly half a million employers.
''The law will only work, like tax laws, if the majority of employers comply voluntarily,'' said John Brechtel, the agency's assistant district director for investigations in Los Angeles.
Mr. Brechtel said the agency had been unable to thwart the widespread sale of fake documents. Although there have been nearly 100 convictions for the counterfeiting of documents in Los Angeles in the last year, the price of false documents has sharply fallen, Mr. Brechtel said. He said a fake Social Security card and a green card could be bought for $35. But several workers put the cost for a good set of the same documents at about $300.
 
Government Is Criticized
The immigration service's enforcement efforts have drawn considerable criticism. Peter Larrabee, a lawyer in San Diego who represents many companies in immigration cases, says the agency concentrates its enforcement on small employers, ignoring big companies that can mount vigorous legal defenses.
He also says the agency avoids cases against chronic employers of illegal aliens, because they keep no records.
''The employers whom the law was intended to go after are not being bothered at all,'' Mr. Larrabee said. ''They simply don't keep the records the I.N.S. needs to make a case. It's too difficult for the I.N.S. to make a case against sweatshop owners and the employers who pay people off the books.''
Mr. Larrabee said the immigration service most often prosecutes companies that try to comply with the law but inadvertently hire an undocumented worker or fail to keep paperwork properly.
The feelings among those companies are ''unanimously of total and absolute fear and confusion,'' Mr. Larrabee said. ''They don't understand why, when they fail to dot an 'i,' cross a 't' or date a form, they should get a $1,000 fine.''
 
Officials Say Enforcement Is Fair
IMT Inc., a machine shop in Fullerton, Calif., that has 15 employees, was recently fined $3,500 for knowingly employing one illegal alien and for failing to complete all paperwork properly. Charles Hays, the company's manager, said the company was fighting the fine, which he said was based on information the company itself had provided.
''They should be helping us enforce the law and not coming after us and other people who make a substantial effort to comply,'' Mr. Hays said.
Immigration officials say that they are fairly enforcing the law and that they have gone after egregious violators as well as those employers who have failed to meet paperwork and other technical requirements. Mr. Moyer cited the case of a day-labor company in Chicago that was fined $60,000 after what he said was a long and labor-intensive investigation.
''We'll work with an employer as long as that employer has made a good-faith showing that they are trying to comply,'' Mr. Moyer said.
The immigration service said its most recent figures showed that as of June 30, it had conducted 21,745 investigations of employers. The agency said it had issued 4,634 warnings and 2,511 fines seeking a total of $11.8 million. Many fines are settled for less than the agency first demands.
Mr. Moyer said the immigration service still believes that sanctions will ultimately work as a deterrent to illegal immigration. ''I've said all along that this law is going to take three to five or maybe even eight years to have a full impact on immigration patterns to the United States,'' he said.

HEADLINE: To Find Out About Soviets, F.B.I. Turns to Advertising

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
In a novel approach to the second-oldest profession, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has turned to advertising to recruit potential Soviet counterintelligence assets and beckon would-be defectors.
On Friday, the F.B.I. began running daily display ads in a Russian-language newspaper in New York City, calling on recent Soviet emigres and other readers to share information on operations of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence service, in this country and abroad.
''Replies will be kept in the strictest confidence,'' the advertisement in Novoye Russkoye Slovo promises.
James M. Fox, director of the F.B.I. office in New York, said the appeal aimed to capitalize on the potential intelligence bonanza offered by the influx of some 150,000 Soviet citizens since 1975 and the expected arrival in the country of another 80,000 over the next year or so.
American intelligence officials have long assumed that their Soviet counterparts smuggled in some agents along with the emigres, and the newspaper campaign is aimed in part at unmasking spies. And yes, Mr. Fox said, he knows the K.G.B. will be sending him double-agents in response to the advertisement, and he is ready. 
''We'll be very alert to the K.G.B. trying to send in ringers and plants,'' Mr. Fox said. ''Without being specific, we're prepared for that.''
The $300-a-day advertisement takes note of the waves of immigrants - some 50,000 have settled in the New York area alone - and suggests that ''many emigres have found themselves in a position to assist the F.B.I. in its counterintelligence mission.''
It goes on, ''Some of you are emigres who, for one reason or another, have direct knowledge of K.G.B. methods or operations, either in the U.S.S.R. or abroad, but particularly in the United States.''
It concludes with an appeal: ''If you are such a person, wishing to make an important contribution to your adopted country, please call or write your nearest F.B.I. office.''
It supplies the number of the bureau's office at 26 Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan, (212) 553-2700, and the extension of the counterintelligence section, 3037, where Russian-speaking agents were said to be standing by.
 
Six Calls So Far
The first two days of the advertisement - in the Friday newspaper and in a weekend issue - generated six calls through yesterday afternoon, the F.B.I. said. Agents declined to characterize the nature of the calls in any way.
Mr. Fox said that the bureau was always looking for qualified Russian linguists, and that callers, once properly cleared, might find themselves offered jobs with the F.B.I.
F.B.I. officials said the bureau was also interested in collecting information on criminal activity by Soviet underworld gangs known to be operating within the emigre community in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn and elsewhere.
The F.B.I. also appears to be trying to counter recent criticism by some defectors that it and the Central Intelligence Agency had treated them poorly.
The advertisement does not mention compensation, but benefits do exist for those who help gather intelligence for the United States.
 
Read by Soviet Diplomats
The C.I.A. did not comment directly on the advertising campaign. Regarding criticism over the treatment of some defectors, Bill Devine, a C.I.A. spokesman, said the agency ''has taken several steps to improve our resettlement program, such as assigning more experienced officers'' and creating an external review board.
The advertisements, which cover about one-fifth of an inside page, are scheduled to run daily for two weeks and then intermittently. The F.B.I. said the newspaper, which is generally hostile to the Soviet system, had a circulation of more than 50,000 nationwide, largely in emigre communities. The paper is officially off limits to most Soviet foreign-service officers but is known to be read by a number of Soviet diplomats. The advertisements are not running in any other publication. Mr. Fox of the F.B.I. said that since so many of the new arrivals gravitate to Brighton Beach, ''We thought it would pay us to get the message out saying this is what the F.B.I. does.''
While he said it was the first time he knew of that newspaper advertisements were used in that way, he and other counterintelligence experts noted that coded messages in the newspapers were long a tool of spycraft. How Do We Reach the F.B.I.? The unorthodox initiative was approved by bureau headquarters in Washington, Mr. Fox said, adding, ''We explained the logic and they thought it was a good idea.''
He said the effort grew out of comments from recent defectors who complained that they did not know how to make contact with the F.B.I.
When agents told them that the F.B.I.'s phone number is listed on the inside cover of the white pages telephone book, the defectors asked, ''How do I get a telephone book?'' In the Soviet Union, telephone books are a closed guarded commodity.
Some other defectors have told the F.B.I. that for months before they made contact with the American authorities, they had tried without success to attract the attention of F.B.I. surveillance agents with surreptitious waves and other signals that would not at the same time tip off curious Soviet colleagues.
 
Defector Praises Ads
One recent Soviet defector, Boris Beliak, a 47-year-old former official with UNICEF at the United Nations, who said he loved his homeland but detested the Communist system, praised the F.B.I. initiative.
''It is the duty of every person who comes here to help out this country, a duty to help the U.S. Government, it's as simple as that,'' he said in an interview last week.
Mr. Beliak, a lawyer, economist and former member of the Soviet Olympic crew team, who is now looking for a job in New York City, said the advertisements were vital to show emigres as well as Soviet diplomats that the F.B.I. was not an ''instrument of oppression'' like the K.G.B., and that agents were not the ''bad guys'' portrayed by Soviet security briefings.
But along the crowded streets of Brighton Beach, where Soviet emigres ran errands and relaxed over vodka and smoked fish this weekend, reaction to the advertisements was mixed.
Some, like Michael Stremlin, encouraged the F.B.I.'s solicitations. A 50-year-old engineer who arrived in New York last year from Leningrad after a long campaign to leave, said running advertisements was a smart way to reach embittered emigres willing to share information that could help topple a repressive Soviet regime and protect the United States against espionage.
''I know what kind of country I left,'' said Mr. Stremlin, who has settled with his family in Brighton Beach. ''It's oppressive and should be changed immediately. It's all of our responsibility to support the F.B.I. any way we can.''
 
A Different Opinion
But others thought the F.B.I.'s campaign was ill conceived and bound to fail.
''Unless you actually worked inside the K.G.B, you don't know the first thing about it - it's a very secretive organization,'' said Aron Fischer, 48, a grocery store owner. ''And if you had been in the K.G.B. and were able to come to the United States, you probably wouldn't come forward because you'd be scared the American Government would consider you a Communist.''
The F.B.I's new efforts come at a time when the K.G.B. has been trying to put on a more human face, to transform its image as an agent of repression.
Mr. Beliak, the former UNICEF official, said he ''had a lot of apprehensions'' about his decision to become an American. But he said: ''I saw people who were genuinely interested in helping me out rather than pushing me or harassing me for information. That was a pleasant surprise.'' He said he performed no espionage work for either the Soviet Union or his adopted country.
 
Expected to Be Homeless
Two other recent defectors, a couple who spoke on the condition that they not be named, also praised the F.B.I. advertisement.
They said they had been ''brainwashed'' to expect harsh treatment by the F.B.I., including efforts by agents to compromise them by planting store goods in their pockets when they went shopping so they would be arrested for shoplifting. ''I was afraid to go out alone,'' the woman said.
She also said she knew so little about how defectors were treated that she expected they would become homeless and have to live on the street in a cardboard box. Her fears were all allayed, she said, and she wanted her countrymen to get that message.
''Americans don't realize how great is your country,'' she said.
F.B.I. counterintelligence officials said the cold war's thaw and spreading spirit of glasnost, or openness, did not eliminate the need for vigilance against espionage, but represented heightened risks.
''Everyone thinks the Soviets are wonderful, and doors are opened,'' one said. ''But the K.G.B. is still at work.''

HEADLINE: Louisiana Changes Course And Accepts Tax Increase

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Reversing at least part of the message they sent in a spring election, Louisiana voters on Saturday overwhelmingly approved a gasoline tax increase intended to finance a costly building program and breathe life into the state's dismal economy.
The tax increase of about a penny a gallon was rejected overwhelmingly in April, when voters defeated a fiscal overhaul program sought by Gov. Buddy Roemer. After that defeat, Governor Roemer and the Legislature put together a modified package of measures to be voted on separately, and some of them were approved on Saturday.
''We've got a big win,'' Governor Roemer said in a telephone interview today. ''It's been a long road.'' 
 
State Still Faces a Shortfall
But the Governor did not say that the tax increases approved on Saturday would end the shakiness of the state's finances, which is a result of the oil industry's decline. While he maintained that the broad package that was rejected in April would have gone a long way toward a solution, he said the steps approved on Saturday were a start.
Louisiana faces a budget shortfall of at least $400 million next year if it does not reduce state spending and renew sales taxes that are due to expire.Budget cuts have already resulted in the elimination of 6,000 state employees since the Governor's election in 1987.
Nevertheless, many people in the state were smiling today, from fishermen in the coastal wetlands that were a big beneficiary of the vote, to business leaders who campaigned for the thousands of jobs expected to result from the new four-lane highways and port and airport improvements in a $1.4 billion construction program financed by the new gasoline tax.
Political analysts here saw the vote as a sign that Louisiana voters are willing to assume some fiscal responsibility, providing the cost is not too high.
While voters approved the increase in the gasoline tax to 20 cents a gallon and removed a $3 limit on fees for license plates, they defeated other proposals to allow municipal governments to increase property taxes, to decrease business taxes and to extend a tax break for property owners in historic districts. Voters also approved a proposal to make the seizure of assets of drug dealers easier.
 
Voting on 13 Measures
The coastal erosion trust fund approved by voters will be paid for by oil and natural gas revenues. The fund is significant chiefly for its use in attracting Federal matching funds to help slow the rapid erosion of the state's wetlands, its supporters said. ''We've baited the hook for the Federal Government,'' State Senator Ben Bagert said.
The gasoline tax measure, which establishes a transportation trust fund, was approved 71 percent to 39 percent, as was the environmental trust fund. The voter turnout was 31 percent for the election that considered 13 separate measures, not all of them dealing with the state's fiscal problems. Voters also rejected two proposals to increase the number of state judges who are black.
The election did not provide a solution to Louisiana's chronic budget shortages, Mr. Roemer said. ''We've taken a bankrupt situation and gotten on solid ground one year at a time,'' he said. ''We're halfway home.''
Comparing the proposal approved on Saturday to the package to change the state tax system that was defeated in the spring, he said, ''Fiscal reform would have done it 10 years at a time.''
The election was Mr. Roemer's third attempt to change the state's tax system. Last fall legislators defeated his effort to change the property tax system, under which most homeowners pay no property taxes.
 
Moving From Long's Legacy
Politicians, political analysts and ordinary people saw the results on Saturday as a sign that Louisiana was moving away, at least a little, from the anti-tax populism that has been strong since the 1930's when Gov. Huey P. Long and the Legislature enacted high business taxes that forced oil companies to pay the state's bills.
But some, including Edward Renwick, a political analyst and a leading poll taker, saw the movement as limited. ''Basically people said we'll give you a little money if you use it for specific purposes,'' he said.
''The vote was conservative populist,'' Mr. Renwick said. ''The tax they went with affects everybody equally -no progressivity. The taxes that would not help everybody equally all went down.''
Mr. Renwick said the voters' willingness to raise the $3-a-year-license plate fee, long seen as an inalienable right, to at least $10 a year is a symbol of the state's willingness to change, but a small one.
''Things haven't changed that much,'' he said. ''It's not a revolution. But it helps Roemer. He finally got something passed.''
But environmentalists said that the vote on the wetlands signaled a major change in the way the state views the environment and that it was a top priority even among people who live far from the endangered coastal marshes. ''It's the strongest of signals,'' said Oliver Houck, a leading conservationist.

HEADLINE: Growing Gap in Life Expectancies Of Blacks and Whites Is Emerging

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
After narrowing for decades, the gap in life expectancy between blacks and whites has grown for three years in a row, Federal health experts say, and most of the disparity is due to patterns of behavior.
The experts said the trend has been caused almost entirely by deaths from causes like AIDS, drug abuse, alcoholism and car accidents, and not by diseases that are much less subject to control.
In fact, for the three leading causes of death - cancer, heart disease and stroke - the new statistics show that improvement among blacks has been as good as or better than that among whites, said Dr. Harry M. Rosenberg, chief of the mortality statistics branch of the National Center for Health Statistics.
But from 1984 to 1987, the gap between the races increased from 5.6 years to 6.2 years, Dr. Rosenberg said. A white child born in 1987, the latest year for which the data have been analyzed, could expect to live about 75.6 years, Federal figures released last week show. A black child could expect a life of 69.4 years. 
 
A Good Overall Measure
Life expectancy statistics are a good measure of both overall health and death rates because they are taken from a complete count and analysis of all the approximately two million death certificates filed each year in the United States.
The causes of death that increased much more for blacks than for whites and were the chief factors in the widening gap, were, in order: AIDS; drug overdoses and other drug-related factors; diseases and disabilities that kill infants in their first year; accidents, chiefly those involving motor vehicles, and chronic liver disease including cirrhosis caused by alcoholism.
Dr. Christine Hale, an expert in mortality statistics at the University of Washington, said, ''The trend is appalling. And there is one thing all these causes have in common: they are preventable. This is essentially self-destructive behavior, and it is a pattern you get when people are despairing.''
Since the statistics were first compiled in 1900, there has been a gap between the races, but it had narrowed from 14.6 years in 1900 to 5.6 years in 1984.
 
A Change in 1984
Then in 1984, for the first time, the life expectancy for blacks began to fall while it continued to rise for whites. The difference was noted, but statisticians were uncertain of its causes.
In the latest report, the National Center for Health Statistics said the gap had continued to widen for a third year. In addition, Dr, Rosenberg said, two major trends are expected to worsen considerably, the number of AIDS deaths and homicides among young black men.
As medicine and public health practices improved, the life expectancy for both races had improved. Life expectancy sometimes fell, like during outbreaks of influenza, but until now the figures for both races dropped and rebounded together.
Life expectancy at birth is a statistical measure that represents the average number of years infants would live if they were to experience the death rates that prevail for different age groups in the year they were born.
 
Trend Is 'Ominous'
''The numbers themselves don't seem large yet, but the direction is so ominous that it is of great concern,'' said Dr. William P. O'Hare, director of policy studies at the Population Reference Bureau, a research center here. ''The Government and society should be concerned about these numbers, because it means the loss of many productive workers and taxpayers.
''I suspect that the mortality rate is also an indicator of something else. In addition to the people dying, there are other ones who are disabled and become a burden to society and the health care system from the same causes. We have to pay to take care of them as well as losing their capacity to work.''
Dr. William Julius Wilson, a sociologist at the University of Chicago and the president of the American Sociological Association, said the ''disturbing decreases in life expectancy correspond with recent increases in the black poverty rate and, more important, increases in the severity of black poverty.''
He noted that in 1978 one third of poor blacks had an income of less than $5,000 a year, when the Government designates a family of three as poor if its annual income is less than $10,000. By 1987, Dr. Wilson said, nearly half of poor blacks had fallen below the $5,000 level.
 
Decreases in Social Programs
Dr. Wilson also cited large decreases in social programs as possibly contributing to the widening gap in mortality rates. The total appropriations for programs like subsidized housing, health services, social services and job training fell by 54 percent from 1981 to 1988, he said, and programs like food stamps and aid to families with dependent children were also cut substantially.
Earnings of black workers have also declined, Dr. Wilson said. The median earnings of young black workers who head families have dropped by one half from 1973 to 1986, after being adjusted for inflation, he said.
''It is hard for me to believe that these factors are not related to the decline in life expectancy,'' Dr. Wilson said. ''People with less income cannot get the kind of medical care others do. People without jobs or money resort to drug use as they try to deal with their frustrations.''
 
A Question of Policy Choices
Dr. Herbert Nickens, the director of the division of minority health at the American Association of Medical Colleges, said the main question now is, ''What policy choices should be made in the face of these numbers?''
''We don't have a vaccine for homicide,'' he said. ''But on drug-related deaths we ought to open more drug treatment facilities. We should not have people on waiting lists for treatment.
''Most people have a sense that things are spinning out of control. There is a bleak outlook and a locked-in quality to these conditions. No one since Lyndon Johnson has stood up and said, 'We're going to fix this.' We simply have not had a national resolve.''
Another main element in the widening gap has been infant mortality. The disparity in infant mortality between blacks and whites has widened since the late 1970's, said Kay Johnson, director of the health division for the Children's Defense Fund.
The infant mortality rate for blacks was 1.78 times that for whites in 1973, she said. But by 1987 it had risen to 2.07 times the white rate.
''Progress has just stopped,'' Ms. Johnson said.

HEADLINE: When the Money Really Would Stop

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
With Congressional leaders and Administration officials failing again over the weekend to work out a way to allow budget legislation to be enacted this week, prospects grew that across-the-board spending reductions in Government programs would automatically go into effect on Oct. 16.
From a practical standpoint, the cutbacks of 2 percent to 5 percent in most programs, from military procurement to Medicare payments, would make little difference. Eventually, a budget will be approved and the lost money restored.
But from a political perspective, missing the deadline would worsen the already widespread view that today's politicians are unable to manage the fundamental obligation of Government: to raise money from taxpayers and allocate it in the best interest of the country. 
 
Energy, Effort and Lost Focus
Few legislators, economists or political analysts disagree with the assessment of Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the leader of the Senate's Democratic majority. ''We expend so much energy and effort here seeking to get and retain tactical and partisan advantage, we lose focus in dealing with legislation in a responsible way,'' he said last week.
Paradoxically, the procedures that place lawmakers in the bind they find themselves in now - the 1974 law that established Congressional budget procedures and the Gramm-Rudman law that set annual deficit-reducing targets - were designed to force Congress to act more responsibly.
This year was not supposed to be one for missing budget deadlines. In April, President Bush and Congress struck an agreement for cutting the Federal deficit by about $14 billion, enough to lower it below $100 billion, the mandatory target for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.
 
Gimmicks for Expediency
They reached the goal mostly with gimmicks like advancing a military payday by one day and removing the Postal Service from the budget. But on both sides the deal was considered a get-me-through-the-night arrangement to buy time until the new President and the new Democratic leaders in Congress could sit down and do some serious deficit-cutting for the next fiscal year.
What threw sand in the gears was Mr. Bush's insistence on fulfilling his campaign promise to lower the capital gains tax and his determination that the measure be attached to a budget bill known as reconciliation legislation.
As envisioned by the 1974 budget law, which was written to give Congress a handle on fiscal policy, the reconciliation procedure would be routine. Congress would set overall spending and revenue figures at the beginning of the year. Then it would pass all its appropriations and tax legislation. If, as would likely happen, the numbers in all the bills did not add up precisely to the figures agreed upon in the beginning, a reconciliation bill would be passed to add a few dollars here or make small trims there so that everything came out even.
 
And What Really Happens
That is not the way it has generally worked in recent years. Reconciliation bills have become kitchen-sink measures, crammed with legislation, that have little to do with the budget but much to do with overall Government policy.
Because Presidents must sign or reject bills in entirety, Congress has used reconciliation bills to force enactment of policies that might be vetoed if they stood alone; Presidents have used them to force Congressional consideration of policies that might otherwise be bottled up in committees that opposed them.
This year's bill is no exception. The 2,000-page legislation approved by the House of Representatives late last month and now before the Senate includes not only a temporary reduction in the capital gains tax but also repeal of Medicare insurance against the cost of catastrophic illness, expanded Federal support for child care, reinstate ment of the fairness doctrine for broadcasters, prohibitions against pornography on the telephone, pension law changes, an excise tax on ozone-depleting chemicals and dozens of other items big and small.
 
'Baggage Car' Legislating
It became, said the House Republican minority leader, Representative Bob Michel of Illinois, a ''baggage car'' for measures that could not ''stand the test of independent consideration.''
The bill might still have stood up under the excess weight had it not been for capital gains. ''The dominoes were falling neatly and in order until we came to the bridge washed out by the capital gains debate,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee.
President Bush and nearly all Republicans in Congress maintain that a capital gains tax cut would stimulate investment and help the economy. Enough Democrats agree so that it was passed by the House and has a slim but clear majority in the Senate.
But it is vigorously opposed by most Democrats and especially the leaders who control the committees and the vote schedules. They believe such a cut would amount to a giveaway to the wealthiest taxpayers.
Last week, the leaders of both parties in the House and Senate were on the verge of agreeing to strip the reconciliation bill of the capital gains provision and all other extraneous matters so that the budget measure could be passed before the Oct. 16 deadline.
 
Role of Top Bush Aides
But the President's principal advisers - Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff - argued that unless the capital gains measure was part of the reconciliation bill, the Democratic leaders might be able to block it from coming to a final vote.
The two sides spent all day Saturday and part of today trying to find some ironclad agreement that would allow a bare budget bill to come to a vote with a guaranteed vote on capital gains later in the year. They plan to resume meeting on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, in the various Government departments and agencies, bureaucrats are busily juggling accounts in case no political agreement is reached and the automatic spending cuts do go into effect on Oct. 16, a week from Monday. In budget parlance, such automatic cuts are called sequestration.
One result would be an immediate 2 percent reduction in Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals and individuals. Borrowers in the guaranteed student loan program and farmers expecting crop-support payments might also be affected.
But most Americans would not notice the difference, and those who received lower payments would almost certainly be reimbursed as soon as a budget was approved.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is probably the most knowledgeable lawmaker on the intricacies of the budget, says it would be 30 to 45 days before the bite of sequestration was really felt. Across-the-board cuts went into effect briefly two years ago before a budget was approved, and no one was the worse for wear.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: CORE CURRICULUMS IN COLLEGE URGED

BYLINE: By JULIE JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Asserting that too many college students graduate with limited exposure to the ''basic landmarks of history and thought,'' the National Endowment for the Humanities urged colleges today to bolster required undergraduate studies.
Issuing a new report, the latest in several recent indictments of American education, the agency said colleges should require students to pass a core of courses in Western civilization, math, science, foreign language and social sciences.
Lynne V. Cheney, chairwoman of the endowment group, an independent Federal agency that supports research and education in the humanities, released an accompanying national survey of college seniors that she said showed significant gaps in their knowledge of history and literature. 
The Gallup Poll of 700 college seniors showed, for example, that more than 40 percent of those surveyed did not know when the Civil War was fought and that nearly one-third said Reconstruction was a plan of American economic aid in Europe after World War II, rather than the period when the Union administered the Southern states after the Civil War. A quarter of the seniors were unable to distinguish the thoughts of Karl Marx from the ideas expressed in the United States Constitution. When Was the Korean War? In addition, reflecting an overall difficulty the seniors appeared to have in remembering dates and matching them to significant historical events, 24 percent of the students said Columbus landed in the Western Hemisphere sometime after 1500. Almost 60 percent of those polled said the Korean War began during the Presidencies of either John F. Kennedy, Franklin D. Roosevelt or Dwight D. Eisenhower, or did not know.
''If the students' answers were to be graded, more than half of those tested would have failed,'' the report said.
The poll, conducted from April 4 through April 27 of this year, was based on 696 interviews with college seniors who attend four-year colleges or universities in the United States. Its margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points.
Mrs. Cheney said: ''What you also have is almost half of these bright-faced college graduates apparently unaware of what 'Moby Dick' or 'David Copperfield' are. And on those questions where they have confused Karl Marx and the Constitution, these go to the heart of our democratic heritage and that is deeply troubling.''
Even so, seniors indicated a surprising grasp for detail on some basic historical facts, including some that could be considered relatively esoteric. For example, 60 percent correctly identifed Thomas Paine as the Revolution author of ''Common Sense,'' his argument for colonial independence. More than 80 percent knew of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's disputed investigations into alleged Communist activities in the 1950's.
Mrs. Cheney's report does not explain the gaps between what students do and do not learn. She acknowledged that some students ''manage to put together a coherent and substantive'' program of study. But knowledge gaps remain, she said, largely because most colleges have loose ''distribution requirements'' that allow students to pick and choose between courses in a variety of areas.
 
A '50 Hours' Proposal
The call for a ''core curriculum,'' based on a specific number of semester hours that college undergraduates must pass - like a ''50 Hours'' proposal offered today by Mrs. Cheney -is not new.
But its release comes as parents, teachers and businesses increasingly find education lacking. And, officials of the endowment agency said, the report complements the policy recommendations made two weeks ago at the meeting on education that President Bush had in Charlottesville, Va. with the nation's governors.
Mrs. Cheney's proposal is heavily rooted in Western civilization and omits altogether any requirement that undergradutes study composition or some form of writing. But it opened immediate debate among educators about the notion that there is a precise set of facts, books or other knowledge a person should have.
''A reform that relies so heavily on the traditional Western civilization courses runs the risk of a dangerous superficiality,'' said James Underwood, dean of faculty at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y., which began a general education curriculum this fall that is based on history and literature.
Bari J. Watkins, vice president for academic affairs at Queens College in Charlotte, N.C., a liberal arts school that has been praised by higher education groups for its core curriculum, said, however, that many small liberal arts colleges already have moved in the direction Mrs. Cheney recommends.
Copies of the report, ''50 Hours: A Core Curriculum for College Students,'' can be obtained free by writing the Office of Publications and Public Affairs, National Endowment for the Humanities, 1100 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, D.C. 20506.

HEADLINE: The Democrats - Late and Lame

 BODY:
The Democratic Party is in trouble. The floundering over capital gains taxes has raised serious questions about the quality of the party's leadership, the coherence of its message and the condition of its soul. The Democrats aren't wholly to blame for their troubles. But the signs of decay are worrisome - not just for the party but the country.
A feeble opposition is no great help to George Bush, either. Two weeks ago the Democrats had critical things to say about Soviet policy that deserved Mr. Bush's attention. Secretary of State James Baker was able to dismiss them with a smug reference to the President's high approval rating on foreign affairs. That rating could drop after the latest Panama fiasco. But the Administration's complacency owes much to the Democrats' failure to offer a sustained response to Republican policies. 
It isn't easy to be a Democrat now. Three straight Presidential defeats have left the national party rudderless, while scandal has left the Congressional party in largely untested hands. A long period of peace and general prosperity has blunted traditional issues. The amiable Mr. Bush, whatever his shortcomings, presents an elusive target. And the Democrats, no less than the White House, seem politically and intellectually paralyzed by the budget deficit. The belief that new ideas invariably cost large sums of money has arrested the production of new ideas.
Still, the party has shown a perverse capacity to miss even low-cost opportunities to assert itself. One of the biggest issues confronting the present Congress is ethics in public life. Given the years of Reagan sleaze, the Democrats should be pressing hard for legislation that would reform a corrosive system of campaign financing and straighten out the matter of Congressional pay. They've done virtually nothing.
The capital gains mess is only the latest example of what seems to be terminal confusion. Here, at least, a few Democratic senators advanced admirable arguments. They identified Mr. Bush's capital gains tax cut as a gift to the rich that would have no lasting impact on the budget deficit and would violate the letter and spirit of the 1986 tax act.
This sensible philosophy found little echo in the House. Influential Democrats like Dan Rostenkowski actually endorsed a capital gains tax cut. A plausible alternative - restoring an I.R.A. deduction for all - arrived so late that it seemed more an act of legislative desperation than economic common sense and justice. And though many Democrats voted against the capital gains tax plan, a crucial 64 did not. The response to efforts to repeal catastrophic-health care was similarly flawed. Again, the Democrats failed to muster a coherent philosophical response. Again they waited too long before offering a less Draconian alternative. And again they suffered big defections.
One likely reason for this performance is that Congressmen generally have grown too comfortable with incumbency. In 409 House races in 1988 contested by incumbents of both parties, 402 won. And the winners apparently want to keep their jobs - even if it means, for Democrats, siding with Mr. Bush on important tests of party philosophy and discipline. Almost 40 percent of the Democrats from districts Mr. Bush carried in the 1988 campaign voted to cut capital gains taxes.
Yet incumbency ought to be a source of strength, a secure platform from which to project contentious ideas and a sense of priorities. It would also be useful if those ideas had some originality. When Mr. Bush announced his war on drugs, Senator Joseph Biden called for tax increases to expand it. The party chairman, Ronald Brown, swiftly rebuked Mr. Biden for resurrecting discredited ''tax and spend policies'' before laying out the programs he wanted the money for.
Mr. Brown was on to something. Winning the drug war will take money; the question is how to spend it and where to find it. And that means making tough and candid choices. Whether it's drugs or the homeless or a fair chance for children or defense, one sensible strategy for Democrats is to identify what's important to America's health and what isn't, and then to propose a wrenching readjustment of budget priorities.
Such an effort might reap surprising political rewards; even Mr. Bush's partisans seem concerned that he's caught in a time warp, excessively preoccupied with old challenges and insensitive to new ones. A recent Washington Post/ABC poll showed that Mr. Bush enjoyed wide popularity. It also revealed anxiety about his approach to problems like drugs and pollution. Similarly, a New York Times/CBS News Poll portrayed a public much less fearful than it was four years ago about nuclear war and Soviet relations, and much more concerned with the fabric of American life.
These findings may contain the seeds of a Democratic revival, for what they suggest is a developing national unease that America is misapplying its energies. To capitalize on this unease will require a huge effort by a party that seems long ago to have lost its bearings, an effort requiring candor, courage and above all conviction. The Democrats cannot earn public confidence without first restoring confidence in themselves.

HEADLINE: Benefits of Soviet Entry Into Tariff System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Keep Moscow Out of Gatt'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 17), Michael Samuels, former United States delegate to General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade meetings, correctly argues that the Soviet Union is not yet a market economy, but he incorrectly concludes that we must therefore keep it out of the GATT community.
As it happens, GATT has already admitted into its fold other centrally planned economies, including Czechoslovakia, Poland, Hungary, Rumania and Cuba. These countries were less market oriented at the time of their admission than would satisfy a purist. The objection to Soviet entry cannot therefore be one of principle. 
The key problem is that GATT membership would give centrally planned economies access to our markets, but in view of their reliance on planning and bureaucrats in place of markets and prices, such economies could not give us meaningful reciprocal access to their markets.
There is no altogether satisfactory solution to this problem. But with the other centrally planned economies admitted to GATT we have settled for their undertaking to increase overall imports by specified amounts annually. Why not do this equally for the Soviet Union?
This would bring Moscow closer to integration into the world economy and its institutions, strengthening the hands of the proponents of perestroika. Full Soviet readiness to allow imports rests on the speed with which the Soviet economy can generate exports. The process, in turn, requires successful price reform and a convertible ruble, both inevitably slow.
If GATT entry were also to stipulate a realistic time schedule in which Moscow would assume market-economy-style obligations and offer foreigners free access to its markets, that too would serve to hasten continuing reform of the Soviet foreign trading system.
To ask the Soviet Union to wait for GATT entry until perestroika reforms are complete is to put the cart before the horse. Beginning in 1948, when GATT became effective, we did not insist on this requirement for countries of Western Europe. They took nearly a decade to restore their war-devastated economies and return to the currency convertibility that is necessary for insuring effective market access.
We did not require it of the developing countries either, giving them special and differential treatment so that they enjoyed GATT rights and had few obligations until they were ready to handle them.
Does Mikhail S. Gorbachev, engaged in a Herculean effort whose outcome concerns us all, deserve any less?
 
PADMA DESAI
Professor of Economics
Columbia University
 New York, Sept. 20, 1989
