HEADLINE: Yugoslav Chief to See Bush and Seek His Support

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ante Markovic is to arrive in Washington on Monday to ask President Bush's support for the economic program that he hopes will pull Yugoslavia out of its long crisis of hyperinflation, high unemployment, a steadily declining standard of living and a crippling foreign debt.
But Mr. Markovic made clear in an interview in his office that Yugoslavia, unlike Poland and Hungary, has no immediate plan for coupling economic renewal with an end to one-party rule. He appeared irritated when asked a question that grieves liberal Yugoslavs as they watch Hungary and Poland, two nations that remain firmly in the Soviet orbit, advance toward parliamentary democracy:
Will Yugoslavia, which broke from the Soviet Union in 1948 and has long been the most open Communist nation, loosen the rule of the Communist Party over its political life?
Except for recently formed minority parties in the most Westernized constituent republics of Croatia and Slovenia - parties that are tolerated without being legal - Communists control organized political life either directly through the party or through a catch-all organization, the Socialist Alliance, which is fully in the party's hands. All important public offices are reserved for Communists. 
''Yugoslavia had free candidacies and free elections in earlier years, when no one would have dreamed of such things in those countries,'' Mr. Markovic said testily, referring to Poland and Hungary. ''There can be no development of the political system without developing the economic system, or vice-versa. Our experience tells us that superficial changes in one or the other are no guarantee of substantive change of lasting nature.''
The Prime Minister said he did not mean to characterize Polish or Hungarian restructuring as superficial. Multiple-candidate elections have long been held in Yugoslavia, but all candidates have the blessing of the Socialist Alliance and represent no opposition forces.
Mr. Markovic avoided replying directly to questions on whether he favored the creation of independent parties, but hinted at the reasons for his reticence when asked whether he shared the view that in this multi-national country a multi-party system would produce parties along nationality lines and heighten ethnic tensions.
''That could easily be the case,'' he said. ''Our reality is very complex. We are one country with two alphabets, three religions, four languages, five nationalities, six republics and 23 million incorrigible individualists.'' Nationalist tensions in Yugoslavia are believed by experts on Eastern and Central Europe to be even more dangerous than those in the Soviet Union. The nationalities are more evenly balanced in numbers and the Belgrade Government lacks the strong central power of Moscow. The six component republics and two provinces wield considerably more authority than the Soviet republics and regions.
As Prime Minister, Mr. Markovic has authority covering largely the conception and execution, over much resistance from the republics, of economic policy.
He said that although many of the economic indicators were negative and worse could be expected, his Government had a framework to apply the laws of the market to the collective Communist economy. ''We came to the conclusion that, the market being an achievement of our civilization, it is irreplacable, and we accept that now.''
The Prime Minister said that inflation stood at more than 800 percent over the last 12 months, and that 1.1 million of the work force of 6.5 million were unemployed. But he said progress was being made in reducing the foreign debt, reported to be close to $20 billion, raising convertible-currency reserves and increasing productivity and exports.
In his meetings with Mr. Bush, Cabinet members, leaders of international lending institutions, bankers and businessmen, Mr. Markovic said, he would urge support for joint ventures in Yugoslavia, more transfer of Western technology, advantages for Yugoslav exports and help with management training.

HEADLINE: Albany Gets Private Offer To Purchase Its Airport

BYLINE: By CARL H. LAVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 6

 BODY:
While virtually every American airport served by scheduled airliners is publicly owned, Albany County is considering an unusual offer by a private group to buy its 61-year-old airport.
If the deal goes through, other airports may follow suit.
The private proposal to the Albany County Legislature comes from a group that wants to buy or lease the airfield, the gateway to the capital region and the Adirondacks. Aviation experts said that the investors would be the first to gain control of a large public airport and that public agencies in other states would probably jump at the chance to do the same thing, thereby bolstering budgets while escaping the headaches of managing a complicated transportation resource.
 
Problems Also for Sale
''This is indeed novel,'' said Quentin S. Taylor, the top airport official at the Federal Aviation Administration. 
More is at stake than just the name on the airport sign.
Free enterprise advocates say private ownership could solve knotty problems that limit airport expansion and contribute to delays, crowding and safety concerns. ''The natural solution is the privatization of airports,'' said Bernard F. Conners, chairman of British American, a local real-estate company that, together with Lockheed Air Terminal Inc., hopes to buy or lease the airport.
Airport officials in Peoria, Ill., and Los Angeles are already talking about similar deals. Lockheed Air Terminal, a subsidiary of the Lockheed Corporation, has almost finished a privately owned international terminal in Toronto.
Two years ago Albany's County Executive, James J. Coyne, proposed selling the airfield to a public transportation agency that operates buses in four counties here. Negotiations for that sale at $24.25 million were near completion this summer when British American offered $30 million.
The private group presented another choice, too: a 40-year lease that could ultimately bring the county three times as much money. Under it, the county would get $25.5 million right away, $24.5 million more over 40 years, and $40 million more for the next 40 years if the lease were renewed.
Each concern said it would invest more than $100 million in the terminal, expanding and adding jetways that enable passengers to board planes without going outside. Despite Albany's winters, the nine-gate airport here has only two jetways.
Critics of the deal, including a local business development group, insist that only a public agency would represent the diverse interests catered to by a commercial airport. And they say that a private airport operator would lose eligibility for Federal money. ''Are we going to be the guinea pig and risk the loss of whatever quality development we need?'' said Kenneth C. Wagner, director of the Center for Economic Growth, an nonprofit group financed by businesses here.
Airlines worry that a private operator may cut services to increase profits. USAir, which carries about a third of the two million passengers flying into and out of Albany each year, said it favored the bus company's offer, which would keep the field in public hands.
The F.A.A. is studying whether a private operator would remain eligible for grants, Mr. Taylor said. An answer, expected this month, will open the way to a decision by the County Legislature.
''The primary thing that we are interested in is that the facility continue to be available to the flying public,'' Mr. Taylor said. ''We want to protect our investment.''
 
Cash Squeeze for County
While Washington wrestles with eligibility questions, county officials in Albany say their top concern is getting the most from the deal.
Mr. Coyne said his preliminary 1990 budget, due to be released Tuesday, would include income from the sale or lease of the airport. ''Raising property taxes is the only other alternative,'' he said.
Much of the cash squeeze comes from cuts in Federal and state contributions and a big cost overrun for a new stadium in downtown Albany.
Not far from the new stadium, Frank J. Commisso stood at the counter of his deli, serving up Gorgonzola cheese, fresh linguini and an ode to private enterprise. As head of the mass-transit committee of the County Legislature, he could be the deciding voice in the debate over the airport.
If the decision rests heavily on his shoulders, he doesn't show it as he tells customers short of cash to pay him next time and answers questions about the airport.
''I'd like to see it go to British American Lockheed,'' Mr. Commisso said. ''They will cater to the passenger trade.''
He said a lease would allow the county to retain the land for generations. ''I'm sure my children will be saying 40 years from now, 'Hey, dad, we didn't think that you knew so much, but this is really worth something.' ''
He said he was still concerned about the job security of airport workers, the cleanup of fuel spills that have tainted the ground under the field and the ability of British American Lockheed to obtain grants. These topics will be on the table when the transit committee meets Wednesday, he said.
 
Public Ownership Backed
Dennis J. Fitzgerald, executive director of the Capital District Transportation Authority, manages bus operations in four counties and is ready to take over the airport, he said. He is proud of the authority's 60-cent fare, the lowest in the state, he said, and is sure his agency could do a good job with the airport.
''The primary role of public officials is to serve the public,'' Mr. Fitzgerald said. ''Does a private owner and manager have that same accountability to the public?''
''We're counting on reinvesting everything made at the airport in the airport,'' he added in a dig at the profit-hungry private sector.
Mr. Conners has a quick response. ''The profit motive isn't always that bad,'' he said as a maid served coffee in his English manor house just outside Albany. ''That's what our whole economy is based on.''
Or almost the whole economy, noted his partner, Viggo M. Butler, president of Lockheed Air Terminal. ''When someone goes on a trip,'' Mr. Butler said, ''everything they come in contact with is provided by private entities -the bus or limousine, the airplane, the airline - except the airport. And the airport's always underfinanced.''
 
Large Expansions Lag
While Lockheed manages other public airports, including Stewart and Republic in New York State, it does not have a stake in the finances of those fields. Public airport expansions are financed with a delicate blend of airline leases, bond issues and Federal grants, and are further shaped by environmental restrictions and neighborhood sensitivites.
Traffic increases, tight budgets and sprawling development have made huge expansions more difficult. No large new airports have opened in the United States since Dallas-Fort Worth in 1974, although Denver received Federal approval last month for a new airport after years of public debate. Dozens of airport operators have found it impossible to expand as fast as the air travel market has grown since deregulation began in 1978.
Most of an airport's budget usually comes from concession rentals and airline fees. Operating losses are usually made up by the airlines, and any surpluses are used to improve the field or to reduce airline fees the next year. Agencies that take Federal airport grants are prohibited from using any surplus for non-aviation projects.
One big question Albany County has for the F.A.A. is about the status of any lease payments. Mr. Taylor said the agency was near a decision on whether those payments could be used in the county's general budget.

GRAPHIC: Bernard F. Conners, chairman of British American, at the Albany County airport, which his company has offered to buy or lease. ''The natural solution is the privatization of airports,'' he said. (NYT/David Jennings)

HEADLINE: Rising Taxes Are Issue In Jersey Shore District

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OCEAN TOWNSHIP, N.J., Oct. 6

 BODY:
The green lawns of many homes in the 11th Assembly District along the Jersey Shore are festooned these days with ''for sale'' signs.
The string of small beachfront communities from Sandy Hook south to the Manasquan inlet were once summer resorts whose housing ranged from unheated bungalows to mansions to huge wood-frame hotels. The seasonal population gave way to permanent residents after the Garden State Parkway opened in the 1950's, but most of the jobs remained in the urban north. The communities had to rely on taxes on the new residents' homes to pay for added services and schools. 
The growth in these taxes has placed home ownership out of the reach of many young couples looking for their first home and is squeezing many longtime residents whose incomes are unable to keep pace with the growth in taxes.
 
'Can't Afford to Live Here'
''They should just put a for-sale sign on the whole state,'' said Maria Bertucci, owner of Maria's Colonial Inn in Manasquan. ''People can't afford to live here any longer.
''When I see regular customers who haven't been around for a while, they tell me they've moved to Virginia or South Carolina, where they can build or buy a bigger home than they could afford here,'' she said.
The campaign for the district's State Senate seat and two Assembly seats has focused on environmental concerns linked to ocean pollution that has fouled area beaches in recent summers and on abortion and automobile insurance. But evidence of the migration out of the area is forcing the tax issue into the campaign.
''As I go around, I meet people who tell me they are leaving the state because of high taxes and auto insurance rates, and that bothers me,'' said Assemblyman Joseph A. Palaia, a Republican who is running for the State Senate seat that became vacant last November when Senator Frank Pallone won a special election to Congress.
''The quickest way to reduce property taxes is to fully fund state aid to education,'' Assemblyman Palaia said. ''School costs make up half or more of local budgets.''
 
A Former Teacher
Mr. Palaia, a former teacher and school principal, is chairman of the Assembly Education Committee and is campaigning on his sponsorship of a bill that would put state aid to local schools on a current year basis, instead of the present system that reimburses towns for increases in school costs the following year.
He said this change would cost the state $247 million and should be phased in over three years, starting with the poorest school districts.
The level of state funds is set initially by the governor when he submits his budget to the Legislature, and Gov. Thomas H. Kean has fully financed the state school aid formula in only one of his eight years, in 1985 when he ran for re-election and the state's economy was booming.
Mr. Kean has increased state school aid each year but has said the formula is outstripping the state's ability to finance it and should be revised.
Democrats said the 62-year-old Mr. Palaia must shoulder his share of the blame for the level of aid because of his committee chairmanship.
Mr. Palaia's two Republican running mates in the Assembly race are making their first bids for state office. Paul A. Kapalko, 35, is a lawyer and former Asbury Park Councilman, and Dr. Dennis G. Sternberg, 40, is a dentist and environmental advocate who in 1986 helped found the Save Our Shores organization that gave voice to growing public concerns over ocean pollution.
 
Democratic Ticket
The Democratic ticket is headed by John D'Amico, a former Oceanport Councilman and Monmouth County Freeholder who was appointed to fill the Senate vacancy left by Mr. Pallone. The Assembly candidates are an incumbent, John A. Villapiano, 38, a former County Freeholder who won a special election to fill an Assembly vacancy in September 1988, and Daniel P. Jacobson, 27, an Ocean Township Councilman.
''This campaign is a microcosm of the governor's race,'' Mr. D'Amico said. ''Essentially, I've taken the same positions as Florio on the major issues, abortion, auto insurance, the environment and gun control, and my opponent has taken positions similar to Courter's.'' Representatives James J. Florio, a Democrat, and Jim Courter, a Republican, are opposing each other in the race for governor.
In the Assembly race, the Democratic campaign literature mentions Mr. Florio, who Mr. Courter has conceded is leading in their race, while the Republican campaign literature does not mention Mr. Courter.
''As long as Florio keeps rolling along, I'll be happy,'' said Jay Neel, the Democrats' legislative campaign manager for the district.
While Dr. Sternberg probably has the highest public profile as an environmental advocate, he has not been endorsed by any environmental organization. Allan Willinger, chairman of the Sierra Club's Committee on Political Action, said the organization felt Dr. Sternberg was ''a single-issue candidate.'' But it did endorse Mr. Kapalko for his work on commissions that worked to clean up two lakes in Asbury Park, and it also endorsed Mr. D'Amico for his sponsorship of the Natural Resources Trust Fund bill and Mr. Jacobson for his efforts to preserve open space in his hometown.
Mr. Jacobson said the Sierra Club endorsement and another by the Vote Environment Committee were vital to Democratic hopes of victory. ''And this is not just an endorsement - there will be a green army of volunteers knocking on doors,'' he said.
 
'Yelling and Screaming'
Dr. Sternberg, who has advised Mr. Kean on ocean pollution programs, said, ''I've been yelling and screaming from the back of the room about pollution problems for 10 years, and now I want the opportunity to help pass the laws that will solve the problem.''
All the candidates say changes in the state's tax system must be made to reduce reliance on property taxes. ''We have to make sure living in New Jersey is still affordable and stop losing population to other states,'' Mr. Villipiano said. ''If our unemployment rate and interest rates go up even a little bit, a lot more people will be in trouble.''
Residents of the district have other concerns. Barbara Ruane, a waitress at the Old Orchard Inn in Eatontown, said she was upset by high auto insurance costs and has lost her desire to swim in the ocean near her home because of the pollution problems, but her primary concern is for the homeless.
''There should be more state funding to provide housing for the homeless, and some research to find out exactly how big the problem is,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Farmer's Apples Aren't Pretty, and She Likes Them That Way

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILTON, N.Y., Oct. 6

 BODY:
For Amy Hepworth, a fruit grower here, a shiny red apple without a single blemish is a sign of an unhealthy agriculture.
Miss Hepworth operates a 300-acre fruit and vegetable farm without spraying the pesticides other commercial growers normally use to produce apples and other fruit without unsightly marks.
She describes herself as an ecological farmer who tries to do as little damage to the environment as possible. That means forgoing synthetic chemicals if possible, but using them if she believes they are less harmful to fruit, trees and soil than natural sprays. 
Even though growing fruit that way is expensive and labor-intensive, the biggest problem Miss Hepworth faces is that most consumers reject blemished apples despite a public concern about pesticides and food safety.
 
Accepting Blemishes
''Consumers want 100-percent-perfect fruit,'' she said.''The farmer cannot decrease his use of chemicals unless the consumer will accept some cosmetic blemishes on fruit. Those blemishes have no effect on flavor or quality. The consumer will have to change his idea of what fruit looks like if he wants pesticide-free food.''
Miss Hepworth, who is 29 years old, is in the forefront of a major change in American agriculture in which many farmers are trying to minimize the use of chemicals through a program called integrated pest management.
In a study made public last month, the National Academy of Sciences endorsed chemical-free farming after a 17-member panel of experts concluded it can often be just as productive and more profitable than farming with chemicals.
Miss Hepworth grows organically -without using chemicals - on about 80 acres, which yield fruit with black marks. She grows ecologically - with as few chemicals as possible - on about 170 acres, which yield almost blemish-free fruit. She also has about 20 acres in organic vegetables like carrots and onions.
 
Methods Viewed With Skepticism
Because she uses some chemicals, she is not a certified organic farmer. That does not bother her, she said, because she thinks the rigid requirements of organic farming are unrealistic for commercial operations.
In the farm belt of the Hudson Valley, Miss Hepworth's methods are viewed with considerable skepticism, said Warren Smith, the fruit expert of the Cooperative Extension Service of Cornell University.
''I admire what she is doing, but I don't think she can make an economic success of it,'' he said.
In integrated pest management, farmers first use pest-resistant plants and biological controls for insects and then monitor their crops for damage before resorting to chemical sprays. A recent survey by Cornell reported that 80 percent of New York growers were using some form of integrated pest management.
 
Safety Biggest Concern
Safety is the biggest reason for concern about the use of synthetic pesticides. This year, for example, Alar, a chemical used to keep apples on trees longer, until they can be picked, was withdrawn from the market after consumer objections and reports that it might be a carcinogen.
Unlike most other commercial growers, Miss Hepworth does not use artificial fertilizers or weed-killers. She spreads organic matter as fertilizer and feeds trees with a leaf spray of kelp, bone meal and rock dust.
She uses various forms of spores and soap to control predators like aphids, mites, leaf rollers and psylla. When apples are picked, she does not use dips to kill fungus growth or wax to enhance shine.
Despite her largely organic methods, Miss Hepworth rejects some predator controls recommended by the organic movement.
 
Using Some Chemicals
For example, she disapproves of spraying sulfur on trees seven to 12 times a growing season to control primary scab. ''The sulfur spray is harsh and acidifies the soil, which is detrimental to the land,'' she said.
Instead, she uses a synthetic fungicide called Rubigan. ''It's highly specific, it's biodegradable, it's benign, it has been released by the Environmental Protection Agency after 17 years of testing and you use much less of it than sulfur,'' she said.
Miss Hepworth's apples and vegetables fill scores of baskets labeled ''ecological'' at the stand in front of her farm here on Route 9W in the heart of the fruit area of Ulster County. The farm, owned by her mother, Lois, has been in the family since 1818.
Apples labeled ''ecological'' were free of marks, but there were few apples at the stand that were grown organically, because they were covered with black marks left by fungus disease. Miss Hepworth sells most of her organic production to wholesalers who supply natural food stores.
 
Wholesale Operation Unprofitable
So far, she said, consumers who will accept the blemished fruit are few and far between. She has about 15,000 bushels of McIntosh apples, almost 15 percent of her total production, that she has been unable to sell.
Despite the skepticism about her methods, Miss Hepworth, who started to reduce chemical use on her farm eight years ago, is not discouraged. Although the farm's wholesale operation is not profitable, she keeps going through sales at the farm stand, which is operated by her mother, and a cider mill.
She said she believes in trying to minimize chemical use to maintain healthy land and food.
''As an ecological grower, I believe in doing everything possible organically,'' she said. ''But I also believe in using technology for the betterment of the planet.''

HEADLINE: Opera Musicians Reject Pact

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
The orchestra of the New York City Opera, which has been on strike since Sept. 13, voted 56 to 4 on Saturday to reject the company's latest proposal. The vote was tabulated yesterday. The rejection increases the possibility of a cancellation of the rest of the company's season, scheduled to run until Nov. 19. Martin J. Oppenheimer, vice chairman of the City Opera board and its chief labor negotiator, said yesterday that the company's ''key players'' would meet tomorrow morning. The City Opera had given the orchestra until yesterday to agree to a settlement, after which it said it would cancel the rest of the season. 
By ''key players'' he meant himself; Robert W. Wilson, the board chairman; Christopher Keene, the general director, and other members of the administrative staff.
John Palanchian, a City Opera violinist for 22 years and vice president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, which represents the orchestra, said yesterday that the musicians were fully prepared for a cancellation announcement.
 
'They're Not Going to Work'
''This was a vote taken with the secure knowledge that the season is over,'' Mr. Palanchian said.
The company's proposal came late Friday evening at the end of an eight-hour bargaining session, the first to include Timothy Germany of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.
The musicians have been seeking wage increases of more than 20 percent, to achieve parity with the orchestras of the Lyric Opera of Chicago and the San Francisco Opera.
In its Friday offer, the company abandoned its effort to eliminate six weeks beyond the regular 23-week season in which it has been providing the musicians either full employment or half-pay supplemental income. The proposal was for a four-year pact (as opposed to the normal three years) with a 5 1/2 percent wage increase each year (and an additional 1 percent that could be applied to wages, but would almost definitely go to shore up the welfare fund instead).
Mr. Palanchian said yesterday that a 5 1/2 percent wage increase not only failed to address the goal of parity, but was also actually one-half of 1 percentage point under the current inflation rate.
Asked if the season could still be revived after a cancellation notice, Mr. Oppenheimer indicated that the season might be saved if a compromise could be reached quickly.

HEADLINE: A Debate On Controls Of Exports

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Faced with calls for increased economic cooperation with Poland and Hungary, the Bush Administration is under growing pressure from its European allies, led by West Germany, to allow the export of sophisticated machine tools to Communist countries.
The debate is complicated by the position of American makers of machine tools, who sense an expanding market and are generally taking the European side.
But the Bush Administration is worried that enforcement of export controls is lagging. So great are its concerns that President Bush sent letters to allied leaders in September urging them to tighten procedures aimed at keeping high technology with military applications from falling into Communist hands, Administration officials said. 
 
Maintaining Export Curbs
The Atlantic debate exemplifies the problems the Western industrial nations and Japan will face in trying to maintain export curbs in the 1990's.
The controls are managed by the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, or Cocom. The organization, based in Paris, was formed more than 40 years ago, when the cold war had just begun, and now consists of 17 nations.
Machine tools are essentially machines that make other machines. The more advanced are computer-operated, with a dozen or more cutting axes, or cutting directions, and are able to shape metal to an accuracy of a ten-thousandth of an inch.
Such versatile precision machines have been a focus of Cocom for two years, since the Toshiba Machine Company of Japan and Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk of Norway illegally sold the Soviet Union advanced tools that could be used to build silent submarine propellers.
The European complaint is that the Cocom tool controls have not been liberalized in 15 years. While the group bans export of tools like those that may have helped to strengthen the Soviet Navy, it catches in the same net many other tools that are far less sophisticated, of the type already manufactured to some extent in East Germany and in newly industrialized countries like Taiwan and South Korea.
 
Demands for Technology
At the same time, demands for more advanced technology to reshape the economies of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union are spurring industries in West Germany and other industrial countries, unhappy with any type of export controls, to press their governments to liberalize the rules.
There are strong economic incentives. About 45 percent of West German machine tool exports, excluding shipments to East Germany, end up in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.
The Soviet Union alone imports about $1 billion a year worth of machine tools from industrial countries. The West Germans account for up to 40 percent of the Soviet market, industry officials say, and the Japanese about 10 percent. American sales are a paltry $1 million to $3 million a year.
Yet the United States industry expects improved exports as well, and is becoming a strong force for liberalization in Washington. ''The important thing is to have a level of technology that reflects reality,'' said Jim Mack, spokesman for the National Machine Tool Builders Association, which represents the industry. ''To assume that other people are going to control the day-before-yesterday's technology is nuts.''
 
Call for Cooperation
In Bonn, Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich Genscher said last week in a radio interview: ''We have to assist the reform-oriented countries via comprehensive cooperation. This means economic and technological cooperation. It means assistance to help in modernizing their agriculture. It also means to give expertise, exchange of experts, transfer of technology and examination of the Cocom list.''
Bonn's aim, noted Hans-Henning Horstmann, spokesman at the West German Embassy in Washington, is ''to trim the Cocom lady to what the French would call a mannequin to suit the policies of today.''
He added, ''In an age where via dialogue and cooperation we try to assist reform processes in Poland, Hungary and the U.S.S.R., Cocom is outdated.''
Washington's response has been to press the allies to commit to better enforcement, while maintaining an open position on streamlining the embargo list.
One problem, officials said, is that enforcement is not uniform. The allies do not have in place the kind of rigorous bureaucratic system for controlling exports that the United States uses.
When there is ambiguity in the regulations, American officials point out, the Europeans and Japanese tend to rule in favor of allowing the export, while in Washington there is probably a greater tendency to deny it.
 
'Torrent' of Actions
In a recent study, the Center for Security Policy, a Washington-based policy research group that reflects hard-line Pentagon thinking, called for ''an immediate moratorium on the torrent of decontrol actions now being proposed.''
In recognition of the high stakes, the President himself has intervened. His letter to the allied leaders, one Administration official said, expressed the view that ''we're very concerned and we need to reach agreement on compliance, enforcement and streamlining.''
Still, no one is predicting an early agreement. As one American official put it, ''There is every chance of a major confrontation.'' At a Cocom meeting in Paris on Thursday and Friday, American officials again resisted the European and Japanese calls for liberalization.
 
Next Round of Debate
The next round of the debate among higher-level officials will be in Paris on Oct. 25 and 26. The American negotiating team will be led by Reginald Bartholomew, Under Secretary of State for coordinating security assistance programs; Paul D. Wolfowitz, Under Secretary for defense policy, and Dennis E. Kloske, Under Secretary of Commerce for export administration.
One possible outcome that officials have been discussing is the establishment of a special category for Poland and Hungary, relaxing restrictions more for them than for the Soviet Union and other countries of Eastern Europe.
In 1985, Cocom made such a concession for China, then in the throes of economic reform, to differentiate it from other Communist countries.

HEADLINE: Cargo Boom Causes Plane Shortage

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Sharp growth in cargo shipments by air is producing a shortage of freighter aircraft around the world. Companies with freight to ship are having trouble finding planes on short notice, and freight rates have begun to rise.
Air-freight carriers seeking more capacity have placed new orders with aircraft manufacturers, which might be slow to respond because of large backlogs of passenger-plane orders. Indeed, the Boeing Company has delayed until 1993 the scheduled initial deliveries of its giant 747-400 freighters. If a strike by the company's 58,000 machinists that began on Wednesday lasts a long time, even that timetable may slip.
In the meantime, freight carriers are bidding up the price of used planes and refitting those that had been in passenger service at a cost that can run to $18 million each. 
 
Economic Expansion a Factor
Demand for fast transportation has grown worldwide, with air-freight movements increasing by a third in the last three years. Industry experts attribute the expansion to prolonged growth in the global economy, burgeoning exports from the United States and the growing tendency of companies producing parts in one country and assembling them in another.
So severe has the shortage of planes become that when the Defense Department began a 160-flight effort to deliver food, electric generators and communications equipment to communities devastated by Hurricane Hugo last month, its sudden need for cargo planes snarled United States military air transportation around the globe.
Altogether, more than 100 military air transport missions were postponed because no civilian air freighters were available for charter to replace military transports abruptly diverted, a spokesman for the Military Airlift Command said. The planes were needed not only in the hurricane relief effort but for moving equipment to Colombia for the effort against drug traffickers.
''The air carriers are at 100 percent, or near that, and can't pull an aircraft,'' said Col. Ronald N. Priddy, the command's assistant for civilian air operations. ''Most of our major peacetime exercises suffer somewhat.''
While the growth in air freight will likely prompt the manufacture of additional planes, giving the military access to more aircraft for mobilization in wartime, the current shortage makes it difficult for the Defense Department to find planes on short notice now, said Colonel Priddy. ''Almost on a daily basis we run into that problem,'' he said.
 
Foreign Factories Affected
Civilian shipping agents are also having trouble finding planes. Hemisphere Forwarding Inc., a Long Island-based shipper, was recently asked to fly a 9.5-ton piece of factory equipment to Bombay, India, but could not, said Morton Brautman, the president and chief executive.
''It was too high to fit in the passenger planes and there was no cargo plane available,'' he said. ''So they had to send it by ship, which can take a month.''
Factories in underdeveloped countries often have to shut when they cannot obtain delivery of key equipment, Mr. Brautman added.
In a sign of how tight the supply of freighters is, the cost on scheduled freighter flights from the eastern United States to East Asia in September approached that of a special charter flight for the first time in recent years, said Fumiaki Niizeka, vice president for Japan Air Lines's cargo operations in the West.
J.A.L. raised its rates to Japan to $1.10 a pound, from 90 cents, on Oct. 1, Mr. Niizeka said, adding that this particular decision reflected strong demand rather than a lack of planes at the carrier. The higher rates make it less profitable for American companies to export.
On the other hand, the cost of freight moving by air from East Asia to the United States is more than double that for goods moving the opposite direction - reflecting the United State's huge appetite for imports.
 
Increased Production Expected
Although Boeing declines to commit itself, industry experts expect the company to produce the $120 million 747-400 freighter jet on an accelerated schedule, which would likely end the current shortage. Boeing had delayed production of the freighter in order to address a larger-than-anticipated demand for the passenger version, a spokeswoman said.
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation delivered its last DC-10 freighter in July, and will start delivering a successor, the MD-11F, in 1991, a company spokesman said. Airbus Industrie, a European consortium based in Toulouse, France, is a small player in the freighter market, having produced only six freighters and convertible freighter-passenger planes out of its total production of 550 aircraft over the last 15 years, a spokesman said. Airbus is not currently producing freighters or convertibles.
In the meantime, Boeing is setting up a plant in Wichita, Kan., to convert passenger 747's into freighters beginning next year. The process consists of removing the passenger-cabin interior, cutting a 10-foot-by-11-foot side door, and installing a stronger floor and cargo handling equipment. The plant already has six orders - two from established air shippers and four from latecomers to the international air freight business, Evergreen International Aviation Inc., with three planes ordered, and United Parcel Service Inc., with one on order.
Pemco Aeroplex Inc., a subsidiary of Denver-based Precision Standard Inc., has already converted several 747's and has several more on the way, said Walter F. Moede, the senior vice president and chief financial officer of Precision Standard. In addition, he said, ''there are a lot of 727's being done.''
But a converted passenger jet has several limitations, especially in moving large or heavy cargo, said G. Antoine Girot, the deputy vice president for cargo of Air France. ''It hasn't got the same lift, it hasn't got a nose door - it's not adequate,'' he said.
Air France placed a $600 million order last month for five Boeing 747-400 freighters, becoming the first airline to do so. Ten other airlines have had serious discussions with Boeing about buying the new plane, the aircraft manufacturer said.
 
Value Increases With Age
The limited supply of aircraft has meant that planes, unlike most cars, are increasing in value as they age. The quoted price for a Boeing 747-200 freighter built in 1979 is now $65 million, compared with an initial delivery price 10 years ago of $40 million, said William B. Kilerlane, the director of appraisals at Avmark Inc., an aircraft brokerage in Rosslyn, Va. Yet few planes are changing hands even at the quoted price because current owners need them.
The current order backlog at major aircraft manufacturers is also making it harder for carriers to order spare parts for aircraft no longer in production. The Airborne Freight Corporation, a Seattle-based shipper, began milling its own spare parts for aging DC-8's and DC-9's a year and a half ago after learning that McDonnell Douglas could take as long as five years to do the job, said Graham E. Dorland, the chairman of ABX Air Inc., Airborne's air operations and package-sorting subsidiary. ''If they cannot supply us with a part, they supply us with an engineering diagram,'' he said.
Recent increases in air freight rates may in part reflect the continued use of older, inefficient aircraft by carriers unable to acquire more modern equipment, said Edwin C. Laird, of the Air Cargo Management Group, a Seattle consulting concern.
Other experts disagree. The higher depreciation costs associated with buying new planes may balance out the greater operating costs of older planes, said R. Lawrence Hughes, a senior vice president and director of the DHL Corporation, an express-package shipper.
Two circumstances have prevented the shortage of aircraft from becoming even more severe. One is that much of the growth in worldwide air freight has come on flights from the United States that until recently had a lot of extra space.
''This is really an exceptional time in air cargo, when carriers are flying good loads in both directions,'' said William H. Clarke of Airline Economics, a Washington consulting concern.
The other circumstance is that passenger airlines still have plenty of room in the bellies of their aircraft on some routes for hauling cargo as well as travelers' baggage. As much as three-quarters of the cargo capacity aboard some American Airlines passenger jets is unused. The problem is that this extra space exists mostly on domestic routes, that passenger flight schedules often don't meet the demands of shippers and that some cargoes might pose a hazard to passengers.

HEADLINE: Business Near Victory on Worker Benefits

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Led by an army of inflamed small-business owners, the nation's 3.5 million employers are on the verge of a sweeping legislative triumph that would free them of what are widely acknowledged as overly burdensome regulations governing health-insurance and other employee benefits.
Whether approved as part of omnibus budget legislation or as a separate measure, repeal of intricate rules forcing employers to prove each year that their benefit plans do not discriminate in favor of senior management at the expense of the rank and file is almost certain to be signed by President Bush, and soon.
''Section 89 and all its descendants and siblings are pretty thoroughly dead,'' declared Edward Thomas Veal, a senior manager in the Washington office of Touche, Ross & Company, the accounting firm. Section 89 of the tax code would impose administrative requirements on corporate America that even its authors now admit were ''wildly too complex'' in the words of one aide to the House Ways and Means Committee. 
 
Growing Rebellion
The provisions, which initially received little attention, are contained in the huge 1986 overhaul of the tax law, but they have yet to be applied. For various reasons, including legislative refinement, it took until this March before the Internal Revenue Service could issue hundreds of pages of regulations to enforce the provision and the growing rebellion has prompted repeated postponement in bringing them to bear on business. The provisions were supposed to take effect at the beginning of 1989.
Conceived in the Reagan Administration's Treasury and supported heavily by Democrats, Section 89 is likely to be recorded as one of the more egregious examples of how the Government's execution of a well-intentioned idea threatened to produce the opposite results. Many employers, especially smaller ones, said they would drop benefit plans rather than hire the help needed to meet the paperwork requirements.
With employers able to deduct the cost of such fringe benefits as health insurance and group life insurance from their income taxes - at a cost to the Treasury of an estimated $38 billion a year - a main goal of Section 89 was to prevent companies from setting their plans up in a way that gives disproportionate advantages to senior executives. The rank-and-file, in other words, should get a reasonable share of a public subsidy.
 
Variety of Goals
Other goals were to encourage companies to provide fringe benefit-packages to the 37 million Americans without them, and to raise revenue.
By this spring, however, the complexity of the requirements had inspired such a backlash from the United States Chamber of Commerce, the National Federation of Independent Business and others that a majority of the House was co-sponsoring a bill for repeal. The measure was initiated by John J. LaFalce, Democrat of Buffalo, and head of the House Committee on Small Business.
After various efforts by Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, to find a compromise, the House voted 390 to 36 in late September to scrap the rules. The Senate, where a similar measure has committee approval, is expected to follow.
 
'We'll Be Back to Fight'
Speculation has already begun about what may happen when the issue resurfaces, probably by spring. Mr. Rostenkowski, though badly bruised on this and other tax issues this year, vowed just before the House repeal vote to try again. ''Section 89 may go away, but the issue of fundamental health-care protection for rank-and-file Americans will not,'' he pledged. ''We'll be back to fight again another day.''
Most business groups and other opponents of Section 89 - there is almost no organized support - agree there will be new challenges.
''No issue ever goes away,'' said John L. Norman, national director of taxation at Pannell Kerr Forster, an accounting firm. He thinks one of the first efforts may involve ending tax benefits for plans for executives only.
But other ideas abound, with legislators likely to be drawn to those that could raise significant revenue. The notion of a simple levy on benefits received can probably be ruled out -imagine sending somebody who has just had open-heart surgery an extra tax bill - but Congress could decide to tax individuals for the premiums used to provide specific benefits.
Or the Government can limit the amount of benefits companies can deduct from their taxable income.
 
'Jammed on the Accelerator'
In addition to raising money, any levy that would discourage overuse of insured health care would serve the broader purpose of curbing demands on the nation's medical system and thereby counter inflation. The fact that health premiums are tax free -compensation better than cash -means ''we have our foot jammed on the accelerator,'' an aide to the Senate Finance Committee said.
''There are going to be attempts to tax employee benefits,'' said Sharon Canner, an industrial relations specialist for the National Association of Manufacturers. With a proposal now circulating for taxing pension funds, even the status of health benefits seems threatened, analysts suggest.
Nor is Mr. Rostenkowski likely to find it difficult to find supporters for a practical way to achieve the anti-discrimination goal. Some, however, question how big a problem this is apart from corporations of lawyers, doctors and other professionals.

The First Constitution Financial Corporation has agreed to be taken private by a group of New York investors at a price of $25 a share, or a total of $275 million.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Funds Cautious On Hong Kong

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
SIR PIERS JACOBS, Hong Kong's financial secretary, is out ''beating the drum'' for the bustling market at China's door.
In New York, London and Paris last week, the No. 3 man in the Government worked to counter the the negative impact of June's massacre in Bejing's Tiananmen Square.
But the victory by the hard-liners in Bejing has raised some serious doubts among foreign investors who had been bullish on Hong Kong. And this attitude will affect the way the market is viewed until China's intentions are much clearer. 
Several international funds are scaling back their exposure in Hong Kong. They are now looking at the market, said Gavin Dobson of Murray Johnstone International Ltd., as a trading market in which to see an opportunity and get in and get out quickly. The long-term view, for him, has become less attractive.
The stocks these funds are looking at are also different. The funds are moving away from companies with large property holdings, which had been popular. If there is a problem with China, property values will drop the fastest. Even with the recovery since June, prices are 10 percent to 15 percent below where they were, economists say.
''We see quite a lot of potential if developments in China are reasonable,'' said David J. Warren, executive vice president of Rowe, Price, Fleming International in London. ''But we think there is a danger that hard-line forces allied with the army will consolidate their power, put a wall around China and say the capital road is not for us.''
Mr. Dobson of Murray Johnstone adds: ''With so much money to be made in politically safe countries, I don't see any reason to be overweighted in Hong Kong.''
The Hong Kong market tumbled in wake of the repression of the democracy movement and it stopped short only of its record fall in October 1987. But more important, the turmoil brought to the fore new concerns about what will happen to this free-market haven on July 1, 1997, when China takes over. The promise to continue the capitalist system for 50 years does not look so good now.
Sir Piers is optimistic, but he has to be - that is the party line. ''I think we're going through the most difficult time now,'' he said. ''In 1995, the situation could look good, far more optimistic than 1989 and 1990.''
Sir Piers argues that there are two factors favoring Hong Kong. The first is that China needs Honk Kong. ''China is not going to turn its back on the world,'' he said. He and others estimate that there are now about 1.5 million to 3 million Chinese working across the border from Hong Kong in Guangdong Province that are directly or indirectly employed by businesses in Hong Kong. A major portion of foreign loans and foreign investment since 1979 has also come from the colony.
The other factor is the resilience of the Chinese in Hong Kong. It is assumed that they can bounce back from almost anything, as they did from the crash of 1987, the impact of the Chinese Cultural Revolution in the 1960's and as, Sir Piers says, they are bouncing back now from June 4.
He acknowledges the problems of the worker shortage and the resulting inflation. And he says the future does not promise economic growth so strong as in the past.
But, he notes, the stock market, according to the Hang Seng index, has recovered 732.60 points since June 4 and at 2,809.96 on Friday is poised to break through 3,000 by year-end. That the market did not close on Monday, June 5, shows the new Securities and Futures Commission is working well. And trade between Guangdong and Hong Kong continued during the crisis, he also said.
Sir Piers lists the deals that have been completed since June and the 11 new banking licenses. And he says an announcement on a new airport will come this week. He will not say what the decision is, but he does not deny that there have already been many stories saying the Government will go ahead. But he cannot dismiss the real problem -the problem of confidence that is so much more real now than it was nine months ago. ''What you need to hold it together is the confidence,'' he said.
The so-called brain drain - the emigration of talented Chinese - is continuing. And it is not clear if the new British policy of guaranteeing ''essential'' people the right to move to England will help.
Andrew F. Economos, manager of the Scudder New Asia Fund, is not worried. ''Before Tiananmen Square, people were overly optimistic about the People's Republic of China,'' he said. ''Now they are overly bearish.''
But Mr. Dobson of Murray Johnstone and Mr. Warren of Rowe, Price, Fleming are not convinced. They have been cutting back their exposure in the stock market since Tiananmen Square and are now below the normal average in Asia.
Mr. Warren says many stock sales to foreigners now are by local Chinese, which he does not take as a good sign. And Mr. Dobson worries that even the best intentions, like the orderly transition to Chinese sovereignty, can go awry. ''What seems to be totally impossible and can't happen,'' he said, ''can happen through sheer pigheadedness.''

HEADLINE: Inflation Drops In Argentina

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8

 BODY:
Argentina's inflation rate, which in July reached a record 196.6 percent, fell below 10 percent in September for the first time in seven months. It was the second consecutive monthly drop in the inflation rate. 
Official figures issued Friday showed the consumer price index rose in September by 9.4 percent, compared with a rise of 37.9 percent in August.
Through September, prices have risen this year by 3,826.4 percent.
The figure for September matches earlier predictions of single-digit inflation by President Carlos Saul Menem, who introduced a tough program to fight Argentina's economic crisis when he took office in early July. But some public officials had recently forecast a 7 percent rise.
Foreign exchange dealers said that by the close of trading Friday, the black-market rate for the United States dollar had risen to a 5 percent premium over the official rate for Argentina's currency, the austral.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Mexico's Baja Wines In Bid for U.S. Market

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VALLE DE GUADALUPE, Mexico

 BODY:
If the wines of California can become world-renowned and gain respect, then the wines of Baja California should be able to do the same. If Mexican beer can be made to appeal to the American palate, the same should be true of Mexican wine.
In the verdant fields of this tranquil valley, just 50 miles south of San Diego, a growing number of Mexican wine makers are hoping that such an analysis of the international market for alcoholic beverages will soon prove correct.
Spurred by increased competition here and by the remarkable success of beers like Corona and Dos Equis, they are modernizing rapidly and gradually turning an eye to the world's biggest consumer of exports - which to their good fortune lies virtually at their doorstep. 
 
The Two Top Producers
Leading the way are L. A. Cetto, a winery in Tijuana that accounts for more than 70 percent of all the wine consumed in Mexico, and the Mexican affiliate of Pedro Domecq S.A. Both companies produce millions of gallons of wine and brandy annually at modern plants here. But small boutique wineries have also begun to spring up, intent on duplicating the success achieved in the Napa Valley a few hundred miles to the north.
''Baja California is really turning into a premium wine district, producing some lovely, prime California wines,'' said Leon D. Adams, author of ''The Wines of America'' and a recent visitor here. ''It could have been so all along, but they just didn't have the competitive spirit.''
For years, in fact, Mexico's closed economy and high tariffs assured vineyards here healthy profits from a captive market. But the wrenching economic changes that have swept Mexico in recent years have shocked Mexican wine makers out of their complacency and forced them to look for new opportunities both at home and abroad.
 
New Competitive Climate
The economic crisis that began in 1982, bringing recession and triple-digit inflation, severely discouraged wine sales by putting prices beyond the reach of the average consumer. Then, Mexico's entry into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, in 1986 opened the domestic market to fine French, Italian and German wines, creating a new competitive climate.
The impact of those two situations has been felt at big vineyards like Bodegas de Santo Tomas, which has been producing wine in Baja California since 1888. From a peak production of about 350,000 cases a year at the height of the oil boom a decade ago, Santo Tomas's sales have fallen to about 100,000 cases a year, said officials at company headquarters in Ensenada.
''The lesson for large-scale producers of wine has been that if you do not constantly modernize, you die,'' said Luis Cetto Salazar, the 24-year-old grandson of the founder of L. A. Cetto and the company's heir apparent. ''The economic opening of the past year or so has really hit all of us quite hard.''
 
A Recent Start-Up
But the new environment has also attracted oenologists like Hans Backhoff, 42, a biochemical engineer with a doctorate in food sciences from Nottingham University in England. With an initial investment of $1 million, Mr. Backhoff and four partners this year will produce 10,000 cases of their Monte Xenic label, including both a chenin blanc and a cabernet sauvignon that they hope to place in the American market within a few years.
''Our project coincided with Mexico's joining GATT, which means we have a lot of competition from other countries,'' he said. ''That can be seen as something negative when you are just starting out, but it also means we have to have a good product, which we do. We're not ready to export yet, but that, too, will come.''
To experts, enterprises like Mr. Backhoff's and the nearby Bodegas San Antonio run by Octavio Jimenez, a former wine master at Santo Tomas who is the technical adviser, are a promising harbinger of the future. Helped by the chic image that Mexican food and beer have acquired in the United States, they say, Baja California wineries are likely to become a welcome new source of table wines for consumers conscious of both price and quality.
 
Resuming a Historical Role
''I visited Baja California last year, and I was impressed with the facilities, the knowledge of the state of the art and with the product,'' said Philip Hiaring, editor of Wines and Vines, a leading trade magazine. ''The grapes are thriving and the Guadalupe valley itself is one of the most beautiful vineyard valleys you can find anywhere in the world, so the Mexicans can travel in fast company.''
In expanding and modernizing production here, Mexican wine makers are merely resuming the historical role they once played. The first wine fermented in the New World was produced in Mexico in 1554, historians say, and vineyards have been tended in Baja California since 1697, initially by the same Jesuit and Dominican missionaries who later took their cuttings north to what was then Alta California.
''Mexico was the cradle of viniculture in the Americas, so it is entirely appropriate that we now see all of this happening,'' Mr. Adams said. ''The wines of Chile, which have found a strong market niche, as well as those of Argentina and Peru, all originated from Mexican cuttings.''
 
Exports to Europe and Japan
Production figures are closely guarded, but wineries here have begun exporting to distant markets like Japan, Eastern Europe and Britain, ''even without our really seeking it,'' said Hugo D'Acosta, wine master at Santo Tomas. But to penetrate the market that matters most - California and the American Southwest -wine makers here recognize they must first overcome a familiarity that borders on contempt.
''I am sure that we can achieve greater penetration of foreign markets,'' said Antonio Badan, a member of the Wine Brotherhood of Baja California, a local group dedicated to encouraging wine growing and consumption. ''But first we have to destroy the myth of 'Mexican what?' anytime you mention Mexican wine.''
In an effort to remind consumers of the strong wine-growing tradition here, L. A. Cetto red wines have been marketed in California under the slogan ''America's first wines are America's best wine values.'' Mr. Hiaring said such efforts must be accompanied by more advertising, more contact with liquor wholesalers and retailers, and more testing and research - a judgment with which Mexican wine makers heartily agree.
''We can't be exporting just for the sake of exporting,'' Mr. Cetto said. ''The failure of one line is the failure of all and damages the image of Mexican wine in general, so there must be a careful handling of this.''

HEADLINE: The Russians Are Still Coming

BYLINE: By Richard Pipes; Richard Pipes is professor of history at Harvard University.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
We live in an age of image-building - an age in which it is increasingly difficult to distinguish appearance from reality. Soviet leaders have taken full advantage of this situation in conducting foreign policy. They say one thing, and do another. Since most people cannot determine where the truth lies, they believe noble intentions.
The sense of good feeling is pervasive: An influential essay by a State Department official, Francis Fukuyama, assures us that the liberal cause has triumphed globally and that the ''end of history'' is at hand. 
Since Mikhail Gorbachev came to power, the Soviet Union has been far less aggressive in its foreign policy pronouncements. Desperately needing foreign aid to shore up a collapsing economy, it has projected with all the propaganda means at its disposal the image of a country that requires peace and defense-budget cutbacks. Such professions and certain steps, largely symbolic, have had the desired effect of blurring the perception of the Soviet Union as an aggressive, hostile power. This has resulted in an increased flow of foreign loans (the external debt has doubled under Mr. Gorbachev) and a corresponding decline in the West's willingness to bear the burdens of defense.
How genuine is the change in Soviet foreign policy? Take defense expenditures. Moscow has finally released what it claims to be its true military budget. The 77 billion ruble figure announced earlier this year is about half of what U.S. experts believe to be actual defense appropriations.
Washington estimates that military outlays under Mr. Gorbachev continue to grow at the rate of 3 percent a year in constant rubles. Although there have been indications of a slowdown in certain categories of weapons, the modernization of the four military services proceeds under perestroika at the same tempo as in the ''era of stagnation.''
In the Middle East, the Kremlin has often stressed the desire to replace confrontation with negotiations. Although rumors abound of worsening relations with Syria, Moscow's principal ally and a major aggressor, Syria has received MIG-29 fighters and supersonic Sukhoi 24 bombers. (Moscow has also sold Sukhois to Libya).
Taking advantage of Syria's massive debt owed to the Soviet Union, estimated at more than $15 billion, the Kremlin has secured a major naval facility at Tartus. This port, fully controlled by Soviet personnel, will service surface ships and submarines, obviating the necessity of having them go for maintenance and repairs to the Black Sea and the distant Kola Peninsula. The U.S. Navy has no comparable Mediterranean facility.
In the Far East, the Soviet buildup of client states continues. North Korea has been provided with MIG-23's and is reported in line for the more advanced MIG-29's. Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia have been given $2 billion in aid since 1987. Moscow has doubled its economic assistance to Vietnam, and has reportedly doubled military aid to Cambodia over 1988 levels. Vietnam has allowed Moscow to improve its new Pacific naval base at Cam Ranh Bay, originally constructed by the U.S.
Although Moscow has withdrawn combat troops from Afghanistan, it has increased economic and military assistance to the quisling Government in Kabul. Nothing suggests that the Soviet Union intends to relax its hold on that country.
In Nicaragua, the Sandinistas were saved from near-disaster by their decision to allow democratic elections. They have often let it be known, however, that they will not surrender power, come what may. (The only certainty is that the contras are doomed.) In Nicaragua, despite Mr. Gorbachev's assurances that no Soviet aid would be forthcoming, Soviet bloc and Cuban military assistance is reportedly being generously supplied.
And in Angola, Jonas Savimbi is in retreat and South Africa is pulling out, but Soviet aid continues to flow in.
There are at least two reasonable explanations for the discrepancy between Soviet professions and performance. One is that Moscow regards the present period as a breathing spell, to restore its flagging economy and popular morale, before resuming a worldwide offensive. The other is that the leadership is so beholden to its generals, especially in view of growing internal unrest, that it cannot afford to alienate them with cutbacks in appropriations and foreign commitments.
Whichever explanation is correct, world stability and peace are nowhere as close as much of world opinion would like to believe. The Kremlin's professions of peaceful intent, and certain steps carefully calculated to mollify the West, do not alter the fact that Soviet military activities at home and abroad under Mr. Gorbachev have proceeded pretty much as they did under Leonid I. Brezhnev.
The ''new thinking'' in international relations has shown more style than substance. In fact, the soft-line policy has enabled Moscow to spread its influence and power abroad more effectively that when it had pursued an overtly hard line.
One paradoxical effect of the Gorbachev peace offensive has been to promote Soviet interests in regional conflicts.
Even as the Soviet Union is withdrawing, its clients in Cambodia, Angola, Nicaragua and Afghanistan have been growing stronger at the expense of U.S. allies.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Foundation Seeks Self-Sufficiency for Puerto Rico

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R.

 BODY:
With help from foundations and United States corporations, a new style of philanthropy is taking root here and scattering seeds through the Caribbean.
The Puerto Rico Community Foundation, conceived by the Ford and Rockefeller foundations and the Carnegie Corporation as an experiment six years ago, emphasizes projects to move the island toward greater economic self-sufficiency. It aids small businesses and tries to generate jobs in poor mountain towns so they are not deserted by young people seeking a better life in the city. The foundation also tries to deter young people from using drugs, dropping out of school or having unwanted pregnancies. 
''We are the community foundation that speaks in Spanish,'' said Dr. Ethel Rios de Betancourt, president of the foundation, which was set up to draw support from a variety of donors, including local business concerns.
Decisions about spending are made by a board whose members represent a cross section of society, from the board chairman, Manuel H. Dubon, a real estate developer, to representatives of the community like Hilcia Montanez, who directs an alternative school for dropouts and is a voice for the 40 percent of the island's poor people who live in public housing.
 
A Tradition of Giving
''At first I was frightened about speaking up - what do I know about investments?'' Ms. Montanez said. ''But that soon passed.''
Giving to charity is a tradition in Puerto Rico, where even the poorest families among the United States commonwealth's 3.2 million people will scrape together a contribution for needy neighbors, the church or the victims of a calamity. But the concept of raising charitable dollars to start a business, organize a housing cooperative or provide medical care was unknown until the Ford Foundation offered a $2 million grant.
Ford's lead was followed by other offers, including ones from the Rockefeller, Carnegie, MacArthur, Kellogg and Robert Wood Johnson foundations. The Cleveland Foundation provided a staff for administrative help in the Puerto Rican group's critical early months.
Even before Hurricane Hugo wreaked havoc on the island's economy, the problems that the foundation was trying to address were daunting. Although a number of new pharmaceutical and electronic plants have improved economic conditions on the island in the last decade, Puerto Rico's per capita income, less than $5,000, still ranks below that of Mississippi, the poorest state in the Union.
 
Unemployment Is High
Puerto Rico's unemployment rate is officially reported at 15 percent, three times higher than the nation's as a whole. But unemployment on the island is believed to be higher than the official figure. Sixty percent of Puerto Rico's population qualifies for food stamps, a substantial part of the $6 billion in aid that the Federal Government provided last year.
The foundation's resources are too modest for a major role in coping with the devastation of Hurricane Hugo but the philanthropy shaped its own response: It focused on helping to rescue projects it began, including agricultural greenhouses.
Many of the 167 projects supported by the foundation, which now spends $1 million a year, are aimed at making the island less dependent on food imports. Puerto Rico imports about 85 percent of its food. This included about 300,000 pounds of frozen rabbit from China annually, so the foundation made a grant to teach farmers in the central mountain region how to raise rabbits. The farmers now hope to produce at least 100,000 pounds of rabbit meat a year.
''We use the meat and the skins, and the remaining animal parts are purchased by phramaceutical firms for research and by pet food manufacturers,'' Dr. Betancourt said. ''We use everything but the proverbial squeal.''
 
A Small-Business Incubator
Elsewhere, the foundation supports efforts to reclaim neglected farms to start an organic farming industry.
In a converted schoolhouse in the poor mountain town at Cubuy, Dr. Antonia Pantoja directs ''Producir,'' a small-business incubator that has already established a local bakery, a marmalade factory and clothing and beauty shops. Organizers say this may help reverse the trend in which young people leave their rural homes to seek jobs in big cities.
Dr. Pantoja, a retired professor from the University of California who has been a founder of several Puerto Rican civic organizations in New York City, preaches a sermon of self-help. ''We use our center to celebrate our community, our country and our culture and to make people feel good, to get them into entrepreneurship and stop leaning on the government check coming in,'' he said.
 
Model for Latin America
Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon recently praised the foundation as a pioneering venture deserving the support of local enterprises, saying, ''I also trust it will succeed in its desire to serve as a model philanthropic institution for the rest of Latin America.''
There are signs that wish will be fulfilled. Fifteen countries have already sent officials here to attend foundation meetings, including Margarita Penon de Arias, whose husband is President of Costa Rica. She is president of the Arias Foundation, which was started with money from her husband's 1987 Nobel Peace Prize.
''We opened our books, our financial records,'' said Dr. de Betancourt, a classical scholar and educator who has been with the foundation from its outset. ''We showed them everything to be helpful, just as we were helped at the beginning by the Ford and Cleveland foundations.''
The Ford Foundation is prepared to help start similar philanthropies in Latin America and the Caribbean, said Susan V. Berresford, Ford's vice president, who visited here last month.
Puerto Rico's experience is expected to have influence elsewhere in Latin American, said Hector Ledesma, vice chairman of the board of Banco Popular of Puerto Rico, who is a former chairman of the foundation. ''All Latins like to see something running before they buy it, and they will say, 'If you can do it in Puerto Rico, so can we.' ''
