HEADLINE: An Old Land Deal Nettles the West

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOAB, Utah

 BODY:
Nearly a century after the West was won and tamed, the Western states have come to regret a deal in which they accepted millions of acres of land from Washington in tiny plots like islands in an ocean of Federal territory.
Now Utah, saying these scattered lands are so difficult to manage that it cannot get much money for their intended purpose of supporting schools, has brought the issue to a boil by proposing to sell 82,000 acres of land the state owns inside four national parks.
And to dramatize its grievances, the state has made the provocative suggestion that the tracts could be developed for curio shops, convenience stores, public showers and resort cabins.
 
Hope for Congressional Solution
Utah officials say they do not really plan to desecrate national parks, but acted out of frustration to call attention to a problem that has festered for decades. The Utah Board of State Lands and Forestry had set Oct. 1 as a deadline for starting the sale, but it recently postponed action at the urging of Gov. Norman H. Bangerter, saying there was hope for a Congressional solution. 
What Utah really wants is to exchange much of its holdings for valuable property in the Glen Canyon National Recreation Area to build commercial boat marinas on Lake Powell and, beyond that, to forge a fundamental redefinition of who controls public land in the West.
The battle, in a sense, is over how to unscramble an egg. It reflects a deep resentment in the West against Federal control of land use and is a source of constant bickering among state and Federal officials, environmentalists, ranchers, miners and timber and tourism interests.
As Western territories joined the Union, the Federal Government allotted each new state millions of acres scattered about evenly in one-square-mile sections like a vast checkerboard, to be leased for grazing, mining and other purposes to generate revenue for schools. In return, the new states agreed to give up their claims to vast tracts within their borders.
 
From Rain Forests to Deserts
While much has been sold or traded over the years, millions of acres of checkerboard land remain, from the rain forests of Washington state to the deserts of New Mexico. The rest is in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Oregon, Utah and Wyoming.
Most tracts are remote and inaccessible, all the more so because they are now embedded in national forests and wilderness areas, in national parks, monuments and recreation areas run by the National Park Service, in military bases, in Indian reservations and, mainly, in vast grazing lands run by the Federal Bureau of Land Management.
The Federal Government still owns 553,000 square miles, or 47 percent, of the 11 states west of the Rockies, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, which lack checkerboard land. The Government owns 64 percent of Utah.
The issue has sharply focused a debate between development and conservation interests over how best to use the vast public lands that still cover the West.
On one side are local officials and residents, particularly in Utah, where the resentment of Federal land control is most deeply rooted. They want to bargain the state holdings for control of desirable Federal lands to promote tourism and perk up depressed rural economies.
''Colonialism has been virtually eliminated except in the Western states,'' said Calvin Black, a former uranium miner and businessman from Blanding, who is the driving force behind the confrontation as a member of the Utah lands board. The state's chief concern, he said, is not to preserve remote Utah for a few backpackers, but to raise the most money possible for its schoolchildren.
Conservationists see the checkerboards as threats to wilderness and parks, ''little bombs buried in protected areas,'' in the words of Darrell Knuffke, the Central Rockies regional director for the Wilderness Society.
The beauty and starkness of Utah unfolds as Brant Calkin flies his one-engine Cessna 182 over the arid Colorado Plateau in southern Utah, over places with evocative names like Hells Backbone and Coyote Gulch. It is a surrealistic land of soaring castles and pinnacles sculptured from striated red sandstone, of massive buttes and mesas riven by deep, lush canyons.
To Mr. Calkin, executive director of the Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance, the state has allowed its land to be abused, overmined, overgrazed and neglected. ''They don't even know what's happening on most of these tracts,'' he said. ''They say they want to maximize revenues, but it's a sham.''
The states have been trying for years to devise means to resolve conflicts arising from checkerboard patterns.
 
Exchanges in New Mexico
In New Mexico, which has about 6.3 million acres of checkboard land scattered over 5,000 tracts, it took 40 years to negotiate the exchange of 340,000 state acres in the White Sands Missile Range. The state is now trying to address the problem of what to do with 78,000 acres in the Navajo Reservation.
Arizona has exchanged about 2.5 million acres with the Bureau of Land Management over the last five years, receiving land near fast-growing cities and giving up its holdings in the environmentally sensitive San Pedro River area in southeastern Arizona.
Nearly everybody involved agrees that the solution is to give the states, in exchanges with the Federal Government, equal land in larger, contiguous blocks. But these exchanges have been bedeviled by complex issues of determining equal valuation, of mineral rights, archeological and wildlife concerns, state sovereignty and animosities between Federal agencies. $12.5 Million in Earnings In 1896, when Utah was admitted to the Union, it received one of every nine sections of land in exchange for giving up its land claims. What remains are 3.5 million acres, divided into more than 5,000 isolated sections. The state says it earned only $12.5 million for its chronically underfinanced public schools last year from leases, mineral royalties and other sources of revenue on this land.
The Congressional enabling act that made Utah a state requires it to use that land only for schools, said Patrick D. Spurgin, director of state lands and forestry. ''Something other than leaving the land to look nice has to be done,'' he said, ''because that generates no dollars.''
An attempt by the previous Governor, Scott M. Matheson, a Democrat, to solve the problem by a comprehensive exchange bogged down over which side was getting the better of the deal. His plan died when he left office in 1985.
Two years later his Republican successor, Governor Bangerter, reached an agreement with the Secretary of the Interior, Donald P. Hodel, to trade state holdings within national parks for Federal land outside.
That plan also broke down, and Mr. Bangerter proposed trading for 96,000 acres in the Glen Canyon National Recreation Area, a part of the national park system, to build five boat marinas on Lake Powell, which straddles the Utah-Arizona border, so Utah could compete better with Arizona for tourist dollars now spent on the more accessible Arizona side.
The National Park Service rejected the plan out of hand. Willis Kriz, the agency's chief of land resources in Washington, said the lake is already too heavily used by boaters, who leave trash and human waste in its dramatic canyons. ''To convey to the state for additional development would compound problems,'' he said.
Frustrated, the state land board in July proposed the sale of its 82,000 acres within four national park domains, Arches National Park, Capitol Reef National Park, Dinosaur National Monument and Glen Canyon, as well as 35,000 acres in the Navajo and Goshute Indian reservations.
This was ''blackmail'' to get Congress to approve the Lake Powell marinas, said Terri Martin, regional representative of the National Parks and Conservation Association, a group that tries to protect national parks.
The state still prefers the Lake Powell alternative, seeing a potential boom in tourism as a way to help the depressed counties in southern Utah. Even though 97 percent of Lake Powell lies within Utah, 2.8 million of the 3.5 million visitors to the area enter through Page, Ariz.
 
Environmentalists' Solution
''It is not the responsibility of Utah's schoolchildren to protect the national parks,'' said Mr. Black, the land board member.
Environmentalists like Mr. Calkin maintain that the better solution is to trade for Federal land outside the parks that are near existing towns and roads, so that tourist accommodations could be built away from scenic areas.
But Karl Kappe, a policy analyst at the State Division of Lands and Forestry in Salt Lake City, says such trades in the past have been thwarted by the Bureau of Land Management because of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, which requires the Government to preserve its land holdings in the West and receive equal value for any land traded away.
Representative Wayne Owens, a Democrat from Salt Lake City, recently visited Moab, whose economy has turned from mining to tourism, and said he was working on a compromise that would give the state Federal land just outside the Glen Canyon Recreation Area for motel and restaurant development while maintaining the integrity of Glen Canyon. He said he expected the support of the Governor and the remainder of the state's Congressional delegation, all of them Republicans.
After a meeting in Washington with Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. on Sept. 27, Governor Bangerter said the Secretary was amenable to the plan.
But even if such an agreement is reached, millions of acres of checkerboard land problems would remain unresolved in Utah and the other Western states. Some believe that Congress will ultimately be forced to rewrite the laws that granted statehood to the Western territories and come to grips with whether the Federal Government should encourage the exploitation or preservation of the tracts it still holds.

LENGTH: 585 words

HEADLINE: TENTATIVE ACCORD ON INDIAN FISHING

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: RHINELANDER, Wis., Oct. 9

 BODY:
A band of Chippewa Indians has agreed to curtail its spearfishing and other treaty rights in exchange for a multimillion-dollar aid package.
The tentative agreement was reached late last month after months of negotiations by the state with leaders of the Lac du Flambeau Chippewas, whose spearfishing has led to widespread protests by opponents of Chippewa treaty rights.
If approved by tribal members and the Wisconsin Legislature, the agreement would be the first reached between the state and its six Chippewa bands. The Mole Lake group had reached a tentative agreement with the state, but tribal members rejected that 10-year $10 million package in January. 
Treaty rights of the Chippewas to hunt and fish on non-reservation lands across much of northern Wisconsin have been upheld in a series of Federal court rulings since 1983.
 
Trust Fund Is Included
Donald Hanaway, the State Attorney General, said the tentative agreement with the Lac du Flambeau band would span 10 years and include a trust fund. The Lac du Flambeau band, the most active of the Chippewas in spearfishing, would continue ceremonial spearfishing but ''agreed to forbear and forgo the exercise of their treaty rights,'' he said.
Both sides declined to disclose details of the proposed agreement.
Leaders of the Lac du Flambeau band had been seeking a 10-year agreement worth $42 million, including payments of about $1,400 to each member of the Indian group. The state recently added other provisions, reportedly worth up to $10 million.
Mr. Hanaway said he hoped to have a final document ready for the Legislature by mid-October.
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican, said he supported the tentative accord, but some legislators expressed caution.
 
'An Encouraging Sign'
David Prosser, a Republican who is minority leader of the State Assembly, called the agreement ''an encouraging sign.'' But another Republican, State Senator Joseph Leean, said voters did not believe that ''we ought to have to ante up millions of dollars when the problem was created by Federal treaties.''
Michael Allen, the Chippewa tribal chairman, said the tribal council approved the package. Tribe members' approval is also needed.
James Klauser, who as state administration secretary is Governor Thompson's chief adviser, said the fund would be administered by trustees and used for education, law enforcement, health and economic development programs.
The accord could serve as a model for the state's five other Chippewa bands, said James Jannetta, the Lac du Flambeau group's tribal attorney. ''Hopefully, other bands will look at this as a historic step,'' he said.
 
Protests and Court Rulings
Spearfishing by the Chippewas prompted demonstrations at some northern lakes by hundreds of people in recent years.
Opposition to spearfishing grew even more heated this year after the state announced it would reduce the number of walleye pike that sport anglers were allowed to catch. The announcement came after a Federal court ruling that allowed Chippewas to spear as many walleye pike that biologists determined could be taken without hurting the fish population.
Last spring's spearfishing season was marked by incidents of name-calling and stone-throwing at some lakes and resulted in about 200 arrests.
Federal court rulings since 1983 have upheld provisions of 19th-century treaties that allow the Chippewas to fish, hunt, trap and harvest wild grain on non-reservation lands across most of northern Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: St. Croix Has No History of Racial Unrest

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Last Friday should have been a time of unrestrained joy for me. After five harrowing days and sleepless nights, I had finally received word that my family in St. Croix in the Virgin Islands - including my infant daughter - was alive and well following the destruction wrought by Hurricane Hugo.
My happiness, however, was tempered by outrage caused by your report that United States Army troops landing on St. Croix found looting and devastation (news story, Sept. 22). You may have accurately portrayed the desperate situation in the wake of the storm, but I am deeply offended by the comment that St. Croix ''has a history of racial tensions.'' 
As a black woman who lived in St. Croix for 15 years until coming to the mainland United States in 1979, I can emphatically say that I never witnessed any such racial unrest.
Indeed, the island's one widely reported incident - the Fountain Valley killings of 1979 - was first labeled as a racial attack, but was later reported to have involved drugs. I hardly believe that this one incident justifies branding St. Croix as a racial hotbed.
As a frequent visitor to the island, I have seen no increase in racial tension on St. Croix in the decade since I left. The effects of your statement may be significant and far ranging. In the short term, people in the mainland United States might be wary of making vital aid donations to St. Croix if they are led to believe that the island is some kind of racial boiling pot.
Potentially more harmful is the impact on St. Croix tourism, an industry on which 80 percent of the island's economy is based. Unfounded claims may very well dissuade people from visiting St. Croix, thereby having an adverse effect on the island's economy - at a time when it is in its greatest need.
 
SHERYL MOSELY
East Orange, N.J., Sept. 25, 1989

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
'Covert' Means Fiasco

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Once again, in misguided zeal to rearrange another nation's affairs, the U.S. Government has demonstrated all that's wrong with ''covert operations,'' and why they have no useful place in the policies of a democratic nation.
The latest fiasco in Panama - following earlier pratfall efforts to oust the odious dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega - continues a disastrous, dishonorable, bipartisan tradition: Iran-contra and the Bay of Pigs, to name the most notorious.
Even when covert operations succeed in the short run (in Iran and Guatemala in the 50's, for example) they damage U.S. interests (not to mention the victim nations) in the long term. Usually they backfire immediately - for instance, the C.I.A.'s harebrained mining of Nicaraguan harbors. 
Bush Administration officials, trying to explain the latest foul-up, claim to have been handicapped by lack of information. What did they expect? Little is ever clear in war and crisis, particularly at long range; and rumors, disinformation, surmise, silence and either wishful or fearful thinking are the background to any supposedly secret, outlaw operation.
The attempted Panama coup posed another problem typical of any such situation. No one in Washington could be sure whether the plotters would form a government preferable to General Noriega's criminal regime, and Mr. Bush resorted to the laughable demand that the coup leaders declare themselves democratic. Such uncertainty of consequence hangs over any covert operation.
Whether they choose themselves, as in the Panama failure, or the U.S. picks its own man, as in Guatemala, the nature of a successor regime is problematic. Nor can it be certain what might happen during the operation itself; Mr. Bush and his aides never learned for sure whether General Noriega's opponents would remand him to the U.S. for trial on drug-running charges.
For a quarter-century, former Kennedy Administration officials have insisted that they opposed the murder of Ngo Dinh Diem during a coup they authorized in South Vietnam in 1963; Diem was assassinated anyway. When the C.I.A. tried to direct a military takeover to prevent the election of Salvador Allende Gossens in Chile during the Nixon Administration, the operation succeeded only in causing the murder of Gen. Rene Schneider, a constitutionalist partial to the U.S.
These and other ''covert'' operations quickly became public, contributing heavily to the world's view of the U.S. as a ''great power'' little more concerned than the Soviet Union to respect the sovereignty of other nations. In Latin America, the ancient list of gringo interventions -even so inept as last week's in Panama - deeply prejudices Latin attitudes toward norteamericanos.
Everywhere, the inevitable disclosure of U.S. efforts to overthrow governments - even the hateful Noriega regime - makes a mockery of American pretensions to world moral primacy and to American rhetoric about the self-determination of peoples and the rule of law. But it's not possible -repeat, not possible - in a democratic society with a free press to keep for long such ''secrets'' as the C.I.A.'s funding of the contras in Nicaragua.
Worse, perhaps, than any of these other characteristics of covert operations is the necessity for the U.S. Government, from the President on down, to lie about them. Nothing so damages government credibility and public trust as the exposed lie of a formerly trusted leader - for example, President Eisenhower's cover-up of his knowledge of U-2 flights over the Soviet Union.
For his part, Mr. Bush emphatically assured the public in an effective TV ''sound bite'' that rumors of an ''American operation'' in Panama were ''not true.'' Since Panamanian officers did hatch their own scheme, the President may have achieved some shred of ''deniability'' with this formulation. But he and other officials purposely left two clear but false impressions - that the coup not only was not Washington's idea but that in Panama the U.S. had stayed scrupulously clear of the action.
In fact, the coup attempt was inspired by George Bush's repeated invitations to the Panamanian military to seize power. Without these assurances of U.S. sympathy and the implication of U.S. support, the attempt hardly would have been made. U.S. troops, moreover, blocked two roads to aid the plotters, and U.S. officials negotiated with them for custody of General Noriega.
If both covert action and the open invasion of Panama are to be ruled out, some may ask, what's to be done about the dictator? Leave him to his people, I say, to his neighbors, to economic and political isolation; if all else fails, leave him to Heaven.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: 2 Fund-Raising Groups Form to Aid Hispanic Organizations

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
For the first time in the New York region, hundreds of Hispanic social service or cultural groups that have competed for dollars, often with scant success, will have two new fund-raising organizations to help them.
In New York City, the Hispanic Federation of New York City will solicit the city's two million Hispanic residents to help children and the unemployed, sick, elderly and homeless. The Federation will be linked to the United Way of New York City, temporarily housed at its Manhattan office and given financial help as it begins fund raising.
In the region, the Latino Fund of Tristate will seek contributions in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut for the estimated three million Hispanic residents in these states. The fund will try to stimulate economic development and strengthen cultural institutions. 
Charity in New York is influenced and administered by groups like Catholic Charities and the United Jewish Appeal/Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, said Hector Gesualdo, a vice president of the United Way of New York City. ''Now Hispanics also will have a federation,'' he said.
 
'I See Unity Developing'
Details of how the two groups will work are undecided. It will be months before the impact of the organizations can be measured, but the potential is exciting, said Glenn S. Clarke, president of the Avon Products Foundation, who arranged a recent luncheon meeting of officials of both groups.
''I see unity developing among the millions of Puerto Ricans, Cubans, Dominicans and other Central and South Americans who have done good things individually and in small groups but can do much more now speaking as Hispanics.''
The federation and the Latino Fund will encourage Hispanic people to develop their own groups, said Luis A. Miranda Jr., Mayor Edward I. Koch's special adviser on Hispanic affairs.
''It is clear both organizations are needed to raise public awareness about the situation of Hispanics.'' he said. ''Puerto Ricans, the largest group among the Hispanics, are the city's poorest minority. Other Hispanic groups that came in the 70's and 80's are only now developing their own human service agencies as Federal funds are drying up.''
 
Independent Collaborators
The groups will be independent, but will collaborate, under an agreement reached after months of uncertainty.
''I firmly believe both organizations are moving in stride toward meeting the needs of the Hispanic community,'' said Fernando A. Fleites, one of the federation's organizers.
''We have come together and joined forces,'' said Luis Alvarez, chairman of the Latino Fund. ''Heaven knows there is enough work for everyone.''
According to the Latino Fund, Hispanic people are 25 percent of the city's population and about 17 percent of the tri-state region's. ''There is no precise data on philanthropic contributions reaching Hispanic organizations,'' said Miguel A. Garcia, the fund's president, ''but our preliminary analysis indicates Hispanic-administered organizations get less than 4 percent.''
 
Toward Greater Self-Sufficiency
He cited a 1987 study by the National Puerto Rican Coalition showing less than 3 percent of United Way money went to Hispanic-run groups.
United Way officials say the data does not take into account aid to groups that are not administered by Hispanic people but provide services to them.
The foundation aims to move Hispanic organizations toward greater self-sufficiency, but it will not be easy, said Horace Morris, executive vice president of the United Way of New York City.
''The Hispanics face an uphill struggle, more so than blacks who learned to organize in the civil rights movement and built a structure of organizations such as the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the Urban League, and also had the support of a strong church and fraternal associations.'' he said.
''New York City is no longer white, Protestant and middle-class. Half our residents are from minorities and Hispanics are the second-fastest growing group, after Asians. Corporations have a vested interest in the community; they get their labor force from it. The companies know this, the banks know this. If Hispanics do poorly, everybody does poorly.''

HEADLINE: Coptic Pope's Visit Cheers Faithful

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
When they say ''Pope'' at the Roman Catholic school where Michael Muraghy is in the fifth grade, they of course mean Pope John Paul II. But the other day, Michael, 10 years old, and hundreds of other Coptic Orthodox Christians had a chance to meet their own Pope - Shenouda III - at a Brooklyn Church.
''John Paul II is okay,'' Michael declared after being blessed by Pope Shenouda III, ''but my Pope's better.''
Pope Shenouda, 66, was in the New York area to visit the largest Coptic Orthodox community outside of Egypt, where he lives and oversees the worldwide church of 20 million members. The New York stop was part of an 11-week trip the Pope is taking through the United States and Canada, during which he hopes to visit each one of the 40 Coptic Orthodox Churches in North America. 
In recent years, thousands of Copts have emigrated to the United States, Canada and Australia seeking economic opportunity and religious freedom. Many say that it is difficult to live as Christians in Egypt's Muslim society.
 
Hopes for a Coptic School
The growth in the United States has been rapid. In 1970 there were only two Coptic Orthodox Churches in the United States, one in Jersey City and the other in Los Angeles; today there are 40 with some 200,000 members. Hopes of building a Coptic school have yet to be realized, however, and many Coptic children, such as Michael Muraghy, attend Catholic schools.
In an interview between visits to local churches, Pope Shenouda said that many theological issues that separated the Coptic church from Roman Catholicism have been resolved.
Pope Shenouda, who speaks English, Arabic, Coptic and French, is a pioneer in trying to bring the Coptic church closer to Roman Catholicism. In 1973, he and Pope Paul VI signed a common declaration that said that the two Christian faiths were essentially one, while acknowledging that historical differences remained on dogma and ritual. The declaration set in motion theological dialogue aimed at resolving those differences.
Pope Shenouda said he had no plans to meet with Pope John Paul II, but hinted that it might happen even without plans. ''These things always come in a natural way,'' he said.
 
Dispute Over Divinity
Just as the Roman Pope traces his lineage to the Apostle Peter, the Coptic Pope is the heir to the church established in First Century Alexandria by the Evangelist Mark, the author of the Second Gospel. His official title is Pope Shenouda III, the 117th Pope of Alexandria and Patriarch to the See of Saint Mark.
The Coptic church was among the so-called Oriental churches that split with Rome at the Council of Chalcedon of 451 in a dispute over the definition of the divine and human natures of Christ.
During his two weeks in New York, Pope Shenouda met with bishops of the Armenian, Syrian, Greek and Russian Orthodox churches as well as with officials of the Roman Catholic church. Because of a scheduling problem, he was unable to meet with John Cardinal O'Connor, the head of the New York Archdiocese, but met instead with his representatives.
Pope Shenouda's American tour is being coordinated by the Rev. Gabriel Abdelsayed, rector of St. Mark Coptic Orthodox Church in Jersey City. Father Abdelsayed said that the Pope, who left New York on Sept. 22, expects to visit every Coptic church as he continues with his travels to more than a dozen cities, including Seattle, Philadelphia, Boston, Atlanta, St. Louis and Dallas. In mid-November, Pope Shenouda will leave the United States for a similar pastoral visit in Australia before returning to Egypt for Christmas.
 
Businesses Were Closed
In Brooklyn, Pope Shenouda was greeted with great excitement at the Coptic Orthodox Church of St. George at 11th Avenue and 67th Street in an area that is between the neighborhoods of Bay Ridge and Bensonhurst. The visit was on a Wednesday morning and many closed their businesses to be there to participate. Parents took their children out of school.
''There is a happiness today, like a Christmas day and an Easter day,'' said Michael Mankaryous, an Egyptian native, who closed his Brooklyn business, Cleopatra Travel, to be at the church to greet the Pope.
Hundreds of people packed the church and its balcony. As is the Coptic custom, men sat on one side of the church and women and children on the other, a sign of the Muslim influence on the Egyptian Christian faith.
During the three-and-a-half-hour mass - held in Coptic, Arabic and English - dozens of men and boys were consecrated deacons for various religious roles in the church, including singer, reader, and assistant for the mass. Each new deacon wore a white robe and a sash embroidered with Coptic crosses in red and gold.
 
Handfuls of Holy Water
For communion, the faithful were given pieces of a consecrated round bread that, in accordance with tradition, was baked with the imprint of a great cross. The bread, doughy in consistency and measuring a foot in diameter, had been baked early the same morning by a church member.
At one point, the Pope, his dark eyes beaming, walked down the aisle joyfully throwing handfuls of holy water from a silver decanter into the crowd. The ebullient faithful leaned foward with hands outstreched to be sprinkled and blessed.
At the end of the mass, Pope Shenouda sat in a chair at the altar and distributed silver Coptic crosses to each churchgoer, as a souvenir of his visit. The Coptic cross is made up of two bold lines of equal length that intersect at the middle at right angles. At each angle are three points, representing the Trinity of the Father, the Son and the Holy Ghost. All together, the cross has 12 points symbolizing the Apostles whose mission it was to spread the Gospel message throughout the world. As Pope Shenouda handed each person their own Coptic cross, he said in Arabic ''Rabbina Yibaarkak,'' which means ''May Our Lord Bless You.''

HEADLINE: For Top U.S. Science Students, a Soviet Magazine

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
A SOVIET magazine that helped America's student team win top honors in this year's international Physics Olympiad will soon be distributed to top high school science students throughout the United States.
The Soviet magazine, Kvant (for Quantum, as it will be called in this country), is intended to fill a long-standing gap in American science education. Timothy M. Weber, managing editor of Kvant's American translation, said the United States has never had a counterpart, so ''our organizers turned to the Soviet Union to get us started.'' 
The Physics Olympiad, a grueling series of competitive examinations, was held in Warsaw in July. For the first time in the four years the United States has entered the competition, the Americans won a gold medal (awarded to Steven Gubser of Englewood, Colo.) and scored highest overall in a field of 30 nations.
The first issue of Quantum will be distributed this autumn to 100,000 American high school students taking part in physics or mathematics programs for the gifted. The first two issues will be free, but if the magazine proves successful, students will thereafter pay $9.95 for four issues. Eventually, the plan is to bring it out nine times a year. At first, all the articles will be translations from the Soviet magazine; Mr. Weber said that eventually American scientists would contribute to Quantum and their articles would be made available to Kvant.
Money to start Quantum was provided by the National Science Foundation, but eventually the magazine will have to support itself. Unlike its Soviet progenitor, Quantum carries some advertising. Articles by the Soviet contributors challenge students by posing important problems in mathematics and physics in terms of everyday experience rather than abstract theory. In the first issue, for example, subtle ideas in solid geometry are presented in terms of the folds required to make a paper bird, and the student is advised to look for relationships rather than work out formal mathematical proofs.
The organizers of the Soviet-American Quantum collaboration were Dr. Sheldon Glashow of Harvard University, who shared the 1979 Nobel Prize in Physics; Dr. Edward D. Lozansky, a physicist and former Soviet dissident who emigrated to the United States in 1977, and Dr. William Aldridge, executive director of the National Science Teachers Association.
 
'Don't Stand Under the Bulb!'
''This collaboration would not have been possible in the days before Gorbachev,'' Dr. Lozansky said. ''We are also working on Soviet-American student exchanges and on an American university we hope to found in Moscow. There has been a vast change in climate. Two years ago, all this would have been inconceivable.''
But Dr. Lozansky said the Soviets want something in exchange. ''They recognize that we are ahead of them in business education, economics and computer science,'' he said. ''Those are fields in which their educators hope to learn from us.''
Quantum's American staff, based in Washington, acknowledges that some examples used in the magazine might seem more pointed to Soviet readers than to Americans. For example, an article by A. N. Pegoyev, ''Don't Stand Under the Bulb!'' deals with the physics of different ways in which light bulbs burn out - or explode, something they rarely do in America.
American scientists also acknowledge that some of the problems published in Quantum might be beyond the preparation of its American readers. ''But our goal,'' Dr. Lozansky said, ''is to improve American education. Quantum will serve as a beacon to aim at.''

Companies
G.M. said it might buy a minority stake in Jaguar and was also discussing joint ventures in manufacturing and marketing with the company. The announcement pits G.M. against Ford, which has already bought a stake in Jaguar and signaled that it might seek control of the company. [Page D1.] 
USAir's share price rose $3.625, to $52.25, after a report in USA Today that its largest shareholder wanted it to raise its market value and would consider a hostile bid. USAir later said it expected sharply lower profits for the third and fourth quarters. [D1.]
Wildcatters and pipeline companies are struggling over how to exploit a 1987 Arco discovery of a major natural-gas field in southeastern Oklahoma. [D1.]
North American developers are rushing to get a foothold in Europe before 1992, when trade barriers fall. But real estate experts say many developers will soon be limping home after they discover how complex building in Europe can be. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Developers Rushing Into Europe

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
With tight regulation keeping office vacancy rates in Europe below 3 percent, North American developers are rushing to get a foothold in this profitable market before 1992, when trade barriers fall.
In east London, Olympia & York, a Canadian company with vast United States operations, is building the $5 billion, 12-million-square-foot Canary Wharf, which will be the world's largest office and retail complex.
In Brussels, Paris, Munich, Hamburg and Frankfurt, Trammell Crow, the largest real estate developer in the United States, is building office towers and commercial warehouses.
And in Frankfurt, Tishman-Speyer Properties, a New York real estate giant, is building the 53-story Messeturm, a tower that will be the tallest building in continental Europe.
''A lot of people are looking and considering it,'' said David Shulman, head of real estate research at Salomon Brothers. 
But real estate experts say many developers now jetting across the Atlantic will soon be limping home after they discover how complex building in Europe can be. Charles Grossman, managing director of Jones Lang Wootton Realty Advisors, an international consulting firm, said: ''Only the leading American developers are going to make it in Europe. It's hard to find sites and hard to get consent to build. You're not going to go to London and wave your magic wand and build a million-square-foot building.''
For many reasons American builders have become suddenly dazzled by Europe, and taken together they make a compelling argument.
For one thing, big developers ''are looking for something to do; the opportunities in the States aren't as present as they were just a few years ago,'' said William Conway, managing director of Jones Lang Wootton. ''Second, for the last several years returns on investment-grade property have been greater in Europe.''
 
Different Traditions
Moreover, he added, ''In Europe there is not the tradition of organizing large pools of capital to do large development projects speculatively, as there is in the States. The American developers are bringing skills to the European marketplace as it is developing. They've done things on a scale that Europeans haven't done except through the state.''
The European market is also attractive because it tends to expand and contract on a different cycle from the American market, allowing investors to hedge their bets and enabling developers to keep growth advancing steadily.
''There is clear evidence of countercyclical behavior,'' Mr. Grossman said. ''While the U.S. markets were entering a burst of overbuilding, the European markets were coming out of a burst of overbuilding and going into a very tight market. Now you have restricted supply and strong demand, hence high rates.''
 
Higher Returns in Europe
According to a study done by Jones Lang Wootton, real returns on European office buildings have been higher than in the United States. ''The seven major European markets averaged total returns of 12.5 percent and 16.2 percent over the last 10 years and 5 years, respectively, compared with 5.5 percent and 2.3 percent in the U.S.,'' the study said.
One factor is that the supply of office space in Europe is still fairly limited at a time when businesses are expanding quickly. Vacancy rates have been around 3 percent largely as a result of strict planning controls and a dense pattern of existing development. With economic expansion and growth in certain business sectors, like financial services, demand for space has been steadily growing in some cities, and rents have followed.
By contrast, in American cities over the last 10 years the office vacancy rate has risen from roughly 5 percent to 20 percent, a Salomon Brothers study said. In markets like New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, vacancy rates ''have fallen little from their 1986 peak - near 17 percent in the downtowns and 24 percent in the suburbs,'' the study said. The Salomon report found 475 million square feet of vacant office space, or 19.1 percent of the total inventory, after surveying 50 American metropolitan office markets.
 
Tough Act to Follow
American real estate ''will be hard pressed to repeat the superior performance reported during 1977-81,'' Mr. Shulman, Salomon's research director, said in another recent study. He said that between 1977 and 1981, the Frank Russell Company Index of institutional properties earned a real return of 7.1 percent annually. Office vacancy rates were negligible, he said, adding, ''Today's real estate markets are glutted.''
Some analysts think the rush to do big commercial developments in Europe could eventually create similar problems there.
''The U.S. is exporting the office building boom to Europe, and we think it could mean the same type of overbuilding we had here,'' said Donald Williams, chief executive of Trammell Crow. ''We think this is the time to be careful. In London, for example, it looks like there is serious overbuilding already.
''We've been building offices and warehouses in Europe since 1971. It's not zillions of dollars, but it's steady. You need to find niches of economic activity; you can't just go over and say we're going to build America again.''
 
'Different Ball Game'
Many developers warn that Europe's commercial real estate markets are not money trees waiting for Americans to shake them.
''It's a whole different ball game over there,'' said John C. Portman 3d, president and chief operating officer of the Portman Companies. ''Land prices as a percentage of construction are so much greater.''
Mr. Portman, whose firm is heavily engaged in development in East Asia, is now considering doing a construction project in Moscow, but he said he was afraid of taking on too many difficult foreign markets.
One obvious challenge is simply distance. It can be tricky for an American company to develop and manage properties 3,000 miles away.
 
'Making a Huge Mistake'
''When something is under your nose it's much easier,'' said Lawrence Silverstein of Silverstein Properties, a New York developer.
Many developers rushing to Europe are ''making a huge mistake,'' said Jerry I. Speyer, the head of Tishman-Speyer. ''Things are much more difficult when they're far away.''
He said all sorts of regulations constrict what developers can do. ''There are countries where the laws require that every office worker has access to window space,'' he said. ''You end up with office floors that are small by American standards, like 1,200 square feet, rather than about 30,000.''
But Debra McClain, head of Morgan Stanley's European real estate operations, said the big developers that have made the jump across the Atlantic have so far approached the markets carefully.
''The big developers are working in some way with local expertise, either with local consultants or with local developers as partners,'' she said, adding that planning restrictions are not the only challenge. ''You need to know who your competitors are, and you need to know the local authorities to get through the planning process.''
 
Styles of Retailing
Analysts also emphasize that different approaches to retailing affects building. In Europe, mom-and-pop stores dominate the retail business, but in the United States, the huge chains that rent space in the malls and shopping centers have made many American fortunes. Some consultants say European land-use commissions are often dominated by people determined to preserve the small local retailer, often making it impossible for developers to build American-style malls.
''Mom-and-pop retailers still have an incredible amount of control over the approval process,'' said Mr. Williams of Trammell Crow, ''and they will not let you into the market. We've had to learn modesty the hard way.''
Mr. Speyer of Tishman adds that in many European cities so many buildings have landmark status that just finding land can be a challenge. So much of the activity in the cities is converting building to offices.
Still, despite the obstacles, many developers are determined to build in Europe as 1992 draws near. They foresee enormous demand for commercial space as European corporations start new operations to take advantage of falling economic barriers, like fewer limits on the movement of capital, goods and labor.
 
Property Values Soar
''The general attitude is that this thing is going to be bigger than the Marshall Plan,.'' said Mr. Conway of Jones Lang Wootton.
In Brussels, headquarters of the European Community, the anticipation has sent property values and rents soaring, sparking protests by citizens groups against the speculative buying and development that has transformed housing blocks into offices and driven up residential rents. And in Frankfurt, a hub for banking activity, spending on commercial construction has skyrocketed.
In the post-1992 era, European corporations are likely to move toward larger, more centralized plants, and that will mean an increase in construction, analysts say. Trammell Crow's recent construction of a 600,000-square-foot warehouse and office complex for Nissan may be an example of what is likely to come. The complex, in Dusseldorf, will be the focal point of the Japanese car maker's operations in continental Europe.
 
More Activity Now
''The 1992 unification is a reality,'' Mr. Williams of Trammell Crow said. ''There is more economic activity now than I've ever seen in Europe.''
But some developers are not so sure 1992 means more demand for space. Peter Rogowski, a German who heads Trammell Crow International from an office in Brussels, said developers are convincing themselves that 1992 will be a panacea.
He said 1992 ''is considerably overestimated,'' and added: ''There will be a shift in certain centers of gravity in terms of distribution centers, but in the office centers we are headed for overbuilding. In our industry people always try to make themselves believe these things until the crunch comes.''
Mr. Speyer of Tishman said 1992 ''is going to come and go.''
''The difference between the present Europe and the future Europe is that it's going to be far more united,'' he continued. ''It doesn't mean that there's going to an explosion in the need for space.''
If the 1992 naysayers are right, many American developers will soon be happy again to be building on familiar shores.

HEADLINE: USAir Stock Rises Sharply, But a Profit Slump Is Seen

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Stock in the USAir Group, owner of the nation's seventh-largest airline, rose sharply yesterday after a published report that its largest shareholder, the money manager Michael H. Steinhardt, wanted the company to increase its share price and might consider a hostile bid.
After the close of trading, USAir announced that it expected sharply lower profits for the third and fourth quarters and that its flights were less full in September than in September of last year.
Shares of USAir climbed $3.625, to $52.25, and were the most-actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange. More than 1.6 million shares changed hands on an otherwise quiet trading day. 
The second-most-active stock on the Big Board was the AMR Corporation, which owns American Airlines. AMR rose $1, to $104.75, with 1.2 million shares traded. Last week, the developer Donald J. Trump offered to buy the company for $120 a share, or $7.5 billion, if the company's management was amenable.
AMR, which is expected to reject the proposal, has been studying for weeks whether to create an employee stock ownership plan to help deter any takeover attempt, an investment banker who asked not to be identified said.
The heavy trading in USAir and AMR follows a $3.65 billion leveraged buyout in August of NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, and an agreement for a $6.75 billion buyout of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines. The vigorous takeover activity in the airline industry has prompted strong criticism in Congress and the Department of Transportation that could make it more difficult to carry out further transactions.
One concern of critics of the deals is that airlines are assuming heavy loads of debt and might be vulnerable if airline traffic continues to slip, as it has this year.
USAir said yesterday that traffic had tumbled in September, with its planes flying 56.3 percent full, down from 57.4 percent in the same period last year.
In addition, USAir said its third- and fourth-quarter profits would be ''significantly lower than those of the comparable 1988 period.'' The company cited a weakening economy and the effects of Hurricane Hugo.
In November 1987, USAir bought Piedmont Airlines, which had its hub in Charlotte, N.C. ''We had 300 flights a day out of Charlotte,'' said David Shipley, a spokesman for USAir. ''That day, I think we had two or three,'' he added, referring to the hurricane. At one point during the storm, 18 airports with USAir operations were shut, he said. It took three days to restore normal operations.
 
Hubs in Pittsburgh and Charlotte
USAir, formerly Allegheny Airlines, merged its operations with Pacific Southwest Airlines on April 9 of last year and with Piedmont on Aug. 5. It is repainting the planes of those two carriers with its own colors. USAir's major hub airports are in Pittsburgh and Charlotte.
The announcement of the fall in profits followed a report by Dan Dorfman in USA Today that Mr. Steinhardt, who owns 8.4 percent of the stock, wanted the company to consider such options as expanding international service, selling a stake to a foreign carrier, or paying a large cash dividend to shareholders.
Mr. Steinhardt was not in his office yesterday and was not available for comment, his assistant said.
Mr. Shipley of USAir declined to comment on Mr. Dorfman's column. Unlike many United States carriers, USAir does not have any joint marketing agreements with foreign airlines. In addition, the company is not aware of any purchases of its stock by other carriers, Mr. Shipley said.
 
Takeover Defenses
USAir created two takeover defenses in August. It put 5 percent of its shares in an employee stock ownership plan, and it sold to Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor, an issue of preferred stock that is convertible into shares equal to a 12 percent stake in the company.
Mr. Steinhardt is an aggressive trader who runs a $1.4 billion partnership that bears his name. His habit of rapidly changing the stocks in his portfolio on a daily basis makes him one of the highest generators of trading commissions on Wall Street. Professional traders were skeptical yesterday that he would seek to buy the company.
''What's he going to do with it?'' asked an arbitrager who requested not to be identified. ''He's not an operator.''
But the traders and an airline industry analyst added that his interest would focus attention on USAir and put pressure on its management to change the company's financial structure to benefit shareholders.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 11, 1989, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the USAir Group misstated the period this year in which the airline's passenger flights were less full than in 1988. Last month, USAir flights were 56.3 percent full, compared with 57.4 percent in September 1988.

HEADLINE: Little Chance Seen for Bills That Would Put Rein on Fed

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9

 BODY:
This month, Congress plans to take its first close look in years at how the Federal Reserve makes economic policy. Two competing measures introduced by House Democrats, one supported and the other strongly opposed by the Fed, would in totally different ways assert political influence over the powerful, secretive institution.
Neither measure seems to stand much chance of becoming law. But public hearings before the House Banking Committee's subcommittee on domestic monetary policy, scheduled to begin Oct. 25, will provide a forum for critics and friends alike. 
The critics say the Fed should be more accountable politically, and the friends want to add political muscle to the central bank's efforts to drive down inflation.
One of those friends, Stephen L. Neal of North Carolina, the chairman of the subcommittee, has introduced a resolution that would require the Fed over the next five years to eliminate inflation, now running just under 5 percent. The bill offers no specifics on how this would be done.
Competing with Mr. Neal's resolution is a bill introduced by Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana and Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota that would make the Treasury Secretary a member of the Fed's policy-making committee, force policy decisions to be made public immediately and require Government audits of the Fed's accounts.
By being able to raise and lower interest rates, the Fed has by far the most influence over the nation's economy of any Government body. And as Congress and the executive branch have lost their grip on budget policy in recent years, the Fed's authority has increased markedly.
Because of the way the institution was set up, its operations are more removed from political accountability than any other part of the Government outside the judiciary. The Fed governors and regional bank presidents have no real guidance from Congress or the President.
The meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee, where policy decisions are made, are held behind locked doors, and no transcript is kept. The decisions are not announced for six weeks, and even then only a skeletal summary of what transpired is made public. No other branch of Government can veto the decisions.
The point of Mr. Neal's measure, he maintains, is that Congress should state unambiguously that ending inflation is a primary policy goal.
''By eliminating inflation,'' he said in an interview, ''we establish the essential foundation for the highest possible sustainable levels of economic growth, employment, savings, capital formation, investment, productivity, competitiveness and efficiency.''
Mr. Neal drafted his measure to get the support of Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, who is scheduled to be the first witness at the hearings.
 
Little Effect Expected
Few other lawmakers have shown interest in the Neal proposal, and most believe that since it has no enforcement mechanism it would have little effect. No particular event precipitated the interest in the House. In the Senate, there seems to be no inclination to meddle with the Fed. Moreover, Mr. Greenspan, astute in the ways of Washington, is more open in his dealings with Congress than many of his predecessors were and the consensus in Congress, adhered to by Mr. Neal, Mr. Hamilton and Mr. Dorgan, is that the Fed chairman is doing a fine job.
Disagreement remains, however, over the proper role of the central bank and the policies it should follow in the future. Mr. Hamilton and Mr. Dorgan take issue with Mr. Neal's premise that inflation should be ended at all costs.
''I don't accept that as the single goal of economic policy,'' Mr. Hamilton said. ''The question is how you hit a target of low inflation, full employment and growth. I can foresee price stability and 20 percent unemployment or price stability and recession, and that is unacceptable.''
 
'Profoundly Undemocratic'
Mr. Hamilton and Mr. Dorgan said they had no complaint with current Fed policy but worried that, in Mr. Hamilton's words, the central bank was ''profoundly undemocratic.''
Mr. Dorgan said, ''We ought to lift the veil of secrecy, the cloak of mystery about how it works.''
For his part, Mr. Neal said that placing the Treasury Secretary on the Open Market Committee would ''politicize the Fed'' and result in ''roller-coaster economics.''
Mr. Greenspan agrees with that view. The chairman believes that putting the Treasury Secretary in a policy-making position would make it more difficult for the Fed to take unpopular political stands, like raising interest rates, that are in the public's long-term benefit. And he maintains that announcing decisions when they are made would lead to instability in the financial markets and make it impossible to put a policy in place gradually.
 
Bid for Control Seen
Some economists agree with Mr. Greenspan. Herbert Stein, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Nixon Administration and is now a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, said the Hamilton-Dorgan bill was ''designed to increase control over the Fed by people whose general interest is in pumping the economy up.''
Jerry L. Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp and a member of the Council of Economic Advisers in President Reagan's first term, said the markets would ''move in a nanosecond'' if the Fed disclosed its interest rate targets.
But other economists are not so sure. John Paulus, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said the main reason the Fed governors cherish secrecy is that it ''makes it easier for them to avoid public criticism.'' And if decisions were released as soon as they were made? ''I think the Republic would survive quite well,'' he added.
Political scientists are almost unanimous in their criticism of the Fed's independence from elected officials. Prof. James David Barber of Duke University said he was amused by the argument that Fed governors could act in the public interest only if they did so in secret. ''That,'' he said, ''is the kind of argument King George III would make.''
 
Reluctance by Brady
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady does not want to serve on the Fed's policy committee. His assistants say he does not want to compromise the central bank's independence. Some Democrats in Congress think, however, that he does not want the responsibility and that the real reason is that the Bush Administration wants to maintain its freedom to blame the Fed if economic policy turns sour.
Congress has debated the Fed's policies and place in the Government occasionally over the years but has rarely acted. Since the Federal Reserve System was established in 1913, the nature of the Fed has been altered significantly by Congress only twice. A 1935 law centralized policy control in Washington and made the system basically what it is today. In 1980, Congress gave the Fed control over the reserves of private banks.
Paradoxically, one key provision of the 1935 law was to remove the Treasury Secretary from a position on the Federal Reserve Board.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Narrowly Mixed; British Pound Moves Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was narrowly mixed yesterday in thin holiday trading. Gold prices were lower. Currency dealers said trading was subdued and abbreviated because of the Columbus Day and Yom Kippur holidays. The markets in Hong Kong were also closed for a holiday, while trading in Japan slowed on the eve of a holiday there. 
Taking the spotlight was the British pound, which sank below 3 West German marks in Europe for the first time in 18 months, despite last week's rise in base lending rates in line with similar rate hikes across Europe.
Some dealers said they were worried that Britain's anti-inflation strategy might tilt the nation's economy into a recession.
''There are no positives for the pound,'' said Jeremy Hale, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''Recession is now the center of concern.''
The pound closed at $1.5775 in London, down from $1.6030 Friday. The pound fetched $1.5775 in New York, lower than $1.6055 on Friday.
In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell 0.22 Japanese yen to close at 142.23 yen. It traded at 142.80 yen in London, and at 142.85 yen in New York, up from 142.43 yen on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.8875 West German marks, down from 1.8885; 1.6485 Swiss francs, up from 1.6420; 6.3995 French francs, down from 6.4050; 1.17525 Canadian dollars, unchanged, and 1,383.25 Italian lire, unchanged.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday, included: 1.8865 West German marks, down from 1.8880; 1.6457 Swiss francs, up from 1.6435; 6.4005 French francs, down from 6.4035; 2.1310 Dutch guilders, down from 2.1350; 1.1749 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1760, and 1,384.00 Italian lire, up from 1,380.25.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $363.10 an ounce, down 60 cents from Friday. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $362.50 an ounce, off 75 cents.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $362.75 an ounce, from $363.25 on Friday, but it was unchanged in Zurich at $362.80 an ounce.
Silver prices declined. On the Comex, silver for current delivery fell to $5.050 an ounce, from $5.117 Friday. Silver fell in London to $5.09 an ounce, from $5.14.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Rate Steady Because of Service Sector

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Some big companies have been making big layoffs. But the relatively steady unemployment rate, which has fluctuated between 5.1 percent and 5.3 percent since April, means that others must be hiring.
Several manufacturers have been aggressively cutting costs and jobs. The International Business Machines Corporation, for example, is offering early retirement to 1,000 employees. And Borden Inc. plans to eliminate 7,000 jobs from its dairy operations. So who is hiring? Steven Haugen, an economist with the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said job growth was concentrated in the service sector, which includes everything from data processing to theme parks to beauty parlors. Experts say this sector is creating more than 1.5 million jobs a year. 317,000 New Service Jobs ''Services is very labor-intensive,'' said John Hekman, a senior economist at the Claremont Economics Institute in Claremont, Calif. 
In September alone, when the loss of 103,000 manufacturing jobs pushed the unemployment rate up one-tenth of a percent, to 5.2 percent, service industries added 317,000 jobs. That reflects the return of teachers to their classrooms and the ending of a telephone workers' strike. But economists say health-care providers, temporary-help agencies, hotels and the entertainment industry consistently added jobs.
The health-care industry is growing at just less than 10 percent a year, said Geoffrey Fenton, a spokesman for Baxter International Inc., a large medical supplies manufacturer in Deerfield, Ill.
Baxter added 2,400 jobs in 1988, and Mr. Fenton said the payroll continued to grow this year. Revenue rose 10 percent last year, and sales are significantly higher this year, he said.
Orders to the 6,000 to 7,000 hospitals Baxter supplies are increasing as an aging population requires more medical care. But the fastest-growing area of new business for Baxter lies in the sale of ''alternate-site'' products, like intravenous solutions and dialysis items used at home and in nursing homes. Overall outpatient care is growing at the rate of about 20 percent annually, Mr. Hekman said.
 
'Meteoric' Growth
For temporary workers, employment growth has been ''meteoric'' over the last five years, said Mitchell Fromstein, chief executive of Manpower Inc.
As a result of this growth, Manpower's permanent staff has increased by 1,000 employees since the beginning of the year, Mr. Fromstein said.
''We're increasing the number of offices we operate by 10 percent a year, and we will do at least that going forward,'' he said.
Mr. Fromstein noted that the number of people employed temporarily has tripled since 1982.
In the entertainment and recreation sector, theme parks are booming. The Walt Disney Company has added about 4,000 people to its payroll with the opening of three new attractions at Disney World in Orlando, Fla. -Disney-MGM Studios, Typhoon Lagoon water park and a nighttime entertainment section, a spokesman, Erwin Okun, said. $600 Million Investment MCA Inc. is investing $600 million in a Universal Studios movie park that will compete directly with Disney's Florida attractions when it opens in the spring.

HEADLINE: Summit Bid By Venezuela

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 9

 BODY:
Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez, is calling for a special summit meeting of rich and poor countries to tackle the crippling debt and other economic problems of South American nations.
''If our relations with creditor countries do not improve by next year, there could be unforeseeable consequences in Latin America,'' Mr. Perez said in an interview published today in Le Figaro, the French daily. 
He said Latin America's worsening economic crisis risked sparking riots in Venezuela and other countries like Argentina, Brazil and Mexico.
''We have arrived at a turning point,'' Mr. Perez said. ''If we do not settle the debt problem, all our sacrifices will be for nothing, because of the resources that will have to be spent servicing our debt.''
Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Venezuela and Chile are among the 10 most-indebted third world countries, owing a total of $343 billion.
In Venezuela, 300 people were killed in February in riots against price controls and the removal of state subsidies introduced as part of austerity measures.
Mr. Perez, supported by India, Egypt and Senegal, issued a similar call at the seven-nation summit of top industrial democracies in Paris in July. France backed the idea, but the United States, Britain and West Germany were unenthusiastic.

HEADLINE: On Horse Racing;
Gold Cup Upstaged By OTB

BYLINE: By Steven Crist

 BODY:
rrMaybe the Belmont Special train that left Penn Station Saturday morning is still stuck in a tunnel somewhere. Maybe 15,000 people all got the day wrong and thought that the Jockey Club Gold Cup was next Saturday. Or maybe the meters on the turnstiles counted only every second customer.
Sadly, none of the above is likely, and the fact remains that only 18,260 people were at Belmont Park three days ago to see Easy Goer win the Gold Cup: a day, a race and a horse that would have drawn at least twice that crowd a generation ago. 
Where have all the horseplayers gone?
Easy Goer is as popular a horse as has raced in New York this decade, and the rest of the Gold Cup card was one of the year's best. The weather was as crisp and inviting as autumn in New York can be.
Nor was it the fact that Easy Goer probably had to fall down to lose and would pay off at the stingy rate of just $2.20 for $2. When Kelso won five straight Gold Cups from 1960 through 1964, he never paid more than $2.80, but the stands were packed. rrSo where have all the horseplayers gone? Gone to OTB, in many cases, which was not an option in Kelso's day. An estimated 100,000 people a day bet through Offtrack Betting Corporation shops around the state. On Saturday, they bet $5.28 million on the Belmont card. Those at the track bet $5.16 million.
Optimists and bottom-liners would say that Saturday's $10.44 million betting handle means the game is better than ever. OTB has enabled the total horse betting handle to grow faster than inflation since Kelso's era, allowing New York to continue presenting the nation's best racing in summer and fall. Few would argue that OTB is necessary for racing to survive the competition for the entertainment and wagering dollar.
That does not mean, however, that it does not matter whether fans are participating from a storefront betting shop on Broadway or from a seat in the Belmont grandstand. There are major differences, both financially and philosophically.
For every dollar wagered at the racetrack on most bets, 83 percent is returned to the bettors. Half of the remaining 17 percent, or 8.5 percent, goes to the track. The rest is shared by the State of New York (5 percent), race purses (3 percent) and the state breeding fund (0.5 percent). rrAt New York City OTB, the purses and the breeding fund get the same slices, but only 1.75 percent (instead of 8.75 percent) goes to the track, and just 1.1 percent (instead of 5 percent) goes to the state. The remaining 10.65 percent goes to OTB itself, which also takes a 5 percent surcharge on winning payoffs for payments to the city.
OTB is administered in such a way, by six regional corporations created solely to provide six times as many paychecks for political appointees, that it barely turns a profit, despite its exorbitant slice of the betting dollar. And every dollar it handles provides less than a quarter of the revenue for the track and the state than an on-track dollar does.
It is tempting to fault Belmont officials for failing to drum up a larger crowd for the Gold Cup. These officials have certainly made mistakes. They have allowed cheap horses and New York-bred runners to dull the daily racing fare and have failed to persuade legislators to ease the excessive takeout rate and unreasonable withholding taxes that are driving gamblers to other games. rrBut Belmont did everything right in promoting this year's Gold Cup. A heavy print-advertising campaign reminded day after day that this would be the last chance to see Easy Goer race in New York this year. The racing office put together a fine card, and bringing the old gelding Creme Fraiche back for a retirement parade down the stretch was nice.
OTB should be creating new customers, who might bet mostly at the storefronts but then might actually want to see racing in the flesh on a day like last Saturday. It is just not happening. The message that racing has failed to deliver is that being there means more than an extra 5 percent on your winning tickets.
It means seeing a magnificent thoroughbred at the top of his game, watching him closely and feeling something special as he walks by you in the paddock. It is the tension of the post parade, the clang of the starting bell, the murmurs and then the shouts of encouragement from the crowd when the favorite makes his move.
It is reveling in an afternoon like last Saturday at a park as glorious as Belmont, glimpsing the last flowers of summer and the first turning leaves of fall, taking a deep breath as the horses turn for home and feeling the chill of coming winter sting your lungs and clear your head.
It's a ticket you can't buy at any OTB shop.

HEADLINE: With Phones Everywhere, Everyone Is Talking More

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
Americans tell pollsters that they do not have enough time to cook, clean, see their children or just relax. But they are spending an ever-growing part of their day on the telephone.
In some business and social circles, it is de rigueur to complain about all this telephoning, and new devices to insulate people from callers seem to be catching on. But from 1980 to 1987, the time Americans spent on the telephone increased 24 percent, from 3.017 trillion minutes to 3.754 trillion minutes, while the population grew only 7 percent, according to the Federal Communications Commission.
Business and residential use grew about equally, the F.C.C. said. While some of the increase is due to facsimile machines and computers, ''I'd be real surprised if machines talking to machines accounted for more than 10 percent of the increase,'' said James Lande, an F.C.C. economist. 
Checking in. Catching up. Passing it on. Sounding off. That is what people do when there is a phone in the car, on the plane, in every room, in the backyard and even on the golf course, not to mention call waiting, automatic redial, answering machines and a sharp drop in long-distance rates. The time spent on the phone is also increasing because it can be used for so much more: information services, shopping, banking and socializing with strangers.
''It's like the Law of the Hammer,'' said Arnold Brown, a consultant in New York who helps companies prepare for the future. ''When you give a child a hammer, everything becomes a nail.''
 
A Domino Effect
Joel Gross, a telephone analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, sees something he calls ''the Ping-Pong, or domino, effect.'' From his research he has concluded that users of cellular car phones are often making calls they would not have had time to make before. And each of these new calls can generate several other calls.
The opportunity to talk to almost anybody from almost anywhere is most appealing to those who believe that time should always be used for purposeful activities. Randy Friedman, a partner in a Detroit law firm and the owner of several businesses, said the car phone he bought five years ago has allowed him to double his workload. ''Once you can do business in your car,'' he said, ''you're always doing business.'' Now, he never worries about being late to the office: ''If I'm caught in traffic, I just do business on the phone.''
Carey Lyons, who sells dental equipment for the Swiss company Bien Air from his office in Cornwall, N.Y., makes work and personal calls from his car phone. After learning that an acquaintance needed a lawyer, he used the car phone to find someone who could help. ''I would have forgotten about it otherwise or definitely delayed it,'' he said.
 
Long Distance No Obstacle
Mr. Lyons and his wife, Elaine, both 34 years old, make long-distance calls frequently and casually, unlike older people who remember when coast-to-coast calls cost five times what they do now. They call her parents in Florida at least three times a week. ''After the first three minutes,'' he said, ''they talk a lot faster.''
Younger people have no such inhibitions. Michael Findley, a 22-year-old salesman at a Manhattan telephone store called the Fone Booth, lives in his parents' house in Queens. In his room he has two telephone lines, four telephones and a fax machine. He uses the fax to send notes to his girlfriend in Japan.
''If someone calls me, I'm always accessible,'' he said. ''If I had only one phone, I wouldn't talk as much.''
Remarkably, sociologists have little hard data about how the use of the telephone may be altering human communication. The effect of the telephone on society has been studied far less than, say, the effect of television or the computer.
 
A Way of Reaching Out
To some, the increasing use of the telephone is just another way for people to expand their reach. Dr. Deirdre Boden, an assistant professor of sociology at Washington University in St. Louis who studies telephone conversations, said, ''We live in a society where people can't be face to face.''
Communication by phone closely mimics in-person contact, she said. She has found, for example, that with car phones when callers have a choice of using a receiver or a speaker, they tend to choose the intimacy of the receiver.
Dr. Claude Fischer, a sociology professor of the University of California at Berkeley, says the telephone mostly augments traditional communication. ''Many telephone conversations are conducted to arrange face-to-face meetings,'' he said.
Not always, though. James Katz, a sociologist at Bell Communications Research in Morristown, N.J., said, ''The telephone is very good for keeping families together, because some people may find it easier to talk to their relatives on the phone than to see them in person.''
 
Calls Generated by Technology
Whatever the psychological implications, new technology has clearly made the phone more omnipresent. More calls are generated because of answering machines, now owned by 28 percent of the nation's households, according to the Electronic Industries Association. People who use them say they make and receive more calls because of them. ''In olden days you would just miss the call,'' said Michael Beglin, a businessman in Nashville.
Jill Goodman, an art dealer in New York, says she talks on the phone so often that ''I'm tortured about it, teased and insulted.'' She uses the phone to socialize, shop and check in with people she wants to stay in touch with but does not want to take the time to see.
''I have two lines in the country, two lines at home in the city and three lines in my office, if that gives you any idea of how much phone I can generate,'' she said. A month ago, after resisting initially, she decided to have a car phone installed. ''I thought it might be nice to have a couple of hours without being reachable,'' she said. ''But I didn't like not being able to reach when I wanted to.''
Increasingly, too, people are using the phone to get services, information and products. The 900 numbers, which require callers to pay the cost, and the 800 numbers, paid for by the calls' recipients, are growing quickly. Sprint Gateways started a new 900 service in May that already has 250 lines. Callers can get wrestling trivia, financial updates, real-estate information and a host of other data. They can even play a version of ''Family Feud,'' which receives as many as 7,000 calls a day, said Adrian Toader, the director of sales and marketing.
Telephone shopping through 800 numbers continues to grow, too. In 1986, L. L. Bean, the retailer in Freeport, Me., received 60 percent of its orders by telephone and 40 percent by mail; by 1988, telephone orders had risen to 70 percent. Like an increasing number of retailers, L. L. Bean allows customers to call in their orders 24 hours a day.
 
Personal But Anonymous
But callers to 800 numbers often want more than a new shirt or sweater. Susan Dilworth, who takes telephone orders for L. L. Bean, said, ''A lot of people call and say: 'I'm coming to New England for the first time. How should I dress?' '' Other callers order merchandise but then begin talking about their personal lives. ''I think they're lonely,'' Mrs. Dilworth said.
Indeed, these anonymous but personal contacts are so popular that some people are becoming hooked. Marilyn Ng-A-Qui, the acting executive director of the New York City Self-Help Clearinghouse, said one man called looking for help because he had run up a $5,000 bill calling 900 numbers. ''It is emerging as a problem all over the country,'' she said.
Despite the deluge of telephone conversation, there are holdouts. Lois Korey, a partner in a New York advertising agency, writes letters whenever she can, often suggesting lunch meetings. ''I really like to see who I'm talking to,'' she said.
But even her partner, Allen Kay, calls her from his office just four feet away. The only time he could not telephone, Mrs. Korey said, was when he was in his car. And now those days are over. ''He got a car phone a month ago, and he calls all the time,'' she said. ''When I sit in the front seat of his car, I try to step on it.''
