HEADLINE: California Alliance Proposes Vote On Broad Environmental Measure

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10

 BODY:
In a move that has as much to do with California politics as the environment, an alliance of politicians and environmentalists today offered a ballot measure that they called the broadest effort ever mounted to protect air, food and water against chemical contamination.
If passed, the measure would phase out all agricultural pesticides that cause cancer or birth defects, ban new oil drilling off the coast and set up a $500 million state cleanup fund for oil spills, cut by 40 percent carbon dioxide emissions believed to contribute to global warming, prohibit the clearing of ancient redwood stands and create an elected environmental advocate with the power to sue to enforce the law.
 
Given Strong Chance for Passage
The measure would have profound consequences well beyond the state's borders for the chemical and agricultural industries and is expected to draw bitter opposition from them.
It has also received a cool reception from some environmentalists who say it tries to do too much and may not withstand legal challenge. But the measure is given a strong chance for passage amid a rising tide of public concern about the environment. 
Drafters of the proposal were unable to say today what the measures would ultimately cost.
The complex measure is the latest move by states and localities to take the lead in environmental legislation and proceed with more dispatch than the Federal Government. Tom Hayden, a Democratic State Assemblyman who was chairman of the panel that drafted the initiative, called it ''the most significant proposal for protecting the environment ever placed before the voters in this country.''
Drafters hope to put the proposal on the ballot next year, on the same date that Californians will vote for governor. The measure is already emerging as a major factor in the gubernatorial race. Candidates in the state have increasingly taken to linking their names to popular ballot measures to bring out sympathetic voters. But critics charge that the candidates are using the measures to skirt strict limits on campaign contributions, since there are no limits on contributions to ballot drives.
Even before the measure was written, Attorney General John Van de Kamp, a Democratic candidate for governor, endorsed it. His action put off balance two potential opponents, Dianne Feinstein, a Democrat who is a former Mayor of San Francisco, and Senator Pete Wilson, a Republican. Both have been asked to endorse the initiative and are considering it. But Senator Wilson, who has made elaborate gestures toward the environmental vote, wrote the drafters today that he would join only if certain ''defects'' in the measure, like transferring environmental enforcement authority from the governor to an environmental advocate, were corrected.
 
'Greater Concern' on Pollution
Environmentalists say they detect a rising tide of opinion against pollution in California and elsewhere that made the time ripe for today's move. ''There is greater concern than ever before,'' said Al Meyerhoff of the Natural Resources Defense Council, a nonprofit environmental advocacy group. ''This measure recognizes these issues cannot be dealt with piecemeal. California is going to set the stage for the battle over the environment.''
A ballot measure is needed, environmentalists say, because the Legislature has failed to act. ''A lot of these proposals have been discussed ad nauseum in the Legislature,'' said Lucy Blake, executive director of the 25,000-member League of Conservation Voters, a political action committee. ''As the environmental challenge becomes more staggering, we must circumvent many competing forces in the Legislature and get a clear expression from the voters.''
The measure was drawn up by representatives of the Sierra Club, the League of Conservation Voters, the Natural Resources Defense Council, the National Toxics Campaign, Citizens for a Better Environment, Lieut. Gov. Leo McCarthy and Attorney General Van de Kamp.
 
Three Major Concerns
The measure is aimed mainly at three concerns: the food supply, global warming and protection of coastal waters. The main elements are these:
* All pesticides and herbicides known to cause cancer or reproductive harm would have to be phased out by 1996. This would affect 24 chemicals in use in California, including Alachlor, Captan, 1,3-Dichloropropene and Aldicarb. If no alternatives could be found and ''severe economic hardship'' to the state's agriculture industry would result, a three-year extension could be obtained.
* The allowable levels of pesticide residues on foods would be reduced to levels safe for children. Produce imported from other states and countries would have to meet the same standard.
* Exposure of farm workers to dangerous pesticides would be reduced by lengthening quarantine periods before workers are allowed into a treated field. The workers would also be allowed access to pesticide use records.
* The state would develop a plan to reduce emissions of any gases that contribute to global warming when they rise into the stratosphere. The focus is on carbon dioxide, a major product of combustion, which would have to be reduced by 40 percent by the year 2010, less an adjustment for population growth. The measure does not specify how that would be done.
* The use or manufacture of all chlorofluorocarbons must be phased out by 1997, except for medical uses. CFC's are used in hundreds of ways in making electronic products and have been found to destroy the protective layer of ozone in the upper atmosphere.
* A $200 million state fund would be established to purchase stands of ancient redwood trees if threatened by logging. A one-year moratorium on the clearing of such strands would be imposed on the day of the vote, Nov. 7, 1990. Trees consume carbon dioxide and are thought to be needed to counter global warming.
* New offshore oil drilling would be permitted within the three-mile state limit only in a national emergency and the state would draw up a oil spill prevention plan. Oil producers would be assessed a fee of 25 cents a barrel to establish a $500 million oil spill prevention and cleanup fund.
The measure does not address other concerns like smog, drinking water quality and solid waste disposal. The drafters said these matters were already being addressed by other legislation.
Unlike in New York, voters in California can make law directly through the voter initiative under the State Constitution. And in the last 12 years Californians have used the ballot to try to roll back insurance rates, cut property taxes, limit state and local government spending and put new curbs on campaign contributions. An initiative becomes law if it gets more than half the votes cast.
 
Not Taking Sides
The environmentalists said today that in putting aside past differences and working with the Attorney General they were not taking the Democrat's side in the gubernatorial race. ''We have not any evaluation on the race yet,'' said Ms. Blake of the League of Conservation Voters.
But Otto Bos, Senator Wilson's campaign manager, said the Republican was invited to join the initiative process only at the last minute, and he suggested that Mr. Van de Kamp was using it to get around state campaign contribution limits. Backers of the proposal believe Mr. Wilson may remain neutral on it next year.
At a news conference this morning, Mr. Van de Kamp vigorously disputed suggestions that he was using the measure to get around contribution limits. ''Utter nonsense,'' he said.
Conspicuously absent from the measure is the Environmental Defense Fund, the major backer of a measure three years ago that requires warnings on products that cause cancer or birth defects. David Roe, a lawyer with the group in Oakland said he supported the initiative ''in principle'' but had reservations about the way the measure was drawn. It is almost certain to be challenged on the ground that it violates a California constitutional provision that ballot measures address only a single topic.
Clark Biggs, a spokesman for the California Farm Bureau Federation, representing the state's agricultural industry, said his organization had not seen the full proposal and was unable to comment in detail. ''We certainly aren't opposed to pesticide regulation if it's reasonable and protects agriculture and farm workers,'' he said. Mr. Meyerhoff said substitutes were available for most of the affected pesticides.
Mr. Hayden said the group would start next month to gather the 500,000 signatures needed to qualify the measure for the ballot, adding that $700,000 had already been raised for gathering the signatures and promoting the measure.

HEADLINE: Bush Will Attend Latin Drug Talks

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The leaders of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia urged President Bush today to meet them within 90 days to discuss ways to curb the cocaine trade, and the President quickly agreed.
The three South American leaders are meeting in Ica, Peru, to forge a strategy to battle the region's cocaine cartels. Peru and Bolivia produce more than 90 percent of the world's coca. Colombian drug cartels turn the partly refined coca paste into pure cocaine and smuggle it into the United States and Europe. 
Responding to the request for talks, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. said, ''We accept. The President will go.'' White House officials said that the President would try to meet the 90-day timetable but that it was uncertain if he could do so.
Mr. Bush has long advocated such a high-level meeting on the drug crisis, and White House officials said they had hoped that it would be convened this fall to complement the President's much-promoted national drug strategy, announced last month.
 
Refers to Bush Strategy
The gathering of Latin American leaders in Ica, a small desert town southeast of Lima, included Presidents Alan Garcia of Peru, Virgilio Barco Vargas of Colombia and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia.
Referring to the Bush drug strategy, which calls for increased economic and military aid to their countries, the presidents said in a communique: ''We welcome the Bush initiative and accordingly we invited him to a meeting in the next 90 days.''
As the leaders were meeting in Ica, a bomb exploded in Trujillo, a nearby city where the foreign ministers of eight Latin nations were meeting, The Associated Press reported. No group took responsibility for the attack, and there were no injuries.
 
7 Slain in Medellin
BOGOTA, Colombia, Oct. 10 (AP) -Gunmen on motorcycles killed two executives of the newspaper El Espectador today in an apparent effort by cocaine traffickers to force the daily to end its anti-drug campaign.
The shootings, in Medellin, follow 13 bombings reported in three other Colombian cities overnight. It was the largest outbreak of attacks since the Government began its war on drugs.
Tonight the police said assailants in Medellin shot to death Roberto Sarasty, the 55-year-old director of Cronista Democratica magazine, on a downtown street. In a northern Medellin barrio, four people were killed when a working-class neighborhood bar was sprayed with gunfire.
The outbreak of violence today came during a visit by Gen. Maxwell Thurman, who heads the United States Southern Command, based in Panama.
The slain newspaper executives were Marta Luz Lopez, administrator of the paper's Medellin office, and Miguel Soler, the circulation manager there.
The El Espectador publisher, Guillermo Cano, was assassinated by drug traffickers on Dec. 17, 1986.

HEADLINE: JUDGE REJECTS BAN ON NASA LAUNCHING

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
A Federal district judge this evening denied a motion by environmentalists to delay the launching of the space shuttle Atlantis on Thursday because of concerns over a nuclear power supply.
Nevertheless the launching could be delayed for days because of a potential engine problem. Engineers at Cape Canaveral, Fla., uncovered an apparent malfunction in one of three main rocket engines of the Atlantis. 
After hearing sharp debate over the possibility of plutonium peril from an accident, Judge Oliver Gasch ruled that the space agency had complied with environmental requirements and he refused to grant a temporary restraining order to block launching of the shuttle carrying the nuclear-powered space probe Galileo, which is targeted for Jupiter.
Judge Gasch said, ''This court will not substitute its own judgment regarding the merits of the proposed action for that of the government agencies.'' He said delaying the liftoff with a restraining order probably would cause the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to miss the launching window to Jupiter, which closes in mid-November. Such a delay would push the next available launching opportunity to 1991 and cost the nation an addition $164 million to maintain the $1.5 billion program until then, he said.
The plaintiffs said after the ruling that they would go back to Judge Gasch Wednesday seeking a judgment on another motion they filed for a preliminary injunction. If that move is denied, they will seek an emergency appeal to a higher court, said Jeremy Rifkin of the Foundation on Economic Trends, one of the groups.
In two hours of testimony, lawyers representing environmentalists charged that there is a high probability of an accident like the explosion on the space shuttle Challenger that could spread deadly plutonium. But Government lawyers vigorously denied that contention.
The lawsuit filed by three groups contends that NASA failed to follow environmental regulations and that the flight should be stopped because ''there is a very high probability of an accident'' that could spread deadly plutonium over central Florida.
 
Peril Described as Minute
Justice Department lawyers, arguing for the Government, said the likelihood of a plutonium release was very small. Even if such an accident occurred, they said, tests indicate that radiation would be contained by protective casings around nuclear fuel elements in the Galileo spacecraft.
Shuttle officials must decide on Wednesday morning whether to continue with the countdown, looking to a launching Thursday afternoon, or to replace an electronic control unit in the suspect engine.
 
Technological Outlook
Replacing the control unit could cause a one-week delay, said Capt. Robert Crippen of the Navy, who is deputy director of the space shuttle program for NASA.
Byron Wood, manager of the shuttle engine project at Rocketdyne, a division of the Rockwell International Corporation, said the malfunction occurred Monday night while the three engine systems were undergoing routine preflight tests.
At the court hearing, Edward Lee Rogers - representing the Florida Coalition for Peace and Justice, the Christic Institute and the Foundation on Economic Trends - said NASA failed to consider alternative times and launching vehicles for flying Galileo, as well as different types of power.

HEADLINE: Charleston Unemployment Rises After Storm, but Mayor Is Hopeful

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 10

 BODY:
Hurricane Hugo put a lot of people out of work temporarily but should not cause long-term damage to Charleston's economy, Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. says.
Unemployment in South Carolina jumped from 4.5 percent to more than 16 percent after the hurricane, which struck Charleston on Sept. 21 and killed 25 people in the Carolinas.
The storm, which struck Puerto Rico and several Caribbean islands before reaching the United States mainland, did an estimated $4 billion to $5 billion damage in South Carolina and $725 million in North Carolina. 
In Charleston, which bore the brunt of the storm, unemployment is estimated at 10 percent, the Mayor said on Monday. But he predicted that the economic forces behind the city's most prosperous period in 100 years would help the economy recover quickly.
''Our goal is to have our tourism economy back to full steam as quickly as possible so that jobs that have been lost can be replaced,'' Mr. Riley said.
Growth will continue, he said, as thousands of people migrate to the area to retire or work in the beach resorts.
''Charleston was booming more than it had in 100 years,'' he said, ''and the reasons for that boom have not changed.''
The Rev. Jesse Jackson suggested that unemployed youths be given Federal job training so they can help rebuild the region.
''The silver lining in the cloud is the chance to train and retrain people,'' Mr. Jackson said Monday in Greenville, S.C.
Mr. Jackson said he met last week with Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, who he said was receptive to the proposal.
At the urging of Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr,, a Federally organized program was set up last month to provide temporary jobs for the unemployed removing debris, but while more than 3,300 jobs are available, only a few hundred people have signed up for them.
About 250 engineers and soldiers from Fort Stewart, Ga., arrived on Monday to help remove debris in Charleston and Berkeley and Dorchester counties. They brought 13 front-end loaders and 40 dump trucks.
Mr. Riley said he hoped that much of the debris could be cleared in two weeks, although Army officials were not as optimistic.
''We could have people cleaning up for the next six months,'' said Lieut. Col. Jim Scott, district engineer for the Charleston District of the United States Army Corps of Engineers.
Streets throughout the region are still littered with piles of leaves, limbs and logs cut from felled trees.
Refrigerators and other appliances are piled up along the streets in low-lying areas and islands that were flooded in the storm.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Abortion Foes Lose Plea for Hearing on Their Racketeering Law Penalties

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today let stand a lower court's ruling that found a group of abortion protesters liable under the Federal racketeering law for damages to a Philadelphia abortion clinic they tried to drive out of business.
Because the Court did not rule on the merits of the case, instead refusing to review a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia, the decision has no formal effect outside Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware. But the Court will have more opportunities to consider the issue of whether abortion protesters should be subject to the stern civil penalties of the racketeering laws when a dozen similar lawsuits now in the Federal courts reach the appellate level.
The decision today leaves in place a decision in March in which the appeals court upheld a jury verdict. The verdict ordered 26 members of the Pro-Life Coalition of Southeastern Pennsylvania to pay $108,000 to the Northeast Women's Center, a Philadelphia abortion clinic that had been the focus of the group's protests since its opening in 1976. 
 
Nine Years of Picketing
As often as three days a week for nine years, anti-abortion demonstrators had picketed the clinic, trying to block access and dissuade patients from entering. The clinic was eventually forced to move after it lost its lease.
The clinic filed suit under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act. The law, intended to aid Federal prosecutions of organized crime, also permits private damage suits against those who conduct an ''enterprise'' through a ''pattern of racketeering activity.'' Successful plaintiffs can win triple damages plus their legal fees.
The clinic's lawsuit focused on four incidents in 1985 and 1986 in which the protesters had forced their way into the building to conduct sit-ins. As a result of those incidents, the protesters were convicted in state court on charges of trespass, criminal conspiracy and disorderly conduct. The Court of Appeals found that the protesters' behavior amounted to extortion, a Federal offense that was an appropriate basis for a suit under the racketeering law.
The protesters' Supreme Court appeal, McMonagle v. Northeast Women's Center, No. 88-2137, was prepared by G. Robert Blakey, a law professor at Notre Dame Law School who helped to draft the racketeering law when he was a Senate staff member and who has often argued for new and expansive uses of the statute. In the appeal, he argued that the law, usually known as RICO, was not intended to be used against an organization that did not have a profit motive. He also argued that the protesters should not be penalized for engaging ''in a prolonged struggle to bring about political and social change by exercise of their First Amendment rights.''
 
Brief Dissent by White
Only one Supreme Court Justice, Byron R. White, voted to hear the appeal. In a brief dissenting statement, Justice White said the Court should have taken the case to resolve a conflict among the Federal appellate circuits over whether RICO liability can be found ''despite the absence of any economic motivation on the part of the defendants.''
The Supreme Court does not give reasons for refusing to hear a case. Typically, however, the Court does not take up a legal issue until it has been addressed by several appellate courts. The fact that no other racketeering suit against abortion protesters has yet even gone to trial made the Philadelphia case an unlikely candidate for Supreme Court review.
Abortion rights groups have vowed to use the racketeering law aggressively against those who try to disrupt abortion clinics. But those groups are not the only ones interested in that legal strategy. Earlier this year, the town of Brookline, Mass., brought a similar suit against Operation Rescue, the most active of the groups that protest in front of abortion clinics. The suit seeks recovery of the overtime that the town has had to pay its police force to protect local clinics.
Other action at the Court today included the following:
 
Death Penalty
There were several developments today concerning the death penalty. In the case with the broadest potential implications, the Court agreed to hear the State of Arizona's appeal of a Federal appellate ruling that overturned an Arizona murderer's death sentence.
In the drug-related killing, a man injected a woman with an overdose of heroin and then choked and beat her when she did not die immediately. The state courts upheld the death sentence on a finding that the murder was ''especially heinous and depraved'' as specified by Arizona's death penalty law.
But the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, which is based in San Francisco and includes Arizona, overturned the sentence on the ground that while the killing was a ''grisly affair,'' it was not particularly shocking compared with other Arizona murders in which the death sentence had not been imposed. The appeals court was ruling on the murderer's petition for a writ of habeas corpus, which is a challenge to the constitutionality of a sentence and is the principle avenue of Federal court review of state criminal systems.
In its Supreme Court appeal, Ricketts v. Jeffers, No. 89-189, the state is arguing that a Federal court, when ruling on a death row inmate's petition for a writ of habeas corpus, should be required to show greater deference to the findings of the state courts. If the Supreme Court accepts this argument, the jurisdiction of Federal courts when considering such petitions could be substantially circumscribed.
The Court's ruling in June in the case of Johnny Paul Penry, a retarded death row inmate in Texas, formed the basis for two other actions today. In the Penry case, the Court ruled that while the Constitution does not bar the execution of mentally retarded murderers, it does require a jury to consider a defendant's mental limitations before imposing sentence.
Today the Court overturned a death sentence of another Texas murderer whose request to instruct the jury that he had been ''impaired as a result of voluntary intoxication'' was refused by the judge. The Court ordered the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals to reconsider the case in light of the Penry ruling. (James v. Texas, No. 89-5484.) And the Court agreed to hear an appeal by still another Texas death row inmate whose lawyers had not presented evidence of his paranoid schizophrenia at his 1980 murder trial. The issue in the case, Selvage v. Lynaugh, No. 87-6700, is whether the Penry decision is to be applied retroactively, and under what circumstances.
 
Search Warrants
The Court agreed to decide when the police may, in the course of conducting a search, seize evidence that is in plain view but that has not been listed in the search warrant. The scope of what is known as the ''plain view exception'' to the search warrant requirement has been a troublesome question in criminal law for years.
After an ambiguous 1971 Supreme Court ruling, most lower courts have held that the police must have come upon the unlisted evidence ''inadvertently'' for the seizure to meet constitutional requirements. In the case the Court accepted today, Horton v. California, No. 88-7164, the California Court of Appeal rejected the ''inadvertent discovery'' approach. The California court found no constitutional violation in the seizure of guns when the police entered a robbery suspect's home with a search warrant that specified only stolen jewelry.
 
Wiretap Evidence
The Court agreed to hear a Justice Department appeal growing out of the 1983 robbery of the Wells Fargo depot in West Hartford, Conn. Twenty members of a Puerto Rican group, Los Macheteros, have been charged with the $7.2 million robbery in a case that has not yet gone to trial.
After a long pretrial proceeding, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, ruled earlier this year that the Federal Government could not use a number of wiretaps as evidence because the Government had not acted quickly enough to have a judge seal the tapes as protection against tampering. In its Supreme Court appeal, U.S. v. Rios, No. 89-61, the Government is arguing that while the delay of several months was a mistake, the court order barring use of the tapes as evidence was not justified in the absence of any evidence that the tapes had been altered.

HEADLINE: They Aren't Fleeing Hungary

 BODY:
Why are thousands of East Germans taking to the streets and thousands more running from home? Why are Hungarians doing neither? The explanation has less to do with economics than with everything else.
The standard of living is similar in both countries. But Hungary has now begun to persuade its people that they will soon have a chance to govern themselves, giving the disgruntled an opportunity to change things. 
In Budapest over the weekend, the ruling Communist Party voted to junk orthodox Marxism, change its name to the Hungarian Socialist Party and submit itself to popular judgment in contested elections.
In East Germany, meantime, with the whole world and Mikhail Gorbachev watching, an ossified Communist regime observed its 40th anniversary by turning riot sticks on the workers it purports to represent. Protesters chanting ''Gorby! Gorby!'' and ''We need freedom!'' completed the debacle for a Government already stunned by the flight of 45,000 mostly young people.
The Bush Administration, properly, responds to these dramatic developments in undramatic, nonprovocative ways. Mr. Gorbachev can't afford the luxury of such detachment. Moscow's contradictory needs for stability and change challenge even his extraordinary political skills.
Nobody can predict the outcome of Budapest's remarkable political experiment, but one salutary result is already evident - the only mass exodus from Hungary is the throng of weekend shoppers moving across open frontiers to Austria. True enough, Hungarians who might consider leaving have nothing like the temptations open to East Germans: automatic citizenship in a flourishing West Germany sharing a common language. Even so, a regime in Budapest willing to risk elections can bank on a very different popular response than can the tired, stodgy rulers of East Germany.
Faced with the worst crisis in his tenure as party leader, the 77-year-old Erich Honecker castigates ''imperialists'' for trying to destabilize East Germany and ''slander'' its achievements, thereby emulating Don Quixote's ''futile running against the steadily turning sails of a windmill.''
Mr. Honecker's words, in the apt vernacular, are off the wall. The gusts unsettling East Germany blow from Moscow, not Washington or Bonn. Far from stirring up trouble, capitalist West Germany lavishes billions in subsidies on East Germany to make life easier for kith and kin. Tellingly, Mr. Honecker complains about Bonn's treating all Germans as common citizens, but does not complain about Bonn's giving Common Market privileges to his country's exports.
In fact, tens of thousands of East Germans want changes, not exit permits. They want to be treated, finally, as grown-ups. They want the right to travel, to have greater access to non-Communist publications, to belong to true opposition parties. They want what has already been won in the Soviet Union, Poland and Hungary.
The fleeing East Germans mainly embarrass Mr. Honecker. What truly challenges and threatens his regime is stubborn East Germans shouting ''We're staying here!''

HEADLINE: A Welcome Shift on Child Care

 BODY:
''A witches' brew'' is what Representative Thomas Downey calls the upcoming Senate-House conference on Federal support for child care. He's not far off the mark. There are conflicts not only between the House and Senate but within the House itself, which endorsed a legislative package last week that is roughly parallel to the Senate's Act for Better Child Care Services. Even so, it's possible the brew can produce a palatable child care bill before the end of the year. 
The original A.B.C. bill, sponsored by Senator Christopher Dodd, proposed $2.5 billion a year to help states provide child care for lower-income working families. The states would match 20 percent of the Federal money. That original bill would also have established a commission to set national standards for day care centers and personnel. George Bush, then running for President, soon weighed in with a Republican initiative: a ''children's tax credit'' that would have given poor working parents $1,000 per year per child.
Since then the Democrats and Republicans have been competing with one another to expand or further refine this package of benefits. Legislation now in both houses is a combination of expanded tax credits and Federal grants far more complicated than Senator Dodd's initial proposal, and far more costly and comprehensive than anything President Bush had in mind.
The Senate's $3.5 billion package would provide expanded tax credits and grants directly to families and help states increase the supply of day care providers and establish standards for them. The new House version is similar though somewhat costlier, but contains a conspicuous contradiction: unable to mesh a proposal for direct appropriations to states and one for block grants, the House approved both.
In addition to resolving these differences, Congress still needs to address a lingering church-state issue. Millions of working parents depend on church-sponsored day care, but resistance to any form of public funding of sectarian child care programs is widespread.
Despite these complexities, there is every reason to hope that the final result will give lower-income working families access to safe, decent child care and boost them a little higher up the economic ladder. Indeed, the legislation already must be counted as evidence of a remarkable and wonderfully welcome change in America's politics and priorities.

HEADLINE: Reaganism Now Liability For Giuliani

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
When Ronald Reagan became President in 1981, Rudolph W. Giuliani went to Washington as a top official in the Justice Department and vigorously pursued the new administration's policies.
Now, Mr. Giuliani's opponent for mayor of New York City has tried to make Mr. Giuliani's role in a conservative Republican administration in Washington a campaign issue in a Democratic city that twice rejected Mr. Reagan by large margins.
David N. Dinkins, the Democratic candidate, has depicted Mr. Giuliani, former United States Attorney in Manhattan, as a loyal Reagan Republican who carried out the President's agenda that ''was painful to our city and our urban centers.''
At the same time, Mr. Giuliani has tried to distance himself from the conservative Administration, pointing to occasions when he dissented from its policies and portraying himself as the candidate of a nonpartisan reform movement.
 
No Direct Policy Role
The record shows that Mr. Giuliani, while occasionally dissenting, was more often an aggressive spokesman for the administration on some matters ranging from social policy to criminal law. He was charged with implementing the administration's policy of detaining Haitian refugees seeking political asylum, and he pushed a plan to limit use of the insanity defense. 
But there is no evidence that Mr. Giuliani had any direct role in broader Reagan Administration policies, as Mr. Dinkins has contended - for example, in the cutting of the Federal housing budget from $31 billion to $7 billion a year.
Asked for an interview to review that record, Mr. Giuliani declined. Charles Perkins, a campaign spokesman, said that Mr. Giuliani wanted to concentrate on issues affecting New York City's future.
''The problems of our city are beyond partisian politics,'' Mr. Giuliani told a recent luncheon meeting of the Mortgage Bankers Association.
But in his primary campaign, Mr. Giuliani noted frequently that he was supported by the liberal wing of the Republican Party and maintained that he never embraced Mr. Reagan's broad conservative agenda.
On one occasion his campaign staff released a copy of a letter he wrote in June 1984, as United States Attorney in Manhattan, in which he appeared to oppose efforts by the Administration to improperly deny Social Security disability benefits to some recipients.
 
Prosecuted Meese Associates
Mr. Giuliani has also noted that as United States Attorney, he prosecuted two men who were close to former Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d - his financial adviser and a close friend -in the bribery case involving the Wedtech Corporation, a now-defunct Bronx defense contractor that was treated favorably by the Reagan Administration.
Beginning in 1975, when Mr. Giuliani was appointed to a Justice Department post in the Administration of Gerald R. Ford, until this year, when he resigned as United States Attorney, Mr. Giuliani's Government career closely followed the fortunes of the Republican Party. When Democrats recaptured the White House in 1976, he returned to New York and practiced law.
In 1981, Mr. Giuliani joined the Reagan Administration as an associate Attorney General, the third-ranking post in the Justice Department. In that job he directly oversaw much of the Federal Government's law-enforcement and immigration activities.
 
Angered Reagan Officials
Mr. Giuliani pressed for passage of the Criminal Justice Reform Act of 1982, which would have sharply reduced the rights of defendants, including virtually eliminating the insanity defense. To plead insanity under the bill, he said at the time, a suspect would have had to have ''the mental age of a 2-year-old'' or have been ''so paranoid'' that he believed he was was ''shooting at a house, instead of a human being.'' The measure was not adopted.
In 1983, when President Reagan vetoed legislation setting up a Cabinent-level post of drug czar, Mr. Giuliani took a leading role in explaining the veto. He said the measure would have led to ''conflict and confusion'' and was opposed by ''all law-enforcement agencies that have drug responsibilty.'' But Mr. Reagan signed legislation with a similar provision in 1988.
When Congress, at the request of many police officials, considered a broad ban on handgun bullets capable of piercing bulletproof vests, Mr. Giuliani - though personally supportive of the measure - pointed out flaws in the bill and laid out the Administration's case for a weaker alternative more acceptable to gun lobbyists.
But he angered some Administration officials when he added a single sentence to his testimony in which he urged Congress to pass the bill. A similar measure was passed several years later, after gun groups softened their opposition.
 
Opposed Haitian Political Asylum
While the mantle of Reagan Republicanism has been worn proudly by many candidates across the country, it is an ill-fitting garment for candidates in New York City.
After decades of declining Republican enrollment, Democrats in the city now outnumber Republicans five to one. In the last two Presidential elections, the Democratic candidate has carried the city handily.
Mr. Giuliani's role in opposing political asylum for most refugees from Haiti is not likely to help in a city in which many New Yorkers are either black or immigrants or their offspring.
At the time, the Administration discouraged the immigration of Haitians seeking political asylum in Florida because of concerns by Florida officials that they were being overwhelmed by thousands of immigrants.
As a result of the policy, thousands of Haitian refugees were kept in overcrowded detention centers, some for more than 18 months.
Testifying in a lawsuit challenging the policy in April 1982, Mr. Giuliani argued that the refugees were seeking economic opportunity, not fleeing political oppression. He said, ''There is not a problem, a major problem, a systematic problem of political repression in Haiti.''
 
Sensitivity Questioned
His testimony - offered after he had visited Haiti for two days and reviewed State Department reports - came as human rights groups protested the arrests of journalists and opponents of the Haitian Government.
''He was involved in a brutal program that singled out Haitian refugees,'' said Arthur Helton of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, the group that sued the Government over the immigration policy. ''It has implications for his ability to be sensitive to the diverse communities in New York City.''
Mr. Giuliani has said in his mayoral campaign that the detention policy was needed because of an ''emergency situation'' in Florida. Once the emergency abated, he said, he argued privately within the Administration to limit how long immigrants were detained.
Mr. Perkins, the campaign spokesman, said that in his testimony, Mr. Giuliani clearly acknowledged that there were some valid claims of political repression in Haiti and that he was arguing that some refugees left Haiti for other reasons. Mr. Perkins said Mr. Giuliani's views on political repression in Haiti were based on State Department reports.
In a forum on immigration issues earlier this year, Mr. Giuliani said he opposed, in most instances, the detention of aliens seeking political asylum. He also said he favored wider amnesty for illegal aliens and he pledged to continue to provide city services to them.
 
Called Bork 'Fully Qualified'
While in Washington in 1981, Mr. Giuliani also intervened to drop charges against four top executives of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in a major overseas bribery case that had been vigorously pursued during the Carter Administration.
Mr. Giuliani, who had just taken office in an Administration that promised to be more pro-business, said later that he ordered the settlement because the Government laywers were ''prejudiced against business.'' The case was settled, over the objections of the five Government lawyers handling the case, with a fine against the company.
Mr. Dinkins has also sought to link Mr. Giuliani to Mr. Reagan through the confirmation fight over the United States Supreme Court nomination of Robert H. Bork, a conservative judge who was rejected by the Senate following heated objections from liberals.
When asked if Mr. Giuliani had in fact supported Mr. Bork, Kenneth Caruso, a deputy campaign manager, said it would have been inappropriate for Mr. Giuliani, as a United States Attorney, to comment.
But in an Associated Press dispatch in 1987, when Mr. Giuliani was considering running as a Republican candidate for Senate, he was quoted as saying that Mr. Bork was ''fully qualified'' to be on the Supreme Court.
Asked about the interview, Mr. Perkins said Mr. Giuliani's comment was not an endorsement of Mr. Bork, but merely a comment on his qualifications.

HEADLINE: Vital New York Taxes Lag, and Economy Is Blamed

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Revenue from several of New York City's most important taxes lagged well behind expectations in the last three months and, in some cases, dropped sharply from the same period last year, budget officials say.
The slumping revenues deepen concern about the city's ability to deliver promised services this year without raising taxes. The figures bolster the case of those who say the city needs the $247 million it has budgeted from the huge Columbus Center redevelopment project, which faces a legal challenge.
Officials also fear that the poor performance of the taxes foreshadows more serious and widespread problems for the city economy.
Collections from the general-corporation tax declined 17 percent, to their 1985 level, in the first quarter of the fiscal year that began in July, the budget officials said. The mortgage-recording and real-property transfer taxes plunged 25 percent, compared with the same period last year, and sales-tax receipts failed to match inflation, growing by less than 5 percent, the weakest rate since 1986. These taxes are seen as the most sensitive to changes in economic conditions. 
Although money withheld from paychecks under the personal-income tax rose, by slightly more than the 12 percent officials had expected, the city is facing a shortfall, three months into its fiscal year, of $166 million in taxes that are sensitive to economic conditions.
Although seasonal variations complicate projections, officials regard tax collections in the first quarter of the fiscal year as the best early picture of revenues for the year, especially for the corporation tax. First-quarter tax revenues were also below projections last year, but by less than half of this year's shortfall, and some of the gap was thought to stem from technical factors like changes in tax laws.
In contrast, officials said they believed the slumping revenues this year were a sign of a stagnant local economy that is unlikely to improve soon.
In a plan revising the $27 billion budget, which is expected to be issued in a few weeks, the Koch administration is expected to project that the city will end the fiscal year in June with $217 million less than it had expected from taxes that are sensitive to economic conditions. Property-tax revenue, which is more stable, is off too. But officials expect those collections to improve.
''We are going to take down our estimates,'' Mayor Edward I. Koch said in an interview last week. ''We are not going to wait.''
Mr. Koch said that by acting now, rather than holding off until the end of his term on Dec. 31, he was leaving his successor ''in a better position.'' Still, it seems likely the next mayor will have to cope with difficult budgets for several years, because the city is already being called on to increase spending for social services and its justice system.
The revenue shortfall is increasing the pressure on Mr. Koch and the man he hopes will succeed him, Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins, to help resolve the legal challenge to the Columbus Center project. In response to the latest suit over the plans to build a twin-tower office and apartment complex on the site of the New York Coliseum, opposite the southwestern corner of Central Park, and to earlier estimates of sluggish tax revenues, the Koch administration instituted a partial hiring freeze last month.
 
Manual on Layoffs
The Mayor indicated his strategy for the remainder of his tenure would be to make further cuts in this year's spending, citing what he said was a preliminary figure of $75 million. If the Coliseum project cannot move forward this year, Mr. Koch said, he would ask the City Council for a property-tax increase, and if it is rejected, the city would be forced to lay off municipal workers to balance the budget.
The administration is to distribute a manual today to the heads of agencies advising them of the procedures to follow should layoffs begin.
The sluggish performance of the taxes also has gloomy implications for the city and its economy over a longer term, officials said. An analysis by the Office of Management and Budget said, ''It is not unusual in an economic slowdown to see retail sales growth and corporate profitability decline first and for output, employment and personal income to decline later.''
''If you're asking if we are in a recession, you would have to say no,'' Budget Director Paul Dickstein said. ''On the other hand, if the business taxes are a harbinger of what's to come, if you ask that same question in six months, you might get a different answer.''
 
'It Isn't Unique to Us'
The city still expects revenues from taxes that are sensitive to economic conditions to grow at rate of 6.9 percent this year, largely because of the strength of the personal-income tax. It had been projecting a growth rate of 10.8 percent for those taxes, some of which were broadened this year.
Officials said the slump was also being felt in the region, as other governments adjusted to lower growth.
''The city has been the first to observe what has been the likely slowing of the economy that everyone is talking about,'' a deputy budget director, Allen Proctor, said. ''It isn't unique to us. It's a New Jersey and a Connecticut and a Federal issue.''
The regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, said he believed New York City was experiencing a ''a much sharper fall.'' He said that the finance industry was ''now a source of weakness,'' that business and professional services were ''also kind of flat'' and that tourism was off, as well.
 
Slimmer Profits Than Predictedt
''New York City's key growth engines have lost steam or gone into reverse,'' he said.
In any event, officials thought this year would be better, based on the prospect of higher inflation, which helps governments, at least temporarily, and more optimistic estimates from businesses, including retailers.
Mr. Proctor said he believed corporations were reporting slimmer profits than anticipated and were making lower tax payments as a result. Consumer activity is also down, accounting for weakness in the sales tax. And sales of commercial and residential real estate declined more than 25 percent last summer from 1988.
The receipts from the property tax, the city's most lucrative levy, also fell short of projections by $43 million in the first quarter. But officials are confident some of that money will be recovered before the fiscal year ends.
 
'Irresistible Expenditure Needs'
The rise in the stock market may enable the administration to reduce contributions again to the municipal employees' pension funds, though that is likely to save just a small part of the $300 million the city saved last year in a similar adjustment. The administration is also said to be considering refinancing some bonds.
Service reductions seem probable in areas like street cleaning and repair and parks maintenance. Mr. Dickstein said it would be ''very tough'' to make large cuts at a time there appeared to be ''irresistible expenditure needs.'' He cited spending for AIDS and other health costs, as well as for crime and drug abuse.
This year's budget includes money for 2,000 additional police officers, and in his unsuccessful re-election campaign, Mr. Koch also advocated a tax increase to hire a further 4,000 officers. Speaking of the 2,000 officers, Mr. Koch said, ''The police class is the last to go.'' But he said efforts to hire the additional 4,000 officers were ''out the window until this problem is solved.''
A midyear tax increase would be the first since 1980, Mr. Dickstein said. A property-tax increase of the size envisioned by the Koch adminisration might cost the average homeowner an additional $50 a year.
Budget officials said they were concerned about the effect of raising taxes on business income amid economic malaise.

HEADLINE: Finance Law Evens Odds in Jersey Contest

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: NEWARK, Oct. 10

 BODY:
With less than a month to go before the Nov. 7 election, the candidates for governor have reached or are close to reaching the limit on campaign contributions set by New Jersey's public-financing law.
But Republican leaders say their candidate, Representative Jim Courter, would be in big trouble if contributions - and spending - were not limited by law.
According to reports filed today with the state, Mr. Courter has raised $1.56 million of the $1.7 million in private contributions allowed under the public-financing law. Each private dollar is matched by two dollars from the state, to a maximum $3.3 million in public money and a total of $5 million. The New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission, which administers the state's public-financing laws, today approved $214,200 more in public funds for Mr. Courter, bringing his total in public funds to $3.1 million. 
 
Easily Reached the Maximum
Mr. Courter has had trouble raising the money. Republican contributors had been drained by five major candidates in the party primary that he won in June, and last month he suspended his own fund raising to aid the party's efforts. But he has said he expects to reach the maximum soon.
His Democratic opponent, Representative James J. Florio, easily reached the maximum by Aug. 21, collecting $1.7 million in 2,617 separate contributions.
Fund raising has gone so well among Democrats that since August the state committee has continued collecting contributions in what may turn out to be record fashion. Party leaders have said the amount could exceed $5 million. The money cannot be spent by Mr. Florio, but it will be used to help legislative candidates and for general television advertising about party policies that does not mention candidates by name.
The campaign-financing law, first adopted in 1974, has changed the way campaigns in New Jersey are run. Because spending is capped at $5 million, Mr. Florio's early advantage in raising money was neutralized, allowing Republicans to breathe easier knowing that they only had to catch him at that level.
Instead of becoming anxious about raising money, the Republicans have been able to concentrate on the campaign and on events like Wednesday night's televised debate, which will be broadcast at 7 P.M. on Channel 7, WABC, in New York and Channel 6, WPVI, in Philadelphia.
The four public television stations of the New Jersey Network will rebroadcast the debate at 11:30.
''If this was a non-capped race we'd have a serious, serious problem right now,'' said Kenneth Connolly, Mr. Courter's campaign manager. ''The money is just flowing to Florio.''
Emma N. Byrne, executive director of the State Democratic Committee, said that the party had to file a report with the New Jersey Election Law Enforcment Commission today detailing how much money it has raised. Mrs. Byrne would not confirm a figure, but she said the money was rolling in.
''It will be the largest single report ever filed in the history of the compliance commission,'' Mrs. Byrne said. The actual figures will not be made public until Thursday.
Party leaders are deciding now whether to use any of the money to pay off a debt of close to $300,000 that stems in part from Mr. Florio's 1981 loss to Gov. Thomas H. Kean.
The law limits individual contributions to $1,500. A computer list of contributors reveals that both candidates have relied on out-of-state donors, party regulars and a few celebrities.
Mr. Florio, who represents the First Congressional District in southern New Jersey, accepted more than 45 contributions from businesses and individuals in Philadelphia, just across the Delaware River from Camden.
One of those contributions, for $1,000, came from Local 30-30B of the Composition Roofers Union, whose leaders were convicted in 1987 of racketeering, bribery and extortion.
 
A Trustee Takes Over
Earlier contributions to Mr. Florio's Congressional re-election campaigns from the same union have been highlighted in a television commercial by Mr. Courter. The ads linked Mr. Florio to the convicted union leaders and, it was implied, to organized crime.
At the time the ads first ran, Mr. Florio said he had not accepted contributions from the union after its leaders were indicted in 1986 and before the union was taken over by a court appointed trustee in 1988.
On July 15, the union's political action and education fund made a $1,000 contribution that Mr. Florio submitted to the commission as part of his private fund-raising efforts. Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's spokesman, said the current contribution ''was not the least bit troubling because the union is under the authority of a Federal court.''
 
From American Samoa
A spokesman for Mr. Courter declined to comment on the union's contribution to Mr. Florio.
State records show that both candidates ranged wide in raising money. On June 28, Mr. Florio accepted $1,500 from someone named Sun Ho Hwang who is listed as living in Pago Pago in American Samoa.
Armand Hammer, the industrialist, donated $500 and Vincent Tese, the New York state economic development commissioner, gave $1,000. Howard Rubenstein, a public relations executive, made a $1,000 contribution.
Mr. Florio also accepted $1,500 contributions from Arthur Imperatore, a trucking executive and waterfront developer, and Joseph Barry, a developer in Hoboken.
 
Half the Contributions
According to the state records, Mr. Courter has received about half the individual contributions Mr. Florio has, a total of 1,565 to Mr. Florio's 2,617. A single family, that of Fletcher Creamer of Hackensack, contributed $13,500, making nine individual contributions of $1,500 a piece from either members of the family or different components of J. Fletcher Creamer & Son Inc., a construction company that has done extensive work for the state.
The family of Ralph Loveys, a former assemblyman and now chairman of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, gave Mr. Courter $5,000 and William H. Tremayne, chairman of the New Jersey Highway Authority, which runs the Garden State Parkway, donated $1,500.
Chuck Leitgeb, a spokesman for Mr. Courter, said the officials are Republicans and ''it's not strange for members of the party to attend fund-raisers.
''It doesn't mean that Jim Courter is not going to act in the best interest of the people,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Critics Accuse Cuomo Of Budget Double Talk

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 10

 BODY:
In the face of tremendous fiscal problems, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo this year proposed the tightest state spending plan in a decade and reproached many of his critics for demanding more money. ''I would put the emphasis on tighter management and spending discipline,'' he said.
But Mr. Cuomo bristles when President Bush, invoking a similar theme in the face of demands by the states for Federal money, calls for Governors to do more with less.
''You cannot do it with nice words like efficiency,'' Mr. Cuomo said recently in deriding Mr. Bush's plans for education and the fight against drugs. ''It takes more resources.'' 'A Two-Edged Sword' 
While most legislators in Albany hardly fault the Governor for trying to get more money from the Federal Government, some of his conservative critics chide him for preaching thrift at home but lambasting the idea when restraint is asked of him.
Even some of Mr. Cuomo's supporters suggest that his strong statements on the national scene recently may complicate his work on next year's budget, especially if he renews his pleas for discipline and restraint.
''It's kind of a two-edged sword,'' said Saul Weprin, the Queens Democrat who heads the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee. ''Some of his critics, when they come for more money next year, may try to throw the Governor's words back at him.''
At a conference of governors in Virginia called by President Bush in September to discuss education, Mr. Cuomo was one of the few to rebuke the President publicly on his appeal for fiscal restraint.
''If we want to catch up, we're going to have to spend more,'' Mr. Cuomo told reporters in Virginia. He was also sharply critical of the President's drug plan, suggesting that Mr. Bush had declared a war but was trying to make the states pay for the bullets.
 
Inconsistency Charged
State Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Nassau County Republican and an ally of the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said he believed the Governor was being ''inconsistent.'' The President, he said, is only ''asking for the same thing that Mario Cuomo wants people to do at the state level.''
The Governor denies any inconsistency. He maintains that New York State's budget constraints stem largely from the Federal Government's reluctance to help the states deal with homelessness, drugs, crime, AIDS and other growing problems.
Federal grants accounted for 24 percent of New York State's operating budget last year, down from 27 percent in the early 1980's, according to figures compiled by the Governor's budget office.
Still, even some of the Governor's traditional allies say his remarks about the Federal budget have only underscored their contention that another year of what they term tight-fisted state spending could be devastating.
After five years in which the general funds state budget increased by an annual average of 8.5 percent, the increase was held this year to 5.3 percent, the lowest percentage rise in 10 years. The general funds budget represents most of the money that the state gets from taxes and fees.
Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and chairman of the New York State Public Employee Conference, representing more than a million state and municipal workers in New York, said he believed Mr. Cuomo's recent comments about the Federal budget also applied to the state's obligations to its citizens.
''The kinds of things he said at the education conference are going to be used by me, and I'm sure by others, to help make sure we have a budget that will not do damage to the fabric of our economy,'' he said.
The Governor frequently asserts that part of the problem at the Federal level is how the Government spends it money and that changing this does not necessarily mean raising taxes. Rather, he said in Virginia, some of the billions spent this year by the Federal Government on ''banks'' - a reference to the bailout of the savings and loan industry - and on ''bombers'' should go to schools and to fight drugs.
Neverthelesss the Governor does not dismiss the notion that Federal taxes may have to be raised.
Some of the groups affected by Mr. Cuomo's own budget plan may challenge his contention that with more prudence, they can spare themselves pain. Administrators at the State University of New York, for instance, who are projecting an increase of at least 8 percent in their $1.4 billion budget next year, may wind up citing the Governor's own words to bolster their case.
''You can't build a University of Virginia with a speech,'' the Governor said at the summit in Virginia. ''You know it takes bricks, and that means dollars and cents.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (93%);

HEADLINE: Giuliani Ties Racial Harmony to Strong Economy

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday the poor ''will suffer the most'' without a strong city economy, as his mayoral campaign continued its strategy of making a policy statement each day.
Mr. Giuliani warned of continuing unequal opportunities ''if New York City is weak and indecisive and unwilling to make the hard choices presented by a fiscal crisis.''
And, referring to poor black and Hispanic residents, he added, ''it will be impossible to achieve racial harmony unless we provide all New Yorkers with the services and opportunities they need to achieve their full potential.'' 
''To do that,'' he said, ''we must have a city that is economically vibrant, a city humming with business activity.'' He did not elaborate on the link between racial harmony and improved opportunities and services.
 
Handling Budget Deficit
Mr. Giuliani spoke at a news conference where he presented his ideas for handling a projected city budget deficit of at least $400 million.
His plan calls for a city hiring freeze, revising the way teachers' pension funds are invested, refinancing city bonds, and more aggressive recovery of unpaid taxes on incomes hidden by drug dealers and other workers in what he called ''the underground economy.''
He said a tax increase would ''absolutely be the last resort.''
Paul Dickstein, the city budget director, said the city had announced a hiring freeze two weeks ago. He said that Mr. Giuliani's proposal for reinvesting part of the teacher's pension fund would raise more revenue but would not offer budget relief for many years. He also called Mr. Giuliani's plan to refinance city bonds, which Mr. Giuliani said would provide $50 million, ''a reasonable thing to say.''
Mr. Giuliani said that his Democratic opponent, David N. Dinkins, had not offered any serious suggestions for handling the projected deficit.
 
Dinkins Names Four Advisers
''Where is David Dinkins on the issues of grave concern which I have addressed today?'' he asked.
But Mr. Dinkins said at a news conference yesterday that he would convene a council of fiscal advisers to recommend ways to deal with the deficit. He named four members who have agreed to serve on the council and said others will be appointed.
The four are Felix G. Rohatyn, a partner at the investment firm of Lazard Freres and chairman of the state Municipal Assistance Corporation; James D. Robinson 3d, chairman of American Express; Joseph H. Flom, a partner in the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom; and Reginald F. Lewis, chief executive officer of TLC Beatrice International.
Mr. Dinkins said he was not prepared to detail specific remedies for the deficit, saying he needs more information.
''I can give you some general answers, such as: I have no intention of increasing taxes,'' he said.
Mr. Giuliani was also pressed for specifics. He too said that further study was necessary and that he was not prepared to provide details until he had complete access to city records.
Asked if his new campaign strategy of highlighting an issue a day meant an end to his attacks on Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Giuliani flashed a tight smile.
''Wouldn't you consider this an attack?'' he asked.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
ABOUT EDUCATION

BYLINE: By Fred M. Hechinger

 BODY:
A standard criticism of the public school system is that, as a monopoly, it treats its customers - parents and their children - as captives. The remedy? Competition, a growing number of educators and politicians say. Letting parents choose their children's schools. This was one of President Bush's key proposals at the recent education summit.
Parental choice is both politically and educationally attractive: the idea of letting parents vote with their children's feet for or against particular schools unites liberals and conservatives in the belief that good schools will drive out bad ones. Not all educators agree. 
Ideology aside, many experts on children say that different types of schools succeed with different types of children. And for junior and senior high schools, these experts find merit in magnet schools that respond to students' special interests and talents in such areas as the arts, science, economics and literature.
In the past, the mention of choice raised the hackles of public school supporters. They saw it as a plot to introduce vouchers with which parents could pay for private secular or parochial school tuition, thereby taking money away from public schools.
The Reagan Administration made vouchers a cornerstone of its education program, thus insuring the defeat of any choice proposal. The Bush Administration has dropped the voucher scheme, giving choice a sturdy new life.
Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos plans to promote choice in meetings with parents, educators and politicians in five cities. The first will be Monday and Tuesday in New York, in East Harlem. The other cities are Minneapolis-St. Paul, Denver, Charlotte, N.C., and Richmond, Calif.
A recent Gallup poll shows that most Americans (60 percent of the respondents) favor parental choice, even though 42 percent did not think it would necessarily raise students' achievements.
Educators are divided. Dennis P. Doyle, a senior research fellow at the Hudson Institute in Virginia, writes in American Educator, the magazine of the American Federation of Teachers, that ''a school that is chosen is a school in which children, parents and teachers are collaborators, accomplices, if you will.''
A school board endorsing choice, he adds, gives its community and its teachers a vote of confidence. He underscores that, in a system of choice, teachers should also have the right to choose where they want to teach.
Seymour Fliegel, former associate superintendent of District 4 in East Harlem and now an education consultant, says, ''I have a simple philosophy: what's good enough for rich children is good enough for poor children.'' He is on the executive committee of the Center for Educational Innovation of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, a ''think tank'' generally considered conservative. The institute has published a policy paper, ''Model for Choice: A Report on Manhattan's District 4.''
Anthony Alvarado, superintendent of District 2 in lower Manhattan, says this year 92 percent of his junior high school students are in the schools of their first choice, with 44 percent in schools other than those to which they would normally be assigned.
Choice is not unanimously supported. Lewis W. Finch, superintendent of Anoka-Hennepin School District 11 in Coon Rapids, Minn., writes in American Educator, ''The claims for school choice and snake oil have a lot in common.'' He admits that choice as a populist notion is ''not entirely without merit,'' but warns that unrestricted choice ''could dash all hope for equal education opportunity for many students.''
He urges caution about ''ecstatic'' claims for ''forcing public schools into the highly competitive, dog-eat-dog open market,'' pointing to abuses, including misleading advertising, that pollute the commercial open market. Will more money go to schools with ''high-powered Madison Avenue consultants'' to proclaim their virtues? Will students follow the lure of strong sports teams? Will schools recruit the best and the brightest, leaving the less talented and handicapped behind?
Donald R. Moore and Suzanne Davenport of Design for Change, a Chicago research center, warn in The School Adminstrator (American Association of School Administrators) that complex admissions procedures give middle-class families an advantage and leave the poor behind. However, Mr. Alvarado points out that choice works in his district, where more than 60 percent of the children are from poverty-level homes.
Some opponents charge that choice could lead to the resegregation of schools. Even enthusiastic supporters of choice concede that school authorities must block such abuse.
Despite certain dangers, including that of touting it as a panacea, choice seems crucial to reform by making the system less monolithic.
The 19th-century hope for ''the one best way'' has been slow to die, even in the face of the school establishment's lip service to the right education for every child. Reformers know that, without competition, systems cling to the status quo even when all indicators demand change.

HEADLINE: Deal to Buy MGM/UA Collapses

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 10

 BODY:
An Australian entertainment company's deal to acquire the MGM/UA Communications Company collapsed today amid recriminations and legal action, opening the possibility that Rupert Murdoch might make another bid for the film and television studio.
MGM/UA said it had terminated its agreement to sell the company to Qintex Australia Ltd. for more than $1.5 billion after Qintex failed to put up a $50 million letter of credit required by the deal. Qintex's ability to finance the acquisition had been the subject of considerable speculation in Hollywood and on Wall Street since the Australian company failed to deliver the letter of credit as scheduled on Sept. 22.
MGM/UA also said it had filed suit against Qintex in the Federal District Court in Los Angeles, charging breach of contract and fraud and seeking at least $50 million in damages. 
 
Letter From Quintex Chairman
Qintex's aggressive chairman, Christopher C. Skase, a former financial journalist, maintained in a letter to the Brisbane Stock Exchange that Qintex had taken steps to secure the letter of credit but that MGM/UA proposed ''bad faith'' changes in the deal that, he said, ''shifted daily and, in essence, reflected an attempt by MGM to extract higher economic value.'' He added that Qintex intended to sue MGM/UA for damages.
The deal's collapse came less than a month after MGM/UA turned down a $1.35 billion bid from Mr. Murdoch, who already owns the 20th Century-Fox studio. Dennis Petroskey, a spokesman for Mr. Murdoch's Fox Inc., said the company had not been in contact with MGM/UA about reopening negotiations. Mr. Murdoch was in Australia, according to Howard Rubenstein, his spokesman, and could not be reached.
 
Master Negotiators
But analysts said Mr. Murdoch would almost certainly remain interested, although both Mr. Murdoch and Kirk Kerkorian, the financier who owns 80 percent of MGM/UA, are master negotiators who might circle each other for some time before deciding how to proceed.
''I'm sure the phone calls between the bankers have already been made,'' said Jeffrey Logsdon, an analyst at Crowell, Weedon & Company in Los Angeles.
The collapse is a severe embarrassment for Qintex and Mr. Skase, who has built Qintex into one of Australia's largest media companies. He had portrayed the MGM/UA acquisition as a big step in building a global communications company.
Jeffrey C. Barbakow, MGM/UA's chairman and chief executive, said the company had worked hard with Qintex to find a solution to the Australian company's apparent financing problems. He said that executives of the two companies had met for the last week and that Mr. Skase was present at a meeting Sunday in Los Angeles.
''Almost every day, Qintex assured us that the letter of credit would be immediately forthcoming,'' Mr. Barbakow said in a statement. ''We believe it is now clear that Qintex repeatedly misled us regarding its ability to furnish the letter of credit.''
Qintex had originally agreed last spring to acquire just the United Artists studio and library, which includes the James Bond, ''Rocky'' and ''Pink Panther'' movies, from MGM/UA in a complicated deal valued at almost $700 million. But after Mr. Murdoch's surprise bid for the entire company last month, weeks before the original Qintex deal was set to close, Mr. Skase negotiated a new deal for all of MGM/UA that topped Mr. Murdoch's offer.
During the year that MGM/UA has been for sale, many of the world's largest entertainment companies have expressed some interest, including the Sony Corporation, which last month agreed to acquire Columbia Pictures.
Last year, a deal to sell a large stake in MGM/UA to a group including the producers Jon Peters and Peter Guber collapsed at the last minute. The company has been run for the last year by Mr. Barbakow, a former investment banker at Merrill Lynch whom Mr. Kerkorian brought in, largely to find a buyer.
 
Terms of Terminated Deal
Under last month's revised Qintex-MGM/UA deal, Qintex was to have paid $25 a share for MGM/UA's 50.6 million shares of common stock and $18 a share for 10 million preferred shares. Qintex would also have assumed $400 million in debt.
But Qintex was widely rumored to have been having trouble financing even the previous, smaller deal.
In a letter to the Brisbane Stock Exchange last week, Mr. Skase said Qintex would get backing from about 10 ''major international companies, many of whom have an involvement in the broadcasting and entertainment industry.'' He did not identify the companies or provide any financial details, except to say that Qintex's total financial participation would be about $125 million to $150 million.
 
Comment by Kerkorian
In a brief telephone interview today, Mr. Kerkorian, who rarely speaks to reporters, said the two companies ''really put in an effort'' to salvage the deal. Asked what had kept Qintex from delivering the letter of credit, Mr. Kerkorian replied, ''Obviously, it's financing problems, maybe priorities.'' He declined to elaborate.
Mr. Kerkorian said the collapse of the deal would not affect his plans to build a theme park in Las Vegas, Nev., through his other big holding, MGM Grand Inc. He said MGM/UA's board had not yet decided on its next step. Both he and Mr. Barbakow declined to comment on Mr. Murdoch's interest.
Mr. Barbakow, who stood to reap a huge financial gain as part of his employment contract if the deal had been completed, said in an interview that MGM/UA had tried ''everything we could think of that made sense'' to keep the deal on track. ''We weren't able to get anything that worked,'' he said.
 
Barbakow Statement
In his statement, Mr. Barbakow said: ''MGM/UA has made every effort to cooperate with Qintex, including proposals to reduce the letter of credit, accept substitute security or accept an opinion from Qintex's investment bankers of Qintex's ability to finance the merger. We also proposed that Qintex could proceed without a letter of credit, if MGM/UA also had the opportunity to consider a better offer. Moreover, Tracinda Corporation, MGM/UA's largest shareholder, indicated it was willing to assist in financing up to $135 million of the acquisition cost, without voting rights in the surviving corporation.''
Mr. Barbakow said Qintex's final proposal was to eliminate the letter of credit or any other security, eliminate the minimum damages that MGM/UA would be entitled to if the deal collapsed, postpone the closing by two months and require MGM/UA to invest in Qintex.
''We had no choice other than to terminate the agreement,'' Mr. Barbakow said.

HEADLINE: Pilots to Continue Strike Benefits at Eastern

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The Air Line Pilots Association announced yesterday that its membership had voted to continue paying strike benefits to Eastern Airlines pilots, making it likely that the seven-month strike against Eastern will continue for weeks, or even months.
Sentiment has been strong at some other carriers for an end to the strike, because the working pilots are paying a special strike assessment of 3 percent of their pay to support the strike benefits of $600 a week for Eastern pilots.
The union which represents 38,000 commercial pilots and has a contract with every large airline except American and Continental, did not disclose the margin by which the measure carried. Only a simple majority was needed. 
The pilots' vote came amid growing tensions between Eastern and its creditors and indications that the Senate might create a panel to investigate the strike.
Eastern's machinists struck the carrier on March 4, and the airline's pilots and flight attendants refused to cross picket lines. Eastern filed five days later for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
Ron Cole, a spokesman for the Eastern pilots, said, ''We're extremely pleased but not surprised because our fellow professional pilots understand that the outcome of the Eastern strike will affect their own professional futures.''
Eastern declined to comment. ''I really view it as an internal A.L.P.A. matter,'' said Robin Matell, a spokesman for the airline.
The votes were counted yesterday. Eastern's 3,500 pilots were allowed to vote, except those who have crossed picket lines or otherwise are not in good standing with the union. To be valid, ballots had to be postmarked by Sept. 25.
Timothy Pettee, an airline analyst at Merrill Lynch Research, said the vote meant the strike was likely to continue, but, he added, it was unlikely to affect the stock of the Texas Air Corporation, the parent of Eastern and Continental Airlines, significantly.
While the strike appears to be continuing, Eastern's creditors are becoming increasingly critical of the carrier's treatment of them in bankruptcy proceedings, two people involved in the bankruptcy case said yesterday. ''They have taken a harder line - there's no doubt about it,'' one said.
But the creditors have nonetheless recently allowed Eastern to withdraw $75 million from escrow accounts that hold the proceeds from asset sales like the $365 million sale of the Eastern Shuttle to Donald J. Trump in June. The Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan froze those proceeds, requiring Eastern to obtain court permission and the creditors' acquiesence to spend any of the money.
 
Creditors Meeting
Eastern's creditors will meet on Oct. 17 with their financial advisers from Goldman, Sachs & Company and Ernst & Young, who are preparing a report on Eastern's recent proposal to emerge from bankruptcy late this winter with more scheduled flights and less cash than previously proposed. The creditors are concerned that the ambitious plan will make the airline vulnerable in a recession and are unhappy with Eastern's request to resume routine debt payments after the bankruptcy as though the filing had not occurred, one of the sources said.
The creditors want more collateral and accelerated repayments. If these requests are denied, the creditors may file a legal challenge seeking to take control of the company, one of the sources said. ''It doesn't help to be restored to a series of payments over a number of years,'' if the airline liquidates in the next economic downturn and is unable to make the later payments, the person said.
Mr. Matell of Eastern said that the company had a policy of not discussing negotiations with creditors but that it would repay or reinstate all debts with interest.
 
Affirming a Commitment
A spokesman for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 8,500 Eastern workers, yesterday reaffirmed the union's commitment not to change its stance regardless of what the pilots might do. ''We will stay on strike until we get relief'' - a better contract than management has offered so far, Jim Conley, the union's spokesman, said.
