HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Gold Standard For the Kremlin?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE folks who persuaded Ronald Reagan that deficits do not matter have an idea or two for the Kremlin. Surprisingly, perhaps, Mikhail Gorbachev's economic advisers are giving these ideas a respectful hearing: They were reportedly even discussed at last month's mini-summit meeting in Jackson Hole, Wyo. More surprising still, they might prove part of the solution to the Soviet Union's desperate economic problems.
The economists are the supply-siders - specifically, Wayne Angell, a Federal Reserve governor appointed by President Reagan, and Jude Wanniski, once the brains behind The Wall Street Journal's editorial page and now a partner in the Polyconomics consulting firm in Morristown, N.J. And the concept they are promoting is nothing less than a gold standard for the ruble. 
The idea of tying currencies to a fixed quantity of precious metal has commended itself to assorted intellectuals for the last 300 years. The supply-siders, led by Robert Mundell of Columbia University, are the latest to catch the gold bug. A gold standard (or some other fixed commodity exchange standard) for the dollar, they argue, would prevent Washington from solving short-term political problems with inflationary measures.
But gold is not an easy political sell. Unlike the supply-siders' tax cut that was such a hit in 1981, it offers no way to rationalize private greed as public virtue. Nor is it as stylish: In an age of fast computers and faster bucks, the gold standard smacks of quill pens and starched collars.
Why, then, is gold likely to shine brighter in the gray light of Moscow? In part because all theories seem equally legitimate in the ideological vacuum left by the malaise of Leninist-Stalinist economics. In part because a gold standard might help Mr. Gorbachev cope with a critical problem known as the ruble overhang.
Perestroika has yet to pay off for long-suffering Soviet consumers. In spite of Moscow's best intentions, chronic scarcity has given way to a critical sense of deprivation. Soviet enterprises have been permitted, even encouraged, to raise wages. But per capita production has hardly changed since 1985, and modest cuts in military spending have been more than offset by increased investment instead of a rise in the output of consumer goods.
As a result, more money is chasing fewer goods, and there are longer lines for everything from sausage to shoes. Frustrated consumers have had little choice but to save; this accumulated overhang of rubles may run as high as one-third of one year's total economic output.
As Soviet planners admit, failure to trim the overhang will eventually destroy confidence in the currency - and in Mr. Gorbachev's changes. That leaves the planners with unpalatable options:
* They could follow the recent Chinese example, forcing workers to lock in part of their earnings in long-term bonds. That would obviously erode the Government's popularity.
* They could sell consumer goods purchased in the West. That would drain foreign exchange reserves, or add to Soviet foreign debt.
* They could sell public property - apartments, farmland, small enterprises. That would stir serious discontent among the majority who could not afford to buy and would resent the abandonment of the egalitarian ethic.
Suppose instead, argues Mr. Winniski, Moscow simply made a no-strings offer to convert anyone's rubles into a fixed amount of gold. Some people would undoubtedly take the gold and run. However, if the offer were deemed credible, and the exchange rate plausibly reflected the ruble's purchasing power, most people would not bother.
In fact, asserts Mr. Angell, foreigners might even lend hard currency to the Soviet Union at extremely attractive rates, buying ruble-denominated bonds effectively guaranteed in gold at interest rates as low as 3 percent.
Would the scheme really fly? No one knows because everything depends on the imponderable of public confidence in the Government's will and its capacity to honor future claims against the ruble. But the odds do seem long. To have any chance of working, Mr. Angell admits, it would have to be accompanied by draconian wage restraints or cuts in Government spending to prevent the ruble overhang from growing.
Moreover the choice of an exchange rate could prove critical. Set too low, it would feed expectations of inflation. Set too high, it would further hobble the nation's capacity to expand exports.
Still, the idea has a certain wacky appeal. In the Alice-in-Wonderland world of the post-Communist Soviet Union, no idea for change is too strange. Why not try one that enjoyed its greatest success in 19th-century capitalist Europe?

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Servers Spurring an Evolution in Computing

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10

 BODY:
A new class of specialized computers is becoming the next area of opportunity in the computer business, and a host of new companies are staking their claims to it.
The machines are known as servers, and they perform particular functions for personal computers or work stations hooked together in a network. Ideally, the user never knows which machine is working on the task.
In growing numbers of networks, a person wanting a particular electronic file could order it from a file server, a kind of electronic librarian. Documents to be printed go to a machine that runs printers, known as a print server, and jobs that require intensive computations go to a high-speed number-crunching machine known as a compute server. 
There are also communications servers, to connect one network to another; facsimile servers, to send or receive facsimile transmissions, and applications servers for performing tasks like retrieving information from a data base.
Until now the role of servers has been filled by conventional computers, from a personal computer to a minicomputer to a mainframe, depending on the capacity required. But a flock of new companies think that by designing machines from scratch, they can produce servers that are less expensive and more effective than general-purpose computers.
''The services that are today supplied by one computer are being broken into application-specific servers or computers,'' said Andrew S. Rachleff, a partner of Merrill, Pickard, Anderson & Eyre, a Palo Alto, Calif., venture capital firm that has invested in new server companies.
If servers catch on, ''minicomputers are going to be replaced first,'' said Enzo Torresi, the president of Netframe Systems Inc., which makes file servers.
Forrester Research, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass., projects that sales of servers in the United States will grow to more than $10 billion in 1993 from $2 billion in 1988. And of the new companies developing servers, ''There is the potential for another Compaq or another Digital Equipment,'' said John McCarthy, director of research at Forrester.
The rise of servers is part of a broad evolution in computing that is sweeping corporate America. The new mode of computing is called client-server computing, in which many desktop computers are linked in networks with larger machines.
The clients are the desktop computers, either personal computers or work stations. They do the simple computing tasks, like running a word-processing program or spreadsheet. They also provide the user with the interface system of windows and menus that make the computer easy to use.
But desktop computers cannot handle all jobs. Certain files and data to be used by everyone must be stored centrally, to make sure everyone in a company is using the same data. Certain expensive peripherals like printers are more economically shared by several people. And intensive computing jobs, like numerical simulations, are best done on high-speed ''number crunchers'' because they would tie up a personal computer for days.
Software can be written to automatically distribute pieces of a job to the appropriate machine. In an electronic publishing program, for instance, a user would do word processing on his desktop machine, but a server would align the margins of the document, which takes more computing.
The most common type of this machine is the file server, which acts as a librarian, sending out files of information. Two start-up companies in California, Netframe of Sunnyvale and Auspex Systems Inc. of Santa Clara, recently introduced servers that they said would be faster at retrieving files than conventional computers. Another start-up, Epoch Systems of Marlborough, Mass., has a file server to manage the storage of huge amounts of information on optical disks.
The new file server companies argue that conventional computers are designed to do rapid calculations for an individual. But a file server must dole out information to numerous users, yet rarely has to do much computation on its own.
In a conventional computer, all requests go through the central processor. To retrieve data from a hard disk, for instance, the central processor receives the request and sends out an instruction to the hard disk. The required data are transferred to the computer's main memory and then out through the central processor to the network.
''That central processing unit is getting in the way; you can't go any faster than that unit can go,'' said Larry Boucher, president of Auspex. His company's new server allows requests for files to go directly from the network to the disk drives, eliminating the potential bottleneck.
Applications servers would perform a particular type of job, like getting specific information from a data base. Tricord Systems of Plymouth, Minn., is developing applications servers for purposes like data base access and storing video images.
Peer Networks Inc., a Santa Clara start-up, is working on a communications server - a gateway connecting computers on one network with those on another. Castelle, also of Santa Clara, is working on a facsimile server, which would send and receive facsimile messages for computers on the network.
But the new server companies will not all face smooth sailing. Conventional computer companies are trying to position their own machines to function as servers, or to come out with special servers. The Compaq Computer Corporation is expected to introduce a machine that uses multiple Intel Corporation 80486 microprocessors, allowing it to function as a high-speed file server.
Moreover, servers can grow only as fast as networks do. While client-server computing might be fine for a small department, some corporations are hesitant about applying it to the whole corporation. Huge networks become hard to keep track of and prone to breakdowns. And there is still very little software geared to work on client-server networks.
With all the servers on a network, it is possible there will not be much left for the desktop computer to do, other than provide the interface. An engineer who does not want to do word processing or a spreadsheet might find virtually all the work being done by servers.
That has led to another idea for profiting from client-server computing. Instead of putting an entire work station on each desk, why not merely supply a terminal with windows. Terminals, which are meant to display information but not to compute anything, are less expensive than computers.
Indeed, several companies - the leading one being Network Computing Devices of Mountain View, Calif., - have jumped into the business of supplying what are known as X terminals. These terminals use a standard window system developed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: Dow Slips 6.08 Points, Ending 6-Day Surge

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks fell moderately yesterday as some futures-related trading ended a six-day surge that had carried the Dow Jones industrial average to a gain of nearly 100 points.
The Dow dropped 6.08 points, to 2,785.33, after being off as many as 16 points late in the afternoon. In early trading the Dow average had climbed to within 5 points of the 2,800 level, but selling of blue chips began, ending five straight days of records for the bellwether indicator. 
At the same time, declines on the New York Stock Exchange ran ahead of advances by 831 to 652.
''Most of yesterday's attention was focused on the strong dollar, even in the face of coordinated selling of dollars by world central banks,'' said Edward P. Nicoski, a technical analysts at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. ''Previously, dollar strength resulted in a strong equity market, but today's action may imply a decoupling of the two.''
 
Influence of Bond Prices
Analysts said stocks were also depressed somewhat by investors' perceptions that interest rates would not head lower soon. By late in the day the interest rates on the 30-year Treasury issue were up slightly.
Mr. Nicoski, however, said that more than likely, the stock market pause yesterday would prove ''to be just a breather, part of a normal corrective process before the Dow scales 2,800.''
Volume on the Big Board regained some vigor yesterday, as volume soared to 147.6 million shares from skimpy 86.8 million shares on Monday, when markets were open despite the Yom Kippur and Columbus Day holidays.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.67, to 359.13, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index dipped 0.34, to 199.00.
The Dow Jones transportation average fell 12.62, to 1,505.87, yesterday after rising sharply on Monday.
The AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, fell 3 3/8, to 101 3/8. despite the announced $120-a-share bid by Donald J. Trump. Traders said airline stocks were off as a result of USAir's announcement on Monday that its second-half earnings would be lower than in the period a year earlier. USAir fell 3 1/8, to 49 1/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index rose 0.51, to 397.03, but in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.59 points, to 484.14.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Rises Sharply After Greenspan's Remarks

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Spurred in part by comments from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the dollar rose sharply yesterday, passing the important 1.90-mark level again and breaching 144 yen. The British pound also fell sharply against the dollar and other currencies.
The Federal Reserve sold dollars several times in New York, traders said, but the sales seemed to have no strong impact. 
In New York the dollar ended at 1.9075 marks, up from 1.8875 on Monday, when trading was light because of the Yom Kippur and Columbus Day holidays, and up from 1.8905 on Friday. Against the yen, the dollar was at 144.45, up from 142.85 Monday and 142.65 on Friday.
The British pound ended in New York yesterday at $1.5530, down from $1.5775 on Monday and $1.6045 on Friday. The pound had dropped below the important 3-mark level on Monday, and closed yesterday in London at 2.95 marks, a 28-month low.
 
Speech by Greenspan in Moscow
Mr. Greenspan, in a speech delivered in Moscow, said that a short-term effort to stabilize the foreign exchange markets might not be productive. Such remarks appear to traders to undermine the cooperative effort of the United States and its economic allies in the Group of Seven to push the dollar lower.
The speech was also taken by some as a signal that the Fed would not move to lower interest rates soon, despite the September unemployment report, which was released Friday, showing that the economy was weaker than expected.
''Attempts to hold interest rates at unsustainably low levels have been shown to result in accelerating inflation,'' Mr. Greenspan said. ''Similarly, attempts to maintain unrealistic exchange rates may lead to destabilizing international capital flows, and ultimately have to be abandoned.''
''Greenspan's remarks gave it a real pop,'' said J. Thomas Stanley, manager for corporate foreign exchange at the Chemical Bank.
Francoise Soares-Kemp, vice president at Credit Suisse in New York, added, ''Greenspan's words gave us complete assurance there was nothing coming soon officially.'' But she did note that the closely watched Federal funds rate had slipped slightly in the last few days.
Rudiger Dornbusch, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said that the dollar should be lower and that the Fed should lower interest rates now to push it lower ''even if the move would be a little premature.'' With the dollar at this level, he said, the investment needed to increase exports is being discouraged, which means the trade deficit may worsen.
Against the yen the dollar is now close to the 146 level, which is where it was on Sept. 23, when the United States and its economic allies declared in a communique in Washington that the dollar was too high. The aggressive and coordinated dollar selling that followed pushed the dollar down significantly. But for the last week or so, it has been rising, despite continued dollar selling and a wave of interest rate increases in Europe.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
5-Year Commercial Revival Brings Lift to South Bronx

BYLINE: By Shawn G. Kennedy

 BODY:
WHEN Zaro Bakeries, Farberware Inc., Empire Glass and other companies opened operations in the South Bronx several years ago, they were viewed as risk takers in an area that had come to represent urban decline.
But today, more than five years after manufacturing, warehousing and distribution companies started venturing back into the South Bronx, the area's popularity has begun to push up rents and property prices. And in South Bronx neighborhoods like Port Morris and Hunts Point, there is a shortage of industrial space. 
''In the past few years, rents for average spaces have increased by more than 50 percent,'' said Earle Altman, a senior vice president with Helmsley-Spear Inc., a real estate brokerage company. ''When it comes to resales, property values have doubled in some locations.''
Currently, the rent for multilevel space is between $4.50 and $5.50 a foot, Mr. Altman said. Rent for space in single-story drive-in buildings is higher.
Despite the increases, rents for industrial space in the Bronx are still a relative bargain when compared with rents in Long Island City and Manhattan, where the few remaining lofts go for $8 to $12 a foot.
The price differential remains a prime attraction, but dozens of companies have also discovered that a factory location in the South Bronx offers easy access to Manhattan and to regional transportation arteries. In addition, New York City offers tax benefits and low-cost electricity to companies that relocate in the borough.
Companies that moved into the area in the early 1980's had their choice of buildings. After decades as a manufacturing stronghold, the South Bronx had been abandoned by many companies in the 1960's and 1970's.
In 1984 when Maria Torresy started Empire Glass, a glass-tempering business, she signed a lease for a 34,000-square-foot building at 608 East 133d Street. The starting rent for the building, which had been empty for four years, was $3.75 a foot.
By comparison, the owners of a single-story building on 133d Street are asking $7 a foot for a lease or $70 a foot for the sale of the building.
While the initial attraction of the South Bronx often is modest rents, many have found other advantages.
''The point of taking space here was to be close to the customers in northern Manhattan and the Bronx,'' said Joel Napchen, manager of the Bruckner Boulevard branch of Jetro Cash and Carry, a wholesale food and grocery distribution company.''We've found another benefit of this location in the labor pool.''
Jetro has been operating since March 1988 out of 185,000 square feet in a building at 149th Street and Bruckner Boulevard.
Hudson Scenic Studio has rented space in the Port Morris section of the borough since 1981. The company found that when it started looking for property to buy, there was nothing in the neighborhood that fitted its space requirements and price range.
''We wanted to stay in Port Morris,'' said Gene O'Donovan, who with his partner, Neil Mazzella, moved the theatrical set construction company from Cornwall. ''We have seen rents rise around here, and unfortunately we can't afford to stay if we want to own.''
The company, which was responsible for the sets for ''Les Miserables'' and ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' currently operates in five rental spaces, ranging in size from 10,000 to 18,000 square feet. Mr. O'Donovan has been negotiating with the city's Public Development Corporation to buy three city-owned buildings in the Morrisania section of the borough.

GRAPHIC: photo of Hudson Scenic Studio on Bruckner Boulevard, where the sets for ''Les Miserables'' and ''The Phantom of the Opera'' were created (NYT/Jack Manning)

HEADLINE: Arnold M. Picker Is Dead at 76; Film Executive Was Fund-Raiser

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
Arnold M. Picker, former head of international operations for United Artists Pictures Inc. who was a prominent fund-raiser for Democratic political candidates, died of pneumonia on Sunday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 76 years old.
Mr. Picker, whose family was prominent in the film industry, joined Columbia Pictures in 1935 as an assistant to the foreign manager and became vice president in charge of foreign distribution for Columbia in 1945. 
Six years later he was one of a group of executives who took over the management of United Artists, then in shaky financial condition. As a partner and executive vice president for international distribution, he built a network of foreign outlets that promoted United Artists films around the world. He was named chairman of the company's executive committee in 1961, a position he held until retirement in 1967.
Although his activities in the film industry were entirely on the business side, he was active in preserving films as an art form and was instrumental in forming the American Film Institute. The institute is currently headed by his niece, Jean Picker Firstenberg.
He was also chairman of the National Center for Jewish Film and helped start a film course at City College of New York. His father, David V. Picker, was an executive of Loew's Theater Management Corporation.
 
On Nixon's 'Enemies List'
In politics Mr. Picker was chairman of campaigns for Senators Henry M. Jackson of Washington and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine when they sought national office, and was a major contributor to the Democratic National Committee in Congressional campaigns.
In 1973 his name was No. 1 on an ''enemies list'' compiled by White House aides to President Richard M. Nixon. At the time Mr. Picker was Senator Muskie's chief fund raiser.
Mr. Picker was born in New York and attended City College and the London School of Economics. At his death he lived in Golden Beach, Fla., a resort town near Miami.
He is survived by his wife of 54 years, the former Ruth Cohen; two daughters, Carol Frank of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Phyllis Dessner of Toledo, Ohio; two brothers, Eugene, of Bay Harbor Island, Fla., and Sidney, of Beverly Hills, Calif., and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Milwaukee Helps Pace U.S. As Innovator for Workplace

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Without methodical planning or a grand design, this breezy and muscular city on Lake Michigan has become a flourishing laboratory of the kinds of workplace innovations that national policy makers and private businesses are only beginning to experiment with.
For more than a decade, the city and county governments have provided tuition subsidies for workers to keep abreast of their fields, and have offered job sharing and four-day weeks. In the 1980's, they have adopted unpaid parental leave, giving fathers the same rights as mothers.
City Hall provides pay incentives for 980 managers to do better work and vacation incentives for nearly 9,000 city employees to refrain from abusing sick leave. John M. Tries, the city's director of employee relations, says he is rewriting the entire civil service code to allow the city more flexibility in redefining the workplace. 
At the county's courthouse headquarters, six blocks from City Hall, 170 welfare workers in the Department of Social Services keep ''4-40'' schedules, working four 10-hour days, starting at 7 A.M. Ninety-one members of the department follow ''flextime'' schedules, which many use to work nine hours for four days and four hours Friday mornings. About 110 city and county employees share jobs, working half-time for half the pay and half the benefits.
Because of the years of testing approaches to accommodating the needs of a changing work force, Milwaukee officials have a sense of which approaches succeed, in what circumstances, and which need more testing.
For private employers and other cities around the country, Milwaukee, a city with a long progressive tradition, provides an opportunity to examine their own efforts to accommodate the special needs of their employees, particularly the two-earner family that is now the norm.
''It has been a laboratory for workplace innovation,'' said Byron Yaffe, professor of industrial relations at the University of Wisconsin.
The County Executive, David F. Schulz, says the city has only responded to a trend that is evident everywhere. ''There has been a sea-change,'' he said. ''Employers value their employees more. We're fitting the job to the employee and not the employee to the job.''
John Parr, executive director of the local chapter of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said, ''We've had a long-running, formal relationship with the city so we've been able to get at these issues early.''
How well Milwaukee's workplace adjustments serve the government, its workers and the taxpayers is not established in any detail. High taxes are a likely price, and taxes are a disincentive to businesses that would open up shop here. Among 31 big cities that Fortune magazine surveyed, state and local taxes in Milwaukee are higher per capita than in all but four other cities: Washington, New York, Boston and Baltimore. Boston and another city that is high on the list, Minneapolis, are also often cited as workplace innovators like Milwaukee.
Officials here say that they have found their workplace accommodations hard to apply to the police, firefighters and others who have tightly structured jobs, but that they have worked well for thousands of office employees, especially for those below the top ranks.
 
Job-Sharer's Experience
One illustration is Amy Grow, a job-sharer in the city and county governments. Mrs. Grow, whose husband, a police officer, works the night shift, spends her mornings fielding inquiries from taxpayers in the City Treasurer's office. At noon, she usually leaves to pick up her 4-year-old son at the nearby county day care center and goes home for the rest of the day. Another woman takes her place at the office.
''I have just enough time to get out of the house and have an almost normal home life, too,'' she said. Other job-sharers make quite different arrangements. Two in the county museum carve the five-day week in half, working two full days and a half day each, while two in the county's accounts payable office take turns working two days one week, three days the next.
The arrangements can pose complications when a member of a job-sharing team leaves or shifts to full-time work. But Mrs. Grow's boss, Frank Bartoszewicz, says he prefers job-sharers to people who work nine-to-five. Rather than an employee who wears down as the day progresses, he said, ''I get four hours of a fresh person twice a day.''
Mr. Parr, whose local represents more workers than any other, said of job-sharing, ''They do that instead of having people quit.''
Why Milwaukee's public sector has been more responsive to the changing labor force than most communities seems to owe little to particular leaders, like chief executives who set goals and standards in private industry. Most innovations have been sporadic and spontaneous and confined within individual departments and agencies. Thus one of the smaller city departments, the library, has many more job-sharers, with 12, than any other, and these resulted largely from the pressure of Mr. Parr's union.
 
Practical Pressures
These days, the city has to compete with some real-world practicalities that tend to work against things that people might like to try, like paid parental leave or free day care. The city and the county, under the pressure of tight budgets, are doing things like shaving health benefits, raising some fees, eliminating jobs as population shrinks, and on occasion using temporary workers for jobs that full-time employees did earlier.
At the same time, the governments have to compete for workers in a state with unemployment around 4 percent. That leaves a small pool of people to recruit, most of them women and minority workers and many with little training. Such workers often require special training for ever more sophisticated work, and once trained, they represent investments that a cost-conscious employer has more incentive than ever to try to keep.
Being responsive to workers, moreover, can help the governments respond better to the community, said Mr. Schulz, the County Executive. The 10-hour days that many social workers and financial assistance workers keep, for example, permits them to do paperwork early in the morning so they can be free to meet with clients from 9 to 5.
In such an environment, the innovations keep coming. Last year, City Hall adopted an incentive pay plan under which department heads can spend 4 percent of their payroll budgets to reward administrators for meeting prescribed goals. Under the city's sick leave program, adopted for managers six years ago and for all employees two years ago, employees get an extra day of vacation for every four months they go without calling in sick.
 
Unpaid Parental Leaves
The county, which oversees the courts, highways, the jail and welfare for Milwaukee and 15 nearby small cities and villages, started an unpaid parental leave program for new fathers, as well as mothers, well before most other government institutions. Parents can take a leave, initially for six months, and then apply to their supervisors for an extension, without losing their jobs.
And partly because of the labor shortage in Milwaukee, Mr. Schulz said the county is planning one program next year to train some of the 30,000 mothers on welfare for regular jobs, a project that has taken on some urgency because of the cost of welfare. The county is planning another program under which young, lower-level employees will be granted one-year appointments in other departments to give them broader experience and a chance at bigger jobs.
To help families of employees cope with child care bills that can run as much as $90 per week per child, the county will introduce a cost-saving voucher system in January. Employees will get vouchers covering cost of care. They will submit the vouchers to child-care centers, which will turn them into the city for reimbursement. The employees will still pay for the care, but since the voucher does not count as income, the taxable income will be lower.
No one has compiled comprehensive data on the workers engaged in job sharing, flextime scheduling and the like, so no one can document the effects of the programs. But sick leave, a partial gauge of job satisfaction, seems to be declining. The county lost 514,600 work hours to sick leave in 1982, and 477,400 in 1988.
County officials said annual job turnover shows no clear trend. Over the last five years, it has ranged between the high of 8.6 percent in 1986 and the low of 6.4 percent in 1987.
The four-year-old county day care center, open from 6 to 6, for children 6 months to 6 years old, appears to benefit both parents and government. Mark Kustermann, the county's deputy director for human resources, said he did a spot check of five employees who keep children there. Three reported that their attendance at work had improved, he said, two that they returned to work after having babies sooner than they would otherwise have, and two would have considered resigning had it not been for the center.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Course Set by Pakistan Worrying U.S.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has certified to Congress that Pakistan does not possess a nuclear device, but it expressed concerns at the same time about Pakistan's continuing efforts to develop nuclear weapons.
The certification, which is required each year by Congress to provide assistance to Pakistan, was transmitted in a letter on Oct. 5 from President Bush.
''I have concluded that Pakistan does not now possess a nuclear explosive device,'' Mr. Bush wrote. But the President added that ''Pakistan has continued its efforts to develop its unsafeguarded nuclear program.'' 
 
Warning From Reagan
Last year President Reagan warned that advances in Pakistan's nuclear program were making it increasingly difficult for the Administration to certify that Pakistan does not possess a nuclear weapon.
''The Congress should be aware that as Pakistan's nuclear capabilities grow, and if evidence about its activities continues to accumulate, this process of annual certification will require the President to reach judgments about the status of Pakistani nuclear activities that may be difficult or impossible to make with any degree of certainty,'' Mr. Reagan wrote in a November 1988 letter.
 
Meeting With Bhutto
Administration officials said at the time that Pakistan was privately informed of this assessment, which they said was intended as a warning to curb its nuclear program.
The United States repeated its concerns during Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's visit to the United States in June. William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, gave a briefing to the Prime Minister in which he detailed what Washington knew about the Pakistani program.
In his letter of certification, President Bush took note of Ms. Bhutto's assurances to Congress that Pakistan does not possess, or intend to make, a nuclear weapon. Mr. Bush also noted that his letter did not address the question of whether Pakistan ''is attempting to develop or has developed various relevant capabilities.''
Pakistan received $576 million in economic and military assistance for the 1989 budget year. The Bush Administration has requested $621 in assistance for 1990. The Administration also plans to sell 60 F-16 planes to Pakistan.
 
Comment From Solarz
Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs, said he had ''mixed feelings'' about Mr. Bush's assessment.
''As a strong proponent of close Pakistani-American ties, I am pleased that President Bush was able to issue the certification,'' Mr. Solarz said. But he added that he was ''alarmed by the President's finding that Pakistan continues its efforts to develop an unsafeguarded nuclear program.''
Some specialists outside Government said Mr. Bush's certification did not alleviate their concerns over the Pakistani nuclear program.
''I think it is clear that Pakistan has all the components of a bomb,'' said Gary Milhollin, a professor at the University of Wisconsin who focuses on nuclear proliferation issues. ''What we are looking at is a failure to put it together. To say that Pakistan does not have the bomb is like saying that a person who has not put bullets in his gun is unarmed.''
In his letter, Mr. Bush asserted that his Administration remains ''extremely troubled'' about ''the continued risk of a South Asian nuclear arms race,'' in spite of his certification.
The President said the United States has had ''extensive diplomatic contacts'' with Pakistan over proliferation, adding that Washington ''will continue to make clear to Pakistan that our ability to certify depends on evidence that the assurances give by the Prime Minister are being implemented.''

HEADLINE: Give Economy Priority In Mayoral Campaign

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your report that Mayor Edward I. Koch has imposed a New York City hiring freeze in view of a looming $400 million budget gap for 1990 (news story, Sept. 28) portends greater problems.
There will be budget gaps to contend with that will rival those of the fiscally strapped 1970's. As past reports from my office have pointed to the financial problems now being raised, our recent reports predict more - and equally great - problems that a new mayor, and all New Yorkers, will be tackling in the years to come.
Along with fighting crime and drugs, and helping the homeless, this city should be prepared to tighten its collective belt. Although fiscal issues are not the usual campaign material, the kind of indicators we see today demonstrate a need for the mayoral candidates to give the city's economic status a high priority in the campaign.
 
EDWARD V. REGAN
State Comptroller
 New York, Sept. 29, 1989

HEADLINE: Have the Democrats Lost Their Soul?;
Yes: Blame Election Funds

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich is author of ''The Resurgent Liberal and Other Unfashionable Prophecies.''

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Two things have happened to Congressional Democrats in the 1980's: They have lost their identity; their campaign funds have swollen. There's a single story here.
Not long ago, Democrats would have relished a fight with Republicans over capital gains tax cuts for the rich. But now, even though the gap between the rich and poor is the widest in 40 years, many Democrats are ready to give the rich all the tax breaks they want. What passes as a radical Democratic proposal is to adjust the marginal income tax on the super-rich to match the marginal tax level on the very rich, and to make individual retirement accounts available to the upper middle class. 
Once, Democrats would have hammered Wall Street for insider trading, junk-bond excesses, self-dealing in futures contracts and epic displays of greed. Bold reforms would have been proposed. But today's Democrats are conspicuously silent about Wall Street shenanigans.
In the past, Democrats would have thundered against the negligence of an oil company that destroyed thousands of miles of Alaskan shore; the brazenness of corrupt, incompetent military weapons contractors. There would have been demands for full restitution, indictments, air-tight regulations. But in the wake of such scandals, the Democrats have seldom departed from polite passivity.
In short, Democrats once represented the underdogs against the rich and powerful. There was no need for carefully worded statements of principle, for think-tanks cobbling together ''new ideas.'' Everyone knew what the Democrats stood for: the little fellow.
They lost their identity, not because Americans became more respectful of wealth and power or more convinced trickle-down economics would actually work (polls show widespread opposition to capital gains breaks for the rich) but because Democrats became dependent on the rich to finance their campaigns.
They convinced big business and Wall Street it was smarter to back incumbent Democrats than aspiring Republicans - an honest sales pitch. Incumbents are much more likely to win, especially with a little help from friends. In the 1988 election, 97 percent of House and 85 percent of Senate incumbents who ran for re-election regained their seats.
In 1988, 64 percent of all the money raised by political action committees went to Democratic incumbents in the House and Senate; almost none went to Republican challengers. Most of this windfall ($31.7 million) came from corporate, Wall Street and trade association PAC's, rather than from trade unions (which contributed less than $24 million) or other traditional sources of Democratic funds.
It is difficult to represent the little fellow when the big fellow pays the tab. The problem is not corruption. The inhibition is more subtle. The anticipated need for more money tends to stifle indignation toward the source of funds and to constrain bold thinking. Democrats have come to sound like Republicans because they rely on the same funders and make the same contacts as the G.O.P.
If the Democrats want to regain their identity, the first step is to reform the way Congressional campaigns are financed. President Bush says he wants to abolish most PAC's and allow more campaign spending by political parties. But the Democrats, flush with more PAC money than Republicans, reject this proposal as partisan. (It is, but that's not the point.) They should make a counterproposal that is fairer to both sides: Limit campaign spending by candidates who accept public financing, and cap outside income in return for a pay increase.
If Congressional Democrats fail to embrace campaign finance reform, their current electoral victories may be short-lived. No party can long endure without standing for something. When the public discovers that its only choice is between Republicans and Republicans who call themselves Democrats - between those who champion the rich without qualms and those who champion the rich with an echo of regret - they'll opt for the real thing.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: MASSACHUSETTS, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: A Mix of Roosevelt Island Housing Planned

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
New York City and New York State have developed a plan for almost 2,000 new mixed-income apartments on Roosevelt Island, next to the Queensboro Bridge.
Under the plan, money from the sale of expensive apartments would subsidize nearby rental and co-operative units reserved for families making as little as $16,500 a year.
The new 19-acre development, to be called Southtown, would be the third large housing development on the island. Half of the 1,956 new apartments would sell for an average of $272,000 and would command views of the East River's West Channel and the Upper East Side of Manhattan. 
The other half, about evenly divided between rental and owner-occupied units, would face Queens and be affordable to families earning, under current guidelines, up to $48,000 a year, according to the request for proposals sent to developers.
Developers have until the end of November to submit proposals to the project's sponsors, the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, and the New York City Partnerhip, a private group that constructs housing for low- and middle-income residents on city-owned land.
Gov. Mario M. Guomo is scheduled to announce the construction plan next Thursday. The first apartments are to be available for occupancy in late 1992, and officials expect the entire project to be completed a year later.
By the end of this month, after many delays, the Transit Authority plans to open the Roosevelt Island subway station on the N and R lines. Officials hope this link to Manhattan and Queens will enhance the market for housing on Roosevelt Island. At present the island is accessible only by aerial tramway from Manhattan and by car from Queens.
 
One Site Would Remain Open
With the development of Southtown, only one remaining site on the island, next to the southern tip, would remain open.
The request for development proposals for Southtown contains strict design guidelines to preserve open space and maintain views of the East River and the Manhattan and Queens skylines. The sponsors have specified that the project comprise seven towers, four facing Manhattan and three facing Queens. Between them are to be two nine-story U-shaped buildings containing retail space and most of the rental housing for low- and moderate-income residents. $25 Million in Subsidies Southtown would be about half the size of Lincoln Towers, the 3,900-apartment complex between 66th and 70th Streets on the West Side of Manhattan. Added to the more than 3,200 apartments already built on Roosevelt Island, the new project would make the island one of the largest housing developments in the city.
Besides providing the land, the city and state are to contribute about $25 million in subsidies for the 971 apartments reserved for families meeting income guidelines. More than half are to be condominiums or co-ops.
But the state and city expect income from the sale of the 982 luxury apartments to provide the greatest benefits to Southtown's affordable housing, just as the city is using money from ground leases on expensive market-rate housing at Battery Park City in lower Manhattan to pay for Mayor Edward I. Koch's housing rehabilitation program elsewhere in the city.
 
A Mix of Incomes Planned
A total of 101 apartments, of which 28 are to be co-ops and the rest rentals, would be reserved for people making no more than half the median income for the metropolitan area at the time -or $16,500, given the current median income of $33,000 a year.
Another 101 apartments, divided in the same way, are to be reserved for those making no more than 80 percent of the median, or $26,400 today.
For families making 120 percent of median income, or $39,600, there are to be 159 co-ops and 23 rentals, and a similar number of units for families earning 148 percent of median income, or $48,839.
Besides this so-called ''cross subsidy,'' officials say, the city is committed to fostering the social and economic integration of Roosevelt Island, which is home to the well-to-do and the poor and disabled.
''We feel very strongly about maintaining this kind of mix, and it all added up to put it together this way,'' said Richard L. Higgins, the Commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

GRAPHIC: Photo of a model of Southtown, Roosevelt Island's third major housing development, near the Queensboro Bridge. (Wolfgang Hoyt)

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
Many women at or past the age of menopause are worried and confused about taking hormones to replace the ones their ovaries are no longer producing in ''adequate'' amounts.
On the one hand, they hear, estrogen replacement can perpetuate their premenopausal immunity against heart attacks and it can stop the otherwise inexorable loss of bone with age, a loss that eventually leads to osteoporosis and debilitating fractures in millions of older women.
On the other hand, women are warned that postmenopausal estrogens can increase their risk of developing cancer of the uterus, gallbladder disease and possibly cancer of the breast as well.
They are told that the uterine cancer risk can be negated by taking a second hormone, progesterone or progestin (a synthetic version of progesterone), for about 10 days a month. But they are also advised that by taking progesterone they will continue to have menstrual-like bleeding each month and that, in addition, this hormone may wipe out the benefits of estrogen to the heart. 
Among gynecologists who treat menopausal women, the pendulum is now swinging away from adding progesterone to the regimen, particularly since annoyance with monthly bleeding is why most women stop taking postmenopausal hormones.
About the only certainty surrounding hormone therapy is its unquestioned effectiveness at countering the sometimes life-disrupting symptoms of menopause, from hot flashes that are embarrassing and can seriously disturb sleep to vaginal dryness and atrophy that can cause pain and bleeding during sexual intercourse.
Many women may take replacement hormones for only a year or two, resuming if their hot flashes recur. But what should women do for their remaining postmenopausal years, which could easily represent a third or more of their lives?
At a conference last month, the first meeting of a newly established medical organization, the North American Menopause Society, experts explored the risks and benefits of hormone therapy as currently understood from admittedly less-than-ideal scientific studies. The conference, held under the auspices of the New York Academy of Sciences, was clearly stacked in favor of hormone replacement, with no speakers adamantly against it. But the speakers also acknowledged a desperate need for more and better studies on which to base their advice to women.
The confusion over estrogen's link to cancer is a case in point. Women who choose not to take hormones often cite a fear of cancer as their reason, said Dr. Trudy L. Bush, an epidemiologist at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. But she noted that heart disease, not cancer, is far and away the leading killer of women after menopause. Heart disease takes on average 12 lives a year among every 2,000 women over 50 years old, as against two deaths a year from breast cancer.
Even if hormone therapy doubled a woman's chances of getting breast cancer (and there is no good evidence that it does), it would not come near to canceling estrogen's life-saving potential, she said. In her view, any measure that significantly diminishes the risk of heart disease in postmenopausal women is likely to save far more lives than it may take.
Dr. Rogerio Lobo, obstetrician-gynecologist at the University of Southern California, presented even more dramatic statistics. Factoring in what is known about the risks and benefits of estrogen therapy, he calculated that each year among 100,000 women 50 to 75 years old, the treatment would save 5,561 lives, 5,250 of them from averted heart attacks.
The problem with all these calculations is that they are based on the incidence of disease observed among women who have chosen to take postmenopausal hormones. It is well established that these women tend to be better educated and economically better off than women who do not take these hormones. Thus, on average, hormone-takers are probably a healthier group to start with.
Unfortunately, a long-term study that would eliminate this bias is not likely to be done. In such a study hormone treatment would be randomly assigned to half of thousands of participants, who would then be followed for a decade or more. But the National Institutes of Health decided this would be too costly and long. Instead, the N.I.H. is sponsoring a study of the effects of hormone replacement on cardiovascular risk factors like cholesterol levels in the blood.
 
Hormones and the Heart
Meanwhile, millions have to decide about hormone therapy based on the best evidence available. Given the statistics cited above and the national concern about cholesterol and heart disease, the most pressing facts to consider involve cardiac risk in postmenopausal women. These are the principal considerations:
* Before menopause, women rarely suffer heart attacks or other symptoms of cardiovascular disease. But within a few years after menopause, their rates of heart disease equal those of men 6 to 10 years younger, a situation that continues for the rest of their lives. And while the rate among women never catches up to that among men, cardiovascular disease is by far the leading cause of death of American women after menopause.
* Natural estrogens can protect the heart by raising blood levels of beneficial HDL-cholesterol, believed to be the body's means of cleansing itself of cholesterol that might otherwise be deposited in arteries. The typical increase in HDL's among women taking estrogen can change their risk of heart disease from high to moderate or, if it was moderate to start with, from moderate to low.
* Estrogens also seem to benefit arteries independently of their effect on HDL-cholesterol. Evidence from animal studies, as well as from women who had heart surgery and subsequent arterial studies, suggests that estrogens prevent the formation of fatty deposits on arterial walls, the disease process that underlies most heart attacks and strokes.
* Studies of many thousands of women followed for a decade or more indicate that the overall cardiovascular benefit to women taking postmenopausal estrogens is a halving of their risk of dying of a heart attack, compared with other women their age who do not take the hormones.
* Whether taking progesterone or progestins along with estrogen will negate this benefit is not yet known. But Dr. Lobo said progesterone blunts the beneficial effect of estrogens on HDL's, alters factors that may protect blood vessels from fatty deposits and raises blood levels of another group of fats, triglycerides, which are associated with an increased risk of heart disease. Different progestins and lower dosages are now being introduced in therapy in hopes of avoiding these effects.
* It is also not known whether the benefits to the heart observed among women taking estrogens by mouth will apply to women who use the recently introduced estrogen patches, which allow estrogen to be absorbed through the skin, resulting in less loss through metabolic processes. The patches produce lower blood levels of estrogen and permit estrogen to enter the blood without first being processed by the liver, the body's main cholesterol factory.
Dr. Wulf Utian, who organized the conference, said in an interview, ''The agents, the doses and the methods of administration are changing so fast, we don't yet know which method of hormone replacement is better and which may be worse.'' Dr. Utian, founder of the new society, is director of obstetrics and gynecology at the University Hospitals of Cleveland.
 
Other Considerations
When asked who should not take postmenopausal estrogens, Dr. Utian said he would not prescribe them for any woman who has had breast cancer or who recently suffered a blood clot or who once had a clot while taking birth control pills.
Dr. Isaac Schiff, gynecologist at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, said women with a strong family history of breast cancer should be advised that while the hormones per se would probably not add to their risk, they might be inclined to blame the treatment if they later developed breast cancer.
He and the other experts discounted a recent Swedish study suggesting long-term treatment with estrogens can raise a woman's breast cancer risk, especially if the woman took both estrogen and progesterone. What the study really showed, they said, was that women on hormones who get breast cancer are more likely to survive than breast cancer patients who have not taken estrogens, possibly because estrogen users are more closely monitored and their cancers are detected earlier.
As for cancer of the uterus, this is no problem for women who have had a hysterectomy. In many parts of the country, as many as 40 to 50 percent of postmenopausal women have had the uterus surgically removed, Dr. Bush said.
For those who still have a uterus and are taking estrogens without progesterone, Dr. Utian insists on annual sampling of the uterine lining to detect abnormal growth of endometrial tissue and head off a potential cancer. He pointed out that uterine cancer is a slow-growing disease that is highly curable, especially when treated at an early stage.

HEADLINE: Wrangling On Gains Tax Continues

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11

 BODY:
Congressional negotiations on a budget deal that would provide a separate vote on cutting the capital gains tax continued today, marked by a round of partisan finger-pointing.
As a result of the legislators' inability to reach agreement, the Senate will begin debate Thursday on a $13 billion deficit-reduction package that includes a host of tax and spending provisions but not a cut in the capital gains tax.
Congressional leaders have said for weeks that it is unlikely that both houses will agree on how to reduce the deficit by the Oct. 16 deadline required by law. If they are right, automatic spending cuts totaling $16 billion will go into effect on Monday involving a variety of domestic and military programs.
While the initial impact of the cuts will be almost unnoticeable to most Americans, the elderly will have their Medicare reimbursements cut by 2 percent beginning Monday. 
Despite the seemingly dim prospects for reaching an agreement, Senate Democratic and Republican leaders refused to pronounce their efforts dead and planned to meet once more on Thursday morning before the deficit-reduction package comes to the Senate floor.
The Republican leader, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, said that as far as he was concerned the talks should continue even after the deficit package came up for debate.
Last week, the House approved an $11 billion deficit-reduction plan that includes a two-year reduction in the capital gains tax. But most senators, including supporters of a lower gains tax, object to a temporary reduction, saying it is economically unsound.
President Bush, in his election campaign, had promised to press for a permanent reduction in the capital gains tax, saying it would stimulate economic growth.
The collapse of the talks leaves Senate supporters of reducing the capital gains tax in political and legislative limbo. Sixty votes, rather than a simple 51-vote majority, are needed to attach such a measure to the deficit package, and proponents of the tax cut do not have that many votes.
The White House budget director, Richard Darman, spent much of today in strategy sessions with Senator Dole considering whether to continue to try to include the gains tax proposal in the deficit package, and if so, which version of a gains cut to propose.
 
'The Psychology of Losing'
''It's a question of the psychology of losing,'' said Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee. ''Does losing on the deficit package make things more difficult later or does it give you a chance to make a point now by losing with 54 votes in favor of capital gains reduction?''
The talks between Congressional leaders in both parties have been under way for nearly a week in hopes of producing a compromise on the deficit-reduction measure that would strip various tax and spending provisions from the bill, and at the same time, allow supporters of reducing the gains tax a separate vote on that measure.
Senate leaders in both parties said today that they would try to strip some extraneous provisions from the deficit package that will reach the floor Thursday.
That process could prompt an effort to jettison hundreds of millions of dollars in special tax breaks that are part of the Senate Finance Committee's portion of the package. It could also jeopardize a pet Democratic child care initiative adopted by the tax panel.
 
Differing Versions
The House has approved an $11 billion deficit package, including the temporary capital gains tax cut, and the two chambers will eventually have to work out their differences in conference. Among the provisions in the House package are a child care plan different from the Senate's; restoration of the fairness doctrine in the regulation of broadcasting; repeal of last year's catastrophic health insurance law; legislation to restrict so-called dial-a-porn telephone services and revisions in pension plan laws.
Some House Democrats suggested today that the conference that will follow Senate action on the deficit package could be so protracted that some of the automatic cuts could seriously affect programs like student loans and disaster relief to farmers.
As members of the Senate Budget and Finance Committees grapple with the complicated legislative mechanics of the deficit package, Senate leaders turned their attention to the political fallout.
Mr. Dole took to the Senate floor today to accuse Democrats of failing to respond to three offers from Republicans.
''It's pretty hard to have an agreement unless there are offers and counteroffers, and we're still waiting for a counteroffer,'' he said.
Democrats said the White House had thwarted a deal by placing its desire for a capital gains cut above the necessity of passing a responsible deficit-reduction package before the Monday deadline.
Senator George Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, has complained about the White House stance, and today the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, took up the cry.
''I'm confused by the statements coming out of the White House,'' he told reporters. ''I don't know how we can be dealing on the one hand with the negotiations to allegedly produce a stripped-down bill here with Republican leadership people, and Mr. Fitzwater saying on the other hand that he doesn't support the position of the Republican leaders and wants to keep capital gains in the bill.''
The Senate is scheduled to work through Thursday and Friday on the deficit-reduction package, and Mr. Mitchell said he would not rule out a weekend session. If supporters of a capital gains cut choose not to offer their proposal as an amendment to that package, or if they do and lose, they might seek to add their proposal to a bill later this month to raise the national debt limit.
The Government is operating under a short-term debt ceiling that expires on Oct. 31. Congress must approve either a long-term extension or another interim measure by that date in order to permit the Treasury to continue borrowing in the bond markets.
Treasury officials said today that they had no plans at this time to seek a short-term debt extension, but Mr. Packwood said that situation could change if the Senate nears the Oct. 31 deadline and finds itself bogged down with the usual array of amendments that senators attach to such legislation, in the hope of sweeping them through the legislative process.
Among the many versions of a capital gains cut circulating on Capitol Hill, the two leading contenders are a proposal by Senator Packwood and a similar but considerably more generous measure proposed by Senator David Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat who also serves on the Finance Committee. Mr. Packwood said in an interview today that he and Mr. Boren were trying to meld their plans in hopes of offering a bipartisan capital gains reduction proposal.
''I still haven't decided when to offer it,'' Mr. Packwood said, adding that even if he chooses the debt ceiling legislation as the vehicle he will still have to muster 60 votes to shut off any filibuster that might be mounted by opponents of a capital gains cut.
''You take your openings as they come,'' Mr. Packwood said. ''I think we may be a few votes short the first time or the second time, but we will all know when that last train is leaving the station, and I think on a final vote we will get the 60.''

HEADLINE: Norwegian Wins Nobel For His Work in Economics

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science was awarded today to an obscure Norwegian professor whose pioneering work in methods for testing economic theories helped pave the way for modern economic forecasting.
Trygve Haavelmo (pronounced TRIG-veh haw-VEL-mo), 77 years old, was honored for his work in the 1940's, which resulted in a dramatic change in the way economists drew conclusions from statistical observations of how various parts of the economy affect one another. While economics will always be an inexact science, Dr. Haavelmo's methods were crucial in making it more exact, and thus more useful to society.
His techniques made it possible for others to develop mathematical models, known as econometric models, said Assar Lindbeck, chairman of the prize committee at the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences. 
A model can be used to predict the impact of a particular rise or fall in interest rates on the level of personal consumption or how a tax change might affect the availability of labor or the level of capital investment.
Dr. Haavelmo's contribution is ''the story of how economics was transformed from armchair instinct to empirical science,'' said Bengt-Christer Ysander, a member of the prize committee.
Yet those who know Dr. Haavelmo said his main interest was not forecasting. ''His interest was to show by appropriate methods that we could adequately and accurately test the validity of economic theories and thus better use them to better understand economic phenomena,'' said D. Gale Johnson, an economics professor at the University of Chicago, where Dr. Haavelmo worked in the 1940's and as a visiting professor in the late 1950's. ''I don't think he had any great interest in forecasting.''
Economists noted that others, like Lawrence Klein, also a Nobel laureate, had used the Norwegian's techniques to build forecasting models.
All the sophisticated econometric models developed since the 1940's ''rest on Haavelmo's work,'' said Robert M. Solow, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who won the Nobel Memorial Economics Prize in 1987.
Dr. Haavelmo retired in 1979 and is now a professor emeritus at the University of Oslo.
Dr. Haavelmo could not be reached today through the university, but Reuters said he had told Norway's state radio: ''I am very surprised. Such awards should really go to much younger people. I have had much pleasure from what I've been doing, and all the interesting things I have been allowed to take part in so far have really been reward enough.''
Mr. Haavelmo will receive a diploma, a medal and three million Swedish kronor ($462,820).
The economics prize was established by the bank in 1968 as a memorial to Alfred Nobel, who invented dynamite, and was first awarded the following year. Nobel prizes in physics, chemistry, medicine, literature and peace were set up under the terms of Mr. Nobel's will.
The prize committee singled out as especially influential Dr. Haavelmo's doctoral dissertation, ''The Probability Approach in Econometrics.'' After World War II began, Dr. Haavelmo left Norway for the United States and presented his dissertation at Harvard in 1941. The dissertation was published three years later in the American periodical Econometrica. He returned to Norway in 1947.
One of Dr. Haavelmo's significant contributions was proving that economists could be more precise by integrating statistical probability theory into their formulations.
Dr. Haavelmo was important for demonstrating that relations among all the components of the economy must be considered in making a prediction about one component. For instance, exchange rates are not the only factor that affect the level of imported goods. So do interest rates and tax rates, to name two.
Dr. Haavelmo was born in Skedsmo, Norway, in 1911 and graduated from the University of Oslo in 1933. He was then hired by Ragnar Frisch as a research assistant at the new Institute of Economics in Oslo.
In the 1930's, Jan Tinbergen, a Dutchman, and Professor Frisch did work on testing various macroeconomic relations that won them the first Nobel Memorial Prize in 1969. Several problems they encountered were later analyzed in Dr. Haavelmo's dissertation.

HEADLINE: Japan Lifts Discount Rate; Dollar Still Gains

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 11

 BODY:
The Bank of Japan surprised the foreign exchange market here today by abruptly raising its discount rate a half-percentage point in an effort to stem the dollar's surge. But the increase, announced at midday, had a negligible impact, prompting concerns that central banks are running out of tools for taming the dollar.
''Essentially, they got mugged,'' said Kenneth S. Courtis, senior economist here for Deutsche Bank A.G., referring to the Bank of Japan's move. ''They've tried to intimidate the currency market, and what that market is saying is that it is going to take much more to change things.'' 
After the announcement that the rate would rise to 3.75 percent, from 3.25 percent, effective immediately, the dollar tumbled here to 142.55 yen, from its early morning high of 144.95 yen. By the end of trading, though, it had bounced back to 144.00. In trading in New York and elsewhere, the dollar advanced against most currencies. [Page D18.] The United States Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and the major European central banks - the monetary authorities of the Group of Seven industrial nations - have spent close to $12 billion in recent weeks to try to push the dollar below the 140-yen level, all to reduce the United States' yawning trade deficit.
In addition, nine European central banks initiated a coordinated interest rate rise last Thursday to halt aggressive dollar buying. In theory, a weaker dollar makes American goods cheaper overseas, helping exports, while discouraging imports by making them more expensive.
But the dollar has remained strong, fueled on Tuesday by remarks in Moscow by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, that indicated that he did not believe direct intervention to weaken the dollar would work in the long term. He also gave priority to holding down inflation in the United States, which was interpreted to mean that the Fed would not lower interest rates soon, as some had expected. Higher interest rates in the United States increase the value of the dollar, as capital flows into higher-yielding dollar-denominated investments.
 
Unprecedented Manner
There had been talk here for weeks that the central bank might be contemplating an increase in its discount rate, which is the interest rate it charges on loans to banks. But the abrupt manner in which it was announced was unprecedented in recent times, indicating to analysts that the Japanese central bank is extremely worried about the dollar's recent rise.
Traditionally, the central bank has made such announcements - the last was a rise of three-fourths of a point in May - at 4 P.M., as the local markets closed, to take effect the following day. To further soften the blow, the news has generally been leaked to the local press in advance.
But today, an emergency meeting of the Bank of Japan's seven-member policy committee was secretly called for 11 A.M. At 12:45 P.M. the central bank announced that its discount rate would rise.
Satoshi Sumita, the bank's governor, began the afternoon news conference by apologizing to reporters for springing the surprise on them.
''Most people were at lunch when they made the announcement, and there was some panic initially,'' said Hiroaki Shukuzawa, assistant manager of foreign exchange at the Sumitomo Bank. $200 Million Sold Mr. Shukuzawa added that the Bank of Japan sold a small number of dollars, approximately $200 million, into the currency market near the time of the announcement, but the step had almost no impact.
Elsewhere, stock prices tumbled on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in response to the developments, with the Nikkei average falling 136.28, to 35,240.07.
Susumo Saito, chief economist at the Credit Suisse Investment Advisory Company here, said that while the dollar's strength was a factor in the increase in the discount rate, other factors were equally important. He described the increase as a ''pre-emptive measure'' to cool the economy and halt growing inflationary pressures.
The increase presents some delicate problems for the Japanese Government. In response to intense pressure from the United States for Japan to reduce its huge trade surplus, the Government has spent the last several years encouraging domestic demand, both to stem the rise in exports and to attract more imports. Now, there is concern that by raising interest rates, the Bank of Japan may be squelching consumer buying, setting the stage for an even larger trade surplus.
''This is a very delicate period for the Japanese economy because the growth rate is already slowing,'' said Richard Koo, senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute. ''I don't think they wanted to do this now, but they didn't have much choice. That's the point: they're being pushed to do things they may not want to do just to defend the currency.''

CORRECTION-DATE: October 14, 1989, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about an increase in the Japanese discount rate misidentified the person who said that while the strength of the dollar was a factor in the increase, other factors were equally important. He was Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, not Susumo Saito of the Credit Suisse Investment Advisory Company.
