HEADLINE: Boeing's Fight Over Bonuses

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
The issue at the heart of the Boeing Company strike, which has idled 58,000 workers for more than a week, is a new one in the American labor movement - one that is forcing union leaders to confront not only management but also their own members.
The issue is bonuses - not the occasional Christmas turkey, but big yearly bonus checks that companies across the country are vigorously trying to substitute for raises. ''You see this effort popping up all the time,'' said Jerry Jasinowski, executive vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
In the concession bargaining of the early 1980's, many companies, pleading hardship, said bonuses were less costly than raises and would help give them the relief necessary for survival. Raises are folded into base pay and therefore count toward pensions, vacation and sick pay, overtime rates and, most important, are compounded by subsequent raises. Bonuses do none of this. 
But now that American business is more prosperous, union leaders are trying to reinstate substantial annual raises. The Boeing strike may become a watershed event in this struggle, and it is bringing to light an unusual obstacle. Many workers, not only in aerospace but in steel, autos, telephones and other industries, are now reluctant to give up those bonus checks, whatever their shortcomings. That is particularly true at Boeing. ''If someone offers you $3,000 to $4,000 just before Christmas, you tend to like it,'' said Reginald Newell, chief of research at the International Association of Machinists, which represents Boeing's striking production workers.
Boeing, as part of its contracts with the machinists, has paid big bonuses each Dec. 15 since 1983, which makes the huge aircraft manufacturer a pioneer in a practice that now involves 42 percent of all American workers covered by major union agreements, the Labor Department says.
At Boeing, the bonuses have become a way of life. In interviews with 35 Boeing workers, 26 said they had come to depend on the bonuses for Christmas shopping, paying credit card debt or making a down payment on a house, car or boat.
''It gives us, once a year, a little more buying power, and helps everyone catch up on debt,'' said Richard Young, a 45-year-old union shop steward and metal worker.
Economists and A.F.L.-C.I.O. officials say one reason the bonuses work so well at Boeing is that the company's work force is young, one of the youngest in American manufacturing, and young people, raising families, often have an immediate need for cash. What is more, many Boeing workers have never had a raise. Averaging 38 years of age and only six years at Boeing, they signed on after Boeing's last general wage increase, in 1982.
''Ironically, as wages lose ground to inflation, bonuses become attractive as a way to get ahead for a moment,'' said George Kohl, research director for the Communications Workers of America. ''They're like winning the lottery.''
But if the sweet tooth for bonuses among its members is a problem for a union trying to return to a more traditional system of annual wage increases, another set of circumstances gives the machinists unusual leverage at Boeing. Aircraft manufacturing is a labor-intensive industry, and Boeing cannot operate without its American workers. Unlike autos or appliances, the assembly of big airliners is not easily transferred abroad.
The work is done by teams of specialists in riveting, wing assembly, wiring, strut assembly, cockpit installation, metal binding and numerous other tasks. Other teams, also production workers, inspect each piece of work for flaws. All these people move about in cavernous, hangar-like buildings, principally in Seattle, Boeing's headquarters city, and also in Portland, Ore., and Wichita, Kan.
The strike that started at midnight on Oct. 3 emptied and silenced these buildings, and halted work on more than 30 partly built aircraft. There have been no negotiations since.
The shutdown came just as Boeing was enjoying its most profitable period ever - a prosperity that deprived the company of its justification for making bonus payments in lieu of raises. The company has piled up orders to build 1,600 planes for $80 billion, a backlog that will keep Boeing at full production for more than four years, if none of the orders are canceled. When the strike came, Boeing had been expanding its work force at the rate of 400 a week.
Referring to the union's unusual leverage, Justin Ostro, an international vice president of the machinists, said at a rally of Boeing workers just before they rejected the company's ''final offer'' for a three-year contract: ''If you aren't tough enough to fight today, you never will get anything. If you turn tail and run, don't come back in three years for more.''
But Boeing seems equally determined to resist the machinists, despite the damage this might do to profits and production schedules if the strike lasts more than two weeks. The company's long-term goal is to minimize raises and eventually move the entire work force toward a system that includes not only bonuses but also annual profit-sharing payments, Boeing executives say. These payments would rise during good times and disappear during the inevitable periodic downturns in airplane manufacturing.
The bonuses now specified in the machinists' contract would thus evolve into rewards for profitability and hard work - becoming more like the year-end rewards that executives and Wall Street brokers often get, although much smaller.
Other companies, in other industries, are pursuing a similar strategy. ''There is a broad trend among manufacturers away from raises and toward tying compensation to improvements in productivity and a company's profitability,'' Mr. Jasinowski said. ''We have discussed this at meetings of the National Association of Manufacturers.''
 
'Flexible Pay'
Frank Shrontz, Boeing's chairman, calls the new approach ''flexible pay.'' Harold Carr, a Boeing spokesman, said the company's goal of changing the way workers are paid is not likely to be achieved during the current dispute. ''There is a long-term process for dealing with the machinists union that involves flexible pay,'' he said, ''but you just don't achieve it overnight.''
The quid pro quo for accepting such flexible pay in lieu of raises might be an agreement by Boeing to forgo layoffs, company executives said. That would be quite a departure for the world's largest aircraft manufacturer, which has dealt with past downturns by laying off tens of thousands of workers.
Once in the 1970's, the work force was cut from 140,000 to 35,000 - a cutback that produced billboards in Seattle asking the last person leaving the city to please turn out the lights.
Whatever the lures, the Boeing strike is today focused squarely on the issue of bonuses versus wage increases. The company's ''final offer'' - made a day before the strike - included a wage increase of 4 percent the first year and 3 percent in each of the next two years, the first raises since 1983. Production workers now make from $8.88 to $18.42 an hour.
The proposal was in line with increases accepted earlier this year by steelworkers and telephone workers, and by employees in many other industries, according to Labor Department data. But the machinists' leaders, who had sought double-digit wage increases, rejected Boeing's offer, saying it failed even to keep wages from losing ground to inflation, now about 4.5 percent a year.
Many Boeing workers, however, had anticipated that the company would propose a relatively small wage increase.
''The only way to make a wage increase of 3 percent or 4 percent a year palatable is to have a big bonus,'' said Michael O. Fox, a 43-year-old maintenance worker who earns $35,000 in base pay, and is making payments on a home, a car and a sand buggy.
In the interviews, which took place before the company's final offer was made public, some workers even expressed the fear that a big wage increase would be too costly for Boeing, resulting in a loss of business to Airbus Industrie of Europe or the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
''I hear a lot of people saying we are going to price ourselves out of a job,'' said Vicki Drysdale, a 35-year-old welder and union shop steward, who still favored a double-digit wage increase. ''They feel that if the company has to pay higher wages, that's going to hurt and they can't pay the stockholders.''
 
Favoring a Trade-Off
Such thinking prompted many of the 35 workers interviewed to say they would accept what they called inadequate raises if the bonus was big enough. They spoke of bonuses reaching 18 percent or 20 percent this Christmas, but the Boeing proposal came nowhere near that.
When the last contract was signed, in 1986, the first bonus was 12 percent of total income. For the next two Decembers, the bonuses were 5 percent a year. The latest proposal would sharply cut the bonus payments - to 8 percent the first year, 3 percent in 1990 and nothing in 1991.
The machinists' leadership, in a three-month educational campaign, has had difficulty convincing Boeing workers that bonuses are far less lucrative than pay increases.
One union circular, for example, noted that since 1983, Boeing had paid bonuses equal to 31 percent of each worker's gross pay. For a worker earning $12 an hour, that meant six pre-Christmas bonuses totaling $7,738. If the same 31 percent had been in the form of raises folded into base pay, then the simple process of compounding would have produced more than three times as much new income: $25,938 during the six years.
 
Illustrating the Point
Videotapes prepared by Machinists District 751, which includes most Boeing production workers, used vivid charts to illustrate this.
''Even with all that explanation, people still wanted bonuses,'' a union official said. ''There is that big lump of money all at once instead of a few extra dollars in each weekly paycheck. I can think of no other explanation.''
John Dunlop, Secretary of Labor in the Ford Administration, and now a Harvard economist, said that while bonuses seem popular today, that popularity would disappear quickly if the inflation rate rose sharply.
The sharp rise would quickly erode wage values, he said, and Boeing workers satisfied with bonuses today would begin fighting for raises. ''A low inflation rate is a critical prerequisite for bonuses,'' he said. ''You change that, and they would no longer proliferate.''

HEADLINE: Analysts Expect More Banks to Post Loan Losses

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Led by large New York banks that have already announced plans to take heavy losses on their loans to less-developed countries, other banks are likely to report poor earnings for the third quarter, analysts say.
''The losses at a few big banks will set the tone for the quarter,'' said James J. McDermott Jr., executive vice president at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a New York-based securities firm that specializes in banking companies. ''Under the cover of increasing their reserves for loans to less-developed countries, banks will see an opportunity to clean up a lot of other problems.''
For regional and small banks, analysts said, poor results are more likely to be overlooked by investors when the results for the entire industry are bad. Therefore, these banks may recognize other loan losses at this time. 
 
'The Big-Bank Theory'
J. Richard Fredericks, a banking analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said the deteriorating loan quality and pressure on interest margins (the difference between the interest rates on banking deposits and loans) are the impediments to strong earnings growth at most banks this quarter.
Since 1989 is not going to be a good year, banks are operating on ''the big-bang theory,'' Mr. Fredericks said. ''If you are going to take a hit to earnings, bankers figure they might as well take a big one.''
The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday became the first large bank to announce a third-quarter loss - a $1.1 billion deficit, which it had warned investors to expect. When Chase set aside $1.15 billion as a reserve for losses on loans to less-developed countries, it said it would also take after-tax losses of $85 million from real estate lending at an Arizona bank subsidiary and $25 million from its securities-trading operations.
 
Other Big Losses Expected
The Manufacturers Hanover Corportion, which expects to lose $775 million this quarter, and J. P. Morgan & Company, which expects to lose $1.8 billion, have issued similar advance notices. All three companies attributed the losses to the extra reserves for potential losses on third-world loans. The conditions of the loan agreement reached with Mexico last month and deteriorating circumstances in other countries required greater reserves, executives at the three banks said.
Mr. Fredericks said the Bankers Trust Company and the Chemical Banking Corporation were also likely to announce large additions to their loss reserves for third-world loans this quarter and could report quarterly losses as a result. Investors often favor banks with larger reserves because they can write off the loans and substract the loss from reserves rather than from earnings.
Citicorp, the largest lender to less-developed countries and the banking company most committed to continuing lending to those countries, is not likely to increase its reserves this quarter, Mr. Fredericks said. Citicorp, however, might raise its reserves in the fourth quarter, he said, if the outcome of November's elections in Brazil is likely to make it harder for banks to collect. Brazil missed a $1.6 billion interst payment in September, which hurt earnings at several large banks, even though it did not force them to write off those loans.
 
Troubled Real Estate Loans
Real estate loans are a growing problem to bankers. In New England, the Bank of Boston Corporation said earlier this month that it was adding $370 million to its loan-loss reserve and would report a loss of about $125 million for the quarter.
''We see asset deterioration across the country, with provisions for loan losses rising and nonperforming loans increasing,'' said Lawrence W. Cohn, a banking analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
Another emerging threat to bank earnings are problems related to loans used to finance highly leveraged transactions, like corporate buyouts. At the Bank of Boston, one highly leveraged loan of more than $100 million was placed on nonperforming status.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 11.97 in Reaction to Weaker Bonds

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks ended lower yesterday as a weaker bond market and the selling of blue-chip issues pushed equities down for the second day.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 11.97 points, to 2,773.36. The average, which had set five records in a row before falling 6.08 points on Tuesday, was off nearly 25 points about noon yesterday. It gradually recovered some of that loss, before gaining strongly in the last hour. 
Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances by a wide 1,021 to 458. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.14 points, to 356.99, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index was off 1.19 points, to 197.81.
''Uncertainties in interest-rate direction, combined with a strong dollar, are causing investor nervousness,'' said James Kalil Sr., president of Compu-Val Investments Inc. in Wilmington, Del. ''A retreat from an historically high area is also quite normal.''
He said downward movements could continue until the outlook was clarified for interest rates, the economy and corporate earnings.
Mr. Kalil's assessment of the stock market was shared by Larry Kekst, senior portfolio manager at the National City Corporation in Cleveland. ''Equities took their cue from the strong dollar and the weak bond market to post a slow, orderly decline on the day,'' he said, adding that the late attempt at a rally cut the losses in half. ''The moderate volume indicates a lack of real investor conviction.''
Volume on the Big Board, which has faltered of late, rose to 164.1 million shares yesterday from 147.6 million on Tuesday.
The Dow Jones transportation average showed unusual weakness, plunging 21.34 points, to 1,484.53. The AMR Corporation led the retreat dropping 4 1/4, to 97 1/8. Arbitragers have been speculating in the stock, and AMR has not responded to an offer by Donald J. Trump to acquire the company for $120 a share.
Other airline issues also declined. UAL fell 2 1/4, to 281 3/4; Delta declined 2 5/8, to 77 1/8, and Pan Am was unchanged at 3 7/8.
Among other individual issues, Compaq Computer dropped 1 3/4, to 100 1/2, but the company said it knew of no reason for the decline.
Gulf States Utilities fell 2 1/8, to 12 1/8, and was the most active issue on the Big Board, with 7.5 million shares traded. The company said it was evaluating its options regarding an adverse judicial decision on its River Bend nuclear power plant. The options include an appeal of the Louisiana judge's decision that upholds state regulators' refusal to allow the utility to recover certain portions of the plant's construction cost.
 
Rumors About Paramount
Paramount Communications rose 1 1/2, to 65 1/4, on renewed rumors that the company might be a takeover candidate.
Chase Manhattan fell 1, to 43 3/4, after reporting a $1.1 billion loss for the third quarter. Shares of other big banks were mixed, with Manufacturers Hanover off 1/4, to 43 1/2, and Citicorp up 1/4, to 34 3/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market-value index dropped 1.35 points, to 395.68, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index declined 1.98 points, to 482.16.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
'Junk Bond' Market Comes Under Selling Pressure

BYLINE: By ANISE WALLACE

 BODY:
The 'junk bond' market came under further selling pressure yesterday, swept with rumors about large blocks of bonds being sold by dealers and investors. Prices of some large, actively traded issues like RJR Holdings were quoted down a point and a half, or $15 for every $1,000 face amount.
''If there's a whiff of bad news, people are dumping bonds,'' said a trader at one major firm. ''They prefer to take a one-point hit rather than wait a week and see them down 10 points.'' 
Prices of Trump Taj Mahal bonds were quoted down three points, after a helicopter crash on Tuesday killed three executives of Donald J. Trump's casino operations. Prices of bonds of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. have fallen more than five points in the last four days, one trader said. Some investors are disappointed by the amount the company received from the sale of its Sea World theme parks to Anheuser-Busch Inc.
 
Turner Offering Popular
But investors clamored to buy a $550 million offering of debentures by Turner Broadcasting System. A day earlier, Turner offered $250 million in debt securities.
Some investors said they perceived economic strength in the company's broadcasting franchises. The bonds were priced to yield 12 1/8 percent and at the end of the day prices in the secondary market were up slightly.
''Given the rating of the company I would have thought that they would yield at least 13 percent,'' said Barbara L. Kenworthy, a bond fund manager at the Dreyfus Corporation in New York. ''That tells you the market thinks it's likely to be upgraded.''
Because RJR is one of the most heavily traded junk bonds and is often sold when institutional investors want to raise cash, some investors speculated that mutual funds or savings and loans associations were liquidating some holdings. Traders said a large number of RJR zero-coupon bonds were sold in the afternoon and rumors circulated that the seller was Goldman, Sachs & Company.
A spokesman fore the firm said it did not sell or trade any RJR securities yesterday.
Michael S. Hyland, a managing director of Salomon Brothers Asset Management, said his firm was helping some savings institutions sell their junk bonds and he had been told by lawyers in Washington that they could not swap their junk bonds for other debt securities, as some investors had hoped.
As a result, he said, savings associations are likely to sell the most liquid issues like RJR first.
One company that met with a poor reception was Aztar, the successor to the Ramada Corporation, which last week had postponed and overhauled its offering of $400 million of new securities last week.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Despite Moves By Japan and Central Banks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced yesterday against most leading foreign currencies despite heavy selling by central banks and an unexpected rise in the Japanese discount rate. The British pound continued to fall against the dollar.
Gold prices rose in New York after falling slightly overseas. 
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery closed at $362 a troy ounce, a $1 increase from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $361.50 an ounce, up 50 cents.
Currency dealers said the dollar initially fell after the Bank of Japan announced it would raise its discount rate - the interest rate charged to member banks - to 3.75 percent, from 3.25 percent.
 
Intervention Not a Factor
But the dollar soon shrugged off that unexpected news, as well as reports of widespread intervention by the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and several European central banks, they said.
One European dealer said the central bank dollar-selling was effective only in ''taking the sting out of what looked to be a fairly vicious upward move.''
J. Thomas Stanley, manager of corporate foreign exchange for the Chemical New York Capital Markets Group, said the dollar was being supported by the belief that United States interest rates would hold steady.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.67 yen from Monday to close at 144.00 yen. Tokyo's markets were closed Tuesday for a national holiday. The yen was quoted at 144.50 yen in London and 144.50 yen in New York.
 
Pound Falls From Tuesday
The pound fell against the dollar. It cost $1.5425 for one pound in London, cheaper than $1.5580 late Tuesday. Sterling fetched $1.5460 in New York, down from $1.5520.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's rates, included: 1.9155 West German marks, up from 1.9083; 6.4900 French francs, up from 6.4655; 1.6800 Swiss francs, up from 1.6670; 1.17475 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17625, and 1,402.00 Italian lire, up from 1,394.875.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Tuesday's rates, included: 1.9185 West German marks, up from 1.8965; 1.6785 Swiss francs, up from 1.6545; 6.4925 French francs, up from 6.4300; 2.1630 Dutch guilders, up from 2.1290; 1.1750 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1735, and 1,403.25 Italian lire, up from 1,382.40.
Gold fell in London to $361.25 an ounce from late Tuesday's $362. In Zurich, gold closed at $361.50 an ounce, down from $362. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 0.72 cent to close at $362.36 an ounce.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Profits of Gannett Rose By 11% in Third Quarter

BYLINE: By ALBERT SCARDINO

 BODY:
The Gannett Company said yesterday that lower newsprint costs and cost controls at its USA Today newspaper helped profits rise 11 percent in the third quarter.
But the increase did not impress newspaper stock analysts. ''Some of the gain came from the sale of El Diario, a Spanish-language daily newspaper in New York City,'' said John S. Reidy, an analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''Some came from lower interest costs.'' 
Those items aside, income from operations rose only 7 percent, and that was from lower newsprint costs and advertising rate increases, Mr. Reidy said. Advertising volume declined, as it has for most of the last two years throughout the newspaper industry.
 
Gain of 5 Cents a Share
Gannett, based in Arlington, Va., said after-tax profits for the three-month period that ended Sept. 24 totaled $83.1 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $75.1 million, or 47 cents a share, for the comparable period in 1988. Operating revenue rose 3 percent, to $827.9 million, from $804.3 million. a year earlier.
At USA Today, Gannett's national daily newspaper, the number of advertising pages in the quarter fell more than 9 percent, to 785 from 865, though revenue rose as a result of higher advertising rates and increases in the circulation rate base for the newspaper.
In addition to its 83 daily newspapers, Gannett owns 35 non-daily newspapers, television and radio stations and interests in outdoor advertising and television programming.
The company showed a higher loss from its share of GTG Entertainment, Mr. Reidy said. GTG produces ''USA Today: The Television Show,'' and other programs.
 
Effect of Summer Olympics
Revenue from both newspaper and broadcasting operations suffered when compared with results a year earlier because of the absence of promotional spending associated with the Summer Olympics in September 1988, Mr. Reidy said. Special promotions of the Summer Olympics last year had helped Gannett's revenues during the quarter.
Broadcast revenues totaled $89.62 million, down from $89.73 million in the 1988 period, the company said.
''The softness in the newspaper industry may be a warning for what is to come in the rest of the economy,'' Mr. Reidy said. ''But so far, the slow growth mode has not spread to other parts of the economy, or even to other media. Television advertising has been doing well.''
Gannett's shares fel $1.50, to $43.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

HEADLINE: SWEEPING CHANGE IN MEDICARE FEES NEARS FINAL STEP

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
A measure that could lead to fundamental changes in the practice and costs of medicine is heading for the Senate floor and final Congressional approval in the next few days.
The proposal, approved last week by the House of Representatives and the Senate Finance Committee, applies only to what the Government pays doctors to treat 33 million elderly people under Medicare. But health experts predict it will quickly be adopted by the private health insurers.
The Administration supports the plan and there is virtually no opposition to the proposal in the Senate, where the bill's backers predict overwhelming approval. 
 
New Standard for Fees
The measure would replace the current Medicare practice of paying doctors on the basis of ''customary, prevailing and reasonable fees'' with a standard based on the total costs of the services provided, including the costs of a doctor's training and equipment and the relative value of the technical skills needed.
Intended to redress recognized inequities in fees, the plan in general would mean that doctors involved in surgery and radiological procedures would be paid less than they now receive, while those engaged in evaluation, like family practitioners, would be paid more. But as a group surgeons would still earn more than family practitioners.
Some health experts say the new plan could ultimately change the practice of medicine by changing the financial incentives connected with certain procedures. For instance, they believe that the proposed change in fees, if adopted, would reduce the amount of invasive and radiological procedures while increasing the cost of office consultation and preventive measures practiced by family doctors and internists.
 
Reduce Test Incentives
It could also reduce the incentive to perform unnecessary tests and procedures and by making compensation more equitable it could encourage more medical school graduates to enter family practice and internal medicine, proponents of the plan say.
Historically, private insurers have followed the lead of Medicare in determining payments for certain procedures and setting standards for the length of hospital stays for certain illnesses. Experts say private insurers are expected to follow the new payment schedule, effectively setting new nationwide standards for the costs of medical procesures.
Senator Dave Durenberger, the Minnesota Republican who is the sponsor of the new payment system, predicted, ''This will very quickly be adopted across the board by the private sector.''
''It's a rationalization of the system,'' the Senator said. ''It says that this country has let specialization and technology get out of hand, and there's no longer a reasonable relationship between the dollars we pay and what we're getting.''
Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, the West Virginia Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee's Medicare subcommittee, predicted that the new spending plan would change the practice of medicine ''substantially, and for the better.'' He said the plan would improve West Virginia's paucity of pediatricians and obstretricians.
 
'Preferred Public Policy'
''We're establishing primary care as the preferred public policy,'' the Senator said. ''We're upgrading practitioners of primary care and preventive care and giving more attention to family physicians and wellness.''
Dr. William Hsiao, an economist with the Harvard School of Public Health, who developed the new plan, said that it could remove ''distorted incentives.''
For example, Dr. Hsiao said that a physician could perform an endoscopy, inserting a tube into a stomach to determine if a patient had ulcers, at a cost of $350. The procedure might take 30 minutes. Or he could make the determination on the basis of a complete physical examination, which takes 45 minutes and cost $75. Under the new plan, Medicare would pay considerably less than it does now for the more expensive procedure.
 
A.M.A. Endorses Plan
The plan is endorsed by the American Medical Association. ''There's only so much money in the Medicare program, and it should be equitably distributed,'' said Dr. James H. Sammons, the group's executive vice president.
But the plan has been opposed by the American College of Surgeons, whose members would suffer the greatest losses in income. Dr. W. Gerald Austin, an college official, said in testimony before Congress last June: ''This approach simply does not take into account the greater diagnostic or therapeutic value of specific services for patients. It ignores the quality of the services provided and it fails to consider other factors that play a major role in determining the value of most services purchased in our society.''
 
Part of House Budget Plan
In the House, the plan was approved as part of an overall budget bill that covers all Government agencies.
The Senate Finance Committee approved the proposal overwhelmingly.
The House of Representatives, as well as the Senate Finance Committee, also approved a limit on what doctors could charge Medicare patients to 25 percent more than the Government-approved rates. Thus, if the Government approved $1,000 for a procedure, a doctor could not charge a patient more than $1,250. The patient or his insurer would make up the difference.
In addition, the House and the Senate Finance Committee set a limit on total Medicare payments by the Government to doctors. But the House set a more stringent standard, which is opposed by the A.M.A. The medical group supports a similar Senate proposal that would be nonbinding. Last year Medicare payments to doctors increased 13.3 percent while Government spending on hospitals, which has been severely curtailed, increased only 3.8 percent.
Under the Senate bill, the plan would be gradually implemented from 1992 to 1994. Under the House bill, the plan could be fully implemented in October 1991, or begin a four-year transition in April 1990.
The differences in the two bills would be resolved in a Senate-House conference committee.
The Physician Payment Review Commission, an independent agency that monitors Medicare payments, has estimated that fees of thoracic surgeons and radiologists would be reduced by more than 20 percent, while the fees of family practitioners would be increased nearly 40 percent. The commission recommended adoption of the spending plan.
The proposed fee schedule takes many factors into account in determining the costs of a procedure. In addition to the doctor's education and equipment, it would evaluate the mental effort, judgment and stress involved as well as geographic differences in the costs of medical practices.

HEADLINE: Bill to Cut Capital Gains Tax Appears Thwarted, for Now

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12

 BODY:
Senators of both parties said today that the Democratic leadership had the votes to keep a capital gains tax cut out of the deficit-reduction package that came to the Senate floor today.
Republicans conceded that they could not muster the 60 votes needed to add the capital gains measure to the legislation. But the Republican leadership did not acknowledge defeatand it made clear that it would try to attach the tax cut to other legislation, perhaps by the end of the month.
Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, predicted that senators willing to support the Democratic leadership now would be less willing to oppose a capital gains cut if it was attached to another bill, particularly if they saw it as their last chance to vote on the gains cut this year.
''My guess is they have used up all their chits on this one,'' he said of the Democratic leadership. 
Asked by journalists if he had the votes to block an attempt to add the gains tax cut to the deficit package, the majority leader, George Mitchell of Maine, said, ''Yes, without a doubt.''
Democratic leaders said they would insist on following Senate rules and would not rule out a filibuster on future legislation. Supporters of cutting the gains tax would need 60 votes to cut off a filibuster.
The Senate debate on its $13 billion deficit-reduction package may continue into the weekend, virtually guaranteeing that the package cannot be approved and then reconciled with the $11 billion House measure before the Monday deadline. On that day, automatic spending cuts totaling $16 billion will take effect in a variety of domestic and military programs, includng a 2 percent cut in Medicare reimbursements.
In a meeting with Republican senators this afternoon, the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, said there was ''still a possibility'' that proponents of cutting the tax on capital gains would offer an amendment to the deficit bill.
Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Finance Committee, had said Wednesday that even if such an effort failed, it might serve a purpose for his side by demonstrating that more than 50 senators favored some form of gains reduction.
President Bush had promised in his election campaign to pursue a reduction in the tax on capital gains, which are the profits from the sale of assets like stocks and real estate. He has said that cutting the tax would stimulate economic growth.
 
Objections to House Bill
The House's deficit-reduction package, passed last week, includes a two-year reduction in the gains tax. But senators, including those who support a lower gains tax, object to the temporary measure approved by the House.
The Senate's deficit package includes a host of tax and spending measures that some senators in both parties would like to remove, among them several provisions that have prompted veto threats from the Administration. While there will be attempts on the floor to strip some of these provisions, senators are concerned that doing so may put them at a disadvantage when they go to conference with the House.
The process of removing such provisions is further complicated by the very specific Senate definitions of what is extraneous, germane or deficit neutral. These definitions have little to do with the commonly understood meanings of those terms. In many cases, measures like the special tax breaks or the expansions in the Medicaid program included in the Senate Finance Committee's portion of the package, are in technical compliance with the Senate rules.
 
Provision on Onions
Other material in the huge deficit package may prove easier to jettison. It includes, for example, a provision stipulating that Congress considers mushrooms an important and healthful food, and a provision defining the properties of the Vidalia onion.
''When Medicare reimbursements are cut by 2 percent while we're debating the definition of a Vidalia onion, somebody is going to be very unhappy,'' Mr. Gramm said, referring to one of the automatic spending cuts that will start Monday.
Some Finance Committee provisions, including expanded tax credits to help parents pay for child care expenses and a measure to make the Social Security Administration an independent agency rather than an arm of the Department of Health and Human Services, have prompted strong objections from the Administration. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, sent a letter to all the senators warning them not to act precipitously.
 
A Proposal on I.R.A.'s
The finance panel's portion of the package also includes a provision that would restore deductions for contributions to individual retirement accounts. The capital gains cut proposal that Mr. Packwood and Senator David Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, have been drafting also envisions allowing tax-free withdrawals of savings from I.R.A.'s.
In addition to the Finance Committee, seven other panels have been trying to reduce the deficit by finding savings in programs under their jurisdiction. As was the case in the $11 billion deficit-reduction package approved by the House last week, some of the so-called savings are based on accounting gimmicks and would produce only a one-time reduction in the deficit.
For example, the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee reduced the fiscal 1990 budget by $1.7 billion simply by removing the United Postal Service from the Federal budget. The panel found another $700 million in savings by requiring that lump sum annuities for Federal employees retiring in 1990 be paid out over two years rather than one.
In other cases, Senate committees added provisions that create programs or expand existing ones:
* Changes in acreage allotments and crop deficiency payment schedules for farmers under a variety of agriculture programs would cut Federal costs. But new commodity promotion programs are proposed, and other programs revised, for a $500,000 increase in spending in fiscal 1990.
* An increase in existing user fees and penalties charged by the Federal Communications Commission and new fees on amateur radio operators, ship stations and mobile radios are together estimated to raise $43 million in new revenue for fiscal 1990. Other changes include passenger fees on both airline and cruise ship departures; new Coast Guard user fees and new fees for the rental of airport slots at Kennedy International and La Guardia in New York, O'Hare in Chicago and National Airport in Washington.
* New fees on producing, importing or distributing ozone-depleting chemicals are estimated to raise $455 million in 1990. Changes in licensing of power plants by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission are estimated to bring in $54 million in 1990.
* Reductions in Medicare payments to hospitals, a one-year freeze on increases in Medicare payments to physicians and a 2 percent cap on increases in Medicare payments for medical equipment and laboratory services would go into effect, as would expanded Medicaid coverage for low-income women and children.
* An increase in the amount that Social Security recipients between the ages of 65 and 70 could earn without having their benefits reduced is proposed. The current limit of $8,887 is scheduled to rise to $9,360 in 1990; under the proposed change, the limit would be increased to $11,700 in 1990 and $14,520 in 1991.
* Changes in the law regulating employee pension plans would permit the transfer of surpluses from overfinanced pension plans to retiree health benefit plans. Premiums employers pay to the Pension Benefit Guarantee Corporation would rise.
* The maximum penalties the Government can impose for violations of mine safety and other occupational safety and health standards would increase significantly.
* The Department of Veterans Affairs would be given an extension of its authority to charge a 1 percent origination fee on housing loans that it guarantees.
* A provision of the 1986 tax law that prohibits discrimination against low-wage workers in employer-sponsored health benefit plans would be repealed. Small businesses complained that Section 89 of the law was too complex and burdensome to administer.
The Administration has also warned that provisions in the House-passed deficit package, including a separate child care measure, restoration of the fairness doctrine in broadcasting and changes in pension laws might provoke a Presidential veto.

HEADLINE: Teheran Journal;
Islamic Street Scene: Add a Whisper of Lipstick

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 7

 BODY:
Militancy, once a trademark of this capital city, appears increasingly associated with poor taste.
''What used to be a challenge is becoming normal,'' said a middle-aged man who belongs to the much-maligned Iranian aristocracy. ''You may even say boring.''
After 10 years of amusing himself beating back challenges to his way of life imposed by the Islamic revolution, he says the stern ramparts on codes of behavior, dress and music are crumbling. 
''I guess our quality of life is improving, although our standard of living keeps sinking,'' he said with the wry smile of a skeptic.
He still goes to work shaved and wearing a necktie, but, he says, no one objects anymore, although neckties, and neatly shaven beards, have long been viewed as unbecoming displays of vanity for Muslim men in revolutionary Iran. His Armenian wine and vodka supplier brings the refreshments to his doorstep with the serene reliability of a milkman, every week.
It is more than just an upper-class rebellion in today's Teheran. Iranians seem to be giving up their need to embrace issues with demonstrative fervor.
Since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini died in June, no one can remember a single rally here against ''satanic'' superpowers or anything else.
 
Fashion Notes
A hint of cosmetics can be spotted on many women's faces. They are apparently no longer worried that they may be arrested or reprimanded.
A visitor back in Teheran for the first time since the Ayatollah died notices that now about half the women on the street wear, instead of the traditional black chador, a long, loose modest dress with a scarf around the head. The face is fully in view.
Head scarves, often maroon but sometimes a daring rose shade, are now worn farther back, showing a large fringe of hair, something that used to be incorrect. And it is not unusual to see a touch of eye makeup, rouge or even lipstick.
All things being relative, for all practical purposes Teheran is returning to a somewhat normal pace.
 
Zipping Through Customs
Since he sternly criticized tedious searches at the airport in his Friday speech of Sept. 29, President Hashemi Rafsajani has produced results: Teheran's international airport has just acquired a green exit door for those who have ''nothing to declare.''
So for the first time in a decade some passengers, at least, are entering the Islamic Republic of Iran without the normally exhaustive searches of their persons and belongings.
A return visitor notices other changes as well. A graceful string of water fountains and flower beds have been added in front of the old Hilton, now called Independence Hotel. Clerks no longer seek permission to telex the United States. The coffee shop reverberates with music -Western melodies to which the steady stream of Lebanese Shiite Muslim militants visiting this country tap their feet.
 
A Visit to the Tomb
At the huge Behesht-e-Zahra cemetery on the outskirts of Teheran, only about 50 people were visiting the $2 billion cultural and tourist center under construction around Ayatollah Khomeini's tomb on a recent afternoon.
The visitors, men and women, calmly surveyed the place. There was no flinging of bodies on the gate surrounding the tomb, no shrieking, no streams of tears, as in the days just after the Ayatollah's death. Just curious tourists quietly contemplating.
 
Speaking of Prices
If there is one subject that draws passion among all Teheranis, rich and poor, it is how to live with soaring inflation.
Having finally made the top of the list of virtually all international surveys as the world's ''most expensive'' city, Teheran lives up to its reputation in a way that would be too absurd to recount if it were not true.
A pack of the local cigarettes costs 1,000 rials. At the official rate of 72 rials to the dollar, this is equivalent to $13.88. An imported pack of Winston cigarettes costs twice as much. A pair of blue jeans averages $333. A tiny two-bedroom apartment in a high-rise on an elegant tree-lined avenue runs to $300,000.
Rice, a daily staple, costs $7 a pound, and meat $10 a pound. For those with fine tastes, Iranian caviar is priced at the equivalent of $570 a pound. and pistachios at $25 a pound.
Iranians seeking to travel abroad cart money over to the black market to get a few hundred dollars for a trip to Cyprus or Turkey. The black market value of the dollar averages 1,200 rials, compared with the official 72 rials.
For the great majority of Iranians, making ends meet has become an impossible challenge.
''If I make 60,000 rials a month, this means a pack of cigarettes is worth 2 percent of my income,'' a public servant said. ''Add to this a pound of meat, a pair of pants and some rice, and you don't have anything left to make it to the end of the month. We are all in debt.''

GRAPHIC: Since the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in June, the stern ramparts on codes of behavior, dress and music in Iran appear to be crumbling. A stroll through the bazaar of Teheran offers less of the atmosphere of a fundamentalist Islamic republic than in the past. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: LAW;
Public Service Fellowships

 BODY:
A fellowship program will be established at the Harvard Law School for students choosing careers in public service.
The Irving R. Kaufman Public Service Fellowship Program was created with a $1 million gift from Walter H. Annenberg, the publisher and former United States Ambassador to Britain, the school announced Wednesday. 
Robert C. Clark, the dean of Harvard Law School, said the endowment honors Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, who is a longtime friend of Mr. Annenberg.
The fellowships will be awarded yearly, beginning next spring, to law students or recent graduates who want to enter public service, Dean Clark said. The fellows will each receive $10,000 to augment their regular salary.
 
Salary Differences Cited
The dean said the salaries of many public service salaries start at about $18,000, as opposed to about $65,000 in private law firms. As many as five fellowships may be awarded yearly, each lasting two or three years.
Harvard also awards summer fellowships for public service, he said, but this program is the first of its kind for postgraduate employment.
The announcement comes as Dean Clark has been criticized for his plans to merge the public service placement office with the general placement office. The office counsels students about careers in public service and helps finds jobs in government and other public service fields.
Dean Clark, who described the merger as a streamlining measure, said students facing high tuition costs and low-paying public service jobs would be better served by economic help than by counseling.

HEADLINE: California Changes Phone-Rate Structure

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12

 BODY:
In a move watched closely by regulators in other states, the California Public Utilities Commission today approved a different way of setting rates for the state's two largest local telephone companies. The change is intended to provide freer competition in the marketplace.
Under the new rules, the rates of Pacific Bell and GTE California Inc. will no longer be based on adding a profit margin to the companies' cost. Instead, the commission will set price caps on the services. 
The change takes effect on Jan. 1, 1990, and is expected to pave the way for new services and lower phone rates.
The change follows the Federal Communications Commission's decision, in March, to allow the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the dominant long-distance carrier, to price its services more competitively, subject to ceilings and floors.
California is the first state to adopt such a framework of price caps. ''An awful lot of states have been sitting on the fence waiting for California to act,'' said G. Mitchell Wilk, the commission's president. While each state's requirements are slightly different, Mr. Wilk predicted many regulators in other states would borrow from the California plan.
''The advance of technology and the breakup of A.T.&T. in 1984 combined to require that the P.U.C.'s traditional regulatory approach be overhauled,'' he said. ''It is no longer acceptable to allow rate payers to be at risk for competitive ventures, nor is it appropriate in light of growing competition to insulate Pacific Bell and GTE California from the efficiencies of a competitive marketplace.''
Both Pacific Bell and GTE, which had sought such a decision, said it would allow them to grow and expand their services while offering customers more competitive rates. The commission's decision came after more than two years of study and hearings.
But a San Francisco-based consumer activist group, Toward Utility Rate Normalization, or TURN, contended it would benefit the phone companies at the customers' expense. Customers will have to pay hundreds of millions of dollars more than under the current rate base, the group said. Mr. Wilk disagreed.
 
Prices Updated Annually
Among key elements of the incentive regulatory framework are these:
* Prices for basic service rates will be updated annually based on nationwide inflation rates, minus a productivity factor of 4.5 percent.
* Local calling areas will be expanded to 12 miles in 1990, from 8.
* Touch-Tone charges will be eliminated for residential customers in 1990. Touch-Tone services will be extended to all California customers.
* Earnings above 13 percent will be shared 50-50 with customers; earnings above 16.5 percent will all go to customers.
* Rates will be reduced significantly in 1990 for Pacific Bell's customers. GTE's rates were cut 20 percent last year and may change slightly in the future.
''Over all, we believe this plan is a big improvement over what we have today,'' Gary McBee, Pacific Bell's executive vice president, said in a statement. Customers get expanded service and the chance to share in Pacific Bell's profits, he said, while the company gets the opportunity to grow.
 
Productivity Factor Criticized
GTE officials were also pleased with much in the decision. But GTE called the 4.5 percent productivity factor included in the framework unrealistically high. ''We think the productivity factor should be no higher than the 2 percent to 2.5 percent level historically achieved by the telecommunications industry in excess of productivity in the overall economy,'' said Tim McCallion, GTE California's director of revenue management. ''Anything greater than that will be very difficult to achieve.''
The company has filed plans for incentive regulation in Michigan, Missouri and Washington, where it is awaiting decisions, and is studying opportunities for filings in other states where it has operations.
But TURN said the new framework would result in a windfall for the phone companies at customers' expense. Pacific Bell and GTE ''just got the door to the candy store opened and were told 'no charge,' '' said Audrie Krause, TURN's executive director. ''We've estimated that Pacific Bell will have an additional $240 million in revenues the first year, and GTE an additional $270 million,'' she said.
Ms. Krause said the commission, in approving the new framework, was ''promoting an unproven economic theory at the expense of California customers,'' who would receive little in return by way of expanded service.
Mr. Wilk replied that much of what TURN was saying ''is just not factually correct,'' and that its concerns do not reflect the vast majority of rate payers. ''They're overstating what the telephone companies can earn and ignoring the consumer benefits,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Another Autumn Of Fiscal Discord

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WITH the new fiscal year 1990 under way, and the United States operating without a Federal budget, economic battles are raging in Washington from Capitol Hill to the White House to Constitution Avenue.
If no budget resolution is enacted by Congress before next Monday on a bill that would cut the deficit enough to meet the Gramm-Rudman target of a $100 billion deficit, ''sequestration'' - mandatory cuts in both military and civilian spending -will begin at once.
Nobody wants this meat-ax approach to deficit cutting, but, according to many legislators, it will take a miracle to avoid it.
The Office of Management and Budget at the White House will have to start issuing orders next week directing the agencies that already have their appropriations to cut them by about 5 percent. Agencies with slack in their budgets might avoid immediate pain, for instance by not hiring new employees. But without a prompt budget resolution, some agencies might immediately have to begin laying off people or chopping programs. 
To escape sequestration, the Republicans may give Senator George Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, a temporary victory by backing off from their effort to attach a capital gains tax cut to the budget bill. The struggle over capital gains has been a major factor holding up a budget reconciliation.
Richard G. Darman, the director of the Budget Office, has been President Bush's point man in the fight for cutting capital gains taxes. Mr. Darman insists he has enough votes, counting the White House's Democratic allies, to win in a straight majority vote. But, under Senate rules, it would take a 60-vote majority to attach the capital gains cut to the budget bill. The Republicans, apparently lacking so large a majority, are backing off from the effort to amend the budget bill. Instead, they mean to wage the capital gains fight when the budget is out of the way.
There is utter confusion over what will actually happen on capital gains. Fights are going on over how much to cut the rate, whether to add or substitute indexation against inflation, whether to make the cut effective for only two years or permanently, whether to get rid of it altogether or whether to extend tax breaks to more people by restoring tax-deductible individual retirement accounts for everybody.
In addition, legislators representing special constituent interests have been lining up to make the capital gains cut a veritable Christmas tree with baubles for all. As a result, the basic principle of the 1986 tax law - eliminating tax loopholes while cuttting rates - is likely to be eviscerated. And, in the long run, the budget deficit will increase.
The Administration insists that the capital gains tax cut would spur economic growth enough that the Treasury would lose almost no revenue and might even pick up some extra money. But economists with Congress's Joint Committee on Taxation estimate the revenue cost of the cut at $67 billion during the next 10 years.
Washington is also seeing another fight - this one between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, made a speech in Moscow that caused currency markets around the world to send the dollar up sharply. His comments raised blood pressure at the Treasury, which has been pressing the Fed to push the dollar down by cutting interest rates. Mr. Greenspan seems prepared to resist, fearing that such efforts would exacerbate inflation longer term.
But with corporate profits coming in lower than expected and signs of softness developing in autos and housing, general economic conditions could cause the Fed to relent and avoid an open fight with the Treasury.
There is a third battle going on - between the Treasury and the commercial banks over the Brady plan for rescuing third world debtors through debt reduction, new bank loans and other options. Citicorp seems to be hanging in and trying to muster wider support for the plan, which is named for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Right now efforts are concentrated on trying to complete a debt deal with Mexico, but eventually there will be a protracted struggle to rescue debtors not only in Latin America and the Philippines, but in Eastern Europe as well.
William R. Rhodes, a group executive of Citicorp who is chairman of the banks' restructuring committee, said that based on conversations between members of his committee and banks around the world, ''I would estimate that as of now, roughly 80 percent of the outstandings are leaning toward debt reduction and perhaps toward new money.'' He concedes, however, that many commercial banks are annoyed with the faltering leadership of both the Treasury and the Federal Reserve on the third world debt problem.
With the United States itself deep in debt, the Administration has very shallow pockets to deal with its foreign and domestic problems and opportunities. So rhetoric is taking the place of cash, policy and leadership.

HEADLINE: Bank of New York and Chemical Post Big Losses

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Chemical Banking Corporation and the Bank of New York Company announced large third-quarter losses yesterday as they greatly increased the reserves set aside to cover possible losses on loans to third world countries and to domestic businesses.
Chemical, whose financial condition was seriously weakened by the loss, announced plans to sell $500 million of new stock. It thus becomes the third-largest New York banking company in the last month to sell stock or announce a large stock offering.
Two other companies involved in stock sales, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation, also announced large losses for the third quarter related to problems with foreign loans. J. P. Morgan & Company has announced a large loss for the quarter, but does not plan to sell more stock. 
 
Chemical Loan-Loss Reserves
Chemical attributed its third-quarter loss of $824.6 million to a $900 million increase in its reserve for loan losses. Two-thirds of the additional reserves, or $600 million, was for possible losses on the company's $4.5 billion of medium- and long-term loans to the third world.
The remaining $300 million of Chemical's extra reserve was for possible losses on loans at Texas Commerce Bancshares, a subsidiary plagued by losses that Chemical bought in 1987 without financial help from the Federal Government. Chemical said the additional reserves were needed because of plans for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to sell loans it has held since it arranged for the sale of other banking companies. As the F.D.I.C. sells loans, Chemical said there was increasing ''risk of downward pressure on the Texas real estate market.''
Since Chemical acquired Texas Commerce, other banking companies that have acquired troubled Texas banks have received several billion dollars of Federal assistance. The NCNB Corporation, for example, acquired the First Republicbank Corporation of Dallas last year, and the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, acquired 20 failed banks formerly owned by Mcorp, also of Dallas, earlier this year.
''The earnings report is not pretty reading, with expenses up, net interest income down and trading profits down,'' said Brent Erenson, an analyst at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation.
 
Texas Economy Improvement
Mr. Erenson noted that although Chemical's actions to increase reserves and sell more stock ''do not significantly strengthen it relative to other New York City banks,'' Chemical is a special case because of its large banking operation in Texas.
Although the problems at Texas Commerce have been a drag on Chemical's profits and its financial condition in the last two years, analysts noted that the bank could become highly profitable as the Texas economy improves.
Excluding the special reserves in the latest quarter, and an after-tax loss of $28.4 million from a revaluation of its interest-rate options, Chemical earned $103.8 million. Profits were $130 million a year ago, excluding special factors like an adjustment to the pension plan and tax benefits.
A large part of the weaker performance stemmed from a $50.7 million drop in net interest income, or the difference between the interest paid for deposits and that earned on loans and investments. At Chemical the interest differential contracted to 3 percent in the latest quarter from 3.46 percent a year earlier.
Profits from trading in bonds and foreign exchange were also lower, with a combined profit of $29.8 million, compared with $61.2 million a year ago.
Non-interest expenses for wages, benefits and occupancy and equipment expenses rose by $40.4 million, or about 9.7 percent.
A bright spot in Chemical's earnings was the nearly 10 percent increase in fee income, mostly from corporate finance activities and fees collected from servicing loans that were repackaged as securities.
After Chemical's announcement, Moody's Investors Service lowered the company's senior debt rating to Baa-2 from Baa-1. The Standard & Poor's Corporation held its rating stable at A-, but warned that Chemical's ''flexibility to manage future unforeseen problems stays limited.'' If loan quality deteriorates or other problems arise, ''the ratings could be lowered,'' S.& P. said.
Chemical's stock, which stopped trading on the New York Stock Exchange before the announcement, ended the day at $39.50 a share, down 75 cents. Manufacturers Hanover closed at $43.625, 12.5 cents higher than the offering price of its new stock and 12.5 cents higher on the day. Bank of New York closed at $49.50, down 87.5 cents.
On Wednesday, Manufacturers Hanover sold 13.8 million shares of new stock at $43.50 a share, raising $583.8 million after payment of $16.5 million to securities dealers led by Morgan Stanley & Company. Manufacturers is raising another $150 million from stock sold to Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, the Japanese bank that also agreed to pay $1.2 billion for a 60 percent share of the CIT Group, a finance subsidiary of Manufacturers.
 
Bank of New York
The Bank of New York announced a loss of $271.3 million, as it set aside $400 million of reserves to cover possible losses on third world loans and $200 million to cover other bad loans. Without the reserves, earnings would have been $118.7 million, or $1.60 a share, up from $54.2 million, or $1.39 a share, in the quarter a year ago.
Bank of New York's profits were much larger than a year earlier because of its merger with the Irving Bank Corporation, the final phase of which was completed last week.
Bank of New York now has reserves covering 65 percent of its medium- and long-term loans, compared with 41 percent at Chemcial, 46 percent at Chase, 36 percent at Manufacturers and 100 percent at J. P. Morgan.
Besides adding $200 million to cover possible losses in its domestic loans, Bank of New York noted that nonperforming loans rose $127 million from a year ago. Banking experts said about $90 million of that increase was a loan to the Lomas Financial Corporation, a Dallas-based financial company that has suffered heavy losses in real estate and filed for bankruptcy on Sept. 24.
Mr. Alpert noted that concern about the quality of Bank of New York's loans was heightened because the bank is an active lender to highly indebted companies for leveraged buyouts and other corporate restructurings. Bank of New York has not announced any problems with those loans, which totaled $3.9 billion at midyear. Bank executives said they expect the amount of those loans to decline quickly, but did not disclose the size of their holdings at the end of the third quarter.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Silicon Graphics To Buy Back Stock

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., Oct. 12

 BODY:
Silicon Graphics Inc. agreed to repurchase 2,360,000 common shares held by the Control Data Corporation. The shares will be bought for $22.60 each, below the recent market price, for a total of $53.3 million. The transaction will cut Control Data's holdings in Silicon Graphics to 702,750 shares, or just under 5 percent of the outstanding stock.
Silicon Graphics said the stock repurchase would not affect its business relationship with Control Data. The company's shares slipped 25 cents today, to $23.25, in over-the-counter trading.

HEADLINE: 2 Bankers Cited In Iraqi Case

 BODY:
Two senior officers at the Atlanta branch of Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, Italy's largest bank, were accused yesterday of fraud and racketeering in connection with the issuance of more than $2 billion of loan agreements and letters of credit, primarily to banks and Government agencies in Iraq.
In a lawsuit filed at Federal court in Atlanta, the bank contended that unauthorized and illegal credit agreements had been concealed from the management of the Italian bank and from state and Federal banking regulators in the United States. According to the complaint, Christopher Drogoul, manager of the Atlanta branch, and Paul Von Wedel, vice president, enriched themselves by an unstated amount while defrauding the bank.
Many of the credit agreements with Iraqi banks, with the Iraqi ministries of industry and trade and with other entities were arranged with interest rates and fees lower than prevailing market prices, the complaint said.
Efforts to obtain phone numbers to reach the two officers were unsuccessful.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Slow Trading; Dealers Await New Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell in subdued dealings yesterday as traders awaited the release of new economic data.
Gold prices rose worldwide, with bullion for current delivery on the Commodity Exchange in New York closing at $363.40 an ounce, up $1.40 from Wednesday.
Many currency traders stayed on the sidelines awaiting today's release by the Government of data on retail sales and producer prices for September. 
Bob Morrissey, a senior trader at the New York office of the Bank of Boston Corporation, said that if the Producer Price Index ''comes in on the high side,'' the Federal Reserve would not have the flexibility to push interest rates lower.
''While the Fed is concerned about the level of the dollar, their major priority is to keep inflation'' down, he added.
 
Cut in Discount Rate Rumored
Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar was undermined by speculation that the Fed was considering a cut in the discount rate, its interest charged on loans to member banks. Lower interest rates make United States investments less attractive to foreigners, thereby diminishing their need for dollars.
Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, said that despite the fact that the dollar was holding to key levels, it was likely to come under pressure because interest-rate differentials between nations had narrowed considerably.
American interest rates currently are about 2.5 percentage points higher than those in Japan, he said, adding that historically, as the spread decreases to less than 3 percentage points, ''the dollar comes under pressure.''
Mr. Flanagan also said that the spread was as high as 5 points earlier this year, ''which had kept the underlying support of the dollar all year.''
 
Inflation Fight in Britain
Separately, the British pound got a lift from comments by Nigel Lawson, Chancellor of the Exchequer, who told the governing Conservative Party's annual conference he would continue to fight inflation with high interest rates for as long as necessary.
In New York, the dollar finished at 144.15 yen, down from 144.50 yen on Wednesday. And it cost $1.5527 to buy one pound, more expensive than $1.5460 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's late rates, included: 1.9075 West German marks, down from 1.9155; 1.6735 Swiss francs, down from 1.6800; 6.4670 French francs, down from 6.4900; 1,399.25 Italian lire, down from 1,403.00, and 1.1749 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1748.
On the Comex, silver for current delivery closed at $5.090 an ounce, up from $5.076 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Jackie Mason's Remarks Are as Inaccurate as They Are Dangerous

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The comedian Jackie Mason, dropped from Rudolph W. Giuliani's New York City mayoral campaign for remarks about blacks and Jews (news story, Sept. 28), may not understand why some people might be offended by his remarks, but that should not prevent the rest of us from understanding how dangerous and inaccurate this sort of pandering to prejudice is. Enough people share Mr. Mason's views to make them more important than one might wish.
His claim that black voters will not vote for whites because of past discrimination is nonsense. Blacks have been far more willing to vote for white candidates than the reverse. They've often had little choice, but whatever the reason, voting records show that Afro-Americans remain significantly less likely to base their votes on race than are white voters. From the Presidential campaigns of John F. Kennedy and Jimmy Carter to the local races of Charles J. Hynes and Ruth W. Messinger, electoral history demonstrates the willingness of black voters to look beyond skin color to substance. The same cannot be said of many white voters. 
Public opinion surveys show that Jewish support for most of the economic, social and political items on the ''black'' agenda remains high, Mr. Mason notwithstanding. The support does not come from Jewish ''complexes,'' but from an informed understanding that democracy can be measured as progress registered by the country's Afro-American population. The civil rights movement wasn't just good for the blacks; it was good for the trade union movement, for the elderly, for gays, for women -and it was good for the Jews. All of us win as the most vulnerable among us organize, fight and win.
The quick and gratifying denunciation of Mr. Mason by Mayor Koch and spokesmen for Jewish organizations, who have contributed to divisiveness over the years with claims about black anti-Semitism, was good to see. Maybe things are changing after all. It couldn't be anything but a change for the better.
 
JOHN EHRENBERG
Brooklyn, Sept. 28, 1989
 The writer is a professor of political science at Long Island University.

HEADLINE: Gramm-Rudman? Let the Ax Fall

BYLINE: By Dan Rostenkowski; Dan Rostenkowski, Democratic of Illinois, is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Now that the House has passed the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989, the deficit reduction bill designed to avoid automatic spending cuts under Gramm-Rudman, I have some advice for the members of the Senate, where the debate has stalled. If you think that the Federal budget deficit should be reduced, the surest way to accomplish that goal is to shelve this legislation and allow the Gramm-Rudman spending cuts to go into effect next Monday.
Every criticism of Gramm-Rudman is true: It is mindless, it represents an abdication of responsibility by the President and the Congress and it sends an awful signal to the markets about our ability to govern.
For all of its faults, however, Gramm-Rudman has one thing going for it - it can result in more real deficit reduction than we will ever achieve from the budget reconciliation bill. 
The spending cuts under Gramm-Rudman, distributed across the board between defense and nondefense programs, would reduce the Federal deficit by $16 billion next year and by $80 billion over the next five years. By comparison, the legislation working its way through the Congress will reduce the deficit by only $16 billion over the next five years and will result in growing deficits in 1993 and beyond.
At the beginning of this year, we had a tremendous opportunity to confront the deficit. We had a new President, a new Congress and a growing public awareness of the need to put our fiscal house in order. Instead of grasping the opportunity, we decided on a ''slide-by'' budget, one that would provide only modest deficit reduction but that would set the stage for a grand compromise next year.
Whatever semblance of budget discipline existed at the beginning of this year's legislative process, however, has all but disappeared in recent weeks. The House, for example, rushed to accommodate budget-busting amendments to this bill. In addition to abandoning fiscal responsibility, the House fully retreated on several important initiatives, like repealing the catastrophic health care program, and started the assault on tax reform by passing a reduction in the capital gains tax.
I have been particularly distressed with the cynicism of President Bush's economic advisers, and his supporters in the Congress, in their approach to the entire debate. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, Richard Darman, has enthusiastically decried ''now-nowism'': the pursuit of immediate gratification rather than planning for the future. The Secretary of the Treasury, Nicholas Brady, has forcefully endorsed incentives to encourage long-term economic growth.
Yet the Administration has substituted ''slide-by'' budget plans, blue smoke and mirrors, off-budget financing and short-term revenue ''surges'' for sound budget discipline. The President's budget advisers have been driven by political concerns, with little, if any, regard for the real consequences of their budgetary actions.
Popularly elected presidents enjoy their greatest power and influence in their first year in office. George Bush is no exception. Yet he is squandering his influence to pursue a tax cut for the wealthiest 5 percent of our population in a year when our deficit exceeds $130 billion and study after study shows the gap between rich and poor widening. What kind of priorities does that represent?
Our refusal to attack the deficit would be comic if it were not so irresponsible. We want the Federal Government to step up the war on drugs, but we are unwilling to pay for it. We can't walk down the street without stepping over living, breathing examples of homelessness. We can't keep up with the bills for a cleaner environment. We hide the bills for the savings and loan bailout off-budget. We have 37 million Americans without health insurance and a child poverty rate that is a disgrace.
In a year when we should have been engaged in a serious debate about the national priorities, the deficit provided a wonderful fog to obscure the hard decisions that should have been made.
It's the sad truth that we have a President who refuses to lead and a Congress that is institutionally incapable of leading the deficit reduction effort. This has left budget-watchers wondering what crisis will force the President, the Congress and even the public to finally confront the deficit.
The answer is Gramm-Rudman. Let the cuts go into effect next Monday. Make them permanent and make them hurt. And when the budget process begins next year, maybe all of us, starting with the President, will be ready to meet our collective responsibilities to govern.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
