HEADLINE: Seoul Vows More for U.S. Troop Costs

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 13

 BODY:
President Roh Tae Woo says that South Korea will increase its share of the cost of stationing American military forces here as it grows stronger economically, but that a cutback of those forces should not be considered now.
In an interview on Thursday before his departure on Sunday for Washington, where he is to meet with President Bush and address Congress, Mr. Roh said he was confident that those calling for a cutback of the 44,000 American troops in South Korea represented only a minority in both South Korea and the United States.
''The United States troops in Korea not only defend South Korea against a possible attack from North Korea,'' Mr. Roh said. ''But they are an important factor in the overall military balance of power in northeast Asia. There can be a slight modification as time goes by, but the general level of the American presence is not a subject for any possible change.'' 
Mr. Roh's visit to the United States, and especially his speech in Congress, is regarded in both Seoul and Washington as an important milestone for South Korea's drive to improve its reputation for stability and openness after its uneasy transition to democratic rule.
 
Changes Began in 1987
A wave of anti-Government protests in June 1987 led President Chun Doo Hwan and Mr. Roh, a former army general who was his handpicked successor, to initiate democratic changes. Mr. Roh then won the presidential election in December with 37 percent of the vote, but the opposition formed a coalition and subsequently won control of the National Assembly.
In other remarks, Mr. Roh defended his record on human rights, saying the arrests of several hundred dissidents in recent months, as well as the indictment of Kim Dae Jung, the country's most prominent opposition leader, were prompted by specific violations of the law and not carried out to suppress dissent.
The arrests have drawn criticism from human rights organizations and some in the United States and have been described as a setback in South Korea's progress toward tolerance, democracy and openness after decades of authoritarian rule. Critics point out that there are now more prisoners in jail on politically connected charges than there were in the final years of President Chun's tenure.
Mr. Roh said his critics overlooked a wave of firebombings, attacks on the police and other violence this year, as well as what he said were cases of espionage and subversion connected to unauthorized visits by South Koreans to North Korea.
 
Political Jailings Denied
''I will say firmly that there is at present nobody who can be defined as a political prisoner or a prisoner of conscience,'' Mr. Roh said, speaking at a conference room at the Blue House, his official residence. ''Only those who committed specific acts have been arrested. I don't think that even in the United States they would be called political prisoners.''
On another delicate matter straining relations with the United States, Mr. Roh said that while in Washington he would ask for understanding that South Korea was finding it difficult to open up its markets to more American imports, as the Bush Administration demands.
President Roh's comments about American troops echoed recent statements by both Mr. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle, who visited South Korea last month, that the Administration had no plans to reduce military forces here.
But privately, many Administration officials say budgetary pressures, combined with an apparently reduced threat from the Soviet Union, make a reduction inevitable in the next several years. Some in Congress are pressing the Administration to reduce the force level.
In Tokyo on Thursday, the United States Ambassador to Japan, Michael H. Armacost, said in a speech that ''there will come a time when it is appropriate to adjust the size of our presence'' in South Korea, but that any change would be accomplished only with the concurrence and support of Seoul.
Mr. Roh's insistence that such a time is not on the horizon reflected a widespread assertion in his Government that North Korea continues to pose a military threat and that it is waging a constant campaign to subvert democracy in South Korea.
 
Increased Support Seen
As for South Korea's picking up a greater share of the cost of American forces, Mr. Roh would not comment about any timetable.
But he said: ''Of course the role of the republic will definitely increase. This is a welcome phenomenon for us, as well as for the United States and other friendly countries. About sharing the burden of maintaining U.S. forces in Korea, we will increase our share commensurate to the increased economic ability of my country.''
By United States calculation, Seoul contributed $288 million in direct outlays to support American troops in the fiscal year 1987. Washington says that recently South Korea announced plans to increase this direct contribution to $340 million in 1992. It was not clear if Mr. Roh's intention to increase the contribution would be above and beyond this amount.
Washington also calculates that Seoul contributes real estate, personnel, tax exemptions and other indirect subsidies that save the United States about $1.6 billion a year.
On political issues, he appealed to Americans to ignore human rights organizations and others that assert that he has backed away from promises on establishing due process and other democratic changes by permitting the arrest of hundreds of people on national security laws.
 
Enemies' Campaign Seen
The President said South Korea's enemies had engaged in a campaign to undermine democracy by sponsoring strikes, street protests, illegal demonstrations and covert contacts with North Korea, with which the South is still officially at war.
He said that while many of these activities had originated in South Korea, they were inspired or exploited by Pyongyang, and that they were worsened by feelings of frustration here after decades of repression.
''It has been very difficult,'' Mr. Roh said. ''With eradication of our controls and suppression, and with the coming of this freedom and openness, all the pent-up demands and desires of the society have come up at the same time. As a result of these eruptions, it has been very difficult to maintain law and social order.''
But he added that there was no turning back and that the Government would continue to support press freedom and an independent judiciary. ''The authoritarian government is the story of the past,'' he declared. ''It no longer exists in Korea.''

HEADLINE: Yugoslav Premier Seeks U.S. Aid

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ante Markovic of Yugoslavia met with President Bush today, seeking United States assistance in making economic and political changes opposed by hard-liners in the Communist Party.
Mr. Markovic, who visited Mr. Bush at the White House, was pressing for American financial aid and for help in obtaining new loans to ease Yugoslavia's $19 billion foreign debt and help steer the country toward a market economy. 
Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the President welcomed Mr. Markovic's ''commitment to market-oriented economic reform and to building democratic pluralism.''
Mr. Markovic told reporters on Thursday that he wanted $1 billion for Yugoslavia's banking system, which is being revised in accordance with Western standards. American officials say the money is needed to prop up banks that have been backing money-losing ventures that would lose Government subsidies under anticipated changes.
Yugoslavia is asking the World Bank for a loan of $300 million to $350 million.
Mr. Markovic has been attempting to lure American investment by outlining to American officials and bankers his proposed changes and legislation already enacted that would allow foreign investments and joint ventures.
The changes ''are bound to bring social problems,'' Mr. Markovic said, including an increase in unemployment to about 20 percent and the threat of increased ethnic and political tensions among the country's six republics and two autonomous provinces.

HEADLINE: Charting Drug Trade From the Skies

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
The Central Intelligence Agency and other Federal groups have begun using satellites to spy on the maze of clandestine airstrips, roads and factories run by the illicit drug industry in South America.
The agencies are also using the military and civilian satellites to locate remote areas under cultivation with drug crops, and they now plan to take on the more difficult job of actively tracking ships and planes that smuggle narcotics into the United States.
Most of the new drug-reconnaissance work is secret because officials do not want to tip off the smugglers as to precisely what they know. But a glimpse of the developing activity was obtained through interviews with Bush Administration officials, Congressmen and industry experts.
An official of a private concern that analyzes civilian spacecraft photos, Mark Labovitz, said special processing can now suppress the images of thick vegetation in forests of Colombia and Peru, for example, and highlight the obscured airstrips. 
 
Mapping the Coca Fields
''Some of them stick out like a sore thumb,'' he said. ''You put the photo on a light table and pick them out, boom, boom, boom.''
A vivid example of the new drug reconnaissance is seen in the United States Drug Enforcement Administration's work in mapping the wilds of Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley - which produces nearly half the world's coca leaves and is dotted with cocaine laboratories, hideouts and some 60 jungle landing strips in the high end of the valley.
The maps are made from the enlarged and enhanced satellite photos, with the aid of the Pentagon's Defense Mapping Agency and the United States Geological Survey. The new charts are seen as crucial to the future success of local law-enforcment and D.E.A raids because they can reveal escape routes for drug traffickers, and possibly for their pursuers as well.
''They need to know how to get in and out, so they don't get shot up,'' said a Federal official, who asked not to be identified.
 
Drug-Crop Fields on the Move
The Upper Huallaga, a lush river valley largely controlled by the Shining Path guerrillas of Peru, has been called the D.E.A.'s most perilous assignment. Some 20 decapitated bodies, believed to be those of local informers, were recently found floating down the river past a new Peruvian police ranger and D.E.A. forward command post in Santa Lucia.
Experts say that by concentrating on areas of drug production and traffic routes, space technology is arming law-enforcement agents with more precise information, helping them avoid false leads or fruitless searches and track the shifting patterns of drug production.
''You want the best reconnaissance you can get as these crops move to other locations,'' Peter B. Bensinger, former head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, said in an interview. In reaction to stepped-up anti-drug efforts, he said, the drug operators are constantly moving crop-field locations, the processing plants, and flying and shipping routes, which makes better intelligence crucial.
Representative Nicholas Mavroules, a Massachusetts Democrat who chairs the House Armed Services subcommittee on investigations and is a member of the Intelligence Committee, said he was ''very impressed'' with the effort being made by the nation's spy agencies.
 
Cartels' Use of Intimidation
''They can make a significant dent in the armor of the drug cartels,'' he said.
Representative Mavroules and others said, however, that technology alone will not end the problem. They pointed to the heavy demand for drugs in the United States and Europe, as well as political and economic factors in South America as complicating factors. They said that even when detected, drug smugglers often manage to corrupt or intimidate law-enforcement authorities all along the line - from the fields where the coca plant is grown to the factories where it is processed into cocaine to the streets where it is sold - to avoid arrest or conviction.
''It's one thing to know there are so many hectares under cultivation, and another to destroy them,'' said Adm. Stansfield Turner, former director of the C.I.A.
Nonetheless, he said, space surveillance should be ''a big help.''
 
'You Just Use More Analysts'
Mr. Bensinger, who ran the D.E.A. from 1976 to 1981 and is currently a Chicago-based drug consultant, told Congress in 1981 that the agency ''desperately'' needed satellite-reconnaissance help, that enforcement was ''immediately limited'' without it. ''Today,'' he said, ''reconnaissance is one area where we're ahead of the Medellin and Cali cartels.''
The military and C.I.A satellites are said to be powerful enough to produce photographs taken from orbit that can reveal the numbers on license plates on cars or trucks parked hundreds of miles below.
Maj. Nelson B. Johnson, a retired Army intelligence expert at Comprehensive Technologies International, a management company in Chantilly, Va., said that converting the spy technology to drug detection was relatively simple. ''All it takes is more people'' to analyze photos, he said. ''You don't have to put up another satellite, you just use more analysts.''
The civilian photos being used are from satellites privately operated by Landsat and SPOT, which scientists have used for years for studying the earth's resources, monitoring worldwide crop production, water resources and the condition of world forests. Landsat and SPOT photos are available on the commercial market.
 
Tracking Poppies in Thailand
Mr. Labovitz, manager of applications and analysis at ST Systems Corporation, based in Lanham, Md., said drug intelligence often entails comparing satellite images taken months apart in an effort to identify new structures and clearings. ''Why in the middle of nowhere would you cut down a forest?'' he said. ''Does it make sense in terms of local agriculture? Is there a house around?''
William A. Kennedy, an analyst at the Earth Observation Satellite Company in Lanham, Md., which sells Landsat photos, said a technique called spectral analysis can detect drug plants on the basis of their color ''signature'' but added that it was not always reliable. Coca plants, he said, are easier to detect in that way than marijuana.
With $100,000 from the American Government, the United Nations Division of Narcotic Drugs is studying the feasibility of perfecting the ''signature'' method, convening a panel of a dozen experts at the end of October.
The deputy director of the division, Bertrand J. De Fondaumiere, said in an interview that the SPOT satellite has already been used to track poppies in Thailand. ''So we're not starting from scratch,'' he said, adding that improved techniques gave the method ''a good chance of working.''
 
Spotting Ships and Airplanes
Congress last year greatly expanded the military's anti-drug role. A result is that the Defense Department is now spending $300 million to help control drug traffic. Early this year, the military made public some of its drug-reconnaissance plans. Lieut. Gen. Thomas W. Kelly of the Army, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told a House hearing that the Defense Intelligence Agency was studying ways to concentrate the nation's assets on the drug war, and he alluded to the C.I.A.'s spy satellites and the communication listening skills of the National Security Agency.
''We think we can take national technical means and divert them to spotting those ships and airplanes that are coming in, and spotting where some of this stuff is produced,'' General Kelly told the House Armed Services subcommittee on investigations, chaired by Representative Mavroules.
To aid the effort, William J. Webster, Director of Central Intelligence, in April created a Counter Narcotics Center, based at C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va. It includes agents from the D.E.A., the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the State Department, the Coast Guard, the Defense Department, and the National Security Agency.
A C.I.A. spokesman, Mark Mansfield, said the center had ''full access to intelligence on international drug trafficking.''
A C.I.A. official, who asked not to be identified, said it was ''very safe to assume'' the center relied on the nation's full range of spy satellites. A D.E.A. spokesman in Washington, Joseph Keefe, said the agency could make no comment on the use of military satellites in the drug war.
''Everybody knows they're up there, and knows they help things,'' Mr. Keefe said. ''But we don't like to talk about it. We really feel it's an important tool, but it's not ours to talk about.''

HEADLINE: Times Square Renewal (Act II), a Farce

BYLINE: By Ada Louise Huxtable; Ada Louise Huxtable was architecture critic of The New York Times and a member of its Editorial Board.

 BODY:
After a six year intermission, the curtain has gone up on Act II of the long-running show at Times Square called the 42d Street Development Project. The latest revised production hit the boards in August.
Act I had focused on a set of mansard-roofed towers of blockbuster proportions, dubious historical antecedents and consummate zoning overkill. A staggering amount of the total bulk of the entire renewal area was transferred to four enormous new buildings at the heart of Times Square. 
These buildings were, and continue to be, the anchor of the state- and city-sponsored plan. The 1983 version by the architect John Burgee, with Philip Johnson, consultant, was meant to transform Times Square into a kind of postmodern Rockefeller Center in fancy architectural dress that gave frightening new meaning to the word ''faux.''
The design relied heavily on the architectural free-association game -words and materials such as crested mansards, entrance arcades and stone appliques - to create the buzz images that substitute upscale marketing for the art of architecture.
Act I didn't play well with the critics; the buildings were panned as superficial, stolid and dull. The idea that a squeaky clean office district would cure the area's manifold ills was viewed as deliverance by death.
The scheme had all the elements of a Joe Orton black comedy: a multi-billion-dollar real estate deal that piously packaged public morality and profitable mathematics under the banner of Times Square cleanup, and an unbelievable rerun of discredited 1960's urban renewal, in which the bulldozer promised relief from rot and drove out everything else with the blight. Hitched to the back of the juggernaut was the avowed restoration of the historic 42d Street theaters, to be funded from the profits of the office towers.
But if the sponsors were dealing in one kind of fantasy, the champions of the traditional Times Square were seduced by another: the legendary image of lights, signs and surging crowds, dramatic displays and nonstop entertainment that has made these blocks a magnet for the world.
The reality of the Times Square area is far more complex: It is the most fragile kind of urban fabric, in a constant state of change. This vital and vibrant place has many lifelines. The sordid and the spectacular are never far apart. Broadway and its theaters are in transition, its commerce and culture are in uneasy equilibrium, while pressures build on the older communities around it.
There is no way the image can be fixed by decree; there is no way the reality can be papered over with signs. It was a particularly choice bit of black humor when, in 1986, the city rushed in belatedly to measure signs and setbacks and ''define'' the character of the area, leaving all the larger planning problems untouched. Legislation was passed that required buildings to follow sign and setback directives. The emperor got measured for a new set of clothes.
Fantasy mistaken for reality becomes farce. The play-doctors, or plan-doctors, decided a ''Times Square look'' would make the behemoths acceptable. The buildings' outrageous size and square footage are still the same. The abuses of zoning and urban design, the default of planning and policy issues, have been subsumed into a ludicrous debate about a ''suitable'' style.
And so, new costumes by the designers. Quicker-than-the-eye transformations, like scene shifts in the dark. Abstract wall patterns, kinetic roof lines, state of the art illuminated displays. More surface skills, less historical malapropism. Shell games, so to speak. Give the architects a hand.
Mr. Johnson now says that the original mansard monsters are passe. This is the New Modernism. The Pied Piper of Architecture has led us from Postmodern Classicism to Deconstructivism, which is what the New Modernism is called in circles where they are busy trying to make buildings look as if they are falling down or rushing off in any direction that denies gravity or structural logic. At the glacial pace of this project, this, too, will go out of style. With luck, we could see none of the above.
Because this is not architecture at all. It is cosmetic window dressing. No one at any phase of this project has understood what architecture is or how it can be used creatively and constructively in the context of the city.
Above all, the 42d Street project is a failure of government, from the moment the official design guidelines were literally thrown away by the developer and his architects and an opportunistic patchwork of investment prizes substituted for a plan. There is still no committed construction for Eighth Avenue, where it is essential to stabilize the neighborhood. To say that all will fall into place when the towers proceed is a real estate act of faith more appropriate to private investment than to public expenditure.
Beyond the developer's promise of acquisition costs for theaters, most restoration and operating funds hang on the artistic, commercial and financial feasibility of proposals yet to be judged by a not-for-profit 42d Street Entertainment Corporation that, a year after its announcement, has yet to name its head. Massive new construction is already transforming and tipping the balance of the city's entertainment and tourist heart.
There will be subway improvements. Some sleaze and crime will move. We may save and sanitize the theaters for an uncertain future. But there is no plan or purpose large enough to justify the huge public subsidies of land assembly, tax abatement and zoning bonuses.
And there will be four enormous buildings to demonstrate the failure of architecture and public policy in New York. They could be an effective memorial to Times Square.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Chelsea Lifetime: 81 Years of Love, Survival and Art

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
This is a tale of principles, survival, love, art and, in the most recent chapter, rock music videos and a tire commercial. But it is especially about love.
It begins long ago and in another country. A young anarchist fled a repressive Argentina by going to sea, jumping ship in New York City. He landed work in the silk mills of Paterson, N.J. There, his best friend was Gaetano Bresci, an Italian immigrant saving to bring his sister over. 
But the sister became involved in a bitter strike in Italy. Troops rushed in, and she was killed. Mr. Bresci put his savings to another use. He assassinated King Humbert I on July 29, 1900. The new king summarily banned the name Bresci, forcing not a few name changes.
So it was that the young anarchist, Joseph Thompson - part Scot, part South American Indian - resolved that his first child, girl or boy, would be named Bresci. Bresci Thompson was born on Sept. 13, 1908, in Manhattan's horrid Hell's Kitchen. The family soon moved downtown to Chelsea, then nearly as poor. Bresci, now 81 years old, was to spend his life there.
On Columbus Day, sun streamed into Bresci's six-room, rent-controlled Chelsea apartment. From a window next to the easel where he paints, the Hudson River sparkled. From other windows, he could see a wide sweep of Manhattan. Bresci claimed good health and an adequate income. He doesn't owe anybody anything.
For 51 years, he and his wife, Mary, lived a stupendous love story, becoming neighborhood legends for the way they held hands and gazed into each other's eyes. But at the end, Mary suffered terribly from cancer. ''I wanted her to die because of the pain,'' Bresci said. ''And I wanted her to live because I loved her.''
He paused, then continued, ''The scales didn't balance.'' Scales? ''The scales of justice,'' Bresci whispered. Mary died three years ago. Bresci sank into depression. Then he resumed painting, and is currently staging an exhibition at Hudson Guild, a Chelsea community service organization at 441 West 26th Street. On a lark, he auditioned for minor acting jobs. Already he has been in six movies, four rock videos and a tire commercial for which he was paid $1,500 for a day's work - more than he made in a month as a department store window dresser, his job for 33 years. ''Life is wonderful,'' Bresci said. Bresci's early memories are of cold-water flats with toilets in the backyard. He saw massive drinking and wives who put flour around their eyes to hide the effects of beatings. Tuberculosis was rampant. Children stole produce for family tables. ''Survival - that's the key word,'' Bresci said. ''And you did it by hook or by crook.''
Food was so short that Bresci's mother couldn't produce milk for his infant sister. Coal ran out. Bresci's father was unemployed. The family was about to be evicted. Someone said they should ask the Hudson Guild for help.
The Hudson Guild was the creation of Dr. John Elliott Lovejoy, who began by asking some boys shooting craps on the street to come inside. It came to include a child-care center, sports and crafts for older children, programs for the elderly and a New Jersey retreat.
The Thompson family was well taken care of. The guild gave them coal and food and helped Joseph find a job. And it nurtured an emerging imagination. Pictures on the walls spurred Bresci to make his own art. Acting in guild productions would much later give him confidence to be an extra in movies like ''Wall Street.''
And it was at the guild that he met Mary Fox. ''I loved to dance, and I wasn't such a bad looking guy,'' Bresci said. But Mary, then a guild social worker, worried that he might carelessly break hearts and advised her female charges to be wary. Bresci retaliated. ''Mary Fox, mind your own damn business,'' he snapped.
Three years later, the two began dating. In five more years, they were married. ''She was a lady with a capital L,'' Bresci said.
With the shadows now lengthening, Bresci takes more time to remember. He remembers the smells of his vanished Chelsea - a fish market, bathless bodies, two chocolate factories, the biscuit factory where his father stoked ovens. This anarchist's son still winces at the vilification when he claimed conscientious objector status and refused to buy war bonds during World War II.
But what a strange and satisfying present! Bresci showed off a rock-music video in which he held an hourglass - a confused old man in a heavy-metal world. He hates the music and huffs that he isn't a ''sad sack.'' But he surely relished the director's compliments.
''If I'd have died that day, I'd have died happy,'' Bresci said.

HEADLINE: H.U.D. Ousts Administrator In New York

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
An investigation by the Department of Housing and Urban Development has found that its former New York administrator, Geraldine McGann, violated Federal ethical standards in connection with a subsidized housing program in her hometown of Island Park, L.I., but did not use her position to enrich her family or political allies.
''As a result,'' the agency's counsel, Frank Keating, said, ''we have taken disciplinary action'' by removing her as regional administrator and transferring her to Washington to a position that does not involve financing decisions.
Mrs. McGann was suspended in June, after The New York Times disclosed a 1984 H.U.D. audit criticizing a program that awarded subsidized houses in Island Park to her son and a cousin of her longtime political ally, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. 
 
Despite Lawyer's Instructions
The recently completed four-month investigation of Mrs. McGann found ''suspicious and disturbing facts'' about the distribution of the houses, Mr. Keating said, but no ''direct evidence that she called or requested'' that her son obtain a house.
The investigation found that in the six years she was a top administrator and a member of the Village Board, she had voted on several H.U.D.-related issues in Island Park, despite instructions by the agency's lawyer not to do so.
Mr. Keating said additional action could be taken, pending the outcomes of criminal investigations by the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York and the Nassau County District Attorney's office. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack F. Kemp told reporters, ''She will not be beheaded.''
Mrs. McGann will continue to receive the salary she was paid as a regional administrator, $68,572.
Mrs. McGann did not respond yesterday to calls to her Federal office. Anthony Cornachio, special counsel for the Village of Island in the inquiry, said he could not comment until he saw the report on the inquiry. In an interview in May, Mrs. McGann denied using her village position to vote on H.U.D. issues, including the approval of a housing lot that went to her son. She said the village minutes from 1983 and last year indicated that those votes were improperly recorded. She said the Village Board had revised the minutes.
The former Village Clerk, Harry Scully, said in an interview at that time that the board members had revised the minutes to ''cover up'' for Mrs. McGann. Mr. Keating said the investigators ''did not accept Mrs. McGann's explanation that her votes were improperly recorded.''
The audit in 1984 said that Mrs. McGann's son was chosen for a house in the third phase of the project, ahead of 120 applicants left over from the second phase, that the son's handwritten hand-delivered letter of interest was not numbered or stamped with the time and that even though single people were ''generally not eligible,'' he was selected, with his fiancee, as co-purchasers.
Mr. Keating said the investigators could find no evidence that Mrs. McGann had taken the initiative to have ''her son put on the top of the list.''
In June, Mr. Kemp prohibited all top-ranking administrators from serving on elective or appointed boards that could cause conflicts of interest with their jobs. Mrs. McGann soon resigned from the Island Park board.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER, 14, 1989

 BODY:

Market Turmoil
 The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent, to 2,569.26, as a late wave of selling swept the stock market. While the point decline was the second largest in history, exceeded only by the 508-point plunge of Oct. 19, 1987, the decline in percentage terms was ranked as the 12th worst. [Page 1.] Was yesterday's market plunge the beginning of a replay of the 1987 crash? Many Wall Street executives noted key differences: Stock market prices are not considered extravagant now in relation to corporate earnings. The economy is stable, not overheated, and many do not expect higher interest rates. But many traders pointed to troubling similarities. [1.] Institutional investors behaved as if the takeover craze had ended. Mindful of recent turmoil in the ''junk bond'' market, they grew concerned that corporate acquisitions would grind to a halt because of a lack of credit. [33.] A series of emergency actions were initiated at the major exchanges in an effort to limit price declines. While the mechanisms worked effectively, some traders and industry officials said they also created unintended consequences. [39.] Although Wall Street was stunned by the selling wave that swept the stock market, it was not devastated. [39.] Currency dealers pounded down the dollar in hectic selling. In New York, the dollar closed at 142.05 yen, down from 144.15. [43.] A ''flight to quality'' sent prices of Treasury securities soaring and yields plunging. The yield on the Treasury's bellwether long-term bond fell to 7.86 percent, its lowest since Aug. 2. [36.] Orange juice futures plunged on word that Brazilian producers planned to cut the export price. [43.]
 
Economy
 The Senate leadership agreed to postpone a fight over cutting the capital gains tax and to strip from their deficit reduction plan several poppular meaures. [1.] Producer prices jumped 0.9 percent in September after three straight declines, arousing fears of a return to worrisome inflation levels. The surge was mainly because of increases for energy and motor vehicles. [33.] Retail sales rose a moderate 0.5 percent in September, indicating consumer spending was still fairly strong, despite a slowing economy. [34.] Resolution Trust sold the assets and deposits of four insolvent savings institutions in transactions requiring $7.1 billion in Government assistance. [33.] Sales of American-built vehicles fell 12.6 percent in early October after two months of steep discounts by auto makers. [34.]
 
 
 
Companies
 The group seeking to acquire UAL failed to complete the financing of its $6.75 billion buyout. But the group said its banks advised that the deal could be financed ''on revised terms.'' [33.] Talks between Renault and Volvo are the latest sign of growing concern about increased competition in Europe in 1992, the rise of Japanese auto makers as a global force and the soaring cost of research and development. [35.] Warner filed a $1 billion lawsuit against Sony, saying Sony had induced two executives to breach contracts with Warner. [35.] Alcott & Andrews is going out of business, after failing to get its creditors' support for a 90-day financing agreement. [35.] The ''Friday the 13th'' electronic virus created high anxiety but caused very little actual damage. [37.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 Since the overhaul of the nation's tax laws, many people have rearranged trust funds and shifted assets, but investors are being advised to also update or write new wills. Your Money. [34.]
 Two graduate students patented a new cube puzzle this week that makes the original Rubik's cube seem as simple as a picture puzzle. Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: Sharp Rise of Private Guard Jobs

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Walk into a store, and a security guard looks you over. Try to enter the lobby of an apartment building and a doorman blocks the way. Arrive for an appointment at a company office and a receptionist politely but firmly checks to see if the appointment really exists.
Security people - or guard labor, as some economists call them - are proliferating today in the work force. In a nation trying to protect itself from crime and violence, they now account for at least 1.6 percent of all working Americans, double the percentage in 1970. And few occupations are growing as rapidly, the Labor Department says. 
''If you go to a sneaker outlet in a not-so-poor neighborhood in Boston, there will be three private guards,'' said Richard Freeman, a Harvard University labor economist. ''We are employing many people who are essentially not producing anything.''
 
Drag on Productivity
 The drag on productivity is the most obvious impact of employing so many people for security. The sales clerks in the Boston shoe store have to sell more shoes to pay the salaries of the guards, who do not contribute to the store's income by selling any shoes themselves.
Less noticeably, as the number of security people grows, there is a drop in the nation's median wage level - a measure of how well people can live. While the median weekly wage for all workers is now $385, the median for the nation's privately employed guards is only $273 for a 35- or 40-hour week, the Labor Department reports. Many work fewer hours. Of course, the boom in guard jobs has a positive side: without it, the unemployment rate might be a quarter of a percentage point higher than its present level of 5.2 percent, economists say. Some 1.2 million people work in the private sector as security guards, and most lack the skills to obtain other, better-paying jobs, said Robert McCrie, publisher of Security Letter, an industry newsletter.
But the big economic issue is whether the money spent on security is being wasted. Would the nation be wealthier if at least part of the huge outlay for guards' wages was diverted to other investments? So far, the answer given by consumers and business people is no. They have decided, in effect, that the level of crime and vandalism in the United States justifies the rising outlay for guard labor simply to preserve existing goods and other wealth.
 
No Clear-Cut Statistical Data
 That decision is not based on clear-cut statististical data. The National Association of Retail Merchants, for example, reported that store theft did indeed grow more slowly last year than in earlier years - leveling off at $1.96 in missing merchandise for every $100 sold. But the greater use of guards was probably not the only reason for the improvement, said Alice Bird McCord, the association's vice president.
''It is probably related to more guards, but there are other factors as well,'' she said. These include sales clerks trained to spot potential shoplifters, computerized cash registers that keep close track of inventory, television monitors and merchandise displayed in ways that make theft more difficult, she said.
If, in fact, too much is being invested in wages for security guards - either because there are other ways to deal with crime or because there is not as much crime as consumers and business people perceive - then some of the money now being spent on these payrolls could be diverted into building factories and machinery that create new wealth.
 
Some See Overspending
 Some experts believe the nation is overspending for security guards, among them Lawrence W. Sherman, a professor of criminology at the University of Maryland and a crime control consultant.
Mr. Sherman noted, for example, that apartment house owners sometimes employ two or three doormen on each shift, although one might be sufficient to prevent crime. The landlords do this, he said, to protect themselves against negligence suits brought by tenants who have been mugged and who might maintain that the crime would not have occurred if more doormen had been on duty. Juries have ruled in favor of such tenants, particularly if other landlords on the block employed, say, two doormen, while the mugged tenant's building had only one.
''When some people have more security than others, it raises the perceived standard of security in the eyes of juries,'' Mr. Sherman said.
The whole issue is clouded by another problem: No one knows what the actual outlay is because the data are too vague. The Labor Department, for example, counts 1.8 million people, in a work force of 115 million, who are employed by the private sector or government as guards, bouncers, detectives, police officers, prison guards and patrollers of shopping malls, schools, airports and even golf courses.
 
Growth of 14% - Plus - Since '84
 This corps has grown by 14 percent since 1984. But it does not include the tens of thousands of doormen, receptionists and even clerks whose tasks more and more include security. And finally, the Labor Department does not count as security personnel the more than 70,000 people who install home and office burglar alarms and video monitors.
Whatever the totals are, the growing employment is changing the way crime is fought. Most of the growth in security personnel has come in the private sector, chiefly among companies like Pinkerton's Inc., owned by CPP Security Service, and Wells Fargo Guard Services, a Borg-Warner Corporation unit, that provide guard service under contract. State and local police forces, once the backbone of crime prevention, have grown only slightly in the 1980's.
The nation, in effect, is putting less emphasis on controlling crime for everyone - the job of publicly employed police officers - and more emphasis on private police officers who carve out secure zones for those who pay for such protection.
''We are securing more and more private space and putting less effort into securing public space,'' Mr. Sherman said.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Show A Sharp Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
After three straight declines, prices at the producer level surged nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, mainly because of increases for energy and motor vehicles.
The jump, reported by the Labor Department today, exceeded any since January, when a 1.1 percent increase in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods aroused fears of a return to worrisome inflation levels.
The latest rise, which was at the high end of the range of expectations, was considered a factor in the weakness of the stock market, where prices plunged late in the day. The dollar was initially buoyed by the producer price data, but it fell sharply late in the day as traders reacted to the stock market's drop. 
 
Differing Assessments
 Economists were divided in their assessment of the price data: some were reassured about inflation when they looked beneath the surface while others were not. But there was widespread agreement that the latest figures reduced the chances that the Federal Reserve would soon make additional moves to push interest rates lower.
Hopes for a further easing of credit, a process that seems to have been all but suspended since July, seemed to improve last Friday when the Government reported a startlingly large 103,000 drop in factory jobs for September.
Today's figures are thought likely to confirm the Fed's presumed caution about further credit-easing, a caution grounded not only in the insistence of the Fed on keeping inflation in check but in asserting its independence in the face of challenges from both Congress and the Bush Administration.
One of those troubled by the September price figures was Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''They're disconcerting, to say the least,'' he said, noting that capital equipment jumped a full 1 percent and that 17 of the 24 capital items rose in price, while only four fell and three were unchanged.
He also pointed out that finished goods excluding the volatile food and energy sectors climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, the biggest increase of the year.
But others took some comfort in the fact that price increases for energy and motor vehicles accounted for nearly all of the September jump.
 
'Only Two Bad Guys'
 ''This report was only superficially bad,'' said William C. Melton, chief economist at I.D.S. Financial Services in Minneapolis. Terming energy and vehicles the ''only two bad guys,'' he added that the price jump for vehicles was mainly related to the timing of clearances at the end of the model year while the price of oil could well fall again in coming months.
The Fed confronts ''no serious inflation problems,'' Mr. Melton contended, though he did observe that there was more inflation pressure at the consumer level than was showing up with the gauges that cover prices received by domestic producers. Unlike the Consumer Price Index, 54 percent of which is composed of services, the producer indexes have no direct service component at all.
The September consumer index, which is expected by many analysts to rise by four-tenths of 1 percent, is to be published on Thursday.
 
Statistical Fluke Seen
 Daniel Fell, an analyst at Carroll McEntee & McGinley Inc., seemed neither worried nor complacent about the inflation report. He said that while ''this tells us that inflation is coming back into the picture,'' comfort could be taken in that last month's 3.8 percent climb in passenger car prices was a statistical fluke.
Car makers sought to clear inventories of 1989 models earlier than usual this year, with the main downward pressure on the index occurring in July. A relatively modest five-tenths of 1 percent actual decline for September was thus transformed into a big statistical rise when seasonal adjustment factors - assuming a much larger decline - were applied.
The two indexes that track prices at the intermediate and crude stages of production also presented mixed signals today. Intermediate goods rose four-tenths of 1 percent after three slightly smaller declines, while crude goods rose 1.1 percent after a 1.9 percent drop in August.
In the production of a suit of clothes, a finished good, the intermediate stage would be a bolt of cloth and the crude stage would be raw wool or cotton.
 
Offset by Drop in Food
 The price index for finished goods, which rebounded to its May level, indicated that the jump in car prices and the 6.5 percent climb in energy prices were slightly offset by a drop of six-tenths of 1 percent for food. Prices turned down for beef and veal, pork, fish and pasta, while declines accelerated for fresh and dried vegetables and processed turkeys. Prices turned up for processed chickens, roasted coffee and shortening and cooking oils.
Among intermediate goods, energy provided most of the lift, but durable manufacturing materials - with copper and brass mill shapes up about 8 percent - rose four-tenths of 1 percent while nondurable materials eased by three-tenths of 1 percent.
In the crude sector, oil rose by 5 percent after a 10.5 percent drop in August, while food prices fell despite an 18 percent leap for chickens.
For the third quarter, the finished goods index rose at an annual rate of four-tenths of 1 percent, down sharply from the 5.1 percent rate in the second quarter and the 10.2 percent rate for the January-March period.

HEADLINE: Group Fails To Finish UAL Deal

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The group seeking to acquire the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said yesterday that it had failed to complete the financing of its $6.75 billion buyout. But the group said its banks had advised that the deal could be financed ''on revised terms.''
The announcement by the group, which includes United's pilots' union, UAL executives and British Airways P.L.C., helped bring on a plunge in the stock market yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange halted trading of UAL stock shortly after 3 P.M. While the stock was down $5.50 a share, to $279.75, at the halt of trading, the West Coast brokerage firm Jefferies & Company, which trades stock after the markets close in New York, said UAL stock was trading at $230 a share in London, down more than $55, late yesterday. The buyout price is $300 a share. The stock traded below $120 a share in early June before a bidding war began. 
 
Pressure on Other Deals
 The problems with financing and the sharp drop in the market could put pressure on buyout proposals like Donald J. Trump's offer to buy the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, for $120 a share. Jefferies said AMR stock was trading at $81 share in after-hours markets yesterday, down from $98.625 at closing on the New York Stock Exchange.
Financial advisers to unions and Wall Street analysts said several factors about financing the UAL deal troubled potential lenders, particularly the Japanese. One was fierce opposition to the buyout by the machinists' union at United Airlines, which has argued that the buyout would put UAL too heavily in debt, that it had been based on overly optimistic projections and that it could threaten the viability of the union's pension plans.
 
Tough Negotiations
 Another factor, they said, was the tough stance taken by UAL management in negotiating with lender banks on interest rates and terms for the financing. A third was attempts in Congress and the Administration to put more controls on leveraged buyouts.
The UAL buyout appeared to be moving toward completion until two days ago, when the machinists asked the Labor Department to review the proposed deal.
The buyout group had a letter of commitment that Citibank and the Chase Manhattan Bank had agreed to provide $3 billion in financing for the transaction and that they would make their best efforts to secure an additional $4.2 billion.
Owen Dowd, a senior vice president with Oppenheimer & Company who has followed the airline buyouts, said he thought the buyout group, the Airline Acquisition Corporation, could still complete the financing of more than $7.2 billion.
He said, however, that the group would have to agree to higher interest rates and would probably have to scale back the fees for its investment bankers, attorneys and advisers.
Brian Freeman, the financial adviser to the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers at United, said some Japanese lenders had called John Peterpaul, a vice president of the union, to consult with him about the buyout.
 
Seeking a New Contract
 In addition to asking the Labor Department to review the deal, the machinists' union has asked UAL to open talks on a new contract.
Mr. Peterpaul has warned that the transaction, which would give the pilots' union and nonunionized employees 75 percent of the stock and a large voice in the company, could lead to labor unrest.
An arbitrager who has followed the UAL transaction said strong opposition by the machinists had made potential Japanese investors nervous. The arbitrager, who asked not to be identified, also said the tough position on interest rates might have backfired because it had postponed closing the agreements.
 
Banks Grow Nervous
 Mr. Dowd said attempts by some members of Congress to push through legislation that would let the Department of Transportation to review buyouts before completion had also made banks nervous.
He also cited recent actions and speeches by Samuel K. Skinner, the Secretary of Transportation, who has expressed concern that large debt could force carriers to cut back on maintenance.
It did not help UAL's case that British Airways was putting up $750 million, or more than 75 percent, of the equity in the deal. Mr. Skinner has also expressed concern about the influence that foreign carriers could wield over United States airlines.
 
'Adverse Changes'
 In a statement issued yesterday, the Airline Acquisition Corporation said the inability by the banks to raise the money stemmed from ''adverse changes in the market for this transaction, as presently structured.''
Sandy Gardiner, a spokesman for British Airways, said, ''We are still confident that the acquisition bid will be put together.''
If the group should falter, Marvin Davis, the Los Angeles financier who was a rival bidder, has offered to pay $300 a share as a backup bid.
But Mr. Davis has conceded that the pilot-management group's bid was worth up to $350 a share because the pilots have agreed to grant $250 million a year in concessions in return for a stake in the company through an employee stock ownership plan. Mr. Davis was traveling yesterday and could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Davis courted the unions, including the pilots, for support for his bid, but was unsuccessful.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales in September Advanced a Moderate 0.5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Retail sales rose a moderate five-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government said today. Analysts said the report showed consumer spending was still fairly strong, despite a slowing economy.
The Commerce Department said sales rose to a seasonally adjusted $145.2 billion last month after gaining seven-tenths of 1 percent in both August and July. The July figure was revised upward from the five-tenths of 1 percent first reported. 
''It shows there's good, solid consumer spending out there,'' said John Silvia, an economist with Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
''Even excluding automobiles, sales were up four-tenths of 1 percent,'' Mr. Silvia said. ''Furniture, department and drug stores, they all were good sales numbers, and I think that's what we want to see. We don't want to see a recession.''
 
Third of Overall Activity
 Retail sales account for about one-third of the nation's economic activity and are one of a number of indicators watched by analysts to determine whether the Federal Reserve Board's tight-credit policies are threatening to stall out the economy or just slow it enough to keep inflation in check.
Retail sales have risen every month since February, except for June, when they were unchanged. On the other hand, the manufacturing sector of the economy has grown sluggish, partly, Mr. Silvia said, because of slowing exports.
Lawrence A. Hunter, deputy chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce, said the Fed should not interpret the retail sales report as a sign of excess demand overheating the economy.
''To the contrary, price discounts and 'everyday low prices' are fueling the rise in consumer spending,'' Mr. Hunter said.
 
Lower Interest Rates Urged
 He called on the Fed to reduce interest rates and thus induce businesses to invest more to meet growing consumer demand.
Durable goods sales slowed to a gain of six-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Department of Commerce said, following a strong 2 percent gain in August that was aided in part by a 2.2 percent rise in automobile sales.
But the early summer sales were driven by end-of-model-year incentives that are usually offered in September; that distorted the auto sales gain of five-tenths of 1 percent reported in September, analysts said.
The gain of five-tenths of 1 percent reflected higher prices in September because dealers did not discount vehicles as they usually do, according to David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York. Unit sales actually dropped by 400,000 vehicles in the month, he said.
Besides automobiles, sales of other durable goods categories split - furniture and other home furnishing sales gained 1.3 percent while building materials fell 1.8 percent.
Nondurable goods sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent, in contrast to a drop of one-tenth of 1 percent in August. All categories except apparel gained: department stores, 1.7 percent; grocery stores, three-tenths of 1 percent; gasoline stations, three-tenths of 1 percent; restaurants and bars, two-tenths of 1 percent, and drugstores, 1.4 percent.
Apparel sales were down five-tenths of 1 percent after rising eight-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.
For July through September, overall retail sales were up 6.4 percent. Retail sales so far in 1989 were 6.1 percent above those in the first nine months of 1988.

HEADLINE: Logic Behind Volvo-Renault Talks

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 13

 BODY:
Talks between Renault of France and Volvo of Sweden about possible joint efforts are the latest sign of growing concern about increased competition in Europe when trade barriers fall in 1992, the rise of Japanese auto makers as a global force and the soaring cost of research and development.
While analysts caution that the discussions are very preliminary, they do not rule out the possibility of a full-fledged merger between Volvo A.B. and Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, as the two companies are formally known. On the other hand, there would be formidable obstacles to such an arrangement, including possible opposition from governments and labor unions. 
''Suddenly companies have to think much more creatively than ever before,'' said Maryann Keller, an automotive analyst at Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney Inc. ''A combination between Volvo and Renault is quite sensible. There's an awakening in Europe that the old rules don't apply.''
 
Other Talks Taking Place
 Indeed, Jaguar P.L.C. and Saab-Scania A.B., another Swedish automotive concern, have recently discussed possible joint ventures and alliances with competitors. Other talks are taking place that have not become public, analysts said.
''Everybody is talking to everybody,'' said Dagmar Bottenbruch, automotive analyst for Credit Suisse First Boston in London. But in the case of Renault, she said, ''The question is how would you arrange this kind of a transaction; Renault is almost like a government agency.''
Three years ago, when the Ford Motor Company discussed a merger with Fiat S.p.A., the talks foundered on the question of which company would have supreme authority. Karl Ludvigsen of London-based Ludvigsen & Associates automotive consultants speculated that Renault would be the natural choice to predominate in any combination with Volvo because of its larger size.
 
Effect of Trade Barriers
 Renault and other auto makers in France and Italy have been protected from open competition in their home markets by trade barriers, which are scheduled to fall at the end of 1992. As a result of this protection, Renault and others have not been exposed to marketplace discipline that would, for example, force productivity and quality increases in factories. As a result, they have become less competitive internationally, especially against Japanese vehicles.
Sweden, on the other hand, is one of the few countries in the world with little protection against Japanese imports. ''Japanese cars are very popular here,'' said Hans Renstroem, head of corporate press relations for Volvo. Several Japanese car makers are building factories in Europe, which will give them a bigger portion of a market that is already fragmented among many companies.
Presumably, analysts speculate, Renault and Volvo want to share the vast and increasing cost of developing vehicles. Volvo, which lacks a full range of models, builds less than half a million cars annually, while Renault builds about 1.5 million.
''Production economies of scale aren't the answer for car makers, but research and development economies of scale are,'' Ms. Bottenbruch said.
 

 
FORD GETS 5% OF JAGUAR
DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 13 (AP) - The Ford Motor Company has increased its ownership share of Jaguar P.L.C. to 5 percent on its way to acquiring 15 percent of the British luxury-car maker, Ford said today. The Federal Trade Commission said last week that it would have no objection to Ford acquiring 15 percent of Jaguar. Jaguar has said Ford's move is unwelcome.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Cites Sound Fundamentals

 BODY:
Although Wall Street was stunned by the selling wave that swept the stock market in the last hour of trading yesterday, it was not devastated. Some market participants attributed the 190-point, or 6.9 percent, plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average to overspeculation.
While there was froth at the top of the market, waiting to be blown away, they suggested, underneath were a fundamentally sound market and sound economy.
''It was a pig market, greedy,'' said one of the dark-suited men glumly crowding at Harry's at The American Exchange, a stockbrokers' refuge on Greenwich Street. ''There's a bull market, a bear market, and this was a pig market. 
''There was intense speculation,'' he went on. ''You overdid the bullish scenerio to the upside, you went beyond real value. The raiders stepped in.''
Harry's was jammed, the gleam of burnished tassle loafers on its maroon tile floors, at twilight of the second worst day in Wall Street history. In one corner a man leaned on the wall, sagging against his suspenders and staring into his drink.
''The market moved on air,'' said one of the brokers. ''You eroded the real value of these companies, substituting debt for real value,''
''The market may be in for some rough days and further declines.'' a leading Wall Street arbitrager remarked. Traders unloaded many of their shaky stocks to raise money for a few stocks they wanted to keep in anticipation of an avalanche of margin calls expected to go out early next week.
 
Commercial Bankers Busy
 Commercial bankers said they were far busier than normal processing the end of day loan demands from securities dealers and traders in the futures and options markets. Those bank loans are fully collateralized by securities, and bankers said it was too soon to know if borrowers would have trouble providing the collateral.
Another Wall Street concern will be for companies planning to sell stock issues, like major banks that are planning offerings to raise capital and compensate for losses on loans to third-world countries and real-estate developers.
Chase Manhattan Corportion planned to sell $500 million worth of its stock, perhaps as soon as next week. But based on yesterday's closing price of $40, down $3.625, Chase will find the sale much less attractive than earlier. The Chemical Banking Corporation, which announced plans to sell $500 million of stock on Thursday, finds itself in a similar bind.
The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, however, escaped the worst damage. It sold 13.8 million shares of new stock on Wednesday at $43.50 a share. Yesterday, Manufacturers Hanover's stock fell $3.375, to $40.25, meaning buyers of the new stock have suffered a quick loss, but the bank has raised capital at a relatively attractive price.
Optimism was voiced in the business community. Gary L. Millenbruch, senior vice president and chief financial officer of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel company, said ''I don't see any fundamental changes in the basic economy that would cause the market to have that kind of reaction and, as a result, I think it's something that will correct itself over time.''
The speed with which the market fell made it difficult for most individual investors to respond, said Seth J. Gersch, a general partner and director of administration at Montgomery Securities, a brokerage firm based in San Francisco.
At Wedbush Morgan Securities Inc., a Los Angeles brokerage with many affluent customers who make long-term investments, Ann Margaret A. Papa, a retail broker, said that none of the 50 clients with whom she spoke in the last trading hour placed sell orders. ''Clients I've spoken to are not panicked,'' she said.
In contrast, at Muriel Siebert & Company, a discount brokerage that caters to individuals who buy and then resell shares quickly, ''they were rushing to sell,'' said Rochelle Steinfeld, a retail broker. ''It was a madhouse.''
While most of the traders and analysts coming out of the New York Stock Exchange at 11 Wall Street in lower Manhattan yesterday afternoon were inclined to describe the event as a ''correction'' that should give rise to panic, a few did note that it came on a Friday the 13th.
Merrill Lynch issued a statement saying, ''The fundamentals are sound for a solid recovery.'' The strong United States dollar, slowing economy, easing Federal Reserve monetary policy and falling interest rates all will help stocks, the brokerage house said.
But, it added, ''Our one concern is earnings. The third-quarter earnings were showing weakness.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls in Hectic Day; Gold Shows Little Reaction

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Currency dealers pounded down the dollar yesterday in hectic selling set off by a sharp drop in stock prices.
Traders said alarm swept through the currency markets as prices plunged on the New York Stock Exchange. ''It just seemed everybody wanted to sell dollars,'' said Thomas Palladino, an assistant vice president at the New York office of the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank. ''It was just a mass panic.'' 
The intensity of the stock selloff was especially unnerving because it occurred almost two years after the worst crash ever. ''There was an eerie sense of deja vu,'' said Kevin Laurie, manager of treasury operations at the Bank of Boston in New York. ''The dollar reacted to it pretty violently.''
But gold prices registered little reaction to the slump in stocks and the dollar. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, bullion for current delivery closed at $363.30 an ounce, 10 cents lower than Thursday's settlement. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid of $364.80 an ounce, compared with Thursday's late bid of $363.
 
Below 'Stop-Loss' Levels
 Dollar sales bred additional selling as the dollar sank below thresholds that professional traders had designated as ''stop-loss'' levels. In stop-loss maneuvers, traders sell to guard against possibly losing more money in case a market slide continues.
Initially yesterday, two economic reports had encouraged some dollar buying. A jump of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for September and a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales indicated that interest rates would not decline soon.
But the early enthusiasm for dollars was dampened somewhat by unconfirmed reports that central banks had sold dollars to keep the currency in check. By the time trading was done for the day in New York, the dollar stood at 142.05 yen, down from 144.15 yen on Thursday. The loss of about 2 yen was unusually large. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar fell to 144.00 Japanese yen from 144.60 yen at Thursday's close and in London it edged up to 144.10 yen.
The British pound benefited from the dollar's decline. A pound brought $1.5820 late in New York against $1.5527 Thursday. In earlier London dealings, the pound rose to $1.5625, from $1.5520 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.8720 West German marks, down from 1.9075; 1.6420 Swiss francs, down from 1.6735; 6.34375 French francs, down from 6.4670; 1,376.00 Italian lire, down from 1,399.25, and 1.17385 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1749.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.9025 West German marks, down from 1.9068; 1.6720 Swiss francs, up from 1.6715; 6.4562 French francs, down from 6.4650; 2.1465 Dutch guilders, down from 2.1510; 1,396.50 Italian lire, down from 1,397.50, and 1.1750 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1737.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE MOVES TO PROVIDE CASH TO MARKETS

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Seeking to maintain calm in the nation's financial system, the Federal Reserve Board intends to meet any sudden demands for money that might result from the stock market's sharp plunge Friday, a top official of the nation's central bank said today.
''Markets will be able to count on us to make sure the financial system stays liquid,'' the official, who asked not to be identified, said in an interview.
The Federal Reserve's decision to make money freely available when the markets open Monday is aimed at preventing Friday's 6.9 percent drop in the Dow Jones industrial average from causing a repeat of the situation in October 1987.
 
Factors Behind the 1987 Crash
On the Friday before its 508-point plunge on Monday, Oct. 19, 1987, the Dow average fell 108.35 points. This decline, in a market that was already weakening, led many shareholders of mutual funds to cash in their shares. As the mutual funds themselves ran out of cash, they had to sell more shares, which further depressed stock prices. 
As prices fell, the waves of selling that led to the market's crash were intensified by another factor: margin calls. Many investors who had borrowed to buy stocks had their shares sold when they failed to respond to their brokers' demands for money.
In the 1987 crash, the Reserve also pumped money into the banking system, which helped stave off a financial panic, but it did not make known its intentions until after the worst of the selling.
''To calm the markets it's important that institutions know there are adequate funds available,'' the Federal Reserve official said. ''Once the markets realize there will be no credit crunch, we can resume normal business.''
 
Contact With Foreign Officials
The official said the central bank's decision was taken at meetings late Friday and was being communicated to officials in Asia and Western Europe in phone calls this weekend, not only from the Federal Reserve but also from the Treasury and the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Foreign authorities are being asked to take similar steps to try to avert cash problems that could have a spillover effect on markets.
In normal times, the Federal Reserve, the Treasury and the Securities and Exchange Commission monitor financial markets almost 24 hours a day. In this weekend's emergency, the normal monitoring staffs have been beefed up. ''We expect to be in almost constant communication tomorrow,'' the Federal Reserve official said.
The Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, who returned from a trip to Moscow on Wednesday, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the S.E.C. chairman, Richard C. Breeden, who was just sworn in Wednesday, were all in town. None of them issued statements today.
White House aides said President Bush has been kept informed of the developments.
At the Treasury, an official said two senior monetary officials of the Treasury, Under Secretary David C. Mulford and Assistant Secretary Charles Dallara, had been in touch with their counterparts in the Group of Seven, which includes the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Canada and Italy.
 
Outlook for Tokyo
The Washington market followers will be chiefly focusing on the Tokyo and Hong Kong markets, which will open Sunday evening Eastern time and will probably set the tone for Monday on Wall Street.
In Japan, financial executives said they did not expect a sustained downturn in the Japanese stock market, which is the world's largest, though some predicted that selling by American and other foreign investors could initially push prices down.
The executives also pointed out that Friday's drop in the Dow, which fell 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent, to 2,569.26, had one immediate catalyst: the announcement that a group trying to acquire the UAL Corporation had failed to complete financing for its $6.75 billion buyout of the parent United Airlines.
Japan's daily economic newspaper Nikkei quoted a Bank of Japan official saying: ''On Black Monday two years ago all stocks fell sharply, but this time it was only limited to merger-and-acquisition-related stocks. So we believe the possibility of its affecting Tokyo stock prices may be small.''
Some market analysts pointed out that in the 1987 crash the Tokyo exchange fell less sharply and recovered more swiftly than the American markets.
To deal with the current situation, the Federal Reserve intends to provide money for the banking system through its ''open market operations.'' It buys Treasury bills from banks, adding to reserves that banks are required to maintain against loans. The increase in reserves, in turn, frees cash that the banks can use to make new loans.
This is the reverse of how the Federal Reserve drains money from the banking system. When that is its purpose, the central bank sells Treasury bills that the banks buy, therefore reducing their reserves and curbing their loan-making ability.
 
Central Bank's Intention
The Federal Reserve official did not say whether the central bank planned to lower interest rates, which would expand the amount of credit available. But he did emphasize the Federal Reserve's intention not to let rates rise in the coming week, as they otherwise might be expected to do because of an anticipated large precautionary demand for money.
Lowering interest rates, he said, was a ''separate question'' and would depend on ''our own individual monetary assessment based on our individual assessment of the economy.''
In his analysis of Friday's market plunge, the Federal Reserve official echoed a comment made late Friday by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who said that the drop ''doesn't signal any fundamental change in the condition of the economy.''
The Federal Reserve official said: ''I don't see conditions parallel to 1987, when we had a whole set of economic fundamentals out of balance. What we have today is related to the takeover market, rather than fundamental imbalances in the global economy.''
 
Washington and Wall Street Talk
Over the weekend, Government officials were also discussing the market drop with top exchange executives, including Richard A. Grasso, president of the New York Stock Exchange.
The Big Board was not taking any unusual actions, a spokeswoman, Sharon Gamsin, said, because it is confident that it has adequately prepared through procedures installed over the past two years.
But some traders and exchanges expressed concern over the weekend about the impact of one procedure intended to prevent the market's collapse, a temporary halt in trading. And other officials pointed out that the exchanges had yet to adopt some changes that were viewed as necessary after the 1987 crash.
On Tuesday or Wednesday, the S.E.C.'s Mr. Breeden is expected to testify before the House finance subcommittee of Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, which has been in the midst of hearings on market legislation. Mr. Markey wants the S.E.C. chief to reconstruct Friday's trading to determine who did the selling and why.
