HEADLINE: Congress Skirts And May Revise Law on Deficit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Just as Congress completes one of its most embarrassing failures to meet the requirements of the deficit-reduction law, lawmakers in both parties appear to be focusing seriously on ways to change the statute.
Some of the proposals are meant mostly for political consumption. Others are intended to force more serious budget cutting, but even their proponents acknowledge that it may be impossible to avoid the sort of gimmickry that characterized the process this year.
 
Hearings and Strategies
Legislators and scholars disagree over whether the four-year-old law has, on balance, been good for the country. But there is little disagreement on two points: The law has led to a shortsighted approach in which quick fixes and artificial devices replaced long-range policy making. On the other hand, it has held down Government spending, at least somewhat. 
The Senate Budget Committee plans hearings on the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law next week. A group of senior House Democrats is also meeting to prepare their strategy for changing the law.
Some of the proposed changes would exclude the Social Security surplus from the budget accounting. Others would try to put a stop to devices that reduce the deficit only on paper.
Those changes may be acted on as early as the end of this month, when Congress considers legislation to raise the statutory ceiling on the national debt.
The pressure for change was highlighted when the two Houses left for the weekend without completing action on a budget bill required to adjust spending levels to anticipated revenue. As a result, across-the-board spending cuts in Government programs, mandated by the deficit-reduction law, will go into effect, at least theoretically, on Monday.
But experts in Congress and the agencies say the effect of the spending cuts will not be felt in most programs for a month or more. If Congress approves a budget by then, as expected, the spending levels will almost certainly be restored.
 
Bigger Than Estimated
The 1985 law - sponsored by Senators Phil Gramm of Texas and Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire, both Republicans, and Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, a Democrat - was enacted to provide a framework for reducing the budget deficit. It set specific deficit targets for each fiscal year until 1991, when no deficit was to remain at all. At the time, Senator Rudman called the measure ''a bad idea whose time has come.''
But because the size of the deficit was vastly underestimated when the law was passed, the original goal proved unattainable. In 1987, Congress revised the law to stretch out the targets until the 1993 fiscal year.
Under the law, if enough spending reductions and tax increases to meet the annual targets have not been enacted shortly after the fiscal year begins, spending cuts are automatic, divided evenly between military and domestic programs. Social Security and many programs for the poor are exempt, but most others must be cut by whatever percentage is necessary to lower the deficit to the target amount.
But the targets refer only to the projected deficit each year, not to the actual deficit. Spending cuts are never put into effect once the Administration's Office of Management and Budget projects that the annual target will be met. And while the legal target has been met each year until this one, the actual deficit has proved to be much higher.
 
Off by $24 Billion
For example, in fiscal year 1989, which ended Sept. 30, the Administration projected that the $136 billion target would be met. But the actual deficit turned out to be more than $160 billion, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
Legislation now before Congress would reduce the projected deficit in the current fiscal year below the target of $100 billion. But staff economists in Congress expect that by this time next year it will be clear that the deficit for fiscal 1990 was actually about $130 billion.
One reason the projections are so optimistic is that the Office of Management and Budget has tended to use favorable forecasts of the state of the economy. Another is that once the targets have theoretically been met and the threat of automatic spending cuts is past, the President and Congress often shift spending so it will not affect the next year's target.
Just recently, for instance, a military payday was moved to Sept. 30 from Oct. 1 so it would fall in the 1989 fiscal year instead of 1990, and some payments to farmers were also advanced. Those moves reduced the 1990 deficit by about $4 billion and raised the 1989 deficit by the same amount.
 
Other Kinds of Gimmicks
That is not the only kind of gimmick. Much of the cost of rescuing failed savings and loan institutions was structured so it would not count in the budget deficit, even though that made the bail-out more expensive. Congress and President Bush have agreed to remove the Postal Service and its deficit from the budget altogether. And measures are often enacted that are inexpensive in the beginning but become costly in future years.
As a result, the budget legislation now before Congress, while reducing the deficit in the current fiscal year, would actually increase it by billions of dollars a year down the road.
The law ''provides all the wrong incentives,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee. ''It encourages everyone to focus on the day-to-day funding of this or that program and not on long-term fiscal policy.''
Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee, agrees with that analysis. ''You keep two sets of books,'' he said. ''The official book is based on phony savings, and then there's a real set where you leave unaddressed the problems that are getting worse.''
Nonetheless, Mr. Sasser concedes that the law ''has served a useful purpose in some instances.''
 
'Budget Myopia' Is Perceived
Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist, agreed that the law encouraged ''budget myopia,'' but he added: ''In fact, deficits are lower and spending has been restrained. It's messy, and certainly there's been a lot of evasion. But I ask, where would we be without Gramm-Rudman?''
Senators Gramm and Rudman note that the annual deficit, more than $230 billion and rising when the law was passed, has been cut in half in four years. They acknowledge that much of that improvement is due to an improved economy, but they say their law deserves some of the credit. The rate of growth of Federal spending has slowed significantly, they observe.
Some expensive programs like revenue sharing and urban development action grants were abolished, largely because deficit ceilings had been imposed. And lawmakers of both parties agree that had it not been for the law, Congress would have ordered much more spending this year for drug programs without finding a way to pay for them.
Mr. Gramm said that calling the law a failure because it had not achieved all its goals was like ''defining the success of religion by the number of saints in the world.''
 
The Social Security Factor
Supporters and critics alike agree that the law masks the real size of the Government's operating deficit, the gap between annual expenditures and taxes not earmarked for Social Security.
That is because more money is collected each year in Social Security payroll taxes than is paid out in benefits. The surplus, $65 billion this year and rising at a rate of $10 billion to $15 billion a year, is invested in Treasury securities. It has been earmarked to pay benefits of retired people in the next century and can be used for no other purpose.
Nonetheless, under the budget law, the annual surplus can be counted to offset the deficit. If it were not counted, the deficit in the current fiscal year would be higher by $65 billion, or at least 50 percent.
Senate and House Democratic leaders announced last week that they would propose to remove the Social Security account from the budget law's accounting and to raise the deficit targets each year by exactly the amount of the Social Security surplus. Under that plan, the entire deficit would theoretically be eliminated by 1997.
 
Democrats Seize Advantage
This proposal would make it neither easier nor harder to reduce the deficit in the next few years, since the amount of deficit reduction needed to meet the annual targets in the immediate future would remain precisely the same. But the Democrats used it as a political platform to proclaim their fealty to the Social Security program and to accuse President Bush of understating the size of the deficit.
Although the Democrats said it was not their intention, Senators Gramm and Rudman objected that the proposal might open the way for expansions of Social Security and other benefits for the elderly. ''It could become a convenient pot with which to fund other programs,'' Mr. Gramm said.
Mr. Gramm and Mr. Rudman have proposed leaving Social Security in the accounting until the overall deficit has been eliminated. Beginning in 1994, they would require a reduction in spending in all other areas to offset the Social Security surplus.
Democrats in the House have not decided what changes they want to make in the law. But Representative Panetta suggested that steps should be taken to prevent spending transfers between fiscal years and to require more realistic economic assumptions from the Office of Management and Budget.
But many experts doubt that such changes would make much difference. ''Budgets are like ethics in that you can't legislate compliance,'' said Stanley E. Collender, a budget specialist at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm. ''Politicians will always come up with gimmicks to get around the rules.''

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1609 words

HEADLINE: Town Fights With Neighbors Over Burning of Tons of Tires

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STERLING, Conn.

 BODY:
In this poor rural town near the Rhode Island border, officials say they have found a solution to their financial woes that would also help clean up much of the Northeast: a power plant that burns 10 million discarded tires a year.
Not only would the plant pay nearly $1 million a year in property taxes, nearly doubling Sterling's tax revenues, officials say, it would also provide a regional solution to one facet of the nation's growing garbage crisis.
''The plant is the answer to a town that would have died without it,'' said Trenton Wright, Sterling's coordinator of economic development.
 
Worrying About Next Door
But as Sterling hails the power plant as its economic salvation, many neighboring towns fear the incinerator will draw more truck traffic onto narrow country roads and spew toxic smoke; 10 miles downwind are reservoirs that provide most of Rhode Island's drinking water. Debate rages over the right of one town to shape its own destiny at the expense of its neighbors. 
''Sterling is looking for a quick fix to its economic problems, but they're not worried about what's happening next door,'' said Dr. Jerald Kupperberg, a pediatrician in Foster, R.I., and president of a group of Rhode Islanders who have sued to block the plant.
Thomas E. Steahr, a professor of demography at the University of Connecticut, said there is a conflict between a town's autonomy ''and its negative consequences in surrounding communities.''
 
Poorest Town in Wealthiest State
The conflict here can be seen in different forms throughout the Northeast as local officials struggle to assert local control over development that has a regional impact.
Near Princeton, N.J., the Route 1 corridor is choking on traffic largely because several towns approved office complexes without considering what their neighbors were building. In New Haven, city officials have fought malls in nearby suburbs, fearing that new shopping centers would lure away what downtown stores remained.
In Sterling, the poorest town in the wealthiest state, the argument boils down to economic survival. Sterling, with 2,100 people, has a per capita income of $8,710, the lowest in Connecticut. The statewide average is $14,090.
Unemployment here is 6.9 percent, more than twice the state average of 3.4 percent.
The Revere Prints Textile Corporation mill, the town's largest employer, burned down in 1980. Sterling now has a couple of general stores, two post offices and six churches. The last gas station closed a few years ago.
''We need industry,'' said Ed Morneau, a poultry farmer and greenhouse operator here.
That was the idea in 1985 when Sterling opened a 70-acre industrial park on town land that offered tax incentives to prospective companies. The power plant was the park's centerpiece.
But not everyone in Sterling embraced the plan. In February 1986, residents voted 423 to 368 to reject the plant. A month later, after campaigning by the plant's supporters, residents approved it in a second vote, 513 to 424. #25 Tractor-Trailers a Day This summer, after nearly three years of tumultuous hearings before the Connecticut Siting Council, a regulatory agency, and the state's Department of Environmental Protection, the plant received its final permits.
The $100 million plant, to be built over two years by the Oxford Energy Company of Santa Rosa, Calif., would burn about 10 million tires a year. Every day, 25 to 30 tractor-trailers would bring discarded tires to the plant from tire dealers, bus fleets, junkyards and towns within a 200-mile radius.
The plant would use the tires as fuel to produce 26.5 megawatts of electricity, enough power for 25,000 homes, which would be sold to the Connecticut Light and Power Company.
Sterling officials say the plant will help the town in several ways. Oxford expects to hire 200 to 250 local workers to build it. ''Our lunch business would be outrageous,'' said Steve Zienowicz, who bought Whitford's General Store here three months ago. #50 Jobs, $1 Million in Taxes The plant has attracted other companies to the industrial park. Mr. Morneau plans to buy the lot next to the incinerator and pipe in excess steam from the complex to heat an expanded greenhouse business.
Some of the 50 permanent jobs at the plant will go to town residents, but the main contribution by Oxford will be nearly $1 million a year in property taxes.
First Selectman Robert P. Jordan said the town would probably use the money to reduce property taxes, expand Town Hall and equip its offices with computers, build new ball fields and recreation centers and buy new firefighting equipment.
''It'll be a great boon to the community,'' said Brian Keith, president of the Sterling Board of Education.
Some of Sterling's neighbors, however, have serious concerns. In nearby Plainfield, a town of 14,000 that wanted the plant but lost to Sterling, residents now worry about truckloads of tires rumbling through their streets.
 
Hunting, Fishing, Property Values
''We're concerned that the routes that will be used aren't safe,'' said the First Selectman, Joseph D. Taverna, adding that Plainfield will have to hire two more police officers to deal with the traffic.
The greatest fears, however, center on the plant's environmental safety. People who hunt and fish express concern that emissions could harm lakes and streams.
''People are also afraid it will devalue their property,'' said Rachel Allard, a hotel clerk who lives near the border of Plainfield and Sterling.
Prevailing winds would carry emissions into Rhode Island, where residents fear pollutants could contaminate the Scituate Reservoir, the main source of drinking water for 60 percent of Rhode Island.
''Connecticut seems to be getting whatever good out of this and we're getting all the pollution,'' said Deborah Stein, a 29-year-old mother in Foster.
 
Complied With All Requirements
Officials from Sterling and Oxford say that the plant poses no environmental hazard. Connecticut and Rhode Island environmental officials agreed, after analyzing data on the emissions of sulfur dioxide, nitrous oxides and hydrocarbons from a smaller incinerator that Oxford operates in Modesto, Calif.
The Sterling plant has ''complied with all the state and Federal requirements, and has probably gone beyond those,'' said Mark M. Hultman, an air pollution control engineer with the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection.
Indeed, before the department issued permits for air emissions, solid waste and water discharge this summer, the agency required Oxford to agree to install $2 million in additional downwind monitoring equipment to protect the reservoir.
Oxford officials argue that the plant provides an environmentally sound answer to tire disposal. Right now, there are an estimated 2 billion discarded tires in this country. Recycling efforts have been slow and with landfill space around the country shrinking, experts have been searching for a safe and efficient disposal method.
 
Trapping Gray in Gray Smoke
Using technology introduced at its two-year-old California plant, Oxford plans to install a pollution-control system in the incinerator here that would trap three major pollutants that could be recycled. Steel from belted tires would be sold to scrap metal dealers. Fly ash - the gray in gray smoke, heavily laden with zinc oxide - would be captured by a large vacuum cleaner and sold to zinc smelters.
Finally, scrubbers to control air emissions would spray lime on the emissions. The lime would combine with the pollutant sulfur to form gypsum, a building material. Furnaces burning at temperatures between 2,000 and 2,500 degrees Fahrenheit would incinerate the tires without any noticeable smoke or odor, state officials said.
''I don't feel like we're creating problems for our neighbors,'' said Mr. Jordan, who visited Oxford's tire-burning plant in California. ''There's no black smoke. There's no smell. It's clean.''
Despite assurances from environmental experts, many Connecticut and Rhode Island residents and officials remain wary. ''Tire-burning is an unproven technology,'' said Allan Rydberg, president of the Concerned Citizens of Sterling, a community group that opposes the incinerator and urges more research into tire recycling.
 
'Only Time Will Tell'
''The bottom line is that we're still going to get a lot of emissions from the plant and only time will tell what impact that will have on the people of Rhode Island,'' said Anna F. Prager, senior policy analyst for the Governor, Edward D. DiPrete. ''It doesn't make Sterling the best neighbor.''
As a result of the Sterling plant, Rhode Island enacted a state law last summer than prohibits shipping tires across state lines for burning.
''There are alternate industries -they can't be that desperate,'' said Blanche Fraser, 61, who is selling her house in West Greenwich, R.I., five miles from Sterling, partly out of fears of air pollution.
Not all of Sterling's neighbors, particularly in eastern Connecticut, think the incinerator is such a bad idea. ''They could put one right next to my house and it wouldn't bother me,'' said Willis G. Maynard, the First Selectman of Voluntown, a town of 2,000 on Sterling's southern border that was an alternative site for the plant.
Other officials, convinced that the incinerator technology is safe, expressed hope that if the region's poorest economy can improve, the entire area will profit.
''We all benefit when there's industrial growth,'' said R. Thomas Homan, the town manager of Killingly, just north of Sterling. ''The question becomes, what is acceptable growth?''

HEADLINE: Spain's Prosperity Comes a Measure of Pain

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
Streets crowded with new cars and restaurants crowded with new rich, foreign capital pouring in and stock markets taking off, luxury apartments at Fifth Avenue prices and stylish young people in the latest designs.
After seven years of Socialist government, Spain has been transformed into a collage of dazzling images as a country long known for its dour and isolated way of life has launched itself on a hectic adventure of change and modernization.
Behind the glitter, there are solid achievements. Since joining the European Community in 1986, Spain has enjoyed the region's fastest economic growth rate. In the process, with the middle classes spending as never before, more than 1.5 million new jobs have been created. 
 
Unemployment and Taxes
But another Spain has not kept pace, a Spain that with its expanding work force still has an unemployment rate of 17 percent, Europe's highest, where six million pensioners live on a pittance and dreams of the good life have run up against stiff taxes, poor public services and rising urban crime.
Now, with general elections scheduled for Oct. 29, these two Spains have come into sharper focus than at any other time since democracy returned here in 1975 as Spaniards prepare to give their verdict on the kind of Socialism they have been experiencing.
At the center of the debate is Felipe Gonzalez, who at 47 years of age is seeking a third term as Prime Minister. Felipe, as he is widely known, is both credited and blamed for Spain's metamorphosis in the 1980's.
 
Pro-Business Pragmatism
His critics on the left charge that he has betrayed Socialism by adopting pro-business, anti-labor policies that they characterize as Thatcherism. His admirers contend that by ignoring traditional Socialist dogma, he has designed the development strategy Spain needs.
The victory of his Socialist Workers' Party is not in doubt, because none of the competing leftist, rightist or regional parties seems to represent a credible option. But it is unclear if the Socialists can keep control of Parliament. The main opposition objective is to force Mr. Gonzalez into a coalition.
Polls show that the Socialists, who won 202 seats in 1982 and 184 in 1986, may just win the 176 seats necessary for a majority in the 350-member lower house. But polls also indicate increased support for a United Left alliance, a reflection of worker disenchantment with recent economic policy.
 
Widely Respected Abroad
The malaise at home contrasts sharply with Mr. Gonzalez's image abroad. Latin America's new democratic leaders view the thoughtful young Spaniard as something of a role model. In European capitals, he enjoys wide respect, with President Francois Mitterrand of France pointedly planning to visit here just days before the election.
Washington's early qualms about a Socialist Government in Spain have been replaced by admiration for Mr. Gonzalez's economic and political record. On Thursday, President Bush will receive him for lunch at the White House, a clear nod of approval in the middle of an election campaign.
But while Mr. Gonzalez wants to keep Spain's attention focused on the future - on the twin challenges of prospering in a highly competitive single European market after 1992 and of catching up with Western Europe's living standards by the year 2000 - many Spaniards seem intent on measuring how they are faring today.
''Felipe is looking after businessmen more than the workers,'' said Almudena Delgado de Rico, who supplements her husband's income as a truck driver by working as a cleaning woman. ''He's done more negative than positive things. He's more to the right than the left.''
Yet for many Spaniards, the process of change here today goes far beyond right versus left or rich versus poor. Social habits, cultural traditions, family life, sexual behavior and educational priorities are all being shaken to the point that Spaniards suddenly have difficulty recognizing themselves.
''The old image of Spain as a country of flamenco, bullfights and girls with flowers in their teeth was always false,'' said Matilde Gonzalez, a 25-year-old art historian. ''Spain was always a backward and repressed nation. Today it is breaking free, but it still doesn't know what it wants to be.''
 
Consensus Reached On Design for Future
 In a sense, though, the grand design for the future is already in place. Just 14 years ago, Spain was in the last days of the dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco, but today democracy is taken for granted, with the wounds of the 1936-39 civil war well healed.
By joining the European Community, the country also implicitly accepted the prevailing rules of capitalism. ''The broad lines of the party platforms run very close to each other,'' the respected daily El Pais said in an editorial. ''The confrontation is no longer between models of society but, more modestly, between budget priorities.''
Even the changes in Spanish society are now seen as irreversible. Divorce and abortion have been legalized, while women who once seemed happy to be obedient wives and doting mothers have begun joining the work force in droves. Church attendance has tumbled, forcing the Roman Catholic hierarchy to cede its traditional place at the center of power.
It is therefore a symptom of Spain's political maturity that the current campaign is dominated by the same kind of mundane issues - jobs, taxes, housing, pensions and the like - that are the stuff of elections in other Western democracies.
But this has also meant that the consensus that marked the country's exciting and risky transition from dictatorship to democracy is now giving way to greater confusion. Specifically, what is an economic success story to some Spaniards is a source of intense frustration to others.
 
Gonzalez's Emphasis On Economic Growth
 Mr. Gonzalez, who forced his party to abandon its commitment to Marxism in 1979, demonstrated early on that he planned to govern pragmatically rather than ideologically. He has always insisted that he remains a Socialist, but his point was that social progress would be only possible only with economic growth.
''Everyone who has moved toward a democratic and flexible kind of socialism, everyone who has avoided turning his ideas into a religious code, has been considered a traitor,'' he said in a recent conversation at the French-style Moncloa Palace where he works and lives. ''For example, nationalizations have always been a leftist banner. Yet nothing in history shows that nationalizations bring greater freedom, justice or equality.''
Instead of confronting the private sector, he therefore set about repairing an economy that had been in recession since 1974. The social cost was high. A process of ''industrial reconversion'' forced hundreds of uncompetitive businesses into bankruptcy and put 1.5 million people out of work. At the worst moment, in 1985, 22 percent of the work force was unemployed.
The economy, though, reacted well to this shock. Entry into the European Community in 1986 further bolstered confidence. Soon, foreign investment exceeding $10 billion a year was pouring in, while Spanish businessmen erupted with entrepreneurial energy. Yuppie bankers replaced brave matadors as press heroes and the pursuit of profits became respectable.
Statistics confirmed the turnaround. Spain's growth rate rose from 2.5 percent in 1985 to 4 percent in 1986, 5.5 percent in 1987, 5.3 percent in 1988 and a likely 4.7 percent in 1989, in each case 1.5 to 2 percentage points higher than the European Community average. Less agreeable symptoms have been traffic jams aggravated by the 1.2 million new cars sold last year and a real estate boom fed by speculation. Excessive Consumption Spurs Leftist Opposition Now cecessivcoconsumption is the problem. ''We're growing a lot, but we're consuming faster than we grow,'' Mr. Gonzalez explained. ''And this creates very serious imbalances in the economy.'' Inflation is already hurting the tourist industry, while surging imports have spawned a current account payments deficit forecast at more than $11 billion for 1989.
The Government tightened credit to slow consumer spending in July, although one reason thought to have prompted Mr. Gonzalez to call elections eight months early is that tougher austerity measures may be needed after the elections to prevent the economy from spinning out of control.
But the spending spree of the wealthy and middle classes has proved a political headache, because it has sharpened the contrast between the haves and have-nots and heightened the perception that the ''beautiful people'' from the golden worlds of finance and fashion personify the new Spain.
Viewing the Government increasingly as a class enemy, Spain's two main union groups, the Communist-led Workers' Commissions and the General Workers' Union, organized a one-day general strike last December that paralyzed Spain for the first time since the 1930's. In May, the General Workers' Union ended its century-old alliance with the Socialist party.
Mr. Gonzalez's economic policy has also caused problems among longtime Socialists. ''The party has lost its social sensitivity,'' said Francisco Bustelo, who recently resigned from the party. ''It has forgotten fundamental values of the left, which will be difficult to recover now. Felipe has a major responsibility for this, because rarely in a democratic country has a leader had such power.''
Pablo Castellano, a Socialist lawyer who has also left the party, said he was less worried by the party's ideological revisions than by the authoritarian methods of what he calls Felipismo. ''The party's crisis stems from its loss of internal democracy,'' he said. ''The lines between party, state, government and leader have blurred.''
Many dissident Socialists have now joined the United Left coalition headed by the Communist leader, Julio Anguita, who has made some progress in ending leftist infighting. Backed by the two labor groups, they hope to convince workers that the Government has turned its back on Spain's poor.
 
Conservatives Focus On Taxes and Services
 The conservative opposition, on the other hand, is a prisoner of the Government's economic success. In private, many top businessmen say they hope to see Mr. Gonzalez re-elected with a majority, since they believe that maintenance of the current policy is essential if Spain is to be ready for the European challenge of 1992.
As a result, unable to offer a different economic model, the two opposition conservative parties - the Popular Party headed by Jose Maria Aznar and the Democratic and Social Center led by former Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez - have been reduced to trying to exploit middle-class irritation over taxes and public services.
But while the Socialist platform is peppered with promises that jobs will be created and taxes eventually eased, Mr. Gonzalez is essentially offering more of the same, convinced that only continued rapid growth can ease the problems that have disillusioned poor and middle-class Spaniards.
Recent events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union have even given him a new weapon for dealing with leftist critics. Referring to ''the disaster of incredible magnitude'' affecting the Communist bloc economies, he noted with scarcely disguised pride, ''In our conversations, the Hungarians tell us, 'We want to do as you have done.' ''

HEADLINE: HONDURAN ACCUSED IN THEFT OF U.S. AID

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras

 BODY:
Senior officers in the Honduran armed forces contend that their commander misappropriated millions of dollars in military aid sent by the United States.
The officers maintain that the general, Humberto Regalado Hernandez, treated donated military equipment as a personal gift and sold it to units under his command.
General Regalado deposited the money into a special bank account that he personally controlled, the officers assert.
A commander of one major unit said he was required to pay for fuel, batteries and tires given to Honduras by the United States under its military assistance program. Gasoline acquired under the program was generally sold for about 5 cents a gallon less than the market rate, he said, but units with severe budgetary problems were given much greater discounts, sometimes amounting to 50 percent. 
''We never got any invoices,'' the officer said. ''We just signed a paper, a requisition chit.''
 
Millions of Dollars Involved
The army then took the money owed from the unit's budget and deposited it in General Regalado's special account, the senior military officers say. It remains unclear exactly when the alleged misappropriation began, but the officers say the scheme has been in operation for several years and netted the general millions of dollars.
The officers' allegations have not been made public, but Honduras has asked the United States Defense Department to investigate, a spokesman for the Honduran Embassy in Washington and senior aides to the general said. [State Department officials said in September that they had not heard of the allegations against General Regalado. But the officials confirmed this month that Honduras had asked for an investigation of the charges. The Honduran request was apparently prompted by concern that Congress might cut American aid if there were unanswered questions about corruption in the program, an Administration official said.] The general could not be reached for comment on the allegations of corruption. An interview with General Regalado was repeatedly requested without success through a senior aide in Tegucigalpa, the Armed Forces Press Office and the Honduran Embassy in Washington. Several of the officials said the general would like to be interviewed but did not have the time. Other senior Honduran officers, who are close to the general, said the charges were nothing more than an attempt to smear the country and the general.
The Honduran Army officials making the charges, who asked not to be identified, said they based their allegations on information from trusted friends who had helped create false records for the scheme. The officials are part of a faction seeking to replace the general as the Honduran chief of staff and de facto ruler.
 
Seeks to Retain Command
Some of the officers used to be among the general's most committed supporters but say they became disenchanted after discovering overwhelming evidence that he took millions of dollars from the aid program and is now maneuvering to remain in office after the end of his three-year tour of duty.
Tension is also rising because Honduras' military appropriation, the lifeblood of the army and, many officers say, of the nation, is under debate in the United States Congress.
In the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, Honduras received $41.1 million in military aid from the United States and $74 million in economic aid. It was supposed to get $144 million in economic aid, but the United States withheld $70 million because Honduras did not carry out American recommendations to promote economic growth.
For the current fiscal year, the Bush Administration has proposed $61.25 million in military aid and $146 million in economic assistance. The stated purpose of the military aid is to help Honduras counter threats to its security from Nicaragua by helping Honduras obtain planes and naval patrol boats. A small amount of the money is to be used for training Honduran soldiers.
 
Apparent Snub by Quayle
Senior Honduran military officers opposed to General Regalado say they are deeply concerned that the United States will cut aid to Honduras. They noted that Vice President Dan Quayle did not meet with the general on a recent tour of Central America but did see his counterparts in Guatemala and El Salvador. Instead, the general was invited to a cocktail party.
''That gave us a temperature reading on what the U.S. was thinking,'' one senior Honduran military official said.
Reagan Administration officials said last year that they suspected General Regalado of providing protection to Colombian drug traffickers living in Honduras. The general has denied any involvement in drug smuggling. And Everett Briggs, the former United States Ambassador, defended him. Mr. Briggs said press reports of Honduran military involvement in narcotics trafficking were ''very imaginative and inventive'' and described the general as honest.
Honduran military investigators say that the general's half-brother, Rigoberto Regalado Lara, who recently was sentenced to 10 years in prison in the United States for trafficking in cocaine, told them his supplier was a close friend of the general's. They say that at least one other convicted drug trafficker, also in jail in the United States, told them of having discussed drug deals with the general.

HEADLINE: Eat and Be Wary, Governor

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 13

 BODY:

'Some Shock Value'

HEADLINE: Stock Traders Expect a Revised UAL Bid With Less Cash

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Stock traders said yesterday that they expected a revised buyout bid for the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, to be assembled quickly. But they predicted that the buyout group, which includes the company's pilots union and management, might reduce the value of the bid by substituting securities for part of the cash.
On Friday, the buyout group said large banks had balked at financing its $6.75 billion cash takeover bid. The group's announcement that it would revise its buyout proposal was followed by a sharp drop in airline stocks and then by the stock market as a whole, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent. 
Yesterday, banking executives and large stockholders of UAL said the banks had found the fees and interest rates on the deal inadequate.
 
Japanese Banks Balked
Four Japanese banks were the first on Friday to indicate they would not lend as much money as had been sought by Citibank and Chase Manhattan Bank, the banks leading the effort to provide the financing, said an American banking executive who asked not to be identified. A series of American banks followed suit, forcing the lead banks to tell the buyout group, which included British Airways, that they had not been able to raise the money.
The president of one arbitrage firm, who requested anonymity, said Citibank and Chase Manhattan came up $2 billion short in raising money for the deal. Spokesmen for Citibank and Chase Manhattan declined to comment.
The terms in the UAL deal reportedly sought initial fees totaling about $36 million and an interest rate of one percentage point above the prime lending rate, which is currently 10.5 percent. These were less generous to the banks than those offered for other leveraged buyouts.
 
New Offer Expected Tomorrow
For example, the $3.45 billion in loans that paid for the acquisition of Northwest Airlines carried an interest rate of 1.5 points above the prime rate, said Thomas A. Parisi, a spokesman for the Bankers Trust Company, which organized the lending.
Financing for that deal was significantly oversubscribed, with banks offering to lend $7 billion, he said.
In interviews yesterday and Friday night, five arbitragers said they expected a revised version of the $300-a-share deal to be announced, possibly tomorrow morning. All five hold large blocks of UAL stock and have a strong interest in the deal's revival.
 
Buyers, but No Sellers
They said the previous bid might be replaced with a bid consisting of $260 to $275 a share in cash and some securities, perhaps an issue of preferred stock, to give the deal a value on paper of $300 a share. The securities, however, are unlikely to be worth as much as the cash they replace. Participants in the transaction could not be reached for comment yesterday.
There were indications yesterday of widespread uncertainty concerning the stock's value.
Jefferies & Company, which specializes in after-hours trading, brought seven people into its London office yesterday to trade airline stocks and other issues, but found little demand.
The firm had a potential buyer but no sellers for UAL stock at $230 a share, the same level as off-market trading on Friday evening and down from Thursday's close of $285.25 on the New York Stock Exchange, said Frank Palamara, the manager of the London office. Trading in UAL stock was halted Friday at $279.75 before it could react to the buyout group's announcement.
A block of stock in the AMR Corporation, which has received a $120-a-share takeover proposal from the New York developer Donald J. Trump, changed hands for $81 a share yesterday, down from $98.625 when trading was suspended yesterday, Mr. Palamara said. AMR owns American Airlines. Arbritragers said the financing difficulties encountered at UAL made it less likely that Mr. Trump could finance the purchase of AMR or that the Californa billionaire Marvin Davis could revive his $300-a-share bid for UAL, which has been rejected by the company's board.
 
RESISTANCE AT JAPANESE BANKS
 TOKYO, Oct. 14 (Special to The New York Times) - The group attempting to buy the UAL Corporation had sought to borrow about $3 billion in Tokyo, but it ran into resistance from large Japanese banks, which were worried about the riskiness of the deal, investment bankers close to the transaction said today.
But Japanese officials insisted that their hesitation was shared by many other bankers. ''If the deal was so good, where were the American banks?'' one senior Japanese banker asked.
Some bankers also said they were concerned by the number of big loans they had already made to finance buyouts. ''We are a little fed up with these kinds of deals,'' said Yoh Kurosawa, deputy president of the Industrial Bank of Japan. ''We just don't want to build up too heavy an exposure.''

HEADLINE: New York Limits a Key AIDS Test

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
To the dismay of many New York doctors and advocates for people with AIDS, a key laboratory test that can show whether an AIDS virus infection is progressing is all but unavailable in the New York State, although it is readily available elsewhere.
The test, the p24 antigen test, is the only one in widespread use that directly measures blood levels of an AIDS virus protein. When the level of antigen, a protein that is part of the AIDS virus, is on the rise, it usually means that a person's AIDS infection is picking up speed.
The test has become increasingly important with the introduction or wider use of treatments that are initiated when the virus starts to overcome the patient's immune system. Experts said the test can be necessary for decisions about treatment. 
The New York State Health Department says the test is available through its own laboratory, although it has not licensed commercial laboratories to provide the test because it wants to assure patient confidentiality and quality control. The department also regulates tests for antibodies to HIV, the virus that causes AIDS. But more laboratories offer that test and doctors say it is widely available in New York.
 
State Laboratory Performs Test
The state's Wadsworth Center for Laboratories and Research in Albany will do the p24 antigen test on request, but doctors say the laboratory is inadequate to serve all the people in New York infected with the AIDS virus who might need the antigen test. About a quarter of the nation's 105,000 AIDS casetate.
Dr. Roy W. Stevens, who directs the laboratory for diagnostic immunology at the New York State Health Department in Albany, said the state is thinking of allowing commercial laboratories to do the test, but he could not say when a decision would be reached. ''We are getting the arguments together for the Health Commissioner now,'' Dr. Stevens said.
Clinical data have clearly shown that people infected with the AIDS virus do better if they are treated before they are ill with AIDS. But it can be difficult to know when to institute treatment, which can have serious side effects.
The p24 antigen test, by providing signs that the AIDS virus is growing rapidly, can help with this decision. The test can also indicate when patients are no longer responding fully to AZT, or azidothymidine, the only drug approved for the treatment of AIDS. This has become more important with the introduction of DDI, an experimental drug being tested in people who do not respond to AZT.
 
'Ought to Be Available'
Jay Lipner, the cooperating lawyer for Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, an advocacy group for homosexuals and people with AIDS, said the organization ''believes the test ought to be available.''
''Researchers think the test is important,'' he said. ''Clinicians think the test is of value. New Yorkers ought to have the right to have the same imformation available as people in other states. The New York State Health Department simply has to come to grips with this.''
Dr. Jeffrey Laurence, an AIDS researcher at the Cornell University Medical Center in New York, said, ''I think people are right to be upset'' that the p24 test is virtually unavailable in New York. He said the p24 antigen test is widely used in clinical trials of prospective AIDS treatments and in some cases patients cannot participate unless their antigen levels have risen.
 
'It Is Important to Have'
Dr. Daniel William, a New York doctor with many AIDS patients, said the unavailablity of the p24 antigen test is a real hindrance to good patient care. The test ''is an accepted test,'' he said, ''and when you are making life and death decisons, it is important to have it available.''
''Everyone feels the way I do,'' Dr. William said. ''This is one of the few things that everyone agrees on.''
Officials at Abbott Laboratories in Abbott Park, Ill., which makes the Government-approved antigen tests, said they do not know of any state other than New York that restricts room doctors who warn that with the onset of colder weather, the area's emergency rooms will soon suffer the same dangerously crowded conditions seen last winter.
While no citywide data is available to confirm that the situation this year is comparable or worse than last winter's emergency-room crisis, the experts say that present congestion bodes poorly on the eve of the winter season, when hospital occupancy and emergency room usage traditionally rise. Overcrowding last winter forced many hospitals to provide care in hallways and kept patients waiting several days in emergency rooms before being admitted for inpatient care.
Public-health experts have blamed overcrowding on the emergence of crack use and AIDS as major public-health problems and on rising numbers of poor uninsured patients who do not have access to other health care.
Speaking at a national conference of emergency room physicians at La Guardia Airport on Friday, doctors called for stricter state enforcement of rules that limit the amount of time patients awaiting hospital admission can be held in emergency rooms. They also asked for increased reimbursement to reflect the higher costs of providing emergency care.
''There has been little enforcement of the rules - it has been voluntary compliance,'' said Dr. Mark C. Henry, president-elect of the New York chapter of the American College of Emergency Physicians, referring to state emergency-room regulations that were introduced this year. The rules require emergency rooms to either treat and release patients or admit them for inpatient care within eight hours.
''We need to face up to the fact that this problem is widespread, and that it is caused by economics,'' Dr. Henry said.
Referring to a state plan to introduce universal health insurance, Dr. Henry said, ''if everyone had guaranteed coverage that would be a major step in solving the problem.''
 
'The Worst Delays'
According to one participant at the conference, Dr. Arthur Kellermann, ding problem in New York City and the remedies suggested by emergency room doctors.
 
Five Hospitals Cited
A spokeswoman for the State Department of Health, disputing the assertion that there had been little enforcement of the emergency-room regulations, said that five hospitals in New York City had been cited for violation of the eight-hour stay rule since its introduction.
''We have some hospitals with plenty of open beds and other hospitals that look like they are in a crunch - particularly the municipal hospitals,'' said the spokeswoman, Frances Tarleton.
She said that as of noon Friday, the Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Care Center in the Bronx, a large municipal hospital, had only one available medical-surgical bed, and 23 patients awaiting admission in its emergency room. Meanwhile, another Bronx hospital, North Central Bronx Hospital, had 12 open beds.
Reacting critically to the call for greater enforcement of emergency room rules, Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association said: ''The solution to the emergency room backups, a problem that comes and goes, has nothing to do with the eight-hour limitation and everything to do with an inadequate bed supply. We have to immediately add the 500 beds the Department of Health talked about this summer and start doing other things to address the AIDS epidemic.''

HEADLINE: Picture of Temptations Painted in Garcia Trial

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
One of the prosecution's last witnesses at the bribery trial of Representative Robert Garcia and his wife, Jane Lee, was a Harvard Law School student who worked a few years ago as an intern in the Congressman's South Bronx office.
Mrs. Garcia's lawyer, Ronald P. Fischetti, asked the young man, Cesare Bacchini, whether it was true that he had not made much money working in the Congressman's office. ''No one does in government,'' Mr. Bacchini said. Then he added, with a glance at his old boss, ''supposedly.'' 
In the fifth-floor courtroom in Manhattan Federal Court, Mr. Bacchini's comment sounded more like a question than an accusation. But it capsulized the theme of the four-week trial: whether Mr. Garcia came to care more about money than about the people in the poverty-stricken district that sent him to Washington.
The chief prosecutor, Edward J. M. Little, told the jurors that the Congressman grew greedy. The chief defense lawyer, Robert G. Morvillo, told them that Mr. Garcia was a man who put his constituents first.
 
Temptations of Public Servants
But whatever version is accepted by the jurors, who begin their second day of deliberations tomorrow, the trial presented a clear picture of the pressures and temptations that sometimes enter the lives of public servants.
In his closing statement last week, Mr. Morvillo told the jurors that Congressman Garcia and his wife ''are human beings. They're entitled to have some fun.''
But both sides agreed that the price tag of the couple's life style was often far higher than anything they could afford on their Government salaries. Mrs. Garcia was her husband's administrative assistant until 1984. Together, the Government paid them $120,000 a year.
There were few incentives for the Garcias to rein in their spending. No matter how over-extended Mr. Garcia was, lawyers on both sides pointed out, his banks seemed only too willing to allow overdrawn accounts for this particular customer, who happened to be a member of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee.
 
Loans to Repay Overdrafts
After prosecutors proved that the Garcias ran up bank overdrafts sometimes totaling more than $10,000, defense lawyers quickly said the couple had overdrawn their accounts for years.
In 1984, the couple bought a 65-acre horse farm in upstate New York complete with a swimming pool and a hot tub. They had no trouble obtaining a Veterans Administration-approved mortgage to cover 100 percent of the purchase price. That added a $1,900-a-month payment to their budget.
To repay an overdraft at one bank, the evidence showed, the couple got a $20,000 loan from another bank.
It sometimes seemed during the trial that the trappings of wealth virtually fell into the path of the couple. When they needed spending money for an all-expenses-paid Anti-Defamation League tour to Israel and Spain, Mr. Garcia's lawyer conceded, the Congressman arranged a $20,000 interest-free loan ''between friends.'' The friend was Mario Moreno, the vice chairman of the Wedtech Corporation, the military contractor that was in Mr. Garcia's district.
 
Dinner at Lello's
Mr. Moreno was the Garcias' chief accuser at the trial. When the Garcias took a day's pleasure trip to the Virgin Islands in 1985, they happened upon the founder of Wedtech, John Mariotta. Defense lawyers did not contest evidence that Mrs. Garcia ended the day with a $1,900 diamond and emerald necklace that was charged to Mr. Mariotta's American Express account.
The defense lawyers conceded that the Garcias' finances were often tangled. But they bitterly fought what prosecutors said the Congressman and his wife did about the problem.
The Garcias invited Mr. Moreno to dinner at Lello's, an Italian restaurant on Manhattan's East Side. There, on May 17, 1984, Mr. Moreno testified, the couple asked for payoffs from Wedtech and devised a scheme to make them appear legitimate.
The Garcias' futures depend, to a large extent, on whether jurors believe what Mr. Moreno said happened at Lello's. The defense lawyers ridiculed the tale as the creation of a witness who would say anythed to hear again when they began deliberating Friday.
It is unlikely that anyone who was not at Lello's will ever know with certainty who said what over the dinner table. But there were other incidents witnesses described that provide a glimpse of the way politicians and those around them sometimes operate. Mr. Bacchini, the student intern, played a role in one of the episodes.
Defense lawyers argued from the beginning of the case that Mrs. Garcia had her own consulting business, and that prosecutors mistakenly labeled legitimate consulting payments to her as illegal payoffs. They said she received the payments for work she did for a lawyer in Puerto Rico who hired her for her expertise.
Under an agreement with that lawyer, the jury was told, Mrs. Garcia provided a report on something known as the Caribbean Basin Initiative, a Federal economic development plan. The jury was told the lawyer paid her $50,000 under the agreement.
Mr. Bacchini testified that Mrs. Garcia came to him one day while he was at work in Congressman Garcia's office in the South Bronx and asked him to write the report. He did it for her as a favor, he said. It was not important to get paid for it, he said.
The report that Mrs. Garcia sent to the lawyer was introduced into evidence at the trial. On its cover, it said ''by Jane Lee Garcia.''

HEADLINE: Sculpture for Troubled Places

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON

 BODY:
A strange symbol of hope has been flowering in some of New York City's most troubled neighborhoods. Sculpture.
Over the last five years, dozens of works have popped up and been plopped down in decaying and embattled sections of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens as a result of public and private programs.
They have sprouted in gardens hemmed in by tenements in the South Bronx and central Brooklyn. They have shot up on weed-filled plots alongside the East and Bronx rivers. They rise like vines above the barbed wire that has helped make the industrial cementscape of Hunts Point look like a combat zone. 
They are not made with SoHo and Madison Avenue in mind. The sculptures may be wood fences or thrones or planks suggesting emblems of rural life like porches or cabins. They may be a steel gate that seems to grow, or a huge steel Atlas who seems capable of lifting up the tenement behind him. They may be made of industrial materials and yet, like Bob Rivera's ''Garden Spirit'' in the South Bronx, suggest something almost Edenic.
They never fully fit. ''There were thousands of questions,'' said Geneva McFadden, describing the responses of her neighbors to Gail Rothschild's wooden ''throne sculpture'' on Franklin Avenue near East 168th Street in the Morrisania section of the South Bronx. ''What is it? Is it finished? Are you supposed to climb on it or not?''
If the sculptures are accepted, it may still be with a sense of detachment or distance. ''I just wanted to say how nice these are; they are a diversion for our workday,'' volunteered a truck driver working at the Food Center at Hunts Point in the South Bronx, who went out of his way to communicate his feelings about a sculpture by Christy Rupp of four little bears climbing over an assemblage of file cabinets, and another work, by Terry Lee Dill, in which a large black ball seems ready to break the grip of the yellow and black steel beams that contain it.
While sculpture for these neighborhoods may be invested with extraordinary hope, its success is almost always limited. If the sculpture is too removed from the neighborhood, it moves nobody. If it is too integrated, it loses its capacity to sustain the levels of meaning that give art something more than provincial appeal. If it seems part inside, part outside a neighborhood, it can seem edgy, homeless, as if it had stumbled into the wrong script.
Everyone involved knows that the challenge is daunting. ''This is an area of social anomie,'' said Sigmund R. Balka, the general counsel for Krasdale Foods, the person who set in motion the brand-new Food Center Sculpture Park at Hunts Point. ''People come here and they dump things in the middle of the night. It is difficult to relate sculpture to these locations. The area fights.''
We are not talking about great art here. There may not be a single work commissioned for these neighborhoods that is entirely convincing. But it is apparent that sculpture can make some contribution. After years in which a number of artists have been trying to reach into neighborhoods outside the institutionalized art world, some members of those neighborhoods have begun to reach back.
There are now clearly very few people who are not aware of the social status and economic value of art. People far from the glamour and glitz of Manhattan may know nothing about sculpture; they may not even like it. But they now assume it has something to do with power. And in a place like the Hunts Point Food Center, they believe it can make a social and economic difference.
To this point, however, money has been limited. There is nothing even approaching the scale and ambition of Richard Serra's ''Tilted Arc,'' that roar of hectoring and sheltering steel that the Government removed from Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan earlier this year after bitter dispute.
Some of the sculptures are so slight, so reticent, so wary of hurting anyone's feelings that they almost seem to apologize for existing. Many are so unassuming that they are hardly recognizable as sculpture, even to people who pass them every day. There are few works that try to speak to both the vulnerability and the aggression within a neighborhood.
When they are effective, the sculptures speak so sensitively to an essential aspect of a place that they cannot be imagined anywhere else. They may put an exclamation point on a site, or give it a particular signature. They may become a point around which people gather. ''It may have drawn us closer together,'' said Catherine Jones, a neighborhood resident, of Gail Rothschild's sculpture, which she helps maintain.
Nobody is saying that sculpture can change neighborhoods, although some discussions drip with platitudes about bringing people together, fostering community pride and carrying the torch of art into unfamiliar territory. It may not be the same as missionaries bringing Christianity to heathens, but sometimes the rhetoric does not sound that different. Whether these sculptures succeed or fail, their proliferation has something profound to say about the nature of art - or at least about what people now expect and need from art. For many people who know little or nothing about the sophisticated art world, sculpture has a magical, almost talismanic power.
It can in some sense offer protection to them, they believe, although the sculptures are in constant danger of vandalism. Deborah Masters's cement figures in Prospect Park were destroyed by a sledgehammer by what the police believe to be a group of young people celebrating a high school graduation.
Despite this, sculpture can, they some believe, be a symbol of - and perhaps even be able to impose - civility and culture. In these precarious New York neighborhoods, far from institutions like the Whitney Museum of American Art, where the acceptance of contemporary art depends very much on an esthetic of shock, shock is a fact of daily life and many people want art that can heal.
Gail Rothschild's sculpture is intended as a curative charm. Rothschild, 30 years old, has been artist-in-residence at the Henry Street Settlement for the last two years. Her work, called ''Gaia Earthmother,'' is part of the Artists in the Garden project of Operation Greenthumb, a program of New York City's General Services Administration, which helps communities throughout the city cultivate gardens in abandoned lots previously abloom with dead cars, dead refrigerators and rats.
The sculpture is a wooden throne with steps that rises out of the earth like an Easter Island head. Around the back, like a ring of hair, are 24 medicinal herbs provided by the artist that the 15 caretakers of the garden, 13 of them women, can pick as they wish. Across the street is a boarded-up house. Parked practically in front of the garden on a recent morning was an almost new car, stripped. The one bench in the large garden, where the caretakers sit and talk, is a few feet from the work.
''I moved here in 1984,'' said Geneva McFadden, who is 76 years old and who helped build the garden and the head-throne. ''This was full of weeds. I would come pull weeds so at least I could have a clear space. One man said, 'Why not go for a garden?' It was accepted in 1986. Now I look out and I see the sculpture. It looks like a presence. A human presence.''
For Catherine Jones, another of the caretakers, the garden is an ''oasis in the desert, I'm telling you,'' and the sculpture its guardian. ''At least they haven't come in here and tried to rip it, and the nature of the young people around here is to rip it apart,'' she said.
 
A Proliferation Of Sponsors
 The sculptures in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens are the results of several ambitious projects. One is the Food Center Sculpture Park at Hunts Point, one of the neighborhoods that has given the South Bronx its bad name, an area where drugs sometimes seem more available than food and prostitutes have sold themselves to truck drivers by standing naked in the street.
Because of the social and visual challenges of the site, the economic and political power behind the program, and the conflicting interests sculpture is intended to serve here, this ''sculpture park'' is one of the most intriguing developments in the history of public sculpture in New York City. The first show, through next July, includes 12 sculptures by 10 artists. Ten of the works have been previously exhibited or were made for other sites. With one exception, artists were paid $1,200 a work.
Artists in the Garden, which began in 1984, helps match artists with communities. ''The gardens we put sculpture in are gardens we feel strongly about preserving,'' said Jane Weissman, the director of Operation Greenthumb. ''Sculpture makes the garden more valuable, coalesces the community group, brings more attention to the garden.''
Of the roughly 460 gardens financed by Operation Greenthumb, 16 now have sculptures and eight have murals. Each sculptor was paid $2,000; materials and expenses were covered by the program.
The Socrates Sculpture Park, which opened in Long Island City in 1985, has provided many sculptors with a place to construct and exhibit work in a raw, weedy, four-acre field by the East River, with Manhattan's waves of rising and falling stone in the distance. The sculpture program at Hunts Point was partly inspired by this park's example.
The sculptures also exist because of the art program of the boathouse in Prospect Park in Brooklyn - a park bordered on one side by the rich and on another by the poor - which organized modest sculpture shows in the summers of 1988 and 1989.
They exist as well because of New York City's Percent for Art Program, which began in 1983 and requires that 1 percent of the cost of each new city building - school, firehouse, police station and the like - be set aside for art. Representatives of the community are involved in selecting artists, and they maintain some advisory function throughout the conception and realization of the work.
This program will be an important measure of the success and failure of art around the city. But not yet. According to Jennifer MacGregor Cutting, the director of the program and a member of the task force that brought the Food Center Sculpture Park into being, 6 works -4 of them sculptures - have been completed, and 37 others are under way. About 15 of the works have been commissioned for troubled neighborhoods.
 
Risks of Vandalism In the Age of Crack
 The spread of sculpture throughout New York City coincides with the spread of crack, which may have created a greater openness in these neighborhoods to gestures that could generate some show of solidarity and concern - like sculpture.
Arthur Froman, the director of the Hunts Point Cooperative Meat Market, one of the businesses participating in the Food Center Sculpture Park, has spoken about keeping the loading dock free of crack and wanting sculpture to help create a better working environment.
If crack's destruction of neighborhoods is one of many factors that has inspired people inside and outside these neighborhoods to consider the possibility of sculpture, the presence of crack can also make the installation and maintenance of sculpture dangerous. Enrico Martignoni, the project director of the Socrates Sculpture Park, has seen his share of crime. ''We're in the middle of the crack wars like everyone else,'' he says.
 
'Big Tree' And 'Dragon Tree'
 One artist who has had success making sculpture for sites in troubled neighborhoods is Bob Rivera. He is 46 years old and was raised in upper Manhattan. Like many of the artists commissioned by these programs, he has no gallery affiliation. He has realized commissions for both Artists in the Gardens and Hunts Point.
''Garden Spirit,'' his sculpture at Teller Avenue and East 169th Street in the South Bronx, crowns a garden tended by Project Prep, an alternative junior high school, whose students affectionately call the work ''big tree.'' It is steel and aluminum, with a three-pole trunk and branches suggesting tools and bloom. Both students and teachers like to nestle in the triangular space between the poles.
The sculpture at Hunts Point is called ''Dragon Tree of Maintenance.'' It is a 30-foot-long work, mostly wood, breathing its particular fire just inside the barbed wire at one corner of the New York City Terminal Market at Hunts Point. The dragon's breath, made of tools for plowing, planting and purification, is visible above the barbed wire, advertising the presence of sculpture within the compound to passing cars and trucks. The dragon is a mythical Oriental beast that may have been chosen because 80 percent of the greengrocers using the Terminal Market are Korean.
This sculpture, too, is playful, with a message about work and responsibility, and it speaks to the site. But while it is not out of place, neither is it at home in this sprawling cement zone, in front of its fence-cage. And its exact audience is unclear. Both sculptures will make friends for sculpture, but their capacity to respond to the tensions within their neighborhoods and touch communities outside is limited.
 
At Hunts Point, Sculpture as Logo
 When sculptures are unsuccessful, they may be little more than logos. A number of the works at the Food Center Sculpture Park are abstract and architectural. Because of their geometry, Jeffrey Brosk's ''Prairie Dance'' and Peter Dudek's ''Snug Harbor,'' neither of which was made for its site, in front of the National Foods headquarters, have the capacity to play off the stark verticals and horizontals of the buildings and roads. But these works function very much like works of art in a board room - not so much objects to be taken seriously as adornments that allow those in their presence to pat each other on the back about how civilized they are.
Many of the problems of sculpture in the inner city are raised by this particular project. The sculptures are spread over the Hunts Point Food Distribution Center, at the edge of the Hunts Point peninsula, attached to the flat industrial neighborhood around it but very much a complex unto itself - 329 acres, employing almost 12,000 people and generating more than $7 billion in annual sales. The Food Center includes the headquarters of six wholesale markets, of which five are participating in the sculpture program.
As a sculpture site, it is exciting. Although it is the largest food market complex in the United States, everything in it is on a human scale. It is near the mouth of the Bronx River; it has barbed wire and tall grass and miles of railroad tracks. There are blank walls in all shapes and sizes and numerous signs. Between the big trucks rolling across the stone and the sprawl of unkept fields, there is a feeling of some of the bleakest aspects of city and country colliding.
Judging by the first show, the sculpture program has too many conflicting aims and too little interest in sculpture itself. Sculpture is seen as a way of making the food center more human. ''It is always a struggle to keep the sense of civility and respectability apparent to people who work here, in light of other environmental features of the area,'' said Jonathan Bernstein, vice president and treasurer of National Foods, ''not the least of which is the marine transfer station right next to us, which is where all the garbage trucks from the Bronx dump their garbage.''
The sculpture program has also been partly conceived to change the perception of Hunts Point, both inside and beyond the Bronx. The businessmen and city officials involved with Hunts Point are clear about what they want from sculpture.
''Sculptures are part of the upgrading of this area,'' said Arthur Froman of the Hunts Point Cooperative Market.
''We are trying to change the South Bronx around,'' said Bruce Piel, general manager of the Terminal Market at Hunts Point. ''We have cleaned up, but we need to get the word out.''
When sculpture has so much to do with image, it should not be surprising that it is experienced primarily as symbol. ''Some of it I admit I don't understand, but it's good for the Bronx,'' said Anthony M. Riccio Jr., the commissioner of the New York City Department of Ports and Trade, the food center's landlord.
No one at Hunts Point is pretending that the first show is a knockout. ''It's a modest start,'' said Sigmund Balka, who in 1986 opened the Krasdale Foods Art Gallery in the company headquarters.
What the center does with the next show - there is talk of relocating the existing works, bringing in more works that are part of the city's outdoor sculpture history, and commissioning half a dozen site-specific works - and how it uses the $100,000 set aside for the food center by the Percent for Art program, will provide some answers.
 
For Most Efforts, A Precarious Future
 Except for the Percent for Art program, the future of all the sculpture programs that have brought art into troubled neighborhoods is precarious.
Money is a problem. Jane Weissman, the director of Operation Greenthumb, has to raise money for Artists in the Gardens, and ''fund raising,'' she says, ''is terrible.''
The future of the Socrates Sculpture Park is in doubt. Its five-year lease runs out in 1990. The park will ask for a renewal from the Department of Ports and Trade, but Mr. Martignoni believes that the city has plans to build luxury and moderate-income housing on the site. At the Boathouse in Prospect Park, the destruction of one work by vandals and the near collapse of another suggest that this program has a way to go before its possibilities are clear.
Whatever happens, something important is being worked out. Artists and communities outside the art world are groping for some common ground, and there are signs that it is beginning to exist. Whatever happens, the struggle is helping to bring into the open what we think of sculpture, and of art itself.

Conrad) (pg. 1); Gail Rothschild's sculpture ''Gaia Earthmother'' is intended as a curative charm. ''It looks like a presence. A human presence,'' says Geneva McFadden, above, who helped build the work; Christy Rupp's four little bears climbing over an assemblage of filing cabinets at the Food Center
