SECTION: Section 2; Page 1, Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2007 words

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
TIMID PROGRAMMING, TEPID TELEVISION

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
If television reflects reality, however hazily, we the people would seem to be mired in growing confusion. While news and ''reality'' shows adopt questionable dramatization devices, entertainment formats drift ever further into inane diversions. Meanwhile, daytime shows like ''Geraldo'' are insisting that the land is being overrun by child molesters and Satanists. And, for the most part, the new season of weekly prime-time series only adds to the blur.
There are indeed continuing pressures on ABC, NBC, CBS and the still evolving Fox Broadcasting. All are under relatively new corporate ownerships that have initiated personnel cutbacks and tighter budgets. The inevitable result is to go with the obvious, that which doesn't require much thought or emotional investment. With visual impact becoming an obsession, content floats more and more on surfaces. A ''look'' is more important than integrity, a flashy concept more salable than struggling intelligence. The new season has its pockets of promise and even innovation, no doubt about it. But they are mostly in the form of character tinkerings or slightly adjusted concepts. There's Jack Scalia's more thoughtful tough-guy hero, for instance, on CBS's ''Wolf,'' or the Down's syndrome teen-ager in ABC's family drama ''Life Goes On.'' These and other details, rooted in more or less the real world, are the good part of the picture. 
But as more than 20 new weekly series unfold well beyond their pilot premieres, the overall programming landscape looks increasingly bleak. There's certainly not a single entry of the caliber of ''Hill Street Blues'' or last year's ''The Wonder Years,'' or even ''Roseanne,'' the kinds of shows that take television in new directions. It's as if the commercial networks concluded that kinder, gentler means fuzzier, dumber. Viewers may well remember the cosmetics commercial in which the face of a beautiful woman fills the screen, seductively murmuring: ''I've had it with reality. I want illusion.'' That message threatens to become prime-time's logo. There are, to be sure, other watchable shows on the schedule: the energetic but so far uneven sendup of show-business agents on CBS's ''Famous Teddy Z''; and even ABC's ''Young Riders'' with its frisky attempt to revive the western format, albeit with pretty cowboys who seem to be dressed in Ralph Lauren concepts of the American past. But too many of the other series are downright irritating.
This is the season, for instance, of decidedly odd couples (in entertainment, Jackie Mason and Lynn Redgrave on ABC's ''Chicken Soup,'' Sam Donaldson and in infotainment, Diane Sawyer on ABC's ''Prime Time Live'') and odd pairings (a Catholic nun and a batch of ''misfit'' orphans on NBC's ''Sister Kate,'' Connie Chung and a drama repertory on ''Saturday Night With Connie Chung''). Then there are the always perky youngsters, more than ever obsessed with sex, cosmetics and fashion: the teen-age models on ABC's ''Living Dolls'' or the 16-year-old ''Doogie Howser, M.D.'' on NBC or, on the same network, ''Baywatch,'' with its Los Angeles lifeguards and an endless landscape of unblemished flesh. It should be a good year for dermatologists. Finally - shades of ''I Dream of Jeannie'' fantasy capers - consider Winnie the Witch on ABC's ''Free Spirit'' and the psychic cartoonist on CBS's ''People Next Door.'' Consider, and then carefully avoid.
While hardly new to prime time, titillation now threatens to become the only game in television town. As the networks' audience share in the last decade has plummeted from 92 to 67 percent, the thrust toward cheaper, more accessible product has intensified. With competition from cable and videocassettes continuing, and with advertisers looking anew at market configurations, the networks are not likely in the foreseeable future to become more adventurous, imaginative or, heaven help us, provocative. It's hardly a coincidence that CBS, which once prided itself on being the Tiffany of networks, is this season involved in an extensive campaign of mutual promotion with K-Mart.
This spreading timidity is occurring, of course, at a time when the country is facing a harrowing list of crises: drugs, AIDS, the homeless, failing savings institutions, housing scandals, Wall Street ripoffs and political corruption, just to mention the more prominent. Forget about the rest of the world. But viewers would be hard-pressed to find much evidence of these problems in weekly series.
On the contrary. While the horror of children born with AIDS grows worse, adding to the rolls of parentless children in major urban areas, ''Sister Kate'' offers an episode in which one of the adorable orphans refuses to be adopted because she doesn't want to leave her friend behind in the residential home. Evidently the young ones, like those hordes of homeless and the unemployed who supposedly don't want to work anyway, are best left where they are - periodically exploited by television but carefully kept in their place. Viewers needn't feel threatened, or even terribly concerned.
Programming strategies this year reek of uncertainty. In that sense, they may be reflecting national realities more than is immediately apparent. Witness Washington's Panama scenario. There are indeed a few nods in the direction of what might be considered traditionally ''mature'' programming. CBS, in particular, seems to be focusing on older audiences - in television that means over 30. So ''Island Son'' stars Richard Chamberlain, the mini-series monarch, as a contemporary version of Dr. Kildare, a role that made the actor a star in the early 1960's. But in today's far more turbulent world of medicine, this good and noble doctor comes across as an anachronism.
''Peaceable Kingdom'' has Lindsay Wagner as a mother and the new director of the Los Angeles County Zoo. Significant mention is made at one point of the songs ''Don't Worry, Be Happy'' and ''The Impossible Dream.'' Says mom to her human brood: ''We're never going to have a normal life. Normal is boring.'' So, unfortunately, is ''Peaceable Kingdom.'' In ''Major Dad,'' Gerald McRaney works industriously as a Marine disciplinarian who, for no very convincing reason, marries a ''liberal'' widow with three daughters. The major might easily be mistaken for Ollie North, without the distraction of the Iran-contra scandal.
Elsewhere on the schedule, television continues to woo younger audiences, especially women, the favorite targets of advertisers. On hand is the usual quota of brooding but ever more vulnerable hunks. In addition to Mr. Scalia in ''Wolf,'' there is Richard Tyson, complete with shoulder-length hair, motorcycle and single earring, in NBC's ''Hardball.'' Returning to the old-cop, young-cop formula, ''Hardball'' has Mr. Tyson finding a surrogate father in John Ashton as a veteran detective refusing to be put out to retirement pasture. It is a vintage year for father-son motifs.
As for the always skittish teen-age market, ABC's ''Living Dolls'' may well be setting a new record for exploitation. Michael Learned, once the homebody mother of ''The Waltons,'' is now the chic head of a modeling agency and housemother to several 16-year-old cover girls. When not fussing with their makeup, the fetching lasses are preoccupied with clothes and partying, well on their way to being perfect little consumers. Their own families seem to have disappeared, except for that of one tough street kid from Brooklyn, whose neglectful mother doesn't even want to bother with her birthday. This prompts the poor youngster to use, without permission, a friend's house for a big, messy party. At first the owner, who returns unexpectedly, is furious, but all is forgiven when he learns that the girl only wanted to give herself a birthday party. Awww, coos the sympathetic studio audience.
Authority, parental or otherwise, is clearly a delicate issue on shows geared to young audiences. Most scripts carefully avoid any hint of being old-fashioned, which is nearly always dismissed as boring in an era pursuing the new and trendy. A rare exception was found in a recent episode of ''Doogie Howser, M.D.'' Doogie used, without permission, his parents' home for a big, messy party - yes, plot ideas are rather limited these days - and wound up getting in trouble with the police. Doogie's parents were, and remained, enormously disappointed in him.
Then there are the hunks designed for teen-agers, the kind of leather-jacket-with-earring James Dean types who make daddy glance anxiously at his daughter. Fox Broadcasting has proven especially adept in this market. In ''21 Jump Street,'' about young and unattached undercover cops infiltrating schools and colleges, Johnny Depp emerged as top boyish heartthrob. Then last season Richard Grieco, out of a somewhat chunkier mold, generated so much mail that he has now been given his own series, ''Booker,'' and promoted from rebel cop to unorthodox investigator, though still partial to leather.
How do you like your nation's capital? CBS's ''Top of the Hill'' offers Washington as seen through the idealistic exploits of a youngish surfer turned Congressman (William Katt) who could be mistaken at a distance for Representative Joseph Kennedy. He gives his constituents personal service. Someone missing in the drug thickets of Central America? An adopted woman looking to find her real family for a crucial bone-marrow transplant? No problem. Over on NBC, however, ''Mancuso, F.B.I.,'' with the always estimable Robert Loggia in the lead role, approaches Washington as a cesspool. ''Clout and phone calls and coverups,'' snarls seedy Mancuso, ''that's how this stinking town gets by.'' Consuming dry Manhattans and peanuts in his favorite gin mill, he looks up at the TV set and sneers, ''The First Amendment - television's answer to the Spanish Inquisition.'' Of course, Mancuso is equally idealistic, just in a grittier way.
Also set in Washington, but for no very pressing purpose, is CBS's ''Snoops,'' which seems eager to accomplish for Tim Reid and Daphne Maxwell Reid, also married off screen, what ''Hart to Hart,'' itself a variation on the old Nick and Nora Charles ''Thin Man'' movies, did for Robert Wagner and Stefanie Powers. He teaches criminology. She is a protocol aide for the State Department. Together, with the use of a chauffeured limousine and spiffy wardrobes, they solve assorted criminal cases that, alas, tend to be rather obvious. The only other new series with black actors in the lead roles is the ABC sitcom ''Family Matters.'' And, effectively segregated, this family doesn't venture very far from the standard broad strokes of sitcom. Shouts bossy grandma: ''We gotta eat now or I'm not going to be regular all week.''
If the times might seem especially propitious for comedy, some of the more prominent efforts are struggling noticeably. Few spectacles have been more excruciatingly embarrassing than watching Mr. Mason and Miss Redgrave in the ill-conceived ''Chicken Soup'' pretending to be romantically interested in each other. ''The Famous Teddy Z,'' starring Jon Cryer as a new show business agent who's learning on the job, got off to a hilarious start, then collapsed in a dreary second episode. The next installment, however, recovered nicely as Teddy tended to the career needs of Bobby, a chimpanzee. It seemed Bobby's sitcom was beginning to get to him after six years of production. ''He feels the scripts are all the same,'' the chimp's manager explained. There certainly is potential here.
For the most part, it is still too early to determine which of these new series will survive. The ratings picture is currently being skewed by the championship baseball series. And some established shows, such as ''L.A. Law,'' won't be returning until November. But with the networks grasping at worn formats and questionable gimmicks, it's likely that fewer and fewer viewers will care. There are too many alternatives available, some of them perhaps a bit more attuned to the world around us.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2309 words

HEADLINE: Rewriting the Rules of Retailing

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

DATELINE: TYSONS CORNER, Va.

 BODY:
There is no happier sound to the merchant's ear than that of a constantly ringing cash register.
F. W. Woolworth.
It was a sight that would have warmed Mr. Woolworth's heart.
Like so many faithful drawn to a sacred site, Columbus Day sales brought out the crowds last Monday to what many consider the high altar of shopping - a two-mall complex here of seven department stores and 330 specialty shops in one of America's most affluent areas. The parking lots were packed, the stores crowded and the cash registers - now electronic - were humming with sales. 
But on this particular holiday, there was added drama. Retailing has fallen on hard times as industry profits continue to slide and some of the best names in the business are now on the auction block. At Tysons Corner, these dislocations were abundantly - and often painfully - clear.
At Bloomingdale's, once at the vanguard of merchandising but now struggling with lower profits, a sea of red signs advertising sales of 25 to 50 percent off beckoned, but few customers responded. Bloomingdale's legendary pizazz, it seems, has faded. But a vision of retailing's future was just across the mall. Nordstrom, the Seattle-based department store chain that has honed customer service into an art form, had few markdowns but plenty of shoppers. A pianist played Gershwin tunes in the main lobby and unfailingly helpful clerks waited on customers eagerly buying from an attractive selection of goods.
Retailing, which rises and falls on fashion, economics and demographics, is being turned on its head. Recent headlines may tell the tale of how at least seven crown jewels of retailing, including Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue and Bonwit Teller, are being sold by their parent companies. But those sales - the unpleasant aftermath of a leveraged buyout wave that swept through retailing in the last few years - are only symptomatic of deeper forces reshaping the industry.
Once a growth industry that racked up profits from a rising population tide, retailing has matured into a business where one store's gains now come only at the expense of another. The massive overbuilding of shopping complexes during the 1970's has left America ''over-malled.'' Yet Americans' appetite for these products has slackened. The baby boom generation that turned shopping into a leisure activity is aging, and becoming more interested in saving for the future.
As a result, retailing - which last year was a $418 billion industry, according to the United States Census Bureau - is far less lucrative today. Industry profit margins are a minuscule 1.69 percent, the lowest since 1968, and after-tax profits have fallen by 3.6 percent a year since 1986, according to Columbus, Ohio-based Management Horizons.
''There's a war going on,'' said Howard Davidowitz, head of his own retail consulting firm. ''We've overpopulated America with stores.'' Alan Millstein, publisher of the Fashion Network Report, a monthly trade letter, said: ''These are the most dire times for the industry since the Great Depression of the 1930's.''
Like other American industries - steel and autos, for instance - retailing suffers from overcapacity and is in the process of being restructured. It is moving from big department store dominance to an era characterized by stores that provide highly focused merchandise for specific groups. Mass marketing and centralization have given way to specialty providers and alternative channels of distribution like direct mail, telemarketing and home shopping.
''We're entering a period of slower economic and population growth and that means we're entering a mature market for retailing,'' said Sandra Shaber, an economist with The Futures Group, a Washington, D.C.-consulting firm. ''Competition will largely be for market share and this tends to be price competition. The other way to get market share is to find a new market niche that no one thought of. The marketplace is ripe for that right now. Mass marketing died a long time ago.''
 
Two Types of Survivors
 Ultimately, some predict, retailing will further divide into two groups - department and specialty stores that compete on customer service and highly focused merchandise, and discount giants that offer commodity goods at rock-bottom prices. Success will come to those devoted to the old retailing adage of giving customers what they want, whether it is a Nordstrom that provides top-notch service, a Limited that offers the trendiest fashions or a Wal-Mart that competes with aggressive prices. Providing a broad array of goods for all is no longer enough. The trick is to constantly re-establish a store's focus - something that many traditional department stores have lost sight of.
''Department stores are at the end of their life cycle and have to be reinvented,'' said Peter J. Solomon, who heads his own investment bank. ''People are more sophisticated. They don't want to go out and wander around department stores any more. Department stores are no longer the dominant form of retailing, although, when good, they still have tremendous amounts of capital, muscle and drawing ability.''
This is not to say, however, that all department stores will disappear, even though most agree their ranks will thin. ''Rumors of the death of the department stores are much exaggerated,'' said Stephen E. Watson, chief executive of the Dayton-Hudson Department Store Company.
''The weaker will tend not to do so well and close their doors or be swallowed,'' Mr. Watson said. ''But department stores have been remarkably resilient over the last 100 years. There will be fewer but larger players. The outlook is good for those that can satisfy what the customer wants, which right now is high service and fair prices.''
The greatest competitive threat to department stores has come from specialty retailers, which, along with discounters, have stolen market share. In the $108 billion women's apparel market alone, specialty retailers now have about 15 percent market share, compared with the department stores' 28 percent.
The Limited is perhaps the biggest success story of the group, which includes such national chains as the Gap, Laura Ashley, Ann Taylor, Crate and Barrel. Starting out in Middle Western shopping malls, the Limited operates 754 apparel stores for women in their 20's to 40's. Its sales have grown largely at the expense of department stores to more than $4 billion, up from $238 million in 1979.
Specialty retailers say they can provide something department stores cannot - or do not. ''We just flat out provide better service,'' said Douglas Gantos, head of Gantos Inc. With 131 stores in 22 states, the Grand Rapids, Mich.-based women's retailer has grown by 30 percent a year. ''We greet the customer and try to get her out of the store as quickly as possible. We've got to keep building better mousetraps to get them to our door.''
 
Designers As Rivals
 Department stores have also been hurt by some of their own suppliers. Such purveyors as Ralph Lauren, Wedgewood, Burberry and Liz Claiborne have opened their own stores, often within a stone's throw of department stores.
And there has been greater acceptance of off-price stores and discounters, which sell either lower-quality goods or branded names at bargainprices. Discounters now account for about 28 percent of women's apparel sales and 37 percent in men's.
''Ten years ago, it was socially desirable to talk about where you bought at item,'' said David D. Glass, president of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. ''What's socially acceptable today is what you paid for it.''
Price consciousness has been the force behind the rise of no-frills volume stores like Toys 'R' Us in chidren's goods and Circuit City in electronics. Such ''power'' retailers compete by having lower prices and a superior selection of a single product line. And, on the horizon are new ''hypermarkets'' being pioneered by Wal-Mart, which carry discount merchandise and food in stores the size of football fields.
The rise of new distribution channels that challenge old ways of buying also added to the turmoil. While catalogues, of course, have been around since Montgomery Ward, many direct mail marketers today - L. L. Bean, Sharper Image and J. Crew, to name a few - offer 24-hour order-taking and specialty merchandise.
Some of these catalogue companies have even expanded into hybrid operations with retail stores. For instance, Talbot's, a women's retailer based in Hingham, Mass., whose catalogue circulation is 70 million, is opening stores at the rate of 20 to 25 a year. Talbot's has grown from five stores in 1973 to 137 today. ''The catalogues become a tremendous advertising tool for our stores and the stores give us exposure for our catalogue,'' said Arnold Zetcher, Talbot's chief executive.
Technology, in fact, is making it easier to stay out of stores entirely. Home television shopping, for instance, which peddles primarily low-priced items, is expected to move into higher-ticket goods. And shoppers can even buy products over their personal computers through such services as Prodigy, which is marketed by Sears and the International Business Machines Corporation.
 
Department Stores' Fall
 All these changes were taking place just as department stores were becoming the darlings of Wall Street's takeover artists about three years ago. In fact, many department stores are in trouble in part because the entrepreneurs who paid so dearly for them - Australia's L.J. Hooker Ltd. and Canada's Campeau Corporation - didn't entirely understand what they were buying. ''You had overly ambitious egos getting involved in things they knew nothing about,'' said Kurt Barnard, a newsletter publisher.
When Wall Street came calling, many of these department stores had already become vulnerable. They had lost touch with their customers by relying on a formula that was at least 25 years old. The department store credit card, which tied customers to specific retailers, lost its power as mass cards like American Express and Visa expanded. And much of the merchandise, particularly apparel - the backbone of every department store - began to look the same.
''The stores began to become boring and look too much alike,'' Mr. Barnard said. ''They had fallen into the trap of their own success. They didn't know how to become more competitive.'' Added Robert G. Nesbit, senior partner in retailing at Korn Ferry International, an executive search firm: '' It used to be that the anchor store drew people to the malls. Now the kids are going to find out what's in the specialty stores.''
Many retailers, department stores along with others, failed to keep up with technology. Only a few - Wal-Mart, the Limited and such successful department store chains as Dillard's, based in Little Rock, Ark., and Dayton-Hudson's - implemented highly sophisicated data processing systems to track the ebb and flow of merchandise. ComputerWorld Premier 100, a trade publication, reports that the top 10 retailers spend an average of 1.24 percent of their revenues on information systems, compared with 4.9 percent in banking and 4 percent in transportation.
But instead of these problems, the raiders saw hidden real estate values, undervalued assets and unrelated businesses that could be sold. ''They were the perfect target,'' said Mr. Davidowitz. ''Their stock prices were low, they had hidden assets and could generate cash.''
 
The Raiders Descend
 And so the raiders descended. But, with such heavy debt loads, these companies got caught in a bind. They did not have the cash to re-invest in stores, yet had to generate customers' dollars to cover their borrowings. ''All their money got tied up in debt,'' Mr. Nesbit said. ''The stores have now got to satisfy the banks before they satisfy the customer. They got it reversed.''
The Canadian real estate tycoon Robert Campeau, who paid $6.7 billion in 1987 to buy Federated Department Stores, the parent of Bloomingdale's, is on the edge of bankruptcy. L.J. Hooker, the new owner of Bonwit's and B. Altman & Company. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection this summer. And B.A.T., the British tobacco conglomerate, recently put Saks and Marshall Field up for sale.
In this environment, the lesson is that of the vulnerability of retailing. For instance, it seemed that giant Wal-Mart came out of nowhere - from Bentonville, Ark. - to take on Sears, the nation's largest retailer. Today Wal-Mart has some 1,300 stores with sales of nearly $20 billion. As Sears made ill-fated forays into financial service, insurance and real estate, Wal-Mart stuck to its strategy of building cavernous stores of discount merchandise and rolled up a 35 percent annual growth rate. Sears is now struggling to compete with new ''everyday low prices'' while rival K-Mart has seen its market share drop to about 40 percent, from about 65 percent in 1980.
The small are as vulnerable as the big. Such new specialty shops as Alcott & Andrews, a women's career outfitter that made a splash when it opened, failed largely because of a poorly executed expansion plan. And the once-popular Banana Republic has floundered amid a limited appetite for its safari attire.
Ironically, with so many stores for sale, retailing may return to its roots. Individual stores are expected to be taken out of corporate hands by merchandising entrepreneurs who are often more sensitive to changing tastes and more willing to take marketing risks. Corporations think about numbers; merchandising entrepreneurs, about fashion.
''There's a lot of shaking going on with so many for sale,'' said Mr. Zetcher of Talbot's. ''It's a little disheartening to spend all these years in retailing to see this happening. But we may go back to the way it was, when families and independent operators ran the stores.''

HEADLINE: PERSONAL FINANCE;
Deciding How to Cash In an Annuity

BYLINE: By DONALD JAY KORN; Donald Jay Korn writes about financial topics from New York.

 BODY:
For at least a decade, deferred annuities have been popular with investors. Under these contracts, money you pay to an insurance company builds up, free of current income taxes. The taxes are deferred until you reclaim your cash.
Now, as many annuity investors near retirement age, they have to decide how to get their money. If you are in that position, your options are wider - and more complicated - than you may realize. 
Your basic choice is whether or not to ''annuitize'' your contract. When you annuitize, you sign a new contract with an insurance company, this time providing for a scheduled payout, typically a fixed monthly amount.
Some financial advisers urge investors to delay annuitizing as long as possible. Annuities held as part of retirement plans may require distributions starting at age 70 1/2. Otherwise, you can postpone annuitizing the contract until the insurance company's rules say you must, generally at age 85. ''When you annuitize, you lose flexibility, because you're locked into the schedule you select,'' said Dale McClelland, a financial planner based in Flint, Mich. ''You also wind up paying for the costs of setting up the annuity payout.''
Instead, you can leave things as they are and take out money when it suits your purposes, through loans or withdrawals. Withdrawals generally are better, because there is no interest to pay. Typically, there is an amount you can take out each year without paying a penalty charge to the insurer. After perhaps 7 to 10 years from the start of the annuity, a period that varies by contract, you can make unlimited withdrawals without a surrender charge. (There may be tax consequences whenever you take money out, depending on your age and the age of the policy.) So why would anyone annuitize? To get ''income you can't outlive,'' said Alecia Oberg, senior consultant for The New England, an insurance company based in Boston. With an annuity payout schedule, you can lock in a stream of income for your lifetime, and the life of a loved one, if you choose.
If you annuitize, however, you face a bewildering variety of choices. One choice is between fixed and variable payouts. A fixed payout - so many dollars per month - is the standard. But some insurers also offer you a payout that varies, depending upon investment results. With a variable-payout annuity, your contract may be invested among several mutual funds.
Choosing the variable-payout annuity may help you deal with inflation. So some people direct their annuity contracts into a stock fund or real estate fund, figuring that the long-term growth will provide increasing payouts. Or, to cut risk, you can choose a money market fund. Then, if inflation accelerates and interest rates go back into double digits, your payout likely will keep pace.
Of course, not everyone wants to take a chance with an annuity nest egg. If you want a dependable income for life, choose a fixed-payout annuity.
The basic version is the single-life annuity. When you annuitize, the insurance company will look at your age and your contract amount, make some guesses about future interest rates, then offer you a certain amount for the rest of your life. A 65-year-old man, for example, with a $100,000 contract would currently be offered $926 per month ($11,112 per year) by The New England.
Accepting such an offer is a pure crapshoot. You might collect one payment, then die. If so, the insurance company gets to keep the entire amount left in the contract. (If you die before you annuitize, your named beneficiary gets the money.) But if you live to age 120, the insurance company has to keep on paying you that $926 month after month.
If you have family members to consider, you might accept a smaller monthly payout in return for more security. For example, suppose that 65-year-old man with the $100,000 contract has a 62-year-old wife. He can obtain a ''joint and survivor'' annuity from The New England that will pay $732 per month - $194 less than straight life - as long as either of them still lives.
There are a host of other options, but Ms. Oberg said that the most popular payout mode is ''life with 10 years certain.'' Here, the individual with the contract gets a lifetime payout but the insurance company agrees to pay for at least 10 years, to the recipient's beneficiary, if necessary. At The New England, this payout would be $886 per month.
Different insurance companies make different assumptions about future interest rates. Therefore, payouts can vary significantly from company to company. Before choosing a payout schedule, shop around. You are not wed to the insurance company that held your contract during the deferred buildup period. If you find a better deal at another insurer, you can switch your account via a ''1035 tax-free exchange.''
Taxes, of course, must be considered. Different rules apply when annuitizing or making withdrawals and loans.
If you bought your annuity before Aug. 14, 1982, and are making withdrawals or loans, you are fortunate. ''You can take out as much as you want, via loans and withdrawals, without a 10 percent tax penalty,'' said Joel Isaacson, director of personal financial planning at Weber Lipshie & Company, a New York-based accounting firm. Only after you have taken out an amount equal to all the premiums that you have paid will you run into an income tax on subsequent distributions.
If you bought an annuity since Aug. 14, 1982, however, the tax bite is crueler. Any withdrawals before age 59 1/2 are subject to the 10 percent tax penalty. Your distributions also will be treated as taxable income, up to the total amount of investment income in the contract. Thereafter, cash flow will be a tax-free return of your own money.
As for annuitizing, the Internal Revenue Service considers each payment part income, part return of capital. The income part is taxed; the insurance company will provide an annual statement to help you figure it out.
This can make a big difference in deciding whether to annuitize or make withdrawals. If you bought an annuity after Aug. 14, 1982, you may prefer annuitizing if you are in a 28 or a 33 percent tax bracket, while those in a 15 percent bracket may choose not to annuitize because their tax bill won't be so forbidding.
''In any event,'' Mr. Isaacson said, ''don't be in a hurry to annuitize now - and lock in a return - while interest rates are relatively low.''
Fortunately, taking money out of an annuity does not have to be an either-or choice. ''Many companies will permit you to split your contract,'' Ms. Oberg said. You can take a portion and buy a fixed annuity, for example, while the rest goes into a variable annuity, for growth potential, or stays in the tax-deferral stage, for flexibility.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Tempting New Offerings in Technology

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
When stock prices crashed two years ago, hot young technology companies suffered some of the steepest declines. The market for initial public offerings, particularly in technology, vanished.
Today, with the market back at record levels, investment firms are selling new issues again. But this time, only the most promising technology companies can go public, and then at prices far lower than these companies would have fetched before the crash. As long as Wall Street remains skittish about these stocks, investors can find some bargains. 
The go-go days for new technology issues were in 1982 and 1983, when almost any company with a chip and a dream could go public, often at 30 or 40 times earnings. But for every Apple Computer Inc. that grew into a multibillion-dollar company, there was an Osborne Computer Company or a Victor Technologies Inc. - personal computer companies that flourished briefly and then folded.
Even the largest technology companies have performed so erratically of late that investors remain wary of the entire group. The market is so selective that investors can buy shares in sound companies at very attractive prices. The volume of initial public offerings has remained low, especially ''if you compare today with the heyday of 1982 and 1983 when the high-tech IPO market really hit its zenith,'' said Allan Hadhazy, a senior analyst with the Institute for Econometric Research in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., which publishes the New Issues newsletter.
Technology offerings, virtually absent in 1988, reappeared with the successful debut of the Network General Corporation, a maker of instruments for diagnosing problems in personal computer networks, on July 21. Offered at $8, an earnings multiple of 16, Network General closed Friday at 18 1/4. ''What made Network General so attractive was that a nice company was priced at a very low multiple just to get it out the door,'' Mr. Hadhazy said.
As soon as the Network General deal succeeded, registrations for new offerings dramatically increased. Two of the best-performing initial public offerings this year were in technology, by Network General and later by New Image Industries, a computer image processing company that went public on August 24 at 6 1/2. The stock closed Friday at 12 3/4.
Investment firms that specialize in taking technology companies public are becoming more confident. Sanford R. Robertson, the general partner of Robertson, Stephens & Company in San Francisco, said that while demand for technology issues is not strong, ''I would not hestitate at all to do a technology offering today.'' Robertson finds fault with those who compare the new issues market to a window, sometimes open, sometimes shut. ''That's the wrong analogy,'' he said. ''It's not binary. The real analogy is, the market acts as a filter. That filter is a little bit fine now, but the deals that are getting through are doing well.''
Robertson boasted that his firm's last two offerings have been ''spectacular.'' The Symantec Corporation, a personal computer software company, went public on June 25 at 10 1/2 and closed Friday at 17 1/4; the Cirrus Logic Corporation, a computer chip manufacturer, which also went public June 8 at 10, closed Friday at 13.
Montgomery Securities is also catching the upbeat spirit, after a couple of very slow years. Some of the companies it had once intended to take public had their plans scuttled by the 1987 crash. Many of these companies have turned to other sources of capital; others were so short of money that they had to sell out to larger companies. ''Two years is a long time for a technology company,'' said Alan L. Stein, Montgomery's executive director of investment banking.
Montgomery currently has two technology companies in registration for their initial offerings: the Exabyte Corporation, a maker of computer data storage devices using eight-millimeter tape cartridges; and Knowledgeware Inc., which produces computer-aided software engineering, or CASE, products. ''There is very strong demand on both of these; there is not going to be any problem doing these deals,'' Mr. Stein said. Mr. Stein admits, though, that technology remains a tough sell. Technology issues are priced at 10 or 15 times earnings, he said, about half the prevailing ratios a couple of years ago. ''There have been so many disappointments in the after-market - quarterly disappointments, one after another,'' he said. ''People just don't trust these companies; therefore, the multiples are lower.''
So low, in fact, that some companies are delaying their offerings in hopes of receiving higher prices later. ''We're in the phase where a good company can come public, but the valuations aren't too good,'' said Michael T. Murphy, publisher of the California Technology Stock Letter. He expects new issues to have higher prices later.
Among the respected companies waiting to file, Mr. Murphy counts MIPS Computer Systems Inc., which makes very fast microprocessors and computers based on reduced instruction set computing, or RISC; the Vitesse Electronics Corporation, which makes gallium arsenide computer chips, and the Telebit Corporation, a maker of high-speed modems.
Another prominent company expected to hold back is Sybase Inc., a leading producer of data base management software. Sybase announced last month that it will sell a 15 percent stake to the Lotus Development Corporation, for an undisclosed amount. ''My guess is if they really wanted to come public they probably could,'' said Mr. Murphy. ''But they will probably get a higher valuation if they wait.''

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
October Turns Ugly Once More

BYLINE: By STEVE DODSON

 BODY:
Stocks had a dizzying plunge on Friday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping a scary 190.58 points and reviving painful memories of the 1987 stock crash that produced a 508-point plunge on Oct. 19. Friday's heavy selling wiped out all the gains from an early October rally that, just last Monday, had taken the Dow to a new high of 2,791.41. The plunge came when the employee-led group trying to buy UAL said it could not raise all the money it needed. Deals like the UAL buyout have provided much of the market's strength this year. For the week, the Dow lost 216.26 points, to close at 2,569.26. Bond prices surged as investors shifted money out of stocks. The dollar posted steep declines after the market tumbled.
 
*
 It was a tough week for financing deals. Beside the problems with the United Airlines buyout, Ramada Inc. failed to raise $230 million in a ''junk bond'' financing needed to carry out a plan to shed its hotels and concentrate on casinos. That contributed to a wave of selling in the overall market for high-yield securities. The junk market has been nervous since a severe slump in mid-September, and one widely followed expert, Robert M. Steinberg, the head of arbitrage at Bear, Stearns, said he thought the worst was yet to come. 
 
*
 A jump in wholesale prices in September revived worries about inflation. The increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent last month followed three months of declines. The September figure put the annual wholesale inflation rate at 5.1 percent. The rate for all of 1988 was 4 percent. The September data were heavily influenced by rising energy prices and by auto prices, which were skewed because the auto makers offered their end-of- the-model-year discounts earlier in the summer than usual . . . Retail sales were strong in September, posting a gain of five-tenths of a percent. September was the seventh straight month to register rising sales.
 
*
 The Amex picked a chairman from outside Wall Street. The choice to head the American Stock Exchange was James R. Jones, who was White House chief of staff under Lyndon B. Johnson and served seven terms as a Congressman from Oklahoma. Since leaving Congress in 1986, Mr. Jones, who is 50 years old, has been a lawyer in Washington and has developed wide contacts there and in Europe and Asia. He replaces Arthur Levitt Jr., 58, who has led the Amex for 11 years and is leaving to devote more time to his publishing company.
 
*
 Maurice Saatchi is stepping down as chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi, the world's largest advertising company. The position will go to Robert Louis-Dreyfus, a 43-year-old French executive who is not well known in advertising circles. Mr. Louis-Dreyfus had been chief executive of IMS International, a pharmaceutical market-research and publishing company that expanded rapidly under his leadership. Mr. Saatchi, 43, will remain chairman and executive director and his brother, Charles, 46, will continue as an executive director. Saatchi & Saatchi is under pressure because of its poor financial performance recently. This year it expects to report its first-ever decline in earnings. The largest shareholder, Southeastern Asset Management of Memphis, said last week that it has talked to other parties about ways to enhance the value of Saatchi shares.
 
*
 Banks posted big losses as expected because of the large additions they made to their reserves for bad loans to third world countries. Chemical Bank lost $824.6 million in the third quarter, reflecting a $900 million increase in reserves. Chase Manhattan had a $1.1 billion loss and Bank of New York lost $271.3 million . . . General Electric reported a 16 percent increase in quarterly profits. CBS's earnings were down 11.5 percent.
 
*
 A Norwegian won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. Trygve Haavelmo, 77 years old, was honored for working out statistical techniques that helped other economists develop the econometric models that are used to predict how a change in one aspect of the economy will affect others.
 
*
 Miscellanea. May Department Stores is getting out of the discount business. Its 118-store Caldor chain in the Northeast will be sold for $500 million to a group that includes management, and its 73-store Venture chain in the Midwest will be spun off to shareholders . . . Four 24-cent airmail stamps issued in 1918 and inadvertently printed with an upside- down airplane were sold for $1 million. The sellers were the Weill brothers stamp dealers of New Orleans; the buyer was identified only as ''an American broadcast executive'' . . . Merck and Johnson & Johnson are jointly buying ICI America, an over- the-counter drug operation of Imperial Chemical of Britain. The deal was valued at $450 million.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Salvadorans Wonder How To Think About Peace

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR

 BODY:
VIOLENCE and suffering have been so central a part of El Salvador's experience that the national anthem reminds the people how ''painful and bloody is your history.'' Ten years ago today, though, a group of young and idealistic military officers launched a coup here ushering in a period of turmoil and destruction that has taxed even this country's remarkable ability to endure.
In a decade of civil war, 70,000 have died and the country has sustained several billion dollars in material damages. The people have been left exhausted and hoping that new negotiations between the Salvadoran Government and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front - talks scheduled to begin Monday in San Jose, Costa Rica - can somehow lead to what the national anthem calls ''the supreme bliss'' of peace. But the war has so transformed every aspect of the national landscape that it is difficult for any but the most optimistic Salvadoran to envision the shape of or the timetable for peace. 
Ten years ago, on Oct. 15, 1979, young officers overthrew the military-led government run by their superiors and replaced them with a reformist military-civilian junta. Eventually, they were elbowed aside themselves by more ambitious and decidedly less progressive colleagues, but they did achieve their immediate goal: forestalling a revolution like the one that brought the Sandinistas to power in neighboring Nicaragua a few months earlier. The principal beneficiaries of their pre-emptive action, however, have turned out to be two of the forces that most strongly opposed their reformist program -the military hierarchy and the revolutionary insurgency. Even after presidential elections resumed in 1984, the war continued and the military retained enormous influence over policy making.
With 55,000 men, the armed forces today are four times larger than they were 10 years ago, and have the corresponding political clout without the onus of a military man in the Presidency. American training and $1 billion in military aid have helped make them a more effective fighting force, a far cry from the early 1980's, when they were still struggling to shift away from a doctrine of conventional warfare to that of a guerrilla conflict and were routinely implicated in massacres of civilian noncombatants.
But the guerrillas, who 10 years ago were deeply divided on questions of political and military strategy, have also strengthened themselves. At Fidel Castro's urging, they came together in 1980 to form the F.M.L.N. and have operated fairly effectively as a united front, despite an internal dispute in 1983 in which two leaders were killed. Though a ''final offensive'' in 1981 failed, they have demonstrated that they can control significant chunks of territory and sustain a strategy of ''prolonged popular war.''
The result has been a standoff, with each side showing it can keep the other from winning but cannot vanquish the enemy. In that context, this week's peace talks promised to become, in a reversal of van Clausewitz's famous dictum, an extension of the war by other means, with each side apparently set on engaging the other and testing its strength. Last month, the F.M.L.N. offered a three-stage plan to bring the war to an end by Jan. 31, 1990, starting with a Nov. 15 cease-fire accompanied by fundamental reforms of the political, judicial and military systems. At the United Nations Oct. 2, President Alfredo Cristiani raised the ante by calling for a complete and immediate ''cessation of hostilities,'' to be followed by political talks.
''Each side thinks time is on its side,'' said Guillermo Ungo, a member of the original 1979 junta who now leads the Democratic Convergence, a left-center coalition sympathetic to the F.M.L.N. Each side has also called into doubt the sincerity of the other's negotiating position. ''The possibility of winning power by arms has been exhausted, and we have obliged the F.M.L.N. to reconsider its strategy,'' Defense Minister Raphael Larios said in an interview last week. Similarly, the F.M.L.N. dismissed the Government proposal of an immediate cessation of hostilities as a political maneuver designed to undermine them and to avoid having to carry out reforms.
In the meantime, the country's social and economic fabric continues to deteriorate. One million Salvadorans now live in the United States, and the money they send home has become the battered economy's single largest source of foreign exchange. The 5.25 million people who remain here, including hundreds of thousands who have been displaced by fighting in the countryside and a disastrous earthquake three years ago, have seen per capita income slide back to the levels of the early 1960's as jobs, exports and reserves evaporate. Grappling with these problems has proved to be a challenge beyond the ability of any of the Governments of the last decade. Disgusted with economic decline and corruption after five years of rule by the centrist Christian Democratic Party of Jose Napoleon Duarte, voters earlier this year turned to Mr. Cristiani and the strongly right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance, or Arena. The vote capped a remarkable rise to both respectability and power for the party; it was founded in the wake of the 1979 coup by Maj. Roberto d'Aubuisson, whom an American Ambassador here, Robert E. White, once described as a ''pathological killer,'' as well as by other military men linked to death-squad activity and by their allies in the business community. The vote also indicated the collapse of the political center, which had largely favored the early reforms.
If there is any slight solace for the populace in the current state of affairs, it is that violence has diminished somewhat from the levels of a decade ago and become less indiscriminate, although complaints of repression have begun to rise again, since Mr. Cristiani took office in June. Political murders, which took place at a staggering rate of 750 a month in the early 1980's and were mostly attributable to right-wing death squads, had dropped to about 25 a month by 1988; current figures are the subject of intense debate. F.M.L.N. use of mines, assassination of mayors and forced recruitment have also become human rights concerns, although in urban areas the principal manifestation of the war appears to be the rebels' sabotage of the electric, telephone and transportation systems.
All this would seem to point to a situation that is neither immediate peace nor a larger conflict. ''A final victory against the guerrillas is almost impossible,'' a senior military officer acknowledged. ''You have the example of Northern Ireland, or Spain's battle with ETA.''
El Salvador ''is the country of the two-track policy,'' said Ruben Zamora, leader of the Social Christian Popular Movement and a former member of the insurgency's political directorate. ''In this case, it means more talking, but it also means more fighting.''
 
A COUP PLUS A DECADE OF WAR
 
1979-1980: War Breaks Out
Young military officers stage coup, promise free elections, punishment for human rights violations and economic and social reforms. Country polarizes and successive military-civilian juntas find efforts to implement substantial reforms thwarted. Warfare in countryside and violence in cities break out as extreme right and left maneuver for advantage. Right-wing death squads kill thousands, including Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero.
 
1981-1983: U.S. Aid Grows
Guerrillas' ''final offensive'' fails, but fighting continues. Reagan Administration takes office and steps up commitment to military and economic aid. Junta dominated by Christian Democrats gives way to a figurehead civilian interim President.
 
1984-1988: Duarte Is Elected
Presidential election gives victory to Jose Napoleon Duarte, leader of the Christian Democrats. Violence in countryside continues, as American aid grows to more than $3 billion. Christian Democratic Government gradually loses political credibility, and right-wing Arena party wins 1988 Assembly elections. Earthquake in 1986 kills 2,000.
 
1989: The Rightists Take Over
Mr. Duarte's term ends with him immobilized by cancer. Insurgent violence increases in cities. Arena wins presidential election amid predictions of increased repression and a new surge of death-squad activity. Guerrillas and Government float competing peace plans and agree to begin negotiations.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Next Wave From Vietnam: A New Disability

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
WHEN Nguyen Van Be, once a colonel in the South Vietnamese army, emerged from 13 years in a re-education camp last year, he wrote to his wife in Washington, wondering how to fit into a world that had left him behind. ''He feels he got lost somewhere,'' says his wife. ''He feels like someone from the jungle.''
Now Colonel Be is among thousands of former political prisoners waiting for a chance to move to the United States under an agreement reached last summer. Last week, American officials began interviewing freed prisoners in Ho Chi Minh City, the first step toward bringing the first 3,000 to the United States. 
Another 100,000 former prisoners and their families have requested entry into the United States. Vietnamese authorities have put the figure of former prisoners and their families at 500,000.
Resettling this group will be a step toward closing out this nation's debt to its Indochinese wartime allies. ''These people have been detained because of their close association with us during the war,'' said Robert Funseth, the senior deputy assistant secretary of state for refugee affairs, who has spent most of this decade negotiating their resettlement. ''They are of special humanitarian concern to the United States.''
The United States has accepted more than a half million Vietnamese since the first 135,000 fled Vietnam at the end of the war in April 1975. The first were the lucky ones among the South Vietnamese elite, the ones who succeeded in the scramble for planes and helicopters.
During the mass escapes by boat that began in the late 1970's, the United States committed itself to taking 14,000 Vietnamese a month. This exodus included higher proportions of farmers, fishermen, and other villagers, people who did not fit so easily into Western society. There were proportionately fewer ethnic Chinese, with their economic hustle and Chinatown connections. At the same time, the large numbers of refugees began to strain government and private agencies.
Some communities have been transformed by the influx. In California, a state that officials say may be home to nearly half the Vietnamese refugees, the center of Westminster, just south of Los Angeles, is now known as ''Little Saigon.''
The former prisoners, who could begin arriving in the United States before the end of this year, include many former leaders of the South Vietnamese society that the United States was fighting to keep in place.
''There's going to be a lot of the old political leadership, old generals, old ministers, old party leaders,'' said Dawn Calabia, associate director for refugee affairs at the United States Catholic Conference. ''Some of them are going to be very embittered.''
 
The Lost and the Tough
Some, said Donald Cohon, a San Francisco psychologist who has interviewed former inmates, are likely to be ''shells of people, brutalized to the point where they are nonfunctional.'' Most, he said, will have suffered years of malnutrition.
But, as Ms. Calabia said, ''Some are going to turn out to be tough as nails, survivors of the worst the Vietnamese could do.''
There will be men like Nguyen Hau, an army major specializing in ordnance, who was released after being severely injured in a camp, fled by boat to Malaysia, arrived in the United States at the age of 52 and immediately went to school, after a lifetime of military service, to study to become a mechanic.
Mr. Hau, who was a mechanic until the small company he worked for folded recently, now heads a nationwide organization of former Vietnamese political prisoners. Based in Westminster, it is one of the groups that are preparing to help survivors of the re-education camps.
Another group, the Association of Families of Political Prisoners, is headed by Khuc Minh Tho, the wife of Colonel Be, a Government clerical worker with two children and a woman with a keen sense of the difficulties that some of the released men will be facing.
In his first letter after his release, she said, her husband asked the question that was on the minds of most of his fellow prisoners: Have you been faithful to me? Are you still waiting for me?
Some of the wives she knows here, Mrs. Tho said, have found new mates. ''They tell me, 'I don't think the prisoners will ever get out of the camps,' '' she said. ''They tell me they give up.''
Even now, women like Mrs. Tho cannot be certain whether their husbands will be allowed to leave the country or will be held back by the capriciousness that has marked refugee releases in the past.
''I pray,'' Mrs. Tho said, ''that he will be one of the lucky ones.''

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Who Are the Refugees, And Who's Going to Pay?

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN 1980, when Congress established a comprehensive policy on refugees, there was widespread agreement that the Federal Government should pay for their resettlement because the decision to admit them was made entirely by Federal officials. But that consensus is coming under severe strain as the Federal Government cuts payments for refugees' health, education and welfare expenses.
State officials say they can no longer guarantee that the refugee resettlement program will be as successful as it has been for more than a decade. And it has been successful, producing high school valedictorians, college graduates, taxpayers and hundreds of entrepreneurs in such places as Orange County, Calif., and Arlington County, Va. 
''The majority of refugees currently being resettled have much greater needs than those refugees resettled in the past,'' said Ron Spendal, the Oregon state refugee coordinator, who serves as a spokesman for the National Governors Association on the issue.
''The first wave of refugees who came out of Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos were the doctors, lawyers, politicians and military leaders,'' Mr. Spendal said. ''They were highly educated, often spoke English and were easily assimilated. The refugees coming out of Southeast Asia now are farmers and fishermen with much less education, few vocational skills and little English.''
Many of the new Soviet Jewish emigres are well-educated by Soviet standards. But that does not mean it is easy for them to find jobs. Soviet doctors, for example, may need to be retrained as X-ray technicians or physical therapists.
Since 1975, about 1.3 million people have entered the United States as refugees, according to the State Department. Of that total, more than 857,000 were from Indochina. In the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, the Bush Administration plans to admit 125,000 refugees, including 50,000 from the Soviet Union, 6,500 from Eastern Europe, 51,500 from East and Southeast Asia, 6,500 from the Near East and South Asia, 3,000 from Africa and 3,500 from Latin America.
The number of refugees is set annually by the President after consultation with Congress. Federal law does not specify the criteria, except to say the President should weigh ''humanitarian concerns'' and ''the national interest.'' Fiscal constraints limit admissions, even as political, ethnic and religious groups lobby for more.
The quotas are completely separate from those for regular immigrants, who get visas on the basis of family ties or job skills. Under the Refugee Act of 1980, a refugee is a person with ''a well-founded fear of persecution.''
A principal goal of the law is to help refugees achieve economic self-sufficiency quickly. The Federal Government and the states provide services including medical assistance, job training and instruction in the English language. Most refugees arrive with no financial resources.
 
Waning Federal Funds
From early 1980 through March of 1981, the Federal Government reimbursed the states for all cash and medical assistance given to refugees. Starting in April 1981, the Federal Government limited such payments to a refugee's first 36 months in the United States. In March 1986, Washington cut the reimbursement period to 31 months, and in February 1988 to 24 months.
For the current fiscal year, President Bush proposed to cut the reimbursement period to 15 months. Now Congress is providing money for only 12 months. While planning to admit 125,000 refugees, Mr. Bush acknowledged that his budget would pay for the resettlement of only 84,000, at an average cost of $6,300 each. He did not say where the extra money might be found.
Philip A. Holman, acting director of the Federal Office of Refugee Resettlement, in the Department of Health and Human Services, said the cutbacks did not affect refugees because they were entitled to the same cash and medical benefits. The main difference, he said, is that the states pay a larger share.
Walter Barnes, chief of refugee programs in the California Department of Social Services, said: ''These cuts show the inability or unwillingness of Congress and the Administration to meet the commitments laid out in the Refugee Act of 1980. The constant eating away at resources is, I'm afraid, going to eat away public support for the refugee program.''
 
Destination: California
California took 45 percent of the 76,391 refugees who came to the United States in the fiscal year 1988. New York, with 10 percent, accounted for the next largest share, followed by Florida, Massachusetts and Texas.
Experts warn that the cuts in assistance may increase welfare dependency rates by depriving newcomers of the aid they need to become productive workers. Already the rates are substantial: 52 percent of refugees who have been in the United States for less than two years are receiving some form of cash assistance. (Rates ranged from 14 percent for Poles to 40 percent for Soviet refugees and more than 60 percent for Afghans.) Stephen Moore, an economist at the conservative Heritage Foundation, said: ''As with immigrants generally, refugees tend to be strong contributors to the U.S. economy. They have low incomes and high rates of dependency in their initial years in this country. But after 5 to 10 years, their earnings increase substantially.''
Tax data show that Indochinese refugees who arrived in 1975 had incomes slightly higher than the national median by 1986, the Department of Health and Human Services said.
In view of such data, some members of Congress say that refugees should be required to pay back, after some years, a portion of the money spent on their resettlement. By taking that step, said Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, Democrat of Ohio, ''we could take in more refugees.''

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Congress Takes New Interest in the Airline Business

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE years since deregulation of the airlines in 1978 have seen cut-rate fares and high-priced mergers, frequent flyer bonuses and aggravating delays, a doubling of flights and a hopscotch system of traveling along hub-and-spoke routes. For better or worse, the change has never come so fast as this year, leading the Secretary of Transporation, Samuel K. Skinner, to state the obvious: ''What we know as the airline industry today will be dramatically different 10 to 20 years from now.''
That leaves Mr. Skinner, and others in the Federal Government, debating whether the changes should be shaped by the marketplace or managed by Washington - in a word, reregulated. It is clear where the Bush Administration stands. 
''Deregulation is an important part of the economy,'' Mr. Skinner said at an industry gathering last week. ''We are not here to talk about reregulation. That is not on the board for the Bush Administration.''
But on Capitol Hill, meanwhile, some members of Congress appeared bent on bringing the industry under tighter Government control. Although none of their proposals would return the industry to the days when routes, schedules and fares were dictated by the Federal Government, the new ideas represent a tightening of the reins on an industry that for 10 years has been free to do just about what it pleased.
Leaders of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee introduced legislation meant to strengthen the role of the Transportation Department in reviewing leveraged buyouts of airlines, such as the recently proposed takeover of United Airlines. The Senate is considering a similar bill allowing the department to disapprove proposed airline takeovers.
Republican Senators Jack Danforth of Missouri and John McCain of Arizona have introduced separate legislation that addresses the increasing concentration of airline business. Their bill would force airlines to sell off highly profitable computerized reservation systems, which help the airlines that own them to increase their share of the market. The bill would also allow the Transportation Department to grant competing airlines access to airports where one or two companies dominate passenger service.
The recent flurry of leveraged buyouts - takeovers financed mainly with borrowed money - is closely linked, in the eyes of some lawmakers and regulators, to the increasing consolidation of the industry. Two heavily indebted airlines, Eastern and Braniff, have gone bankrupt this year. Others could go under in the event of a recession in the next few years, some analysts believe. And every bankruptcy means a little less competition to hold prices down. Although economists say that airline prices generally have been held down where deregulation has increased competition, the evidence shows that where there is little competition, ticket prices, measured in airline revenues per mile, are higher than average.
Even as the legislative effort to control the industry's metamorphosis procedes, the Transportation Department is rushing to complete a study of airline concentration and competition by Jan. 1.
Jeffrey N. Shane, assistant secretary of transportation for policy, views some of the industry's trends as disturbing. Department statistics show that in 1988, the 10 largest airlines accounted for 94 percent of the miles traveled by domestic passengers, compared with 78 percent in 1984. Also in 1988, 90 percent of the industry's traffic was carried by just 8 carriers, down from 15 airlines five years earlier. And at 20 of the 27 largest ''hub'' airports, where many flights connect, two airlines control more than half of all flights.
On the other hand, Mr. Shane said, most of the growth in air travel since deregulation has been along routes where passengers are able to choose among at least three airlines. The problem, he said, is that airlines prefer to expand service in cities where they already dominate the market, rather than competing for new territory. This strategy, he said, ''strongly suggests'' that the creation of new competition ''will be the exception rather than the rule.''
In the five years after airline deregulation was enacted in 1978, dozens of new airlines opened shop. In the past five years, most of them went bankrupt or were merged into larger airlines. Experts say that easing the entry of new competitors into the marketplace will require changes in arcane industry practices and fine points of law. At many airports, for example, the airlines' leases preclude airport operators from permitting new competitors to use the airport. Some experts believe that if airports were allowed to charge passengers departure fees, now prohibited on domestic flights, the operators would be less dependent on rental income from airlines and able to demand the right to grant gate space to competing airlines.
Many industry experts fear that unless the capacity of the air transportation system is increased, new competitors will be frozen out. But they are in no hurry for Washington's help. As Oris W. Dunham, Jr., the executive director of Dallas/ Fort Worth International Airport, puts it: ''There are two things everyone agrees on: No. 1, the system isn't working the way it is; No. 2., we don't want Congress to fix it for us.''

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
An Energy Glut in the Ground Imperils Ecological Hopes

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
FOSSIL fuel reserves, almost always discussed with the modifier ''dwindling'' attached, are now growing rapidly. The conventional wisdom of the 1970's was that the world was running out of oil, coal and natural gas. But in the last three years governments and the companies that do the drilling and mining have found far more than has been extracted.
This is not unalloyed good news. Combustion of fuel is the main source of carbon dioxide and other gases believed responsible for global warming, and with current price and supply trends, carbon dioxide emissions could rise by 70 percent between 1985 and 2020, according to a study released by the World Energy Conference, a London-based association of energy engineers, at its convention last month in Montreal. 
Scarcity and high price, once in everyone's forecast, now seem less likely to limit consumption. It looks now as though any incentives to reduce fuel use, thus slowing the greenhouse effect or cutting air pollution, will have to come from governments, not the marketplace.
 
Political Factors
Prices are likely to rise, especially as more of the oil supply is concentrated in OPEC countries. But short-term price increases work against long-term price increases; they quickly dampen demand and increase the incentive to find more oil, gas and coal, which tends to bring prices back down.
In addition, oil is equated with political power in locations as diverse as Texas and Teheran, and governments in both places will look for more oil for reasons other than economic.
According to a survey by the energy conference, the quantity of ''proved recoverable'' oil reserves -the amount of oil in the ground estimated to be recoverable under existing price levels and technology - is up by 30 percent over the last three years to about 890 billion barrels. Even more striking is the reversal in the years of supply remaining, up from 28.2 in 1979 to more than 45, according to Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting company in Cambridge, Mass.
The increase in the number of years of supply represented by the reserves is only partly the product of growing reserves; the other factor is a slowing in demand caused by higher prices and conservation efforts. When prices peaked in 1983, demand dropped to 19.2 billion barrels from 22.9 billion barrels in 1979, a decrease of 16 percent.
Consumption will be back up near the 1979 peak this year because of stable prices and strong economic growth, especially in Asia, according to the Cambridge group. But the fact that consumption has ceased galloping ahead at ever-higher levels has increased the number of years existing supplies will last.
All this ''new'' oil in the ground is of little consolation to the United States. Last year, according to a study by Arthur Andersen & Company, oil companies in this country found only a bit more than half as much oil as they pumped out of the ground. Over the long term they obviously must find as much oil as they produce, or eventually they will have nothing left to drill for.
Production in the continental United States and Alaska is falling by about 7 percent a year. Imports in some months have exceeded domestic production, something that hasn't happened in nearly a decade. The bulk of the additions to reserves, meanwhile, were in Iran, Iraq, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela, all members of OPEC, and three of them in the Persian Gulf.
The growing OPEC reserves are not a reflection of geology but of politics. Cash-hungry OPEC members are forever arguing over the quota of oil they are allowed to pump each year, and one negotiating card the member countries bring to the table is the ratio of their production to their reserves. The bigger their known supplies underground, the stronger the argument they can make that they deserve to be allowed to produce more.
Iran and Iraq, until recently rivals on the battlefield and now competitors in OPEC, would each like more income to rebuild their economies. So Iran added 48 billion barrels to its estimate, and Iraq, 56 billion. The United Arab Emirates, which habitually produces more than its assigned quota, added 66 billion. These countries have always known that if they spent more money on exploration, they could increase proven reserves, but with decades or centuries of future supply in the ground, there was not much need to look.
Meanwhile, reserves of natural gas, once thought to be even more limited than oil, are doubling every 10 years, according to the World Energy Conference. Gas requires greater capital investment to transport, and is hard to move at all by sea unless prices rise above a certain level. Thus it is not as widely traded as oil, though that seems likely to change.
 
Low-Profile Fuels
But as with oil the news does not favor the United States. The Soviet Union's reserves are estimated at 1.5 million billion cubic feet, followed by Iran with about one-third as much, and then the United Arab Emirates and the United States, each with about one-seventh as much as the Soviets, or about 200,000 billion cubic feet.
Coal, like natural gas, is a lower-profile fuel because it can be used in fewer applications and is not traded as widely. But reserves of coal are up an astounding 80 percent in the last three years, according to the World Energy Conference, to nearly 1.1 trillion tons. The study traced most of the increase to China, which is planning a large industrialization drive. China says it has 610 billion tons; the United States, 113 billion, and the Soviet Union, 104 billion.
With growing concern about the greenhouse effect, word that supplies of fossil fuels are ample is a bit like telling a person who is dangerously overweight that the refrigerator is fully stocked. At the end of the 1970's and early 1980's, when oil was $40 a barrel and some analysts said it would reach $100 by the end of the century, the energy problem looked as though it might be self-correcting; as the price rose, oil use would be replaced by nuclear or solar power or conservation. In recent years, however, oil prices have been so low that even natural gas has had trouble competing; nuclear power has largely priced itself out of the market, and solar power, down in cost by a factor of 10, is still too expensive for most uses.
More exotic technologies, like hydrogen, wind or ocean thermal energy, have been driven into the background. When the idea of scarcity allowed the price of fossil fuels to rise, those alternatives were aiming for targets that were getting closer. When prices fell, the targets got farther away.
