SECTION: Section 8; Page 2, Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1134 words

HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES;
Heady Past Bore Giants and A's to Present

BYLINE: By LEONARD KOPPETT

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
The Giants and the Athletics are two of the oldest franchises and hallowed names in baseball history, but as San Francisco and Oakland they are 3,000 miles away from their origins and are meeting in a World Series for the first time since thier transcontinental migration.
The New York Gothams, who acquired the nickname Giants a few years later, entered the National League in 1883, the league's eighth season. They won 17 pennants before leaving New York, but only one in 31 seasons in San Francisco before this year. That was in 1962, when they lost the World Series in seven games to the Yankees. 
The Philadelphia Athletics were charter members of the American League in 1901, appropriating a famous name associated with Philadelphia teams since before the Civil War. They won eight pennants before moving to Kansas City in 1955. Never even a contender there, they moved to Oakland in 1968 and won three consecutive World Series, in 1972-74, the only team to win three in succession in the last 36 years.
They did not reach another World Series until last year, when they lost to the Los Angeles Dodgers in five games.
In general, then, both the Athletics and the Giants enjoyed more success in the first half of this century than since.
For the Giants, it all started in the last century. When the National League was formed in 1876, as a new concept in sports organization, there was a New York team called the Mutuals, which actually played in Brooklyn. There was a team in Philadelphia called the Athletics.
When these two teams refused to make their final scheduled Western trips (to avoid expense and to make money playing nonleague games close to home), they were expelled, and the league went on without teams from its two largest cities for six years.
In 1883, a new franchise for New York was granted to John B. Day, who already owned a New York team in the other league, the American Association. That team was the Metropolitans. Day called his new league team the Gothams. The teams played on adjoining diamonds at the Polo Grounds, just north of Central Park at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street.
Day and his manager, Jim Mutrie, kept shifting players between the two teams, collecting the best ones on the National League team, since it sold 50-cent tickets, compared with the American Association's 25 cents. By 1886, Mutrie was so impressed with his team that he declared, ''My men are giants.'' From then on, they were the New York Giants.
In 1888 and 1889, the Giants won the National League pennant and the World Series (against the American Association champion). But they did not flourish again until John McGraw arrived in 1902. The American League, raiding the National League for stars, had meanwhile established its major league status, and in 1903 the champions of the two leagues played the World Series.
In 1904, McGraw's Giants won a pennant but refused to play Boston, which had won in the new American League. This led to much criticism, and when the Giants finished first again in 1905, permanent rules for a World Series were drawn up by John T. Brush, then the owner of the Giants.
McGraw's greatest find was Christy Mathewson. In the 1905 World Series, Mathewson pitched three shutouts in six days against Connie Mack's Philadelphia team, which had appropriated the name ''Athletics.''
McGraw's teams won pennants in 1911, 1912, 1913, 1917, 1921, 1922, 1923 and 1924, but won the World Series only two more times, in 1921 and 1922.
The wooden Polo Grounds burned in April 1911, and the building was replaced by a steel and concrete structure, which was ready by June. This was the building, gradually enlarged through 1924, that became the ''real'' Polo Grounds. In 1913-22, the Yankees also played there (before Yankee Stadium was built), and the Mets began life there in 1962 and 1963. Meanwhile, in 1919, Charles Stoneham had bought the Giants, and ran it as a family enterprise.
McGraw did not step down as manager until 1932, when he turned the team over to Bill Terry, who was still its star first baseman. Under Terry, with pitchers led by Carl Hubbell and home runs provided by Mel Ott, the Giants won the World Series in 1933 and lost it to the Yankees in 1936 and 1937.
Then came a decade of decline. Ott replaced Terry as manager in 1942. Horace Stoneham, Charles's son, had succeeded him in 1936.
In midseason of 1948, Leo Durocher suddenly replaced Ott. Durocher had been, for 10 years, the archtypical hated Brooklyn Dodger. But in less than four years, he led the Giants to their greatest glory - at Brooklyn's expense.
Trailing the Dodgers by 13 1/2 games in August 1951, the Giants caught up and won a three-game playoff on a ninth-inning home run by Bobby Thomson. The World Series was lost again, to the Yankees, but when Durocher's team won again in 1954, it swept the Cleveland Indians in the Series in four games.
Nevertheless, Durocher, who did not get along with Stoneham, was gone after 1955. Attendance kept running a distant third to the annually more successful Yankees and Dodgers. Plans to build a new stadium in Manhattan fell through.
Stoneham knew he would have to move the team, and was prepared to take them to Minneapolis. But Walter O'Malley was moving his Dodgers to Los Angeles, and wouldn't a double move to California make more sense? It would. Stoneham went to San Francisco. The Athletics, as one of the eight original members of the American League when it went major in 1901, had Mack as part-owner as well as manager from the start. He built, gradually, the best team of its time, and won pennants in 1910, 1911, 1913 and 1914.
That made his stars expensive. A third major league, the Federal, pushed up all salary scales. World War I was causing economic problems. So Mack dismantled his champions by selling off the stars, and finished last for seven successive years.
Then he built an even greater team, which dethroned the legendary Babe Ruth Yankees in 1929, 1930 and 1931. With the onset of the Depression, he again sold off the stars to pay his bills. The Athletics were never again a contender in Philadelphia.
Mack managed through 1950, when he was 87. The National League Phillies had become winners, and the city could not sustain both teams. The Athletics were sold and moved to Kansas City in 1955. In 13 seasons there, they never finished higher than sixth, and that high only the first season.
In 1961, the club was bought by Charles O. Finley, a Chicago insurance man, who promptly began threatening to move it elsewhere: to Louisville, Seattle, Dallas, or, ultimately, Oakland.
But he also started collecting outstanding young players, and when he finally did go to Oakland, in 1968, he brought with him the nucleus of a winner that would match Mack's greatest achievements.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 15, 1989

SECTION: Section 8; Page 3, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1702 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL NOTEBOOK;
Hits Are Nice, but You Can't Win Without Scoring Runs

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
Shawon Dunston is best known as a fine-fielding, hard-throwing shortstop of the Chicago Cubs, but during the recent National League playoff, he stood in the middle of the Cubs' clubhouse and played baseball philosopher, raising a series of interesting questions.
''Do you think Matt Williams will hit for average next year?'' he asked a reporter many years his senior and supposedly wiser.
''Which would you rather have, batting average or runs batted in?'' ''Is batting average overrated?'' Williams, the third baseman for the San Francisco Giants, the team that beat the Cubs to the World Series, prompted Dunston's inquisitive and pensive thoughts. He batted only .202 this season but hit 18 home runs and drove in 50 runs. Despite his anemic average, Williams was one of 45 players who hit 18 or more home runs and one of 120 players who drove in 50 runs or more. 
None of the other 44 hitters had a better home-runs-to-hits ratio and only two of the other 119 had better r.b.i.-to-hits ratios.
So Dunston's questions, at least the second and third ones, were properly thought-provoking. If Williams could drive in 50 runs with a .202 average compiled on only 59 hits, is average overrated? And if a player had to settle for a high average with a low number of r.b.i. or a low average with a high number of r.b.i., which would be preferred?
In the first instance, average in some cases could be overrated, but it could be argued that if Williams had hit for a higher average, he could have driven in even more runs.
In the second, most baseball people agree that runs, not hits, win games. Certainly, batters have to get hits to get on base so someone can drive them in, but so many are left on that most hits are wasted. It's the player who can bring the runners home who is valuable and most necessary to victories.
Williams, whose hitting has restricted him to partial major league seasons the past three years, would like to provide a ''yes'' answer to Dunston's first question. If Mike Schmidt is any example, he will, if not next season, then in the seasons thereafter.
Williams's performance this year was remarkably similar to Schmidt's effort in 1973, his first full season in the majors. Batting 75 more times than Williams did this year, Schmidt batted .196, hit 18 home runs and drove in 52 runs. His ratios were not as good as those achieved by Williams, and he struck out more frequently, once every 2.7 times at bat to once every 4.1 for Williams.
Schmidt raised his average the next season by nearly 100 points, to .282, and finished his Hall of Fame career with a .267 average.
For Williams this season, one out of every 3.28 hits was a home run. That was a better ratio than Kevin Mitchell, his teammate, had in leading the majors with 47 home runs. One of every 3.36 hits was a home run for Mitchell.
With r.b.i., only Jose Canseco and Jack Clark used their hits more efficiently. Williams averaged .847 of a run batted in for every hit he had (50 r.b.i., 59 hits). Canseco's ratio was .934 (57, 61) and Clark's was .855 (94, 110).
By comparison with players who hit for high averages, of the four players who reached the 200-hit plateau, Wade Boggs had a ratio of .263 of an r.b.i. for each hit, Tony Gwynn was at .305, Steve Sax .307 and Kirby Puckett .395.
Viewing Williams's performance from another angle, he was one of five players who drove in exactly 50 runs. While he collected 59 hits, Ozzie Smith took 162 to do it, Robby Thompson 132, Steve Lyons 117 and Lance Parrish 103.
Hitters, of course, drive in runs without hits and their r.b.i. totals often depend on their position in the batting order. The hitless r.b.i., however, represent a tiny percentage of the total, and many players bat in advantageous spots and don't capitalize on them.
In other words, or in Dunston's words, ''Two-oh-two, 18 home runs, 50 runs batted in - that's amazing.''
 
The Henderson Question
 When Rickey Henderson was hitting in the .240's and not stealing bases for the Yankees earlier this season, he posed a puzzling question: With his contract expiring at the end of the season, why wasn't he turning on the retrorockets that make him the special kind of player the Yankees saw in 1985, his first year with them?
That Rickey could get a $3 million-a-year contract. This Rickey was getting a $2.4 million-a-year offer from the Yankees and they were in no way comfortable offering that.
A few months and one league championship series later, Henderson has made the Oakland Athletics uncomfortable. His price as an impending free agent has skyrocketed, and the Athletics are in a position where they have to decide if they can afford to let him go for a second time, saying they can't or won't pay what it would take to re-sign him. They offered that explanation when they traded him to the Yankees five years ago.
''We haven't had a word from them,'' Richie Bry, Henderson's agent, said. ''I called Sandy Alderson to congratulate him the day after they won the playoffs and he said, 'I'll talk to you when this is all over.' I think that's the appropriate thing to do.''
Bry said he didn't know if Henderson would re-sign with Oakland; nor did he say if Henderson wanted to become the first $3 million-a-year player.
''We last discussed what he wanted in spring training,'' the agent said. ''That's out of date now.''
Barring an uncharacteristically quick and overwhelming offer from the Athletics, Henderson will file for free agency later this month. Most likely the teams that will command his interest will be the Athletics, the Yankees and the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Without discussing prospective suitors, Bry said, ''Rickey likes the limelight.''
 
Measuring by Barfield
 Jesse Barfield has set the economic standard for this year's prospective free agents. He agreed to a three-year contract with the Yankees for $5.4 million. He was coming off a three-year contract worth $4.2 million, and his production declined drastically during the life of that contract.
In 1986, he batted .289, hit 40 home runs and drove in 108 runs. His average in succeeding seasons fell to .263, .244 and .234. His home runs and r.b.i. plummeted the first two years, to 28 and 18 and to 84 and 56, but they inched back up this season to 23 and 67. Under his new deal, he will receive a $500,000 signing bonus and salaries the next three years of $1.1 million, $1.8 million and $2 million.
 
Careful Wording
 What's most important in the minds of baseball owners these days as labor negotiations approach?
The Texas Rangers chose not to exercise the option in Charlie Hough's contract for 1990 at a salary of $900,000. Then they re-signed him for $1 million.
The reason: Under the old contract, they would have had to pay the veteran pitcher even if they locked out the players, as the players suspect they will, next year. In the new contract, Hough agreed to what is called ''neutral'' lockout language, meaning that if there is a lockout, an arbitrator will decide if Hough and many other players with similar clauses should be paid.
 
Like a Loser
 Most sports teams like to copy winners, but in Cincinnati, Marge Schott, the Reds' owners, obviously likes to copy losers: the Yankees.
In naming Bob Quinn as the Reds' general manager, Schott has now hired three consecutive general managers who with George Steinbrenner's invaluable assistance oversaw losers in New York. Bill Bergesch and Murray Cook were the first two.
Under Steinbrenner, of course, no one ever really is a general manager in the true sense of the title. His latest setup epitomizes the Steinbrenner method.
The man presumably in charge of front-office operations - that is, when Steinbrenner isn't on the phone or in his office - is George Bradley, who has the title of vice president for player development and scouting. Bradley, however, works out of the Yankees' minor league complex in Tampa, Fla. The arrangement has prompted baseball comments about the Yankees' running a major league organization in a minor league way.
Obviously, they have telephones in Tampa, but they don't play major league games there for a would-be trademaker to see the players he might want to trade for.
To replace Quinn, the Yankees have hired Harding (Pete) Peterson, who becomes the 14th man in the 17-year Steinbrenner regime to have the title or so-called responsibility of general manager. Peterson, though, has been out of baseball for four years, since the Pittsburgh Pirates dismissed him as their long-time general manager after he almost single-handedly allowed the franchise to deteriorate to the point where the city almost lost the team.
The man who saved the Pirates for Pittsburgh was Syd Thrift, who replaced Peterson and who was dismissed three years later because he didn't conduct business the way the owners wanted him to. Thrift became the Yankees' top front-office man last March, then resigned last month.
It has become a mind-boggling business, but general managers of other teams keep things straight when dealing with the Yankees by understanding Yankee reality.
Asked whom he calls if he wants to talk trade with the Yankees, one general manager said simply, ''George.'' He meant Steinbrenner, not Bradley.

HEADLINE: TALKING: Parking Space;
Protecting Rights in a Conversion

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
IN New York City, where garage space rents for as much as a small apartment and a single space sells for more than $20,000, it is little wonder that the right to a rent-stabilized parking space, or at least the right to retain a place on a building's waiting list, has become an issue worth fighting for.
The right to such a space has long been included in most rent-stabilized leases, provided the building had an underground or surface parking area. Charges were subject to the same limitations as the apartment itself. If a space was not immediately available, at least the tenant had the right to a place on a waiting list. 
However, according to officials and lawyers familiar with these buildings, these spaces, as they become vacant, are increasingly being ''warehoused'' by sponsors rather than being given to the next resident on the list. The sponsor is thus able to provide a purchase incentive to prospective buyers during a conversion to co-op or condominium ownership.
After conversion, most co-op corporations or condominium associations have continued to award vacated spaces exclusively to purchasers - in effect, tearing up any existing list. ''There is no doubt in my mind that preferential treatment is routinely given to buyers and existing shareholders,'' said Stuart Saft, vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives.
Lately, however, the outcry from nonpurchasing tenants has become so loud that both the Attorney General's office, which supervises conversions, and the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, the state agency supervising rent regulation, have issued statements. They were an official memorandum from the Attorney General and a public letter from Richard L. Higgins, Commissioner of the division, to the Park West Village Tenants' Association, an organization of 1,100 tenants in seven Upper West Side buildings undergoing condominium conversion. Both were intended to make certain that parking rights are no longer denied a nonpurchasing tenant during or after a conversion.
According to the Attorney General's memo, such behavior violates the General Business and Multiple Dwelling Laws. The division reaffirms that a nonpurchasing tenant must have access to the same services as existed before conversion, including the right to parking.
While the language of both documents appears to indicate that both co-op boards and sponsors must refrain in the future from such practices, lawyers maintain that such edicts may not be so easily enforced, at least in conversions that have already taken place.
Goldie Rotenberg, a Manhattan lawyer specializing in co-op conversions, maintains, for example, that the division has no control over a co-op corporation - only over the owner of an individual apartment. And while it has the authority to award the nonpurchasing tenant a decrease in rent to reflect the loss of the right to a parking space, or require reinstatement, the burden would be on the owner-investor to make good. And that investor might have to sue a reluctant co-op corporation to do so.
Adrienne Kivelson, director of program development for the division's office of Rent Administration, agrees there is a practical enforcement problem. ''We realize there are different sets of circumstances in these buildings,'' she said, ''and we are attempting to come up with solutions even if it means involving other government agencies.''
MR. SAFT expects sponsors to sue the Attorney General's office - as has happened over other issues - maintaining that it may have exceeded its authority by trying to get involved in the parking issue, especially after conversion. Office officials concede this is likely should a complaint be filed by a nonpurchasing tenant. Further, if the sponsor no longer holds a voting majority in the co-op corporation, he may insist he can do nothing anyway. ''It could become very messy,'' said Mr. Saft.
Georgia Malone, another lawyer specializing in co-op issues, asserts that nonpurchasing tenants could now be inadvertently encouraged to abuse the system. They might seek a space to make conversion more difficult or costly for the sponsor. Or they might try to profit from that right by making an under-the-table deal to sublet the parking space to an outsider.
All of which creates a profusion of new challenges for co-op corporations, condominium boards, private investors who own apartments occupied by nonpurchasing tenants and the nonpurchasing tenants themselves. All these parties might be well served by consulting a lawyer if parking rights are at issue.
However, some general guidelines can be offered. Tenants in buildings now undergoing conversion, or those slated for conversion, can rest assured that their parking rights will be better protected in future.
Mary Sabantini DiStephan, an assistant Attorney General who handles conversion plans, said that conversions of buildings with on-site parking will no longer be approved unless a plan clearly states that any tenant on a parking-space waiting list maintains that position after conversion. This was not done in the past, she said, because ''we had been unaware of this sort of violation.''
However, if the garage or parking area was never part of the building's regular services and mentioned in the lease, but instead was owned or operated as a totally independent business, the residents will not be able to gain any such rights, she noted.
After conversion, she added, the owner of an apartment occupied by a nonpurchasing tenant may, in some instances, be required to make up the difference between the market-rate for that parking space and the rent- regulated amount, as is now being done on the apartment itself.
Not necessarily so, argues Ms. Rotenberg. The responsibility for paying the difference could also hinge on other matters, such as past policy of the co-op corporation concerning nonpurchasing tenants who already have spaces or the language of any lease held by a garage operator toward subsidizing such tenants.
Ms. Rotenberg also said that tenants and investors should be aware that the responsibility of a co-op corporation to reinstitute parking rights to nonpurchasing tenants could also be governed by the language of the conversion plan. Some older plans did, in fact, guarantee those rights to renters, thus binding the corporation. A careful check, she said, may therefore be warranted before further action is considered.

HEADLINE: Dune Law

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on Michigan's lakefront-dune law [''Battlelines Form on Michigan's New Rules,'' Aug. 13] describes the development of dune property, but falls short in discussing the complex issues of what constitutes a ''taking'' when the private use of a natural resource, e.g. a lakefront dune, is circumscribed by concerns for public welfare.
It ignores recent United States Supreme Court decisions supporting laws limiting the extent to which property owners can exploit a resource if such use is detrimental to the public welfare, i.e., Keystone Bituminous Coal Association v. DeBenedictis. 
In this case, the Court noted that ''long ago it was recognized that all property in this country is held under the implied obligation that the owner's use of it shall not be injurious to the community.'' The Michigan legislation is premised on the belief that the protection and preservation of dunes closest to the water are in the interest of the whole community. Overall, the Supreme Court has been inconsistent in its rulings on what constitutes a ''taking.''
Furthermore, conservationists argue that the protection of these dunes is the state's responsibility under the so-called ''public trust doctrine'' - the obligation of the state to protect the public's common heritage in streams and navigable waters. They say it should be extended to include protection of various environmental and ecological resources. The Michigan Legislature in enacting the lakefront-dune law appears to be fulfilling its obligation as public trustee for this complex ecological resource vital to the Michigan public.
The controversy surrounding the Michigan law points to the problems of reconciling the protection of complex environmental resources with existing laws protecting private property.
 
STEVEN E. KRAFT
 Carbondale, Ill.
 
The writer is a professor in the Department of Agribusiness Economics at Southern Illinois University at Carbondale.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Fort Greene

BYLINE: By YANICK RICE LAMB

 BODY:
WHEN Fort Greene residents want a night on the town, they can stay close to home. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music and its Majestic Theater, there is everything from ballet to opera to jazz. Sheila's Restaurant offers such musicians as the violinist Noel Pointer, and drama and comedy can be found at the Cecil Alonzo Theater, the Paul Robeson Theater and the Restoration Project Theater Company.
''It's a lot like Greenwich Village, but not as funky,'' said Eric Allison, a local historian who owns a brownstone on Lafayette Avenue. ''There are a lot of artists who live here.'' The neighborhood also has the 1929 Williamsburgh Bank Building, surmounted by a clock tower with four faces, each 27 feet in diameter. At 512 feet, the building is Brooklyn's tallest. And that's not all, for all three of the city's subway lines traverse the neighborhood. Richard Sommer, a vice president in corporate bond trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert, said that it took him 35 minutes to reach lower Manhattan when he lived on the Upper West Side. He now has a 10-minute commute from Fort Greene, where he recently bought a brownstone on Carlton Avenue for $475,000. 
''We have a jumble of all different styles of architecture on any given block,'' said Mr. Allison, a member of the Fort Greene Landmarks Preservation Committee, referring to the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Fort Greene Historic Districts. In 1983, he and his wife, Mary Ann, paid $115,000 for an 1857 Italianate brownstone, one of many rooming houses carved out of what were once fine homes during the Depression. They spent $100,000 more to renovate the four-story structure. Such brownstones - many of which have been divided into two and four units over the years - now sell for as much as $500,000, said Earl Drummond of Renaissance Properties. Houses in the $300,000 range go quickly, he added. Audrey Edwards of Plaza Properties recently sold a boarded-up, four-family house on Clermont Avenue for $275,000.
Fort Greene has a handful of large co-op apartment buildings, among them the 200-unit Griffin on Lafayette Avenue at South Oxford Street and University Towers, three 15-story towers at Willoughby Street and Ashland Place. Studios and one-bedrooms at the Griffin are $50,000 to $110,000, with a two-bedroom penthouse for $200,000. At University Towers, prices are $42,000 to $141,000 for studios to three-bedroom apartments in a conversion that is expected to be declared effective soon.
MR. DRUMMOND said both co-ops and rentals - one bedrooms for $650 to $850 and two-bedrooms for $850 to $1,400 - are readily available.
Just five years ago, co-ops were as low as $30,000 and some rentals were a few hundred dollars. In 1976, Melba Tolliver, an anchor for ''News 12 Long Island,'' paid $60,000 for a five-story rooming house on Lafayette. The 1863 Italianate brownstone, which was featured in the 1988 Fort Greene House Tour and has two duplexes and a floor-through apartment, was recently appraised at $500,000.
Prices started climbing in 1978 after both historic districts were designated by the city that year. The market was further stimulated by the flurry of development by the architect Stephen B. Jacobs and others, as well as the anticipation of the Metrotech office complex, which is under construction close by in downtown Brooklyn.
The wave of renewal has not, as it has in some communities, wiped out the racial, ethnic and economic diversity in Fort Greene - a fact that residents, almost without exception, note with pride. More than half of the 42,000 residents are black, some the descendants of shipbuilders who settled there in the mid-1800's.
An Italian settler, Pieter Cesar, became the first resident in the 17th century. The ferries that began operating in the early 1800's made it convenient for businessmen and skilled laborers to live in Brooklyn and commute to Manhattan. By the 1850's, residential development had spread beyond Brooklyn Heights to Fort Greene, where farmers had subdivided and sold their land. Wealthier residents began to head for the suburbs in the late 19th century, and by the mid-20th century, many houses had fallen into disrepair.
Many say Fort Greene still carries an undeserved reputation for crime. ''Fort Greene has been fortunate in the recent crime epidemic,'' said Abigail Golde, publisher of The Hill, a community newsletter. Even Ms. Tolliver, who has been mugged and whose house has been broken into several times over the years, has noticed some change. ''I don't think it's as bad as it was,'' she said. ''I see fewer people just hanging around.''
''There's more crime in Brooklyn Heights than there is over here,'' said Emile Dufau, a detective at the 88th Precinct, which covers Fort Greene. ''I think this community is a very good community to live in.''
In the 88th Precinct, there were 5,680 felonies and 4,131 misdemeanors in 1988. In the 84th Precinct, which includes Brooklyn Heights, felonies and misdemeanors for the same period numbered 6,501 and 6,488, respectively.
RESIDENTS also value the 33-acre Fort Greene Park, designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, who also designed Central and Prospect Parks. Rising from its center is the 1908 Prison Ship Martyrs' Monument, designed by Stanford White and honoring 11,500 Americans who died on British ships in Wallabout Bay - later the site of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. During the Revolutionary War, George Washington retreated to Manhattan from what is now the park but then was Fort Putnam.
Today, tennis on six courts and jogging are among the activities at the park, which was featured in Spike Lee's film ''She's Gotta Have It.'' Mr. Lee, who lives across the street on Washington Park, recently renovated a building on St. Felix Street for his Mo' Better Movie Company. His 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks is around the corner on Dekalb Avenue.
Across from the park is Brooklyn Technical High School, which accepts students by citywide examination. The school offers its 4,600 students 12 majors, including computer science, biomedicine and engineering. ''Virtually 100 percent of our students graduate,'' said the principal, John P. Tobin. ''We get many capable, well-prepared young people from the local schools,'' he added. Among them are P.S. 20, or the Clinton Hill School, on Adelphi Street and Junior High School 113, known as the Ronald Edmonds Learning Center, on Clermont. Both schools stress integrated learning, which incorporates subjects like science into other classes, said Argie K. Johnson, Superintendent of Community School District 13.
J.H.S. 113 has five tracks, or subschools, for media communications, performing arts, the gifted, business/technology and special education. The Jacques D'Amboise Dance Company and Il Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera have also taught classes at the school. P.S. 20 also offers special education and programs for the gifted.
Also in Fort Greene are the Roman Catholic Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School and Queen of All Saints elementary school and the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University, which is on the site of the old Brooklyn Paramount Theater.
If residents could make any changes in Fort Greene, they would add a large supermarket and a few more shops to supplement those beginning to open on Fulton and Myrtle. Among the popular restaurants are Sheila's, Cino's, Cellar's, Greene's Grill, Miss Ann's and Two Steps Down, which is doubling its seating capacity from 50 to 110 in response to demand.
Mr. Jacobs, who recently opened General Greene's Emporium on South Portland, which sells gourmet food and housewares, said he might consider more commercial development. ''If we don't lose our shirts with this store,'' he said, ''maybe.''
 
GAZETTEER
 
Population: 42,000 (1989 estimate).
 
Median family income: $23,000 (1986 estimate).
 
Median price of brownstone: $350,000.
 
Median price of one-bedroom co-op: $92,500.
 
Median rent of one-bedroom apartment: $750.
 
Distance to midtown Manhattan: 6 miles.
 
Rush-hour commutation to midtown: 20 minutes by A, B, C, D, G, M, N, Q, R, 2, 3, 4 and 5 trains.
 
Government: Councilwoman Mary Pinkett (Democrat-Liberal).
 
Generally Speaking: Fort Greene Park is named for Gen. Nathaniel Greene, who supervised the building of a line of Brooklyn fortifications in 1776 that included the present park site. It was first known as Fort Putnam - for Gen. Rufus Putnam, who designed the fort itself - and it soon fell to the British in the Battle of Long Island. In the War of 1812, it was rebuilt and renamed Fort Greene. The park's architects, Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux, named it Washington Park, but residents persisted in calling it Fort Greene Park and the name stuck.

HEADLINE: Business Survey Finds Confidence in State Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
IN a survey of 1,200 state businesses, the Connecticut Business and Industry Association last week said that it had found a profound lack of confidence in the state government's economic policies.
The association, the state's largest pro-business lobby, said that the approval of $800 million in new state taxes this year ''has eroded employers' confidence in Connecticut as a good place to do business'' and that three out of five businesses surveyed would be more likely to relocate out of state than in Connecticut. 
These are the main findings of the survey, which was made public on Wednesday:
* Fully 85 percent of Connecticut's businesses lack confidence in the state government's ability to make decisions that will strengthen the state's economy; 55 percent said they were ''not very confident'' in state government, and 30 percent said they were ''not at all confident.''
* Sixty-two percent said they would be most likely to relocate in or expand to another state if they were to expand or move their companies; 36 percent said they would expand in Connecticut.
* Anti-Connecticut sentiment was highest among manufacturing businesses: 73 percent of them said they would either relocate or expand out of state.
Of those who said they would relocate or expand out of state, 62 percent said their primary reason for leaving would be lower business taxes.
The survey found one trend encouraging to businesses: the state's labor shortage appears to be easing.
The percentage of businesses that said they were having difficulty finding professional workers dropped to 27 percent this year, from 44 percent last year. The shortage of technical workers dropped to 45 percent, from 64 percent last year, and the shortage of production workers dropped to 55 percent from 79 percent.

HEADLINE: House Built by Students Awaits a Buyer and Site

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: TOMS RIVER

 BODY:
IT is apparent that real estate is in a slump when a new two-bedroom house in Ocean County is advertised at $16,000 for four months and does not sell.
This house, however, does not have a yard, or any land at all. This is a house without a home.
''It's the third one we've built,'' said Ray Gudzak, a teacher at the Ocean County Vocational-Technical School, ''and I have to tell you, I'm disappointed.'' 
Mr. Gudzak teaches construction technology at the 1,700-student vocational school here. For the last three years, students in his class have designed and built a house, beam by beam, from the ground up.
 
'I Built That House'
When the house is finished, usually in June, and after the annual ''post-construction party'' (''Hamburgers, hot dogs, girlfriends and boyfriends,'' Mr. Gudzak said), the building is sold at auction and the proceeds used to finance the next year's project.
This year's sale was to be held during the Aug. 15 school board meeting. Advertisements were placed in local newspapers, and throughout the summer students who participated in the project would pass by with their friends, point to the building and say, ''I built that house.''
In years past, spirited bidding usually drove the price a few thousand dollars above the $16,000 minimum bid. But this year, something went wrong.
''I couldn't believe it,'' Mr. Gudzak said recently. ''I got to the August school board meeting and no one was there.''
The sale was postponed a few weeks, he said, and then a few weeks more, while school officials waited for bidders to appear.
 
No Lack of Bidders Before
''The bottom just dropped out of the real-estate market,'' said the school principal, George Sampson, Jr. ''We've never had any trouble selling the houses before.''
John Dusenbery, 18 years old, a student who worked on the project, said: ''I know it isn't us. I know we did a bang-up job on that house.''
Mr. Gudzak agrees. ''This is a great accomplishment for the boys,'' he said. ''They worked hard; it's a good house.''
One of the problems, Mr. Sampson said, is that the house had to be designed relatively small to keep moving costs to a minimum. But at 1,072 square feet, the building fails to meet the minimum zoning requirements of many towns in the area.
In addition, he said, whoever buys the house must already own the land to put it on and have the funds needed to complete the interior. The kitchen and bath must be installed, the walls need Sheetrock and painting, and the floors must be finished and covered. The cost to finish the building is estimated to be $30,000.
 
A Bidder Appears
''We had some newlyweds who wanted to buy it,'' Mr. Sampson said, ''but they wanted us to provide the financing.''
This was not exactly the kind of deal school officials were hoping for. So they continued waiting until finally a bidder appeared.
''Yes, we do have an offer,'' Mr. Sampson said. ''It's from a gentleman who has a summer place in Ortley Beach with an old cottage on it. He's going to tear that down and put this house on the property.''
The bidder, John Blysick of the Bronx, is waiting for his offer to be officially accepted at the school board meeting on Tuesday.
While he waits, he is busy obtaining estimates from house movers who will haul the building from Toms River to Ortley Beach, a distance of about 14 miles. ''I'm thinking in terms of about five grand for the move,'' Mr. Blysick said. His offer, which has not been disclosed, would make ''an economically nice package'' if it is accepted, he said.
 
Lumber Shed to be Built
School officials said that one other bid had been received, but that Mr. Blysick's offer was the better of the two.
Meanwhile, Mr. Gudzak and his class have dropped out of the residential construction business - for this year at least.
''We're building a 75-foot-long lumber shed for the school,'' Mr. Gudzak said. ''We really needed a place to store materials anyway.''
Although his students are happy that the house is finally being sold, they are a little sad to see it go.
Robert McCann, 18, one of the builders, said, ''I'd buy it if I had some property, - and some money.''

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
When the Aged Need Care, Their Families Need a Hand

BYLINE: By John Paul Marosy; John Paul Marosy is president of the Center for Home Health Development, a Princeton-based nonprofit research and education organization for improving home health care.

 BODY:
A WOMAN in Middlesex County has worked for her company 10 years. Over the last two years, she has spent much of her time caring for her widowed mother, who is partly paralyzed from a stroke. Her mother has become confused, and she fears being left alone in the house they share.
Preoccupied with her mother's needs, the woman scoots home from work on her lunch hour to check on her mother; she loses time from work taking her to several doctors. She is constantly fatigued, and she knows her work is slipping as she struggles to maintain her mother at home. She cannot afford to pay someone to stay with her mother. 
Nearing the breaking point, she requests a short leave of absence to stabilize her home situation. Her request is refused, and seeing no alternative, she resigns.
A couple in their 50's are more fortunate because the husband works for a company that offers an elder-care benefit. With one teen-age daughter left living with them in their northern New Jersey home, they were looking forward to a relatively calm fall and to their first winter getaway vacation in years. Then the husband's 80-year-old mother fell and broke her hip.
The husband travels extensively to meet job demands, so his wife agreed to adjust her part-time work schedule to help his parents. She soon discovered what so many families learn when they are faced with caring for an elderly relative: finding the help needed can be a time-consuming and emotionally overwhelming task.
The wife was spending four hours a day making the round-trip drive to the Jersey Shore community where her husband's parents live, stopping at the hospital, then preparing lunch and an evening meal that the elderly father could heat and eat later.
Soon, the wife began calling in late and sometimes missing work altogether as she tried to juggle her life to care for her husband's parents. Her husband found his productivity falling off; he worried about his father's safety and found himself distracted from work priorities. Then the husbband learned about an ''elder-care hot line'' offered by his company.
His wife called the service, and a trained counselor helped her think through all the options for care. Then, by tapping a statewide computerized data base of all elder services, she helped find a homemaker who now cooks and cleans for the father. The counselor also made a referral to a family counseling service to address the longer-term issues facing the middle-aged couple and the husband's parents.
While a significant number of employers now recognize the benefits of assisting employees with child-care needs, only a few pioneering companies offer any help for employees caring for their elderly relatives. However, the number is likely to increase because a projected labor shortage in New Jersey will be complicated by unprecedented demands on families to care for their elderly relatives. Pending state legislation would require provision of unpaid dependent-care leave.
The State Department of Labor projects that by 1995 our economy will create 100,000 more jobs than there will be qualified workers to fill them. Therefore, retaining good workers will be crucially important, and more than 1.5 million of those workers are women.
In the 1980's employment in New Jersey grew at a rate exceeding that of any other industrial state in the Northeast or Midwest. That growth was fueled largely by women who entered the work force. Today, over 70 percent of women between the ages of 35 and 54 are employed outside the home.
Wives, daughters, nieces and granddaughters have traditionally cared for the old in our society. Today, 70 percent of all home care for the aged is provided by family members, the majority of whom are women.
Only Florida has an population older than New Jersey's (by median age), and the number of our residents over 75 years old is projected to increase by 60 percent over the next decade, from the current 368,000 to 588,000. This fact is especially important because people over 75 are twice as likely to require assistance with dressing, eating, toileting, etc., than their counterparts between the ages of 65 and 74.
Addressing elder-care needs differs from child care because the needs of children are more predictable and because we, as individuals, and our institutions are plagued by a fear of aging: our own aging and that of our parents. Therefore, we tend to avoid thinking about or planning for meeting the needs that accompany the decline of mental and physical health in old age.
As a result, we experience the onset of elder-care needs as a ''crisis,'' an event that disrupts our usual routine. In our everyday lives, most of us tend to deny the changes that signal our parents' loss of good health and independence.
Recent studies show that over 20 percent of all employees provide assistance to one or more elders, and 30 to 50 percent of these caregivers have at least one dependent child at home. The stresses felt by those in this ''sandwich'' generation are considerable.
The adverse effects include economic strain and mental and physical illness. These translate into tardiness, extensive phone calls, excessive absenteeism, unscheduled time off and loss of productivity due to lost concentration because of concern for a dependent relative at home.
What can be done? Caregivers responding to a survey by the American Association of Retired Persons say they need time and timely information to cope with their stresses. Recognizing this, some employers now offer flexible work time, unpaid caregiver leave and dependent-care spending accounts under flexible benefits plans.
To fill the information gap, other companies distribute information handbooks and videotapes, conduct care-giving fairs that bring community agency representatives onto the worksite and offer lunchtime seminars and professionally run support groups in which caregivers share problems and ideas.
With fewer qualified workers chasing more jobs in the 1990's, job seekers will shop for the position that offers the best opportunity to strike a balance between work and family responsibilities.
Flexibility and creativity in benefits offerings will make a difference in recruiting and retaining employees. The workplace is the focal point of most of our lives today. It is fast becoming the backdrop against which we will grapple with a central family issue of our time: long-term care for our aged relatives.

HEADLINE: ART;
Interned Artists, Devoid of Grievance

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON

 BODY:
''WE had to make friends with the wild creatures in the camp, especially the spiders, mice and rats, because we were outnumbered.''
That description was of a camp at the Tanforan Racetrack near San Francisco, one of several centers in California where Japanese and Japanese-American residents (Issei and Nisei) were held before being interned in areas remote from the West Coast. The quote comes from ''Citizen 13660,'' a humorous but pointed account of this reaction to the bombing of Pearl Harbor that was first published in 1946.
Mine Okubo is the author; she is also one of the contributors to ''From Bleakness,'' the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson's show of art and artifacts made in Tanforan and elsewhere, organized by Gary Bates, Robert Donald and Kitty Herman Nakagawa. 
In a history of cruelty, Executive Order 9066 would not rank high; the one fatality recorded by Ms. Okubo, although it was never fully explained, resulted in the camp guards being relieved of their weapons. Nevertheless, the economic and emotional effects of the internment were severe, and the United States Government has yet to make good on its promises of reparations.
Whatever the reason - a sense of historical perspective, an acceptance of racism as an inevitability, cultural identity or a mixture of all three - the artists in this show seem devoid of grievance. One is reminded of the well-known Issei, Yasuo Kuniyoshi, who although not interned seems never to have felt free of the obligation to prove his loyalty during the war.
The landscapes of Byron Takashi Tsuzuki owe something to Kuniyoshi, whom he may have known as a teacher when studying at the Art Students League. His technique, however, is more expressionistic, and there are touches of humor in his scenes of the Utah camp, where inmates do their laundry and play shogi despite continual dust storms. Shogi is a board game involving 20 pieces inscribed with characters. Mr. Tsuzuki carved the example in the show - perhaps at the same time his wife was crocheting the yellow blouse also on view.
Henry Sugimoto shows the influence of Kuniyoshi, too, but only in ''My Papa,'' a large painting of a young man being escorted from his farm by a brown-suited official as his wife and child and a small dog look on. It is not an autobiographical image, the painter having been already established and a father himself at the time of the internment; it is, rather, a statement about the whole episode and, as such, is the closest the show gets to politics.
Mr. Sugimoto's other images are of daily activities that are sometimes expressionistic, sometimes a little naive in style, but that are always cheerful in atmosphere.
Koho Yamamoto, the daughter of a calligrapher and herself the founder of a school for sumi brush drawing in Manhattan, is represented by relatively recent works in this style, as well as conventional watercolors of camp landscape. Ms. Yamamoto, a Nisei born in 1922, studied with a sumi artist in her camp but may also have profited from Abstract Expressionists who were influenced by Japanese calligraphy.
Dates are few and far between in the show, which makes it hard to tell first-hand impressions from reminiscences. Ms. Okubo's original drawings for her book illustrations are lighthearted; her charcoals of stylized figures with heavy outlines are somber and imply the influence of Picasso as it was sustained by artists like Bernard Buffet and Ben Shahn.
Then there are her small caseins - which are similar to watercolors -of camp workers done in a Work Projects Administration-chunky style; before her incarceration, Ms. Okubo was in the Federal Art Project doing mosaics and murals for the United States Army in California. She was released in 1944, when Fortune magazine invited her to help illustrate an issue about Japan and has since been fully occupied as a painter, an illustrator and a writer.
Cracks are to be found in some paintings but, on the whole, the works have been remarkably well-preserved - some in the Japanese-American National Museum in Los Angeles, others in private collections. A spectacle that includes a Buddhist shrine and its accoutrements by Hanzo Takesako (Hara), it should be an affecting experience (and an object lesson) for all Americans.
But for this observer it is the craft items that are the most moving. They run from Kobu carvings that are tree stumps altered and polished, to miniature getas (Japanese clogs) with painted decorations. Outstanding, however, are the tiny replicas of stringed instruments by Tom Kanda; James Haruju Saito's lapel pins that are birds carved from wood and painted; and the embroideries of Isaburo Nagahama. The most beautiful of these is an impression of green and yellow mountains on a blue-black background. As a 75-year-old former teacher of the art, Mr. Nagahama can't have rated high as a security risk. But he was interned, nevertheless, and imparted his skills to innumerable inmates.
A symposium on the internment will be held today at 2:30 P.M., in the Masters School Theater, at 49 Clinton Avenue in Dobbs Ferry. The show can be seen through Nov. 5, Wednesdays through Sundays from noon to 5 P.M. The gallery is in the Municipal Building on Maple Avenue.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Reaction Sought on Greenway Proposal

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
COUNTY residents will have a chance this week to comment on the state's ''greenway'' concept, a plan to preserve the Hudson River Valley by creating a chain of interlocking parks, trails and recreation sites from New York City to Albany.
Legislation signed more than a year ago by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo calls for preserving scenic, environmental and cultural resources along the Hudson River, as well as encouraging public access to its shores. The goal, say its sponsors, is to develop a coordinated open-space plan that would be compatible with economic development.
The Hudson River Valley Greenway Council will hold a public meeting at Philipsburg Manor in Tarrytown on Friday at 1 P.M. The meeting is the seventh in a series being conducted statewide by the 19-member council. 
''People seem to realize that this is the last chance an agency or any group will have to save the Hudson,'' said David S. Sampson, the executive director of the council, who added that public interest in the greenway plan has been high.
Describing a growing concern about the future of the Hudson River, he said increasing public access to the river was emerging as as major priority at the meetings.
 
Solutions Seem Complicated
''People are becoming concerned that the river and the historic and ecologically significant values it represents aren't going to be around much longer,'' said Klara Sauer, a member of the council and executive director of Scenic Hudson, the Poughkeepsie-based environmental group. ''Change is happening so fast, and the solutions seem so complicated. The Greenway Council meetings provide an opportunity to participate in something very important.''
The greenway concept is not a new idea. Its roots extend from the hunting preserves of medieval times to the linear parks that define the Bronx River and Taconic Parkways. But environmentalists and planners have become increasingly concerned that the country as a whole is running out of ''green.''
In l987, the President's Commission on Americans Outdoors proposed the creation of a ''Greenway for America,'' a national network of trails and wildlife corridors. The Hudson Valley Greenway Council represents one of the most ambitious attempt to carry out the commission's ideas.
Earlier attempts to develop a coordinated approach to development in the Hudson Valley have been short-lived because proposed state actions were perceived as threatening the home-rule powers of local officials.
 
Some Delicacy Is Wanted
Municipal officials have testified at Greenway Council meetings that they need help in controlling development, Mr. Sampson said, but the council is aware that it ''walks a thin line - people want help, but they don't want it with a club.''
The Greenway Council, Mr. Sampson said, ''is trying to describe a mechanism whereby communities can control growth along the proposed greenway but, where necessary, receive aid and guidance from New York State.''
If the council succeeds in its objectives, Mr. Sampson said, ''it will be a matter of thinking more creatively about how you mix uses'' and sharing that knowledge with the local communities.
The Greenway Council, for example, would provide municipalities with information about the effect a proposed development would have on the surrounding area. Its Geographic Mapping Program will include an inventory of all public lands and private green space along the 154-mile proposed greenway corridor.
''If someone comes along and wants to build a condominium development,'' Mr. Sampson said, ''a community will at least be able to look at our computer-software program and see there's a trail here, and a trail there, and be able to determine the effect of the condo immediately.'' The mapping program will be distributed to communities throughout the Hudson Valley.
Although some private property owners are ''very fearful of a land grab,'' Mr. Sampson said, the Greenway Council hopes instead to act as a resource. It would, for example, he said, explain to municipalities and to private landowners how to achieve public access through conservation easements, in which landowners donate or sell rights in their property to a public agency in return for tax benefits.
 
Recommendations by March
After completing the public meetings next month, the Greenway Council plans to release a draft of its recommendations by March 1. A round of public hearings on those recommendations will follow.
The Legislature has imposed a November l990 deadline for the council to submit its recommendations and its draft legislation designating the lands and waters that would make up the proposed greenway. The deadline also applies to recommendations for the historic trails in urban settings that could be included in the greenway and to financial estimates of the cost of implementing the plan.
The Greenway Council is also charged with determining which management agencies have jurisdiction over particular public lands along the greenway. Many state agencies are unaware they own certain parcels of land, Mr. Sampson said, ''because of poor record keeping.''
In some cases, the actions of a state agency, such as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, have prevented public access to open spaces, Mr. Sampson said. Speakers before the Greenway Council have complained about losing public access to the river as the M.T.A. steps up its removal of graded crossings for safety reasons.
 
Access to Park in Ossining
Natalie H. Macintosh, the assistant village manager of Ossining, appeared at the July meeting of the Greenway Council in Rockland County to plead for state help in providing access over the railroad to the river.
A two-acre park in the historic Sparta area of Ossining has been cut off since the Metro-North Commuter Railroad removed the old graded crossing, extended the third rail and put up a fence, Mrs. Macintosh told the council.
Recently completed engineering studies estimated the cost of constructing a pedestrian foot crossing over the railroad to the park at $500,000 to $750,000, Mrs. Macintosh said.
''I told the Greenway Council one of their concerns should be the railroad,'' Mrs. Macintosh said last week. ''We feel the railroad and the state have a responsibility to provide access across the tracks, and this should be addressed by the greenway study.''
Thirty speakers have signed up to testify before the Council on Friday. They represent conservation groups, municipal officials and developers.
Public comment is being encouraged on such issues as the physical and conceptual definition of the greenway, methods of providing better access to the Hudson, the kinds of economic development that would be most compatible with the valley and the role of the state in forming the greenway.

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Winthrop, Me.;
Main St. Renewal

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

 BODY:
A BUILDING that for decades dominated Main Street in this central Maine city has been moved back 150 feet to make room for a parking lot, dramatically changing the streetscape and making some residents unhappy.
The 150-year-old clapboard building had for 30 years been Grant's Variety Store and was destined for demolition by the city as part of a downtown redevelopment plan. It planned to buy the building and tear it down with money from a state community development block grant. 
But the owner, Walter Stanley, who operates a jewelry store from the building, said he refused to let it be torn down because it would cost at least $300,000 to build a new one elsewhere. In January, the city offered to pay for moving it.
''At first, I was dead against it,'' said Mr. Stanley. ''I was going to fight the town and not let them move my building. But now I'm enthusiastic. I think it's going to be good for the town.''
The city paid him $52,000, the estimate for moving the building ($19,500) and building a new foundation ($9,500), with the rest for repairing any damage and doing minor restoration. But construction problems have increased the cost to more than $80,000, and Mr. Stanley had to pay the difference.
His store will share the first floor of the remodeled 10,000-square-foot building with an appliance store. The second floor will be three rental apartments.
Tom Gordon, the city's code enforcement officer, said some residents in this town of 5,600 were not happy with the way the downtown looks now that the building has been moved back.
The once-solid wall of buildings has a hole where the store once stood. The buildings that flanked the jewelery store remain flush with the sidewalk. Several townspeople have said they hope landscaping of the parking lot will improve the way the downtown looks.
The city's revitalization plan also includes rebuilding sidewalks and installing decorative street lights to complement the downtown's mix of brick buildings, most of which were built more than a century ago. The street has a variety of businesses, including a telephone company office, an arts and crafts shop, a barber shop and a market. On both ends of the street, stately clapboard homes have been turned into offices for doctors, lawyers and other professionals.
''It used to be that property owners never did anything with their property,'' Mr. Stanley said. ''I was ashamed to think this was the town I grew up with. I think it looks better now.''

CORRECTION-DATE: October 29, 1989, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A Northeast Notebook item on Oct. 15 about redevelopment in Winthrop, Me., misidentified the former variety store that was moved. It was Wilson's, not Grant's.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: GARY M. YOUNG;
'I Think We're Middle of the Road'

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
GARY M. YOUNG'S portrait of the state of the arts in Connecticut would excite even the most jaded listener. Last year alone, said Mr. Young, the executive director of the Connecticut Commission on the Arts, the nonprofit arts industry generated $354 million. In addition, the arts employed 12,300 people and attracted an audience of more than 8.5 million people.
Connecticut's per capita income, the highest in the country, has been the main force behind the expanding art world, he said. But on the downside, the marketplace for talented new artists remains limited, he said, because of the disinterest of some art presenters in venturesome work. And a flurry of gallery closings has narrowed the market even further.
Under Mr. Young's direction, the commission uses its $2.2 million budget to provide funds to individual artists, arts organizations and arts presenters. It also provides an arts information network and support services to artists. 
Prior to his appointment in 1981, Mr. Young was the executive director of the Oregon Arts Foundation for eight years.
In an interview in his Hartford office, Mr. Young discussed the commission, arts education and the controversial exhibit of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe, which will open at the Wadsworth Atheneum on Oct. 21. Here are some excerpts from the conversation:
Q. What has been the response to the upcoming Mapplethorpe exhibit?
A. So far people are just musing about it. Candidly, we just got an inquiry from our legislative budget people asking us how much money we give to the Atheneum. I think I know why that question's being asked now. Other than that, the Governor's office wants us to respond to a letter sent there from someone who was really outraged about the Mapplethorpe show.
Q. Do you think that there is any justification for Jesse Helms's crusade to cut Government funding art deemed ''obscene or indecent?''
A. No I don't. We have a Constitution that defends the right to expression as long as it's not pornographic, and we have courts and guidelines to determine whether or not that's the case. Helms and his people may be outraged about Mapplethorpe, but I'm just as outraged about the Ku Klux Klan. Yet, the Constitution gives them the right to gather and express freely their views as long as they don't threaten to overthrow the Government.
One of Helms's arguments is that it's O.K. to express yourself but you can't necessarily use public funding for it. I feel that the Constitution applies to every area, not just those funded or not funded by the Government. There should be no distinction.
When I was going to divinity school in the 1960's, I had a professor who taught a course in religion and literature. He also had been a witness in the Henry Miller ''Tropic of Cancer'' censorship trial. His argument was that an artist's role is to explore all the avenues of human experience, to interpret what is real. I think that the same applies to Mapplethorpe. It just so happens that the areas of sexual experience he's interested in aren't acceptable in the mainstream.
Q. Are Connecticut art audiences generally conservative?
A. Connecticut audiences are pretty mainstream. You don't have a critical mass like you do in New York City. But it's not fair to hold ourselves up to the yardstick of New York because its art world is exceptional. We can't compare ourselves to that large of a population and cultural base. If we compare ourselves to other parts of New England or the country, I think we're middle of the road. We're certainly not on the edge. That seems to be the mood with most of the country.
For instance, theater in the United States is not by a long shot doing the most adventuresome work. Mark Lamos, the artistic director at Hartford Stage Company, says he is so tired of American theater concentrating on three characters in a kitchen. He says that when we come to the theater, we should come to attest to mysteries, to hear oracles, not always to be comforted by visions of ourselves but to be confronted with dangerous and beautifully wicked provocations.
I think Hartford Stage is one place where audiences can go to expand their expectations. ''Peer Gynt'' was beautifully provocative and also sold out.
Q. What is Connecticut's artistic claim to fame?
A. Connecticut's art world is really marked in a lot of ways by its theater. Connecticut produces more plays on stage per year than Broadway. We have the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, which is a laboratory for new plays. The Goodspeed Opera now has a laboratory for musicals. Yale Repertory has a winter festival. Long Wharf has its Stage II. Almost all of these theaters have produced plays that have later got Tony Awards. Outside of New York, you probably won't find that number of exceptional nationally known theaters.
Then we have all the smaller theaters, such as the Boston Stage Company, the Downtown Cabaret and Lucille Lortel's White Barn Theater. The theater here both preserves traditions and advances the new edge of what's happening.
Q. Why don't we see more nationally renowned artists exhibiting in Connecticut?
A. It would be wonderful to see a retrospective of Robert Motherwell's work or Helen Frankenwaller's, both Connecticut residents, but in some ways there's not an expansive commitment to contemporary art. We have the venues such as the Yale Art Gallery, one of the most prominent university galleries in the United States. We have the Wadsworth Atheneum, the New Britain Museum of American Art and the Aldrich.
I think the problem is that those institutions have scaled down their aspirations. Those aspirations revolve mainly around economic resources. It takes money and staff to put on a major show. Also, if you don't have a track record of presenting major artists, then you won't be able to draw major artists to exhibit.
Q. Has the market expanded for Connecticut artists?
A. We have a program called Art in Public Spaces where 1 percent of every state office building is devoted to works of art. The commission also invites artists to propose a show, and we'll look at it and decide if it's something we can exhibit. Typically, we focus on artists we've given fellowships to. We also try to seek out artists who don't get seen very much.
The traditional art gallery area isn't improving very much. They open and close. In New Haven five years ago there were bundles of little galleries that are now gone. A new development are the art consultants who fell to Connecticut-based corporations. In that area more money is being spent on Connecticut artists than on New York artists.
Q. What about opportunities for a minority artist?
A. In our Heritage Arts and Storytellers programs, we try to call attention to the fact that we live in a multiracial culture of African-Americans, Asian-Americans and Latino-Americans, that there are many different versions of our culture. We've made a big effort to recruit groups from other cultural traditions and put them into our programs and offer them funding.
Q. Has patronage for the arts increased?
A. We did a study of a core or arts institutions in the state and found that corporate giving has leveled off. My hunch is that it's totally flat. But individual giving continues to climb at a very substantial level. This makes sense considering Connecticut has the highest per capita income level in the country and the fact that attendance for the arts has doubled in the last few years.
Q. What's the biggest issue concerning arts in Connecticut?
A. The role of arts in education. We have to establish the arts as part of the core curriculum and not as an enhancement activity. The National Endowment for the Arts did a nationwide study and found that serious arts education does not exist. The commission, along with the Department of Education, has put together a task force that will have a major action planned by next year to incorporate the arts into the curriculum.
Among the things we want to accomplish is getting arts institutions that have educational programs into the venues of the education world. For instance, getting museums to teach teachers how to incorporate the arts, say, into social studies.
We now have a number of studies that show that the arts are a helpful tool in developing criticial and creative thinking skills. Our kids are missing a large part of their heritage, not just in Western European art, but from other cultures as well. It's incredible. How can you teach a history of a people without looking at their art?
Q. What are the commission's proudest accomplishments?
A. The first is this task force on education in the arts. It's the first time we've worked on this with the Department of Education, and I think together we'll be able to make some big changes in this area.
The other is our annual arts awards in June where we identify individuals that we feel are making a contribution. We use it as a miniature festival of the arts and have performances by Connecticut artists ranging from Dave Brubeck to the bass player Gary Karr. I'm really proud of the quality and how it highlights what a great and talented state this is.
Q. How can the public help the commission reach its goal?
A. People have to let their legislatures know how important it is to support the arts. A lot of things that we do wouldn't happen unless we didn't help them. Maybe the Long Wharf would move right along without our support, even though they claim it's terribly important. But there are programs such as art education programs that wouldn't exist without our funding. We also identify cultural groups and promote them all over the state. That wouldn't happen without us. If politicians understand that the cultural quality of our lives is a real issue, then changes will result.
