HEADLINE: Shore Confronts New Trends in Tourism

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

DATELINE: LAVALLETTE

 BODY:
AS local and state tourism officials and oceanfront communities finish their assessments of last summer and start to plan budgets for next year, the talk is focusing on a trend that has been changing the face of the Jersey Shore in this decade.
Quite apart from annual fluctuations brought on by changes in ocean water quality, officials and others say, there are fewer people visiting the beach these days. Most of those who do go, they say, spend only a day or a weekend, a far cry from the stays of a couple of weeks or entire 10-week seasons that were common less than 10 years ago.
''The Shore business community is just starting to adjust to the new trend of people taking more vacations for fewer days at a time,'' said Noreen G. Bodman, director of the State Division of Travel and Tourism. ''Business owners definitely must adjust to that trend and market to that trend.'' 
For example, Mrs. Bodman said, motel and hotel owners especially need to change their minimum-stay requirements of a week or so to perhaps a couple of days if they hope to meet the new demands of tourists.
Interviews with real estate agents and merchants, local and state officials and spokesmen for Chambers of Commerce, as well as a review of the latest studies on vacation patterns, showed that several factors have influenced what has become a new Shore economy. They are:
* Societal changes in the nuclear family, including fewer children and more two-income married couples. There are also, according to the United States Data Information Service in Washington, more single parents and single professional people taking short vacations.
* The rapid development of some Jersey Shore towns, which has begun reducing the number of available rentals there as once-rustic summer spots are transformed into more settled residential and second-home communities.
* Competition from diverse and conveniently situated vacation alternatives, in the mountains or elsewhere in New Jersey and New York, that feature getaways of two or three days.
* The failure of many Shore communities to package and market their attractions until recently. Some still do not have promotional budgets for next year.
Either by themselves or cooperatively through regional efforts, many Shore towns began selling themselves to the public this year in an attempt to restore the loss of hundreds of thousands of tourists and more than $1 billion in revenue that occurred in the last two summers alone.
Boardwalk owners and Chamber of Commerce officials said these promotions had begun reversing the sharp decline in revenue experienced in 1987 and 1988, years in which the long-term downward trend in Shore tourism was exacerbated by reports of pollution and beach closings.
''A terrific effort was made by the tourism industry this year, and it has been working,'' said Nancy James, a spokeswoman for Jenkinson's Pavilion in Point Pleasant Beach. Most of the boardwalk businesses are situated in the pavilion.
Jenkinson's, Ms. James said, began winning back tourist dollars last summer with special offerings like new group travel packages and the Festival of the Atlantic. The festival was a series of 10 free professional concerts on the beach that drew thousands each week and quickly became the Shore's largest outdoor music festival. It will be expanded next summer, Ms. James said.
To the south, the borough of Lavallette supplemented its summer with small concerts and other attractions. Although its ocean waters were sparkling clean all summer, its beaches along Barnegat Bay, which are longtime family attractions, were closed almost every day because of bacterial contamination.
Over all, Mrs. Bodman said, Shore tourism revenue was ''up a little but not substantially'' over 1988, and still not close to 1986, the last real banner year the Shore experienced.
 
Beach Badge Income Watched
Income from beach badges at municipal and private beaches is considered to be a barometer of the economic climate. Beach attendance figures provided by individual communities for this year showed continued declines in revenue and even sharper decreases in the sale of season beach badges, which were down 50 percent or more from 1988, perhaps reflecting the move toward shorter vacations.
In Monmouth County's southernmost municipality, Manasquan, beach revenue was down by a third - $408,000 compared with $598,000 in 1988. But the figures are only part of the picture. Neil B. Hamilton, a Manasquan councilman and chairman of the Borough Council's beach committee, said beach attendance last summer showed that attendance had declined 90 percent in the five years.
Only four or five of the town's nine beaches with lifeguards were open on weekdays last summer, he said, and no more than six or seven beaches ever opened on a weekend.
Manasquan's beaches showed a net loss of $109,000 last year. The paucity of beachgoers, Mr. Hamilton said, prompted the town fathers to offer free parking at Manasquan's four parking lots, which never did fill up. As for finding promotional money in an increasingly scant beach budget, Mr. Hamilton said, ''We can't afford it.''
In Belmar, beach revenue has ''been going down for the last several years,'' said Marie Newbery, a municipal spokeswoman. ''Families generally aren't coming like they used to even five years ago. When they do, it is mostly for day trips.''
Belmar sold $1.05 million worth of badges this year in all categories, compared with almost $1.3 million in 1988. The sale of full-season badges this year declined to less than half of the 1988 figure.
 
An Advertising Campaign
Long Beach Island, the barrier island in Ocean County between Barnegat Light and Long Beach Township, did better this year than last by spending $50,000 on advertising in newspapers. Also, some 30,000 brochures that presented the island's individual community attractions as entire packages were distributed statewide.
''People are not coming to the beach to sit on the beach anymore,'' said Jeanne DiPaola, executive director of the Southern Ocean County Chamber of Commerce, which takes in Long Beach Island. ''They want concerts, antiquing and other activities.''
Although beach attendance in one of the municipalities, Long Beach Township, was down this year almost 15 percent compared with 1988 - from 52,770 visitors to 45,756 last year - Ms. DiPaola said nonbeach business was generally up. With ''few families and more professional couples with no children, as well as single parents'' coming to the beach, she said, ''the nightclubs were hopping here last summer because the demand for night life has increased.''
The shorter-term vacationers, she said, are dining out less frequently and heavily patronizing takeout restaurants and ones that cater.
 
Season Extended in Cape May
In the state's southern tip, the city of Cape May, which is believed to be the oldest seaside resort in the nation, is not subjected to the same vicissitudes as most oceanfront communities. As officials there pointed out, Cape May does not have a boardwalk amusement area, and it is a national historic site that has successfully extended its tourist season well into the spring and fall.
Nevertheless, beach revenues declined there to $415,104 this year from $419,877 last year, a slight drop that officials said had to do with a very rainy season.
But Harry Mogck, a captain with 20 years on the Cape May beach patrol, said that while familiar families still frequented the beach, ''there are more daily people than we've ever had before - different faces every day.''
Meredithe Semselski, director of the Greater Cape May Area Chamber of Commerce, said that even the over-50 crowd that made up much of the tourist trade in Cape May was taking two- or three-day vacations, three or four times a year, rather than spending a week to a month.
Aware of the changing times, Ms. Semselski said Cape May would participate in a corporate travel trade show in Philadelphia next year to increase its income from small conferences and business meetings.
Cape May, Ocean City and the Wildwoods spent more than $250,000 last summer on a Cape Island advertising campaign that began in 1988 and that sought to give the area an identity separate from the rest of the coast.
 
'Creating an Identity'
A similar regional marketing effort was begun this year by Roy Childers, a lifelong resident of Lavallette who owns four real-estate agencies in the area. Concerned about how the last two years of bad publicity had ''accelerated'' the longer-term trend of fewer vacationers, Mr. Childers organized some 100 businesses and groups along the island between Point Pleasant Beach and Island Beach State Park and gave the region a new name, Barnegat Beach Island. He also helped establish an independent newspaper, The Beach Reader and News, in Seaside Park.
''There was a question of creating an identity that we did not have,'' Mr. Childers said.
The island, he said, grew rapidly in the last decade. Some towns have been losing their rustic sand-in-the-shoes charm as the corner custard stands, tiny movie houses and outdoor produce stands have begun to give way to gleaming convenience stores, more valuable residential conversions of commercial property and large shopping malls only minutes from the beach in places like Toms River and Brick.
''As the year-round beachfront community grows, it is not really the backwater getaway that it once was for vacationers,'' Mr. Childers said.
Mrs. Bodman was supportive of the latest push to sell the Shore, a place that, she said, ''until recently had always sold itself.''
Even though it is experiencing changes, Mrs. Bodman said, one thing that the Shore still has in its favor is a diversity of communities - from small back-bay villages, where one can still rent a rowboat and go crabbing, to the glitz of Atlantic City.
All this, she said, will continue to give the Shore a broad appeal for some time to come.

LENGTH: 1714 words

HEADLINE: STEPS ARE TAKEN TO CALM INVESTORS IN STOCK MARKETS

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The financial community and Government officials yesterday took steps to deal with volatile Wall Street trading expected today, seeking to assure investors that the markets are ready for any reaction to Friday's collapse.
The first significant sign of the fallout from Friday's drop of 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent, in the Dow Jones industrial average was felt in Tokyo, where stocks fell at the opening. By mid-afternoon, the 225-share Nikkei index, which had dropped by as much as 610 points in early trading, was at 34,551, down 564, or about 1.6 percent from Friday's close.
An opening drop in Tokyo, as well as on Wall Street, had been largely expected by investors. But industry officials expressed relief that the initial trading in Tokyo was relatively calm. 
''This is early in the Japanese morning and I cannot predict the rest of the day,'' Leo Melamed, the chairman of the executive committee of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, said last night. ''But clearly if it is around these levels, you can breathe a bit easier.''
 
Exchanges in Contacts Abroad
But exchanges continued to maintain contacts overseas. ''We're talking to the institutions in Tokyo and London tonight to get a feel for what impact action in their markets will have here,'' John J. Phelan Jr., chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday.
In Washington, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who headed the Presidential panel that explored the causes of the 1987 market crash, was coordinating the Bush Administration's response to the market's turmoil. A spokesman for Mr. Brady said he was in his office yesterday afternoon talking by telephone with Wall Street and Government officials.
In addition, the Securities and Exchange Commission checked with mutual funds and large brokerage houses in an effort to get an indication of how much selling there would be in early trading today, a commission official said. Such a check could provide the regulators and the exchanges with a sense of what they have to expect.
President Bush spent most of the day at Camp David, the Presidential retreat in Maryland. A White House press officer said she assumed the President had been in touch with Mr. Brady, but referred further questions to the Treasury.
Preparations for this morning resulted in some rule revisions at the major financial exchanges. For example, the New York Stock Exchange will allow orders to begin to be placed in its computer system at 7:30 A.M., an hour earlier than usual. Trading personnel were also required to come in early.
At the market's opening, the exchange will activate an express delivery system for individual investors, which is usually used to move such trades ahead of institutional ones after the market moves up or down by 25 points. These moves are expected to allow the markets to better prepare for the opening.
 
Trying to Gauge the Action
Brokers and institutional investors spent the weekend trying to gauge the possible action in the markets today. Some traders were busy making lists of the stocks they thought they should trade, while brokers were speaking to their customers to determine what they might do.
Industry officials were quick to point out that the domestic financial markets were in a radically different position from what they were on Oct. 19, 1987. These officials said that if the plunge in the market continued, they did not expect a meltdown such as occurred two years ago. They stressed that the changes that had been made would serve to protect small investors.
''This is a market with far more value than we saw in 1987, and with a different economic backdrop,'' said Alan R. Ackerman, senior vice president at Gruntal & Company.
Nevertheless, some industry experts said some of the changes in the last two years had also brought problems. ''The negative side of the differences is that we are two years later along the leveraged buyout route, and so there is more leverage in the system,'' Mr. Melamed said. ''That is the reason the markets have been so jittery.''
 
Touched Off by UAL News
Indeed, Friday's debacle was touched off by news that the group planning a buyout of UAL Inc., the parent of United Airlines, in a highly leveraged deal could not get financing and would have to revise the terms.
After the plunge, many exchanges began reviewing the financial impact on their members. On the New York Stock Exchange, the financial conditions of member firms were checked and they were found to be in good shape.
Other exchanges, including the American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, called members in on Saturday to resolve trade disputes left over from Friday, clearing the way for today's opening.
Most important, on Saturday a Federal Reserve Board official said any sudden demands for money that might result from Friday's collapse would be met by the central bank. In 1987, those assurances were made only after the market collapse began. ''The Federal Reserve is doing exactly what it should do,'' said Neil J. Pinsky, a former economist with the Chicago Federal Reserve. ''It learned its lesson in 1929 and in 1987.''
The weekend's preparations were expected to prove necessary today because, industry executives said, trading would be volatile, although there was not yet any indication of where the market would close.
 
Relationship With Futures
The reason for the volatility, exchange officials and traders said, lay in the relationship between the futures and stock markets. On Friday, trading was limited in futures after contracts based on the Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 30 points. That left the stock markets open for 15 more minutes, with stocks closing far above the related stock futures contracts.
As a result, industry officials said, the futures contracts closed at a discount to stocks of the equivalent of some 50 to 70 points on the Dow. In order for the stock exchanges in New York and the futures exchanges in Chicago to get back in synchronization, that difference will have to be captured in early trading, either by a decline in stocks or a rally in futures.
But the overall direction of the market will depend on several critical signals. First, the close of the markets in Japan, as well as the first hours of trading on the European exchanges, will be examined closely by American traders seeking to get a sense of the possible direction of the domestic markets.
Initial mixed reactions of the foreign markets to the Friday plunge came throughout the weekend. On Saturday, Taiwan's stock market declined by more than 2 percent, but South Korea's market finished generally higher. Yesterday, Israel's stock market lost some 7 percent of its total value, while in New Zealand, the market fell about 10 percent in its Monday morning session.
 
Options Index to Be Watched
Traders and industry executives said they would be watching trading in the Major Market Index, or M.M.I. a single options index that starts trading 15 minutes before the rest of the market. The index is composed of about 20 stocks, including International Business Machines, Procter & Gamble, Merck and other blue-chip companies.
The index, known among traders as ''the missile'' because its trading symbol is ''MX,'' was the first sector of the market to begin to recover after the 1987 crash, signaling possible buyers of stock that it was time to step in.
''The last time, when the missile started rallying, that was a sign the market itself had bottomed out,'' said Jeffrey Tabak, a partner with Miller Tabak Hirsch & Company, a New York investment banking firm. ''Guys like myself remember that.'' Many investors, wary after the 1987 crash, have chosen to put their money in other investments besides stocks, market analysts pointed out, and as a result, institutions are playing an even more important role than they did two years ago.
In 1987, the market had been on a steady decline since late August, but the ebullience that surrounded the five-year bull market had not been squeezed out. Investors were heavily laden with stocks and other financial instruments, and cash holdings were at a low level.
As a result, when concern started to mount on the morning of Oct. 19, there were many investors who wanted to sell, but there were few takers with the cash to buy.
 
Significantly Different Market
Today, the makeup of the markets is significantly different. Despite the fact that the Dow has been steadily rising for months, reaching new records, this has been a market with no euphoria. Many investors have stood back watching the rise, putting their money into cash assets, such as money market funds, certificates of deposits and other investments, and keeping their exposure in stocks to a minimum.
''This has been a bull market full of anxiety,'' said Mr. Ackerman of Gruntal. 'But there is an abundance of cash worldwide looking for value.''
Individual investors appear to have not been significantly involved in Friday's selloff. Fidelity Investments in Boston polled some of its shareholders over the weekend, and found that only 1 percent of those asked had withdrawn their assets from stock or mutual funds on Friday, said Neil Litvack, vice president of marketing.
 
Psychological Preparations
The preparations over the last two years for market difficulties have been not just been structural, but psychological as well. Since the 1987 crash, officials in the securities and futures industry have learned how to deal with rapidly declining markets, something that many of the younger players on Wall Street had never seen. Since the crash, volatility in the stock market, often driven by computerized program trading, has pushed the market to near-record drops as well as to new highs.
''Since Oct. 19, 1987, we have been educated in volatility, and nothing will ever be the same,'' said Donald Stone, a partner with Lasker, Stone & Stern, a specialist firm on the New York Stock Exchange.
Regardless of the outcomes today, industry officials said yesterday that they hoped investors would act based on their experience from the crash. ''We hope that people have learned a lesson from 1987,'' Mr. Phelan said. ''A great deal of caution should be used before anyone decides to go rushing to sell.''

HEADLINE: Papal Trip's Last Stop: An Island Gem

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT LOUIS, Mauritius, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Normally, papal trips to third world countries are journeys among strongmen and marches through gut-wrenching poverty. So it was a decided change for Pope John Paul II this weekend when he brought his ministry to this palm-flecked island nation.
Mind you, Mauritius hardly qualifies as rich. It is a teardrop in the Indian Ocean, 1,200 miles from the southern African coast, with its share of tin-roofed hovels and illiteracy. 
But it is unlike any other country in this part of the world. For one thing, democracy has remained intact since the island won independence from Britain 21 years ago. The Government can lose elections, and has.
For another, Mauritius has no army or significant foreign-policy worries except for its desire to regain sovereignty over the distant island of Diego Garcia, which Britain still controls and leases to the United States for use as a military base.
 
Virtually No Unemployment
Moreover, the economy, while still fragile, has managed to chug along admirably. Unemployment among the 1 million Mauritians is said to be about zero, thanks to a decision several years ago to end near-total dependency on sugar cane for economic survival. These days, there is a network of light manufacturing, invigorated by foreign investors who were lured with promises of no income taxes and no duties. The island produces and exports such diverse items as clothing, cut diamonds and surgical gloves.
One result is that the annual per capita income is approaching $2,000 a year, equivalent to seven or eight times that of Madagascar, the nearest big neighbor, 500 miles west. And now business leaders dream that their country may one day become an African Hong Kong or Taiwan through offshore banking services and perhaps even a stock exchange.
In fact, Mauritius is doing well enough to have merited a papal lecture today on the perils of materialism, something fretted over as well by some local politicians who say they fear for the ''Mauritius soul.''
At a meeting with Mauritian youths, the Pope acknowledged that economic development has saved their island from crisis. But he added: ''The mere accumulation of goods is not enough to realize human happiness. You become a slave to the enjoyment of material things.''
That would be a special shame here, John Paul added, because of the unusual blend of races, cultures, religions and languages - a ''rainbow,'' as the Pope called it, where ethnic strife occurs infrequently.
Should Mauritius become a victim of materialism, he warned, it ''could certainly fall short in its mission as a cultural crossroads, where the confluence of diverse cultures gives an authentic spiritual vision to life.''
 
Hindus in Slight Majority
Indigenous Mauritians do not exist. Over the last three centuries the island has been ruled successively by the Dutch, the French and the English, who brought in slaves or permitted immigration from Africa, India and China. Almost everyone speaks French and Creole, yet the official language is English. Hindus form a slight majority, but Christians and Muslims are amply represented.
This balance must be preserved, the Pope said today, throwing in an admonition that ''racial prejudice, blasphemous to the Creator, can be fought only at its root, the heart of man.''
Mauritius is the last stop on a trip that also took the Pope over the last 10 days to South Korea and Indonesia. John Paul would have done well to spend some time on the island's sunny, silken beaches, but that, of course, is hardly papal style. For him, instead, this has been a grueling voyage of 24,522 miles. By the time he returns to Rome Monday, the 11th anniversary of his papacy, he will have spent more than 58 hours, or one-fourth the entire trip, in the air.
Fatigue has shown in his 69-year-old face. At one stop in Indonesia, where temperatures climbed above 100 degrees, he began to nod off during a meeting with seminarians, prompting an aide to thrust a copy of his planned remarks into the Pope's hands to jar him awake. Still, he is remarkably durable, and he has begun already to talk about trips he hopes to make one day to the Soviet Union and China and, preferrably sooner, to Lebanon.

HEADLINE: SOVIETS REDUCING ARMS FOR MANAGUA

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 10

 BODY:
After a decade as the largest supplier of weapons for the Sandinista army, the Soviet Union now appears committed to reducing its military aid to Nicaragua in order to strengthen its relations with Washington, diplomats here say.
The cut in arms shipments, discussed during a visit here last week by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, has already affected nearly all direct shipments from the Soviet Union to Nicaragua. Western diplomats say they expect further reductions in indirect military aid that passes through other Soviet bloc nations, like Cuba and East Germany.
After first disputing such reports, American intelligence officials said last week that total Soviet bloc military aid to Nicaragua was now about 20 percent less than it was last year. In the past, the total value of Soviet military aid to Nicaragua has been estimated to average $500 million a year. 
 
Elections in February
Officially, both Nicaragua and the Soviet Union are describing the cuts as a temporary suspension of aid until national elections are held here in February. The reductions were presented by Mr. Shevardnadze as part of a Soviet-sponsored disarmament plan in which the Soviet Union and United States would serve as guarantors of Central American stability.
But diplomats familiar with last week's negotiations said the cuts were not likely to depend on such an ambitious framework. They described the cuts as a product of Moscow's effort to eliminate friction between the superpowers and to cut back its extensive Third World commitments.
Although many experts had expected Mr. Shevardnadze to bring news of cuts in economic aid as well, Nicaraguan and Soviet officials gave no indication of any significant changes in that area. Some analysts suggested that economic aid would be deliberately maintained to permit, and reduce the impact of, the military cutbacks, which are considered far more important to the United States.
 
Reorganization of Economic Aid
Foreign experts here said they believed that the Kremlin would continue its current high levels of economic aid, now estimated at about $465 million a year, or roughly $133 a year for every Nicaraguan citizen.
But in his remarks, Mr. Shevardnadze said such economic aid would have to be reorganized to make it more efficient, and he pointedly praised the Sandinista Government's recent economic recovery program, which relies on traditional Western techniques for economic stabilization.
According to statistics released recently by the Nicaraguan Ministry of External Cooperation, Soviet nonmilitary aid from 1981 to 1988 amounted to $2.9 billion. The current three-year aid agreement provides a total of $1.4 billion in nonmilitary aid.
The new Soviet policy toward Nicaragua first began to emerge clearly in May, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev told President Bush in a letter that no direct Soviet arms shipments had been made to Nicaragua since Jan. 1. The policy was then refined and explained directly to Sandinista leaders in the one-day visit by Mr. Shevardnadze, who arrived here fresh from his lengthy negotiations with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other American officials.
 
Regional Issues Mentioned
During Mr. Shevardnadze's visit, the Nicaraguan Government formally committed itself to a suspension of all new Soviet military supplies until the February elections. Both sides also declared their support of a regionwide framework for removing bases, banning foreign military advisers and reducing arms levels under the joint Soviet-American structure.
''The stability of the region requires the maintenance of a balance of forces, in which each Central American country has sufficient armed forces for defense and no more,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said.
In Washington, State Department officials quickly discounted any suggestion that the Soviet Union might have a direct role to play in overseeing regional affairs, an idea that would conflict directly with the Monroe Doctrine. That doctrine rejects the intervention of outside nations in the hemisphere. Which Shipments Are Included? Western officials' enthusiasm over the announced cuts in Soviet aid was also tempered by ambiguity over the range of shipments that would be included in the cuts. American analysts have asserted that large shipments of arms from the Soviet bloc continue to reach the Sandinista army through Cuba and East Germany, but Soviet officials have insisted that they cannot control the actions of those allies.
Uncertainty surrounding that point was increased during Mr. Shevardnadze's visit, after which the Soviet and Nicaraguan sides issued separate communiques rather than a single negotiated document. According to the Soviet text, Nicaragua accepted a suspension of all arms shipments. But in the Nicaraguan document, the reference specified suspension of ''armaments from the Soviet Union to Nicaragua.''
Commenting on the negotiations, American officials made it clear that they had chosen to interpret the Soviet statement as a ban on all shipments, direct or indirect.
The understandings reached during Mr. Shevardnadze's visit were ratified Oct. 7, when President Daniel Ortega Saavedra met with the Mr. Gorbachev while both were attending East German anniversary celebrations.

HEADLINE: Special House Election in Mississippi To Test G.O.P.'s Southern Strength

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BILOXI, Miss., Oct. 14

 BODY:
For the last 16 years, Mississippi's Fifth Congressional District has been a bulwark of the Republican Party's Southern strength, as native conservatism and popular Presidential candidates have built a political force that has won offices down to the county level.
The Republicans' strength on the Gulf Coast will be tested on Tuesday in a special Congressional election that pits Tom Anderson, a longtime aide to Senator Trent Lott, the man who led the Republican charge in the area, against Gene Taylor, a conservative Democratic State Senator.
Mr. Taylor's profile as a maverick and an advocate of a strong defense has helped make him a surprise frontrunner in public opinion polls.
Indications of just how high the stakes in the race are could be seen earlier this week in the campaign visit here by President Bush, who touted Mr. Anderson for his Washington experience and for the conservative philosophy he would bring to the office. The Democrats countered with a letter signed by the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley, and other Democratic leaders promising to install Mr. Taylor on the Armed Services Committee. 
 
The Military Influence
Much of the district's economy is built on military spending generated by the huge Ingalls shipyards in Pascagoula, four military installations and the large number of retired military personnel who live in the district.
The winner of the special election will serve the remaining 14 months in the term of the late Larkin Smith. Mr. Smith, a popular Republican sheriff who won the seat after Mr. Lott quit it to make a successful run for the Senate last year, was killed in a plane crash on Aug. 13.
''It is definitely a conservative district,'' said Dan Leonard, deputy press secretary for the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, which has been helping the Anderson campaign. ''We just have to convince voters that they are conservative Republicans and not conservative Democrats.''
Brian Martin, a Taylor strategist and former executive director of the Mississippi Democratic Party, said the Taylor campaign marked a Democratic resurgence.
 
Fewer Blacks in District
For years, he said, Mississippi Democrats as well as party officials in Washington had been cowed by Mr. Lott's popularity in the district, never seriously challenging him and allowing him to become entrenched. Much of the party's strength in the state, Mr. Martin said, is built on a strong black vote in the central and Delta regions. Little attention was paid to the Gulf Coast, where blacks make up less than 20 percent of the population.
''This race might be the best thing to ever happen to the Mississippi Democratic Party,'' Mr. Martin said. ''The people here are ticket-splitters and leaners, and if we really go after them, we might not turn them all into to Democrats, but we will reduce the Republican vote.''
The 43-year-old Mr. Anderson, whose family runs a retail clothing chain in the area, has been a behind-the-scenes factor in Mr. Lott's longtime dominance in the area.
As administrative aide and executive assistant to Mr. Lott, Mr. Anderson not only helped shape the combative persona that propelled Mr. Lott to a position of leadership as the House minority whip and a national spokesman for conservative causes, but also directed the important constituent services aspect of Mr. Lott's eight terms as Representative.
 
The Strong Hand of Lott
From the beginning Mr. Lott has taken a strong hand in pushing Mr. Anderson's candidacy. When the seat became vacant, he was believed to have discouraged Mr. Smith's widow and a number of others from running.
That has cut both ways for Mr. Anderson. On the one hand it has convinced some people that he will have access to the White House, but on the other it has raised the specter of bossism. A recent editorial cartoon in The Jackson Clarion-Ledger depicted Mr. Lott and Mr. Bush meeting at the airport, with the President carrying his lap dog, Millie, and Mr. Lott carrying a lap dog labeled Tom Anderson.
Mr. Taylor, who is 36, began his political career as a City Councilman in Bay St. Louis in his early 20's and went on to win a seat in the State Senate. He came through a bruising Democratic primary to win the nomination in last year's Congressional race, but lost to Mr. Smith in the general election by 10 percentage points.
But that exposure helped Mr. Taylor in the special election this year. He was considered the underdog in a three-way nonpartisan primary on Oct. 3, a race that involved Mr. Anderson and the Mississippi Attorney General, Mike Moore. But he ended up leading the field; Mr. Moore ran a distant third.
Although Mr. Anderson is outspending Mr. Taylor by more than 4 to 1 - at the end of September, Mr. Anderson had spent $403,000 to Mr. Taylor's $81,000 - the Democratic candidate has clung to his pledge not to accept money from political action committees.
''I'm not Washington's candidate or the candidate of some U.S. Senator or some Democratic power brokers in Jackson,'' Mr. Taylor said in a debate recently. ''I'm a southern Mississippi candidate.''

HEADLINE: Louisville Journal;
Keepers of the Flame Stoke Freedom's Fire

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 15

 BODY:
The descendants of the patriots who fought at places like Bunker Hill and Trenton and Yorktown met here this weekend to check on the fires of freedom.
They found them still burning but in need of some stoking.
It was a meeting of the 100 trustees of the Sons of the American Revolution, a national society that is a century old this year and whose 25,000 members are dedicated to perpetuating the ideals and achievements of the American Revolution.
Every member of the society can be traced back to someone who fought in the Revolution or aided and abetted those who fought. Some society members wore tricornered hats and wigs. There was much spirited singing and some good-natured joshing of the better-known sibling society, the Daughters of the American Revolution, which includes a number of wives of S.A.R. members. 
But at heart the meeting was dead serious business for the men who journeyed to the society's Louisville headquarters from around the country. Their forebears' legacy seemed to weigh on their consciences.
''As descendants of the original Revolutionary War patriots, we feel that we have a special calling to keep freedom's fires burning,'' said the society's current president general, James R. Westlake, a Federal economic development official from Atlanta whose membership in the society traces to a Virginia militiaman.
Stoking those fires, the trustees passed a resolution demanding that President Bush sign a bill that prohibits desecration of the flag. The resolution read: ''Our flag, in essence, is considered a living person in our society.''
The society is a nonprofit organization and ''nonpolitical.'' It responds to issues like flag desecration and, sometimes, defense issues, but, generally, it avoids political controversy. ''We're only partisan when it comes to patriotism, freedom and good old American democracy,'' Mr. Westlake said.
In its first 100 years, it distributed millions of leaflets about the flag and what it meant to be an American citizen. It pulled together collections of important historical documents and studies and posted markers on the graves of heroes and at the sites of major historic events. It offered prizes and scholarships to students who wrote essays and gave speeches about American history, patriotism and democracy.
The trustees vowed to keep up this work. They expressed concern that the nation remained woefully ignorant and often unappreciative of its past and its meaning. They called upon schools to do a better job in teaching history.
''We should be disgusted and shamed by recent surveys that show that one of every four college seniors doesn't know when Columbus discovered America,'' said Fred Jeffries, who operates a publishing company in Denver. ''It's not a cliche to say that those who do not remember history are doomed to relive it. What's to become of our country?''
As for what's to become of the Sons of the American Revolution in the next 100 years, the trustees not only promised to continue the programs of the first, but also called for efforts to increase membership.
The S.A.R. has recently been growing by only about 500 members a year. Many of its officials say that if it does not increase that rate its reputation will continue to lag behind that of the 225,000-member D.A.R.
The D.A.R., which has been more involved in controversial issues than the S.A.R., celebrates its centennial next year.
''I figure there easily could be up to 20 million American men eligible for membership in our society because the ancestral line can come down either directly or through marriage,'' said Carl F. Bessent, a retired steel company executive from Baltimore who is the society's historian.
He claims at least eight ancestors who fought in the Revolution. Many other society members claim more. A Georgian claims 87.
''It's not really all that hard to trace an ancestor,'' Mr. Bessent said. ''We're not dealing with ancient history. There are people alive today who have talked with people who knew Revolutionary War veterans, maybe even a soldier who was at Yorktown. Just think of that! A talk with a Yorktown veteran!''

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Helms Keeps the Capital Pot Boiling

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
As well-mannered as a church-going schoolboy, as full of homespun charm as a Chamber of Commerce president, Senator Jesse Helms is the kind of guy who fetches coffee for his aides and allows misguided tourists to use the special elevator reserved for senators.
He also routinely holds foreign policy initiatives hostage, puts ambassadorial nominees in limbo, paralyzes Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearings and undercuts treaties. He is, people in Washington say, a spoiler Secretary of State.
''Oh mercy, of course not,'' the 67-year-old Republican Senator says in response. ''I just have my opinions and my agenda. I just take a swipe at the ball when it comes over the plate, and I do the best I can.'' 
This month, Senator Helms seemed to be doing his best to outdo himself.
 
Criticism and Fire
Racing to the Senate floor the day after the collapse of the attempted coup in Panama, he criticized the Bush Administration for incompetence with the same oratorical fire that back home earned him the honor of Grand Orator of the Grand Lodge of Masons of North Carolina. Using information gathered by his staff, the Senator asserted that the United States had failed to respond to pleas by Panamanian rebels for crucial help.
Senior officials at the White House seethed. At a White House meeting, Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, railed at two of Mr. Helms's aides who refused to disclose their sources.
''My personal feeling is that the Senator was badly misserved by his staff,'' said one senior White House official. The Senate speech, the official said, was ''so factually inaccurate that I suspect the Senator will feel uncomfortable when it is analyzed.''
Not so, Mr. Helms insisted. ''I've got no apologies to anybody,'' he said. ''I wouldn't take back one syllable.'' Courtship by Baker Incidents like the Panama crisis have helped give Mr. Helms an importance out of proportion to his position as the ranking minority member of the Foreign Relations Committee. Conscious of Mr. Helms's power to wreak havoc on carefully planned policy, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has courted him, seeking his advice and assistance in frequent telephone conversations or at lunch at the State Department.
''There's not a separate Jesse Helms strategy,'' said a senior official at the State Department, ''but it's fair to say that the Secretary has a strong desire to keep the Senator in the loop on things.''
As for the President, those who know Mr. Helms well say he and Mr. Bush are like oil and water. To Mr. Helms, who quit college to become a newspaperman, the President represents the kind of privilege that he disdains.
''There are certain philosophical and cultural views that Jesse doesn't share with the President,'' said Richard S. Williamson, a former Assistant Secretary of State who has known Mr. Helms since they worked together on the 1976 Republican Party platform. ''Worse than being a liberal is being a pragmatist, and worse than that is being an Eastern Establishment Ivy League WASP.''
Publicly, Mr. Helms remains a Bush loyalist. He was not happy with Ronald Reagan's choice of Mr. Bush as a Vice Presidential candidate in 1980 and made that clear. But when Mr. Bush asked Mr. Helms to show up at a North Carolina campaign stop last year, Mr. Helms drove himself there despite the fact that he was recovering from a hernia operation.
As evidence of his friendship with Mr. Bush, the Senator told of a recent visit to the Oval Office when the President offered to help when Mr. Helms is up for re-election next year. '' 'I'm ready and we'll work it out if you're ready,' '' Mr. Helms quoted the President as saying. ''I told him that's one of the nicest things anyone ever said to me.''
 
Bad Feelings Are Denied
Similarly, the White House insisted there were no bad feelings because of Panama. ''I certainly don't feel that the Senator has any specific feelings against the Administration,'' Mr. Sununu said in an interview. ''I don't think the President feels that. I've considered the Senator a friend for a long time and feel very comfortable talking with him about issues and asking him for help.''
Mr. Helms listens to cassettes of Winston Churchill's speeches in his 1984 Oldsmobile and unwinds by playing along with ''Jeopardy'' and ''Wheel of Fortune,'' two of his favorite television programs.
A two-finger typist, he uses an old Royal typewriter and pecks out dozens of letters every week to his constituents. And he puffs half-heartedly on unfiltered Lucky Strikes, which sits well with the tobacco lobby back in North Carolina.
But if he is a cocker spaniel in his personal life, Mr. Helms is a pit bull in the Senate.
 
Not Trying to Get Along
''If you don't have a set of principles and you try to be popular, that's when you go nuts,'' Mr. Helms said, ''and I have no intention of going nuts.
''I didn't come to Washington to be a yes man for any President, Democrat or Republican. I didn't come to Washington to get along and win any popularity contests.''
Indeed, people who have known the Senator for years say his tactics -large doses of anti-Communism and lectures often served up with filibusters and last-ditch amendments, all of them time-consuming, many of them tiresome - have left him few friends among his colleagues.
''He is a true believer who's often out in left field all by himself,'' said Tom Ellis, a lawyer in Raleigh, N.C., who ran Mr. Helms's first Senate campaign in 1972.
Mr. Williamson, the former Assistant Secretary of State and a fellow conservative, put it this way: ''Jesse is the skunk at the garden party, and he doesn't mind it one bit.''
 
A Classic Performance
A classic Helms performance came recently when he sharply cut off Senator Claiborne Pell, the courtly Rhode Island Democrat who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. In an effort to accommodate the Administration's request to move a proposal to send $9 million in election aid to the Nicaraguan opposition without a committee vote, Mr. Pell explained, ''We are trying to accommodate the President. We felt at that point --''
An angry Senator Helms interrupted, ''You felt that you were going to snooker us is what you felt.''
The exchanges in last year's Senate debate on the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty were even more vitriolic. At one point, Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who supported the treaty, accused Mr. Helms of gratuitous attempts to modify the treaty, calling his stalling tactics ''ridiculous.''
''I want to challenge you on the business of being ridiculous,'' Mr. Helms responded to Mr. Lugar, who had supported economic sanctions because of South Africa's apartheid policies. ''We could go back to South Africa and some of your stands, and we can talk about what's ridiculous.''
It was a position that Mr. Lugar had promoted when he was chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee from 1984 to 1986. Mr. Helms had chosen to be chairman of the Agriculture Committee, a North Carolina necessity, but when the Democrats won a majority in the Senate, Mr. Helms insisted on exercising the seniority principle and displacing Mr. Lugar as the ranking committee Republican.
 
Staff Is Independent
Mr. Helms, who gets much of the ammunition for his arguments from his committee staff, a committed group that includes former journalists who know how to get their views across. It was Mr. Helms's staff that amassed data on the Panama situation, telephoning Administration officials and Panamanian exiles in contact with the coup leaders and even phoning members of the Panamanian military while the coup attempt was in progress.
But some staff members are so independent that they have been known to make decisions without informing their boss. When Senator Lugar tried to pass a resolution congratulating South Korea for successfully holding the Summer Olympics last year, a member of Mr. Helms's staff said it could not be done. Mr. Lugar telephoned Mr. Helms for an explanation, and the Senator not only agreed to support the resolution but also to co-sponsor it.
In terms of concrete results, Mr. Helms's record is not particularly impressive. This year he delayed but did not stop the confirmation of Richard R. Burt as President Bush's negotiator for the strategic arms limitation talks. He was unable to push through an amendment limiting the Administration's contacts with the Palestine Liberation Organization. And his attempt to block the Administration from aiding the Presidential campaign of the Nicaraguan opposition seems doomed.
Back home, his tactics - which also applied to blocking the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday or to trying to stop Federal money for what he called ''obscene'' and ''indecent'' art - have earned him the sobriquet ''Senator No.'' The Democrats, who are having trouble finding a candidate to run against him next year, are expected to argue that Mr. Helms spends too much time on issues irrelevant to North Carolina.
''The Senator knows how to manipulate the rules to his advantage, to slow things down and to grandstand on the issues,'' said Mark Helmke, a private consultant who served as press secretary to Senator Lugar. ''But eventually he loses. People point to the fact that he screams and shouts, but forget that in the end he doesn't win.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 16, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1273 words

HEADLINE: Rights and Wrongs of Blaming Japan

 BODY:
Frustration with Japan in the United States and resentment of America in Japan are near the flash point. Many Americans are upset about recent shifts in the global balance of economic power, shifts that seem to threaten American jobs and international influence. Yet to put all the blame on Japanese behavior is to deflect attention from important domestic causes.
The important facts have to be sorted out before the two economic giants, so critical to each other's future, can sit down and talk about how to fix the genuinely troubling aspects of their mutual economic relations. 
A fair standard for sorting out legitimate grievances is the principle of equal treatment. That's the thread that runs through the following analysis of mutual Japanese-American investments and trade.
 
Investments
Japanese investment in America has surged. But it needs to be put in perspective. Total foreign investment in the U.S. at the end of last year was close to $1.8 trillion, of which one-sixth - $330 billion - was direct investment in ownership or control of U.S. businesses. Japanese direct investments at year-end amounted to $53 billion, only half as much as the British and roughly the same as the Dutch. Yet it was front-page news when the Sony Corporation recently bought Columbia Pictures.
Why? One reason is that Japanese investment has grown so swiftly. The feeling of being overwhelmed has been aggravated by friction over trade issues. America has a global trade deficit of $150 billion this year - $50 billion with Japan alone.
Trade and investment issues are linked. By importing more than it exports, America puts hundreds of billions of dollars in foreign hands. Most of these dollars come back as investments, mainly in corporate and Government securities. Japanese investment has helped finance the Federal budget deficit. This support is a mixed blessing. Unfortunately, it eases pressure on Washington to reduce the deficit. But without the foreign cash, the Treasury would have to pay higher interest rates.
Setting aside the effects on fiscal policy, America gains from foreign investment - 3.2 million jobs and $9.4 billion a year in Federal income tax. There is, of course, proper concern that foreign owners not undermine national security. Adequate laws to screen such investments are already in place. Foreigners can't buy the shipyards that build nuclear submarines, and they aren't always welcome to buy vital high-tech component producers.
Nervousness about Japan doesn't stop there, though. Some think the Columbia Pictures deal presages Japanese thought control over American culture. But two major Hollywood studios are already foreign-owned, and their output is no more or less insidious than before.
Some worry about Japanese ownership of U.S. banks. Worriers might pause to reflect on the extent of American industry and banks abroad. What makes it fair for Americans to invest everywhere in everything, but unfair for others to do the same?
Total American investment abroad is nominally the same size as foreign investment here. But U.S. capital abroad is actually greater because official statistics are based on original book value, rather than current worth.
Japanese acquisitions here include major companies like Firestone Tire, the CIT Group loan business, glittering names like Tiffany's, pricey Los Angeles real estate, thousands of acres of ranchland and now Columbia. Japanese banks and manufacturers have also opened U.S. offices and plants.
But while Japan's biggest banks are now the world's largest, its manufacturers are not nearly so muscular. Moreover, overseas production by the Japanese is barely 4 percent of their total output. America's overseas share is 18 percent. The issue of American investment in Japan, however, raises troubling questions of equity. Japan appears to be the only country that receives less investment from the United States than it sends here. Historically, the Japanese have been stubborn and difficult about letting foreigners buy into their industry or establish operations there. Their barriers have been somewhat relaxed recently, but remain too strict. For a country with such a highly visible investment presence abroad, these restrictions invite fair and strong criticism.
 
Trade
The balance of trade presents still thornier issues. It is not expected, or desirable, that every country balance its trade with each of its trading partners. America will always run surpluses with some countries and deficits with others, and ideally the grand total will balance out someday.
But America's trade deficit with Japan is particularly stubborn. The dollar has been sharply devalued, and this has helped to cut the deficit with Western Europe in half. But while Japan has imported more, its exports have also risen. The imbalance has stuck at $50 billion for several years. Why did the prescribed tonic of a devalued dollar work so poorly with Japan?
Americans buy Japanese products because of their quality and in many cases uniqueness. The U.S. no longer has a consumer electronics industry of any significance. Color TV's, VCR's and fax machines must be imported, and many of these imports come from Japan. The competitiveness of a wide range of American manufacturing industries is in evident decline.
Some of America's competitive problems are Washington's fault: Federal budget deficits have raised interest rates and forced U.S. companies to seek quicker paybacks on their investments.
Other causes of decline lie with the affected industries themselves. Detroit was far too slow in taking its Japanese rivals seriously. Though it has since improved the quality of its cars, they still do not match Japan's.
Japan cannot be faulted for those problems that are entirely of American making. To the contrary, its challenge has helped stir some complacent American industries to produce higher quality goods. But Japan can be faulted for its resistance to U.S. exports. Japan has greatly reduced its tariffs under the rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. But many invisible barriers remain.
The most egregious case of market denial affects semiconductor chips, an industry as fundamental to electronics as machine tools are to manufacturing. Preferring not to buy from the American companies that invented the technology, Japan created its own industry. American companies have never managed to acquire more than a token 10 percent share of Japan's market.
Japan tends to curtail imports where they compete with industries Tokyo wants to develop. The layers of protection include an industrial structure of cross-owned company groupings, known as keiretsu, that commonly buy from one another, and a domestic distribution system that tends to exclude foreign goods and makes even Japanese goods extremely expensive.
Japanese officials deny that their markets are closed, attributing the weakness of American sales to poor quality or lack of effort by American exporters. These criticisms seem justified in part. But they don't tell the whole story.
Japan's economy seems to be run largely for the benefit of its producers, whereas America's is run for the benefit of its consumers. The trouble is that the match between the producing and the consuming economy is vastly uneven. Companies in the producing economy, able to take a longer term view, enjoy a considerable advantage over their rivals in the consuming economy.
There are many remedies the United States can take for itself. But Japan needs to be more conscious of the inequities created by its policies and more open to suggestions for change.

HEADLINE: Time to Seek Reconciliation With China;
Attacking Corruption

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a visitor to China from May 13 to June 6, I can agree with most of Anthony Lewis's Sept. 28 column on China's 40th anniversary. However, what he says of the Chinese Government's attacking private enterprises as corrupt requires amplification. 
Behind China's inflation, besides unsound banking practices, are both corruption and capital expenditures at uncontrolled levels. Corrupt business practices are not limited to Government operations in the public sector, but are also found in the private sector. Given the rapidity of change in the last 10 years and the lack of adequate supervisory institutions why should it be otherwise? (Think of our savings and loan problem!) Allocating scarce resources for capital expenditures is related to regional development policy, local and national priorities, diversion of capital to nonproductive purposes and the difficulties of a multiple-pricing system.
If the Government closes legitimate private companies or ignores problems with public companies on the pretext of attacking corruption, we will know that the clock is being turned back on economic reform. But it seems too early to state this categorically.
 
MAX R. BLOOM
 Syracuse, Sept. 29, 1989
The writer is a retired management professor at Syracuse University.

HEADLINE: CUNY Science Courses Teetering on 'Disaster'

BYLINE: By SAMUEL WEISS

 BODY:
A City University of New York task force has concluded that the university's programs in science, engineering, technology and mathematics are ''teetering on a brink of disaster'' and require ''forceful and dramatic'' action to insure their survival.
In a report, the task force said that failing to improve the science programs ''will be to forever condemn the City University to third-rate status and virtually eliminate the institution as a factor in the technology-based local, regional and national economies of the 21st century.''
In a letter accompanying the report, the group's co-chairmen said the low level of scientific achievement at the university, the nation's third largest, was a result of inadequate financing and a lack of leadership.
 
'Landscape Is Bleak'
''While there are pockets and islands of greatness in the university's scientific sector,'' they wrote, ''the general landscape is bleak, having been run for far too long on a shoestring, without focus and vision, with little moral or fiscal commitment.'' 
The co-chairmen, Dr. Elizabeth S. Boylan and Dr. Avigdor M. Ronn, addressed the letter to the vice chancellor for academic affairs, Dr. Carolynn Reid-Wallace, who appointed the 15-member task force in May 1988.
Among the problems cited were aging laboratories and outmoded equipment, few faculty members who were pre-eminent in their fields, low salaries, inadequate financial support for graduate students and a lack of long-range planning at any level.
The panel recommended the creation of new programs in emerging fields like biotechnology. It also recommended the modernization of what it called ''grossly inadequate'' laboratories and an expanded effort to recruit replacements for an aging faculty.
 
Revise Graduate Programs
Further, the task force recommended that greater effort be made to interest students in scientific careers, that a panel be formed to revise graduate science programs and that a new post of deputy vice chancellor for science, engineering, technology and mathematics be created In interviews, Dr. Boylan and Dr. Ronn said any large-scale improvement of City University's science and technology programs would cost millions of dollars. But they said the report does not estimate long-range costs or advocate a crash spending program; rather, they said, it tries to focus attention on general problems.
Dr. Boylan is professor of biology and acting assistant provost at Queens College. Dr. Ronn is executive officer of the chemistry doctoral program at the university's Graduate School and University Center.
The task force's report was submitted early this month to the university's Chancellor, Dr. Joseph S. Murphy, as well as to its 20 college presidents and 17 trustees. A copy of the report was obtained by The New York Times.
 
'Harsh Self-Criticism'
In an interview, Dr. Murphy called the report a ''harsh self-criticism'' but said it would be premature to comment on its details.
The report emphasized that the university could have a major role in the metropolitan area in developing ''a technologically trained manpower pool'' that it said is needed for a new industrial base.
The task force found that the university ''rated rather badly'' in science programs against other large universities and that of all the science programs offered throughout the university system, only the physics and chemical engineering departments of City College had earned international reputations. The university has a faculty of 14,000 people teaching 190,000 students at 20 campuses.
One area of concern, the task force said, was faculty recruitment. Some senior faculty members at other major universities are paid more than $100,000 a year, the report said, while a City University faculty member with a rank of distinguished professor receives about $90,000.
Because of the comparatively low salary structure, the task force said, 25 percent of the faculty positions in City College's electrical engineering department remained vacant. The report also said little money was available for research projects, further hampering recruitment efforts.

HEADLINE: Bush's Ties to Congress Show Strain

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
As relations between the White House and Congress grow more combative, President Bush's personal ties to Capitol Hill show signs of strain, and complaints about the Administration's handling of Congress are growing louder, even from members of his own party.
The President has scored some important victories in Congress, and lawmakers and strategists on both sides of the aisle said that, at least in the short term, he can count on a reservoir of good will filled through months of playing a more bipartisan legislative strategy than did President Ronald Reagan.
But some Republicans have started complaining, mostly in private, that the drive for bipartisanship has meant neglecting single-party strategy sessions at the White House in favor of meetings with the leadership of both parties.
 
'Out of the Loop'
They said that Mr. Bush's staff has sometimes sent mixed signals in the heat of legislative battle and that his Congressional liaison staff is ''out of the loop'' on decisions made by Mr. Bush, his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and the budget director, Richard G. Darman. 
Some of Mr. Bush's recent problems in Congress stem from a Democratic opposition that has grown more aggressive, if not always more successful. Some Republicans said the White House has trouble picking the right fights and, when it has chosen to join difficult legislative battles, has sometimes been slow to do so.
Mr. Bush has benefited from the fragmented Democratic opposition, and a lack of major economic problems has kept his standing high in the opinion polls. But some Democrats and Republicans said they were concerned about whether the Administration would effectively confront a reversal in either area.
''There is a serious reluctance to engage in issues, even pinpoint what the major issues are,'' said Senator John S. McCain, Republican of Arizona.
''The President has done a good job himself,'' Mr. McCain said. ''So we don't know yet whether we've been seeing a couple of aberrations or something that is symptomatic of a more systemic weakness.''
 
Sharpest Test to Date
As Congress struggles to finish its current session, the Administration's Congressional relations and legislative strategy are getting their sharpest test of Mr. Bush's eight months in office.
After an initial victory in the House on a proposed cut in the capital gains tax, the Administration is still grappling with the Senate over the issue. A surprise House vote for Federal financing for some abortions has left Mr. Bush searching for flexibility while trying not to appear to compromise on that hot political issue.
The failed Panamanian coup raised questions about the White House crisis-management operation. And some lawmakers, especially Mr. McCain, criticized the White House for not taking a stand on the fight to repeal the Medicare surtax that finances benefits from insurance covering the catastrophic costs of long-term health care for the elderly.
White House officials said they had seen many pitfalls and few benefits in that issue. ''It isn't all that clear what ought to be done on it,'' Mr. Bush said on Friday. ''And so, we are letting the Congressional process hash this out.''
Mr. McCain and others read that as timidity and also complained that the Administration had tripped over its own feet in the debate. At one point, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, made a strong plea for retaining the insurance program, while Mr. Darman informed the Congressmen in writing that Mr. Bush took no position.
Last week, Mr. Sununu and William K. Reilly, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, also sent Congress contradictory messages, this time about a measure on clean-burning fuels.
 
Timing Questioned
The White House's sense of timing has been called into question several times. During the losing battle over the nomination of John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense, Senate Republicans said the White House was late in joining the struggle and then left Mr. Sununu frantically trying to salvage the vote by telephone from the Far East without ever trying to postpone it.
Because Mr. Bush relies more heavily on his personal contacts and lobbying by top aides than did Mr. Reagan, members of Congress and their aides said Frederick D. McClure, Mr. Bush's legislative liaison, has a less effective role that his predecessors.
Mr. McClure disputed that, saying Mr. Bush's personal contacts made his job easier. ''He's not averse to making phone calls when I suggest that he make phone calls,'' Mr. McClure said.
But a senior Republican aide on Capitol Hill said Mr. McClure's staff was inexperienced and ''the White House doesn't always tell his people what is going on.''
A Republican strategist with close ties to the White House said Mr. Bush's top aides had seemed ''amateurish'' in recent weeks on the alternative fuels and health insurance fights.
A Democratic leadership aide said, ''With Reagan, the liaisons' presence wasn't overpowering, but it was certainly a presence among our own membership. I don't think the Bush people have been able to get that same degree of infiltration into the Democratic members.''
Some Republicans said the Administration had expended too much energy on the capital gains issue.
 
Overwhelming Emphasis
''Capital gains permeates everything,'' said the Republican strategist. ''George Bush wants to win at all costs, even if it so ruptures the atmosphere that meaningful deficit reduction becomes doubtful and the prospects for a budget summit in 1991 grow dimmer.''
Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, said some Senate Republicans did not think the tax issue was as important as the White House presented it. But he said such differences were not serious and attributed much of the increased contentiousness to normal late-session tensions.
''This is stress time,'' Mr. Rudman said. ''If Valium were not a prescription drug, I expect there'd be a ton of it used up here every morning.''
But as the 1990 Congressional campaigns grow closer, the bipartisan mood seems certain to be strained.
''There's an exasperation here with the lack of leadership, lack of purpose,'' said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader. ''The best thing the Administration seems able to do is public relations, press conferences, worrying about the way things look.''
For his part, Mr. Bush plans a series of campaign trips over the next six weeks to raise money for Republican Congressional candidates in states like Florida, Illinois, Rhode Island and Texas, White House officials said.
In doing so, he planned to make a more partisan assault on Congress while trying to keep up the bipartisan effort in Washington, the officials said.
''You're going to see more campaigning for candidates by this President than you've seen in a long time,'' a senior aide said. ''You don't have to let a good strong partisan political operation interfere with bipartisan legislative work.''

HEADLINE: The Tools a Writer Used for Building An Industrial Novel

BYLINE: By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE

 BODY:
In his novel ''Sybil,'' Benjamin Disraeli wrote of a Britain that consisted of two nations ''as ignorant of each other's habits, thoughts and feelings as if they were inhabitants of different planets.'' He had in mind the rich and the poor of the Victorian era; but he might have been talking prophetically about the subtler splits of the 1980's.
He might have been referring to what David Lodge calls the two cultures of modern middle-class England: the intelligentsia and the industrial community, divided as they are by suspicion, prejudice and scorn.
That is certainly Mr. Lodge's own view; and as an intellectual working in grimy Birmingham, he is well placed to know. Half a mile from his home is the university where he is an honorary professor of modern English literature, and a bit farther away are the drab factories that actually crank out the city's wealth. Aptly enough, Disraeli's words form part of the epigraph to Mr. Lodge's latest novel, ''Nice Work,'' published by Viking; and ''Nice Work'' itself is a conscious attempt to revitalize the tradition of ''Sybil,'' Dickens's ''Hard Times,'' Elizabeth Gaskell's ''North and South,'' and other such analyses of a changing Britain. 
As an updated industrialist or state of England novel, it is by common consent the most ambitious book that Mr. Lodge has yet written. ''Changing Places'' and ''Small World,'' his fictional guidebooks to academic life, have already made him a cult figure on both sides of the Atlantic. But the critics were still more enthusiastic about ''Nice Work'' when it was published in his native Britain and, just recently, in the United States.
The idea for ''Nice Work'' began to gestate in Mr. Lodge's mind soon after the appearance of ''Small World'' in 1984, and partly because of that book's reception. Some reviewers, Philip Larkin among them, had questioned the wisdom of writing about jet-setting professors at a time when British universities were struggling to survive severe Government cuts.
Again, Mr. Lodge said he was worried by the wider impact of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic policies. ''You could see that England was being really shaken up, really changed, and this had caused a terrific recession in the engineering industries around here,'' he said in a recent interview. ''I thought it was time to write about a nonacademic side of Birmingham I'd never worked with before.''
 
The Great Divide
Accordingly, ''Nice Work'' turned out to be partly a troubled if comic communique from the groves of academe, partly a sharp if wry critique of their inhabitants. One of Mr. Lodge's two principal characters, Robyn Penrose, is a post-structuralist critic of rare ability, yet she is unable to rely on a permanent job at Rummidge, as Birmingham University has been rechristened.
Again, her special subject is the Victorian industrial novel, yet she feels no need to understand the complexities of modern industry. For the other main character, Vic Wilcox, who actually runs an engineering works, she at first feels nothing but vague disdain, born of socialism, feminism and intellectual superiority.
That seems to Mr. Lodge symptomatic - and worrying, given the predicament of the universities, and their arts faculties in particular. As he said: ''I was especially interested in the tragic irony that English and literary studies have reached a point in their theoretical development when they've become almost incapable of communicating to the layman at the very historical moment when they've most needed to justify their existence.
''The brightest and most innovative people in literary criticism are as impenetrable as nuclear physicists. The left-wing intelligentsia is trapped in a kind of ghetto that only they understand, and so can't bring any leverage to bear on the body politic.''
For Mr. Lodge himself, the accusation is close to the bone. Literary theory is his own academic subject, and he is assembling a collection of essays on deconstructionism and other such topics. Though he tries to avoid becoming too abstract, and describes himself as ''basically a liberal humanist trying to domesticate structuralist and post-structuralist ideas,'' he is well aware how limited the view from the ivory tower can be. Indeed, he knew he would somehow have to expand his horizons before he began writing ''Nice Work.''
In early 1986, under the not-altogether-false guise of learning more about job opportunities for students, he began to shadow a friend who ran an engineering company. That meant sitting in on meetings, visiting clients, getting to know just how industry and commerce functioned.
''For instance, he took me to a foundry which was the dirtiest, most infernal, strangest-looking place I'd ever seen,'' Mr. Lodge said. ''I can remember molten metal coming down like a river of lava from the top, and two Sikhs with their white eyes and teeth poking away at it like a couple of devils. As soon as I saw it, I knew I wanted it in the novel.''
 
At the Narrative Core
The incident duly appeared there, along with several others. It is hard to believe that a managing director would send underlings to lurk day and night outside a client's factory, in hopes of discovering which of his competitors was supplying it with cheap parts; but Mr. Lodge's friend did precisely that and, like Vic Wilcox, found that it was a close business associate who was undercutting him. Indeed, the shadow scheme itself became the novel's narrative core.
''I realized it was a good device for bringing a young woman from an educational background into contact with a middle-aged businessman,'' Mr. Lodge said. ''And if the woman was a feminist, in that very masculine world, it would increase the conflict, as well as the comedy and the possibilities for debate.''
In the event, Robyn acquires a certain respect for Vic, as he does for her; and that, too, reflects Mr. Lodge's own experience. ''I think that literary culture makes you despise all business, all trade, and that's a very narrow-minded point of view,'' Mr. Lodge said. ''I deplore some aspects of the Thatcher years. I don't believe the marketplace can take care of everything.
''But at least people have been reminded that high culture exists by the generation of wealth, and you can't have universities and National Theaters and so on without industry. Also, I liked the managers I met. They had a gritty, pragmatic quality and seemed very concerned to keep the factories going and the men in them happy. The university world seemed somewhat jaded and enervated by comparison.''
The 54-year-old Mr. Lodge relishes paradox as a writer, and is one as a person. He is of Irish, Belgian and Jewish as well as English descent, the son of a dance musician and an innkeeper's daughter. ''Which means,'' he said, ''I don't fit in any typical groove of the English class system.'' He is a highly successful man who was brought up in relative poverty in one of the drearier lower-middle-class London suburbs. He is also an impishly funny novelist who, though he has given up teaching for writing, has built a solid reputation as a university professor.
''There is a sense in which my fiction has satirized what I actually practice quite seriously as an academic,'' he said. ''In fact, I've had a rather schizophrenic existence. If you're a professor, you're required to show a responsibility to your institution and your students. But writers are essentially rather anarchic and unscrupulous people who question everything, and instead of suppressing evil thoughts will explore them, use them. I think my two careers are ultimately contradictory.''
 
'A Natural Fence Sitter'
Yet the strength of Mr. Lodge's fiction, as perhaps of his life, is that he has embraced rather than resisted contradiction. ''Perhaps I'm a natural fence sitter,'' he said. ''Certainly, my imagination does seem to work in a rather pendulumlike way. You know those plastic key rings with three-dimensional pictures that float to and fro and sometimes seem to overlap, depending on your angle on them? Well, my writing's a bit like that. I seem drawn to situations and themes that have two sides to them. I get pleasure in working out all the possible conflicts there, and I don't feel required to choose between them.''
So Mr. Lodge is pleased rather than worried that the critics have variously described ''Nice Work'' as an anti-Thatcher and a pro-Thatcher book, and have differed radically in the sympathy they have felt for Robyn and Vic, academia and business. He wanted both characters to present their respective cases and, in the end, to acknowledge that their particular world was not the only important one. Indeed, he even admits to finding a moral of sorts in their encounters.
It is one that is implicit in those Victorian industrial novels, and explicit in a later state-of-England book, E. M. Forster's ''Howard's End.'' It appears, as an erudite in joke, on the T-shirt of one of Robyn's students. In Mr. Lodge's view, it could usefully be emblazoned on every university, every place of business, in Britain. It is ''Only Connect.''Pearsond(Viking)
