HEADLINE: The Roots Of a Selloff

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The October slide in stock prices began in Japan and Europe, touched off by rising interest rates, and then spread to the United States with a sharp, startling one-day drop that provoked memories of 1987.
Today, after a weekend of worrying and official reassurances, markets will act first in Asia, then in Europe, and finally in the United States to determine whether the drop will continue or be reversed.
In Tokyo today, stock prices were lower. The Nikkei average of 225 stocks, which had dropped as much as 610 points in early trading, was down 407.84 points, or about 1.1 percent, to 34,708.18 by the end of the morning trading session.
Rising interest rates in Japan and Europe, brought on by government fears of rising inflation and falling currencies, had already led stock prices to fall by 2 percent or more in Japan, West Germany and Britain in the first two weeks of October, even before Wall Street's selloff on Friday sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent. 
 
Vulnerable to Bad News
The immediate cause of the Friday plunge was the word that financing for the buyout of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, was in trouble. But the round of rate increases had created a sense of concern that the American stock market was out of step with markets in other leading industrial nations, leaving share prices on Wall Street more vulnerable to bad news than they might otherwise be.
The foreign markets, able to act first because of the vagaries of time zones, are sending the signal today as to whether the New York plunge will spread worldwide, as it did two years ago, or be isolated.
Some traders in New York said there were signs of limited Japanese buying in the final minutes of trading Friday, after the Dow had dropped by more than 200 points, and voiced hopes that more foreign money would come into the market when trading resumes today.
Today's market action could also show the extent to which foreign investors, as well as those who manage American institutional investment firms, still accept the consensus that pushed stock prices higher for most of this year.
 
New High Reached Last Week
That consensus - based on falling American interest rates, an expectation of continued takeover activity and an economy that was growing at a moderate pace - raised the Dow to a record high early last week, and even with Friday's fall the average is at about the same level as in mid-July, up 18.5 percent from the end of 1988 and 47.8 percent since it fell 508 points on Oct. 19, 1987.
Higher interest rates tend to slow economic growth, but they also help to fight inflation and support the value of a currency. The increase in Japan's discount rate on Wednesday by one-half percentage point, to 3.75 percent, was viewed in part as an effort to slow that country's inflation rate, which officials fear could rise under the weight of higher costs of imported goods if the yen declines in value relative to the dollar.
The Japanese move came on the heel of similar increases the previous week in both West Germany and Britain. Both West Germany and Britain reported poor inflation figures on Friday.
The slower European economies that higher interest rates are expected to bring could reduce the demands of those countries for American goods, thus cutting profits of American companies and increasing the United States trade deficit even if the dollar also drops in value.
 
Signs of Improvement
While the trade deficit has been improving, there have been signs that the improvement was slowing. Concerns regarding that were heightened on Thursday when Japan reported that its seasonally adjusted trade surplus rose in September for the first time since June, reflecting surprisingly strong exports.
International interest rates were rising two years ago, just before the 1987 market crash, but the situation is now sharply different. Then, the United States was under international pressure to raise interest rates to support the dollar, which was falling, and American officials led by James A. Baker 3d, then the Treasury Secretary and now the Secretary of State, reacted angrily to an increase in West German interest rates.
Now the international pressures on the United States are the opposite: to lower interest rates to depress the dollar, which has attracted rising investments this year for reasons ranging from a buoyant takeover market to an increase in ''flight capital'' from investors worried about political instability in several countries.
European investors reacted nervously to the comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, in Moscow on Tuesday.
''Attempts to hold interest rates at unsustainably low levels have been shown to result in accelerating inflation,'' he said. ''Similarly, attempts to maintain unrealistic exchange rates may lead to destabilizing international capital flows and have to be abandoned.''
 
Europeans See a Split
Mr. Greenspan's comments may have been intended to be a warning to the Soviet Union, whose official exchange rate for the ruble is far above black market rates. But in Europe, it was seen as an indication of a split between the Federal Reserve and the Treasury, which negotiated the accord by the Group of Seven industrial nations that pledges to hold down the advance of the dollar.
If that interpretation is correct, it could indicate that the Fed would be reluctant to cut interest rates, particularly after Friday's report that producer prices in the United States rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, more than many economists had expected. A Fed official said over the weekend that the central bank would take steps to insure the markets had access to sufficient money, but he did not discuss its plans for interest rates.
Two years ago, in the aftermath of the 1987 crash, the Fed reversed course and quickly eased credit, thus reducing interest rates and helping to forestall a widely expected recession. Interest rates on Treasury bills -short-term borrowing by the Government - fell half a percentage point, to 7.2 percent, on Friday as investors foresaw a similar move by the Fed.
Lower rates normally help share prices, and could provide a lift for the stock market when it resumes trading today. But an easing by the Fed is not certain and in any event might not help the corporate raiders and takeover firms, whose ability to borrow money helped to create an expectation of a market pushed ever higher by takeover activity. Interest rates rose on the highly speculative high-yield ''junk bonds'' that those borrowers use to finance their takeovers.
 
Other Financing Problems
The problems with the UAL deal followed several other deals that ran into financing problems, a list that last week included the proposed takeover of MGM-UA by an Australian company and a planned restructuring of Ramada Inc., the hotel and casino operator.
A sign that nervous investors are again ready to buy such junk bonds would be greeted by shareholders with a sigh of relief.
''Nobody concentrated on the fact that the ability to finance the junk bond market was beginning to grind to a halt,'' said Stanley Shopkorn, chief equity trader for Salomon Brothers in New York. He voiced hopes that Friday's fall simply took some speculative excesses out of share prices and that foreign investors, along with American institutions, would return to the market this week.

HEADLINE: Japan's Banks: A Caution Flag

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
The growing presence of Japanese banks in the United States could invite a backlash, Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, warned last week.
Twenty United States banks control a total of $30 billion in assets in Japan, while about 36 Japanese banks control $370 billion in the United States, Mr. Corrigan said at an economic conference here Thursday. 
Public policy concerns could be aroused by ''any pattern of future behavior which might be viewed by some as an aggressive strategy of expansion through acquisition,'' Mr. Corrigan said. ''The initial point of friction, if it arises, is likely to be more political than economic.''
Japan must make every effort ''to insure that all barriers, visible and invisible, to expansion and openness in Japanese banking and financial markets are eliminated,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Silver Lining for Business Chiefs

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 14

 BODY:
Almost 150 past and present chief executives of American businesses gather here twice a year for a meeting of the Business Council and rarely do they have an event like Friday's stock market plunge to talk about.
But few executives seemed overly troubled by news of the 190-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, and some were decidedly optimistic.
''This just means that Mobil stock is now a better buy,'' said Allen E. Murray, chairman of the Mobil Corporation. ''If this brings a flight to quality in stocks and blows out some of the speculative fever, I think that would be a good thing.'' 
Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of the AMR Corporation, which owns American Airlines, seemed distinctly pleased with the Wall Street developments as he chatted with fellow chief executives. While he declined to make any public comment some council members predicted that Donald J. Trump might now have a harder time coming up with the financing to complete his $7.5 billion offer for AMR.
''I think some C.E.O.'s are breathing easier, because now they will find it easier to focus on the real business of the company, instead of trying to fend off takeovers,'' said George M. Keller, former chairman of the Chevron Corporation. But he added that there might have been good reason for the stock market's decline.
Mr. Keller noted, for example, that while the stock price of Chevron had risen by 30 percent in the last six months, earnings growth was nowhere near that level. ''I think people finally decided to look at earnings and found out they were not what they thought,'' he said.
Many executives at the meeting here at the Homestead Hotel seemed startled by the size of the decline and attributed it to the short-term investment horizon of Wall Street players.
''I'm surprised about this,'' said David T. Kearns, chairman and chief executive of the Xerox Corporation. ''The problem is that nowadays everyone moves at the same time. When one goes, everyone goes.''
John F. Akers, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, said, ''Why would the value of American business be all of a sudden 7 percent or so less?''
To some executives, the stock market's fall reinforced their doubts about the economy. Lewis T. Preston, chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company, warned that interest rates were too high, the Bush Administration and Congress were not doing enough to reduce the budget deficit and foreign markets could lose confidence and move out of dollar investments.
Kenneth H. Olsen, chief executive of the Digital Equipment Corporation, worried that the country was spending too much on consumption and too little on future productivity and not saving enough. ''The cost of capital is the most important single factor in making the United States economy competitive,'' he said. ''And we are not investing enough in competitiveness and not investing enough in the future.''

HEADLINE: Professionals Watching the 'Junk Bond' Market

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
Professional investors say they will be watching the ''junk bond'' market closely this morning. If this $200 billion market of high-yield, high-risk securities continues to suffer sharp selloffs with poor trading liquidity, the stock market is likely to decline further, traders say.
Many experts believe the junk bond market may be hard hit today. Some closed-end junk bond mutual funds that use ''margin,'' or credit, to enhance the yield on their funds were given margin calls late last week, people at Wall Street brokerage firms said. This means the fund managers cannot wait for prices of their bonds to stabilize before selling. They are being forced to sell junk bonds from their portfolios to raise cash to meet the margin call. 
On Friday, some money managers found special significance in the unwillingness of Japanese banks to finance the proposed buyout of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines.
 
Lenders of Last Resort
With the junk bond market unwilling to finance deals and United States banks beginning to slow their lending in such deals, the Japanese banks had been viewed as the lenders of last resort for these transactions, said Neil J. Weisman, general partner of Chilmark Capital Management, a New York firm that invests $220 million. ''Who is left after the Japanese connection?'' he asked.
The stock market's nervousness comes a month after the junk bond market began crumbling. Many junk bond investors have been spooked because some large consumer-oriented companies that issued bonds to finance leveraged buyouts or other restructurings are having trouble with their finances.
Executives at some of these companies, like the Seaman Furniture Company, are finding that the consumer is not spending at the rate they had anticipated.
And in other cases companies that hoped to pay off their creditors by selling corporate assets are finding that with so many businesses for sale, buyers are not willing to pay top prices. On Friday, some investors speculated that the sharp selling in bonds of RJR Holdings, the largest and most actively traded securities in the junk bond market, reflected concerns about the ability of this company to sell divisions to pay back creditors.
 
'Two-Tier Market'
''It is going to be a two-tier market,'' said Pamela McCann, vice president of the GTE Investment Management Corporation, a GTE subsidiary that manages the company's $10 billion pension fund. ''The market is going to favor companies with long-term positive earnings, not asset plays.''
And Leon G. Cooperman, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company responsible for the firm's Investment Management Group, said the ''dysfunction'' in the junk bond market is suggesting that the economy is weaker than Government statistics indicate.
Individual investors appear not to have been involved in Friday's selling. Fidelity Investments in Boston used the Gallup polling organization to survey some shareholders over the weekend. The firm found that very few of its customers had withdrawn their assets from stock or mutual funds on Friday, said Neal Litvack, vice president for marketing.
Like other mutual fund organizations, Fidelity has been suffering steady redemptions from its junk bond mutual funds over the last month. Customers have withdrawn almost $100 million from the fund and over the weekend they took out an additional $20 million from the high-yielding mutual fund.
 
Replacing 'Bridge Loans'
The turmoil in the junk bond market will almost certainly hurt the companies that have short-term ''bridge loans'' with Wall Street firms. The rates on these loans, which are used in buyouts or other recapitalizations, are almost 15 percent, or as much as 6 percentage points over the bond yield paid by a high-rated company. If the turmoil in the junk bond market continues, such companies, like Prime Computer and Grand Union, could find it almost impossible to replace these expensive loans with junk bonds.
And if the companies must then pay higher-than-expected interest rates at a time when the economy may be slowing, some companies could default, leaving Wall Street firms like First Boston, Shearson Lehman Hutton, Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch with nonperforming loans.
Over the weekend, Wall Street executives dismissed the suggestion that the bridge loans could create a problem for them. ''I don't see a scenario of securities firms being pressed to the wall by bridge loans,'' said Barry S. Friedberg, a managing director of investment banking at Merrill Lynch. HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Activity Hinges On Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Much as it was two years ago, near-term developments in the credit markets are completely dependent on how stock market investors react this week to Friday's stunning 190.58 drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.
Trading in the stock market is likely to overshadow a heavy schedule of economic reports including merchandise trade for August and consumer prices for September, all of which are due this week.
Most market analysts were unwilling to go beyond predicting a bumpy opening for the stock market this morning. But most said that in a number of important respects conditions now are fundamentally different -and better - than they were two years ago. 
Despite a sharp drop on Friday, the dollar is not the battered currency it was in October 1987. Inflation, which because of a rise in energy prices moved higher last month, is nevertheless perceived by economists to be trending lower, while two years ago prices were seen as moving higher. And interest rates, which rose all through the spring and summer of 1987 as the stock market surged, have been declining for the last six months, albeit at a slow rate.
 
Conditions Are Better
''In general, conditions surrounding the crash of two years ago are not present today,'' said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns & Company. ''The stability of the dollar and the declining trend in interest rates are major plusses for the financial markets.''
In the aftermath of tumbling stock prices, what had been a gentle decline in interest rates turned into a near free-fall on Friday, as investors sought a safe haven in Treasury securities.
By the close of trading, rates on three-month bills had plummeted by 70 basis points, or hundredths of a point, to 7.16 percent on a bond equivalent basis. And yields on the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds fell to a late offered rate of 7.86 percent, down from a late Thursday yield of 8.01 percent.
''What we saw on Friday was a flight to quality, which is a signal of nervousness,'' said Sanford J. Grossman, a professor of finance at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania and one of a group of experts who worked on a study of the 1987 crash commissioned by the New York Stock Exchange. ''But I would be surprised if we see a 500-point down move in the stock market on Monday.''
Further interest rate declines are likely, if not certain, should stock prices sell off sharply again this week. In addition, the Federal Reserve Board has indicated that it would respond as it did two years ago by pumping liquidity into the system and engineering a further drop in short-term rates.
While a stable dollar and declining interest rates could help ease a free-fall in equity prices, some analysts suggested that a further decline in the stock market might do more damage this time than it did two years ago.
 
'Economy Is Weaker'
''The economy is definitely weaker now than it was in October 1987,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''But the key element in light of what has happened in the stock market is that history doesn't necessarily repeat itself.''
Moreover, a slower pace of economic growth and high debt burdens are cutting into corporate profits.
Citing Commerce Department data, Robert A. Schwartz, a vice president and senior financial economist at Merrill Lynch, said that in the second quarter more than 30 percent of cash flow at non-financial corporations was used to service debt, the highest that ratio has ever been.
''The last previous peak was in the recession of 1974, and we are beyond that,'' Mr. Schwartz said. ''There is no question that servicing the debt is eating into profits.''
A further decline in stock prices would push interest rates lower, but analysts said that stable or higher equity prices would likely push rates up from their Friday levels.
''If this is a one-day wonder, there will be some adjustments in interest rates,'' Mr. Fine said. ''The market has a very, very good memory. What traders did on Friday was to hedge against that memory.''
Participants in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market, where prices have been under pressure for months, were not prepared to predict when the slide would end. But they added that with Friday's steep decline in Treasury yields interest rates on junk bonds have reached eye-popping proportions.
''We probably started Friday with yields on junk issues between 650 basis points and 700 basis points above Treasuries, and with the rally in the Treasury market, it will be even wider this week,'' said Mark Vaselkiv, a vice president at the T. Rowe Price High Yield Fund.
''I may be biased, but I would argue that people consider taking a little money out of equities and look for some high-quality junk issues,'' Mr. Vaselkiv said.
James Caywood, president of Caywood Christian, a San Diego money management firm with a portfolio of more than $2 billion in high-yield bonds, said, ''Some of my brokers told me early Friday that non-traditional buyers were purchasing issues like Fort Howard zero-coupon bonds, issues that are offering a better rate of return than is being offered on stocks.''
Because of the big price declines that have already occurred, a further steep drop in equity prices would probably not do a commensurate amount of damage in the high-yield market, participants said. Fears of an impending recession pushed junk bond prices down sharply after the 1987 stock market crash.
''The difference for us right now is that high-yield paper is significantly undervalued,'' Mr. Vaselkiv said. ''In 1987, junk was expensive.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Still Uneasy After Beijing Turmoil

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
When Communist authorities cracked down on protesters on June 4, the blood was shed 1,200 miles from here, in Beijing. But the greatest financial aftershocks occurred in Hong Kong, sending many Chinese managers rushing to emigrate and leaving gaps in the middle and upper ranks of corporations.
Along with the shrinking pool of talented executives, Hong Kong is facing rising uncertainty about the growth of its economic relationship with China.
On Monday, June 5, the Hong Kong stock market lost about 22 percent of its value, or $16.6 billion in United States currency, in the territory's biggest stock plunge since October 1987. 
 
Slump in Tourism, Too
In the aftermath, the tourism industry also slumped, mostly because fewer travelers were venturing into China, and in June only 385,000 tourists came to Hong Kong - or 20.5 percent fewer than a year earlier. Hotel occupancy rates were 71 percent in July, compared with 93 percent a year ago, according to the tourist bureau's most recent statistics.
No one is writing off Hong Kong's future, for the British colony has demonstrated enormous resiliency in the past. But the latest troubles have reminded Hong Kong that dependence on the Chinese market carries risks as well as rewards, and its 5.7 million residents are still grappling with several economic challenges that find their roots in the shootings on Tiananmen Square.
''Before June 4, one would have expected to see the economy slow down gradually,'' said David K. P. Li, chief executive of the Bank of East Asia Ltd. in Hong Kong. ''Now, people are saying there will be more of a slowdown than before. This year, we will have a respectable growth rate, but next year will be slower.''
A renewed and even deeper distrust of the Chinese Government has intensified the desire to emigrate of many skilled, educated Hong Kong Chinese. Many are leaving for Canada, Australia and the United States; those with less money or fewer skills are inquiring about Panama, Colombia and Mauritius.
''Most people were sitting on the fence, but now, 90 percent of the people sitting on the fence have decided to emigrate,'' said Roderick W. Macneil, president of Macneil Pacific Ltd, a consulting firm based in Hong Kong.
''If your mind is on emigration, it's not on your work or on spotting opportunity in Hong Kong,'' he added. ''That can't be a good thing for Hong Kong. If out of 100 entrepreneurs, 50 are thinking about how to start a business in Toronto, that's not a lot of energy going into creative venture.''
 
Emigrants May Not Return
Although some emigrants may return with new passports before 1997, when Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule, most probably will not.
About 45,000 Hong Kong Chinese emigrated last year, and the Government has said that number will rise to more than 55,000 this year. The expected increase in emigration will put greater strains on businesses in banking, accounting, computers and other services that are crucial for Hong Kong's growth as a financial and headquarters center.
''Hong Kong Chinese used to be very choosy about what financial center they emigrated to,'' said one foreign trader in Hong Kong. ''Now some of them think it's O.K. to get a job as a dishwasher in Mexico.''
Experienced Chinese managers and technicians will be costlier and harder to find, and companies will be forced to meet the shortage by bringing in foreign executives at higher salaries.
Another basic building block of Hong Kong's economy, business linked to the neighboring Guangdong province of China, is facing new uncertainties.
Hong Kong is China's largest investor, with small labor-intensive factories mostly in southern Guangdong, where Chinese speak the same Cantonese dialect as in Hong Kong. Likewise, China is Hong Kong's largest trading partner, accounting for 29.1 percent of Hong Kong's total trade last year, and 30.1 percent in the first seven months of 1989.
Moreover, many companies not directly conducting business in China are in industries, like real estate, transportation, hotels and some financial services, that are indirectly linked to China.
China began an austerity program last fall, however, and Chinese businesses have since been plagued by cash shortages and tight foreign exchange. The events of June 4 in Beijing have further aggravated cash-flow problems.
One long-time exporter of refrigerators to China said that since June, Chinese authorities had simply halted import licenses for luxury items, like his product, and he doubts he will make another sale this year. China is trying to slash its imports to help balance its trade deficit, and although trade with Hong Kong has increased substantially this year, it is expected to grow more slowly in the future.
Flows of Hong Kong capital into China have also slowed, economists and China analysts say, and most investors will wait to see if the Chinese Government will alter its economic policies in Southern China. Manufacturers are considering expanding, as some already have, into other Asian countries, like Thailand and the Philippines.
Yet for companies who can pay back their investment quickly and earn a significant return in a few years, the alternatives to China are not always appealing. Greater distances, unfamiliar customs and language barriers usually mean higher costs.
''Thailand's bureaucracy is bureaucratic, too,'' said Raymond K. F. Ch'ien, managing director at Lam Soon Hong Kong Group, a packaging company. ''It's easier to operate in Guangdong.''
Companies may thus still prefer to expand in China, and presumably they would be flexible enough, as they have in the past, to find the pattern to survive.
While Hong Kong faces serious challenges, its problems are not fatal. The territory's economy had overheated and growth in gross domestic product was already cooling down from 13.8 percent in 1987 to 7.3 percent in 1988 to an earlier expectation of 6 percent this year. Mainly because of the turmoil in China, however, the growth forecast was revised to 5 percent.
There is talk about relocating the back-office operations of international service and financial businesses to cities that are more politically stable, like Singapore. But economists and executives say that even with political uncertainty Hong Kong is still more attractive. It is less regulated than Singapore, and its telecommunications network, the widespread use of English, low taxes and central location in Asia give it an edge over many other places.

HEADLINE: Actually, Prohibition Was a Success

BYLINE: By Mark H. Moore; Mark H. Moore is professor of criminal justice at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
History has valuable lessons to teach policy makers but it reveals its lessons only grudgingly.
Close analyses of the facts and their relevance is required lest policy makers fall victim to the persuasive power of false analogies and are misled into imprudent judgments. Just such a danger is posed by those who casually invoke the ''lessons of Prohibition'' to argue for the legalization of drugs.
What everyone ''knows'' about Prohibition is that it was a failure. It did not eliminate drinking; it did create a black market. That in turn spawned criminal syndicates and random violence. Corruption and widespread disrespect for law were incubated and, most tellingly, Prohibition was repealed only 14 years after it was enshrined in the Constitution. 
The lesson drawn by commentators is that it is fruitless to allow moralists to use criminal law to control intoxicating substances. Many now say it is equally unwise to rely on the law to solve the nation's drug problem.
But the conventional view of Prohibition is not supported by the facts.
First, the regime created in 1919 by the 18th Amendment and the Volstead Act, which charged the Treasury Department with enforcement of the new restrictions, was far from all-embracing. The amendment prohibited the commercial manufacture and distribution of alcoholic beverages; it did not prohibit use, nor production for one's own consumption. Moreover, the provisions did not take effect until a year after passage -plenty of time for people to stockpile supplies.
Second, alcohol consumption declined dramatically during Prohibition. Cirrhosis death rates for men were 29.5 per 100,000 in 1911 and 10.7 in 1929. Admissions to state mental hospitals for alcoholic psychosis declined from 10.1 per 100,000 in 1919 to 4.7 in 1928.
Arrests for public drunkennness and disorderly conduct declined 50 percent between 1916 and 1922. For the population as a whole, the best estimates are that consumption of alcohol declined by 30 percent to 50 percent.
Third, violent crime did not increase dramatically during Prohibition. Homicide rates rose dramatically from 1900 to 1910 but remained roughly constant during Prohibition's 14 year rule. Organized crime may have become more visible and lurid during Prohibition, but it existed before and after.
Fourth, following the repeal of Prohibition, alcohol consumption increased. Today, alcohol is estimated to be the cause of more than 23,000 motor vehicle deaths and is implicated in more than half of the nation's 20,000 homicides. In contrast, drugs have not yet been persuasively linked to highway fatalities and are believed to account for 10 percent to 20 percent of homicides.
Prohibition did not end alcohol use. What is remarkable, however, is that a relatively narrow political movement, relying on a relatively weak set of statutes, succeeded in reducing, by one-third, the consumption of a drug that had wide historical and popular sanction.
This is not to say that society was wrong to repeal Prohibition. A democratic society may decide that recreational drinking is worth the price in traffic fatalities and other consequences. But the common claim that laws backed by morally motivated political movements cannot reduce drug use is wrong.
Not only are the facts of Prohibition misunderstood, but the lessons are misapplied to the current situation.
The U.S. is in the early to middle stages of a potentially widespread cocaine epidemic. If the line is held now, we can prevent new users and increasing casualties. So this is exactly not the time to be considering a liberalization of our laws on cocaine. We need a firm stand by society against cocaine use to extend and reinforce the messages that are being learned through painful personal experience and testimony.
The real lesson of Prohibition is that the society can, indeed, make a dent in the consumption of drugs through laws. There is a price to be paid for such restrictions, of course. But for drugs such as heroin and cocaine, which are dangerous but currently largely unpopular, that price is small relative to the benefits.

HEADLINE: PATTERNS;
Turbulence in London

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
After all the pushing and shoving in Milan, store buyers and fashion editors seemed relieved to be in London. But the English fashion scene is far from sedate, and the backstage business is quite as turbulent as Seventh Avenue.
A story in The Financial Times here today had the headline ''Fashion trade hangs on by a thin thread,'' and described an industry troubled by sluggish consumer spending, steep rises in imports and intense pressure for rapid profits by large retailers.
Sound familiar? This week, matters were made even more unsettled by the news from Wall Street. British suppliers remember the fall-off in orders from America in the wake of the October 1987 stock plunge. 
While American buyers and editors gave the shows mixed reviews, they carefully shopped the large trade exhibit at the Olympia 2 convention hall and the popular London retail streets, especially Newburgh and Carnaby (yes), looking for new ideas. As fashion remains in a conservative period, trend-setting London has diminished in importance, but buyers still find it influential in the junior market.
''The street fashion is always here, and it's coutured and picked up all over the world,'' said Bernie Ozer, a vice president of Associated Merchandising Corporation, a consulting concern that reports on trends to many American retailers.
Mr. Ozer added that American stores also send representatives to London shows for knitwear from companies like Artwork, and evening clothes by designers like Murray Arbeid, Ben de Lisi, Tomasz Starzewski, and Monica Chong.
Mr. de Lisi, a native of Long Island who designs and shows his clothes in London, said Bonwit Teller, one of his two New York accounts, sent no regular buying team to England this season. This summer he had been forced to halt shipments when Bonwit's filed for bankruptcy protection.
The softened tailoring so evident in Milan this season was also a feature of the London collections. It is a case of business driving fashion, Mr. de Lisi said.
''It's less expensive to produce,'' he said. ''I've used a few basic shapes throughout the entire collection. No zippers. No fly fronts. No waistbands. No structure. When the buyers tell you they can't afford the clothes, you have to change.''
Another problem for British designers is that many important American buyers now skip the London shows because of hefty minimum orders required by large Milan fashion houses, which deplete their budgets, or ''open to buys.''
Joe Casely-Hayford, who was nominated for the British Fashion Council's Designer of the Year award (to be announced Tuesday night), was packing up his collection to bring it to a showroom in Paris for the first time. Many others do the same.
But Britain's fashion establishment maintained a stiff upper lip, perhaps abetted by their crystal jewelry, a symbol of new-age optimism that everyone seemed to wear.
 
Witty Street Styles
''The white is for purity and spirituality,'' said Rifat Ozbek, the designer whose all-white collection opened the London shows.
The witty clothes, based on American street styles, were well-received, but buyers and editors were wondering if the designer would have the audacity to sell them that way. White, after all, doesn't travel well on the New York City subway.
Those who visited Mr. Ozbek's loft showroom at Haunch of Venison Yard, an alley off Bond Street, and examined the sequined belt packs (called ''bum packs'' here), rhinestone-embroidered knapsacks and leather jackets with ''New Age'' in mirrored letters on the back, discovered that the clothes were also available in colors. This was a concession, Mr. Ozbek said, to his business people.
Tommy Perse, the owner of Maxfield, a high-fashion store on Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles, was buying the collection in white.
''This line is perfect for L.A.,'' Mr. Perse said. ''They can wear it everywhere. The clothes are very young, but California women are very body-conscious.''
Prices were definitely Beverly Hills. A sequined knapsack will retail in the United States for $400, the belt pack $200. The same backpack in rhinestone embroidery, which gives it a dazzling mirrored effect, will run about $6,500, the belt pack $2,000. A baseball jacket with the mirrored look is expected to cost $30,000.
There was no price quoted for the rhinestoned leather basketball shoes. Mr. Ozbek is giving the one-of-a-kind sneakers to Neneh Cherry, the rap singer. They just happened to fit her.
